description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Israelis Are Sentenced in Bombing Attempt
description: Three militant Israeli settlers were sentenced Tuesday to prison terms ranging from 12 to 15 years for parking an explosives-laden trailer outside a Palestinian school for girls in East Jerusalem in April of last year.

title: A Kitchen Of Kung Fu In a Korean Confection
description: Music, mayhem and magic are only a few of the ingredients in the savory stew of skillful, high-energy, silly good fun that opens the new season at the New Victory Theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WASHTON, NATHAN
description: WASHTON--Nathan, 86, of Fairfield, CT and Manhasset, NY, on September 30, 2003 of lung cancer. Nathan retired as professor of education and coordinator of science education at Queens College, CUNY, in 1982. His publications include more than 30 scholarly articles, several textbooks, and a number of edited science series. During WWII, Nathan served his country as a captain in the 20th Army Air Force, piloting B-29s based in India and training pilots in San Antonio, TX. Nathan is survived by his loving wife of 58 years, Sylvia, his three daughters, Gale Dubrow, Ruth Washton-Brown and Laura Orr and their spouses, his five grandchildren and four great - grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at 10:30 AM on Thursday, October 2nd at Congregation B' nai Israel, 2710 Park Avenue, Bridgeport, CT. Interment will be at 1:00 PM at the family plot in Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: The Dolphins Return to a Familiar Locale to Play the Giants
description: This weekend the Dolphins will return to the place where they saved their season. They will stay at the same hotel, dress in the same locker room and play on the same field as they did when they beat the Jets on Sept. 14.

title: My Hummer, Myself: And the Rest of Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Road to '06 Cup Could Start in January
description: The United States men's team could begin play in qualifying matches for the 2006 World Cup in January under a plan submitted yesterday to FIFA, the sport's worldwide governing body. FIFA must approve the schedule, which would have matches played through November 2005.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Apology For Nazi Flag
description: The superintendent of Paris High School and the director of its band apologized for a football halftime show in Dallas on the evening of Rosh Hashana in which the band flew the Nazi flag and played ''Deutschland ber Alles'' in a program on World War II. School officials said that they were unaware of the holiday and that their only objective was historical accuracy. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: In Pitchers' Duel, a Muffed Bunt Drives the Giants
description: Jason Schmidt turned to watch third baseman Edgardo Alfonzo field Derrek Lee's grounder and throw to first for the final out Tuesday. Schmidt punched the air gently, a modest exclamation after a powerful performance. He had pitched a three-hitter as the San Francisco Giants overwhelmed the Florida Marlins, 2-0, in the opener of their National League division series.

title: Senate Wants Iraq to Share Recovery Cost
description: Senate Republicans, bowing to what appears to be a Senate majority, said Tuesday that they had begun exploring a compromise that would require Iraq to repay at least part of the $20.3 billion in reconstruction aid the Bush administration wants to spend.

title: Group Criticizes Product Placement
description: The growing practice of product placement was criticized yesterday as ''an affront to basic honesty'' by an advocacy organization, which asked two federal agencies to insist that television shows disclose all such deals.

title: Alliance Suspends 2 Fund Executives in Trading Inquiry
description: Alliance Capital Management, one of the nation's largest money managers, said yesterday that it had suspended two executives over improper trading in its mutual funds, after inquiries by regulators into trading practices in the fund industry.

title: Divers Losing Underwater Eden; Developers Buying Beach to Rockaway Scuba Haven
description: From dry land, Almost Paradise does not exactly resemble an exotic diving spot.

title: Tyson Pleads Not Guilty
description: Mike Tyson, appearing in Brooklyn Criminal Court yesterday, pleaded not guilty to assault and harassment charges stemming from a summer altercation. On June 21 at 5:30 a.m., Tyson, 37, was arrested after checking out of the Marriott Hotel in Brooklyn. Outside the hotel, Tyson encountered other guests, Nestor Alvarez-Ramos, 24, and Samuel Velez, 22. When they asked for an autograph, Tyson declined and a fight ensued. Tyson and the two men were arrested and charged with assault, harassment and menacing, all misdemeanors. A pretrial hearing is set for Nov. 18. Geoffrey Gray

title: G.I. Is Killed in Iraq; 4th Woman to Die There
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 1 — An American soldier died today in a bold daylight attack on her convoy just outside an American military base in Tikrit, the birthplace of Saddam Hussein, a military spokesman said.

title: Rangers Claim 2 Players Off Waivers
description: Before filing their list of protected players for Friday's National Hockey League waiver draft, the Rangers claimed defenseman Shawn Heins and right wing Jeff Heerema off waivers yesterday. Heins, 29, and Heerema, 23, were then left unprotected at the 4 p.m. deadline as the Rangers considered leaving right wing Ronald Petrovicky or left wing Dan LaCouture unprotected. Jason Diamos

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 18 about President Bush's formal request to Congress for $87 billion to finance military operations and reconstruction projects in Iraq and Afghanistan referred incorrectly to the way $12 billion in expected oil revenues in Iraq would be spent next year. Bush administration officials say it will be used primarily to run the Iraqi government, with a small amount applied to rebuilding efforts; the entire amount will not be spent on reconstruction.

title: Miscellany
description: * The Extra Extra unit of the Paper Publishing Company, New York, which publishes Paper magazine, signed an agreement with Starwood Hotels and Resorts, White Plains, to provide the Starwood chain of W Hotels with city guides for concierges and guests. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Harlem: One Man Dead, One Hurt In Fire
description: One man was killed and another critically injured by a fire in their Harlem apartment yesterday, the Fire Department said. The fire, on the top floor of the six-story building at 540 West 144th Street, near Amsterdam Avenue, was reported at 11:34 a.m. and was confined to the victims' apartment. The two men were taken to Harlem Hospital, where one died. The Fire Department did not disclose the men's names yesterday. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: U.S. Concerned About Rebels in Philippines, Ambassador Says
description: MANILA, Oct. 1  The United States government is "very, very concerned" about the links between the militant Jemaah Islamiyah and a Muslim group that is fighting for independence in the southern Philippines, the American ambassador to the Philippines said today.

title: Silenced Again In Kabul
description: American efforts to build a democratic, tolerant Afghanistan are facing a serious challenge: the draft of the Afghan constitution, which may be made public as early as this week, does not yet provide for crucial human rights protections, including freedom of thought, conscience and religion. The United States and the international community should insist that the draft presented by the constitutional commission explicitly protect these core human rights for all Afghans.

title: The Iraq Reconstruction Bonanza
description: Complaints about the $20 billion down payment that President Bush wants for the reconstruction of Iraq are going in the wrong direction. There's no question that the United States has an obligation and clear interest in rebuilding the country it invaded. The cost cannot be whittled down through political compromise or disguised as a loan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Monday about the trial of L. Dennis Kozlowski, former chief executive of Tyco International, misstated the cost of an umbrella stand he bought with company money. It was $15,000, not $17,000.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: State Still West Nile Leader
description: State health officials said that 2,013 people in Colorado were infected with the West Nile virus this year, resulting in 42 deaths. The numbers are still the nation's highest. Those who died were 53 to 89 years old, and most had complications of meningitis or encephalitis. Cooler weather has reduced the mosquito population, but officials still recommend insect repellant. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Report Criticizes City on Civil Rights Cases
description: The city commission responsible for enforcing local civil rights laws, an agency that the Bloomberg administration took office pledging to revamp, is still not living up to its potential, according to a report released yesterday by a civil rights group.

title: Justice Linked To Profiling In New Jersey Will Resign
description: Justice Peter G. Verniero, who came close to impeachment in 2001 in the furor over racial profiling in New Jersey, said on Tuesday that he would step down from the State Supreme Court next August.

title: European Demand Helps Pepsi Bottling
description: The Pepsi Bottling Group said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 2.8 percent as demand in Europe increased. Sales fell in Mexico amid increased competition.

title: Brooklyn Violence Spills Outside Cybercafes
description: This is what cutting class looks like these days for many high school students in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn: A long, narrow room with two small fluorescent lights where boys sit at desks for hours on end, staring straight ahead at computer screens, rarely speaking to one another and more rarely seeing a girl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUNNEWELL, RICHARD FARNSWORTH
description: HUNNEWELL -- Richard Farnsworth on September 29, age 81, in Newport, RI. Son of the late Emmeline Ticknor and James Frothingham Hunnewell of Boston, Richard graduated from St. Paul's School and Harvard College. He served in WW II as a Navy Lieutenant on the destroyer Charles J. Badger. After the war, he moved to New York where he married Rosalie Clark in 1949. He joined the Hanover Bank (later the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co.) in 1957, retiring in 1983; he then worked at the English Speaking Union until 1992. He was predeceased by his wife Rosalie in 1970 and by his second wife, Julie Desloge Haggerty in 1993. He is survived by his wife, Martha Sulzby Clark, by two children, Sarah Hunnewell, of Water Mill, NY, and John Hunnewell, of South Londonderry, VT, by two grandchildren, Mark and Priscilla Hunnewell, and by eight stepchildren. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, October 7 at Trinity Church in Newport, RI. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Redwood Library and Athenaeum, 50 Bellevue Avenue, Newport, Rhode Island 02840.

title: Yen Declines After Japan Moves to Stem Its Rise
description: The yen fell against the dollar in New York trading yesterday after Japan's Ministry of Finance sold yen to stem a gain that had pushed the currency to its highest since December 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   NEWMAN, DEBRA SHERYL
description: NEWMAN--Debra Sheryl, 6/13/80--10/1/02 Debra darling, you succeeded in fulfilling your vision, ''to be a superior student, an honest person, an encouraging friend; to work earnestly, to speak kindly, to act sincerely, and above all else, to live life to the fullest.'' We love you and miss you. Mom, Dad, Family & Friends

title: Top Editor at El Diario Quits Over Decision on Castro Article
description: The top editor of El Diario/La Prensa resigned this week over a decision by the newspaper's owners to kill an article by Fidel Castro.

title: Minarets and Steeples: Can France Balance Them?
description: Hamida Maiga looks out over a green field ringed by white suburban houses and low-rise apartment blocks here, and imagines the spires of a mosque's minarets rising above it all.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Economic Growth Rises
description: Britain's economy grew twice as fast as previously reported in the second quarter as construction work accelerated, increasing the likelihood of a rise in interest rates later this year. Gross domestic product rose 0.6 percent, instead of the 0.3 percent reported last month, the government said in its final estimate of the second quarter. Construction rose 4.4 percent rather than the 0.8 percent estimated last month.

title: Out of the Shadows
description: With the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, 2001, immigration reform in America came to a halt. The emphasis understandably shifted from inclusiveness to security and the failures of the immigration service. For the estimated six million illegal immigrants who are here to find work or a better life, any hope for a guest worker program or an easier time for their children was stalled as well. Only now, two years later, is there some chance that Congress might focus on needed immigration reform.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Google Buys Web-Search Company
description: Google, the world's most popular Internet search site, yesterday acquired the closely held Kaltix Corporation, which is developing technology to help people get personalized results of Web searches. Financial terms were not disclosed. Kaltix, based in Palo Alto, Calif., was formed in June, Google said in a news release. Google, a closely held company based in Mountain View, Calif., is the ''ideal vehicle'' for continued development of Kaltix's technology, the company's co-founder Larry Page said in a statement. A company spokesman, Nathan Tyler, did not immediately return a voice-mail message seeking comment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEDERMAN, ANNETTE
description: LEDERMAN--Annette. Beloved wife of the late Justin. Devoted mother of Mark and Leslie, Sanford and Sheryl. Cherished grandmother of Andrew, Bryan, Jocelyn and Stacy. Services Thursday 1PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: CREDITORS OF PENTHOUSE PUBLISHER REQUEST LIQUIDATION
description: Creditors of General Media Inc., the bankrupt publisher of Penthouse magazine, asked a federal judge to order the company to liquidate its assets. General Media, a unit of Penthouse International Inc., filed for bankruptcy on Aug. 12, after competition from the Internet, retail video outlets and cable television left it unable to pay its debts. The company is 85 percent owned by Bob Guccione. A panel of General Media's creditors asked Judge Stuart M. Bernstein of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan to change the case to Chapter 7, which results in liquidation, from Chapter 11, which provides for reorganization. Penthouse International, which is based in New York, did not file for bankruptcy.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airlines Get New Loans
description: The Japan Air-lines System and All Nippon Airways secured 85 billion yen ($765 million) in loans from the Development Bank of Japan to offset the downturn in travel from the SARS virus and the war in Iraq. Japan Airlines will get 70 billion yen and All Nippon will get 15 billion yen from the government-owned lender. The carriers will pay off bonds and invest the money. They lost money in the April-June quarter. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Artifacts of berkitsch Evoke Old East Germany; High and Low Culture Offer Powerful Reminders
description: Sibylle Bergemann spent 11 years photographing the construction of a Marx and Engels monument that still stands at the Palace of the Republic here. The bronze statue, now a brisk tourist site, was finally erected in 1986, three years before the Berlin Wall fell.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Good Cigars and Bad Communists
description: Nothing seems to stick to Arnold Schwarzenegger. Democrats are throwing rocks, dredging up Mr. Schwarzenegger's past braggadocios about group sex, drug use and even the seduction of a best friend's girlfriend. Too far in the past, voters are saying. Old news.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Training Explosive At Airport Is Missing
description: An explosive used to train bomb-sniffing dogs at Newark Liberty International Airport is missing, officials confirmed yesterday. Steve Coleman, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the airport, said he did not believe that terrorists had the explosive. He said the inquiry was focusing on those who signed in and signed out the explosive from the locker room at the airport's training center. The explosive, Primasheet, is a plastic bonded explosive that comes in rolls and is cut into rectangular sheets. The sample, a small amount, has been missing for at least a week, Mr. Coleman said. He would not confirm that it was as much as half a pound, as reported by WABC-TV on Monday night. Alicia Zubikowski (NYT)

title: Energy Dept. Seeks Power To Redefine Nuclear Waste
description: The Energy Department has asked Congress to allow it to redefine some nuclear waste so it can be left in place or sent to sites intended for low-level radioactive material, rather than being buried deep underground.

title: Teacher Reassigned Amid Reports of Selling Tickets to Students
description: A math teacher at a Queens high school was reassigned yesterday as school officials investigated whether he sold students tickets to last week's free Dave Matthews Band concert, officials said.

title: Korean Actor's Reality Drama: Coming Out as Gay
description: Around the corner from Gay Hill and Hooker Hill, among the serpentine side streets in the Itaewon district that visitors roam with intent, Hong Suk Chon was trying very hard one recent night to relax inside his bar, ''Our Place.''

Paid Notice: Deaths   TOWNSEND, FELICIA T.
description: TOWNSEND--Felicia T. Died at age 94 on September 27, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Edward Townsend and the late Eduardo Andrade. Mother of Jose E. Andrade and Lydia A. de Sanctis and the late Maria F. Andrade. Mother-inlaw of Malle T. Andrade and Francesco M. de Sanctis. Stepmother of Rosalind T. Hodgkins and Victoria T. Roschen. Stepmother-in-law of Robert C. Hodgkins and William E. Roschen. Grandmother of Eduardo N. T. Andrade, Pier Francesco de Sanctis, Jose Andrade and Felicia M. de Sanctis. Grandmother-inlaw of Christine M. Andrade and Sophie M. de Sanctis. Step-grandmother of Mary Samantha Vermeer, Stephen Walsh, Alexandra Couillard and Rosalind Hodgkins. Stepgrandmother-in-law of Todd Vermeer, Kristin Walsh and Jay Couillard. Interment private. A memorial service for family and friends will be held at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 5th Avenue at 53rd Street, Thursday, October 9, 2003 at 12:45 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Westtown School, PO Box 1799, Westtown, PA 19395.

title: Jackie Flosso, 77, Magic Shop Maven, Dies
description: Jackie Flosso, the last owner of a little shop of magical wonders that was once partly owned by Houdini, died on Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 77.

title: Iraqi Villagers and G.I.'s In an Uneasy Coexistence
description: The aftermath of Monday's six-hour firefight in this palm-studded village 50 miles west of Baghdad was an encounter on Tuesday with two different countries.

title: Justices to Rule on Immunity of States in Bankruptcy Suits
description: The Supreme Court added a significant new federalism case to its docket for the new term on Tuesday, accepting an appeal filed by the State of Tennessee on whether states are immune from suit under federal bankruptcy law.

title: Ricotta and Camembert With a Woolly Origin
description: BEAVER BROOK FARM in Lyme, Conn., has been in the Sankow family since 1917, but it wasn't until 1984 that Stan and Suzanne Sankow introduced sheep to their 175 acres. They broke into the cheese business in an unconventional way with ''half a flock,'' as Mrs. Sankow put it: a ram bought for her by her husband at an agricultural fair in Massachusetts. She spins and weaves, so, they thought, why not have their very own wool producer?

title: Energy Company Accused of Trying to Skew Index
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission sued the American Electric Power Company yesterday, accusing it of falsely reporting prices in an effort to manipulate the natural gas market from at least November 2000 through October 2002.

title: A Blessed Event, and Everything Leading Up to It
description: Anyone, male or female, who has ever gone through pregnancy and childbirth will find familiar material in ''A Rooster in the Henhouse,''

title: American Is Killed in Afghan Firefight
description: An American soldier has been killed and two have been wounded in a gun battle in southeastern Afghanistan close to the Pakistani border, the United States military announced in a statement on Tuesday. Two suspected Taliban militants were also killed in the firefight, which took place on Monday, not far from the American firebase at Shkin.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times yesterday with an article about operations to separate conjoined twins misstated the relationship between a woman and a twin from Eygpt whom she was kissing. She was Naglaa Mahmoud, a nurse, not the children's mother.

title: In a Reversal, Torre Puts 11 Pitchers on Yanks' Postseason Roster
description: After saying for weeks that he did not want to put 11 pitchers on the postseason roster, Yankees Manager Joe Torre reversed course before Game 1 and took Jeff Weaver after all. Infielder Erick Almonte was left off the roster.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: 2 Boiler Workers Found Dead
description: Rescue teams found the bodies of two of four men missing in a scaffolding accident that sent workers plunging into a 270-foot-deep boiler at a power plant in Geertruidenberg, 60 miles south of Amsterdam. The missing workers, who were presumed dead, included an American, but the names and nationalities of the recovered men were not released. Officials released the name of an American whose body was pulled from the collapsed scaffolding. He was David Lee Pope, 45, of Marceline, Mo. Three other workers -- two Americans and a Turk -- were rescued Sunday. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: 'Upstairs, Downstairs,' With Nanny-Cam Running
description: Everyone talks about how often the best television dramas outdo plays and films. But when a play is compared to a sitcom, it usually means high-speed laughs accompanied by low-level complexity.

title: Shunned by Omnivores
description: To the Editor:

title: An Accusation and a Bush Memo Coming at an Especially Bad Time
description: The memorandum from the White House counsel on Tuesday morning was terse, and unusual for the Bush administration: The Justice Department had opened a preliminary criminal investigation into the possible leak of an undercover C.I.A. officer's name, and every member of the White House staff was being ordered to ''preserve all materials that might be relevant.''

title: California Syrahs' Novelty Has Worn Off
description: REMEMBER the Rhone Rangers? Back in the early 1980's they were an iconoclastic group of young winemakers who rebelled against what one of their leaders in those days, Randall Grahm of Bonny Doon Vineyard, called the ''cabocentric'' world of California wine. From Mendocino to the Mexican border, they saw little but endless acres of cabernet sauvignon, and they wanted to do other things.

title: California Democratic Group Seeks Fund for Recall Expenses
description: Agroup of California Democrats announced today that it was seeking $100,000 in donations to educate California's Democratic voters about correct voting procedures during the recall election next week and to pay for the costs of legal challenges that might arise from the election.

description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAYE, EARL W.
description: HAYE--Earl W. A memorial service will be held at Saint Luke's in the Field, 487 Hudson Street at 7:30 P.M. Thursday, October 2nd.

title: As Funny Cide Runs, Empire Maker Retired
description: Funny Cide worked a strong five furlongs in 59.52 seconds yesterday at Belmont Park and is a possible starter in the Breeders' Cup Classic in Santa Anita on Oct. 25. The gelding, who won the Kentucky Derby and Preakness, has not started since finishing third in the Haskell Aug. 3 and has been sidelined with an illness.

title: DISNEY CHIEF EXPECTS STRONG GROWTH IN PROFITS
description: The Walt Disney Company expects ''strong earnings growth'' in fiscal 2004, the president and chief operating officer, Robert Iger, said yesterday. Mr. Iger, speaking at an investment conference in New York, cited growth at Disney's cable networks and improved financial performance at the company's ABC television network. A gradual recovery at Disney's theme parks and strength at its studio unit from DVD sales will help results in the fiscal year that begins this month, Mr. Iger said. Stock in Disney, which is based in Burbank, Calif., fell 11 cents, to $20.17.

title: Moynihan Is Recalled as a 'True Visionary'
description: Daniel Patrick Moynihan was remembered yesterday at a memorial service in Manhattan as a scholar and public servant whose searing intellect propelled a convention-shattering government career, while repeatedly recasting the nation's political debate.

title: White House Besieged With Questions Over Leaking of Name
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  The White House was besieged again today with questions about who disclosed the name of an undercover C.I.A. officer in what appeared to be an attempt to get back at the officer's husband for questioning the Bush administration's rationale for going to war in Iraq.

description: To the Editor:

title: Wood and Cubs Act as if They've Been Here Before
description: First it was the Chicago Cubs' fans who made themselves at home. They swarmed into Turner Field tonight rejoicing over a rare appearance by their team in the postseason.

title: It Takes a Bold Bird to Stand Up to a Big Grape
description: CENTRAL COAST syrahs are a curious category among wines, much in the way that, say, lacrosse is curious in the world of sports. They are challenging and enjoyable now and then, but they might not be for everyone. I imagine that most wine lovers could enjoy dabbling in these syrahs but that very few would become devotees.

title: Hating the Policy, Not the President
description: To the Editor:

title: Harry Goz, 71; Played Lead in 'Fiddler'
description: Harry Goz, an actor who was an understudy in ''Fiddler on the Roof'' and wound up playing the lead, died on Sept. 6 in a hospital in Manhasset, N.Y., where he lived. He was 71.

title: A Federal Marshal With a Fondness for Bourbon
description: Cellphones are a boon to stagecraft. With only a small clutch of electronics pressed to the head, characters can now convincingly perform monologues anywhere: in cars, on the beach, in the tub. ''Karen Sisco,'' which has its premiere tonight, exploits this device, spinning drama chiefly from close-ups on the radiantly made-up face of Carla Gugino, the show's star, as she bathes, paces and drives in Miami. And, all the while, talks into her flip-top mobile.

title: Air France and KLM to Merge, Europe's No. 1 Airline
description: Europe's skies are changing, and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and Air France intend to stay ahead of the changes. They will create the largest European airline through the first major cross-border airline merger in decades, their chief executives said on Tuesday.

title: House Members Meet Clark, And Come Away Interested
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark, the newly minted Democratic presidential contender, swept through the capital on Tuesday, introducing himself to House members and trying to persuade them that his candidacy was viable.

title: Accusation of Leak and a Bush Memo Come at a Bad Time
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  The memorandum from the White House counsel on Tuesday morning was terse, and unusual for the Bush administration: The Justice Department had opened a preliminary criminal investigation into the possible leak of an undercover C.I.A. officer's name, and every member of the White House staff was being ordered to "preserve all materials that might be relevant."

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: $20 Million For Bio-Containment
description: The National Institutes of Health awarded two research centers more than $20 million to build a regional bio-containment laboratory, one of nine such centers in the country specifically working on combating bioterrorism and new pathogens like the SARS and West Nile viruses. The federal construction grant went to the University of Medicine and Dentistry - New Jersey Medical School in Newark and its neighbor, the Public Health Research Institute in Newark's Science Park. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANDS, NORA CARSON
description: SANDS--Nora Carson, 75, passed away on September 24, 2003. She is survived by her children, Louise OwensPapaceno, Jacqueline Sands O'Connor, and Richard R. Owens, her son - in - law Charles Papaceno, her grandchildren, Benjamin and Christopher O'Connor, and Augustus Papaceno, her brother C.S. Sands, her twin brother Ben Frank Sands and his wife Mary Lou along with dozens of nephews and nieces, and great-nieces and nephews. She was preceded in death by her parents, Ben F. and Martha Ann Carson Sands of Madisonville, Tennessee and her dear son-in-law Paul T. O'Connor. She was the guiding force behind the American Institute of Musical Studies (AIMS). A former opera singer and co-founder of AIMS, she was the inspiration to thousands of young musicians who attended the AIMS program in Graz, Austria every summer for the past 34 years. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Nora Sands Memorial Fund benefiting AIMS C/O AIMS 6621 Snider Plaza, Dallas, Texas 75205.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RONIN, ROSALIND
description: RONIN -- Rosalind. Beloved wife and best friend of Harold. Best mother in the world to Bonnie and Judy. Wonderful mother-in-law to Jeff and Marc. Adored nanny of Robert, Andrew, Jennifer, Jonathan and Elizabeth. Caring sister-in-law, aunt, cousin and friend. There 'll never be anyone else like you, Rozzy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   AARON, GREGG
description: AARON--Gregg. 9/19/67--10/01/01. Remembered with love. Mom

title: Union and Board Debate Teachers Not on Payroll
description: A month after they started work, 3,900 New York City public school teachers are still not on the payroll, their union president said yesterday.

title: Bryant Case Looms Over Lakers
description: One day into training camp, Coach Phil Jackson conceded that the Los Angeles Lakers had more to learn than just the intricacies of the triangle offense this season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ECCLES, VISCOUNTESS MARY
description: ECCLES--Viscountess Mary. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 2nd at 5PM, at Christ Church United Methodist, located at 60th St and Park Ave in NYC.

title: Democrats And Bush Seek Money Nationwide
description: President Bush raced across the Midwest on Tuesday collecting money for his re-election campaign, raising $5.3 million at two events, his record for a single day. Democratic presidential candidates raised money from Los Angeles to New York before the deadline for third-quarter financial reports.

title: Guantnamo Inquiry Widens As Civilian Translator Is Held
description: Federal officials said on Tuesday that they had arrested a civilian Arabic-language translator at Logan International Airport in Boston on suspicion of espionage at the naval base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, where he helped the military interview prisoners suspected of being members of the Taliban and Al Qaeda.

title: Australia Damaged By Drought
description: In a nation that calls itself the sunburnt country, it takes a mighty dry patch to reach the record books and knock farmers sideways.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Ex-Congo Colonel Charged
description: The Dutch police arrested a former colonel from Congo's national guard and charged him with acts of torture and rape in Congo in the 1990's. The officer, identified only as S. N., had sought political asylum in the Netherlands, but Dutch investigators found that three Congolese nationals had filed charges against him for abuses committed during the rule of the longtime dictator Mobutu Sese Seko. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: In Reversal, Torre Takes 11 Pitchers on Yanks Postseason Roster
description: After saying for weeks that he did not want to put 11 pitchers on the postseason roster, Yankees Manager Joe Torre reversed course before Game 1 and took Jeff Weaver after all. Infielder Erick Almonte was left off the roster.

title: Dean Struggles With a Stance Over Medicare

title: Corrections

Bush administration officials say it will be used primarily to run the Iraqi government, with a small amount applied to rebuilding efforts; the entire amount will not be spent on reconstruction.

description: When Michael R. Bloomberg was running for mayor, he told voters that what New York City needed was a ''professional manager, not a professional politician.''

description: The Chicago Climate Exchange, a start-up venture hoping to create a market for member companies and governments to trade rights to emit gases associated with global warming, got off to an ambiguous start yesterday with an auction that laid the groundwork for trading to begin Oct. 31.

description: The Bush administration announced a new vision for biomedical research on Tuesday that it said would give patients swifter access to the fruits of scientific discovery and foster greater collaboration between the government and private industry.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Pope In 'Bad Way,' Cardinal Says
description: Pope John Paul II ''is in a bad way'' and the faithful should pray for him, Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, one of the Vatican's most senior officials, said in an interview in the German weekly Bunte. The remarks by Cardinal Ratzinger, the head of the influential Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, were made Sept. 22, a day before the 83-year-old pope skipped his usual weekly appearance before an audience at the Vatican, one of several recent changes to his schedule. John Paul suffers from Parkinson's disease and severe arthritis, among other afflictions. On Sunday, he announced -- months earlier than many Vatican officials had expected -- the selection of 31 new cardinals. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Love on Campus: Trying to Set Rules for the Emotions
description: The University of California is beginning the academic year under a new policy that bans ''romantic or sexual'' relationships between professors and their students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLOAN, IRVING
description: SLOAN--Irving. On September 29, 2003 at age 88. Beloved husband of Hilda. Loving father of Bruce and Alan Sloan. Stepfather of Barbara. Step grandfather of Lauren. Dear brother of Hilda. Much adored uncle of many nieces and nephews. Early founder of United Cerebral Palsy of N.Y.C. Inc. and founder of supermarket chain. Funeral service will be held Friday, October 3rd, 1;30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Contributions in his memory may be made to United Cerebral Palsy of N.Y.C., Inc., 80 Maiden La., N.Y., N.Y. 10038-4811.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BURR, ELIZABETH LONG
description: BURR--Elizabeth Long. September 28, 2003, of Matinicus Island, Maine, formerly of Lloyd Harbor, NY. Beloved wife of the late Robert Page Burr, loving mother of Susan, William, James, Jonathan, Elizabeth, and David. Devoted grandmother of twelve grandchildren. Born Eli zabeth Jaquelin Long, Hewlett Harbor, NY, November 22, 1927, daughter of William Henderson Long and Dorothy Jaquelin Smith. She attended Wellesley College and was an avid gardener and collector of rhododendron and hollies. Throughout her life she made significant contributions to the communities in which she lived, particularly as the first woman trustee of the village of Lloyd Harbor (1968 to 1977), assessor for Matinicus Island Plantation (1982-1997), and member of the Matinicus Plantation Electric Company advisory committee until her death. Instrumental in the preservation and development of Caumsett State Park in Lloyd Harbor as an environmental education facility. Recently, she traveled extensively to remote areas throughout the world. Memorial services will be held at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Rockland, Maine, Saturday, October 4, 2 PM and Matinicus in June of 2004. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Maine Seacoast Missionary Society, Bar Harbor, Maine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARTIN, CLIFFORD JAMES
description: MARTIN--Clifford James, 86, of Fredericksburg, VA died Monday, September 29, 2003. Born 1917 in Jersey City, N.J. He was a U.S. Army World War II veteran having served in the European Theatre and was the circulation manager for the Stars and Stripes Newspaper. Mr. Martin worked for the Journal American from 1945-1962 and then became The New York Times Director of Circulation from 1962-1985. Survivors include his wife of 59 years, Phyllis Martin; two daughters, Kathryn Wilewski and her husband, Henry; Bonnie Kurz and her husband, Jack; seven grandchildren and six great grandchildren. A funeral mass will be held at 11 A.M. Thursday, October 2, at St. Mary Catholic Church, Fredericksburg. Burial will be in Quantico National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to the Mary Washington Hospice, 2300 Fall Hill Avenue, Suite 210, Fredericksburg, VA. 22401. On-line guest book convenantfuneralservice.com

title: Vietnamese Food Is Just Part of the Point
description: ANYONE who thinks restaurants are in the business of preparing and selling food is only half right. Food is what logicians would call a necessary but not sufficient condition for restaurant success. A restaurant with no food would be a work of conceptual art. But restaurants with wonderful food have been known to sink like a stone, and some very successful restaurants almost seem to take pride in the awfulness of each and every dish they send out of the kitchen. What they offer instead is a highly desirable setting for a certain kind of person. Restaurateurs who can match the setting to a target audience have created their own A.T.M.

description: ATLANTA, Sept. 30 - The gates to Turner Field opened at 5 p.m., and Cubs fans swarmed through wearing Sammy Sosa jerseys, carrying signs declaring an end to their misery and flashing wide smiles. In 30 minutes, the brick plaza to the Braves' home park could have been Wrigley Field. For every Braves hat you saw, there were 20 Cubs hats bobbing in the crowd.

description: YELLIN--Helen. title: Study Recommends Not Using Hormone Therapy for Bone Loss
description: Hormone replacement therapy should no longer be prescribed solely to prevent or treat the bone-thinning disease osteoporosis, researchers said in a study being published today, disputing the policy of the Food and Drug Administration.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Audit To Be Released
description: The Dutch food retailer Royal Ahold said it would release its much-anticipated 2002 audited yearly results tomorrow, along with restated figures for previous years. The company, which owns supermarket chains worldwide including Stop & Shop in the United States, had said it would release results Tuesday, after several delays. The company's lenders agreed Tuesday to a short extension. Ahold is struggling to recover from a $1.1 billion accounting scandal that included considerable irregularities at a subsidiary, U.S. Food Service. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

description: Martha Burk, whose coalition has protested Augusta National Golf Club's men-only membership policy, said yesterday that John S. Reed, the interim chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, should resign his membership at Augusta National, the home of the Masters tournament.

description: ONE recent afternoon, Jeff Smedstad walked into his backyard at the edge of the desert here to gather some greens for dinner. Kneeling over a pile of rocks and concrete, Mr. Smedstad, owner of Los Sombreros restaurant in Scottsdale, reached out with a pair of kitchen tongs and a knife and snipped bristly nopales, the spiny leaves of a prickly pear cactus.

description: A closely watched legal dispute over the ownership of works of art once looted by the Nazis reached the Supreme Court on Tuesday as the justices accepted an appeal by Austria and one of its state art museums on whether American courts have jurisdiction to resolve such cases.

title: F.C.C. Plans To Enforce No-Call Rules
description: Federal regulators told a Senate committee yesterday that they planned to enforce a national do-not-call registry starting today despite logistical complications caused by a federal judge's ruling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOLTON, HILARY
description: KOLTON--Hilary, 53, died peacefully on September 29th. After a long illness, she passed away at home in the presence of her family. Beloved wife of Robert, mother of Jordan and Joanna, and daughter of Julius Cohen, she is predeceased by her mother, Rosalyn Cohen, and her brother, Lee Cohen. She will be remembered as a youthful, vibrant, beautiful woman who took tremendous strength and joy from her many wonderful friends and her close and loving family. Funeral will be held at 11:30, Wednesday morning at Congregation B'nai Yisrael, 2 Banksville Rd, Armonk NY. In lieu of flowers, a donation in her memory may be made to The Institute for Neurosciences at Northern Westchester Hospital Center, 400 East Main St, Mt. Kisco, NY 10549.

title: Hate by Numbers
description: Across the city, the number of hate crimes reported to the police has been on the decline. Until recently, that was especially true on Staten Island, which took pride in a dramatic decrease in such incidents. The picture of harmony was pierced on Labor Day, when white youths attacked a black visitor named Rachel Carter and her friends.

title: Bank Group In Japan Lifts Outlook For the Year
description: The Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group doubled its profit expectations for the full year on Tuesday as a mending economy reduced the number of bad loans in the company's portfolio and the costs of writing them off.

title: Coach on L.I. Says He Knew Of No Hazing
description: The head coach of Mepham High School's football team apologized on Tuesday for not being able to protect three freshman players who say they were sexually assaulted by three older teammates at a preseason training camp. But at the same time, the coach, Kevin McElroy, said he and his staff did everything they could to ensure the safety of the students.

title: In Paris, 800 Food Titles, And Sausages to Gape At
description: Claude Deloffre, above, a fashion publicist who describes herself as an ''amateur de cuisine,'' wanted to start a serious food magazine. Financing wasn't available, so instead she opened a Paris shop selling cookbooks and culinary guidebooks, about a third in English and the rest in French. Her bright little white store is called Food and is at 58, rue Charlot, on the Right Bank near the Place de la Rpublique. The shop has about 800 titles so far and an exhibition area upstairs, where framed oversize photographs of sausages, taken by Hans Gissinger, are currently on display.

title: Gephardt Won't Get Early Backing of Labor
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced yesterday that it would not endorse a Democratic presidential candidate this month, dealing a sharp setback to the campaign of Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri.

description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, Oct. 1 — This week's annual Labor Party conference has seen bonds being re-established between Prime Minister Tony Blair and his restive party members, but it has also seen the distance grow between Mr. Blair and his chief rival for power, the chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown.

description: More than a week remains before Gov. George E. Pataki's commission on educational financing even holds its first meeting, yet it has already lost its distinction as the only game in town.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm To Introduce New Products
description: Palm, the largest maker of hand-held computers, plans to announce its fall line of new devices today, including a unit that lowers the price of having a color display to $199. That unit, the Tungsten E, includes a higher resolution screen and the ability to play MP3 songs, the company said. Another new Palm device, the $399 Tungsten 3, is more full-featured, including the ability to rotate the display and updated software that includes additional conveniences. The company, based in Milpitas, Calif., will also announce a new entry-level Zire for $99. The hand-held computers are part of the company's semiannual new product announcement, the last round before Palm completes its acquisition of Handspring, a competitor it announced its intent to purchase this summer. Shares of Palm fell 48 cents, to $19.33. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; Mangled in the Outfield: The Yankees Get Sloppy
description: Outfielders are taught to surround the ball from the time they begin playing Little League. It is a basic task. If an outfielder cannot corral a liner or a fly ball, he must at least get himself into position to retrieve the ball as soon as possible. Again, basic stuff. Letting a ball rattle in the outfield gaps like a pinball can be as dangerous as losing the opener of a three-of-five-game series at home.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Official Helps In An Arrest
description: A high-ranking police official helped arrest a suspect in a home-invasion robbery last night after seeing him in a surveillance tape, the police said. The official, Michael O'Looney, the deputy commissioner for public information, had released the surveillance tape yesterday, with the man unidentified. Commissioner O'Looney recognized him around 7:30 p.m. near Union Square and followed him into the subway, where a police officer, Jaime Soto, and three civilians helped stop him. After a brief chase, he was arrested on the subway platform. The man was wanted for a robbery on Sept. 17 in which he pushed his way into the apartment of a 29-year-old woman on West 16th Street, robbed her and stabbed one of her hands. Charges against the man are pending, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: U.S. Urges Seizure Of Restaurant
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn filed charges yesterday seeking to seize the Casablanca Restaurant in Maspeth, Queens, a reputed landmark in the recent history of organized crime. The Casablanca, at 66-15 60th Lane, is said to be the longtime meeting place of one of its owners, Joseph C. Massino, who has been under indictment since January as the leader of the Bonanno crime family. Yesterday's filing added charges against Mr. Massino and included the allegation that he and other members of the Bonanno family should forfeit $11.7 million in what the prosecutors said were criminal proceeds that include the Casablanca. William Glaberson (NYT)

description: BEIJING, Oct. 1  President Hu Jintao made a vague but insistent call for more democracy in China on the eve of the country's National Day holiday, raising expectations that the new leader might support introducing greater pluralism in the one-party state.

title: A Man and His Young Son Are Dead, and a Rich Suburb Is Stunned

But they can only guess why he stepped in front of a New Jersey Transit commuter train on Monday, shortly before the police found the body of his 8-year-old son, Eric, in the family's expensive home in Short Hills.

title: DYNEGY TO SELL DEBT IN PRIVATE PLACEMENT
description: Dynegy Inc., an energy producer and supplier based in Texas, said it planned to sell $300 million in notes in a private placement to help pay off a term loan and a lease obligation. The offering will include 9.875 percent notes maturing in 2010 and 10.125 percent notes maturing in 2013, Dynegy said. Proceeds will be used to repay $194 million remaining on a term loan that matures in 2005 and to help retire a $170 million lease obligation, the company said. Dynegy, which is based in Houston, expects to complete the note sale by Oct. 15, pending an amendment to its credit line by banks.

title: Homemade Or Semi? A Bake-Off
description: IN the world of Sandra Lee, cookbook author and self-proclaimed ''lifestylist,'' life is hectic and people are busy. Cooking food from scratch takes too much time, and is too difficult and too expensive. And while Ms. Lee believes that cooking food for someone is the greatest gift, it really isn't worth too much of your time.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: GLEN COVE: PACT TO CLEAN WASTE FROM WATERFRONT The waterfront in Glen Cove, contaminated by industrial compounds and radioactive waste, will be cleaned up under an agreement announced yesterday by the United States Department of Justice and the Environmental Protection Agency. The pact provides initial federal funds of $20 million, $1.6 million from Glen Cove and $700,000 from the Wah Chang Smelting and Refining Company, which operated in the area. The total cleanup cost is estimated at $54 million, and federal officials said they were pursuing 25 companies that also used the site to force them to pay their share of the remainder. The project will dispose of mounds of radioactive waste and heavy metals already excavated from a 50-acre former industrial site along Glen Cove Creek and Hempstead Harbor. City redevelopment plans call for a hotel and conference center and other commercial and residential uses. Bruce Lambert (NYT)
