title: A Heroine (and a Star) at Risk
description: The soprano Rene Fleming, for all her greatness and success, has insecurities like almost everyone else. To protect herself, she has often said, she has hidden behind unfamiliar repertory. Over the years she has sung certain well-known roles, like Mozart's Fiordiligi and Strauss's Marschallin, but she has avoided the iconic Puccini and Verdi roles, the money parts. You can't sing Tosca without expecting painstaking comparisons with earlier classic performances. Instead, Ms. Fleming has sought less familiar roles that challenge her, from Rossini's Armida to Carlisle Floyd's Susannah.

title: Clinton, in Switch, Supports Naming Special Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  In her recently published memoir, "Living History," Hillary Rodham Clinton describes how deeply opposed she was to the appointment of an independent counsel to look into the failed Whitewater land deal involving her and President Bill Clinton.

title: CALENDAR
description: Helping Union Square Park

title: Israel Seen as Likely to Approve Barrier
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's government is expected to approve a plan, over American opposition, to build a barrier deep inside the West Bank around a large Jewish settlement, Israeli officials said Tuesday.

title: Hating the Policy, Not the President
description: To the Editor:

title: Lingering Resentment As Martin Begins Camp
description: Training camp opened for the Nets on Tuesday, and Kenyon Martin was there working as hard as anyone on the court, sweating in the midst of players who would soon be plying their trade in some far-off country or in the N.B.A.'s developmental league.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Huge Cocaine Cache Seized
description: Nearly 1,000 pounds of cocaine destined for distribution in Washington Heights and parts of the Bronx was seized on Monday, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday. The cocaine has a street value of $11 million, Mr. Kelly said. Five people said to be part of what Bridget Brennan, the special narcotics prosecutor, called the ''extremely sophisticated and fast-moving'' drug-smuggling operation were arrested, and $50,000 was seized, Mr. Kelly said. The cocaine, packed in suitcases, was discovered in the back of a tractor-trailer at a warehouse at 886 East 149th Street in Hunts Point. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Mother Selects Fourth Partner
description: Mother in London, which is planning to open its first office in the United States, has named Rob DeFlorio as the fourth partner at the office, scheduled to open in New York by the end of the year. Mr. DeFlorio, 42, had most recently been global advertising director at Nike Inc. in Beaverton, Ore., and before that worked at agencies in New York like Chiat/Day and McCaffrey & McCall. The other partners, announced previously, are Andrew Deitchman, Linus Karlsson and Paul Malmstrom.

title: Sweetney Mourns Loss And Finds Inspiration
description: The intense instruction, the sprints, the post battles with his fellow rookie Maciej Lampe, these were the easy parts of training camp for Mike Sweetney, the Knicks' first-round draft pick.

title: Hello, Old Friend: Rediscovering Manhattan's Chinatown
description: NOBODY says much about Chinatown these days. Not Manhattan Chinatown, anyway. Flushing is where the excitement is, or Brooklyn. ''You know,'' one Chinese-food maven whispered to me recently, ''there are really two Chinatowns in Brooklyn now, Sunset Park and the Avenue U area near Bensonhurst, but nobody knows about that one.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Drivers To Advise Taxi Regulator
description: Taxi and livery drivers will be able to give advice to the Taxi and Limousine Commission under legislation passed yesterday by the City Council. The advisory board will consist of 14 licensed drivers, half of whom will be appointed by the Council and half by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg by the end of the year. Councilman Miguel Martinez, the bill's sponsor, said the board would represent the interests of the drivers before the Council and the commission. Matthew W. Daus, the taxi commissioner, has supported the board. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOSTER, ROBERT C.
description: FOSTER--Robert C., age 77, resident of Bergenfield, New Jersey, on September 25, 2003. Devoted father of Robert A. Foster, Victoria Dziezawiec and Marjorie Foster; grandfather of ten. Also survived by his sister Margie Zaremba. He was a decorated World War II veteran with two Purple Hearts, a member of VFW Post 6467 in Bergenfield, NJ. A printer for the New York Times for over 35 years. Buried at the New Jersey Veterans Memorial Cemetery, Arneytown, New Jersey.

title: Iraqi Schools Expelling 'Beloved Saddam'
description: When Iraqi children return to school this Saturday, they will no longer see Saddam Hussein's portrait in the classroom or start the day chanting of his heroic struggle against the snakehead of the devil that is America. But Mr. Hussein has still not quite been expelled.

title: Rules That Work
description: The Bush administration has spent the better part of three years weakening federal regulations and belittling their value. Now, from a most unlikely source -- the fervently anti-regulatory Office of Management and Budget -- comes persuasive evidence that the health and social benefits of these rules greatly outweigh their costs.

title: Health Care in a Civil Society
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WM. WRIGLEY JR. CO., Chicago, the chewing gum maker, said it had named Bill Wrigley Jr. to be chairman while continuing as chief executive and president. Ronald V. Waters will become chief operating officer, while remaining chief financial officer.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Paypal Sues Bank One Over Patent Infringement
description: The PayPal unit of eBay has sued the Bank One Corporation, the third-largest issuer of credit cards in the country, charging infringement of a patent for conducting financial transactions over the Internet. PayPal contends its online bill-payment system, patented in 1998, is being wrongly used by the Chicago-based bank. PayPal, based in Mountain View, Calif., seeks a jury trial and unspecified damages in the lawsuit filed Monday in United States District Court in Wilmington, Del. ''Bank One's infringement of the patent has continued unabated'' since PayPal notified the bank's lawyers in February of the reported patent infringement, the lawsuit said. a Bank One spokeswoman, Calmetta Coleman, said, ''We haven't seen the lawsuit and don't comment on pending litigation.'' Shares of Bank One rose 19 cents, to $38.65. Shares of eBay fell $2.01, to $53.64.

title: Israels Cabinet Approves Barrier Inside West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 1 — Israel's government approved today construction of new barriers deep inside the West Bank to shield several large Jewish settlements. The move significantly expands the scope of the already controversial project and could draw sanctions from the Bush administration.

title: Meals to Go At Grand Central (Just Add Stove)
description: Maggie Talisman, the chef and an owner of Dishes at Home, which just moved into the Grand Central Market at 43rd Street and Lexington Avenue, does not have anyone's diet in mind when she whips up her silky, almost candylike Valrhona chocolate pudding ($4.25 a half-pound), or fries her torpedo-size Russian mushroom or meat-filled piroshki ($3.50 each).

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Edward W. Said, the Columbia University literary scholar and advocate of a Palestinian state, misidentified the city that was his childhood home and misstated the date of Jerusalem's partition into Jewish and Arab areas. Although Mr. Said was born in Jerusalem, in 1935, his family's home was Cairo; they did not move from Jerusalem. Jerusalem was partitioned in 1949, not 1947.

title: Market Place; S.E.C. to Revise Election Rules For Directors
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will approve rules next week to make it easier for a company's shareholders to elect a limited number of independent directors, commission officials said Tuesday.

title: Class-Blind Lovebirds And Hidebound Parents
description: The old Boston accent gets a workout in ''It's All Relative,'' a comedy of manners that pays tribute to that city's venerable (exhausted?) class conflict between proper WASP's and rowdy Irish Catholics. Mace (Lenny Clarke) and Audrey O'Neil (Harriet Sansom Harris), a middle-aged couple, drop R's with abandon. So does their daughter Maddy (Paige Moss), along with patrons of the Hub pub, which they own.

title: Health Care in a Civil Society (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Lack of Hiring Appears To Be Biggest Economic Ill

title: Off the Menu
description: MATSURI, the Japanese restaurant that opened on Monday in the Maritime Hotel, 363 West 16th Street, is a few steps below street level in the vast vaulted former meeting hall of the National Maritime Union. As it has more than 200 seats on several levels, one only hopes that the sushi chefs can keep up with the orders. TADASHI ONO, above, the former chef and an owner of Sono, now closed, is a partner in Matsuri with MIKIO SHINAGAWA, the owner of Omen. Mr. Ono's menu includes Kobe beef seared with mustard vinaigrette, roast duck with wasabi-chive sauce, and a casserole of rice with seafood and chicken. Reservations will be taken starting Oct. 13.

title: Chicago Exchange Cited for Lax Oversight
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has sanctioned the Chicago Stock Exchange for failing to adequately oversee trading as it tried to attract business from technology stocks during the Internet boom.

title: Drug Company Lease Gives Security to a College
description: As a small Roman Catholic liberal arts college for women, Emmanuel College had good reason to worry about its future. Drawing its students from poor and working-class families, it had relatively few of the kind of affluent alumnae who can keep an endowment flush. And it was finding it hard to compete with small private colleges that also accepted men.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 20 about an Israeli delegation sent to Washington to discuss the barrier that Israel is building along the West Bank referred incorrectly to the past boundary known as the Green Line. It existed between 1949 and 1967; it was not established after the 1967 war.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GURARY, RABBI SCHNEJER ZALMAN
description: GURARY -- Rabbi Schnejer Zalman. His wife, children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren note with sadness and profound loss the passing of our family patriarch. A shining light and formidable spirit, he will live on in our hearts and minds always. Rabbi Gurary's life was marked by an unparalleled devotion to the Lubavitcher Rebbes; indeed, it was while praying at their gravesites that he suffered cardiac arrest. He passed from this world a few hours later on the morning of Rosh HaShana 5764 corresponding to September 27th, 2003. His piety, fierce intellect, sparkling wit and love for his family were matched only by his myriad communal involvements and legendary philanthropy. May his memory be for a blessing.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When we taught about bacteria in biology class, we explained that Saddam brought antibacterial soap and drugs into Iraq. Whenever his name was mentioned, it had be followed with 'God protect him and keep him our president.' ''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Turkish Government To Pay City $5 Million
description: The Turkish government has agreed to pay $5 million to settle a lawsuit by New York City that sought $70 million in unpaid property taxes and interest on Turkey's United Nations consulate offices. The city argued that Turkey has used part of the building for commercial purposes, making it taxable. Lawsuits seeking $36 million in taxes and interest are continuing against the governments of the Philippines, India and Mongolia, Corporation Counsel Michael A. Cardozo said yesterday. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Giants Have 13 Sacks But Face Test in Fiedler
description: The Giants' defensive coordinator, Johnnie Lynn, is right: statistics are always skewed after three games, much like the batting average of a hitter who has been to the plate only a few times.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Acquires Most Assets Of Sector7
description: I.B.M. has bought most of the assets of the closely held Sector7, adding services and programs that make it easier for clients to switch their software to run on Linux and I.B.M.'s AIX operating system. Financial terms were not disclosed, I.B.M. said in a statement yesterday. The company will hire an undisclosed number of Sector7 employees to work in its services unit. Sector7, which was established in Britain in 1985, is now based in Austin, Tex. I.B.M., the world's largest provider of computer services and second-largest software company behind Microsoft, has been bolstering its services, software and hardware offerings amid a decline in corporate spending on computers. I.B.M. bought Rational Software for $2.1 billion in February, adding tools used by programmers. Shares of I.B.M. fell 1.12 cents, to $88.33.

title: New York Schools to Compete for Reading Grants
description: New York State will receive $129 million in new federal money to pay for a program designed to improve literacy among young schoolchildren, Gov. George E. Pataki announced Tuesday. The money is the first installment of what is expected to be $460 million over six years for early literacy programs in poorly performing schools, as part of President George W. Bush's education reform bill known as No Child Left Behind.

title: Beret, Fatigues and a Puzzle About a Gunman's Motive
description: In the weeks before his sudden murderous rampage Sunday night and Monday morning, Gary Heiland began wearing military-style camouflage fatigues, a beret and sometimes an empty holster on his hip. But people who lived with him in a trailer park in this southern New Jersey hamlet said that Mr. Heiland was, outwardly, as easygoing and even-tempered as always, even dancing at the park's Labor Day picnic earlier this month.

title: The Roster of Ground Zero Architects Grows
description: Three celebrated architects -- including Norman Foster, who offered his own vision last year of twin towers rising from ground zero -- were added yesterday to the growing roster of international designers working on the World Trade Center site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NAIDECH, SYD
description: NAIDECH -- Syd. Devoted mother of Neil and Ingrid. Dear sister of Ann Weissberg, Lillian Lindemann, Rose Simstein and Ray Goldman. Loving grandmother of Alison. Service Wednesday, 10 AM, Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51 St. For information call ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'' 212-769-4400.

title: Tax Protester in Texas Pleads Guilty to Felony Charge
description: ATexas businessman who stopped withholding taxes from paychecks in 1999, making him a hero to the small but growing movement that contends most Americans are not required to pay taxes, has pleaded guilty to a felony tax charge.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Ranch Sale Upheld
description: An attempt to stop the sale of an Australian ranching company that is considered by industry leaders to be the largest beef-raising operation in the world was rejected by a federal court. The company, the Stanbroke Pastoral Company, which runs about 500,000 cattle on 27 ranches covering 25 million acres in the state of Queensland and the adjacent Northern Territory, was sold this month for 490 million Australian dollars ($332 million) in a tender process to Nebo Holdings despite higher bids by AACo, Australia's third-largest ranching group. Stanbroke was owned by AMP, an Australian insurance group that is selling assets to balance overseas losses. The purchasers include five Australian ranching families and Jack Cowin, an American who founded an Australian fast-food chain. The sale was challenged by Peter Holmes  Court, who is the chairman of AACo. He asserted that he made three offers that were higher than the winning bid. The federal court rejected his claims.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Glen Cove: Pact To Clean Waste From Waterfront
description: The waterfront in Glen Cove, contaminated by industrial compounds and radioactive waste, will be cleaned up under an agreement announced yesterday by the United States Department of Justice and the Environmental Protection Agency. The pact provides initial federal funds of $20 million, $1.6 million from Glen Cove and $700,000 from the Wah Chang Smelting and Refining Company, which operated in the area. The total cleanup cost is estimated at $54 million, and federal officials said they were pursuing 25 companies that also used the site to force them to pay their share of the remainder. The project will dispose of mounds of radioactive waste and heavy metals already excavated from a 50-acre former industrial site along Glen Cove Creek and Hempstead Harbor. City redevelopment plans call for a hotel and conference center and other commercial and residential uses. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Bush Orders Full Cooperation in Leaking of Name
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  The Justice Department said on Tuesday that it had begun a full investigation into whether Bush administration officials illegally disclosed the name of an undercover C.I.A. officer to journalists, and the White House directed its staff to cooperate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROMBERG, DR. JULES H.
description: BROMBERG--Dr. Jules H. of Maplewood, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn Konoff Bromberg. Devoted father of Carol Berman, Dina Bromberg, Kimberly Kaplan and the late David K. Bromberg. Devoted father-in-law of Simeon Berman, Edward Kaplan and Barrett Sinowitz. Adoring grandfather of Sara and Abby Berman, Michelle Kaplan and Gordon Sinowitz. Loving and grateful son of the late Esther and Samuel Bromberg and loving brother of the late Molly Cohos and Leah Green. Loving and admired brother-in-law of Edna M. Konoff and Pauline K. and Robert Marks. Dear friend of Ann Harris. Loving uncle and great uncle of many nieces and nephews of the Marks, Hamerman, Sprinzen, Green and Cohos families. His family and friends will miss his warmth, kindness, generosity and great enthusiasm. Contributions in his memory may be made to Dartmouth College or to the charity of your choice. For info. Bernheim Apter Kreitzman, 800-938-6372

title: 'Inherent Cruelty'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharpton Loses 2 Pivotal Aides; New Hurdle For Campaign
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton's long shot bid for the Democratic nomination stumbled on Tuesday after two top aides resigned, and some ardent supporters complained that the candidate had failed to build a cohesive campaign.

title: Loving the Circus, and Negotiating With the Lions
description: THE frosty temperature inside Barry F. Lipton's union office screams meat locker, but no, it's not an occupational hazard; it's a negotiating ploy.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Charges In Evidence-Room Thefts
description: Two civilian employees of the Memphis Police Department and 13 other people were indicted after a yearlong police and F.B.I. investigation of thefts of drugs and valuables from a police property and evidence room. The authorities seized more than $1 million in cash as well as cars and homes they say were bought with illegal proceeds. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Rights for Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Donald Mitchell, 80, Lawmaker Who Brought Defense Jobs North
description: Donald J. Mitchell, a Republican from New York who served in the House of Representatives for 10 years, died on Saturday in Little Falls, N.Y. He was 80.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: SHARING BOOKS Laura Bush arrived in Moscow on the second leg of her five-day trip to France and Russia. At a Kremlin discussion with, from right above, the Russian first lady, Lyudmila Putin, and their counterparts from Armenia, Bella Kocharian, and Bulgaria, Zorka Purvanov, Mrs. Bush, a former school librarian, talked about American values found in children's books. "American children's literature is a way to teach values that people in our country share — and people around the world share — values that have to do with living a good life and being a good person," she said. She passed around books that she said were important to her and her family. They included "Little House in the Big Woods," about pioneer life, "Amazing Grace," about a black girl who overcomes race and gender stereotypes, and "Hop on Pop," which she said her daughters used to act out by bouncing on their father.    (Reuters)

title: Butterflied If Not Free
description: FROM the perspectives of tenderness, flavor and economy, there really is no better cut of meat for serving a small crowd than boneless leg of lamb. And now that supermarkets regularly stock it, there is no need to visit a skilled butcher to get one; happily, we can add ease to its list of attributes.

title: Sports of The Times; For the Twins, a Victory That Goes Beyond Dollars and Cents
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago, George Steinbrenner watched the Yankees suffer a lopsided loss to the Boston Red Sox and delivered this gem: ''One acorn does not a fall make.'' But some losses make your jaw drop, and some make believers of doubters.

title: PHARMOS DRUG TO RECEIVE ACCELERATED F.D.A. REVIEW
description: The Pharmos Corporation said the Food and Drug Administration granted ''fast track'' status to its experimental medicine that mimics the effect of marijuana to treat head trauma. The status will speed the application process for the drug, called dexanabinol, which is now in the last of three stages of testing usually required for approval. The drug is similar to marijuana's central ingredient, tetrahydrocannabinol, without the euphoric mental effects, Pharmos said. Pharmos, which is based in Iselin, N.J., is seeking to enter a market for treating brain injuries that it said may be worth more than $500 million a year. Stock in Pharmos rose 52 cents, to $2.53.

title: Aioli in Five Garlic-Tweaking Flavors
description: Homestead View Farm, an organic grower in Gansevoort, N.Y., has introduced five alluring aiolis in its Saratoga Garlic line. In addition to the plain (but forceful) variety, there are curry, green mustard (wasabi), saffron and sambal (chili) flavors. Any would enhance a sandwich, a seafood stew, a plate of cold shellfish or an array of grilled vegetables. The aiolis, in 6.5-ounce jars, are $5.99 each at Fairway markets. A Web site, www.saratogagarlic.com, provides more information and recipes.

title: Corrections
description: A pop/jazz listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for a Highlights in Jazz concert by the Billy Taylor and Cyrus Chestnut Trios tomorrow misstated the location in Manhattan and the telephone number. The place is the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, 199 Chambers Street, not the Pace Downtown Theater. The number is (212) 220-1460.

title: Blair Is Conciliatory, but Firm on War Stand
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair said on Tuesday that he had no question that his decision to go to war in Iraq was right, and he asserted he would do it again in the same circumstances.

title: A Failure of Logic And Logistics
description: THE federal No Child Left Behind law of 2002 may go down in history as the most unpopular piece of education legislation ever created. It has been criticized for setting impossibly high standards -- that every child in America must be proficient in reading and math by 2014 -- while providing meager financing, as President Bush has budgeted billions less than what the law allows.

title: Muslim Workers Claim Bias at the Plaza
description: They say that they were told, ''Don't blow up the building,'' and ''Muslim terrorists are all the same.'' One was kicked, they say, and several were not called by their given names but were instead referred to as ''Osama'' or ''bin Laden.''

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Glass That Turns Every Wine Into Noir
description: At blind wine tastings, the bottles are covered, but the taster has only to look in the glass to see if the wine is red, white or ros. And variations in color can tip off a taster as to whether the wine is young or aged.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Unemployment Down, Spending Up
description: Japan's unemployment rate fell to a two-year low of 5.1 percent in August as more people stopped looking for work, the government statistics agency reported. The labor force fell by 310,000, reflecting a labor market that is still stagnant, but the jobless rate fell because those who stopped looking for work were not counted as unemployed. Another measure of the economy improved, however, as spending by households headed by a salaried worker grew 2.2 percent in August. The increase came largely as a result of a big decline in spending in July. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBLIN, GERSON D.
description: LUBLIN--Gerson D. (1908-2003.) Died peacefully September 29th at Jewish Home and Hospital. Loving father and grandfather. 1928 Yale graduate, Wall Street partner, WWII veteran, musical scholar, tennis and chess player. Your wit, wisdom & goodness will be cherished forever.

title: Photographer's Brilliant Solos, Inspired by the Dance
description: Rare is the photographer who looks at a familiar art form and shows it in a new light. But Sherif Sonbol, a 46-year-old Egyptian whose stunning and revelatory dance photographs are on view at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center through Oct. 18, has a particularly agile eye.

title: $16 Million Is Pledged To Renovate Tully Hall
description: Lincoln Center has received a $16 million grant from the Alice Tully Foundation toward the renovation of Alice Tully Hall, the center's prime stage for chamber music and jazz. The gift, announced yesterday, is the largest so far by a private donor for Lincoln Center's redevelopment project.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARTIN, CLIFFORD J.
description: MARTIN--Clifford J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Clifford J. Martin, associated with The Times from May 1967 until retiring in August 1985.

title: Consumer Confidence Slips To Its Lowest Since March
description: Consumer confidence fell to a six-month low in September as the economy's failure to generate jobs raised questions about whether the expansion can be sustained, a report showed yesterday.

title: Welcoming Autumn Jar by Jar
description: THERE is something about this time of year, with summer gone and fall not yet truly upon us, that makes me want to bustle about the kitchen canning and preserving and setting aside all manner of good things for the harsh months ahead.

title: Man Menaces 2 S.I. Girls
description: A man tried unsuccessfully to grab two girls on their way to school on Staten Island yesterday, the police said.

title: Washington Talk; New Hands Grip Reins, But Budget Won't Budge
description: When Congress got tied up in knots last year over its annual spending bills and failed in one of its most basic duties, Republicans were aghast.

title: Five Reasons the Jets Are 0-4 (There Could Be a Lot More)
description: In a season gone awry, the Jets could probably point to 50 moments that sent them to their 0-4 start.

title: Stewart's Reach Exceeds Grasp of Yanks Fans
description: When the ball soared off Hideki Matsui's bat toward the left-field wall in the ninth inning, Ron Gardenhire, the Twins' manager, did not even bother to peek out from the third-base dugout.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Economic Growth
description: Brazil's gross domestic product totaled 366.7 billion reais ($125 billion) in the second quarter, growing 6.5 percent over the first three months, the government statistics institute IBGE said. According to the data, the economy's performance in the first half of the year was 14 percent better than the first half of 2002, totaling 711 billion reais ($240 billion). The figures were the first good economic news that the government of President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva has received since taking office in January. The government had to raise interest rates to more than 26 percent early in the year to stifle inflation, and that move depressed economic activity and increased the jobless rate. But in recent weeks, the central bank has relaxed its tight policy and its president, Henrique Meirelles, left, predicted yesterday that Brazil's base rate, currently at 20 percent, would fall further in coming months, helping to spur the economy. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Former Banker At Credit Suisse Will Take Stand, His Lawyer Says
description: Frank P. Quattrone, a former Silicon Valley investment banker at Credit Suisse First Boston, will testify in his own defense, his lead lawyer said yesterday.

title: Edward Said's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little More Ceci and Cela Underfoot and Overhead
description: Carine Tontini has turned a side interest, ceramics, into a career.

title: Off the Color Wheel
description: As decorative styles change, so do wall colors.

title: A Sense of Old New York
description: As the Fulton Fish Market prepares to move, will grit give way to gentrification?

title: A Remote Control for Every Occasion
description: When it comes to remote controls, who's really in control?

title: Picturing History
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STARK, FLORENCE FORMERLY FRIEDLANDER
description: STARK--Florence formerly Friedlander. On September 30, 2003 in her 91st year. Beloved wife of the late Max Stark and the late Harold Friedlander. Devoted mother of Toby Friedlander Perlman and mother-in-law of Itzhak. Loving grandmother of Noah and Stephanie, Navah and Robert, Leora and Meredith, Rami, and Ariella. Cherished great-grandmother of Laila and Aviva. Services Thursday 12:45 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Three Missed Opportunities For Defense to Play Trump
description: Textbooks on the game often focus on the situations in which the declarer draws trumps. They say little, however, about the defenders' need to do likewise. On the diagramed deal, West had a chronic allergy to playing trumps, and it proved fatal.

title: Buyers Cash In on Offers to Keep Car Sales Strong
description: September auto sales slowed from August but continued to show strength, surprising analysts.

title: Loud Tables, but Not a Restaurant
description: The mighty roar of 20 metal tables dragged across the floor is heard not throughout the land but at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where William Forsythe's splendid dancers in Ballett Frankfurt are staging the grandest of all finales this week. As the dancers race to the rear of the stage, pulling five rows of tables whose legs scrape and bounce on a flat surface, the program ends with a high-decibel screech.

title: Human Genome Placed on Chip; Biotech Rivals Put It Up for Sale
description: The genome on a chip has arrived.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: OFFICIALS SAY BUSH SEEKS $600 MILLION TO HUNT IRAQ ARMS
description: The Bush administration is seeking more than $600 million from Congress to continue the hunt for conclusive evidence that Saddam Hussein's government had an illegal weapons program, officials said Wednesday.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC To Pay $1.35 Million Penalty
description: SBC Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to pay a $1.35 million penalty to resolve an investigation into whether the company sold long-distance service in states where it was not yet permitted. Under a settlement with the Federal Communications Commission, SBC will revise training and compliance programs and alter some computer systems, the F.C.C. said in a statement. SBC, based in San Antonio, which will make the payment to the Treasury, did not admit any violation or liability as part of the agreement. SBC, which said the incidents were inadvertent, had five types of potential violations, like providing long-distance connections in California for some customers before receiving F.C.C. approval last December. In October 2002, the F.C.C. fined the company $6 million for not giving rivals access to its local network as required in five Midwest states. Shares of SBC rose 35 cents, to $22.60.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurance Executive Named
description: The Royal and SunAlliance Insurance Group, a British insurer, named John Tighe as chief executive of its United States unit. Mr. Tighe will succeed Steve Mulready, who will complete the company's sale of the majority of the renewal rights of its United States insurance to the Travelers Property Casualty Corporation, Royal and Sun said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 23 about international concern over Iran's nuclear programs misidentified the delegate to the International Atomic Energy Agency who said that country would meet the obligations of the nuclear nonproliferation treaty. The delegate, Ali Akbar Salehi, represents Iran, not Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BORITZER, ROSE
description: BORITZER -- Rose. The Schwartzberg family mourns the passing of our dear friend Rose Bortizer. Rose was a cherished friend of the family, as well as a longtime trusted partner. Rose was a respected leader in the Long Term Care industry of New York for over 40 years and set the standard for honesty, hard work and innovation during her career. Rose was a precious friend, through the good times, the hard times, she was always there for her friends and family. Her impact on our family will be felt for generations. We had many exciting adventures with Rose and Arno over the years, and for those great memories we are very thankful. She was a human being that has had a positive impact on all whose lives she touched. She will be sorely missed.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the leaking of an undercover C.I.A. officer's name reversed the identities of two White House aides in some editions. Karl Rove, President Bush's senior adviser and political strategist, whose responsibility for the leak was denied by the White House, was at the right. Scott McClellan, the White House spokesman, was at left.

Though their performances were not flawless, they were major successes. Not since the days of Birgit Nilsson and Jon Vickers had two singers sung the roles so excitingly.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Torricelli Accuser Released
description: David Chang, the New Jersey businessman whose campaign donations and lavish gifts to Senator Robert G. Torricelli helped drive the senator from office, completed his 18-month prison term yesterday and was freed. Mr. Chang begins a two-year period of probation. After pleading guilty to funneling $53,700 in illegal contributions to Mr. Torricelli's 1996 campaign, Mr. Chang told prosecutors he had also given cash and gifts to the senator. While some bank records and other documents corroborated several of Mr. Chang's accusations, federal prosecutors did not seek an indictment of Mr. Torricelli, saying that Mr. Chang had too many credibility problems. Nonetheless, in October 2002, Mr. Torricelli ended his campaign for re-election, saying that the questions about Mr. Chang prevented him from discussing other issues. David Kocieniewski (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: U.S. Warning On Rebels
description: The United States is ''very, very concerned'' about links between Jemaah Islamiyah, Al Qaeda's Southeast Asia affiliate, and a Muslim rebel group, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front, a secessionist movement in Mindanao, in the south, the American ambassador, Francis Ricciardone, said. He warned that the links could jeopardize millions of dollars in American aid to Mindanao, home to most of the Muslim population in the mainly Roman Catholic country. Western and Philippine intelligence officials say the Moro rebels have provided training grounds for Jemaah Islamiyah, which has been tied to the nightclub bombings that killed more than 200 people last year on the Indonesian island of Bali. ''The U.S. will not provide economic development assistance in areas controlled by the M.I.L.F. if that organization maintains its ties with outlaws and terrorists,'' Mr. Ricciardone said. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

RMC, the world's largest maker of ready-mix concrete, confirmed the approach.

title: A Building With a Song in Its Heart
description: Some great buildings allow you silence. Others give you song. The new McCormick Tribune Campus Center in Chicago got my fingers snapping. On my visit this weekend before Tuesday's dedication, the Goo Goo Dolls were playing on the building's sound system. But another track was playing inside my head: a bouncy 2002 lounge tune by Joseph Malik with a silly lyric that goes, ''You oughta take it all in and check it all out.''

title: Masters of the Household Universe
description: MOST remote control owners will recognize the tedious stick-shifting that is often required to play a DVD: first, pick up the cable remote and click On. Next, do the same with the remotes for the TV, the DVD player and the stereo, assuming you want full surround sound. Now grab the TV remote and switch to DVD input, then -- you're almost there -- go back to the DVD remote, navigate through the menu, and hit Play.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Traffic-Reduction Plan Set
description: City and state officials announced a one-year pilot program yesterday to reduce congestion and pollution in Astoria by allowing trucks to use part of the Grand Central Parkway from which they are now banned. The program, which will begin Nov. 17, allows trucks to use a nearly one-mile stretch of the parkway between the Triborough Bridge and the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. Trucks crossing the bridge are now forced to exit on Hoyt Avenue and use local streets. The program is expected to reduce the number of trucks on Hoyt Avenue, 29th Street and Astoria Boulevard by as much as 70 percent. Winnie Hu (NYT)

And while established figures like Marc Newson, who has just designed a line of cookware for the French manufacturer Tefal, could be expected there, it was particularly rewarding to see small design houses with a more personal perspective. Each rating point equals 1.08 million television households.

Bush, "was not involved."

description: In what is believed to be a first for a public college, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill announced on Wednesday that it would cover the full costs of an education for students from families of the working poor without forcing the students to take on loans.

description: With the Rangers having gone a franchise-record six seasons in a row without a playoff berth, could this be a make-or-break season for Glen Sather, the team's president, general manager and coach?

description: YONKERS, Oct. 1 — Saying he did not want to spoil the Republican Party's chance to retain the leadership of this slowly rebounding city, State Assemblyman Michael J. Spano announced on Wednesday that he would withdraw from the race for mayor.

title: Limbaugh Resigns From ESPN's N.F.L. Show
description: Rush Limbaugh resigned last night from ESPN's ''Sunday NFL Countdown'' three days after he made race-related comments about how the news media view the Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Donovan McNabb.

title: National Briefing | Politics: A Nod For Gephardt
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, one of 10 Democratic presidential candidates, won the endorsement of the Amalgamated Transit Union as he continued his drive to win support from individual unions one day after failing to win the early backing of the powerful A.F.L.-C.I.O. With 15 unions endorsing him, Mr. Gephardt has more labor backing than any other presidential contender. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: TWO SKETCHES IN MURDER CASE The police yesterday released sketches of two men, one slender and the other heavyset, wanted in the killing of Matthew Hall, 18, a Hunter College sophomore who was fatally shot in the back last week. The sketches were based on the description of a witness who saw two men running from the scene, a police official said. The witness told detectives that one of the men, who was depicted in the sketch wearing a dark baseball cap, had a gun in his hand, an investigator said. The police said the man who was wearing the hat was a black man, about 19 to 22 years old, 5-foot-10, weighing 150 to 160 pounds. The first man also wore a a sweater with orange, white and black stripes and blue jeans. The second man, a black man 20 to 22 years old, was about 5-foot-11 and 220 to 230 pounds. He had a crew cut and was wearing blue jeans, a black hooded sweatshirt with a red T-shirt underneath, black and white beads around his neck. The police asked anyone with information to call the Crimestoppers hot line at 1-800-577-TIPS (1-800-577-8477).

title: Organizers Encouraged By Attendance Numbers
description: Attendance at Women's World Cup games has fallen drastically from 1999, when the event was also held in the United States. But this year, soccer officials say, figures do not tell the story.

title: Jets' Abraham Is Arrested After Accident
description: John Abraham, the Jets' Pro Bowl defensive end, was arrested early this morning and charged with driving while intoxicated after he was involved in an automobile accident in Baldwin, N.Y., the police said.

title: Game Controller With a Screen Resolves the TV Turf Battles
description: For as long as there have been game consoles, there has been the need for a TV set to use them with. But Hip Gear, a company that makes game controllers and accessories, has now eliminated that requirement with its Hip Screenpad, a controller with a built-in screen.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Tim Offers Live-TV Handset Service
description: The push by European mobile phone companies to tempt clients with new services took a step forward yesterday as Telecom Italia Mobile, known as TIM, said subscribers with some of the latest handsets could begin watching live television. TIM is the first company in the world to offer the service, which is free until January. Until now the closest thing to live television on a mobile phone has been the possibility to download short video files, like newscasts or sports highlights.To keep revenue growing TIM and its rivals need new services because it has become nearly impossible to add subscribers in the saturated European market. Nonvoice services, like text messaging, already account for 10 percent of TIM's revenue and Marco De Benedetti, the chief executive, said yesterday that he expected that to double in three years.

title: British are conquering Milan's 'golden triangle'
description: MILAN  For years, Milan's Via della Spiga, Via Sant' Andrea and Via Montenapoleone, in an area otherwise known as the "golden triangle," was dominated by premium Italian luxury brands.

title: U.S. Troops Battle Guerrillas in Sunni Muslim Area of Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 2  American troops traded shots with guerrillas in a firefight this afternoon near the center of Falluja, a town about 30 miles west of Baghdad, witnesses said.

title: Parking-Lot Etiquette For the Wireless Keyboard
description: Some wireless devices are like rude houseguests, always interfering with other gadgets under the same roof. But Apple's new cordless keyboard and mouse are models of decorum, discreetly taking the measure of their environment and bending over backward not to get in the way.

title: A Newspaper's Cuban Revolt
description: The idea of censoring the Cuban dictator Fidel Castro -- who regularly silences journalists and tortures dissenters in his own country -- may sound appealing to some, but when it is done by an American newspaper, the effect is unsettling. That is what happened in New York, where El Diario/La Prensa -- the oldest Spanish-language daily newspaper in the United States -- killed a column it had sought from Mr. Castro.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett Wins $500 Million Army Pact
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, the world's second-biggest computer maker, has won a United States Army order valued at as much as $500 million for computers and services. The three-year contract began yesterday and the company will supply equipment including desktop, notebook and server computers and printers and related services, the company said on its Web site. The order includes networking equipment made by Cisco Systems Inc. The Army awarded the contract under a program to integrate various computer systems. The $70 billion market for supplying computer systems and services to governments is expanding three times faster than the information-technology industry as a whole, Ann Livermore, Hewlett-Packard's executive vice president for services, said in July. Hewlett-Packard has sold products to the military for more than 60 years. Hewlett-Packard shares rose 24 cents, to $19.60.

description: The Parliament dealt Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi an unexpected setback that suggested dissent within the ranks of his governing coalition. description: ROME, October 2  A prominent European cardinal today described Pope John Paul II as "dying" and said that the pope was "approaching the last days and months of his life."

title: Architect Named For Hall of Fame At Jazz Center
description: A hall of fame planned for Jazz at Lincoln Center in the new AOL Time Warner headquarters will be designed by David Rockwell, responsible for the look of the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles, the restaurant Nobu in New York and the hit Broadway show ''Hairspray,'' center officials say.

title: 15 Years Later, Pushing to Clear His Name in Murder of Parents
description: Fifteen years ago, Arlene Tankleff was slashed across the throat and bludgeoned to death, and her husband, Seymour, was mortally wounded in the middle of the night in their affluent Long Island home. Their son, Martin, 17, confessed, then recanted. But in 1990 he was convicted of their murders in a highly publicized trial that was featured on Court TV.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBERTS, DONNIE

Adored grandson of Marie. Also survived by many other loving relatives and friends. Funeral services Friday, 9:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Entombment to follow at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations in Donnie's name may be made to City Meals on Wheels, 355 Lexington Ave., New York, NY 10017, 212-687-1234.

title: Assessments Say Iraq Needs $55 Billion for Rebuilding
description: A team of economic specialists led by the World Bank and the United Nations has determined that Iraq needs $36 billion for reconstruction over the next four years. This would be in addition to a separate assessment by the American-led occupation of $19 billion for a different set of needs in Iraq over the same period, diplomats and economists said Wednesday.

description: The judge in the federal trial of Frank P. Quattrone, the former Silicon Valley investment banker, declined yesterday to allow defense lawyers to use a document that they said would undermine some of the government's evidence.

The Yankees must do that again to get rid of the Minnesota Twins, the hard-charging underdog that never stopped nipping them in a 3-1 defeat in Game 1.

description: This 30-second advertisement, titled ''Trouble,'' began broadcasting statewide on Tuesday. It was produced and paid for by Californians for Schwarzenegger, one of two committees supporting Arnold Schwarzenegger.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Chemical Companies Fined
description: The European Commission fined four chemical companies a total of 138.4 million euros ($161 million) for participating in a cartel that fixed the price of sorbates, a food additive, over 17 years ending in 1996. Hoechst of Germany was singled out as the ringleader and fined 99 million euros. The others were all Japanese: Chisso, Daicel Chemical Industries, Nippon Synthetic Chemical Industry and Ueno Fine Chemicals Industry. Chisso was granted immunity from fines for blowing the whistle on the cartel. ''Because of this conspiracy, European consumers paid more for many everyday products than if the companies had competed against each other,'' the competition commissioner, Mario Monti, said. Hoechst is a unit of Aventis of France. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: 3rd Death Sentence Handed Down in Bali Case
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 2  An Indonesian court today sentenced to death an Islamic religious teacher accused of overall responsibility for the Bali terrorist attack, which killed 202 people.

title: A School for New Dutch Masters
description: THE best international design used to be Italian, from the Brionvega television of the 1960's to the sleek Cappellini sofas and Boffi kitchens of the last decade. But increasingly it is Dutch product designers who are making waves -- especially students from a school in the southern Netherlands called Design Academy Eindhoven, which employs an unusual academic curriculum to create an education that values both the highly conceptual and eminently practical. Corporations are taking notice, recent graduates are seeing their furniture represented by prominent manufacturers and students are enrolling from all over the world, including the United States. Murray Moss, who owns Moss, a design store in Manhattan, called Eindhoven ''without question, currently the best design academy in the world.''

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cirrus Shares Surge On Sales News
description: Shares of Cirrus Logic Inc., which makes chips for DVD and MP3 players, rose as much as 15 percent after the company said yesterday that second-quarter sales met the top of its forecast and that it had settled a patent lawsuit. The company had forecast $45 million to $50 million in sales in the quarter ended Saturday. Sales totaled $73.3 million a year earlier. The company, based in Austin, Tex., reports full results on Oct. 22. Sales of new chips for DVD recorders helped results, while customers pared inventory and returned to ''more normal buying patterns,'' the Cirrus vice president, Kirk Patterson, told an investor conference in Austin. Shares of Cirrus rose 59 cents, or 10.7 percent, to $6.11. They rose as high as $6.35 and had gained 92 percent this year. ATI Technologies Inc., the world's second-biggest maker of computer-graphics chips, will pay $7 million to Cirrus, after expenses, to settle a patent-infringement lawsuit. Shares of ATI sold in the United States rose 96 cents, or 6.7 percent, to $15.82. ATI is based in Markham, Ontario.
