description: MOST electric vehicles work by connecting the wheels to a motor. But tomorrow a Dutch company plans to unveil a bus in which motor and wheel are one, a refinement that promises more miles per charge and a vehicle that is safer and easier to maintain.

title: Party Meeting Shows Wider Split Between Blair and Rival
description: This week's annual Labor Party conference has seen bonds being re-established between Prime Minister Tony Blair and his restive party members, but it has also seen the distance grow between Mr. Blair and his chief rival for power, the chancellor of the exchequer, Gordon Brown.

title: Sports of The Times; U.S.-Norway: Excellence With an Edge
description: IT was hard to tell that this was the classic rivalry of women's soccer. You had to know that Norway still holds a slight edge over the United States.

title: U.S. Offers Revised Blueprint For Multinational Iraq Force
description: The United States circulated new revisions on Wednesday to Security Council envoys for a draft resolution that would authorize a multinational force in Iraq.

title: A Clerk Is Accused Of a Racist Threat
description: A clerk at the city's Board of Elections was accused this week of leaving a threatening racist message for a black manager who is the wife of City Councilman Bill Perkins, police and city officials said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Escape Leads To Suspensions
description: A police officer and a sergeant were suspended without pay yesterday, a day after a prisoner escaped from a Queens courthouse, the police said. Officer Quang Dao and Sgt. John Vitale were suspended after Kamar Thomas-Reid, 20, who was arrested for trespassing, claimed he was another prisoner, who was about to be released. When the other prisoner's name was called, Officer Dao presented Mr. Thomas-Reid to Sgt. Vitale without the proper paperwork, the police said. Mr. Thomas-Reid was then released. He was recaptured at 7:40 a.m. yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Althea Gibson, the first black competitor in the United State tennis nationals and the winner of five Grand Slam titles, gave an incorrect surname for the first black player in a United States Lawn Tennis Association title event. He was Dr. Reginald Weir, not Benjamin.

title: The Unmet Needs of Motherhood Bring Out the Entrepreneurial Spirit
description: A new wave of professional women is leveraging pregnancy into business opportunity.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   STEINHORN, HARRIET
description: STEINHORN--Harriet. Grammy, we miss you so much. Forever in our hearts. Amy, Brad, Alex, Jason, Eva

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Plane Deal Near
description: Embraer and its Chinese partner said they might sign their first sales contract for their small jetliner with Chinese carriers by the end of this month. The Harbin Embraer Aircraft Industry Company, a venture of the Brazilian company and the AviChina Industry and Technology Company, was set up last year to make 37-50-seat ERJ145 planes in the northeastern Chinese city of Harbin. ''We're close to signing contracts with buyers from China's big three airline groupings,'' an AviChina vice president, Li Yao, said. ''We have entered into the final phase of discussions.''

title: Cisco Agrees To Suspend Patent Suit For 6 Months
description: Cisco Systems Inc. said on Wednesday that it had agreed to suspend its patent infringement lawsuit against Huawei Technologies, a Chinese maker of telecommunications and network equipment.

title: The Difference Between Movies and Music
description: You cant pick up a newspaper without reading about the escalating battle between music companies and their customers. The recording industry believes that its decline in CD sales stems primarily from music pirates who download songs from the Internet. All kinds of loopy behavior has resulted, including lawsuits against everyone from 12-year-old girls to 80-year-old grandmothers.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Cuts 700 From Services Unit
description: I.B.M. laid off about 700 workers in the United States from the company's services business, its largest and fastest-growing unit. The workers were notified of the cuts yesterday, a spokesman, James Sciales, said. They will be given 30 days to find other jobs with the company. The cuts represent less than 1 percent of the work force of 180,000 at the services unit. I.B.M. said less than a week ago that it would cut 400 workers at its software division. The company in August announced plans to layoff 600 workers in its chip-making business and furlough another 3,000. I.B.M. employs about 315,000 workers in 160 countries. The services unit, which runs corporate computer networks, had $36.4 billion in sales last year.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: NEW HAVEN: NEW JURY IN CORRUPTION TRIAL A new jury was selected yesterday in the federal corruption trial of Ben F. Andrews, a former Republican candidate for secretary of the state and a civil rights activist. One member of the new jury lists his race as "other"; the rest are white. The trial is scheduled to begin Oct. 14 in United States District Court in New Haven. The trial had been scheduled to begin Sept. 15, but Judge Ellen Bree Burns dismissed the jury, which was all white. Mr. Andrews is black. Judge Burns, while not explicitly ruling on the racial composition of the jury, ordered a new one impaneled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOFTUS, ROBERT M.
description: LOFTUS--Robert M. in his 84th year, Bob died peacefully on September 29, 2003. Born in Brooklyn, Bob was a longtime resident of Stewart Manor, NY. Beloved husband of the late Eileen, loving father of Kathleen Ryan, Carol Walsh and Robert Loftus Jr. He is survived by his loving sister Patricia O'Neill, seven grandchildren, three great grandchildren, and five nieces and nephews. A graduate of St. John's University, Bob retired after 35 years from Asiatic Petroleum. Friends may call Friday 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Homes, Floral Park Chapel, 29 Atlantic Avenue. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered on Saturday 9:30 AM at St. Anne's R.C. Church in Garden City. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: Wambach's Goal Sends U.S. to Semis
description: It became evident early Wednesday night that United States versus Norway would be a familiar game of muscle and determination, of ferocious tackling and rough jostling for balls in the air, of ceaseless pressure and hard running, a match defined by effort, not elegance.

title: Where a Fresh-Caught Fish Is the Best Neighbor
description: THERE are several ways to consider the fish smell that hangs over the stone-paved streets by the Fulton Fish Market in Lower Manhattan. One is as a seasonal calendar, its pungency changing with the tides and temperature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RACHELSON, GERTRUDE HIRSCHHORN
description: RACHELSON--Gertrude Hirschhorn. On October 1, 2003 at age 93. Beloved widow of Morris Rachelson, mother of Carol Goldstein and Dr. Herbert Rachelson, motherin-law of Eli and Rosemary. Cherished grandmother of Linda and Alan Sherman; Steven and Sharon Goldstein; Simon, Joshua and Joanna Rachelson; and great-grand mother of Lauren and Emily. Services on Sunday, Mount Ararat Cemetery.

title: Chinese Girls' Toil Brings Pain, Not Riches
description: Each eyelash was assembled from 464 inch-long strands of human hair, delicately placed in a crisscross pattern on a thin strip of transparent glue. Completing a pair often took an hour. Even with 14-hour shifts most girls could not produce enough for a modest bonus.

title: Mets May Make Pitch To Wallace After Playoffs
description: Look for the Mets to make another run at Dave Wallace, the Boston Red Sox' interim pitching coach, once the postseason ends.

title: The Poetry Is in the Glow
description: The Maison et Objet home design show, in Paris last month, is considered one of Europe's most important. And while established figures like Marc Newson, who has just designed a line of cookware for the French manufacturer Tefal, could be expected there, it was particularly rewarding to see small design houses with a more personal perspective. Many of the artisans below began in other fields and only later found their way into making pillows, tiles, pottery and lighting fixtures.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Water Utility Acquired
description: Macquarie Bank Ltd., Australia's only publicly traded investment bank, bought the British water unit of the French company Bouygues for 386 million ($642 million). The unit, South East Water, will be transferred to Macquarie's new European Infrastructure Fund, which seeks to raise as much as a billion euros to invest in European utilities, roads and railways, Jim Craig, managing director of the fund, said. Macquarie will also assume 40 million of debt.

title: The Columnist and the Disclosure
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FIDELITY INVESTMENTS, Boston, the largest mutual fund company in the United States, said it had acquired the HR Access unit from I.B.M. Corp., Armonk, N.Y., to get software that runs human resources departments. About 200 I.B.M. workers will transfer to Fidelity. Terms were not disclosed.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: GARBAGE STRIKE IN CHICAGO More than 3,000 trash haulers have gone on strike, leaving the Chicago area's large apartment buildings, commercial and industrial complexes without garbage pickup. The strike affects all of Cook County, including Chicago and its inner suburbs, as well as Lake and McHenry Counties and parts of DuPage County. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: TENET EXECUTIVE RETIRES AFTER SECOND TERM
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that its executive vice chairman, Michael H. Focht, who rejoined the company in January, retired again. Mr. Focht, 61, first retired in 1999 after 20 years with Tenet and a predecessor company. He was asked to return by Tenet's board this year, with the company saying at the time that Mr. Focht would stay a year or two. Tenet is under investigation by federal authorities after disclosing in November that it used price increases to bring in higher Medicare payments for some patients. The former chief executive, Jeffrey Barbakow, quit in May, and the company's top lawyer, Christi Sulzbach, announced her resignation last week. Tenet is based in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: A Mother in Touch With Her Inner Elf
description: BROWNIE Troop No.1973 held its first meeting the other day.

title: Officials Expect Party Leader to Be Indicted
description: The Brooklyn district attorney's office has decided that it has enough evidence to pursue criminal charges against State Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., the Brooklyn Democratic leader whose personal finances and role in the selection of judges have been under investigation for months, according to lawyers and others involved in the case.

title: Braves' DeRosa Is Latest Surprise Hero
description: The Atlanta Braves reclaimed their ballpark and reclaimed some respect Wednesday night. They did it with one unlikely event after another in a 5-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs in Game 2 of their National League division series.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Tasting the Foie Gras, Listening to the Jam; Fine Restaurants Are Adding D.J.'s
description: It was 10:42 p.m. at the new fusion of night life and fine dining in Manhattan, and Steven Travolta-DuPlantier, the D.J., was spinning, matching and blending in his booth. He segued from the midtempo ''I Got Somebody New'' by George Levin to the mellow warmth of ''A Little Deeper'' by Ms. Dynamite.

title: Senate Talks Stall On Ending Program For Tobacco Farms
description: Senate negotiations over a proposal to give the Food and Drug Administration authority to regulate tobacco broke down on Wednesday, lawmakers said, jeopardizing a plan to end a Depression-era program of price supports for tobacco farmers.

title: Schwarzenegger Lays Out Agenda for First 100 Days
description: Buoyed by a surge in the polls, Arnold Schwarzenegger acted on Wednesday as if he had already made the transition from campaigning to governing, confidently outlining his plan for the first 100 days of his administration.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: 6,000 Apply To Be Bear Hunters
description: More than 6,000 hunters applied for the state-sanctioned bear hunt in December, enough to help reduce the swelling bear population, officials said yesterday. It is the state's first bear hunt since 1970. Only licensed hunters who have previously received firearms-safety instruction are eligible. About 6,300 hunters applied by Tuesday's deadline, fewer than the 10,000 permits available for the six-day hunt, said Martin J. McHugh, director of the division of fish and wildlife. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: TV's Intense Glare Makes the Odd California Campaign Seem Even Odder
description: The television barrage intensifies in the early evening but never lets up all that much -- a dawn-to-dusk blur of unfiltered promises, denunciations, spin and counterspin.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Candidate Withdraws
description: Saying he did not want to spoil the Republican Party's chance to retain leadership of the city, State Assemblyman Michael J. Spano announced yesterday that he would withdraw from the race for mayor. ''In a city with 44,000 registered Democrats and 24,000 registered Republicans, if you have a split like this, it almost guarantees that a Democrat would be elected,'' said Mr. Spano, who was running as the Conservative and Independent candidate. Phil Amicone, the deputy mayor for eight years, won the Republican endorsement last month after a bitter primary race against Mr. Spano. It is too late for Mr. Spano's name to be removed from the ballot. Mr. Spano urged his supporters to vote for Mr. Amicone. The Democratic mayoral candidate is Joe L. Farmer. Debra West (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Aid Repayment Late
description: The European Commission is taking France to the European Court of Justice for failing to reclaim 450 million euros ($525 million) in rescue aid it handed out to Bull, a struggling French computer company. The commission initially permitted the rescue aid on the condition that the amount was repaid by June 17 this year. The competition commissioner, Mario Monti, described France's failure to meet the deadline as ''a grave violation of state aid rules.'' Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Ex-Trader at Hedge Fund Pleads Guilty to Securities Fraud
description: Aformer hedge fund trader pleaded guilty this afternoon to securities fraud in the New York State attorney general's widening investigation of the mutual fund industry.

title: After 0-2 Fall, Auburn Runs To Recovery
description: Throughout August, the Auburn Tigers insisted that their egos would not swell at the sight of the university's name back in the preseason top 10. But the junior quarterback Jason Campbell admitted recently that some of the Tigers paid more attention to polls than to details.

title: MetroStars Earn Chance for First Title
description: The MetroStars will play for the first championship in their eight-year history after a 3-2 victory over D.C. United in the semifinals of the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup on Wednesday night at Yurcak Field at Rutgers. They will face the Chicago Fire for the title on Oct. 15 at Giants Stadium.

title: Banks Cut From Suit By Enron Pensions
description: Citigroup, J. P. Morgan Chase & Company and other banks sued by the Enron employee pension funds for reportedly helping the energy trader misstate its finances have been dismissed from the $3 billion lawsuit by a federal judge, a lawyer for the workers said.

title: Athletics' Zito Had Tough Act To Follow
description: Cy Young to sayonara? Not exactly. Barry Zito, the Cy Young award winner last season, is no Sparky Lyle, the former Yankees reliever for whom Graig Nettles coined that phrase in 1978 after Lyle was supplanted by Rich Gossage and traded to the Texas Rangers.

title: Actors Closer On Pay Agreement
description: A tentative pay agreement for actors in television and radio commercials has moved a step closer to final approval, as the boards of the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists voted to recommend the deal to their members for a vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENNETT, JAY I.
description: BENNETT--Jay I. On September 30, 2003 at age 77. Adoring husband of Madeleine of 53 years. Devoted and loving father of Bonnie and cherished grandfather of Lily. He was a true confidante, advisor and trusted friend. Jay enjoyed life and people to the fullest. He devoted over half a century to Revlon, where he played a major management role from the company's modest beginnings to its huge success. He will be greatly missed and forever warmly remembered. Funeral service Thursday, October 2, 2003 at 9AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Trade Surplus Surges
description: With exports to China surging, South Korea posted a trade surplus of $2.6 billion last month, its largest in five years, the government said. The surplus was triple that of September a year ago, as exports rose 24 percent, to $17.2 billion. Leading the list of exports were mobile communications equipment, semiconductors, computers and automobiles. Exports to China exceeded those to the United States, which typically had been South Korea's largest export market, for a second consecutive month. Despite the strong exports, South Korea's economy, which fell into recession in the first half, remains sluggish and the government expects its annual growth rate to remain below 3 percent this year. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: Mourning Starts Nets Career
description: It was a day to introduce the latest edition of the Nets, the first chance for the entire roster to get together and state why this season will be different. It certainly had a different meaning for Alonzo Mourning, who may be the biggest difference in this franchise since Jason Kidd arrived.

title: Brooklyn Judge Is Reprimanded on Use of Funds
description: A Brooklyn judge has been reprimanded for misusing thousands of dollars he had raised for his election campaign, state authorities announced yesterday.

title: An Automated Secretary Keeps Computers in Sync
description: As computer prices have fallen, it has become easier for some people to own more than one. But having, say, a desktop machine and a laptop is not always convenient. Keeping important files and lists updated and synchronized on more than one computer can be a trying task.

title: Shakespeare's Prince Hal, Told Without Emotion
description: Falstaff's belly is, as usual, certifiably round, though worn lower on the midriff than usual, suggesting a woman in the last weeks of pregnancy. Everything else in Richard Maxwell's interpretation of Shakespeare's ''Henry IV, Part One'' -- the opening production in this year's Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music -- is relentessly, numbingly flat.

title: The Columnist and the Disclosure
description: To the Editor:

title: A Beefy Toney Weighs In
description: James Toney, looking as if he were still enjoying the products of the Ann Arbor, Mich., bakery he worked in while growing up, weighed in at 217 pounds yesterday, only two pounds lighter than Evander Holyfield for their 12-round pay-per-view heavyweight bout tomorrow night at the Mandalay Bay Events Center in Las Vegas. Toney weighed 190 pounds in his most recent fight, when he won the International Boxing Federation cruiserweight title on April 26. Holyfield, his usually rippled self, was one pound lighter than he was for his last fight, a 12-round loss on points to Chris Byrd last Dec. 15.

title: ART: A RUBENS RETURNED
description: Valued at $92 million, the stolen 17th-century Rubens masterwork ''Tarquinius and Lucretia'' has been confiscated by the authorities in Russia at the request of the German government after a dealer offered it for sale. The oil painting, depicting the imminent rape of a Roman citizen's wife by a king's son, was stolen from the Sanssouci Palace in Potsdam, outside Berlin, apparently by a Red Army officer in the confusion in 1945 at the end of World War II. Hartmut Dorgerloh, the director of the museum at Sanssouci, expressed hope that when Chancellor Gerhard Schrder of Germany and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meet this month, they would agree on the return of the painting to Germany. ''Tarquinius and Lucretia'' was last displayed at Sanssouci in 1942. KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: Corrections
description: A review on Sept. 20 about a performance by the soul singer Joss Stone at Joe's Pub, in Manhattan, misspelled the surname of a singer in the band. She is Gwen McCrae, not McRae.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEIT, SOL
description: LEIT--Sol. 1927-1992. Happy birthday. We think of you today and every day. Lovingly, Bobbie and family.

title: Man Rescued At South Pole Plans to Stay Close to Home
description: The ailing American worker whose evacuation from the South Pole was delayed for almost a week because of dangerous winds and snow said Tuesday that his medical ordeal had prompted him to stay closer to home, at least for a while.

title: Siebel Systems Picks Venables, Bell
description: Siebel Systems, the business software company, said yesterday that it had named Venables, Bell & Partners in San Francisco as the worldwide agency of record to handle its account.

title: A New Function For a Landmark Of the Jet Age
description: IN its expressively sculptural forms -- roof vaults that embraced travelers like sheltering bird wings, swooping walkways that propelled them to waiting jetliners -- Eero Saarinen's Trans World Airlines terminal at Kennedy Airport was meant to be a prelude to flight.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Soccer Deal Investigated
description: The Euro-pean Commission is poised to investigate BskyB and the English Premier League's $1.7 billion, three-year contract to broadcast live soccer, Mario Monti, the competition commissioner, said Wednesday. The deal, struck last month, will give BskyB ''an even greater monopoly'' over broadcasting of top-level live English soccer matches than the satellite channel has had until now, Mr. Monti said. BskyB, the British satellite company owned by Rupert Murdoch, above, has dominated Premier League soccer broadcasting since 1992. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: The Columnist and the Disclosure
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: SBC TO PAY $1.35 MILLION PENALTY SBC Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to pay a $1.35 million penalty to resolve an investigation into whether the company sold long-distance service in states where it was not yet permitted. Under a settlement with the Federal Communications Commission, SBC will revise training and compliance programs and alter some computer systems, the F.C.C. said in a statement. SBC, based in San Antonio, which will make the payment to the Treasury, did not admit any violation or liability as part of the agreement. SBC, which said the incidents were inadvertent, had five types of potential violations, like providing long-distance connections in California for some customers before receiving F.C.C. approval last December. In October 2002, the F.C.C. fined the company $6 million for not giving rivals access to its local network as required in five Midwest states. Shares of SBC rose 35 cents, to $22.60. (Bloomberg News)

title: To Rest and Dream Boldly
description: The Maison et Objet home design show, in Paris last month, is considered one of Europe's most important. And while established figures like Marc Newson, who has just designed a line of cookware for the French manufacturer Tefal, could be expected there, it was particularly rewarding to see small design houses with a more personal perspective. Many of the artisans below began in other fields and only later found their way into making pillows, tiles, pottery and lighting fixtures.

title: Mozart's Tale Of Delusions About Love
description: Bedlam in opera. For even casual observers, the link is clear: opera is crazy both onstage and off. Many composers have explicitly worked madness into their scores, from Donizetti (''Lucia di Lammermoor'') to Stravinsky (the final scene of ''The Rake's Progress'' is set in Bedlam itself). And some directors have brought seemingly sane works into madhouse settings. I will never forget a production a few years ago that placed Handel's ''Messiah'' in a lunatic asylum. I wish I could forget it, but I can't.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Education page yesterday with an article about the University of California's ban on romantic relationships between professors and their students misidentified the campus where a critic of the policy, Virginia Griffey, is an undergraduate. It is Berkeley, not Los Angeles.

title: Van Gundy's Chance For More Misery
description: Moments after his first practice as coach of the Houston Rockets on Tuesday, Jeff Van Gundy had a flashback. He thought he was back at Purchase College, surrounded by a horde of ravenous reporters dying to fill the newspapers with imagery of him as the grim and gloomy taskmaster who coached the Knicks.

title: Limbaugh Quits Job On Pregame Show
description: Rush Limbaugh resigned his position with ESPN's National Football League pregame television show, three days after making race-related comments about how the news media view Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Donovan McNabb.

title: Worth a Detour Off the Color Wheel
description: AS decorative styles change, so do wall colors. Walls lighten and darken, shifting from stark white to linen white to darker, more intense colors -- and back again. But these days, there are unexpected deviations from the standard paint store color wheel. It is now possible to paint a wall metallic copper, gold or silver with water-soluble latex. For modernists, there is a range of paints reproduced from the colors ordered by the architect Le Corbusier, who specified color details in his otherwise all-white houses. A textured wall can also add interest to a room, and some textures come right out of a paint can. Once you think beyond linen white, the possibilities are endless.

title: Stores of Dreams: More Value and Service (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Irving Sloan, Grocery Executive And Philanthropist, Dies at 88
description: Irving Sloan, a retired supermarket executive and a philanthropist with a special concern for the handicapped, died on Monday at Beth Israel North hospital in Manhattan. He was 88 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Predict the Future? You Can Bet on It
description: THE off-again, on-again recall election in California hasn't been easy on politicians and voters in that state. It hasn't been too easy on Gavin Peters, either, even though he lives 2,500 miles away in Toronto.

title: Indonesian Bank Agency Fading Out
description: After dominating Indonesia's financial landscape for almost six years, the Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency is plotting its own extinction, selling all it can of its vast holdings and preparing to close a difficult chapter in this nation's economic life.

title: DANA FORMS JOINT VENTURE WITH DONGFENG IN CHINA
description: The Dana Corporation, a maker of axles for light trucks, said yesterday that it would form a joint venture with the Dongfeng Motor Company to create the largest maker of axles and components in China. The venture with Dongfeng follows another partnership with the company to build gaskets in China, said a spokesman for Dana, Jeff Cole. The new venture will build axles for both Dongfeng, based in Xiangfan and one of the largest makers of trucks and buses in China, and for Dana, based in Toledo, Ohio, Dana said.

title: Dayne Resembles Miami's Williams in Number Only
description: Wearing the No. 34 that has terrorized opposing defenses this season, the former Heisman Trophy winner took on the Giants' defense Wednesday. He had only mixed success. He dropped a few passes. He was stuffed at the line once or twice. He broke a few.

title: Wambachs Goal Sends U.S. to Semis
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Oct. 1 - It became evident early Wednesday night that United States versus Norway would be a familiar game of muscle and determination, of ferocious tackling and rough jostling for balls in the air, of ceaseless pressure and hard running, a match defined by effort, not elegance.

title: Aggressive Running On Bases Lifts Twins
description: Maybe to everyone else, it looked risky and audacious, even reckless. But Minnesota Twins shortstop Cristian Guzman dashed from first to third base on a single to left field in Game 1 of the American League division series on Tuesday because this is how the Twins have played (and won, mostly) for three months.

title: Exxon May Offer $25 Billion for 40% of Yukos
description: ExxonMobil is in talks about taking a stake worth as much as $25bn in Russia's premier oil group in what would be easily the largest deal in the country's fast-restructuring energy sector.

title: Dark, Handsome And Short; Star of a Sundance Hit Is Ready for an Encore
description: All eyes are on Peter Dinklage's body at the beginning of the film ''The Station Agent.'' But then, inevitably, the eyes are drawn to the face. Surrounded by lush, dark curly hair, it is quite handsome, the brow strong, the eyes large and blue. It registers pain, loneliness, resignation and also cheekiness, flirtatiousness, a mischievous humor. Mr. Dinklage speaks very little in the film. All he needs is the face, and the panoply of human emotion seems to wash across it effortlessly.

title: What's in a Name?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fierce Debate Is Expected Over Nominee
description: When the Senate Judiciary Committee votes Thursday on the nomination of Charles W. Pickering Sr. to be a federal appeals court judge, there will be little doubt that the Republican majority will approve him and send the nomination to the Senate floor.

title: When 'Do Not Call' Means Do Not Call
description: To the Editor:

title: Firms tune in to private equity
description: MILAN  Private equity is the flavor of the season in Italy as luxury goods companies discover an alternative source of finance at a time when the outlook for capital markets remains uncertain.

title: Murder Case Defendant Is Called Delusional
description: Last summer, prosecutors announced that they would seek the death penalty against Larry Smith, a Brooklyn man charged with stabbing his pregnant fiance to death and drowning her 6-year-old son in a bathtub. Prosecutors say the murderous rage was set off when the boy spilled a bottle of bubble-blowing fluid.

title: Iraqi Civilians Caught in Crossfire of Guerrilla War
description: Friday, Sept. 12, was much the same as most days here.

title: Software For Media Moguls
description: IN ''The Terminator,'' Arnold Schwarzenegger is an unstoppable machine. In the climactic battle sequence, he is blown up, incinerated and mutilated, yet he keeps on coming. Eventually, there's nothing left of him but a silver robotic skeleton that just doesn't know when to quit.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Senate Panel Endorses Tax Break on Foreign Profits

title: National Briefing: New England
description: NEW HAMPSHIRE: 20,000 ON THE WAY TO `LIVE FREE' A group of libertarians announced a project to get 20,000 Americans to move to New Hampshire and work to transform it into a "free state" with fewer laws, smaller government and greater liberty. New Hampshire, whose motto is "Live Free or Die," beat out nine other finalists for the Free State Project. Wyoming was runner-up in voting by 5,000 members of the project nationwide. The 5,000 members have promised to move to the selected state, and the project hopes to increase its numbers in the state to 20,000 within two years. (AP)

title: Pataki Choice For Judgeship Is Assailed
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's choice for a federal judgeship in Brooklyn came under harsh attack Wednesday, amid disclosures that she was ''gratuitously rude'' toward lawyers during her years as a trial judge and even screamed and threw objects at them.

title: Manufacturing Expands Again
description: Manufacturing expanded for a third month in September, driven by the strongest growth in orders this year, an industry report showed yesterday.

title: Market Place; Another Firm Under Inquiry Fires Workers
description: Prudential Securities has joined a growing number of financial services companies that are rapidly responding to a widening investigation of mutual fund trading practices by firing or suspending employees.

The strike affects all of Cook County, including Chicago and its inner suburbs, as well as Lake and McHenry Counties and parts of DuPage County. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   APFEL, IKE
description: APFEL--Ike. 6/1/52 to 10/2/92. It's been 11 years. Pain never goes away. Always loving you, always missing you. Love, Mom

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Tuesday about New Bridge Strategies, a consulting firm with close ties to President Bush that advises companies on doing business in Iraq, misidentified the publication that first reported its formation. The report was in National Journal, a weekly magazine of government and politics, not The Hill, a Congressional newspaper.

title: Economic Scene; The economic plan for Iraq seems long on ideology, short on common sense.
description: IRAQ'S new finance minister, Kamel al-Gailani, announced a sweeping liberalization of his country's economy at the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund in Dubai early last week. Amid the controversy over President Bush's request for $87 billion to finance the American presence in Iraq, the new laws hardly attracted attention in the United States.

title: Williams Prepared To Carry Dolphins
description: He wears a dark-tinted covering on his face mask, giving him a sinister Darth Vader look, and dreadlocks spill from the back of his helmet. He is a sculpted 225 pounds, about 10 pounds less than last season. This is the look of the N.F.L.'s defending rushing champion.

title: INVERNESS EXPANDS WITH PURCHASE FROM ABBOTT LABS
description: Inverness Medical Innovations Inc., a maker of fertility testing kits for women, paid Abbott Laboratories $92.5 million to gain rapid pregnancy tests and products used to detect drug abuse. Abbott will receive $55 million in cash and 1.55 million Inverness shares for its assets, the chief executive of Inverness, Ron Zwanziger, said yesterday. The purchase includes the Fact Plus, TestPack and Signify diagnostic lines, he said. Mr. Zwanziger is expanding the company's product line through acquisitions in a bid to return Inverness, which is based in Waltham, Mass., to profit after a net loss last year.

title: Corrections
description: An architecture review on Tuesday about the new football stadium at Soldier Field in Chicago misidentified the headquarters city for one designer, Ben Wood; it is Boston, where he is a partner with the other designer, Carlos Zapata -- not Chicago. The review also misstated the timing of the decision to rebuild the original stadium. It was in 1998, not the early 1990's.

title: Unearthing the Past, Then Burying It With Respect
description: DR. SHERRILL D. WILSON had a grandson born on Sunday morning -- her third grandchild -- but she has not yet had the chance to meet him.

title: So, That's the Way The Cookies Crumble
description: In these days of worms, Trojan horse attachments and other security threats delivered through the Internet, the personal computer can seem like a medieval castle under siege. Fireball CyberProtection Suite from Red Cannon Security offers several weapons for the defense arsenal so you will not have to dig a moat around your desk.

title: Knicks Cautious on McDyess
description: Antonio McDyess will be on the court today when the other Knicks veterans report for training camp, although he will be off to the side shooting for 20 minutes in noncontact drills. The Knicks will be conservative in bringing him back. He will be able to walk through plays with his teammates, he will continue to run in a pool for 20 minutes and he will gradually increase his activity.

title: White House Looks to Manage Fallout Over C.I.A. Leak Inquiry
description: The Bush administration pursued a two-track political strategy on Wednesday to minimize the damage from the criminal investigation into the disclosure of a C.I.A. officer's identity.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: State Minister Wounded In Attack
description: The chief minister of the southern state of Andhra Pradesh, N. Chandrababu Naidu, was wounded when a series of explosives detonated under his convoy. Mr. Naidu suffered a fractured hand and minor injuries to the collar bone, chest and face when the land mines went off as he was en route to visit a temple. Four others were wounded. Police officials said they suspected the Peoples' War Group, which has been waging a left-wing insurgency in the state. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Iran Names Panel on Nuclear Inspections
description: Iran has appointed a five-member team to decide the country's policy toward an Oct. 31 deadline that the United Nations nuclear agency has set for it to permit closer inspection of its nuclear activities, the daily newspaper Entekhab reported Wednesday.

title: Think Small in Iraq
description: American soldiers in Iraq are frustrated by the small guerrilla units that attack convoys and patrols before fading away into the woodwork. Yet the Americans, persisting in operating from highly visible bases, seem to have ignored a tremendous geographical advantage they hold over the insurgents -- one that Egyptian security forces used to suppress attacks by Al Gamaa al Islamiyya, or the Islamic Group, in the 1990's.

title: Yankees' Hopes Rest With Pettitte
description: Andy Pettitte carefully navigated his car off the Harlem River Drive for his first trip into Manhattan as a member of the Yankees eight years ago. It was an important night and a nervous night for Pettitte, who followed his teammate Sterling Hitchcock's vehicle so closely that they almost touched bumpers. The country kid was finally and warily taking a nibble of the big city.

title: Ghosts of Playoffs Past Follow Red Sox to Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 2 - This was supposed to be a different Red Sox team, unburdened by the franchise's heartbreaking failures of postseasons past. But, for one night, at least, the end was frighteningly familiar.

title: Burnett President Leaves in Shake-Up
description: The top-level shake-up at Leo Burnett Worldwide in Chicago, a division of the Publicis Groupe that has been struggling to renew its growth, is continuing with the departure of Robert C. Brennan, president since January 2001.

title: Teenage Violinist With a Mature Violin
description: Ah, those early teenage years with all that waiting to be old enough to drive, to stay out late, to be independent of parents, or in the case of the Japanese-born violinist Mayuko Kamio, to make your New York recital debut in knuckle-busting works by Saint-Sans, Ravel and others.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Sketches In Murder Case
description: The police yesterday released sketches of two men, one slender and the other heavyset, wanted in the killing of Matthew Hall, 18, a Hunter College sophomore who was fatally shot in the back last week. The sketches were based on the description of a witness who saw two men running from the scene, a police official said. The witness told detectives that one of the men, who was depicted in the sketch wearing a dark baseball cap, had a gun in his hand, an investigator said. The police said the man who was wearing the hat was a black man, about 19 to 22 years old, 5-foot-10, weighing 150 to 160 pounds. The first man also wore a a sweater with orange, white and black stripes and blue jeans. The second man, a black man 20 to 22 years old, was about 5-foot-11 and 220 to 230 pounds. He had a crew cut and was wearing blue jeans, a black hooded sweatshirt with a red T-shirt underneath, black and white beads around his neck. The police asked anyone with information to call the Crimestoppers hot line at 1-800-577-TIPS (1-800-577-8477). William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Jeb Bush Leads Re-election Team For Presidential Effort in Florida
description: Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida will serve as chairman of his brother's re-election campaign in the state, whose votes could prove crucial in the presidential election next fall.

title: J. M. Coetzee Wins Nobel Prize for Literature
description: PARIS, Oct. 2 — John Maxwell Coetzee, a widely acclaimed South African novelist who has often used his country's apartheid system and its post-apartheid transition to mirror the bleakness of the human condition, was awarded the 2003 Nobel Prize for literature today by the Swedish Academy in Stockholm.

title: When 'Do Not Call' Means Do Not Call
description: To the Editor:

title: In Setback to U.S., Judge Refuses to Drop Moussaoui Case
description: Afederal judge handed the United States government a huge setback today by ruling that prosecutors can not make any allegations that Zacarias Moussaoui was linked to the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Sports of The Times; Situational Pitching To Bonds Is Risky
description: BY the time Barry Bonds batted for the third time yesterday here at Pacific Bell Park, Marlins Manager Jack McKeon had attempted the strategy of pitching to the Giants' muscle man in the first inning, which failed when Bonds doubled in a run, and walking him in the fourth, which failed worse when Edgardo Alfonzo doubled home a pair.

title: Hope for New Vigor At European Bank
description: Next month, after years of waiting and wondering, Jean-Claude Trichet is to take the helm of the European Central Bank. He is not about to wallow in nostalgia during his final weeks in Paris.

title: British Energy In Agreement On Bailout
description: British Energy, Britain's biggest power generator, on Wednesday agreed with creditors on a 1.5 billion ($2.5 billion) government bailout and a plan to swap some debt for equity that will help the company avoid filing for bankruptcy protection.

title: Delivery Systems for Wordsmiths
description: WRITERS write with them and designers design with them but neither profession has paid much attention to the evolution of pens and pencils. Now comes ''Design in Hand: The Evolution of Writing Instruments Since 1784,'' a show opening on Sunday at the Providence Art Club in Rhode Island. The exhibition, with some 300 items cleverly deployed along a timeline, runs through Nov. 2, along with a show of pen drawings and a sale of collectible pens on Oct. 18.

title: Yankees to Change Lineup for Tonight
description: The Yankees will have a different lineup tonight for Game 2 of their division series against Minnesota. That could mean a change for Nick Johnson, who ended the season 0 for 17 and went 0 for 4 in Game 1.

title: National Briefing | Politics: Kerry Attacks Dean For Bush Pact
description: Senator John Kerry attacked the record of Howard Dean, a former governor of Vermont and fellow candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, saying he had struck a deal with George W. Bush in 1998, when Mr. Bush was governor of Texas, to ship Vermont's nuclear waste to a poor, mostly Hispanic community. In a campaign swing through Texas, Mr. Kerry criticized the 1998 compact, in which Vermont and Maine agreed to pay $25 million each to ship low-level nuclear waste to Sierra Blanca, Tex. Dr. Dean's campaign countered that the arrangement had been negotiated in the open and later approved by President Bill Clinton. Ultimately the plan was not carried through because Texas environmental officials said it was unsafe. David M. Halbfinger (NYT)

title: Cancn Trade Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New Castle: Inmate Charged In Kidnapping
description: When a 79-year-old woman returned home to Overlook Road about 3 p.m. yesterday, a man rushed out of her house, threatened her with a knife and demanded that she drive him to the Bronx, the police said. When she refused, the man, who was wearing a pair of her pants, then demanded that she take him to the Ossining train station, which she did. In the car he robbed her of $25 and told her he was an escaped prisoner. The Tarrytown police later stopped a southbound Metro North train and arrested Louis Cortalano, 42, an inmate at the Westchester County Jail who the authorities said had escaped from a work detail at the Hudson Hills Golf Course around noon. He was then turned over to New Castle police. Mr. Cortalano was charged with kidnapping, burglary, robbery and weapons charges. Other charges were pending, officials said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Senate Democrats Boycott Hearing on E.P.A. Nominee
description: Senate Democrats boycotted a committee hearing on Wednesday morning on President Bush's nomination of Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah to become administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, delaying a vote that would have moved it to the Senate floor.

title: Mix of Donors Adds to Dean Coffers
description: Howard Dean turned heads this week when he raised more money, almost $15 million, than his rivals for the second consecutive quarter. His performance can be attributed to a carefully planned strategy to maximize both small donors and traditional larger contributors.

title: Mother's Liability in Son's Suicide Is Debated, Then Jury Gets the Case
description: After hearing closing arguments, a jury began deliberations on Wednesday in the trial of a mother accused of being criminally negligent in the care of her 12-year-old son, who hanged himself in his bedroom closet.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a picture on Monday with an article about a coming exhibition of El Greco paintings was reproduced in mirror image. In the photograph, of the painting ''A Cardinal (probably Don Fernando Nio de Guevara),'' the brocade hanging should have appeared at the right.

title: Top of Lineup Spurs Comeback by Florida
description: After Juan Pierre, the Marlins' leadoff hitter, completed his first postseason game on Tuesday by going without a hit and failing to reach base for one of the few times this season, the veteran Lenny Harris approached him in the visitors' clubhouse at Pacific Bell Park and again at the team's hotel off Union Square. Harris, whom Florida acquired in August as a bench player and motivational speaker, reminded Pierre why he had been so successful over 162 games and wondered why he had tried to change for one game.

title: Americans Confidence In Bush Has Dropped, Poll Shows
description: The public's confidence in President Bush's ability to deal wisely with an international crisis has slid sharply over the past five months, and a clear majority of Americans are now uneasy about his ability to make the right decisions on the nation's economy, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 23 about international concern over Iran's nuclear programs misidentified the delegate to the International Atomic Energy Agency who said that country would meet the obligations of the nuclear nonproliferation treaty. The delegate, Ali Akbar Salehi, represents Iran, not Iraq.

title: Extreme Athletes in Search of a Fresh Soundtrack
description: DISNEY'S EXTREME SKATE ADVENTURE

title: DOVER BUYS WARN INDUSTRIES FOR $325 MILLION
description: The Dover Corporation, a maker of winches, gearboxes, hydraulic equipment and other industrial products, said yesterday that it had acquired a closely held maker of automotive parts, Warn Industries, for about $325 million in cash. Warn Industries makes winches for four-wheel drive vehicles and power-train systems for pickup trucks. The acquisition will add to earnings in 2004, Dover said. Warn Industries, based in Portland, Ore., has annual sales of more than $150 million. It will be a stand-alone company under the Dover Resources unit. Warn Industries has 550 employees. Dover, based in New York, had revenue of $4.2 billion last year and 25,000 employees.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Van Service For Disabled
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed legislation yesterday establishing the city's first livery service specifically for the 60,000 New Yorkers who use wheelchairs and motorized scooters. Beginning in two weeks, the livery service, called A Ride for All, will carry people in three minivans throughout the five boroughs. Dispatchers will take calls, in English and Spanish, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: The Columnist and the Disclosure
description: To the Editor:

title: Security Investigators Arrive at Guantnamo
description: Several military investigators arrived on Wednesday at the naval base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, with more to follow this week to examine security at the prison, which houses some 680 detainees, most of whom were captured in the Afghanistan war.

title: Inquiry Into Leak About C.I.A. Officer Is Said to Widen
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  The uproar over who disclosed the name of a Central Intelligence Agency officer to a newspaper columnist intensified in both a political and a bureaucratic sense, as three senators who are women denounced the leak as an affront to women and reports emerged that the federal investigation was widening.

title: F.D.A. Calls Counterfeit Drugs a Growing Threat
description: Counterfeit drugs made by criminals are a "growing threat" to American patients, the Food and Drug Administration warned today in a report that outlined ways government and industry could fight the problem, including the use of hidden tracking devices and markers.

title: From Maven to Outlaw: Evolution of 'Hacker'
description: Q. What is the difference between a ''hacker'' and a ''cracker''?

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: RWANDA: PRESIDENT'S PARTY VICTORIOUS President Paul Kagame's party, the Rwandan Patriotic Front, scored a decisive if predictable victory in parliamentary elections after a race bereft of significant participation by the main opposition. (Reuters)

title: Schwarzenegger Says Hes Behaved Badly and Apologizes
description: Responding to published accusations that he had sexually harassed several women before he entered politics, Arnold Schwarzenegger, the Republican front-runner in the California recall election, acknowledged today that he had behaved offensively at times in his past and apologized for it.

title: Analyst Reduces Ad Growth Estimate
description: The analyst who follows Madison Avenue for Merrill Lynch & Company, Lauren Rich Fine, has reduced her estimates for growth in advertising spending this year and next, partly because of lagging growth for local ads as well as ads appearing in newspapers.

title: Let Justice Take Its Course
description: The case is not yet a week old, but to some senators it is already compromised. They say the Justice Department should appoint a special counsel to investigate accusations that senior administration officials broke the law by revealing the identity of a covert C.I.A. officer. One senator has said he intends to reintroduce a version of the Independent Counsel Act, which expired in 1999.

title: Leaving Her Cultural Handprint on the Wall
description: The Maison et Objet home design show, in Paris last month, is considered one of Europe's most important. And while established figures like Marc Newson, who has just designed a line of cookware for the French manufacturer Tefal, could be expected there, it was particularly rewarding to see small design houses with a more personal perspective. Many of the artisans below began in other fields and only later found their way into making pillows, tiles, pottery and lighting fixtures.

title: North Korea Says It Is Using Plutonium to Make A-Bombs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 2 — With nuclear talks expected in weeks, North Korea said today that it had completed reprocessing 8,000 spent nuclear fuel rods and is using the plutonium to make atomic bombs.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: But, Soft! Yonder Is Thy Furnished Room

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a last-minute agreement to postpone a courtroom dispute over rent between the Bottom Line nightclub and its landlord, New York University, misspelled the surname of a lawyer for the university. He is Martin Meltzer, not Metzer.

title: ICN SELLS RADIATION DETECTION BUSINESS
description: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., which is shedding units to focus on drug research, sold a business that offers radiation-exposure detection services to a subsidiary of American Capital Strategies for $58 million. The Global Dosimetry Solutions unit of American Capital agreed to pay cash for the business and related properties and contracts, ICN said yesterday. The sale is one of the last steps in ICN's makeover, the chief executive, Robert W. O'Leary, said in a news release. ICN is based in Costa Mesa, Calif. American Capital, which is based in Bethesda, Md., invests in small- and medium-size businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POLLAK, RHEA
description: POLLAK--Rhea, 94, of Hallandale passed away September 29, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Loving mother of Penny and Jerry. Cherished grandmother of 8. Adored great-grandmother of 14. Contributions to Abe and Rhea Pollak Fund, C/O Federation Plaza, 3081 Taft St, Hollywood, FL 33021. Services were held in Florida.

title: Attorney General Is Closely Linked to Inquiry Figures
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  Deep political ties between top White House aides and Attorney General John Ashcroft have put him into a delicate position as the Justice Department begins a full investigation into whether administration officials illegally disclosed the name of an undercover C.I.A. officer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOSEPH, KORDELL, SHEL LEY
description: JOSEPH - KORDELL -- Shel ley. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the tragic and untimely death of Shelley Joseph - Kordell, beloved daughter of our dear friends, Burton Joseph, ADL Honorary National Chairman, and Amb. Geri Joseph, ADL Honorary Vice Chairman. Our hearts go out to Burt and Geri at this difficult time. We extend our sincere condolences to Shelley's husband, William ''Woody'' Grandstaff, her daughter, Jennifer, and the entire family. Glen A. Tobias National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: Sports Briefing
description: TENNIS

title: The Health Insurance Crisis
description: Even most experts were surprised by the sharp jump in the number of Americans lacking health insurance last year. The latest Census Bureau figures show that the number of uninsured jumped by 2.4 million, the largest increase in a decade, bringing the national total to 43.6 million uninsured in 2002, or 15.2 percent of the population. The ranks of the uninsured have increased by 10 percent over the past two years, with the likelihood that things may get worse this year.

title: Moss Replaces Conway As Jets Begin Shake-Up
description: The Jets' 0-4 start claimed its first victim Wednesday. Coach Herman Edwards benched wide receiver Curtis Conway, who dropped four passes in the last two games, and replaced him in the starting lineup with Santana Moss, a former first-round draft pick.

title: Hardships and Damage Linger After Hurricane
description: Hurricane Isabel was an equal-opportunity destroyer, flooding the houses, snapping the trees and cutting the power of rich and poor alike. But the lingering hardships imposed by the storm are not likely to be so democratic, officials from across the region say.

title: With Time Short, Boeing and Air Force Push Tanker Deal
description: With Congress coming up on its final weeks of lawmaking this year, Boeing and the Air Force are struggling to salvage a deal to lease as many as 100 tanker planes.

title: The Columnist and the Disclosure (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: In Manhattan, Another Burial For 400 Colonial-Era Blacks
description: The hole is dug. The crypts are ready to be filled. More than 400 hand-carved mahogany coffins, containing the skeletal remains of free and enslaved African-Americans, are sitting in a temperature-controlled room in Lower Manhattan.

title: Big Beasts, Tight Space And a Call For Change
description: Polar bears, lions, tigers, cheetahs and other wide-ranging carnivores do so poorly in captivity that zoos should either drastically improve their conditions or stop keeping them altogether, biologists from Oxford University report today in the journal Nature.

title: For the Stylish MP3 Player, A Sleek Protective Sleeve
description: The iPod from Apple Computer is a designer music player, and with the least expensive model running about $300, it has a designer price tag. To protect the player's sleek, scratchable exterior and the miniature hard-drive technology inside, Terforma has released a new case called the iSleeve.

title: McDyess May Return Sooner
description: After watching Antonio McDyess work out and rehabilitate at the team's practice facility recently, Knicks officials seem cautiously optimistic that his return from his third knee surgery could come sooner during the regular season.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 312 American service members who have died since the start of the war in Iraq. It confirmed the death of the following Americans on Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: Your Own Affair, More (VCR) or Less (MP3)
description: THE Internal Revenue Service is not used to hearing ''no.''

title: Military Practices Downing Hijacked Airliners, General Says
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  The United States military practices how to shoot down hijacked commercial airliners as often as three to four times a week, honing its defenses against terrorist attacks on American cities, a senior general said on Thursday.

title: Cover Story Kept Work For C.I.A. A Secret
description: Valerie Plame was among the small subset of Central Intelligence Agency officers who could not disguise their profession by telling friends that they worked for the United States government.

title: J.P. Morgan Settles Case Over I.P.O.'s
description: J. P. Morgan Securities, a subsidiary of J. P. Morgan Chase & Company, agreed yesterday to pay $25 million to settle regulatory charges that it illegally allotted shares in hot initial public offerings based on promises from customers to buy more shares later.

title: Man Who Quit Withholding Taxes Pleads Guilty
description: A Texas businessman who stopped withholding taxes from paychecks in 1999, making him a hero to the small but growing movement that contends most Americans are not required to pay taxes, has pleaded guilty to a felony tax charge.

title: City Says Closings Slow Fire Response In Six Areas
description: Firefighters are taking longer to respond to alarms in six neighborhoods where engine houses were closed this year because of budget cuts, but fire officials insisted yesterday that the impact on public safety was negligible.

title: J. M. Coetzee Wins Nobel Prize for Literature
description: PARIS, Oct. 2  John Maxwell Coetzee, a widely acclaimed South African novelist who has often used his country's apartheid system and its post-apartheid transition to mirror the bleakness of the human condition, was awarded the 2003 Nobel Prize for literature today by the Swedish Academy in Stockholm.

title: Hong Kong Panel Finds Little to Criticize in SARS Outbreak
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 2  An international panel of experts chosen by the government here announced today that it had found some shortcomings in the government's response to the outbreak here of SARS last spring, but praised the overall response and singled out no officials for criticism.

title: Hospitals Fail to Explain Aid Available to Poor, Report Says
description: Each year, New York's hospitals receive $847 million from Albany to offset the cost of caring for people who do not pay their bills -- usually the poor and uninsured.

title: White House Looks to Manage Fallout Over C.I.A. Leak Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 — The Bush administration pursued a two-track political strategy on Wednesday to minimize the damage from the criminal investigation into the disclosure of a C.I.A. officer's identity.

title: Blackouts? Edison Might Say, 'I Told You So'
description: THE immortals of electricity, in their shimmering Valhalla, must have had a pretty amusing couple of months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBLOOM, RITA
description: ROSENBLOOM -- Rita. On September 30, 2003, at the age of 87. Wife of the late Rabbi Jerome Rosenbloom. Loving and beloved mother of Jane and Charles Roberts, David and Deborah Rosenbloom, and Jonathan Rosenbloom and Peter Clark. Adored grandmother of Andrew, Amy, Leah, Sarah, Joshua, and Lila. Proud great-grandmother of Alexandra, Robert, and Ethan. Dear aunt of Barbara Charles. Graveside service will be private.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Campuses Move to Block Music Sharing
description: FOR those responsible for managing campus computer systems, file-sharing software like Napster and KaZaA has caused consternation for some time because of the huge amount of traffic it generates -- largely illicit music sharing -- and the resulting strain on their servers. Now that the record industry has gone on a legal offensive to stamp out music sharing, colleges and universities are clamping down even more vigorously.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It was the considered judgment of virtually every African-American I knew that they shouldn't have been disturbed in the first place.''

title: B. H. Kamenske, 75, A Ranking Official At Voice of America
description: Bernard H. Kamenske, former chief of the Voice of America's news operation, died on Sept. 25 in Bethesda, Md. He was 75 and lived in Bethesda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZARLIN, MARTIN
description: ZARLIN--Martin. Marty to his beloved wife, Carole of 45 years, Dad to his adoring children, Brad, and Debbie and Scott Edelman, Pop to his beloved grandchildren Rebecca and Zachary, and Dr. Z. to more than 40 years of dental patients. All will remember blue skys, sunny days, your kindness, your laughter and your steadfast smile. There was none who appreciated every moment more or who was more loved. His sudden passing leaves us all bereaved. Services Friday, 10:30AM, Temple Israel Center, 280 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains, N.Y. Donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Sponsors Ease Bill on Gases That Warm The Climate
description: The two senators who are sponsoring legislation to fight global warming announced on Wednesday that they would soften the bill to gain support for a vote expected this month.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Contraceptives For Rape Victims
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed a bill yesterday requiring hospitals to give emergency contraceptive pills to women who have been raped. The new law will require hospitals to tell victims of sexual assault about emergency contraceptives, and make them available at the hospital. Such contraceptives can prevent a pregnancy by stopping an egg from being fertilized or from attaching to the uterus. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

description:
By ANN FERRAR
Too many miles in the saddle? These products will help keep you on the road year-round.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Inquiry After Arrest
description: The police have arrested a man who they said tried to lure a 16-year-old girl into his car last night, and they are investigating whether or not he is responsible for two attempted abductions Tuesday morning. The girl was walking near Westcott and Victory Boulevard in Westerleigh about 7:30 p.m. when a man drove up and tried to get her into his car, said Police Officer Jennara Everleth. The girl ran away and called police, and the man fled. The man, who was not identified, was arrested a few blocks away, 35 minutes later, and the victim identified him, the police said. Charges were pending last night. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Parade of the Predators
description: SHARPIES, ospreys and other raptors -- the predators that include hawks, falcons and eagles -- are on the move, and their annual migration has birders tracking the North American sky in exotic places like Connecticut. Page 2.

title: The Brooklyn Does Europe
description: Degas's painting of Mademoiselle Fiocre in the ballet ''La Source,'' left, is among the works reinstalled in the Brooklyn Museum's renovated European Painting galleries.

title: Dolphins and Giants a Matchup of Strangers
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 2 - They are virtual strangers, even though they have belonged to the same league since 1970. But there is a respect factor involving the Giants and Dolphins, proud East Division teams in different conferences.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Carteret: Bus Fire Snarls Traffic
description: A burning Academy Bus Lines coach snarled traffic on the New Jersey Turnpike during the morning rush yesterday, disrupting traffic and causing it to be rerouted for nearly four hours. Bus company officials did not return repeated calls seeking details on the cause of the fire and the route of the bus. Traffic was slowed in the four lanes of the outer roadway truck lanes of the turnpike just south of Exit 13 near Carteret for more than five miles after the 7:50 a.m. fire. The driver was able to safely evacuate all the passengers from the bus, which was fully occupied. But it was not until 10:51 that the charred hulk of the bus was removed from the roadway and all lanes were reopened. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, RICHARD WADE
description: SMITH--Richard Wade. We mourn the death of our marvelous friend, Richard Wade Smith, who died suddenly on September 27. His generous spirit, his caring friendship and his sense of style enhanced all of our lives immeasurably. He will be deeply missed. Our heartfelt sympathy goes to Richard Redman Maxfield. A Memorial Service will be held at Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 64th Street, at 11AM on October 16. title: Russia and France Not Satisfied With U.S. Resolution on Iraq
description: PARIS, Oct. 3  Echoing questions raised on Thursday by Secretary General Kofi Annan, France and Russia reiterated today that they were not satisfied with the latest version of the United States resolution regarding Iraq's short-term political and military future.

title: City to Impose New Rules On Housing for Homeless
description: A program that shelters homeless families in private apartments and hotels violates city rules and will soon have to meet contract requirements similar to other city services, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday.

title: A Hungry Actor? Audrey II Is Back

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fugitive Sought In 2 Killings
description: The police were seeking a 25-year-old fugitive yesterday who they said strangled a Brooklyn man and who is also being sought for questioning by the police in Buffalo for a killing there. The police described the fugitive, Mickey Cass, as a drifter who had befriended the Brooklyn man, Vincent Neto-Dambrova, 27, and stuffed him into an apartment closet. Inspector Raymond Ferrari, the commander of Brooklyn detectives, said Mr. Cass fled to Miami after killing Mr. Neto-Dambrova, on Sept. 25 at 765 Coney Island Avenue in the Kensington neighborhood. Brooklyn detectives, along with the Miami police, were searching for Mr. Cass in the South Beach area of the city, he said. The police asked anyone with information about the crimes to call the Crimestoppers hot line at (800) 577-TIPS (800-577-8477).

title: Music More Interesting as It Becomes More Morose
description: Blame grunge. A decade ago, hearing a bunch of young bands going mainstream by stripping away hard rock's excesses was exciting: no more flashy guitar solos, no more flashy singing, no more flashy clothes. Inevitably, though, this style became just as ludicrous as the one it dethroned. Nowadays nth-generation neo-grunge bands embrace dreariness the way 1980's bands embraced flamboyance.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Merger
description: The French savings bank Caisse d'Epargne and the state-owned Caisse des Dpts et Consignations said they had signed a merger agreement to form France's third-largest bank behind BNP Paribas and Crdit Agricole. The new bank would have 18 billion euros ($21 billion) in assets and is expected to begin operating next summer. Under the agreement, Caisse d'Epargne will own 65 percent of the new bank, and will pay Caisse des Dpts about 3 billion euros ($3.5 billion) in cash. Ariane Bernard (NY)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WITKIND, RICHARD JULES
description: WITKIND -- Richard Jules. Born in New York City September 23, 1920. Graduate of Horace Mann School and the University of Virginia (1942), where he played goalie on the national champion lacrosse team. Joined the Navy and served as a gunnery officer on the battleship USS Arkansas in the Atlantic and Pacific. Present at D-Day providing support for the landing on Omaha Beach. Started his career in the securities industry at Bache & Co. and subsequently conducted his own business as a member of the New York Stock Exchange. In addition to his business interests, he was a limited partner in the New York Yankees baseball team. Moved from New York to the country (meaning Columbus, Ohio) in 1963. Likely the first to commute weekly by helicopter and plane from Wall Street to the Midwest (see Alvin Toffler's Future Shock). Always the consummate gentleman, he was a wellspring of arcane information, incisive observation and sophisticated whimsy. A beautiful bass speaking voice but no singing ability: his family laughed when he sang the Star Spangled Banner in either Yankee Stadium or Ohio Stadium (see Phyllis Greene's Moonglow). Preceded in death by wife, partner and fan of 45 years, Charlotte Lazarus Witkind. Also predeceased by sister Blanche Witkind Axelrod, brother Lloyd Myron Whitkind and first wife Gladys Butler Witkind. Survived by sons Robert Lazarus Gorman (Linda) and Donald Gorman (Lisal), daughters Babette T. Gorman and Vivian Witkind Davis (Jack), eight grandchildren and one great grandchild, as well as sisters - in - law, brothers - in law, nephews and nieces. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 970 Crupper Avenue, Columbus, Ohio 43229, or the Charlotte Lazarus Witkind Fund for the Celebration of Reading, Columbus School for Girls, 56 South Columbia Ave., Columbus, Ohio 43209. Family and friends will celebrate Dick's life at his and Char's home on Sunday, October 5, kicking off at 12:10 P.M. and ending at 3:00 P.M.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Beer Exports Rise
description: German beer exports rose by 5 percent in the first half of 2003 compared with the period last year, the federal statistics office said. The 140 million gallons exported were worth 363.1 million euros ($424.5 million). Italy was the biggest importer of German beer, followed by Britain, Spain, and France. Sales in the United States, Germany's largest market overseas, slumped by 0.8 percent, to 77.5 million euros ($90.6 million), but in Canada sales rose more than 3 percent, to 6 million euros ($7 million). Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Those Exotic Europeans And Their Curious Ways

Brooklyn owns some classy material in this area, from important Renaissance altarpieces to a clutch of smashing Monets. But most people come to the museum for other things, namely its holdings in what was once called ''ethnic'' art -- Egyptian, African, Meso-American -- which are very fine.

description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 3  The Israeli military has filed manslaughter charges against an army officer for enforcing a curfew by ordering the firing of tank shells and machine guns that killed four Palestinians, including three children, at an outdoor food market, the army said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sharp Forecasts Profit
description: The electronics maker Sharp Corporation expects to post an 18 percent profit increase for the first half of the current fiscal year, helped by strong sales of flat-panel televisions and mobile phones with cameras. Sharp said in a preliminary report that it earned 27 billion yen ($243 million) in the six-month period that ended Sept. 30, an 18 percent increase from the period a year ago. Its sales increased 12 percent, the company said. Sharp, plans to report full earnings figures on Oct. 29. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Art Technology Shares Plunge On Sales News
description: The Art Technology Group said yesterday that third-quarter sales fell at least 35 percent because customers delayed orders. The shares fell as much as 23 percent. Sales at Art Technology, based in Cambridge, Mass., fell to $15 million to $16 million, from $24.5 million a year earlier. Investors expected sales of about $20 million, the chief financial officer, Edward Terino, said in an interview. The loss widened to 5 cents to 7 cents a share, from 4 cents a year earlier. Shares fell 39 cents, or 18 percent, to $1.74 and dropped as low as $1.65. Art Technology's software helps companies process online orders and manage customer service both on and off the Internet.

South Beach seemed to have momentarily relocated to an oversized football stadium and the team owner Wayne Huizenga was thrusting a trophy in the air.

title: MEADWESTVACO IS BUYING DAY RUNNER FROM KAYSUN INC.
description: MeadWestvaco, the maker of Five Star and Cambridge notebooks for students, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Day Runner, the personal-organizer company. Terms were not disclosed. The purchase will be completed by the end of the year, MeadWestvaco said. Day Runner is a subsidiary of Kaysun Inc., a holding company. MeadWestvaco, based in Stamford, Conn., got about 15 percent of its $7.2 billion in sales last year from consumer and office products, with most of its revenue coming from packaging and paper. Day Runner, founded in 1980 and based in Fullerton, Calif., had its peak sales year in 1999, with revenue of $196 million. Kaysun bought the company in 2001.

title: ASTRAZENECA SAYS NEW DRUG IS OFF TO FAST START
description: AstraZeneca, the big European drug maker, said yesterday that its medicine Crestor had gained more than 2 percent of all new prescriptions for cholesterol-lowering medicines in the United States since it was introduced two weeks ago. Doctors have written about 25,000 prescriptions for Crestor, an AstraZeneca spokesman said. The announcement was made ahead of AstraZeneca's business review meeting today with analysts and investors in Wilmington, Del. The chief executive, Tom McKillop, is counting on Crestor and other new drugs, like Iressa for cancer, to help lift earnings as the company's Prilosec ulcer treatment loses sales to generic copies. Sales of Crestor may reach $3.6 billion a year, analysts said.

The southern end of Route 30 heading north out of Johnstown, N.Y., roughly 35 miles northwest of Albany, is no exception. The periodic views of the Sacandaga slipping over its rocky bottom, riffling over ledges or curving away mysteriously into the autumn canopy are lovely in the extreme.

Down below, eight hawkers in full plumage -- sunglasses, baseball caps and jeans -- glanced up and trained their expensive eyes -- Swarovskis, Leicas and Bausch & Lombs -- on the bird. ''A sharpie straight overhead,'' one called out.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Executive Resigns
description: The chairman of Crdit Lyonnais, Jean Peyrelevade, said he would step down immediately to defend himself against claims he was aware of wrongdoing related to the bank's purchase in the early 1990's of assets from a California insurance company, Executive Life. A federal prosecutor in the case ''seems to want to dissociate my personal case from that of the bank,'' Mr. Peyrelevade said in statement. Crdit Lyonnais and the French government reached a tentative agreement last month to pay $575 million to avoid criminal charges related to the Executive Life purchase. Prosecutors charged that the bank, which was then state-owned, violated laws preventing foreign banks from owning insurers.

title: Bush, in Midwest, Promotes Benefits of His Tax-Cut Policies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  Buoyed by the first increase in the nation's employment since January, President Bush campaigned in the Middle West today, where he declared that his tax-relief policies would lead the country out of government deficits and toward wider prosperity for the American people.

description: In ''The Station Agent'' a man named Fin settles into a remote outpost -- a rundown train depot in the wilds of New Jersey -- that is so restful it seems perfect for him. The movie's writer and director, Tom McCarthy, has such an appreciation for quiet that it occupies the same space as a character in this film, a delicate, thoughtful and often hilarious take on loneliness.

It was the first of several planned efforts by lawmakers of both parties to demand greater accountability from the Bush administration before approving its $87 billion spending request for Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Bush Cites Parts of Arms Report to Justify U.S. Action in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 — President Bush made a pointed defense today of his decision to make a pre-emptive strike against Iraq, a day after the government's chief weapons inspector reported that his team had failed to find illegal weapons in Iraq in its three-month search.

title: Houses Near National Forests: Forever Close to Nature
description: WHO -- Jack Cranley, 40, a lawyer in St. Louis
