description: Hollis Taggart Galleries

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: 5 FATAL SHOOTINGS IN A WEEK One man was killed and another wounded yesterday during the fifth fatal shooting in the city this week. In a written statement, the Hartford police chief, Bruce P. Marquis, said he believed that some of the shootings were related and that the people involved knew one another. Yesterday's shooting was reported about 3 a.m. at an after-hours club on Albany Avenue, the police said. (AP)

title: Big Pension Funds Object to Proposal On Proxy Rules
description: Managers of the nation's largest pension funds raised strong objections Thursday to rules proposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission that are meant to make it easier for shareholders to elect company directors. They called the rules a meaningless plan cloaked as meaningful reform.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: CROWDING OUT PLAYGROUNDS A new legislative report charged yesterday that many of the city's overcrowded elementary schools had installed temporary classrooms on playgrounds, without replacing the play areas. Assemblyman Jeffrey Klein and Councilwoman Eva S. Moskowitz, chairwoman of the council's education committee, called on state and city officials to enforce laws requiring access to adequate playgrounds. Jerry Russo, a spokesman for Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, said education officials were working to ensure access to both quality classrooms and recreation facilities, including playgrounds.    Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Shopping List | Biker Gear
description: ARE you born to be wild but achy or numb from too many miles in the saddle? These products will help ease -- from head to toe -- an uncomfortable ride and they'll help keep you on the road year-round. ANN FERRAR

title: A Host of Gay and Racial Ambiguities Ready for Your Decoding
description: There's a certain mystique about Nayland Blake. A big, bearded, tattooed bear of a man, he looks like an outlaw motorcycle gang member, but he exhibits regularly at Matthew Marks Gallery in Manhattan, where his stablemates include blue-chip artists like Ellsworth Kelly and Brice Marden, and he teaches at Bard College, where he heads the International Center of Photography/Bard College masters program in advanced photographic studies. People who know him say he is a generous and gifted teacher and an eloquent speaker. That he is gay and the son of a white mother and a black father is central to his art.

title: Theater Accessibility
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | West: California: Court Rules Against DNA Database
description: The federal government cannot insist that parolees provide a sample of their blood for a national DNA database maintained by the F.B.I., the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, ruled. The court said the requirement, in a 2000 law, is a violation of the Fourth Amendment prohibition against illegal searches. A dissenting judge said parolees had diminished privacy rights. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: INSIDE ART
description: The Legacy Of a Collector

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIMALOVER, JACK K.
description: RIMALOVER--Jack K. Of Princeton, New Jersey and Haven Beach, New Jersey on October 2, 2003. Former Vice President of Lenox Hill Hospital. Survived by his wife of 56 years, Betty H. Rimalover, 3 daughters, Joan Gardiner of Bainbridge Island, WA, Anne Jorgensen of Haddonfield, New Jersey, and Elizabeth Raschbaum also of Haddonfield and seven grandchildren & brother, Harold Rimalover of Englishtown, New Jersey. A celebration of his life will be held in Princeton, New Jersey on Sunday, October 5, 2003.

title: F.D.A. Outlines Plans to Counter Growing Trade in Counterfeit Pharmaceuticals
description: Counterfeit drugs made by criminals are a growing threat to American patients, the Food and Drug Administration warned yesterday. In a report, the agency outlined ways to fight the problem, including hidden tracking devices and markers.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Plea By Man With 2 'Wives'
description: A man who claimed two wives -- Kim and Lisa -- were missing and presumed dead after the Sept. 11 attack has pleaded guilty to stealing more than $70,000 in relief funds. The man, Mark Christopher, pleaded guilty this week to charges of theft by deception, identity theft and falsifying records. Mr. Christopher, who will be sentenced on Nov. 7, faces a maximum prison sentence of 20 years. According to the State Division of Criminal Justice, Mr. Christopher told the American Red Cross on Nov. 14, 2001, that his wife, Kim Christopher, was working in the World Trade Center during the attack. He documented his claim with a Maryland marriage license that had been issued to someone else, the State Division of Criminal Justice said. Using the pseudonym of Mark Palmerri, he also reported another wife, Lisa Palmerri, missing in applications between Sept. 11, 2001, and Jan. 9, 2002, to the Red Cross and the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Interest Rate Unchanged
description: The European Central Bank left its leading interest rate unchanged, as its president, Wim Duisenberg, expressed optimism that Europe's economy was finally on the mend. Speaking in Lisbon at his last rate-setting meeting before turning over the presidency to Jean-Claude Trichet, Mr. Duisenberg said he expected Europe's economy to show a "moderate pickup" in the second half of the year. He signaled that the current interest rate of 2 percent might remain in place for some time. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: XM Satellite Adds 237,395 Subscribers
description: XM Satellite Radio Holdings, the nation's biggest satellite radio service, said yesterday that it added 237,395 subscribers in the third quarter, bringing its subscriber base to 929,648. In a statement, Washington-based XM said the quarter's subscriber additions -- the highest in the company's history -- would allow it to reach 1.2 million subscribers at the end of the year and be ''cash-flow break even'' by the end of 2004. The end-of-quarter subscriber number was lower than the forecast made by at least one analyst, Steve J. Mather of Sanders Morris Harris. Mr. Mather, who has a hold rating on the shares and does not own any, expected XM to end the quarter with 950,000 subscribers. XM and the smaller Sirius Satellite Radio Inc. offer subscription services with better sound quality and fewer commercials than regular radio. XM charges $9.99 a month for its 101-channel service, with about 70 of the channels devoted to music. Customers need a special receiver and a satellite antenna. Shares of XM fell 6 cents, to $15.89.

title: Home Sweet Home
description: The Bush administration's tax experts are properly skeptical about an eye-popping new windfall Congress is trying to create for multinational American corporations that already escape taxes on billions of dollars they earn abroad.

title: Illuminating the Split Personality of White South Africans
description: I could live here forever, he thought, or till I die. Nothing would happen, every day would be the same as the day before, there would be nothing to say. The anxiety that belonged to the time on the road began to leave him. Sometimes, as he walked, he did not know whether he was awake or asleep. He could understand that people should have retreated here and fenced themselves in with miles and miles of silence. Life & Times of Michael K

title: A Reckoning: Iraq Arms Report Poses Test for Bush
description: The preliminary report delivered on Thursday by the chief arms inspector in Iraq forces the Bush administration to come face to face with this reality: that Saddam Hussein's armory appears to have been stuffed with precursors, potential weapons and bluffs, but that nothing found so far backs up administration claims that Mr. Hussein posed an imminent threat to the world.

title: Chewing Over Life and Shopping Bags
description: Tere O'Connor's new ''Lawn'' is a handsome-looking piece that mixes images of rolling green fields and forests and decayed urban sites, all caught on video by Ben Speth with exquisite, luminous clarity. Interjected into the flow, also on video, are a scene in which two dancers sit down to a meal of diced yellow shopping bags from Gristede's and a series of fleeting appearances by a grimacing, capering madwoman (Mr. O'Connor) who has a thing about the white handkerchiefs that float poetically through the sequences.

title: Men Betraying Women, Yet Again
description: Carlotta Sagna, whose powerful chamber piece, ''A,'' is at the Kitchen through tomorrow night, is one of the wittiest choreographers to emerge from the international community of artists that fills the Flemish dance and theater scene in Belgium. Originally a dancer, she came to notice in 1991 in Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker's ''Stella,'' a work to which ''A'' is distantly related.

title: Sports of The Times; In Rivera He Trusts, Torre Shows
description: IN Rivera we trust. Mariano Rivera. And only Mariano Rivera.

title: Lakers in Hawaii, Far From Paradise
description: Less than a week into the Los Angeles Lakers' training camp, the off-court distraction involving Kobe Bryant grows. Bryant, who was scheduled to arrive here on Thursday, surprised the Lakers by telling them he was feeling ''under the weather'' and would be delayed.

title: Fiat Is Said to Consider Austrian to Head Its Auto Unit
description: The Fiat Group of Italy is considering choosing Herbert Demel, an Austrian executive who once ran the Brazilian unit of Volkswagen, to replace the chief executive of its struggling auto unit, according to a person close to the deliberations.

title: Long Island Football Players Are Charged in Abuse Case
description: Three high school football players from Long Island were charged yesterday with a raft of felonies and misdemeanors stemming from allegations that they sexually abused three of their younger teammates at a preseason training camp in Pennsylvania.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business yesterday about the Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency referred incorrectly in some copies to the value of assets the agency has managed. It totals about 533 trillion rupiah (not billion) -- about $63.7 billion.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 2 Canadian Peacekeepers Die In Blast
description: Two Canadian peacekeepers were killed and three more wounded when their patrol vehicle hit a mine in Kabul, officials in Kabul and Ottawa said. The incident was believed to be an accident, but an investigation was under way. The soldiers who died were in the lead vehicle on a routine patrol. The vehicle veered off the road and hit the mine, a spokesman for the NATO-led International Security Assistance Force said. The deaths were the first for the Canadian peacekeepers and the first since NATO took command of the peacekeeping force in Kabul in August. Canada now has nearly 2,000 troops in Kabul, the largest contingent of the 5,500-member peacekeeping force. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: The Pushing and Pulling Of Black Quarterbacks
description: Each black quarterback in the National Football League at some point in his career has been encouraged to move from the position and use his athleticism at skilled spots like running back or wide receiver. Not one has failed to hear the cutting words that he is a better runner than he is a pure passer. Each one has faced his share of brutal jabs about reading defenses poorly, the inference being that black quarterbacks are not mentally up to the task.

title: Bryant's Accuser Won't Have to Testify
description: A judge ruled Thursday that the woman who accused Kobe Bryant of sexual assault would not have to testify at a preliminary hearing next Thursday.

title: Opposition in Chechen Vote Seen as Mainly Underground
description: Late at night, when the Russian soldiers have retreated for safety from the dark and empty streets, somebody is going around the city tearing down election posters that show the main candidate for president of Chechnya, Akhmad Kadyrov.

title: For Leader of Arms Hunt, Report Is a Test of Faith
description: In choosing David Kay last June to head the American weapons hunt in Iraq, George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, called him ''the ideal person'' for the job.

title: Criminal Investigators Focus on Russian Oil Company
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 3 -- Criminal investigators conducted a new round of searches today that focused on Russia's richest oil company, Yukos, a sign that the investigation that has shadowed the company since July is far from over.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lobster Restriction Rejected
description: The lobsters around Fishers Island at the eastern end of Long Island Sound might live in New York waters, but they are not really New Yorkers, and New York State cannot legally bar out-of-state fishermen from taking them, a federal appeals court ruled. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in affirming a lower court ruling, said a residency requirement for fishermen violated the Constitution's provisions of open commerce and equal protection. The suit challenging the ban on out-of-state fishermen was brought by a Connecticut woman, Vivian Volovar, who fishes off Mystic, Conn., and was joined by the Connecticut attorney general.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CUMULUS MEDIA, Atlanta, the radio chain, said it would enter the Kansas City, Mo., market by buying two radio stations from Syncom Radio and Allur-Kansas City for $25 million in cash or stock.

title: El Greco, Bearer Of Many Gifts
description: EL GRECO'S sainted status aside, Antonio Palomino, a Spaniard, had it right 300 years ago: ''We can define El Greco's art by saying that what he did well none did better, and that what he did badly none did worse.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLASER, STEVEN
description: GLASER--Steven. On October 1, 2003 at age 54. Son of the late Max and Sylvia Glaser. He is survived by his sister Dr. Ellen Glaser of CA, his nephews Daniel and Adam. You will always be in our hearts. Services on Sunday 10:30 AM at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. For information call ''The Riverside'', 1-800-448-1939.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUTTER, MAXWELL
description: MUTTER--Maxwell. October 1, 2003. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, greatgrandfather, brother and uncle. He was an accountant for 50+ years and Treasurer Emeritus of Shari Tfiloh. He was the happiness and strength of our family. Hellman Memorial Chapels, 15 State Street, Spring Valley, NY 10977; 845-356-8600.

title: What's On at the New York Film Festival
description: The 41st New York Film Festival, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, opens tonight and closes on Oct. 19. Most films are shown at Alice Tully Hall, except the late show tonight and the closing-night film, which will be shown at Avery Fisher Hall. All films were made this year, except for a restored and newly scored version of the 1929 film ''Piccadilly,'' one of those having special screenings at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center. The others are ''The Kids Are Alright'' (United States, 1979/2003), a documentary by Jeff Stein about the rock group the Who (tomorrow at midnight and Oct. 11 at 8 and 11 p.m.); ''The Best of Youth'' (Italy), a six-hour feature (originally a television mini-series) by Marco Tullio Giordana about 40 years of social and political change in Italy (Oct. 12 at 4 p.m.); and ''Stalingrad'' (Germany), a documentary about the World War II battle, by Sebastian Dehnhardt (Oct. 16 at 7:30 p.m.) Tickets to these are $15. Beginning tomorrow and running through Nov. 5 at Walter Reade will be ''Yasujiro Ozu: A Centennial Celebration,'' 22 films by the director; silent films will have piano accompaniment. Also at Walter Reade, on Oct. 18 and 19, will be ''Seven Views From the Avant-Garde,'' with films by Ken Jacob, Jonas Mekas and others. These Walter Reade screenings are $9.50; $7 for students; $5 for Film Society members; $4.50 for 65+ at weekday matinees. Box office: (212) 875-5600. Many festival screenings are sold out. Tickets: $15, except for tonight's screenings ($30); closing-night screenings ($17 and $30); and the Festival Centerpiece, ''The Fog of War'' ($20); available at the Tully Hall box office, (212) 875-5050. Some are scheduled for commercial release, with dates noted.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Inspectors Arrive
description: Inspectors from the United Nations nuclear agency began talks with Tehran about its nuclear programs. The agency has given Iran until Oct. 31 to convince it that the country is not trying to produce nuclear weapons. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES TO CLOSE PLANT, LAYING OFF 160
description: Interstate Bakeries, the maker of Wonder Bread and Hostess cakes, plans to close a bread and roll bakery in Grand Rapids, Mich., by Dec. 3 and lay off 160 workers. Production from the bakery, which prepares bread and rolls under the Wonder, Butternut and Home Pride brand names, will move to Interstate plants in Ohio and Indiana, the company said. Interstate had 34,000 employees as of May 31, according to a regulatory filing. It has been closing some bakeries and stores as it restructures operations amid declining demand. Interstate, based in Kansas City, Mo., is facing rising costs for employee pay and health care, energy and ingredients.

title: Dutch Grocer Tries for New Start With Write-Down
description: Royal Ahold, the Dutch food retailer, has written down its assets by 3.2 billion euros ($3.7 billion) using United States accounting principles, after improper accounting brought the company close to collapse.

title: Europe Ruling Could Reduce Power of Dominant Concerns
description: Paving the way to an important precedent in European competition law, a senior judge at the European Court of Justice said Thursday that IMS Health, the largest collector of pharmaceutical sales and prescription data in the world, might be abusing its dominant position by refusing to license the way it structures its information about the German market.

title: For Leader of Arms Hunt, Report Is a Test of Faith
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  In choosing David Kay last June to head the American weapons hunt in Iraq, George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, called him "the ideal person" for the job.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ROMANIA: CHILD BRIDE ORDERED HOME Child-protection authorities ordered a 12-year-old Gypsy girl and her 15-year-old husband to live apart after their wedding last Saturday prompted protests from European and local officials. Hundreds of guests and a group of reporters witnessed the girl, Ana Maria Cioaba, try but fail to escape her lavish wedding in the Transylvanian city of Sibiu. The European Commission condemned Romania for turning a blind eye to the wedding and called for immediate action. The child-protection officials interviewed the young couple and their families and ordered the newlyweds to live separately with their families until they reach 16, the legal age to be married. The girl must also attend school, beginning Monday.    (Reuters)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMMONS, MARTIN
description: SIMMONS--Martin, 92, on September 30 after complications from a fall. He was the beloved husband and is survived by his wife, Doreen. He was a member and former governor of the Union Club, a past president of the British Schools and Universities Club, a member of Holland Lodge, St. George's Society, and Brooks's Club in London. He was a most elegant, articulate gentleman, kind and generous, and will be sadly missed by his many friends. Service will be private.

title: RESPIRONICS SAYS STRATEGIC OFFICER TO BECOME CHIEF
description: Respironics, a maker of products used to treat breathing disorders, named John L. Miclot president and chief executive, effective Dec. 1. Mr. Miclot, 44, the chief strategic officer, previously served as head of the company's home-care unit. He will succeed James W. Liken, who has held the posts since 1999. The company, based in Murrysville, Pa., said Mr. Liken, 53, would assume the newly created role of vice chairman.

title: Sure, It Lost Plenty of Money, But, Hey, It's Calvin Klein; Owner Says the Golden Name Is the Bottom Line
description: Bruce J. Klatsky, chief executive of Phillips-Van Heusen, knew that running Calvin Klein would be a challenge eight months ago when he bought the company.

title: REVISED ADMISSION FOR HIGH SCHOOLS
description: New York City education officials have quietly instituted a new mandatory high school admissions policy that allows students this year to apply to as many as a dozen schools but will admit them to only one.

title: The Dark Geometry Of Picasso's Mistress From Every Angle
description: In the 30 years since his death, the epic career of Pablo Picasso has sustained endless parsing and subdivision, yielding exhibitions of ever sharper focus. But few of these shows equal the spectacular close-up provided by ''Picasso: The Cubist Portraits of Fernande Olivier'' at the National Gallery of Art here.

title: BAYER SAYS IT WILL SELL ITS BLOOD PLASMA BUSINESS
description: The drug maker Bayer said yesterday that it would sell its blood plasma business, including the recently approved immune deficiency treatment Gamunex, as the company reorganizes its drug unit. The hemophilia therapy Kogenate is not part of the sale, Bayer said. The plasma business, based in Research Triangle Park, N.C., has 1,350 employees. It had first-half sales of 293 million euros ($342 million). Gamunex was approved in the United States in August. Bayer has said that it expects to introduce no major new products in the next three years.

title: Rangers Add 3 and Lose 3
description: The Rangers claimed three players and lost three at the N.H.L.'s waiver draft yesterday. They selected defenseman Joel Bouchard from Buffalo, forward Sheldon Keefe from Tampa Bay and forward Mike Siklenka from Philadelphia. They lost forward Ronald Petrovicky and defenseman Shawn Heins to Atlanta and forward Jeff Heerema to St. Louis.

title: The Collections:Milan: Prada's quirky cultural trip
description: MILAN  Turning the girlie into the womanly is the mission of the Milan summer 2004 season. Full skirts, soft rain-washed colors and filmy  but not the see-through  fabrics are sending out a pretty woman message. But only Miuccia Prada, with her intellectual brilliance and her fashion instinct, caught the real mood in her quirky and disquieting show.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 20 about the interrogation of a Qaeda operative captured in Thailand misstated the ownership of the Israeli jetliner that was the target of a shoulder-fired missile attack in Kenya last November, which some intelligence officials suspect was carried out by Al Qaeda. The plane belonged to Arkia Airlines, not El Al.

title: The Cost of Israeli Settlements
description: Israel's announcement yesterday that it would build 600 new homes in West Bank settlements is cause for despair. Those, including this page, who consider such settlements to be one of the biggest obstacles to ending the Israeli-Arab dispute have often complained about the hardships they impose on Palestinians -- and about their cost to Israel. The concern has been not only over the prolongation of the conflict and the violence the settlements trigger but also over the money misspent on them that would be far better used inside Israel proper. The true size of that cost, however, has always been something of a mystery. Until now.

title: Frerotte to Start Again
description: The Minnesota Vikings will start Gus Frerotte at quarterback for the second straight week as Daunte Culpepper continues to recover from a lower-back injury, Coach Mike Tice said at a news conference. Frerotte, a 10-year N.F.L. veteran, led the Vikings to a 35-7 victory over the San Francisco 49ers last week, completing 16 of 21 passes for 267 yards and 4 touchdowns. Minnesota (4-0) has a bye week after Sunday's game against the Atlanta Falcons.

title: 'Friends and Family'
description: Directed by Kristen Coury

title: Bill Banning Abortion Procedure Advances
description: Congress moved a step closer on Thursday to sending President Bush the first federal bill that would outlaw a type of abortion, but opponents of the legislation vowed to challenge the measure in court as soon as the president signed it.

title: Investigators Focus on Russian Oil Company
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 3  Criminal investigators conducted a new round of searches today that focused on Russia's richest oil company, Yukos, a sign that the investigation that has shadowed the company since July is far from over.

title: For First Time in 8 Months, U.S. Businesses Add New Jobs
description: The job market in September showed its strongest signs of turning around since the start of the year, suggesting that the economic recovery might finally be powerful enough to help workers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Crowding Out Playgrounds
description: A new legislative report charged yesterday that many of the city's overcrowded elementary schools had installed temporary classrooms on playgrounds, without replacing the play areas. Assemblyman Jeffrey Klein and Councilwoman Eva S. Moskowitz, chairwoman of the council's education committee, called on state and city officials to enforce laws requiring access to adequate playgrounds. Jerry Russo, a spokesman for Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, said education officials were working to ensure access to both quality classrooms and recreation facilities, including playgrounds. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Man Indicted in Mailbox Bombings
description: A Bridgewater, N.J., man charged in a rash of mailbox bombings in Massachusetts has been indicted in more than two dozen similar attacks in west central New Jersey over the last five years and for threatening public officials.

title: In Iraq, Seeking Arms and Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lively, Youthful 'Figaro' Of (Mostly) Opulent Sets
description: In Jonathan Miller's production of ''Le Nozze di Figaro,'' which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday evening, Count Almaviva's palace is in desperate need of a paint job, but is opulent in every other way. The staff of servants is large, bewigged and liveried, and given to eavesdropping at closed doors. And the Count, Countess, Figaro, Susanna and the other principals are dressed in the height of 18th-century Spanish fashion. Indeed, leaving aside the mild eccentricity of the distressed inner walls -- the exterior looks fine in the final act -- this is the model of a traditional, straightforward ''Figaro.''

title: Uneasy Rider
description: FOR Steve Klerk, one of life's pleasures is a short Sunday spin on his motorcycle -- with the emphasis on short. As he rumbles past the farms on the North Fork of Long Island near his home in Wading River, his Harley-Davidson chopper turns heads. It is exactly the type of long, low, gracefully sculptured yet minimalist machine that has been enshrined in popular culture ever since ''Easy Rider.''

title: Air France and KLM Chiefs Talk of U.S. Plan
description: The chief executives of Air France and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, who plan to merge their companies, said yesterday that they might ask the Justice Department to permit Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines to join them in one large trans-Atlantic marketing partnership. But they said they would not seek additional immunity from antitrust laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STARK, FLORENCE
description: STARK -- Florence, whose high energy and continued buoyant spirit made her a mother we admired to our cofounder and co-chairperson, Toby Lynn Perlman, and mother-in-law to Toby's husband, Itzhak. As a dedicated grandmother to five and great-grandmother to two, and friend to many, she communicated a musical inspiration and love of life to all of us involved with The Perlman Music Program. With fond memories from the Board, staff, students and faculty of The Perlman Music Program.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Securities Seller Accused Of Stealing From Ex-Clients

title: Jets' Abraham Faces Drunken Driving Charge
description: Jets defensive end John Abraham apologized on Thursday, a day after he was arrested and charged with driving while intoxicated after a traffic accident on Long Island.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lobbying Inquiry Stalled
description: A state investigation into the conduct of Russell Simmons, left, and Dr. Benjamin Chavis, outspoken opponents of Rockefeller-era drug laws, is in limbo until a federal judge in Manhattan decides whether their constitutional rights have been violated by the investigation. A decision is expected later this month. In July, Mr. Simmons, the hip-hop impresario, and Dr. Chavis, a former leader of the N.A.A.C.P., filed the complaint against the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying, which began the investigation, claiming their rights to petition the government had been hurt by requiring them to register as lobbyists. The men advocate changing the state law requiring long sentences for small-time drug offenders, which they say hurts members of minority groups. The investigation has been suspended since August. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: When 'Welcome' Doesn't Mean Junior
description: NOT long after Gil and Liz Riviere checked into their richly appointed room at the Inn at Ocean's Edge near Camden, Me., the phone started ringing. But it wasn't housekeeping offering turn-down service. It was the front desk saying they would have to leave immediately and that a state trooper was coming to make sure they did.

title: NYC
description: In a New Year, Keeping Alive A Synagogue

title: The Final Frontier: Queens; Museum's Rockets Return After a Tuneup in Ohio
description: You can see a lot of strange things on a New York City street, but on Wednesday night there was something almost literally out of this world.

title: A Substitute Teacher Puts a Spin on the 3 R's (Rock, Roll and Rebellion)
description: Forget all that touchy-feely blather about getting in touch with your wounded inner child. The irresistibly good-natured comedy ''School of Rock'' proposes a far bolder and more playful path toward self-realization. It imagines that deep in the soul of every child, parent and even the crustiest school principal a suppressed rock 'n' roll maniac is clamoring for release. Or as this movie's resident doctor of rock liberation announces to a group of shy fifth graders, rock 'n' roll is about ''sticking it to the man.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''One of the things he looks at, which other people including myself lack the courage to look at, is human cruelty and insensitivity as it occurs in all sort of contexts.''

title: A Public Health Warrior, Tracking 9/11 Trends
description: DR. POLLY THOMAS is leaning over her computer, reviewing a daily graphic chart of people signing up for the World Trade Center Health Registry. Dr. Thomas is an assistant commissioner for the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Report Faults Meat Company And Inspectors
description: A meat producer and the inspection service of the Agriculture Department were criticized in a report by the department inspector general investigating the July 2002 recall of 19 million pounds of beef. The report said that the meat producer, ConAgra Beef Company, and the inspectors had not followed regulations for safe ground beef, leading to what was then the second largest meat recall on record. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: CARTERET: BUS FIRE SNARLS TRAFFIC A burning Academy Bus Lines coach snarled traffic on the New Jersey Turnpike during the morning rush yesterday, disrupting traffic and causing it to be rerouted for nearly four hours. Bus company officials did not return repeated calls seeking details on the cause of the fire and the route of the bus. Traffic was slowed in the four lanes of the outer roadway truck lanes of the turnpike just south of Exit 13 near Carteret for more than five miles after the 7:50 a.m. fire. The driver was able to safely evacuate all the passengers from the bus, which was fully occupied. But it was not until 10:51 that the charred hulk of the bus was removed from the roadway and all lanes were reopened.   Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: In Iraq, Seeking Arms and Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: A Beefy Toney Weighs In
description: James Toney, looking as if he were still enjoying the products of the Ann Arbor, Mich., bakery he worked in while growing up, weighed in at 217 pounds yesterday, only two pounds lighter than Evander Holyfield for their 12-round pay-per-view heavyweight bout tomorrow night at the Mandalay Bay Events Center in Las Vegas. Toney weighed 190 pounds in his most recent fight, when he won the International Boxing Federation cruiserweight title on April 26. Holyfield was one pound lighter than he was for his last fight, a 12-round loss on points to Chris Byrd last Dec. 15. Michael Katz

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROTHMAN, JESSE
description: ROTHMAN--Jesse. Sweetheart, on this your birthday, we miss you more than ever. Your loving family.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Far From Home, and Staying There
description: Catherine Anzivino had excitedly told her son Michael the news. His father, Sgt. Scott Anzivino, who has been stationed in Kuwait for months, would be on a two-week home leave in November, there to celebrate Michael's fifth birthday.

title: 'Slime and Defend'
description: On July 14, Robert Novak published the now-famous column in which he identified Valerie Plame, the wife of former Ambassador Joseph Wilson, as a C.I.A. ''operative on weapons of mass destruction,'' and said ''two senior administration officials'' had told him that she was responsible for her husband's mission to Niger. On that mission, Mr. Wilson concluded -- correctly -- that reports of Iraqi efforts to buy uranium were bogus.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Advertising; Chivas Regal and Johnnie Walker start preaching to the choir in campaigns aimed at Scotch lovers.
description: FOR the marketers of two big brands of Scotch whiskey, Chivas Regal and Johnnie Walker, it was back to the drawing board -- again. Both have discarded advertising they had introduced only recently in favor of significantly retooled campaigns.

title: U.S. Practices How to Down Hijacked Jets
description: The United States military practices how to shoot down hijacked commercial airliners as often as three to four times a week, honing its defenses against terrorist attacks on American cities, a senior general said on Thursday.

title: Korean Claim Leaves U.S. Concerned, But Skeptical
description: North Korea raised the tension in future nuclear talks by saying on Thursday that it is making atomic bombs from plutonium it has reprocessed from 8,000 spent fuel rods. The United States responded that it could not verify the Korean statement, but still took it seriously.

title: Sports of The Times; Red Sox Moments Create a Big Hole
description: THE Oakland A's move decisively from year to year, making the best of their scrappiness and small-budget wits. The Boston Red Sox float high and dip low, like a Tim Wakefield knuckleball, burdened by the weight of a history that ultimately sends them careering to earth.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Ole Wanscher -- 'Danish Modern Master Furniture'
description: Dickinson Roundell

title: Hardly Aged in the Oak Room
description: When the scrappy English jazz singer and pianist Jamie Cullum performs ''Blame It on My Youth,'' his age (only 24) and frisky personality lend the regretful ballad a desperate immediacy that a more mature interpreter could never evoke. Mr. Cullum, who made his memorable New York cabaret debut at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Tuesday evening, is a natural showman with the confidence of a bantam rooster waking up the neighborhood with his crowing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STAPP, PHILIP
description: STAPP--Philip. Called ''one of the most orginal and creative animators ever to work in educational films,'' died on October 2, after a brief illness. He was 95 and lived in Stonington, CT. Over the decades, Stapp contributed finely crafted elements to many films (listed in the International Film Foundation catalog) that set the standard for creativity in animating the educational film. For the past 20 years he designed scrolls using geometrical and musical structures. He is survived by a sister, Martha List and several nieces and nephews.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 315 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Saturdays Top Matchups
description: All Times Eastern No. 9 Michigan (4-1) at No. 23 Iowa (4-1), 3:30 p.m., ABC (regional)

title: Judge Allows Referendum On Class Size
description: A State Supreme Court justice ordered yesterday that a referendum aimed at reducing the size of classes in New York City's public schools be put on the ballot in next month's election, rejecting as unconstitutional the city's attempt to quash the vote.

title: Coetzee, Writer of Apartheid As Bleak Mirror, Wins Nobel
description: J. M. Coetzee, a widely acclaimed South African novelist who has often used his country's apartheid system and its post-apartheid transition to mirror the bleakness of the human condition, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature on Thursday by the Swedish Academy in Stockholm.

title: Orderly and Civil Transition Likely? Well, 'Chaotic' Comes to Mind
description: The last time power changed hands in the governor's office in California, in early 1999, it was an orderly and largely civil two-month affair.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Adhesive Business Acquired
description: The Germany adhesive maker Henkel Group bought the adhesives and construction material business of DESC Group of Mexico for an undisclosed price to strengthen its presence in the Mexican market. The business, which employs more than 900 people, generated sales of $101 million last year, Henkel said. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Top Democrat Backs Opponent of Slain Councilman's Brother
description: The candidacy of Letitia James, the third-party candidate hoping to succeed the late Councilman James E. Davis, got a lift yesterday when she was endorsed by Alan G. Hevesi, the state comptroller.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: ART TECHNOLOGY SHARES PLUNGE ON SALES NEWS The Art Technology Group said yesterday that third-quarter sales fell at least 35 percent because customers delayed orders. The shares fell as much as 23 percent. Sales at Art Technology, based in Cambridge, Mass., fell to $15 million to $16 million, from $24.5 million a year earlier. Investors expected sales of about $20 million, the chief financial officer, Edward Terino, said in an interview. The loss widened to 5 cents to 7 cents a share, from 4 cents a year earlier. Shares fell 39 cents, or 18 percent, to $1.74 and dropped as low as $1.65. Art Technology's software helps companies process online orders and manage customer service both on and off the Internet.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Circuits yesterday about universal remote controls misstated the cost of downloading TV listings onto the Harmony Remote SST-659 from Intrigue Technologies. It is $20 per year or a one-time fee of $40, not both.

title: Limbaugh Still Has a Fallback Position
description: Rush Limbaugh's opinions about race, the news media and a black quarterback led to his resignation Wednesday as an ESPN football analyst, but he is fortunate. He may never get a sports job again, but he can return to his millions of radio listeners who have heard tougher, more incendiary comments on his talk show than those he made Sunday about Donovan McNabb of the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: 36 Hours | Providence, R.I.
description: IN its early days, Rhode Island was known as ''Rogues' Island,'' a reference to the willingness of its founder, Roger Williams, to accept every element of society. A few centuries on, that sobriquet is more likely to connote Providence's colorful former mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr., now serving a 64-month prison sentence after a federal racketeering conspiracy conviction in 2002. Nevertheless, Providence remains a charming hodgepodge, where tidy colonial houses rest just across the river from a hulking power plant. And Mr. Cianci's efforts to renovate this once-beleaguered capital city have resulted in a gleaming downtown, a sparkling waterfront and a vibrant arts community. Small wonder that despite his legal difficulties he has achieved folk hero status.

title: Under Spell of Pettitte and Rivera, Twins Break Down
description: They are the two senior members of the Yankees' pitching staff, the foundation of a championship run. Andy Pettitte and Mariano Rivera came up together in 1995, tasted their first title the next year and have been through everything since. If anybody sensed the urgency of last night's game, surely they did.

title: CONOCOPHILLIPS SAYS OIL PRODUCTION FELL IN 3RD QUARTER
description: ConocoPhillips said yesterday that production of oil and natural gas fell 6 percent in the third quarter from the previous three months and that oil-refining margins widened. Production fell because of asset sales, seasonal declines and scheduled maintenance at fields in Alaska, Britain and Canada, the company said. Refining margins widened from the second quarter and plants ran at close to 95 percent capacity, the company said. Profit declined at its chemicals unit and pipeline operations, ConocoPhillips said. Debt at the end of the third quarter totaled $18.9 billion.

title: Translating Rhythmic Languages
description: The jazz pianist Jason Moran is becoming as well known for his revisions of other people's music as for anything else. With his trio, the Bandwagon, he unveiled a few new cover versions on Tuesday night during a spiky tumbleweed of a set at the Village Vanguard.

title: Opening Night: Glamour, Grumbling and Even Opera
description: Even with air-conditioning and year-round union contracts and summer festivals under every tree, a new season stirs to life every fall. For culture mavens nothing -- not the first blockbuster exhibition opening at the Metropolitan Museum, not the first television shows or post-summer semi-serious films -- symbolizes that new beginning like an opera opening.

title: Corrections
description: Correction: Many people, including Paul Bremer in recent testimony and myself in my Sept. 30 column, have linked Churchill's remark about the ''most unsordid act'' to the Marshall Plan. In fact, Churchill was referring to an earlier program, Lend-Lease. But one suspects that he wouldn't have minded the confusion.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Funds For Immigrant Services
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday that $2.5 million in state funds had been allocated for services for immigrants. Speaking at the Dominican Women's Development Center, at West 189th Street in Washington Heights, the governor said money for 19 community groups would help immigrants seeking naturalization. The largest grant, $660,000, will go to the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, which operates an 18-language telephone line that gives advice on topics like immigration law and discrimination. Colin Moynihan (NYT)

description: Lottery Numbers

title: Same Setup Man, but Different Results This Time
description: First base was open, offering Minnesota reliever LaTroy Hawkins a chance to sidestep the muscular man batting against him. But Hawkins had made up his mind that he was going to go after Jason Giambi with hard stuff. Why not? Hard stuff works for Hawkins.

title: National Briefing: South
description: KENTUCKY: WOMAN PLEADS GUILTY TO FRAUD A woman who had admitted a relationship with Gov. Paul E. Patton pleaded guilty to mail fraud in a deal with prosecutors, who agreed to recommend probation instead of prison time. The woman, Tina Conner, who contends that the governor turned her in after the affair ended, was charged with fraudulently applying for a special certification, that of a "disadvantaged business enterprise" run by a woman, for a construction company operated by her former husband. (AP)

title: Giambi Goes From Zero to Hero
description: Manager Joe Torre gathered the Yankees in the clubhouse about an hour before last night's crucial game against the Minnesota Twins for a speech that he knew would last barely two minutes. But Torre realized that the length of his address to his suddenly fragile players was not as important as what he actually uttered.

title: 'Nothing is what it seems to be'
description: PARIS  A senior company director decked out in a sharp suit and tie gleefully pours a blob of ketchup on a piece of gray fabric stretched out on a small table display stand. The red mass glides quickly down the surface  without leaving a trace  and drops onto a tray below. The executive then grabs a can of Coke, which he proudly pours on the same fabric  it, too, bounces down onto the tray.

title: Political Memo; Despite Polls, Pataki Backs Bush on Iraq All the Way
description: Even as public support for the American occupation of Iraq has begun to ebb, Gov. George E. Pataki has emerged as one of President Bush's staunchest supporters on the war, defending it in speeches across the country as the continuation of a struggle against Islamic terrorists that began with the attacks in New York in 2001.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the resignation of two aides to the Rev. Al Sharpton in his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination misspelled the surname of his lawyer, who commented on the state of the campaign. He is Michael A. Hardy, not Harding.

description: To the Editor:

title: Parlow Gets Physical, Gets Goals
description: In the 24th minute of Wednesday's scoreless quarterfinal match against Norway, forward Cindy Parlow was fouled near midfield. It has become a common occurrence during this Women's World Cup. Parlow gets chopped down, setting up a free kick, and the United States manufactures a goal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORRELL, CHARLES RAYNOR
description: MORRELL--Charles Raynor, 75, of Palm City, FL, died on October 2, 2003. Born in Rockville Centre, NY, he resided on Long Island until 1992 when he moved to Florida as a full time resident. He was a member of the Evergreen Club in Palm City, as well as Southward-Ho Country Club in West Bay Shore, NY. Mr. Morrell spent his entire working career in the Insurance Brokerage Industry and had been very active in industry affairs. He was a past Chairman and President of the National Association of Insurance Brokers and had also served as an officer of the Insurance Brokers Association of the State of New York. At his retirement in 1989 he was Executive Vice President of Alexander & Alexander of New York. He is survived by his beloved wife Gail G. Morrell of Palm City, his daughter Gail E. Morrell-Marshall of Silver Spring, MD, a son Charles R. Morrell, Jr. of Fernandina Beach, FL, a son Donald W. Morrell of Spring Hill, FL and a son Thomas Scott Morrell of Stuart, FL. In addition, he is survived by three stepchildren, Gary Gold of Los Angeles, CA, David Gold of NY and Fran Grayson of Oakland, CA. He is survived by five grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held Sunday, October 5, at 10 AM, at Forest Hills Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Martin Memorial Cancer Center SW Fund are suggested.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOURY, SAM ''DUDY''
description: SOURY -- Sam ''Dudy''. Passed away on October 1. Loving husband of Lilly. Adored father of Michael and Lonnie. Brother and friend of Danny, Estelle, Bette and Joe, and devoted grandfather of Jeremy, Jake, Arielle and Michaela. He is survived by many loving relatives and friends. He was an immensely caring, funny, and unique man who loved his family more than anyone could imagine. Sam made people feel special and important. He will be missed by so many. Services on Friday, October 3, 12 PM, Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy. Donations may be made to the Harlem Center For Education, 1 E. 104 St, NY, NY 10029.

title: Graham Presidential Campaign Considers Changing Strategies
description: A spokesman for Senator Bob Graham's presidential campaign resigned on Thursday as the candidate huddled with aides over how to revive a candidacy struggling to raise money and lagging in the polls.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Manhattan restaurants usually feel cramped even when they are large. Sumile, with a mere 60 seats, seems twice its actual size. Even stranger, it gives the impression of being light and airy without any windows. Other surprises await. The Japanese-inspired menu does away with appetizers and entrees. Instead it offers 20 dishes, each priced at $14, and five $7 desserts. Three or four savory dishes make a meal, and two diners, by ordering six to eight dishes and pushing the plates back and forth across the table, can put together quite a culinary tour.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Guilty Pleas In Copyright Infringement Case
description: Four software pirates have pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit criminal copyright infringement as part of a 15-month investigation, the Justice Department announced yesterday. Travis Myers, 29, of Yakima, Wash.; Marvin Katz, 26, of Yorktown Heights, N.Y.; Walter Kapechuk, 55, of Schenectady, N.Y.; and Warren Willsey, 53, of East Berne, N.Y., all pleaded guilty in New Haven yesterday and admitted to being part of an underground software team, commonly referred to as a ''warez group.'' Such teams are widely thought to be responsible for the bulk of the pirating of copyrighted software and video games on the Internet. They also trade in movies and music files. The investigation, called Operation Safehaven, was conducted by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents out of New Haven. Mr. Willsey faces a one-year prison term and a fine of up to $100,000. The other three each face five-year prison terms, with fines of up to $250,000. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The White House Letter column on Sept. 15 about the family of Scott McClellan, the White House press secretary, and its various connections to political power misstated the time elapsed since Mr. McClellan's mother, Carole Keeton Strayhorn, turned down a first offer of marriage from Ed Strayhorn, who is now her third husband. It was 45 years, not 37.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Utility Measure Passes
description: Argentina's Congress voted to allow the President Nstor Kirchner to raise utility rates frozen two years ago when the economy imploded. But a government official said no increases were expected soon. The government has frozen utility rates since the economic crisis of early 2001 to help the growing ranks of the poor and the jobless. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Refugee Numbers Decline
description: For the second year in a row, the number of refugees settling in the United States fell to less than half of the government's projections, again in large part because of stricter guidelines for security clearances that were instituted after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: No Illicit Arms Found in Iraq, U.S. Inspector Tells Congress
description: The government's chief weapons inspector in Iraq told Congress on Thursday that his team had failed to find illegal weapons after three months of scouring the country, but he said the group had discovered some evidence of Saddam Hussein's intent to develop such weapons and even signs that Baghdad had retained some capacity to do so.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 23 about utility lines damaged by Hurricane Isabel misattributed a comment about the maintenance faults that might have contributed to power failures in Washington. It was Tony Bullock, a spokesman for Mayor Anthony Williams -- not the mayor himself -- who said, ''If you have bare copper wires and old ceramic insulators and frail, brittle poles, you'll suffer more impact than if you had invested some money into improving the system.''

title: Beauty Despite Terror and Melancholy
description: A facile connection is often made between the apocalyptic vision of Olivier Messiaen's ''Quartet for the End of Time'' and the circumstances of its composition, in a German prisoner-of-war camp in 1941. The work's odd scoring -- piano, violin, clarinet and cello -- reflects the instruments available in Stalag 8A.

title: House Rebuffs the White House Over Rules to Limit Overtime Pay
description: In a slap to the Bush administration, the Republican-controlled House reversed itself on Thursday and voted to block the White House from issuing regulations that opponents say would strip millions of workers of their right to overtime pay.

description: Less than two days after 3,300 city and suburban trash haulers went on strike, garbage bins here are already beginning to overflow, leaving residents and business owners struggling to keep their waste vermin-free.

title: Austrian Cardinal Describes Pope as 'Dying'
description: A prominent European cardinal on Thursday described Pope John Paul II as ''dying'' and said the pope was ''approaching the last days and months of his life.''

title: Weekender | Old Lyme, Conn.
description: DRIVING down winding Route 156 in Old Lyme, one cannot help but appreciate the landscape that the Tonalist artist Henry Ward Ranger said was ''waiting to be painted.'' The vistas of Long Island Sound, and the Connecticut, Lieutenant and Black Hall Rivers draw visitors today just as they attracted Ranger and the American Impressionists in the late 19th century.

description: DUPERIER--Rosa. On Tuesday, September 30, 2003 in Nottingham, England. Sister of the late Hilda Steans. Aunt of Bill Cass and the late Valerie Cass. Rosa is remembered by friends and loved ones on both sides of the Atlantic for her great beauty, generosity and love of life.

description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A Film Stud Who Loses His Luster Is Sent to Graze on Seedy Pastures
description: ''Wonderland,'' directed by James Cox, is part of a curious, somewhat unsavory subgenre of movies that involve washed-up, sort-of-famous people and death by bludgeoning. Recent examples include Paul Schrader's ''Auto Focus,'' in which the celebrity (and victim) was the ''Hogan's Heroes'' star Bob Crane, and Fenton Bailey and Randy Barbato's ''Party Monster,'' in which the celebrity (who in real life pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter) was the New York club kid Michael Alig.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAZARUS, STEPHEN
description: LAZARUS--Stephen. October 1st, 2003. Midge's beloved husband of 51 years. Remembered with love by cousins Robert, Astrid, Clarissa and Alexander Lasky. Service Wednesday, October 8, 1PM, Stroyan Funeral Home, 405 West Harford St., Milford, Pa.

title: World Bank Inaugurates Oil Pipeline In Africa
description: The World Bank announced the inauguration of a new Chad-Cameroon oil pipeline on Thursday and promised to help prevent this project from leading to poverty and corruption as such projects so often have in other poor nations.

title: The Collections:Milan: Sensual Gucci is all about Eve
description: MILAN  Tom Ford's new collection for Gucci was all about Eve. As sparkling snakes twined around the torso of little black dresses, wound in bracelets at the wrist and slithered across snaffle bags, the show looked polished and glamorous. Its mix of sport and womanly elegance was not innovative, but this sleek performance put Gucci back on track after a couple of floundering seasons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KABIA, DR. ABDUL H.
description: KABIA--Dr. Abdul H., a resident of Elmsford, New York, and Sierra Leone, died peacefully on Thursday, September 25, 2003, at the age of 68. He was the United Nations Secretary General's representative in Somalia and served in Rwanda during the civil war. During his long tenure at the United Nations he had also served as the Secretary of the Council for Namibia, working towards Namibia's independence. Dr. Kabia also served as a member of the Sierra Leone Parliament from 1964 to 1966, as Deputy Minister of External Affairs in 1966, and as the Consul-General to the United States of America in 1967. Dr. Kabia is survived by his wife and six children. The funeral service will be held at the Westchester Muslim Center in Mount Vernon, New York, on Friday, October 3, 2003, at 1:00 P.M.

title: Chronicling Life Perched on a Volcano's Edge as Change Erupts
description: In his novels and novellas, the South African writer J. M. Coetzee has mapped a harsh geography of loss and violence, denial and perseverance.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Adds Microsoft Games To Site
description: Yahoo agreed yesterday to offer personal computer games from Microsoft in the online gaming part of its site to increase revenue from fee-based services. Financial terms were not disclosed. Fifteen new games from Microsoft will be added to Yahoo Games on Demand, Yahoo said in a statement. The additions include Microsoft Flight Simulator 2004, the second-best-selling PC game in August, according to the market-research company NPD Group. Yahoo Games on Demand is part of Yahoo's strategy to add more services that consumers pay for directly. Fee revenue rose 43 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier, to $69.9 million. A decline in online advertising in 2001 produced a 35 percent sales drop and a $93 million net loss. Shares of Yahoo, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., rose $1.51, to $37.91.

title: What Inspectors Saw, and Didnt See
description: In his statement yesterday to the Congressional intelligence committees, David Kay, of the Iraq Survey Group, said his inspectors "have not yet found stocks of weapons" using chemical or biological agents, or evidence of "steps to actually build nuclear weapons." But he said it was too early to conclude there were no weapons of mass destruction, or to say that they had existed before the war but had disappeared.

title: Inmate Is Jailed Too Long, Causing New Jersey Review
description: The New Jersey Department of Corrections has reviewed the sentences of more than 100 inmates since a court found last month that a prisoner had served two years more than he should have because his release date had been wrongly calculated.

title: Not Ready for Prime Time
description: Breaking through the background chatter of television takes some doing. So ESPN apparently thought it might try something a little different. Instead of more sex, violence or even a nude sportscaster like the one who appeared on another sports show, ESPN brought in Rush Limbaugh, the right-wing radio commentator. He was there to give his hot-button views on one thing: football. And if the idea was to raise ratings, it worked. At least, it worked for one month.

description: Nike Inc. , the world's biggest maker of athletic shoes, will close two factories in its Bauer Nike Hockey equipment division in Canada and cut production at a third as it shifts production to other companies to reduce costs.

description: Two years after losing its headquarters in the south tower of the World Trade Center, the OppenheimerFunds investment management company will return to Lower Manhattan, beginning this weekend.
