title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMOOT, WILLIAM SIDNEY
description: SMOOT--William Sidney, on October 1st, 2003 at age 89. Husband of Katharine S. for 57 years. Father of Sally Smoot Ingraham; grandfather of David Smoot Ingraham and Sarah Jennings Ingraham; brother of Charles Head Smoot and the late Barbara Smoot Ross. A mechanical and electrical engineer, he was an associate in Seelye Stevenson Value & Kneckt and later partner in Wall & Smoot Consulting Engineers. Among his civic and community activities he served as Mayor of the Village of Laurel Hollow from 1969 to 1985 and as President of Action for the Preservation and Conservation of the North Shore of Long Island. Funeral at St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, 11 AM Monday, October 6. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Holyfield Takes On Toney
description: Evander Holyfield, only 15 days before his 41st birthday, will face some very fresh opposition tonight.

title: Pentagon Criticizes High Rate of Allied Deaths by Allied Fire
description: The integration of land, sea and air power carried the military to victory in Iraq, according to a new Pentagon report, but the military ''fell short of expectations'' in preventing ''friendly fire'' deaths of allied forces.

title: Wishing Won't Make Star Wars So
description: President Bush's rush order to begin fielding a costly, unproven system for ballistic missile defense by next September is proving to be riddled with risks for technical failures and budget overruns. Congressional investigators have found the current state of antimissile technology hardly up to the actual threat.

title: Checking City's Archives to Solve a Medical Mystery
description: It was a medical mystery with national policy implications. New York City says it found the solution buried in its archives.

title: Congressional Agency Criticizes I.R.S. Plan
description: The Internal Revenue Service lacks an adequate plan to evaluate the effectiveness of its pilot program requiring certain low-income taxpayers to submit conclusive proof of their eligibility for a special tax credit, according to a report by the General Accounting Office.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Plan To Fight Prison Crowding
description: Gov. Janet Napolitano announced a $700 million plan to reduce prison crowding. The state has 31,000 inmates, 4,000 beyond its capacity, and officials say the number will rise 33 percent in four years. In a legislative session to begin on Oct. 20 the governor plans to ask for $26 million immediately, to rent space from city and county jails, and would seek to build facilities, financed by bonds, for 9,100 more prisoners. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Knicks Cautious on McDyess
description: Antonio McDyess will be on the court today when the other Knicks veterans report for training camp, although he will be off to the side shooting for 20 minutes in noncontact drills. The Knicks will be conservative in bringing him back. He will be able to walk through plays with his teammates, he will continue to run in a pool for 20 minutes and he will gradually increase his activity.

title: BARR LABS AGREES TO BUY ASSETS OF WOMEN'S CAPITAL
description: Barr Laboratories, a leading maker of oral contraceptives, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the assets of the Women's Capital Corporation, maker of a so-called morning-after pill. Terms were not disclosed. The acquisition includes most assets and liabilities of Women's Capital, which is closely held. The company's only product is the Plan B emergency contraceptive, which prevents conception if taken within 72 hours of unprotected sex. The medication is sold only in doctors' offices or through pharmacies in Alaska, California, New Mexico and Washington. Barr said it planned to seek United States approval to sell Plan B without a prescription.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about Joel I. Klein, the chancellor behind the major overhaul of New York City's public schools, misidentified the location of the Woodside Houses, the public housing project in Queens where he lived for much of his childhood. It is in Woodside, not Long Island City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HADERS, RICHARD
description: HADERS--Richard. Children of Bellevue, Inc., notes his passing with sorrow. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Mary Elliott Haders, long time Children of Bellevue Board and Corporate Member.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOLEY, JOHN D.
description: FOLEY--John D. The Partners, of counsel, associates and staff of Morgan & Finnegan L.L.P. mourn the loss of our long time colleague and good friend, John D. Foley. One of the founding partners of our firm as we know it today, John was highly respected and admired for his brillance, wit and sense of humor. We will miss him, and extend our heartfelt condolences to his family.

title: M.T.A. to Include 19th Century Building in Downtown Transit Hub
description: The gateway to Lower Manhattan's 21st-century transit hub may be through the Renaissance Revival arches of an ornate 19th-century office tower.

title: Convict Was in Same Prison As New Witness in Killings
description: A man who says he was wrongly convicted of killing his parents was in the same prison with the new witness who has come forward with information that may lead to his release, an investigator said Thursday.

title: WENDY'S SELLS 15 RESTAURANTS TO FOUNDER'S CHILDREN
description: Wendy's International said yesterday that it had sold 15 restaurants in Columbus, Ohio, to the children of its founder, Dave Thomas, including the daughter who inspired the company's name. Terms were not disclosed. The sale makes Mr. Thomas's five children franchisees in the Wendy's chain, which has 6,341 restaurants and is about 80 percent owned by franchisees, a spokesman said. Mr. Thomas, who died last year, opened the first Wendy's in Columbus in 1969 and named it for his daughter Melinda Lou, whose nickname is Wendy. The sale, along with the purchase of 68 franchise restaurants in Florida, will increase fourth-quarter earnings by 1 cent a share, Wendy's said.

title: How Consumers Should Check Drugs
description: Counterfeit medicine can be difficult to detect because of sophisticated packaging and strong similarities to genuine drugs. The Food and Drug Administration says consumers can protect themselves by looking for certain telltale signs.

title: U.S. Soldiers Are Ambushed By Guerrillas in Iraqi Town
description: American troops traded shots with guerrillas in a firefight Thursday afternoon near the center of Falluja, a town about 30 miles west of Baghdad, witnesses said.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush Nominee Advances

title: 'Concert for George'
description: Directed by David Leland

title: A Spacey Half-Hour at the Planetarium
description: Vertigo is guaranteed at ''SonicVision,'' the latest technological upgrade of that venerable planetarium moneymaker, the rock light show. On the dome of the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History's Rose Center for Earth and Space, the show's digital animations spin and strobe, shimmer and whoosh through simulated space. The secret delight of even the most educational planetarium show -- a sense of motion through the sky -- is happily exploited for 34 minutes of razzle-dazzle: shorter than a concert but far longer than a thrill ride. ''SonicVision'' takes over the planetarium on Fridays and Saturdays starting tonight.

title: Yankees Tie Series With Twins
description: After losing Game 1, the Yankees stormed back to beat the Minnesota Twins behind stellar pitching.

title: The Party
description: Celebrated citizens of the 1970's night, as captured by Marcia Resnick.

title: Forward and Back
description: 23 artists who are helping define a next sensibility.

title: A Winner on Faile Street
description: Jenise Harrell grew up on a street not known for success stories. But she herself is one.

title: A Kibitzer May Be Right, Or May Shoot From the Hip
description: In England, but not on this side of the Atlantic, a contract is sometimes described as a ''kibitzer's make.'' It is a useful term to describe a situation in which, at the end of the deal, a kibitzer prone to quick and superficial analysis tells the declarer something like, ''You could have made four spades.'' But four spades, apparently easy, is not at all simple, and careful thought may show that it cannot be made. It is then a kibitzer's make.

title: Sports of The Times; Yankees' Seventh-Inning Stretch Shouldn't Be So Stretched Out
description: ANDY PRICE was back home in Minnesota on Thursday night, eagerly watching his Twins on television as they played the Yankees in Game 2 of their American League division series.

title: Standards, Unstandard
description: Boz Scaggs has always skated between the cracks of musical genres, from hard blues to folk-rock to the high-gloss pop-disco of his biggest hit, ''Lowdown.'' So it really shouldn't be surprising that he recently released a traditional pop-jazz album of songs like ''What's New'' and ''But Beautiful,'' recorded with a jazz quartet.

title: Honoring the Slaves of New York
description: Historians and community groups have been pressing the federal government for more than a decade to rebury the remains of more than 400 Africans whose graves were accidentally uncovered during the building of a federal office tower in Lower Manhattan in 1991. After years of delays and missed deadlines, the last of the skeletons returned to New York yesterday for a series of ceremonies leading up to a reburial service today in what is left of the Colonial-era African Burial Ground on lower Broadway. The four coffins came ashore at Wall Street, near the city's first slave market and probably the place where Africans left slave ships in chains.

title: Chubby Jackson, 84, a Big-Band Star on Bass
description: Chubby Jackson, a jazz bassist almost as well known for his onstage exuberance as for his playing, died on Wednesday at a hospice in Paway, Calif., near his home in Rancho Bernardo. He was 84.

title: Brooklyn Man Held In Killing at Parade
description: The suspect in a fatal shooting during the Sept. 1 West Indian American Day Parade, tracked to Columbia, Md., by Brooklyn detectives, surrendered on Thursday, the police said. He was returned to New York yesterday.

title: With Bryant Absent, Lakers Begin Practicing
description: Reloaded and rejuvenated, the Los Angeles Lakers tried to be unaffected about the news Friday. Still, the fact remained: They were at training camp and their teammate, Kobe Bryant, was not.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: MEXICO: U.N. HELP IN UNEXPLAINED KILLINGS At the request of the government, a six-member team of United Nations investigators has traveled to Ciudad Juarez, on the Texas border, to make recommendations in an ongoing inquiry into the killings of more than 250 women in the past decade. The team said it had found that a lack of financial and professional resources among federal and state investigators, as well as inattention by government officials, had contributed to the failure to solve or stop the killings. Formal recommendations are expected this month. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCLELLAN, CARMEN T.
description: McLELLAN--Carmen T. On October 2, 2003. Survived by husband Hubert B. and son Neil. Also survived by brother Gerard Gillen and several nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Sunday, October 5, from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian burial on Monday, October 6th, 11 A.M. at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street.

title: About New York; Giuliani Razed Roller Coaster, And the Law
description: ONE morning in the fall of 2000, Horace Bullard answered the telephone at his home in the Bronx. It was an employee of his, Andy out in Coney Island, imparting information that few of us could ever imagine uttering or receiving.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: A Few Good Perks
description: The Defense Ministry is trying to lure young people into the armed forces by offering a 20 percent salary increase, a $620 signing bonus and other perks. Since the country's obligatory military service ended last year, recruiters have managed to fill only 800 of 12,000 available posts. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: VeriSign Agrees to Suspend Disputed Site Finder Service
description: VeriSign Inc., which assigns and administers Web addresses ending in .com and .net, agreed on Friday to suspend its service that redirects misspelled Web queries to its own page, bowing to pressure from an Internet oversight organization.

title: City's Role In Slavery Is Recalled At Rites
description: There were speeches, music and celebration yesterday as coffins bearing the remains of free and enslaved African-Americans unearthed 12 years ago were carried up Broadway in Lower Manhattan to be laid to rest for a second time. But like the syncopated rhythm of African percussion that filled the air, there was also the drumbeat of a word, one freighted with centuries of anger and controversy.

title: Davis Busy Filling Vacancies And Judgeships Just in Case
description: Gov. Gray Davis has made more than 260 appointments to judgeships and state commissions since the California recall election was announced 10 weeks ago, part of a concerted effort to secure a lasting Democratic imprint on Sacramento should the Republican candidate Arnold Schwarzenegger win on Tuesday.

title: Not Elton John, but a Good Simulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Woods's Solid Round Is Close to Spectacular
description: Tiger Woods is not ready to surrender the PGA Tour money title, or the player of the year award, just yet.

title: Bronx Girl Follows Vision: A Future Far From Home
description: In the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, there is a modest street called Faile Street. Its name is not a lie.

title: Twins Starter Is Excited to Face Yankees and Idol
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 3 - The difference between excited and excitable is critical for Kyle Lohse, the Minnesota Twins starter opposing Roger Clemens on Saturday in Game 3 of the American League division series.

title: Mineshaft Is Forced to Retire
description: The $4 million Breeders' Cup Classic lost one of its stars when the trainer Neil Howard announced yesterday that Mineshaft would be retired after three minor injuries to his front ankles and a knee.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Internet Stock Rises
description: Shares in EAccess, one of Japan's largest providers of high-speed Internet access, rose 61 percent on their first day of trading. The shares opened at 180,000 yen ($1,624) each and closed at 290,000 yen. The company, which had 1.1 million subscribers at the end of June, raised 7.2 billion yen ($65 million) in the offering. Company executives said their business started showing monthly profits during the summer. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Mideast Peace: What Will It Take?
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington's Sour Sales Pitch
description: It is no surprise that a federal panel investigating American ''public diplomacy'' in the Arab world reported this week that despite our efforts to win hearts and minds, ''hostility toward America has reached shocking levels.'' However, I doubt that recommendations like spending millions more on public relations and naming ''a special White House coordinator for public relations efforts abroad'' will be of much help.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about renewed criticism of the Bush administration for its handling of intelligence before the Iraq war misstated the circumstances under which international weapons inspectors left Iraq in 1998. They were withdrawn by the United Nations, not expelled by Saddam Hussein.

title: A Director's Calm as a Relentless Force
description: No other filmmaker has paired contemplativeness and wariness in quite the way the Japanese director Yasujiro Ozu did, and the Film Society of Lincoln Center uses the New York Film Festival to give us a chance to luxuriate in his canniness with ''Yasujiro Ozu: A Centennial Celebration.''

title: Handcuffed to the Economy
description: Aides to President Bush say he is willing to make big bets on policies he believes in. When it comes to the economy, Mr. Bush has been like a gambler, pushing through one tax cut after another despite early signs that his policies were not stopping big losses of jobs.

title: An Artist's Stark Vision Of Cambodian Slaughter
description: ''I survived because they liked my paintings,'' says Vann Nath in the unsettling new documentary ''S21: The Khmer Rouge Killing Machine,'' an affecting and effective film that has its premiere tomorrow at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center.

title: Hamilton Is Overlooked No Longer
description: He stands 6 feet 6 inches, but television cameras often overlook him, instead veering down the Giants' defensive line to Michael Strahan. He performs a big, unglamorous job that normally lands him at the bottom of a pile, not on a highlight clip.

title: Rush Limbaugh, Race and Football
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan U.S. Attorney In Line to Be Ashcroft Aide
description: President Bush announced yesterday that he intended to nominate James B. Comey, the United States attorney in Manhattan, to be deputy attorney general.

title: Serbia Will Send Troops And Police to Afghanistan
description: The United States has accepted an offer by Serbia and Montenegro to send up to 1,000 combat troops and police officers to Afghanistan to join American forces there, senior Serbian officials and foreign diplomats said today.

title: Insurer Cuts Profit Forecast
description: The Travelers Property Casualty Corporation reduced its earnings forecast for 2003 yesterday after estimating $75 million of losses from Hurricane Isabel. Travelers, based in Hartford, said it expected profit for the full year to be $1.65 billion to $1.7 billion, down from a previous range of $1.65 billion to $1.75 billion.

title: Criminal Inquiry Into Russian Oil Company Is Renewed
description: Criminal investigators conducted a new round of searches on Friday, focusing on Russia's richest oil company, Yukos, in a sign that the investigation that has shadowed the company since July is far from over.

title: Are More People Cheating?; Despite Ample Accounts Of Dishonesty, a Moral Decline Is Hard to Calculate
description: L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chairman of Tyco International, is on trial, accused of looting his company and investors of $600 million. Schoolchildren are pirating music and films online. Renowned historians like Doris Kearns Goodwin and Stephen Ambrose have plagiarized colleagues' work.

title: Art Too Tempting at Rikers; Plot to Steal a Dal Was Far From a Masterpiece
description: It was near midnight last Feb. 28 when Mitchell Hochhauser, an assistant deputy warden on Rikers Island, arrived for his graveyard shift at the Eric M. Taylor Center carrying his lunch and, strangely, a stapler.

title: McDyess Back in Camp, But Playing Has to Wait
description: While Antonio McDyess was launching jumpers on Friday, some that swished, others that clanged off the rim, he saw his teammates running drills on the adjacent court. He resisted the temptation to join them.

title: Week 4 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Denver Broncos (4-0) at Kansas City Chiefs (4-0)

title: Pennington Increases Throwing
description: Jets quarterback Chad Pennington practiced throwing passes for about 15 minutes Friday, his most extensive throwing workout since he fractured and dislocated bones in his left wrist during a preseason game.

title: Judge Censured For Remarks, And He Agrees To Step Down
description: In one case in the summer of 2002, a veteran Queens judge told a lawyer he was aggressive, then asked if the lawyer was Jewish. Any complaint the lawyer might file, the judge said, would be ''as worthless as a bucket of spit.''

title: Sports Briefing: BOXING; Holyfield Takes On Toney
description: Evander Holyfield, only 15 days before his 41st birthday, will face some very fresh opposition tonight.

title: Lottery Numbers
NASA's Plans for Shuttles Call for Fall '04 Launching
description: Setting a new timetable for resuming human spaceflight, NASA officials announced on Friday that they would try to launch the next shuttle mission to the International Space Station next September or October.

title: States Plan Suit to Prod U.S. on Global Warming
description: California plans to sue the Environmental Protection Agency over the Bush administration's recent decision that the agency lacked the authority to regulate greenhouse gas emissions from tailpipes and other sources, state regulators said on Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times on Sept. 23 with an article about the nesting grounds for billions of birds in the northern forests of Canada misstated the classification of the lesser scaup duck. It is a separate species of wild duck, not a black duck.

title: New Policy for Admissions Is Bringing New Headaches
description: Elaine Davidow was already a battle-scarred, two-time survivor of the New York City public high school admissions process when her youngest child started eighth grade last year. But that did not make applying to schools any easier.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Aluminum Stake Sold
description: Roman Abramovich, Russia's second-richest man, sold a quarter of Russian Aluminum, the world's No. 2 producer, adding to the estimated $5.7 billion fortune he built buying assets after the fall of the Soviet Union. Oleg Deripaska, Mr. Abramovich's partner in the closely held company, declined to disclose the price. Mr. Abramovich, above, and his partners completed the sale of the oil producer Sibneft to Yukos Oil for $13.9 billion in cash and stock. Mr. Abramovich bought the British soccer club Chelsea Village in July.

title: ITALIAN FASHION: A SPECIAL REPORT: The Japanese love affair with the Italian mystique
description: TOKYO  Forget the hype about minimalism  the (yawn) zen truisms about less being more. When a Tokyo woman dons Italian brands, she does so with the conviction that more must be better because she's paying more. A lot more.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the House's passage of a nonbinding bill opposed to the White House's issuing regulations that opponents say would strip millions of workers of their right to overtime pay misstated the final vote. It was 221 (not 211) to 203.

title: Afghan Blast Stirs Debate on Canadian Military Spending
description: The deaths of two Canadian soldiers in Afghanistan from an explosive device that blew a huge hole through their aging all-terrain vehicle has set off new debate in Canada over military spending after years of slashed budgets.

title: A Presidential Candidate Eyes the Auto Body Politic
description: Leaning on a white stock car sponsored by her parents' tanning salon and driven by her 23-year-old son, Elaine Vollmoeller surveyed a garage area at Riverhead Raceway in Long Island that was teeming with Republican family men. She proclaimed it unlikely that any of them would make a political conversion just because a Democratic presidential candidate was sponsoring a racecar.

title: Iraqis Say U.S. Occupation Authority Misspends Millions in Its Awarding of Contracts
description: Last month the Iraqi Governing Council questioned why the American occupation authority had issued a $20 million contract to buy new revolvers and Kalashnikov rifles for the Iraqi police when the United States military was confiscating tens of thousands of weapons every month from Saddam Hussein's abandoned arsenals.

title: Conine and the Marlins Relive the Past
description: Pro Player Stadium may not be charming as a baseball park, but it does have its nooks and crannies. Jeff Conine has a favorite one, where he is sure to seek solitude the next time the Florida Marlins are in a tight game.

title: Mayor Seeks $300 Million in Spending Cuts
description: The Bloomberg administration is looking for $300 million in new spending cuts as it guards against potential shortfalls this year and struggles to close a projected $2 billion budget gap for the next fiscal year.

title: Sports Briefing: HOCKEY; Devils Shut Out by Rangers
description: The Rangers killed off six power plays, four in the first period, in a 2-0 victory over the Devils at Continental Arena last night.

title: Lawmakers, Citing Violence, Seek to Regulate Cybercafes
description: A group of City Council members announced a proposal yesterday to regulate cybercafes, saying the businesses were much like the video arcades of the 1980's in that they were magnets for violence and truancy.

title: Shareholder Suit Against Stewart Dismissed
description: Martha Stewart and other directors of her company have won dismissal of a lawsuit by an investor who contended the company was harmed by her questionable stock sales.

title: INSIDE
description: Records Sought in Leak

title: Israeli Officer Is Charged In 4 Killings In West Bank
description: The Israeli military has filed manslaughter charges against an army officer in the killing of four Palestinians, including three children, at an outdoor food market last year, the army said Friday. The indictment says the four were killed when the officer, identified only as a lieutenant, ordered the firing of tank shells and machine guns to enforce a curfew.

title: Sound-Biting the Deficit
description: There is no sign of brakes' being applied to the spree of record deficit spending and borrowing engineered by President Bush and the Republican-led Congress. Warnings about budgetary disaster continue to mount: the deficits may total $4.4 trillion across 10 years, as the Congressional Budget Office says, or perhaps $5.5 trillion, the private-sector estimate at Goldman, Sachs. Even the U.S. comptroller general, David Walker, stepped up from his nonpartisan General Accounting Office duties to warn that the obligations being rolled forward would present ''unprecedented'' debts ''that threaten our nation's children's and grandchildren's futures.''

title: Montreal's Minaya On Market
description: Omar Minaya, who has been the Montreal Expos' general manager the last two seasons, interviewed to be the general manager of the Mets and the Cincinnati Reds last month, two baseball officials said Friday.

title: TEVA IN NEGOTIATIONS TO BUY SAVIENT PHARMACEUTICAL
description: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, the world's biggest maker of generic drugs, is in talks to buy Savient Pharmaceuticals as the companies work to develop generic versions of biotechnology medicines. Teva, based in Israel, may pay a per-share amount close to Savient's closing stock price Thursday of $6.14, Savient said. Savient, based in East Brunswick, N.J., has a market value of $350 million. A purchase would give Teva access to Savient medicines like Oxandrin, which helps patients gain weight after surgery. Savient and Teva also want to develop a market for generic versions of biotech drugs.

title: Questions Are Raised On Contracts in Iraq
description: Congress is seeking to examine how the American occupation authority and the military are spending billions of dollars in Iraq, and officials and business executives there say millions of dollars' worth of contracts are being awarded without competitive bidding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WESSLER, MARGARET M. (MUHLFELDER)
description: WESSLER -- Margaret M. (Muhlfelder) in N. Andover, MA, on October 3, at her residence, 82, formerly of Albany and Rye, NY. Beloved wife of Stanford Wessler, loving mother of John Wessler and Fredi Harwitz of Andover, MA, Steve Wessler and Beth Nagusky of Litchfield, ME, and Jim Wessler and Susan Goodman of Newton, MA, cherished grandmother of seven. Services private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Sarah Lawrence College, Swinford House, One Mead Way, Bronxville, NY, 10708, or to an educational institute of your choice.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Guilty Plea In Tobacco-Related Case
description: Marc Murr, a Houston lawyer accused of four counts of mail fraud and conspiracy involving the Texas lawsuit against large tobacco companies, pleaded guilty to a single charge of mail fraud. The agreement with prosecutors specifies that Mr. Murr serve six months in prison. Mr. Murr's co-defendant, former Attorney General Dan Morales of Texas, pleaded guilty this year to similar charges. A federal grand jury said the two men plotted to steer millions of dollars from the $17 billion tobacco settlement to Mr. Murr as legal fees. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Busload of Recall Candidates in Leader's Fumes
description: What can you do if you are running for governor of California -- seriously running, that is, with ideas and a platform -- and you are neither famous nor a flake?

title: Epidemic Incubators
description: To the Editor:

title: EMPLOYMENT RISES FOR THE FIRST TIME IN SEVEN MONTHS
description: The job market in September showed its strongest signs of revival since the start of the year, as a government report suggested that the economic recovery might finally be powerful enough to help workers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 24 about an Albrecht Drer exhibition at the Albertina Museum in Vienna misstated the number of the artist's self-portraits that are not in the show. Besides one owned by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, there is at least one other, at the Alte Pinakothek in Munich.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Reprieve For A Children's Home
description: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, who two weeks ago said he would shut down the state's largest residential care facility for children, has given it a reprieve, provided it carry out specific reforms. He said that he would allow about 90 of the facility's 130 children to remain at Maryville Academy, but that 39 of its most troubled students would be moved. The governor said he wanted Maryville, plagued by accusations of sexual abuse among its residents, to improve its management and focus on education rather than therapy and counseling. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: The Elusive Iraqi Weapons
description: The most striking findings in David Kay's interim report on the search for weapons of mass destruction in Iraq are his revelations about the backward state of Iraq's chemical and nuclear programs. Based on the evidence gathered so far in three months of searching, it seems clear that these programs barely existed and posed no immediate threat to the global community. To the contrary, it looks as if international inspectors succeeded in reducing or eliminating Iraq's arsenals and dedicated production capacity, forcing Saddam Hussein to lie low and wait for a new opportunity.

title: Rush Limbaugh, Race and Football
description: To the Editor:

title: Mideast Peace: What Will It Take? (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: New Members Added to Panel On School Aid
description: Gov. George E. Pataki rounded out his commission on education reform yesterday, naming six more members and picking a director to help guide the panel through the task of overhauling the state's school financing system.

title: Behind Two-Hit Gem by Prior, the Cubs Outshine Maddux and the Braves
description: We're often told, ''Don't believe the hype.'' The hype for Game 3 of the National League division series at Wrigley Field on Friday night was that the pitching matchup was one for the ages.

title: White House Is Told to Hand Over Records
description: The Justice Department is demanding that the White House turn over ''all documents that relate in any way'' to the unauthorized disclosure of a C.I.A. officer's identity, and the White House on Friday gave its employees until next Tuesday to comply.

title: 3 Die in Traffic Accidents
description: Three people were killed in traffic accidents in a five-hour period yesterday, the police said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The labor market showed a little bit of life. However, one month does not erase all of the pain we have seen.''

title: Doctors Who Performed Abortions Before Roe v. Wade
description: As the head of a hospital committee on abortion and sterilization in the 1960's, Dr. Mildred Hanson coached women through an elaborate system to prove that an unwanted pregnancy threatened their life or mental health. But one day she received a frantic call from a young woman seeking her help, and without a name or number all she could do was familiarize her with the process and ask her to call back.

title: Hey, Mare, This Old Lady Looks Like Ya
description: ''Blessings,'' a movie on CBS tomorrow night, emits maternal good vibes through a story of cold hearts rekindled by an abandoned newborn. And Mary Tyler Moore continues a successful string of tough-mom roles that take her far from Mary Richards, as if to say it's time to let someone else do some giving.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MBIA, Armonk, N.Y., the world's biggest bond insurer, said it planned to join forces with RenaissanceRe Holdings, PartnerRe and Koch Financial to create a new reinsurance company.

title: Israeli Security Barrier: Bar to Terror or to Peace?
description: For much of the last year, the 2,500 Palestinians who live in this ancient village in the stony hills above Tel Aviv, and about 45,000 Jewish settlers and students who live in hilltop communities nearby, have talked feverishly about the approach of the huge Israeli security barrier that has cut a broad scar down the West Bank lands to the east of Israel's pre-1967 border.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: INTERNET STOCK RISES Shares in EAccess, one of Japan's largest providers of high-speed Internet access, rose 61 percent on their first day of trading. The shares opened at 180,000 yen ($1,624) each and closed at 290,000 yen. The company, which had 1.1 million subscribers at the end of June, raised 7.2 billion yen ($65 million) in the offering. Company executives said their business started showing monthly profits during the summer. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Farm Equipment Maker Cuts Profit Outlook
description: The Agco Corporation, the farm equipment maker, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose less than forecast and that 2003 earnings would not meet estimates because of lower sales and production delays.

title: Mideast Peace: What Will It Take?
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Deride Bush and Dismiss One Another
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  The Democratic presidential hopefuls joined forces to attack President Bush on Friday by seizing on the Justice Department investigation into whether administration officials illegally disclosed the name of an undercover C.I.A. officer.

title: Mideast Peace: What Will It Take?
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvard Names New Museum Director
description: Thomas W. Lentz, director of the international art museums division at the Smithsonian Institution, has been named director of the Harvard University Art Museums, the university announced yesterday.

title: To New Jersey Officials' Scoffs, Most State High Schools Appear on U.S. Warning List
description: Three-quarters of New Jersey's 361 high schools have received warnings that they may be placed on the state's list of failing schools, education officials said on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOVANOVIC, KASNAR, TA TIANA
description: JOVANOVIC - KASNAR -- Ta tiana. Architect, died October 2, 2003. Grieving Dr. Vladimir Kasnar, husband, Maja Kasnar, daughter and Svetlana Misa, sister, with families Kasnar and Lalic. Funeral service will be on October 7, 2003, at 3 P.M., in Zagreb, Croatia. Memorial service date in NYC will be announced in time.

title: Philharmonic and Friends Explore Berlioz's 'Romo'
description: The New York Philharmonic made a large part of its contribution to the Berlioz bicentennial celebrations last season when Colin Davis visited to conduct ''Batrice et Bndict.'' But with the anniversary of this composer's birth still to come, on Dec. 11, the festivities aren't quite finished, and on Thursday evening Lorin Maazel put his orchestra at Berlioz's service once again, this time for a reading of ''Romo et Juliette'' (Op. 17).

title: Within Bounds
description: With his comment about Donovan McNabb, a quarterback for the Philadelphia Eagles, Rush Limbaugh has become the latest figure banished to the corner for being racist. ''The media has been very desirous that a black quarterback can do well,'' Limbaugh said Sunday on ESPN. By Wednesday he was gone from the network.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Offer For Phone Shares
description: Australia's biggest phone company, Telstra, offered to buy back stock for a premium to its recent price. Telstra said it would pay 4.20 to 5.40 Australian dollars a share for up to 1 billion Australian dollars ($678 million) worth of its stock. Telstra closed at 4.83 on Thursday and rose 3 percent after the repurchase offer was announced.

title: An Intrusion in Therapy
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Currency Rating Reviewed
description: Thailand's foreign-currency debt ratings may be raised from the lowest investment grade, Moody's Investors Service said, citing the expansion in the country's economy. Interest rates at a record low of 1.25 percent have fueled consumer spending and increased tax revenue. The finance ministry last week raised its growth forecast to 6.4 percent for the year, the fastest pace since 1995. Moody's long-term foreign-currency debt rating of Baa3 for Thailand has been unchanged since June 2000. Fitch Ratings last month raised Thailand's rating to the second-lowest investment grade. Standard & Poor's rates the country's debt BBB-, the lowest investment grade. The Thai baht, Asia's third-best-performing currency this year, surged as much as 0.7 percent to its strongest in more than two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, JONATHAN
description: GROSS--Jonathan, of Langhorne, PA, on Thursday, October 2, 2003; Beloved son of Martin M. and the late Phyllis Gross; devoted stepson of Arlene; fond stepbrother of Emily Scott Pottruck; dear nephew of Dina Simon and Augusta Citron. Services and Shiva will be private. Contributions may be made to the Phyllis Gross Fund, Woods Services, Langhorne, PA. 19047.

title: Foreigners' Rights In the Post-9/11 Era: A Matter of Justice
description: More than 5,000 citizens of foreign countries have been detained by the government since 9/11 in connection with anti-terrorism measures. Only a handful have been charged with a terror-related crime. Many were held initially without charges, denied access to lawyers, judged in secret and locked up for months without any showing that they had committed crimes or otherwise posed any danger. More than 500 were deported for immigration violations.

title: Corrections

title: VALUEACT CAPITAL OFFERS TO BUY REST OF ONESOURCE
description: ValueAct Capital Partners has offered to buy the rest of OneSource Information Services, a Web-based research-services company, for $72.3 million and take the company private. Peter Kamin, a ValueAct partner, in a letter on Wednesday to Martin Kahn, OneSource's chairman, offered $9.50 a share for the remaining stock, according to a regulatory filing. ValueAct, a closely held investment partnership, owns about a third of OneSource, the letter said. Taking OneSource private would allow it to ''concentrate on its long-term strategic prospects without the reporting obligations of a public company,'' Mr. Kamin wrote. Shares of OneSource rose 83 cents, to $9.52.

title: Former Credit Suisse Lawyer Says Banker Knew of Inquiry

Quattrone, a former Silicon Valley investment banker at the firm, was told about federal investigations into how the bank conducted stock offerings before he endorsed an e-mail message that prosecutors say led employees to destroy documents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHSTEIN, WARREN
description: ROTHSTEIN--Warren. Chabad's Children of Chernobyl mourns the untimely and sudden passing of a dear friend. Cherished Board Member, Warren Rothstein was one of our earliest supporters. His wise counsel and generosity of spirit, his open manner and deeply felt concern will be hugely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Deborah, his children Zachary and Brandon, and his entire family. Jay Schottenstein, Chairman Alan Clingman, President David Tessel, Chairman Exec Committee

title: A Role Best Denied
description: In California's rule-by-referendum, the governor and state legislators have long been of limited influence. The recall campaign that is -- finally -- coming to a conclusion has further demeaned the governor's office into something resembling a civic ducking stool. Time and hope remain for voters to defy recent polls and reject the recall of Gov. Gray Davis as a sorry indulgence.

description: It is a sign of the mania that surrounds Texas Longhorns football that Coach Mack Brown has become the namesake of a new generation.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: BUS ATTACKED Gunmen on motorcycles opened fire on a Karachi bus carrying Shiite Muslim employees of Pakistan's space agency, killing six and wounding six others, the police said. The attack occurred as the workers were on their way to a mosque. Suspicion fell immediately on Sunni Muslim extremists. (AP)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Union Spending
description: The Labor Department issued new final regulations that will require labor unions to disclose more information on how they spend money. The rules will require unions with income of more than $250,000 to itemize many expenses of $5,000 or more. Bush administration officials said the rules would fight union corruption and help union members see how their leaders were spending dues money. Labor officials said the rules sought to retaliate against unions for opposing President Bush. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: An obituary on Sept. 24 about Simcha Dinitz, a former Israeli ambassador to the United States, described his role during the 1973 Arab-Israeli war, in particular his negotiations with Secretary of State Henry Kissinger in attempts to arrange an airlift of American military supplies.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: NORTHERN IRELAND: I.R.A. DEADLINE SET David Trimble, leader of the largest Protestant political party, said that the Irish Republican Army must disarm within a week if elections to restore a home-rule government are to happen this year. In the past, the I.R.A. has rejected Mr. Trimble's ultimatums. Mr. Trimble has met with Gerry Adams, president of the I.R.A.'s political wing Sinn Fein, seven times in recent weeks in an attempt to restore enough confidence for a Nov. 13 vote. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Shares Climb on Enthusiasm Over Employment Figures
description: Stocks rose yesterday, completing their biggest weekly gain in more than four months, as the government reported the first increase in jobs since January, bolstering confidence that growth is accelerating enough to warrant higher share prices.

title: A Full Ride Can Have Its Bumps
description: After a 15-hour day of classes and football and a tiptoed goodnight kiss for his sleeping 2-year-old son, John Square organizes his bills: the $880 a month he pays for his off-campus apartment; the electric, phone and day care that quickly add up to $1,200. And that does not include groceries or laundry detergent or an increasingly rare night out for a hamburger with his wife, Shavon.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nintendo Expects A Loss
description: The video game maker Nintendo said it expected to lose 3 billion yen ($27 million) in the six-month period that ended Sept. 30 because of the rise in the yen against the dollar. Nintendo, which makes the Gameboy hand-held game machine, previously expected a profit of 15 billion yen. It said sales in the period were most likely 9 percent below its earlier forecast. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Sports Briefing: CROSS-COUNTRY; Kenyans Lead Iona
description: Richard Kiplagat, a sophomore from Kenya, won the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association five-mile cross-country race yesterday and led Iona to the team title at Van Cortlandt Park.

title: When the West Intrudes On a Moroccan Village
description: The imagery in ''A Thousand Months'' has a plaintive found-art beauty that Faouzi Bensadi, the director, uses as an elegant contradiction to the deftly woven story lines. This impressively structured melodrama, with daffy, character-revealing comic scenes, has its American premiere today at the New York Film Festival.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: PENSION MEASURE ADVANCES The cabinet of Silvio Berlusconi, Italy's prime minister, approved a bill that beginning in 2008 will raise to 40 from 35 the minimum number of years people must work if they want to collect a pension before reaching the standard retirement age of 65 for men and 60 for women. The bill still must be approved by Parliament, which is expected to rubber-stamp it since Mr. Berlusconi has a solid majority in both houses. Italy's largest trade unions have planned a four-hour general strike for Oct. 24 to protest the changes to the pension system. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: Sports Briefing: FIGURE SKATING; Cohen Defeats Kwan
description: Sasha Cohen made personal history last night in Madison Square Garden. For the first time in her career, the 19-year-old Cohen beat Michelle Kwan, the Californian who has won the world championship five times in the last eight years.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: High-Speed Link Questioned
description: The regional Legislature of Catalonia has requested an inquiry into the safety of Spain's new high-speed train line, which is to link the Catalan city of Lleida with Madrid and begin operating on Oct. 11. Two sinkholes, each about 20 feet in diameter, have formed along a stretch of the line. Geologists have warned that the line passes through land prone to collapse because of underground cavities. They lost forward Ronald Petrovicky and defenseman Shawn Heins to Atlanta and forward Jeff Heerema to St. Louis.

title: US AIRWAYS EXPECTS A LOSS IN THIRD QUARTER
description: US Airways, which emerged from bankruptcy protection this year, forecast a loss for its third quarter because revenue failed to increase as expected and storms forced flight cancellations, the company said. Revenue at the airline, based in Arlington, Va., ''is not coming back at the rate the company had hoped,'' the chief executive, David N. Siegel, told employees, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. US Airways faces challenges adding service with smaller aircraft, he said. Mr. Siegel also blamed increased low-cost carrier competition for the decline in sales. US Airways has been adding smaller planes, or regional jets, to its fleet to reduce costs and improve the match of seats available for sale to lower demand.

The changes bring the two companies' ratings in line as they form Konica Minolta Holdings. Konica's long-term rating was cut one notch, to Ba1, while Minolta's rating was raised to Ba1. The outlook for the holding company, which includes film and office equipment production, is positive, Moody's said. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Justice, Nigeria's Way
description: The reputation of Nigeria, not spotless to begin with, has once again been dragged through the mud with the case of Amina Lawal. Ms. Lawal is the 32-year-old woman who was sentenced by an Islamic court to be stoned to death for adultery, a sentence that was denounced by international rights groups and then, last week, overturned. While justice has been served in the case of Ms. Lawal, the world has been left with a skewed impression of the dangers posed by Islamic law, or Shariah, in Nigeria.

title: ITALIAN FASHION: A SPECIAL REPORT: Gucci is about Eve, snake and all

As sparkling snakes twined round the torso of little black dresses, wound in bracelets at the wrist and slithered across snaffle bags, the show looked polished and glamorous. Its mix of sport and womanly elegance was not innovative, but this sleek performance put Gucci back on track after a couple of floundering seasons.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: U.N. Help In Unexplained Killings
description: At the request of the government, a six-member team of United Nations investigators has traveled to Ciudad Jurez, on the Texas border, to make recommendations in an ongoing inquiry into the killings of more than 250 women in the past decade. The team said it had found that a lack of financial and professional resources among federal and state investigators, as well as inattention by government officials, had contributed to the failure to solve or stop the killings. Formal recommendations are expected this month. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

And no one ever refused to comment regarding an article I was writing because ''they didn't have money that week'' to pay for an advertisement.

title: The Party
description: Maybe the party began at Max's, circa 1966, or at the Factory around '63 -- deciding on a point of origin would be like trying to say who got the first hangover. In any case, by the mid-70's, the party was no longer an event but an institution, and pretty near the only one around. The city then was a ruin inhabited by scavengers, and going anywhere else involved some form of space travel. The night was dark, the streets were empty, the taxis were nowhere to be found, but there, all lighted up at the bottom of the alley, was the party. It was very, very loud. People had X's in place of eyes. Watches stopped working just inside the door. Saturday night could stretch into Wednesday. Drink tickets were legal tender, and dollars were good mainly for rolling into cylinders. Friendships were forged that might last for hours, possibly days. Your coat, tossed in a corner, was as good as gone. If you were at the party, chances are that you remember it in discontinuous flashes, if at all.

Greene officiated at the Cedar Hill Country Club in Livingston, N.J.

description: JOVANOVIC - KASNAR -- Ta tiana. Architect, died October 2, 2003. Grieving Dr. Vladimir Kasnar, husband, Maja Kasnar, daughter and Svetlana Misa, sister, with families Kasnar and Lalic. Funeral service will be on October 7, 2003, at 3 P.M., in Zagreb, Croatia. Memorial service date in NYC will be announced in time.

title: From Pink Slip to Owner
description: UNWILLING to uproot their families and restart their careers in a distant location, several men from a Newtown manufacturing plant that closed last summer managed to save 50 jobs by acquiring a machine shop where they had each logged an average of 20 years' experience.

title: Add Country Inns To Waterfront Projects
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''These guys will be at home, they'll be at parties, they'll be at christenings, and they'll have to leave to go buy a gun. If we don't buy it, someone else is going to buy it.''

title: 'The Eternal Road,' In Endless Quest of a Stage
description: ''THE ETERNAL ROAD,'' Max Reinhardt's lavish pageant of Jewish biblical history and seemingly timeless persecution, was first staged in 1937 and has fascinated conductors and impresarios ever since. But no one has yet managed to create a stage production that has come even close to the one Reinhardt created at the Manhattan Opera House (now the Hammerstein Ballroom, home of rock concert spectacles).

title: On Living in Westchester Versus New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: Holmgren Spruces Up For Green Bay Return
description: He had never been vulnerable, not as a coach. Victory immunized him. A Super Bowl title canonized him.

title: The Nation: Park Avenue Proletarians; Every Four Years, Blue Bloods Put on a Blue Collar
description: IN 1908, the populist presidential candidate William Jennings Bryan had an idea: he'd expose the Republican nominee, the rotund Ohioan Robert Taft, as a rich elitist by using pictures of him playing golf. Golf! The sport of blue bloods.

title: Page Two: Sept. 28-Oct. 4; Limbaugh, Hot TV and the Envelope of Sanity
description: INVITING Rush Limbaugh to be the loudest mouth on ESPN's ''Sunday NFL Countdown'' should have shocked no one who has watched the genre of pregame studio programs evolve from polite analysis of National Football League games to pigskin midways featuring comedians (Fox and HBO), a buxom weathergirl (Fox), a studio audience (CBS), mini-gridirons (Fox and CBS) and game-show buzzers (CBS).

title: NOBEL HANDICAPPING
description: On Friday, the Nobel committee will announce the winner of its Peace Prize for 2003. Nobel watchers say there is no clear front-runner, but a few names keep cropping up.

title: Paperback Advice
description: This

title: The Safe House
description: AMERICAN WOMAN

title: A Mall on a Las Vegas Bridge
description: Shopping has become one of Las Vegas's favorite pastimes, with over three million square feet of high-end retail space built since 1998. And the new Mandalay Place opening over the next few weeks will bring 41 stores, shops and restaurants to the south end of the Las Vegas Strip.

title: After a Flood and a Brief Exile, The Ziegfeld Girls' Club Returns
description: Tomorrow, a New York story with overtly Biblical plot points (a house of God, dancing ladies, a flood, exile) will end, fittingly, on a note of redemption, when the Ziegfeld Club returns to Central Presbyterian Church on Park Avenue.

title: Desperate Pass Gives Columbia The Victory
description: The final horn above the scoreboard had blown, and Columbia quarterback Jeff Otis was still dancing in his backfield, looking to find a receiver, any receiver. So he flung the ball as far as he could. A perfect spiral resulted in a perfect finish Saturday night.

title: Yanks' Aces Send Twins' Offense on a Big Swing Downward
description: Platitudes and clichs came from all parts of the Twins' clubhouse Saturday. But the closest thing to honesty was available only at Torii Hunter's locker.

title: Nora Feeley, Coleman Brinckerhoff
description: Nora Sybrandt Feeley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon V. Feeley of Merritt Island, Fla., was married on Friday in Pocantico Hills, N.Y., to Coleman Merritt Brinckerhoff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Remson Brinckerhoff of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Dr. F. Paul DeHoff, a Presbyterian minister, performed a nondenominational Christian ceremony at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills.

title: A Centennial Debate Over Piano Titans
description: IT'S hard to convey the incredulous excitement stirred in the classical music world when an announcement came, in the spring of 1965, that Vladimir Horowitz would emerge from a self-imposed, 12-year retirement and play a recital at Carnegie Hall. For a new generation of concertgoers, especially fledgling pianists like me, Horowitz was a legend from a bygone era of Russian Romantic virtuosity. That I would someday actually hear him perform was almost as much a fantasy as someday hearing the Beatles.

title: A Mall in Las Vegas; White House Tours; Halloween in New England
description: AMall on a Las Vegas Bridge

title: The Nation: Footwear Politics; Just Who, Really, Is a Birkenstock Voter?
description: AT some point on the campaign route to Iowa and New Hampshire, the name Howard Dean yoked itself to a shoe -- specifically, to a unisex sandal already married in the public consciousness to diversions like mud baths. Birkenstock first surfaced as a political adjective this summer when reporters, surveying the crowds at Dean rallies, began to refer to Dr. Dean's constituents by their presumed footwear preference: the ''Birkenstock liberals.''

title: Yankees Beat Twins; Red Sox Hold Off A's
description: Roger Clemens pitched the Yankees to a 3-1 victory over the Twins yesterday and a 2-1 edge in their American League division series. Also in the A.L., the Red Sox stayed alive by defeating the Athletics, 3-1, in 11 innings. In the National League, the Marlins knocked out the Giants,7-6, to move into the League Championship Series. The Braves averted elimination by beating the Cubs, 6-4.

title: Finding a Niche in Antique Reproductions
description: THOMAS ROMANO was fresh out of college when he announced to his mother in 1989 that he had a plan to transform her antiques importing and retail furniture company. His idea: Wean the company from antiques, which were becoming increasingly expensive, and begin manufacturing reproductions overseas.

title: LOSS OF HIGHWAY FUNDS
description: The state stands to lose $7.2 million in federal highway aid after legislators missed a deadline last week to approve bills that would lower the legal blood-alcohol limit for drivers. In order to receive federal money, the state must lower its alcohol standard from 0.10 percent to 0.08 percent, or risk forfeiting 2 percent of highway aid. A spokesman for the State Department of Transportation said the loss would be recovered if the Legislature approved the tighter standard in its next session. If not, the federal government could withhold $14.4 million next year. Jeremy Pearce

title: Assemblywoman Acampora To Lead Suffolk Republicans
description: Assemblywoman Patricia L. Acampora of Mattituck was elected the chairwoman of the Suffolk County Republican Committee on Sept. 26, becoming the county party's third leader in seven months. She is the first woman to lead the county party in either Suffolk or Nassau.

title: Jeanne Yu, David Robinson Jr.
description: Dr. Jeanne J. Yu, the daughter of Dr. Linda Yu and Dr. Chang-An Yu of Stillwater, Okla., was married last evening to David Graham Robinson Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robinson of Boston. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Colony Club in New York.

title: It Wasn't the Final Curtain After All
description: FRANK SINATRA was always larger than life. Now he's larger than death. ''He's back . . .'' trumpet the ads for a new spectacular, ''Frank Sinatra: His Voice, His World, His Way,'' to be unveiled on Wednesday at Radio City Music Hall.

title: The Nation; Beam Us Up, General Clark
description: WEIRD things certainly happen during election season, but it's doubtful that even the most hardened seen-it-all pundit would have dreamed that Einstein's theory of relativity would turn up as an issue in an American presidential campaign.

title: Paperback Highlights
description: FICTION | NONFICTION

title: A Diaspora of Young Israelis, Decompressing
description: IN an art gallery converted from an auto repair shop in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a few dozen young people milled about in chic black eyeglasses and designer sneakers. They laughed and swirled wine in plastic cups. Some dipped into a Brie wheel. The artist whose opening was being celebrated, a lanky 26-year-old with disheveled hair and ponderous eyes, darted around explaining his installation.

title: PAYING FOR OPEN SPACE
description: Pushing his anti-sprawl initiative, Governor McGreevey urged voters to support a referendum in the November election that would allow the state's Garden State Preservation Trust to borrow more money to preserve open space. Officials estimate that current sales and use tax revenue would allow the agency to borrow up to another $150 million at low interest rates without any more expense to residents. The additional financing would supplement $1 billion the voters approved in 1998. George James

title: The Untouchables
description: Last May, Mayor Michael Bloomberg, facing an almost $4 billion budget gap, made the difficult decision to close six New York City firehouses -- including one in Williamsburg, Brooklyn: Engine Company 212, popularly known as the People's Firehouse. Neighborhood residents refused to take it lying down. By the fall, some three months after the closings -- and long after demonstrations at the five other closed houses (in Harlem, Brooklyn and Queens) had faded -- the protest at Engine Company 212 was still going strong. Firefighters and local residents draped the facade of the two-story, redbrick building on a scrubby section of Wythe Avenue with banners reading ''fire cuts kill'' and ''budgets slashed, brooklyn burned.'' In a tent on the sidewalk in front of the firehouse, volunteers from the neighborhood took turns sleeping each night. By day, they collected signatures on a petition, determined to get their firehouse reopened.

title: Sir Paul's Little Girl Opens in Los Angeles
description: ON the driveway leading to the back garden at 8823 Beverly Boulevard last Sunday night, a hot-dog cart stocked with vegetarian wieners was on hand to feed the guests at the opening of the designer Stella McCartney's West Hollywood boutique. Across from the cart stood a fun-house mirror to let them see how they would look tall and thin. (As if that were necessary.)

title: Bryant Seems to Be Losing Touch With His Teammates
description: The occasion was a backyard mixer about a week ago, and the place was the Beverly Hills cul-de-sac where Shaquille O'Neal lives. After a turbulent summer for the Los Angeles Lakers, O'Neal, the team's center and leader, decided to welcome the families of his new teammates Karl Malone and Gary Payton -- and create a friendly, stress-free environment for Kobe Bryant, who is free on bail.

title: Adventures in Democracy: Blasts From the Past
description: The call and response of a heated political campaign rose in crescendo late in the week in the California recall. Just days before the vote on Tuesday, Arnold Schwarzenegger, believed to be the front-runner, was put on the defensive.

title: So, How Many Big Personalities Can Fit on a Stage?
description: Jason Jennings, a writer and consultant, is gearing up to play second fiddle once again. On Oct. 15, he will share the stage with Gen. Wesley K. Clark, the presidential aspirant, and Steve Forbes, the billionaire publisher. Mr. Jennings will be one of the speakers at a gathering of business leaders in Las Vegas, called the Better Management Live Worldwide conference.

title: Editors' Note; Your Assignment: More Homework
description: Did you do your homework? If so, the Long Island section would like to hear from you. Think back to the best homework assignment you ever had (or maybe the worst). The assignment could have come from an English teacher, a dance instructor, a bar mitzvah coach. Maybe you finished it five days ago; maybe you finished it 45 years ago. Why was it memorable? How did it improve your mind or character?

title: Deals and Discounts
description: WORTH RECALLING -- The voting that may see California get a new governor is scheduled for Tuesday. And for those who want to visit the epicenter of it all, the convention and visitors bureau in Sacramento, the state capital, has Discover Gold packages that combine a room at 19 participating hotels with a coupon book good for savings at attractions, events and restaurants. Rates start at $64 a night at the Quality Inn, and among the other hotels available are the AmeriSuites ($65), the Hyatt Regency ($89 weekdays, $169 weekends), the Hilton Garden Inn ($79), the Holiday Inn Rancho Cordova ($79), the Sheraton Grand ($99) and the Embassy Suites ($119). The coupons are good for half-price admission to the Sacramento Zoo, two-for-one tickets at nine performing-arts sites and other values. Some hotels include breakfast. For information: (800) 359-3653 or www.discovergold.org.

title: Eileen Mullen, Robert Wolejsza Jr.
description: Eileen Patricia Mullen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mullen of Jackson Heights, Queens, is to be married today to Robert Louis Wolejsza Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wolejsza of Astoria, Queens. The Rev. Barry W. Frazzitta is to perform the ceremony at St. Joan of Arc Roman Catholic Church in Jackson Heights.

title: A Way Out
description: To the Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2004 Porsche Cayenne Turbo and Cayenne S; Taking Midlife Crises to New Places
description: SPORTS car buyers are a fickle lot, their purchases rising and falling with the economy. While a Porsche is often the self-prescribed treatment for a midlife crisis, Prozac may be a more affordable alternative when times are tough.

title: On Campus, a Security Card and More
description: KEYS have become pass at Quinnipiac University. The private school in Hamden went digital this year, installing hotel-style security locks on doors and allowing students to access everything from dorm rooms to meals using a card-swipe system that records their every move.

title: The First Couple of Albee, and Now of Beckett
description: HOW fitting that Marian Seldes should speak of love.

title: Windex and Ziploc, And Value Investing
description: THE S. C. Johnson family built its privately held empire on products like Johnson Wax and Raid, then expanded by acquiring other companies at a reasonable cost, adding household names like Windex and Ziploc. But that is by no means the extent of the Johnson family's reach: it is also in financial services and runs four small mutual funds, the JohnsonFamily Funds.

title: Sports of The Times; It's Most Unlikely That Red Sox Fans Will Enjoy the Moment
description: THIS is all a plot, designed to make Red Sox fans suffer even more exquisitely. That is the only way to look at the way the Sox stayed alive last night after the Oakland A's had fumbled away their chances with jittery hands and addled minds.

title: Familiar Prejudices Against Immigrants
description: Re ''In Island's Wealthiest Area, Backlash Against the Poorest'' [Sept. 28]: I was surprised to read about a resident's objection to her daughter being taught Spanish on the elementary school level due to the ''invasion'' of illegal immigrants. Pedagogical theory attests to the fact that the younger children are when they begin to acquire a second language, the more likely they are to retain that knowledge. Current brain research in education also supports this theory. It makes one wonder if the students in Southampton who are also required to study violin on the elementary level are forced to do so as a result of an ''invasion'' of classical musicians in our area.

title: As It Is Written So It Is Viewed
description: IN THE NEWS

title: Wild, Wild West In Bethany (That Would Be West of Hartford)
description: AS a cow ran around the arena, two cowboys on horseback chased after it, twirling ropes. Within seconds, one cowboy roped the cow's attached plastic horns. Then the other roped its back feet, and the crowd cheered.

title: Quicksilver
description: Enoch rounds the corner just as the executioner raises the noose above the woman's head. The crowd on the Common stop praying and sobbing for just as long as Jack Ketch stands there, elbows locked, for all the world like a carpenter heaving a ridge-beam into place. The rope clutches a disk of blue New England sky. The Puritans gaze at it and, to all appearances, think. Enoch the Red reins in his borrowed horse as it nears the edge of the crowd, and sees that the executioner's purpose is not to let them inspect his knotwork, but to give them all a narrow - and, to a Puritan, tantalizing - glimpse of the portal through which they all must pass one day.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Builder of Upscale Homes Is Active in Several Cities
description: LAST February, Annette Mostato, an insurance investigator who works in Manhattan and had been commuting an hour and a half from her home in Carmel, N.Y., moved even farther out. Now she commutes two hours from her new two-bedroom town house in Danbury. ''There's a price you have to pay for good living,'' she said. ''I live alone, and it's wonderful to know I'm coming home at night to a country club and the birdies chirping.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DISKINT, EVELYN
description: DISKINT--Evelyn. On October 4, 2003. Beloved wife of Joseph. Devoted mother of Robert (Christina) and Peter (Joni). Cherished grandmother of Michael, Julia, James, Nathaniel and Jeremiah. Service Sunday, October 12, 2 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Yanks Break The Tension, and Then The Twins
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 5 - The bases were loaded, with two outs and two strikes, and any chance the Minnesota Twins had of surviving depended on this at-bat. The Metrodome fans rose and yelled, 55,875 people in a collective Sunday prayer.

title: Dobbs Ferry Gas Station Site To Make Way for the New
description: A former gas station and automobile repair shop, at the intersection of Route 9 and Ashford Avenue in Dobbs Ferry, will be torn down by the building's new owner, Bruno Maida. In the past, the village has entertained proposals to open a Starbucks and a sandwich shop on the property, which has been vacant for three years.

title: Enclave Is Split on Makeovers
description: ON one level, historic preservation supported by residents of a neighborhood for the common good (translation: higher property values) would seem to be the kind of thing that's not particularly controversial. But in one neighborhood in Yonkers, people are finding that their small enclave of 147 homes has been roiled by differing opinions about what is truly in the common good.

title: Lopsided 401(k)'s, All Too Common
description: IN a ruling last week, Judge Melinda Harmon of Federal District Court in Houston put corporate executives on notice that they may be responsible if their employees' 401(k) plans are destroyed by fraud or mismanagement.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IN the world of FAR FROM HEAVEN (2002), Todd Haynes's lush tribute to 1950's ''women's movies,'' the fall foliage complements the women's color-coordinated hats, dresses, shoes and bags; the suburban wives have daiquiris at lunch; a local society newspaper can praise a woman for her ''kindness to Negroes''; and Elmer Bernstein's music swells whenever the family station wagon has somewhere important to go. Julianne Moore and Dennis Quaid play Cathy and Frank Whitaker, a picture-perfect Connecticut couple whose lives change when Cathy learns about Frank's secret forays into homosexuality. ''I promise you, Dr. Bowman,'' Frank tells his newly hired psychiatrist, ''I am going to beat this thing.'' Dennis Haysbert is the black gardener Kathy confides in. Patricia Clarkson is great as Cathy's best friend, who will stand by her through anything. Up to a point -- Saturday at 9 p.m. on Starz.

title: The Changing Tune Of the TV Theme Song
description: A great television theme song is more than just a jingle: it's a chunk of happy shrapnel lodged in the brain, creating nostalgia for even the worst TV series. Who remembers ''The Greatest American Hero''? But ''Believe it or not, I'm walking on air'' is still running through my head, 20 years later.

title: Flying Not-So-Small Model Airplanes
description: ON a workbench at Cedar Creek Park Aerodrome in Seaford, Joe Di Prima stood his Russian Sukhoi on its nose. Mr. Di Prima tightened its 80-inch wings into place and checked the two-cycle glow engine on the 12-pound scale model of the Russian aerobatic airplane he built from a kit, adding a mix of methanol and castor oil through a thin plastic tube. The pre-flight check went off without a hitch.

title: What Goes With What?
description: The party season revives a basic problem: which wines match which foods? ''The Renaissance Guide to Wine and Food Pairing'' by Tony DiDio and Amy Zavatto (Alpha Books, $18.95), both New Yorkers, offers smart advice, like tuna with dolcetto (red) or albario (white); artichokes with arneis (a white) from Piedmont, Italy; and shepherd's pie with a Rioja reserva (red). The guide is in local bookstores. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: State Has Film Industry All Locked Up
description: FOR filmmakers, planning a shoot is all about the three L's: location, location, location. When a ski scene calls for a winter mountain, they converge on Aspen. If neon and slots are the order, they go to Las Vegas. And if they need a good prison, more and more often, they come to New Jersey.

title: Temptations For the Table
description: If you want to use Long Island bottles to dress up the table at a dinner party, a decorative grouping would consist of Lenz's 2001 gewrztraminer; Lenz's 2001 Blanc de Noir, a seldom encountered ros; and Bedell Cellars' 2002 viognier.

title: Helping Afghan Children Fuels His Dramatic Desires
description: PLAYWRIGHTS, cover your ears; one of your own, William Mastrosimone, is giving away his work again.

title: America and Islam, in the Mirror
description: To the Editor:

title: In Funds' Hands, Value Stocks Often Lose Their Luster
description: OVER time, value stocks tend to outperform growth stocks. But, oddly, mutual funds made up of value stocks do not outperform those made up of growth stocks. How can that be?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOWNSEND, FELICIA T.
description: TOWNSEND--Felicia T. Died at age 94 on September 27, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Edward Townsend and the late Eduardo Andrade. Mother of Jose E. Andrade and Lydia A. de Sanctis and the late Maria F. Andrade. Mother-inlaw of Malle T. Andrade and Francesco M. de Sanctis. Stepmother of Rosalind T. Hodgkins and Victoria T. Roschen. Stepmother-in-law of Robert C. Hodgkins and William E. Roschen. Grandmother of Eduardo N. T. Andrade, Pier Francesco de Sanctis, Jose Andrade and Felicia M. de Sanctis. Grandmother-inlaw of Christine M. Andrade and Sophie M. de Sanctis. Step-grandmother of Mary Samantha Vermeer, Stephen Walsh, Alexandra Couillard and Rosalind Hodgkins. Stepgrandmother-in-law of Todd Vermeer, Kristin Walsh and Jay Couillard. Interment private. A memorial service for family and friends will be held at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 5th Avenue at 53rd Street, Thursday, October 9, 2003 at 12:45 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Westtown School, PO Box 1799, Westtown, PA 19395.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMOOT, WILLIAM SIDNEY
description: SMOOT--William Sidney, on October 1st, 2003 at age 89. Husband of Katharine S. for 57 years. Father of Sally Smoot Ingraham; grandfather of David Smoot Ingraham and Sarah Jennings Ingraham; brother of Charles Head Smoot and the late Barbara Smoot Ross. A mechanical and electrical engineer, he was an associate in Seelye Stevenson Value & Kneckt and later partner in Wall & Smoot Consulting Engineers. Among his civic and community activities he served as Mayor of the Village of Laurel Hollow from 1969 to 1985 and as President of Action for the Preservation and Conservation of the North Shore of Long Island. Funeral at St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, 11 AM Monday, October 6. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Keeping a Helping Hand Out
description: FOR almost 20 years, A-HOME, a nonprofit organization working to provide solutions to affordable housing, has rehabilitated houses in a variety of neighborhoods, respecting the character of the neighborhood and the concerns of the neighbors. Homes in Bedford Hills, Chappaqua, Croton Falls, Katonah, Mount Kisco, Thornwood and Vista provide housing to the elderly, the disabled and single-parent families.

title: The City of Stories Again
description: As anyone who has ever moved here knows, New York is famously tough on its newcomers. For most of us -- whether born in Lubbock or Laos -- it is, at first glance, a source of endless intimidation, as indecipherable and unattainable as a well-bred East Coast lover. But time somehow collapses in New York, and within a decade the unattainable becomes commonplace, the love you feel for an impossible mistress turns into something like the love of a middle-aged child for an ailing parent. ''She has good days and bad days,'' we can say of the city, shocked that a figure that once lorded over us with such a mixture of authority and indifference can, in her weakened state, bring about our compassion and swift allegiance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOLLAND, MRS. ESTELLE
description: HOLLAND--Mrs. Estelle. Of Houston, Texas, died on October 2, 2003. The loving wife, for more than 65 years, of the late George Holland, mother of Ira and Maria, Peter and Merle, grandmother of Matthew, Lizza, John and Kate, great-grandmother of Harris, and a beloved friend to many. She will be missed by all of us who spent time with this truly special person.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a trend among the states to reduce prison sentences and give judges wider discretion, even as the Bush administration does the opposite for federal crimes, misstated the size of the California budget. It is $71.1 billion, not a trillion dollars.

title: Religion and Politics Blur With Sharpton in Pulpit
description: The Rev. Melvin Brown was up at the pulpit one Sunday morning last month, in front of his congregation at the Greater New Hope Baptist Church in Washington, exhorting his followers to give money, cash or checks, to the Rev. Al Sharpton. He wanted big donations.

title: Something Rotten in Brookhaven
description: IT is hard to hear Patricia Strebel proclaim her innocence and doubt her.

title: Sports of The Times; World Series As Product Placement
description: HE emerged from a Metrodome luxury box with dark glasses, a turned-up collar on his windbreaker and his head down, but this secret-agent attire couldn't fool the cornfed herd of Twin loyalists plodding toward the exits.

description: THE GREAT UNRAVELING

description: SOME prominent Americans said this time would come, and now it is here: the season when American staying power in Iraq is being seriously tested.

description: 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath detached colonial at 101-39 107th Street, $319,000.

description: ROBBINS--Rex. We mourn the loss of our good friend who died on September 23 in South Dakota. We extend our condolences to his wife, Pat, and to their children, Maggie, Tim and Tory. The Yale Dramat Alumni Associates
