description: IS there more stretch in the SOX?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RAY, MARGARET
description: RAY--Margaret. Dear Mom, on the 5th anniversary of your death, your legacy lives on in the love and work of your children. Your granddaughter, Sheela Louise, is being raised with all the love you gave me. I miss you every day and continue to work for the mentally ill in your name. Anna-Lisa Johanso

title: Hardcover Advice
description: This

title: Habitats/Mercer Street in SoHo; 1 Loft, 2 Businesses, Twins and 1 Marriage
description: RONALD DELICE was born first, a full 10 seconds before his twin brother, Rony. On a Tuesday morning not too long ago, it was Ronald who led a tour of the brothers' live-and-work space, a mostly pumpkin-colored loft on Mercer Street in SoHo out of which they produce their men's-wear line, called, simply enough, Ron & Ron.

title: Some Hardy Survivors to Add to Your Garden
description: WHEN people think of hydrangeas, they tend to envision the ubiquitous big-leaf variety that bursts with blue or pink blossoms in summer, or the popular peegee hydrangeas), whose white cones start flowering in fall.

title: White House Eases Restrictions on Tours
description: Visitors can once again tour the White House, if they arrange the visit through a member of Congress and pass a Secret Service security check. All tours were suspended immediately after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks; only a few categories of visitor, such as schoolchildren and military groups and veterans, have been allowed to tour the building since then.

title: In the Country With Chabrol
description: WHEN I finally saw Claude Chabrol standing in the doorway holding the phone, I was surprised by his jovial, rotund appearance and the friendly courtesy of his welcome. He was laughing, because we had almost driven past him. Just as he had predicted, the taxi driver had gotten lost on the way to his house in Anjou, in the Loire Valley, so we had wandered quite a while in the legendary countryside, one of the most enchanting in France, studded with medieval cities, churches, vineyards and thousands of castles. The birds -- so many birds -- the softness of the air, the sky . . . no, it's pointless to even attempt to convey the sweetness of that landscape. The ride would have seemed almost unbearably lovely had it not been marred by the tormenting anxiety of being late, so I knew that I had already entered Chabrol-world, where beauty so often masks evil and where serene surfaces invariably yield up hidden recesses replete with secrets of the darkest, most agonizing sort.

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: Simply Nothing Short of Astonishing
description: IFIRST met George Plimpton when he arrived for what might have been the nuttiest golf tournament in history. It was a charity event in Flint, Mich., put on by Alex Karras, the hefty, zany defensive tackle for the Detroit Lions. Now, I didn't actually attend the outing. I read about it about 35 years ago in an article that Plimpton had written for Harper's Magazine. But reading Plimpton, seeing what he saw and hearing what he heard with his astonishing eye and ear - "astonishing" being one of his favorite words, though he was too self-deprecating ever to refer to himself in that way - was tantamount to being there, maybe even better.

title: The Meltingest Pot
description: The building at 59-21 Calloway Street in Corona, Queens, is grandly named the Calloway Chteau, but it is really the 21st-century version of Ludlow Street, the first stop off the long-haul plane from Bukhara or Bombay. You put your bags down here, a half-hour's drive on the Grand Central Parkway from J.F.K., and pause to gather breath for the journey into the hinterland.

title: Taylor Holliday, Craig Havighurst
description: Poleda Taylor Holliday and Craig Perryman Havighurst were married yesterday by the Rev. William T. Friskics-Warren, a Disciples of Christ minister, at the Country Music Hall of Fame in Nashville.

title: Alexa Adams, Eric Shea
description: Dr. Alexa Brett Adams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Adams of New York, was married yesterday to Eric Kenning Shea, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Kenning Shea of Canandaigua, N.Y. The Rev. John T. Ames officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in East Hampton, N.Y., with the Rev. James Coughlin, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

It was a phantom designation conceived by military planners to meet the anxious demands of war.

Mr. Song, a 59-year-old professor of philosophy, was greeted with bouquets at the airport and an invitation to a reception at the Blue House, South Korea's presidential offices. The Korea Broadcasting System, the state television network, created a documentary, ''Return of the Exiles,'' featuring Mr. Song and 33 other returning South Koreans.

An up-and-coming group called the Juilliard String Quartet gave the inaugural recital, followed by the pianist Rosalyn Tureck, the violinist Joseph Fuchs, and an ensemble from the New York Philharmonic.

title: Where Nobody Knows You're a Music Thief
description: IMAGINE that you sell newspapers on the honor system. You put some papers out on a table, along with a can for the money. It would surprise hardly anyone if, at the end of the day, more papers were taken than were paid for.

title: Back to the Future
description: Nineteen seventy-seven. I remember it well. It was the year Son of Sam stalked the streets of New York before he was finally arrested. It was the year of the blackout, when looters rampaged in the face of an overwhelmed New York Police Department, its ranks depleted because of the city's budget cuts. And it was the year I moved to New York.

title: Police Subdue a Tiger
description: A police sniper rappelled down the side of a Harlem apartment building yesterday and fired tranquilizer darts through an open fifth-floor window at a 350-pound Bengal tiger.

title: VERNIERO RETIRES
description: Announcing his retirement from the State Supreme Court, Justice Peter Verniero said last week that he was leaving the bench to re-enter the private sector. Justice Verniero, 44, said that he planned to depart next August, two years before he would be due to face reappointment proceedings. He was appointed to the $158,500-a-year position in 1999. Previously, while serving as the state attorney general under Gov. Christie Whitman, Justice Verniero was criticized for delaying a probe into state police use of racial profiling to detain minority motorists. A later state report found that such profiling was pervasive. Jeremy Pearce

She is survived by her brother Roger Warner, her children Karen Weiss, Robin Weiss, Peter Weiss and Jenifer Weiss, her stepchildren Terence Smith and Catherine Smith O'Maera, daughters-in-law Beth Ruland, Ruth Tobiassen and Elli Sher, 10 grandchildren, five great-grandchildren and her dear friend Peggy Slocum. Her son Kim Weiss predeceased her. A memorial service will be held in Albany at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUNLOP, JOHN T.
description: DUNLOP--John T. Of Belmont, MA, on October 2, 2003, at the age of 89. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy W. Dunlop; father of John B. Dunlop, Beverly D. Donohue and Thomas F. Dunlop; Grandfather of Maria Tobias, John S., Olga and Catherine Dunlop, Michael and Philip Donohue; great-grandfather of Elizabeth and Gregory Tobias, John B. and Jacob Dunlop and Sophia Muys; Lamont University Professor Emeritus of Harvard University; distinguished economist, expert in labor, management and government relations and dispute resolution; public servant; formerly Secretary of Labor, Director of the Cost of Living Council, Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences at Harvard University and chairman of the Harvard Economics Department; Chairman of the Massachusetts Joint Labor-Management Committee for Municipal Police and Fire. His family deeply mourns his loss and draws strength from his life. A private funeral will be followed by a memorial service at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the John T. Dunlop Fund at the Labor and Worklife Program, Harvard Law School, 1350 Massachusetts Avenue, Suite 731, Cambridge, MA 02138. For information Brown & Sons Funeral Home, Belmont.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUNNEWELL, RICHARD FARNSWORTH
description: HUNNEWELL -- Richard Farnsworth on September 29, age 81, in Newport, RI. Son of the late Emmeline Ticknor and James Frothingham Hunnewell of Boston, Richard graduated from St. Paul's School and Harvard College. He served in WW II as a Navy Lieutenant on the destroyer Charles J. Badger. After the war, he moved to New York where he married Rosalie Clark in 1949. He joined the Hanover Bank (later the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co.) in 1957, retiring in 1983; he then worked at the English Speaking Union until 1992. He was predeceased by his wife Rosalie in 1970 and by his second wife, Julie Desloge Haggerty in 1993. He is survived by his wife, Martha Sulzby Clark, by two children, Sarah Hunnewell, of Water Mill, NY, and John Hunnewell, of South Londonderry, VT, by two grandchildren, Mark and Priscilla Hunnewell, and by eight stepchildren. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, October 7 at Trinity Church in Newport, RI. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Redwood Library and Athenaeum, 50 Bellevue Avenue, Newport, Rhode Island 02840.

title: The Metaphysical Poets, Recited on the Fens
description: SOME plays write their meanings large, with bald-faced thesis statements or characters that are clear stand-ins for the author. Jez Butterworth's ''Night Heron,'' on the other hand, works by allusion, ellipses and an appeal to the imagination. It left a good many British critics bewildered when it opened at the Royal Court Theater in London some 18 months ago.

Partly, this was because of his youthful good looks, beautiful family and extraordinary charisma, and partly because he carried with him so many hopes for a brighter, better future. To many Americans, including artists, he seemed like the model president.

He was a true confidante, advisor and trusted friend. Jay enjoyed life and people to the fullest. He devoted over half a century to Revlon, where he played a major management role from the company's modest beginnings to its huge success. He will be greatly missed and forever warmly remembered. Funeral services were held on Occtober 2, 2003.

title: THE NIGHT HERON
description: ''THE NIGHT HERON'' by the British playwright Jez Butterworth, opening on Tuesday at the Atlantic Theater Company, tells the story of best friends who are barely surviving the winter in a ramshackle cabin in bleak countryside east of Cambridge University. Wattmore (Chris Bauer), who is under the spell of a religious cult leader named Dougal, and his protective pal Griffin (Clark Gregg) are unemployed gardeners. When a gruff lodger moves in, the play is injected with Pinteresque menace tinged with a biblical sense of doom. In this excerpt, the fateful visitor is first mentioned.

title: Paris
description: Every fall, France adopts a new theme for the winter's cultural focus. This year's Anne de la Chine, inaugurated tomorrow, promises to be the most extravagant and eclectic so far. The actors Gong Li and Jackie Chan are honorary patrons of a nine-month nonstop festival bringing Chinese opera, circus and ballet -- plus museum exhibits devoted to Chinese history, art and pop culture -- to cities throughout France.

title: Out of Step and Having a Baby
description: ''YOU don't have to be a hero here,'' my friend Jane said, stroking my arm. ''This is your future, the rest of your life. Don't throw it all away.'' She took my hand solemnly. ''You don't have to have this baby, you know.''

title: Streetscapes/Art Students League at 215 West 57th Street; An 1892 Limestone-Fronted Building That Endures
description: ''ARS longa . . .'' goes the saying, even though the architectural history of New York is full of artistic buildings that have not endured. But the Art Students League of New York, which is part way into a multiyear renovation of its 1892 building at 215 West 57th Street, has taken an unusual tack in this direction.

title: An Overstretched Army in Iraq
description: Now that it is clear the United States faces a lengthy military occupation of Iraq, requiring perhaps 100,000 troops for the foreseeable future, it is possible to begin calculating how the war may damage the American armed forces. Since the United States cannot expect much additional help from other countries or from the fledgling Iraqi security forces, the burdens of occupation will start to strain severely the Army's capacity to deploy trained and rested combat forces worldwide in a matter of months. In the longer term, the lives of thousands of military families will be disrupted, the Army Reserve system so carefully built up when America moved to a smaller, volunteer Army three decades ago will be put at severe risk and the global reach of American foreign policy will almost inevitably be diminished.

title: Editorial Observer; Stumbling Upon Wolf Tracks in the Northern Reaches of Yellowstone
description: Three weeks ago I saw two wolf tracks in the mud of a creek bank high in Yellowstone National Park. It was old mud, from the last time the creek had overrun its banks, but the tracks had blurred only slightly. Each one was larger than my hand, fingers outstretched. Rain and snow blew in squalls across the valley, near the northern edge of the park. The long gravel beach was as gray as the clouds overhead, which dimmed and brightened minute by minute. I bent down to look at the tracks again and then returned to my fishing. But before long I reeled in and walked back over to the mud flat, just to reassure myself that the tracks were really there. They were.

title: Temptations
description: IF one can read a place by its dessert case, Lilly's on the Canal is a good study. Front and center, the impeccably clean glass case holds riches enough to confound any diner: A mountainous cake with layers of creamy white, frosted with abandon and bristling with shaved coconut; the even taller seven-layer chocolate cake with its dark, glistening frosting; the rustic apple pie in a Pyrex plate with its thick slices of local apples peeking from a curtain of crunchy crumbs; the demure crme brulees in their own little dishes; the rice pudding given depth with shreds of coconut.

title: The Cat Stevens Countdown

She is pining not for a person, but for her homeland, Cape Verde, off the coast of Senegal. One of the world's masters of happy-sad music, Ms. Evora returns to the poised, slow-swelling music of her classic CD's, ''Cesaria'' (still her best) and ''Miss Perfumado.'' Her voice is at once noble and heartbreaking, her music a sensual slow-dance toward an inevitable abyss.

With no terrorist factions and a highway system made up mainly of dirt tracks, it was a perfect place for me to travel in my favorite manner -- hiking through remote areas untouched by tourism.

title: From Pitchforks to Proposition 13

title: Saving Private Lynch From Misinformation
description: IN November, NBC will broadcast ''Saving Jessica Lynch,'' a made-for-TV movie about one of the best-known episodes in the war in Iraq. Private Lynch, who signed a $1 million book deal with Alfred A. Knopf and promised her first interview to Diane Sawyer (both of which will also appear in November), did not participate in the making of this film. Instead, it is based on the recollections of Mohammed Odeh Al- Rehaief, the Iraqi lawyer who tipped off American soldiers to Private Lynch's whereabouts. Starting with the 507th maintenance company's ambush in Nasiriyah, the movie follows Private Lynch's capture by Iraqi forces, her removal to Saddam Hussein General Hospital, her rescue by a Special Operations unit known as Task Force 20, and her return home to a hero's welcome.

title: The Hunting Of The Snark
description: Things are pretty quiet over at Snarkwatch (http://www.believermag.com/snarkwatch/), the Web page set up by the editors of the literary journal The Believer as a sounding board for "enthusiasms, mystifications, as well as disgruntled reactions to 'critical activity.'" Observers of the literary scene have been checking it regularly, hoping for a dust-up with more zest to it than the stillborn Tibor Fischer-Martin Amis spat. But as of this writing, the half-dozen or so objections registered on Snarkwatch have not been joined by anything new in over a week. (The only detectable activity involves a complaint by the author of a volume of poems inspired by the rock band Queen, who maintains that his book was not given a fair shake in this publication; his lament is sometimes there and sometimes not, for reasons known only to the Web page's administrators.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUFFY, ELAINE M.
description: DUFFY--Elaine M. Of Monte Carlo, Monaco, and East Williston, NY. Passed away at her New York home at age 60 on October 3, 2003 after a nearly five year struggle with breast cancer. She was the daughter of Elaine M. Higgins of Lattingtown, NY and the late Thomas L. Higgins. She was born on January 20th, 1943 in the Bronx, NY. Mrs. Duffy received her Bachelor's Degree from Mary Mount College in Tarrytown, NY and her Master's Degree in Education from Hofstra University in Uniondale, NY. Her passion was the education of young children and she taught fifth grade at Roads School in New Hyde Park, NY. Mrs. Duffy was an active supporter of Mercy Medical Center in Rockville Centre, NY and previously served as President of the Council of Leagues of Mercy Medical Center. She was a member of the Paris/American Club in New York, NY and an active member of the American Club of the Riviera in Nice, France. She was very involved in the American Community in the South of France and Monaco where she had lived since the 1980s and held the status of ''resident privilegie'' in the Principality of Monaco. Mrs. Duffy is survived by her husband James P. Duffy, III an international attorney their two children daughter, Jenifer E. Bendezu of Monte Carlo, Monaco and Chatham, NJ and her husband Luis A. Bendezu, M.D. and son James P. IV also an international attorney of Monte Carlo, Monaco and New York, NY and grandson Liam P. Bendezu. Mrs Duffy's mother also survived her as did her brother, Thomas L. Higgins, Jr. and sister Colleen Ebrahemian. Visiting hours Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Weigand Bros Funeral Home, 49 Hillside Ave, Williston Park, NY. Funeral Mass St. Aidan's Church, 505 Willis Ave., Williston Park, NY 11596 on Tuesday, October 7, 2003 at 11:15 AM. In lieu of flowers the family would prefer a donation in Mrs. Duffy's name to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, Suite 1209, 654 Madison Ave., NY NY 10021. Toll Free: 866FIND/A/CURE for Breast Cancer Research.

title: Dark Victory
description: 'Acting is my profession -- I've been doing it since I was 5,'' Madhur Jaffrey says as she pours a gallon of milk into a saucepan on my 12-burner Garland. ''Cooking is what I would do anyway.'' She sets the milk to low and simmers it v-e-r-y slowly for cardamom-and-pistachio ice cream -- two hours later, it will have reduced by two-thirds and have a curious, almost thready texture. On the other side of the open counter to the dining room, her husband of 36 years, the violinist Sanford Allen, silently and precisely cuts green beans into pea-size cubes. ''I just finished doing two months on 'East Enders,''' Madhur says of her experience on the long-running BBC nighttime soap as she starts the mango soup. ''On the show, I'm the mother of a family who's separated from her husband and living with another man. The husband has told the children I'm dead. But they know I'm alive and visit me. It's quite the drama.'' She laughs girlishly. It's 2:15 p.m., Aug. 14, 2003. Drama? Just wait.

title: Home Away From Home

''I see the gym as a way of extending my New York real estate,'' Chen, a 39-year-old campus recruiter for Banc of America Securities, says. ''It's a way of giving myself treats, without actually having to pay exorbitant prices -- which I can't afford anyway -- for a huge apartment.'' She takes a toning-and-step class at the New York Sports Club, a chain gym, but at least four times a week she heads to Clay, an upscale fitness club just off Union Square whose membership is limited to avoid crowding. ''There are never more than one or two people in the lounge,'' Chen says. ''You feel like you own the place.''

Poet, novelist, playwright, opera librettist, songwriter, artist and movie director, he was also a consummate exhibitionist. In fact, in time, he excelled most at being Cocteau. Yet after he died at 74, 40 years ago this week, his image faded. Without its chief promoter, his legacy was gradually forgotten.

Las Vegas tried the same strategy about 10 years ago and the jury is still out on whether it was a good idea.

''There is no quieter narrative voice than Trevor's impersonal but irreducible one, and none that so demands a reader's strict attention,'' Thomas Mallon said here in 2002.

The first installment of ''Kill Bill'' ends with a cliffhanger; Volume 2 is set to be released in February.

title: (Not) For His Eyes Only

The stalls selling frozen daiquiris in tall plastic beakers are shuttered, and the old-timers disappear from Ruby's boardwalk bar. But walk past Astroland, and you'll find one place lighted up with carny promise, where paintings of a bearded lady and a tattooed man practically reach out and grab the money from your pocket. Inside the Sideshows by the Seashore, the bleacher seats are packed. The crowd is mostly people in their 20's and 30's who are in thrall to Coney's seedy charm or older folks who grew up coming to the boardwalk and have discovered the show on nostalgia trips. Onstage, a woman dressed as a portly man abuses a plastic blow-up doll in unseemly ways. Suddenly, the blow-up doll comes alive, slowly unpeeling her plastic layer, and a woman whose stage name is MsTickle steps out, wearing -- ba-da-boom! -- pasties and a G-string. This is Burlesque on the Beach.

title: POLLING FOR DOLLARS
description: Nearly 90 percent of state residents 50 and older surveyed by AARP say safeguarding the state's prescription drug assistance for the elderly and disabled should be the top priority for legislators. Secondly, more than 80 percent want the Legislature to support home health care rather than subsidizing nursing homes, according to an AARP survey released last week. A majority of the respondents want to see property taxes changed to some form of income tax and most would like to see banks required to obtain consent before releasing information to a third party. The information from the survey will be used in an intensive voter campaign in the next few weeks in which the AARP will publicize legislative candidates' positions on these issues, said Nancy A. Wood, the AARP public affairs officer. Karen DeMasters

title: A Gift Left by Grandmas
description: WHEN Philip Kayal, a sociologist at Seton Hall University, and a cousin, Virginia Jerro Gerbino, a Bergen County secretary, were youngsters, they spent summers raiding the icebox for rose water pudding, the Syrian answer to gelato. Decades later, they have laid off the pudding, Mr. Kayal says, but remain in cahoots raiding their mothers' recipe boxes for ''traditions that take us back to our ethnic roots.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DILWORTH, ELIZABETH
description: DILWORTH--Elizabeth. The Rockefeller University community notes with deep sorrow the loss of our dear friend Bunny Dilworth, beloved spouse of the late J. Richardson Dilworth. Throughout Dick Dilworth's 37 years of dedicated service on our Board of Trustees, Bunny shared his interest in the progress of biomedical research, his passion for creating an environment where modern scientific inquiry would flourish, and his concern for our scientists. In particular, we recall her special regard for The Rockefeller University Hospital and its staff of physicians and nurses. We salute the achievements of Bunny's own pro bono life, including her role in creating the Princeton Country Day School and her involvement with civil rights and social concerns in New Jersey. She generously shared the fruits of her avid love of gardening with the many individuals and groups she welcomed as visitors to her renowned gardens in Princeton. We wish to conclude by recalling that the achievement of which she was most proud was raising four children. We extend our deepest condolences to her beloved children, Alexandra, Joseph, and Charles; to her grandchildren and other family members; and to all who loved her. Paul Nurse, President Jules Hirsch, Physician-inChief Emeritus Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman of the RU Council Carl B. Hess, Member of the RU Council Executive Committee Richard B. Fisher, Chairman of the Board David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman The Rockefeller Unversity

In fact, Whitlock may remind moviegoers of Xavier Quinn, the relaxed police chief in that overly relaxed movie. Quinn heads the force on a sun-dappled Caribbean island; in ''Out of Time,'' which opened Friday, Whitlock polices a small Florida beach community. Both men are affected when a huge amount of money touches their lives. And in each picture, Mr. Washington's performance is so smooth it seems to slide off the screen -- and your eyeballs -- as you watch it.

title: The New Cinematic Realism
description: ''PARTY MONSTER'' is a hall of mirrors, more mind-bending than it seems. The film opens with a scene of a documentary being shot -- we see a clapper that says ''Party Monster Take 1'' -- in which James St. James (played by Seth Green) sits by a pool in bright yellow lounging pajamas being interviewed about his drugged-out life in the 90's and a murder committed by his club-kid friend Michael Alig (Macaulay Culkin). But this scene is not simply based on reality; it is based on a documentary about reality. Right down to the clownish yellow outfit, poolside setting and campy, drag-queen voice, Mr. Green's fake interview mimics an actual interview from a 1997 Cinemax documentary also called ''Party Monster'' and also made by the co-directors of the new movie, Fenton Bailey and Randy Barbato.

title: The Darkest Night

On the way to check his fuse box, he peeked out the window. The whole block was dark. Sekzer ran up three flights to his roof. He looked to the west, across the East River, to Manhattan. The familiar shapes of the world's most famous skyline were all blotted out by darkness. ''Holy cripes,'' Sekzer muttered to himself. ''There's no lights anywhere.'' Figuring he'd be needed, minutes later he was in his car, heading for work.

title: Joints
description: Before Nina, the names Harry, Johnny, Mannie, Carlos and Jack filled Al Hirschfeld's delightful vignettes and caricatures, collected in THE SPEAKEASIES OF 1932 (Glenn Young Books, $32.95). These were but a few of the colorful New York gin slingers who were as well known to their thirsty patrons during Prohibition as the Broadway performers that Hirschfeld would later immortalize. He frequently drew satiric cartoons for magazines like Americana (which he edited with Alexander King) and The New Masses, and traveled around the world with pen and sometimes crayon in hand. According to the introduction by Pete Hamill, ''The Speakeasies of 1932'' reveals a lost world -- ''part social history, part artifact of urban archaeology, part simple reporting on the long history of human folly.'' As a personal artistic record, it also reveals an artist who had not yet found his mtier but was no amateur, either. Hirschfeld possessed a sharp eye and keen knack for capturing the nuance and gesture of his subjects. And while his black-and-white sketches relied too much on clumsy brush shading, which he later rejected for the purity of the pen-and-ink line, key elements of his graphic personality shine through in his idiosyncratic, comic rendering of hands, eyes, noses and mouths. Steven Heller

title: Unambiguously Cindy
description: Cindy Sherman started shooting her ''Film Stills'' right after she moved to New York City in 1977, the summer of Sam and the last blackout. She cast herself as imaginary actresses in fictional roles from the 40's, 50's and 60's -- as she put it, the era of pointy bras and stiletto heels, for which there was no nostalgia yet. She showed the first of the stills late that same year in Buffalo, where she studied. She somehow lost the negatives and contact sheets. A decade later someone found them. They included this picture, which Sherman chose not to print then but now has put into her book ''The Complete Untitled Film Stills,'' to be published this month by the Museum of Modern Art. It is a shot she staged in her loft downtown: a woman in silhouette with a blond wig, her face obscured by the glare from a light stand. ''The image seemed too mysterious to me,'' she said the other day. ''I thought you couldn't see the character. But now I find her emblematic of the whole group. It's a perfectly ambiguous picture.''

title: On The Edge Of The Neo-70's
description: A few years ago, if you rode the D train from Brooklyn to Manhattan, your peripheral vision might have been surprised by a stroboscopic flicker of color at the mouth of the tunnel leading out onto the span of the Manhattan Bridge. If you adjusted your angle of vision properly, you could make out, through pillars and support walls, the bright Krylon hues and characteristic bubble letters of classic wild- style graffiti. By then, the M.T.A.'s subway cars were being made of special paint-resistant stainless steel, and those 50 feet or so of transfigured wall were like a secret museum, a preserved -- more probably an overlooked -- subterranean shrine to a bygone city. I remember once overhearing a young boy ask his mother what those words and pictures were. ''What's graffiti?'' he asked her, and she provided the responsible parental explanation, emphasizing the dangerous, rule-breaking nature of the act. Without knowing it, the child resuscitated an ancient civic and aesthetic controversy -- a standoff, really, between the civic impact of graffiti and its artistic status. ''I think it's beautiful,'' he said.

title: American Woman
description: Red Hook is little more than the junction of a couple of roads, with a farm store, a church and graveyard, a diner. And the post office, a small square cement building with RED HOOK NY 12571 spelled out in metal letters across the flat gray facade. He keeps flying through this sparse nexus of structures, first along the south-north road, then, when he finally manages to slow down and make the turn, along the east-west. He has the idea that the rest of the town must lie just farther on, and that the diner and farm store and church and post office are a far-flung outpost, but he keeps ending up twenty-odd miles away in front of a sign welcoming him to a new town, and so he keeps turning back and retracing his route. He doesn't even see houses in Red Hook, just fence lines along the roads, a dirt drive sometimes winding away. Some of the fences contain fields and some just grass and grazing animals, but everywhere there are smooth humps of hills and distant darknesses of untouched woodland, interesting vistas to the harried urban man. He's enjoying tearing up and down these roads, like swinging hard through the same arc again and again, and catching the same glimpse of the sorry little huddle at the center point, and he keeps at it for a while pointlessly, up down, zoom zoom, but finally he's forced to conclude that he's not missing anything. At the post office he parks and goes in to take a look at her box. If there were a tiny window in the little metal door he would stoop and peer in, but there isn't. At the diner he orders coffee and a jelly donut and tries to figure out where all the people live. A man in overalls asks another man at the counter how to get somewhere. "I'm from over-river," he explains. Back in his car Frazer studies the map. The Hudson lies west of here, about a ten-minute drive on these roads. Might be pretty. Frazer knows he is possessed of the skills to solve such problems as the one that lies before him. He can recognize, for example, that right now he is looking too hard at the wrong thing, and missing the point. He needs to do something else, maybe even give up for the day, find a bar and a motel, and start fresh in the morning. He should have realized that she wouldn't live here; she wouldn't want to be too near the post office. Yet she wouldn't want to travel too far. This is the sort of zero-sum compromise she makes all the time; Frazer knows this about her, having been subjected to the same flawed formulation. Trust Frazer or spurn him? A little of both? He notices, thinking of the man in overalls from over-river, that there aren't so many bridges: just four in the 150-mile stretch from the city to Albany. One lies due west of here, but Frazer's willing to bet that Jenny wouldn't cross the river for her mail. Too much traffic concentration, too confined; there's no good exit from a bridge. He puts an X on Red Hook, then estimates a half hour's driving distance and draws a circle around Red Hook with that radius. He does this mostly to amuse himself, but also because he believes in the inflexibility, predictability, knowability of people. They never stray far from their familiar realms of being. The most shocking act, closely examined, is just a louder version of some habitual gesture. No one is ever "out of character." That idea just makes Frazer laugh.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: NEW ROCHELLE: WHOOPING COUGH OUTBREAK An outbreak of whooping cough has spread to at least 19 people, many of them children who had been vaccinated, in the northwest corner of Westchester County, the county's Health Department said on Friday. Normally, there are only five or six cases a year in Westchester. Whooping cough, also known as pertussis, is contagious, and the Health Department said many of the children are classmates or playmates. They range in age from three months to 14 years old. The two adults who are infected are parents or caretakers of infected children. The first cases were spotted in August, the most recent one on Wednesday. The health commissioner, Dr. Joshua Lipsman, said vaccination would not make someone completely immune, but the illness is generally milder in those who have been vaccinated.   (AP)

title: Democrats' Duty on Energy

Last week, Democrats on the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee, plus the independent James Jeffords, boycotted a meeting at which Republicans had hoped to endorse the nomination of Michael Leavitt as the new boss of the Environmental Protection Agency. The boycott was denounced as partisan pique and a personal insult to Mr. Leavitt, the Utah governor. We prefer to see it as a disciplined, albeit rare, Democratic effort to register dismay with President Bush's environmental policies. Nor will this be the only protest. Should the panel, as expected, eventually approve Mr. Leavitt, the Democrats will block the nomination on the Senate floor until the administration provides honest answers about its policies on clean air and water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WAINWRIGHT, CHARLES ANTHONY
description: WAINWRIGHT--Charles Anthony ''Tony.'' 70, of Palm Beach, FL. On October 3, 2003. Born in Los Angeles, CA, and graduated from The Francis W. Parker School in Chicago, IL, and the University of Colorado at Boulder. Loving husband of Mary Beth; adored father of Colleen, Mary (deceased) and Elizabeth, Joseph Kaplan (Cindy) and Wendy Kaplan (Stephen Haack). A rare man of wisdom, wit, kindness, love and above all, generosity, his friends and admirers are legion. After serving in the U.S. Navy aboard a destroyer escort, he began his advertising career in the mailroom of The Leo Burnett Company. In 1969, he founded the new ventures agency, Wainwright, Spaeth & Wright, in Chicago, which helped develop and launch such new products as Oil of Olay, Stove Top Stuffing Mix and Shake n Bake. Among other positions in advertising, he served as Chairman, Compton Partners, Saatchi & Saatchi, New York; Vice Chairman of CME New York; and, most recently, Vice Chairman of Arnold Worldwide, Boston. He also served on several Boards of Directors including Del Webb Corporation, Danka Business Systems PLC, American Woodmark and the Baylor Hospital Foundation. He is the author of several published books and screenplays, the most recent of which is ''Moments of Truth,'' and the recipient of numerous awards and honors, including both Cannes and Venice Film Festival awards and several Clio awards. Services will be private and a memorial celebration will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Baylor University Medical Center Foundation for Dr. John Fordtran, G.I. Research, 3500 Gaston Ave, Dallas, TX 75246.

title: The Supreme Court Returns
description: The Supreme Court began its fall term early by meeting last month to hear a challenge to the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law. The spirited argument was a fitting kickoff for a term in which the court is being asked, in a pair of cases, to resolve the ground rules of our democracy. The court has also agreed to hear several federalism cases, giving it a chance to decide whether to continue its misguided campaign to elevate states' rights and erode Congress's powers. The court's ideological divisions mean that critical issues -- like campaign finance, employment discrimination and the line between church and state -- are likely to be resolved by the narrowest of margins.

title: Across America in His Merry Winton
description: Ken Burns, the producer of august movies on PBS, has turned out a comic documentary, ''Horatio's Drive: America's First Road Trip,'' which has its premiere tonight. ''Horatio's Drive'' is a two-hour account of a merry 1903 cross-country drive by motorcar, the first of its kind, here rendered in voice-over, archival film clips and many, many panned-over still photographs.

title: Corrections
description: The Weather Report on Aug. 14 included an erroneous reference from the National Weather Service to the uniqueness of a rainy period earlier in the summer. The period from July 31 through Aug. 11 -- with measurable rain every day in Central Park -- was in fact the longest stretch of consecutive days with measurable precipitation there in more than a century of recorded history. (Upon further checking in recent weeks, a 12-day period in the winter of 1875-1876, thought to have matched it, was discovered to have had one day without precipitation.)

title: The Giants Have Their Opportunities, And End Up Making the Least of Them

They were at home, and their once-feared defense stood on the field, its players waving at the fans in Giants Stadium to rally with them.

title: Finding a Middle Earth in Montana; A Teenager's Fantasy Set in a Magical Land Is a Best Seller
description: Christopher Paolini, who has never been to school, was only 15 when he wrote his fantasy novel ''Eragon,'' about a boy who finds a magic stone that is transformed into a dragon and then sets out to avenge the death of his uncle and to defeat an evil king. Now four years later, ''Eragon,'' published by Alfred A. Knopf, is third on the New York Times hardcover children's chapter books best-seller list, outselling four of the five Harry Potter books.

title: GREEN EQUITY INVESTORS TO BUY FTD FOR $420 MILLION
description: FTD Inc., which sells flowers and other gifts via the Internet and telephone, agreed to be bought by Green Equity Investors for about $420 million. FTD, which is based in Downers Grove, Ill., said its stockholders would receive $24.85 a share. Green Equity expects to complete the transaction in the first quarter. Green Equity Investors is an affiliate of the Los Angeles-based private investment company Leonard Green & Partners, a private equity fund. Robert Norton, the chief executive of FTD, will retain his position, FTD said. FTD's sales rose 12 percent, to $363.3 million, in the fiscal year ended in June.

title: House Republicans Trimming Bush's Spending Plan for Iraq
description: House Republicans called Monday for a $1.7 billion cut in President Bush's request for reconstruction aid for Iraq by trimming spending on such items as new garbage trucks and a postal zone system.

title: TANGER AND BLACKSTONE TO BUY OUTLETS FOR $304 MILLION
description: Tanger Factory Outlet Centers, a real estate investment trust that owns 33 shopping centers, and the Blackstone Group have agreed to buy nine factory outlets from Charter Oak Partners for $304 million. Tanger and an affiliate of Blackstone, which manages the world's biggest buyout fund, formed a limited-liability company to buy the centers as a joint venture. The venture also agreed to assume $187 million in debt. Tanger will own a third of the venture, and provide operating, management and marketing services for the properties. An affiliate of Blackstone Real Estate Advisors will own the rest.

title: After the Storm, a Better Look at Ravaged Coasts
description: Measuring the beach has long challenged coastal geologists. Benchmarks are few, and most of them like dunes and high water lines shift from tide to tide and from season to season, as the beach responds to everything from the winds to the phases of the moon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAYTON, BILL
description: CAYTON--Bill. Boxing Manager of the Year 14 times and Boxing Manager of seven world champions, died October 4, 2003. He was 85 years old. Loving husband of Doris, his wife of 58 years, who died three years ago. There was no day that passed he didn't say how much he loved and missed her. Adored and cherished father of Brian, Trish and Merrie. Loving father-inlaw of Meryl and Kurt. Loved grandfather of Vanessa and Gabrielle. Treasured brotherin-law of Doris' brother, Morton Roberts and his wife, Dolores and their children Geri and April. Great friend and loved brother-in-law of his deceased sister Marcelle's husband, Harold Goltzer and their children Dana and Eric. He was loved by Dana's children Alyssa and John, and Eric's children Andrea and Elizabeth. He was loved by his cousins Kathryn and Clifford Goldsmith, and his first cousin, Irving Zuckerman. He was loved and will be missed by Steve Lott, his business associate of 35 years. Bill Cayton was an extraordinary and brilliant man who was an inspiration to everyone who met him. His enthusiasm and optimism, no matter what the circumstances, was dazzling. He had a passion for life. He loved sunshine, his garden, classical music, opera and ragtime. He was a prolific reader and voracious thinker. He was handsome and elegant, kind and soft-spoken. He was non-judgmental, never held a grudge and never had a bad word to say about anyone. All who knew him said he was the essence of integrity and honesty. His warmth and bright smile will be missed by the world. Services will be held Thursday, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bethel: Mother and Child Hurt In Crash
description: A woman, accompanied by a 4-year-old girl, said she was forced off busy Interstate 84 yesterday morning when the driver of a van repeatedly swerved and slammed his brakes whenever her car came up behind his vehicle. The police temporarily shut the highway after the 7:30 a.m. incident. The woman, Thuy Phu, 25, of Danbury, and the child, Mikayla Lawrence, suffered minor injuries when their car veered off the highway and onto an embankment, where they were trapped. The relationship between the woman and child was not immediately clear. Both were freed by emergency workers and treated at a Danbury hospital. The driver of the van, James Stoops, 43, of Naugatuck, was arrested and charged with reckless driving. Witnesses told the police that Mr. Stoops had been swerving between lanes and slamming his brakes ahead of Ms. Phu's car. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Even the Cheeriest Choreographer Has a Dark Side
description: Henning Rubsam is such a cheerful choreographer that his dark new ''Petit Pas,'' presented by his Sensedance company on Saturday night at the Joyce SoHo, is unexpected. True, the program of recent dances also included two Schubert solos that plumb the shadowed sweetness and maturity of the ballerina Eva Evdokimova, a guest artist here. But ''Petit Pas'' is dark and unusually oblique for Mr. Rubsam.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 4 Are Charged In Baseball Bat Attack
description: Four young people were charged yesterday with attempted murder, gang assault, assault and weapons charges in an attack on Saturday in Douglaston, where three teenagers were beaten with baseball bats, the authorities said. The suspects, Kevin Donaghy, 20, David Raneri, 19, Joseph McMahon, 18, and Alexander Nunez, 15, all of Queens, face up to 25 years in prison if convicted. The attack took place about 12:40 a.m. at a park near Van Zandt Avenue, when the suspects surrounded the victims and struck them with baseball bats, the police said. A broken bat was found at the scene. All of the victims, two of them 16 and one 18, remain hospitalized, two in critical condition, said the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Review/Fashion; A Pastel Twilight in Milan

title: Is California Contagious? Don't Laugh
description: NO matter who wins and who loses in the California recall election today, one result is already certain: the circus out there makes one proud to be a New Yorker.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Court Rejects Driver's Drug Test Law
description: The State Supreme Court overturned a law that said that by operating a motor vehicle a driver implicitly consented to a drug or alcohol test after a serious accident. Refusing the test could have resulted in a suspended license for at least a year and having the refusal admitted as evidence at trial. The court said the longstanding statute had allowed for illegal search and seizure. The decision awarded a new trial to Carey D. Cooper, who tested positive for cocaine and oxycodone after a head-on collision in which the other driver's arm was broken. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RADEMACHER, MICHAEL
description: RADEMACHER -- Michael. Michael Rademacher Productions LLC acknowledges the passing of our founder, Michael Rademacher, at the age of 50. Due to legal difficulties which occurred after Michael's death, we are late publishing this notice. Michael leaves behind his wife, Maria, a son, Bryan, who resides in Sydney, Australia and relatives and friends living in Australia, Germany, France, England and the U.S. The Michael Rademacher Charitable Trust has been established to contribute funds to those organizations closest to Michael and Maria's heart. These disbursements will begin after January 1, 2004. Michael's ashes were spread in his beloved Paris. His story and guest book are on www.legacy.com.

They had already been victims of ''The Fumble,'' ''The Drive,'' ''The Shot.'' Now they were about to suffer one more indignity, the latest entry in Cleveland's ledger of defeat, ''The Pick.''

description: This was the season the Atlanta Thrashers had been waiting for since they joined the National Hockey League five years ago. Talented players plucked from the draft had been groomed and a veteran presence had been sprinkled among the solid nucleus of young players.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New Law For Child Performers
description: Employers of child performers will be required under a new law to set up trust funds and place 15 percent of the children's annual incomes in individual accounts. The legislation, signed into law last week by Gov. George E. Pataki, is modeled after a California law named for the child actor Jackie Coogan, left, whose parents spent much of his $4 million fortune in the 1920's and 30's before he turned 18. The trust funds are to be turned over to the children at age 18. The law also requires theatrical employers to pay for tutors for young stars who do not regularly attend school. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Toughing It Out
description: We buried as many of Saturday's victims as possible before the start of Yom Kippur, and then we went to pray -- for safety and quiet and a better year ahead. For three full years, we've gone on with daily life. Untenable daily life, in a land where nowhere is off limits to terrorism, not even a beachfront restaurant in Haifa where Jews and Arabs eat together.

title: Creating Global Airlines
description: The merger agreement between KLM, the Dutch airline, and Air France is more than an intriguing business story. It is an important symbol, perhaps even a landmark, in Europe's continuing integration. Asking a country to give up its gleaming 747's flying the national colors is almost as difficult as asking it to give up its currency to join a monetary union. Politicians, after all, can be like little children when it comes to big planes. That is one reason why Europe's airlines, unlike other businesses, have not been allowed to operate freely in what has ostensibly been a single economic market for a decade.

title: FEDERAL COURT DROPS MYLAN FROM DRUG PRICING CASE
description: Mylan Laboratories Inc., a leading maker of generic drugs, said a federal court in Boston dismissed claims that the company improperly reported prices to the federal government. Separately, a federal judge in Pittsburgh ruled that Mylan infringed patents related to the cancer drug paclitaxel. The patents are owned by NaPro BioTherapeutics Inc. and licensed to Abbott Laboratories. A trial on Mylan's contention that the patents are invalid could go to trial later this year. The Boston ruling involves a consolidated lawsuit against the pharmaceutical industry by consumers, health plans and state attorneys general who say the drug companies tell the government that they charge doctors more than they do, inflating reimbursements. The government uses so-called average wholesale prices to set reimbursements from federal health programs. The suit was dismissed because it ''did not identify any wrongdoing on Mylan's part,'' the company said.

title: As competition heats up in fast food, Quiznos places one new order and reviews other agencies.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Tests Find Smog-Forming Gases In 3 States
description: Testing a broad region across Texas, Oklahoma and southwestern Kansas, scientists have measured high levels of gases that react with sunlight to create smog. In many spots, concentrations of the gases exceeded levels typical of cities like Los Angeles, Houston and New York. In this week's online edition of the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, the researchers, from the University of California at Irvine, said the gases, including methane, butane and propane, were released by oil and natural gas refineries. The researchers estimated that several million tons of methane were released this way each year. Besides contributing to smog, methane is a heat-trapping gas linked to global warming. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

Born on June 2, 1924 in Geneva, Switzerland, Toinon was the daughter of Professor Alexis Francois of the University of Geneva and Marthe Francois. She is survived by her husband Pierluigi Gaspari, her children Philip Littell, Peter Littell, Anita Repp, Carola Di Carlo, and eight grandchildren.

title: A Turn for the Worse in the Mideast
description: A weekend of despicable Palestinian terror and a recklessly inappropriate Israeli military reprisal deep inside Syria has ratcheted up tensions in the Middle East at a particularly difficult moment for American policy there. President Bush should now be urgently counseling all parties to exercise restraint while his administration embarks on a new push to revive moribund peace efforts. Instead, Mr. Bush has unwisely chosen to encourage the most hawkish impulses of Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, reassuring him in private on Sunday and again in public yesterday that Israel ''must not feel constrained'' in defending itself. Neither American nor Israeli interests are well served by such provocative advice.

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: COURT REJECTS DRIVER'S DRUG TEST LAW The State Supreme Court overturned a law that said that by operating a motor vehicle a driver implicitly consented to a drug or alcohol test after a serious accident. Refusing the test could have resulted in a suspended license for at least a year and having the refusal admitted as evidence at trial. The court said the longstanding statute had allowed for illegal search and seizure. The decision awarded a new trial to Carey D. Cooper, who tested positive for cocaine and oxycodone after a head-on collision in which the other driver's arm was broken. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: TAUBMAN REJECTS LATEST UNSOLICITED TAKEOVER OFFER
description: Taubman Centers Inc. rejected a bid by the Simon Property Group, the world's largest mall owner, and Westfield America Inc. after they extended their unsolicited offer for at least the fourth time in a year. The $20-a-share offer for Taubman, a real estate investment trust that owns or manages 31 shopping centers in 13 states, has garnered 19.6 million, or 24 percent, of 81 million shares outstanding, less than the two-thirds needed to make a successful bid, Taubman said. Simon, which owns or has an interest in 238 properties, and Westfield America are seeking 49.3 million common shares; the founding Taubman family owns a controlling stake.

The Yankees had been heavily scrutinized after a sloppy setback to the Minnesota Twins in the opener of their division series and there were enough negative vibes to cause Manager Joe Torre to conduct a pointed meeting before Game 2.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: RAMBUS SHARES SOAR AFTER COURT ACTION Rambus Inc., a designer of high- speed computer memory chips, can pursue a patent infringement suit against Infineon Technologies after the United States Supreme Court refused to intervene in the dispute. Rambus shares rose nearly 38 percent, their biggest increase in more than eight months. The justices rejected Infineon's bid to end the suit and reinstate a jury finding that Rambus committed fraud while pursuing patents for high-speed chips that became an industry standard. Rambus is now free to resume its suit seeking up to $840 million in patent royalties from semiconductor makers. The Supreme Court action yesterday might impede a separate fraud complaint against Rambus filed last year by the Federal Trade Commission, said Michael Crawford, an analyst with B. Riley & Company, who rates Rambus shares a buy and said he owned them. Rambus shares rose $7.07, to $25.80. The shares have more than tripled since the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit ruled in its favor on Jan. 29, overturning a jury's fraud verdict.   (Bloomberg News)

title: A Pregnant Mother's Diet May Turn the Genes Around
description: With the help of some fat yellow mice, scientists have discovered exactly how a mother's diet can permanently alter the functioning of genes in her offspring without changing the genes themselves.

title: Tiger, Tiger
description: In lifestyle, Antoine Yates lived about as far from Roy Horn as is possible. Except for the tiger. Mr. Yates is the man who, until Saturday, kept a tiger named Ming, who weighs more than 400 pounds, in an apartment at the Drew Hamilton Houses in Harlem. Ming was removed by the police after he bit his owner, who failed in his attempt to pass off his injuries as the work of a pit bull. Mr. Yates was lucky. Roy Horn, who is half of the Las Vegas illusionist team of Siegfried & Roy, was attacked during his act on Friday night by one of the team's white tigers and dragged offstage by the neck. He is now in critical condition.

title: Medicare for the Fiscally Healthy
description: With the government wallowing in deficit spending, it is understandable and even encouraging that Congressional Republicans are thinking about requiring high-income retirees to pay more for their Medicare coverage. This rare nod toward fiscal reality arises as the G.O.P.-led Congress attempts to deliver on campaign pledges to provide a Medicare prescription drug program.

title: London Theater Spreads Its Cheer
description: Nicholas Hytner's first season as director of the National Theater in London, now at its halfway point, has exceeded all expectations. Almost all the plays on the company's three stages in its building on the South Bank have received favorable reviews and have played to full houses.

Rubble and burned cars littered the street as smoke rose from residential buildings recently bombed. Hitler Youth scrambled to a cannon position protected by sandbags, and blasts rattled people's sleep throughout the night.

At Washington Middle School here, where he attended seventh grade until he killed himself in January 2002, he may as well have been invisible. And in many ways, he was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUMPHREY, MARK ALTON
description: HUMPHREY -- Mark Alton. Died at age 40 on September 17, 2003 in Bay Ridge, Bklyn. Born in Rome, N.Y., he grew up in Northwich, England returning to the U.S. in 1983. Master carpenter, musician, poet and catalyst, he left us at the happiest time of his life. He was working on a musical with his collaborator Dave Moran, crossing back and forth between the States and the U.K. In Northwich he is survived by his mother Joan, brothers and sister Michael, Dale and Arlene and in California, brother Richard, sisters Lorraine and Elizabeth, in New York by Tom Clark and Leo Overtoom, his associates in The Blacksmith Shop recording studio, his sidekicks Richie and the most famous dog on the lower east side Hoover and his partner Garrison Phillips. On the night of Mark's memorial at Avalon, his beloved upstate retreat, a comet streaked across the sky letting us know he was still brightening our way.

title: Lumps of Labor
description: Economists call it the ''lump of labor fallacy.'' It's the idea that there is a fixed amount of work to be done in the world, so any increase in the amount each worker can produce reduces the number of available jobs. (A famous example: those dire warnings in the 1950's that automation would lead to mass unemployment.) As the derisive name suggests, it's an idea economists view with contempt, yet the fallacy makes a comeback whenever the economy is sluggish.

description: Alimentation Couche-Tard of Laval, Quebec, has agreed to buy the Circle K chain of convenience stores from ConocoPhillips for $820.9 million, including $9.1 million in assumed debt. title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Panel Sees No Link Between Flu Shot And M.S. Relapse
description: Flu shots do not prompt relapses of multiple sclerosis, a government advisory panel said. The 1976 swine flu vaccine did cause hundreds of cases of Guillain-Barr syndrome, which can leave victims nearly paralyzed, but most studies since then have suggested that modern flu vaccines are not linked to the neurological syndrome, said the Institute of Medicine of the National Academies, which is investigating vaccine safety and neurological disorders such as multiple sclerosis. Flu kills about 36,000 Americans each year, and flu shots will be available later this month. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommend shots for everyone over 50 as well as anyone younger with diabetes, asthma or H.I.V. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: Arabs' Fear: A New Crisis

Already, the region is traumatized by the open wound that Israeli-Palestinian clashes have become and by an American-occupied Iraq teetering on the brink of bedlam.

As for the Rangers, they have won just once since 1940 and are looking for their first playoff berth in seven seasons. The Montreal Canadiens, meanwhile, have won more Cups than anybody, but none since 1993. Only Detroit, with three Cups since 1997, has enjoyed recent success.

Yet he has donated $300, so far, to Howard Dean's presidential campaign, monitors its Web sites daily and has lately been luring peers to their first political rallies.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of the New Yorker cartoonist and children's author William Steig in some editions on Sunday and some on Monday credited him erroneously with a famous 1928 cartoon. The drawing, of a child refusing a vegetable, was by Carl Rose, and the caption -- ''I say it's spinach, and I say the hell with it'' -- was by E. B. White.

title: Well Rested This Time, Kirov Returns to Carnegie
description: When Valery Gergiev conducted the Kirov Orchestra at Carnegie Hall in April, the players seemed weary and uninspired, despite their tireless maestro's urgent ministrations. They had, after all, finished their own extended tour in the United States and were then extending it to replace Mr. Gergiev's other orchestra, the Rotterdam Philharmonic, which had canceled its tour on short notice.

description: Forgetting Names

title: Letters
description: Assessing Addiction

title: Singapore And Thailand Urge Region To Integrate
description: The economic powerhouses of Southeast Asia Singapore and Thailand -- took the lead on Monday in calling for fast and definitive action towards a common market in the region.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Man Held In Syria Is Free
description: A Syrian-born Canadian citizen who spent more than a year in a Syrian prison after being accused by the United States of being a terrorist was suddenly released and returned to Canada. The Canadian, Maher Arar, 32, was traveling home to Ottawa from Tunisia on Sept. 26, 2002, when he was detained by American immigration officials at Kennedy International Airport and deported to his native Syria, where he was held without a trial. The circumstances of his deportation, despite his traveling on a Canadian passport, became a thorny issue in Canadian-American relations. United States officials said they had been acting on tips from Canadian law enforcement agencies, while Canada largely denied those claims and had lately lobbied for Mr. Arar's return to Canada. The Canadian foreign affairs minister, Bill Graham, said Mr. Arar would not be taken into custody on his return to Canada. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Market Place; Motorola Will Spin Off Its Money-Losing Semiconductor Business
description: Motorola said yesterday that it planned to divest its struggling semiconductor operations from its cellphone and communications equipment businesses, a step that had long been favored by Wall Street and opposed by top management.

title: Tiger Owner Faced Eviction From Apartment
description: City housing officials went to court in June to evict a 37-year-old man after he failed to pay the rent on a seven-room apartment where he was keeping a tiger and an alligator, a spokeswoman for the New York City Housing Authority said yesterday.

title: The Days of Bons Mots and Arranged Marriages
description: If there was any age more preoccupied than our own with gossip, fashion and who's in bed with whom it was the end of the 18th century. With no celebrity magazines or ''Joe Millionaire'' to satisfy their appetites for the trivial and take their minds off the war in the Colonies, London theatergoers flocked to Drury Lane and Covent Garden to laugh at the amorous shenanigans and foppery of the landed gentry in the reign of George III.

title: Those With Hepatitis C Still Face Long Odds
description: For once, there is some good news to report about a bloodborne virus that has infected 4 million Americans and 170 million people worldwide.

title: Rumsfeld Says Not Told of Postwar Shake-up
description: Donald Rumsfeld, US defence secretary, said on Tuesday he had not been told by President George W. Bush or the National Security Council that the White House was to restructure the handling of postwar Iraq before the media were briefed on the plan by NSC officials.

title: TENET SAYS PEOPLE'S HEALTH RECEIVES FEDERAL SUBPOENA
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, a hospital owner under investigation by at least three government agencies, said yesterday that a company that provided services to one of its units received a subpoena from federal prosecutors in New Orleans. The subpoena does not say what the investigation is about, Tenet said. The company said it owned a 50 percent ''membership interest'' in the company, called People's Health Network. Tenet said prosecutors wanted documents from January 1999 to the present related to several physician practices that hold membership interests in People's Health, as well as data on its membership, policy manuals and other records. Tenet said People's Health provided management services for Tenet Choices Inc., a Tenet unit that runs a Medicare health plan in New Orleans.

title: In Yellowstone, a Subterranean Volcano Exerts Its Influence
description: The rolling pine forests, snowcapped mountains and crisp fall evenings here tend to make people forget the fact that the park sits atop a huge simmering underground volcano. But new geologic events have served up reminders.

title: Restricting Prison Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Resolute Iranian Pilgrims Meet Awed G.I.'s
description: The fall of Saddam Hussein has undammed a flood of Shiite Muslims across Iran's rough border here into Iraq, driven not by the desire to fight Americans but by a religious devotion that United States soldiers here are finding hard to contain or even comprehend.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Company Agrees To Pay $815,000 To Settle Credit Card Case
description: A Web company that sent unsolicited e-mail messages to consumers telling them they were approved and guaranteed to receive major unsecured credit cards agreed to pay $815,000 in consumer redress to settle federal charges, the Federal Trade Commission said. The company, ClickForMail.com Inc., which operated a site called AllPreApproved.com, used mass e-mailings to offer consumers credit cards for $49.95, with limits of as much as $5,000, the commission said. According to the F.T.C., thousands of consumers who paid the fee did not receive cards; instead, they were directed to Web sites where they could apply for other prepaid, or secured, credit cards. ClickForMail.com, based in Austin, Tex., could be forced to pay about $3.6 million in additional fines if the commission finds that it misrepresented its finances in any way during the investigation. As part of the settlement, the company did not acknowledge breaking any law, but it accepted a permanent injunction barring it from selling credit cards or credit services.

title: Bomber Left Her Family With a Smile and a Lie
description: It was a few minutes past 8 a.m. on Saturday when Hanadi Jaradat's parents last saw her. The 27-year-old apprentice lawyer was in a hurry as she walked down the steep, narrow streets of this old Arab town, telling her parents she had a land contract to complete, for a fee of $500 in Israeli shekels, a small fortune for any impoverished family in Jenin.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption in late editions on Sunday about a family of Ecuadoreans at a Queens rally for changes in immigration policy used an incorrect given name in some copies for the mother. She is Maria Asitimbay, not Anna.

title: Keeping His Foot In a Creaking Door; Radio Pioneer Clings to Imagination
description: Radio drama died about 50 years ago, and wistful obituaries consigned the art form to the thrilling days of yesteryear. Himan Brown, though, refused to go to the funeral.

title: Where Rejects Find Buyers Who Love Them
description: The graveyard of retailing looks like this: piles of unopened bottles of wine; pyramids of digital cameras that failed to attract attention; mountains of leopard-pattern ladies' undergarments that no one, ultimately, wanted.

title: Mesa Air Makes Stock Offer for Atlantic Coast
description: The Mesa Air Group said yesterday that it was offering to buy Atlantic Coast Airlines for $512 million in stock in a deal that would form the largest regional airline in the country.

title: Miscellany
description: Marketing Metrics, Paramus, N.J., a specialist in customer relationship management research, was acquired by Ipsos, Paris, which will market its services worldwide under the Ipsos Loyalty name. Terms were not disclosed.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EASTMAN KODAK CO., Rochester, the world's largest maker of film, said it had sold the Burrell chain of photography labs, which it bought in February for $63.5 million, to the closely held Jasco, a holding company based in Rochester. Terms were not disclosed.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose after the president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, said a decline in the dollar was ''unavoidable'' because of a record deficit in the United States current account.

title: Keeping Balance, With a Jiggle
description: A little jiggle in the shoes may help keep older people upright, a new study involving vibrating insoles suggests.

title: U.S. to Ask Appeals Court to Revive Case on 9/11 Suspect
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 - The government said this afternoon that it would appeal a judge's ruling that prosecutors cannot seek the death penalty against Zacarias Moussaoui, who they argue is a central figure in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Officials Warn of Absentee Vote Factor
description: About 3.2 million Californians have requested absentee ballots for Tuesday's recall election, and election officials are growing worried that counting this record number of absentee ballots could drag out the results of an already unwieldy election.

title: Russian and 2 Americans Win Nobel Prize in Physics
description: ARussian and two foreign-born American citizens, one from Russia and one from England, were awarded this year's Nobel Prize in Physics today for their insights on how electricity can flow through some metals without resistance and some fluids can flow without friction.

title: US Air and Union in Dispute on Overhauls
description: The US Airways Group, which emerged from bankruptcy protection this year, said yesterday that it had hired a Singapore unit of Technologies Engineering to overhaul 10 aircraft. The airline's mechanics' union will seek to block the action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YANKOWITZ, LAURA
description: YANKOWITZ -- Laura. Be loved wife of the late Seymour. Devoted mother of Robert, Alan and Andrew. Beloved sister of Beverly. Cherished grandmother of Emily, Ethan, Dana, Daren and Charlotte. Dear sister-in-law of Jane Yanowitz. Loving aunt & great-aunt and a special friend to many. Services Tuesday 10AM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W Broad St, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: NetScreen To Acquire Neoteris
description: NetScreen Technologies Inc., a maker of equipment used to safeguard computer networks, has agreed to buy Neoteris Inc. for as much as $295 million in cash and stock to add products that allow access to networks from remote locations. NetScreen will pay $245 million in stock and $20 million in cash for closely held Neoteris, the companies said in statements yesterday on their Internet sites. As much as $30 million in additional cash will be paid if some sales goals are met. Neoteris, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., makes products that enable employees to have secure access to company files and messaging systems from home computers, remote offices and computing kiosks like those found in some airports. Neoteris has more than 550 clients, including Deutsche Bank. The acquisition is expected to close by the end of the year.

title: Turkish Parliament Gets Iraq Troop Bid
description: The Turkish government on Monday officially requested parliamentary approval to allow troops to be sent to Iraq to work alongside American soldiers.

title: House, Home and Health
description: ''Health and Community Design: The Impact of the Built Environment on Physical Activity,'' by Lawrence D. Frank, Peter O. Engelke and Thomas L. Schmid. Island Press, $30.

description: REID--George B., Jr. In memory of George B. Reid, Jr. Bacardi Limited

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Chicago Names Police Superintendent
description: Philip J. Cline, a law enforcement veteran of 33 years, was chosen as the new police superintendent of Chicago. Mr. Cline had served as acting superintendent since Terry Hillard retired from that post in mid-August. The other two finalists were Garry McCarthy, deputy commissioner of the New York Police Department, and Joseph DeLopez, chief of the police department in suburban Winnetka. Mayor Richard M. Daley called Mr. Cline a fine leader and an excellent administrator, and said he was the best man to continue Mr. Hillard's work. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Africa's Betting Public Lures Foreign Investors
description: The world's poorest continent has long had a gambling itch. But with betting restrictions eased in some nations and with foreign investors and corporations beginning to capitalize on Africa's gambling market, more and more Africans are regarding the good life as just one scratch card, sports bet or roulette spin away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLAIR, ROBERT A.
description: CLAIR--Robert A. It is with great sorrow I experience the loss of the most wonderful man I have every known, my brother Robert. Jerry Clair

title: For Sideline Reporters, Making Quick Hits Is the Key on Game Day
description: A half-hour before Sunday's Giants-Dolphins game, Armen Keteyian, CBS's lead sideline reporter, walked to the Miami locker room, led by the team's head of public relations, Harvey Greene. They spoke briefly in the Giants Stadium corridor with Coach Dave Wannstedt, then Greene opened a door and they stood in a vestibule.

title: London Journal; Car Owners' Hero Dresses for the Job
description: As is so often the case, the trickiest part came when he had to explain himself to his family.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Rubber Group Formed
description: Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia have signed an accord intended to increase rubber prices and prevent surpluses. The three countries, which produce about two-thirds of the world's natural rubber, completed the deal in Bali, Indonesia, to to buy from farmers and manage supplies.

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: TESTS FIND SMOG-FORMING GASES IN 3 STATES Testing a broad region across Texas, Oklahoma and southwestern Kansas, scientists have measured high levels of gases that react with sunlight to create smog. In many spots, concentrations of the gases exceeded levels typical of cities like Los Angeles, Houston and New York. In this week's online edition of the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, the researchers, from the University of California at Irvine, said the gases, including methane, butane and propane, were released by oil and natural gas refineries. The researchers estimated that several million tons of methane were released this way each year. Besides contributing to smog, methane is a heat-trapping gas linked to global warming. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Times Magazine on Sept. 28 about the recall election in California referred imprecisely to Charlotte Goland, a neighbor of Gov. Gray Davis's who was an early donor to the recall cause. She lives across a small pond from his house, not next door.

title: GOODYEAR TO ELIMINATE 1,100 JOBS AT ALABAMA PLANT
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company will close an Alabama factory by Dec. 5, cutting about 1,100 jobs as part of cost reductions allowed under a labor contract approved last month. The shutdown of the plant, in Huntsville, will result in fourth-quarter expenses of $255 million, the company said. Goodyear estimates that it will save about $100 million a year as a result.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rambus Shares Soar After Court Action
description: Rambus Inc., a designer of highspeed computer memory chips, can pursue a patent infringement suit against Infineon Technologies after the United States Supreme Court refused to intervene in the dispute. Rambus shares rose nearly 38 percent, their biggest increase in more than eight months. The justices rejected Infineon's bid to end the suit and reinstate a jury finding that Rambus committed fraud while pursuing patents for high-speed chips that became an industry standard. Rambus is now free to resume its suit seeking up to $840 million in patent royalties from semiconductor makers. The Supreme Court action yesterday might impede a separate fraud complaint against Rambus filed last year by the Federal Trade Commission, said Michael Crawford, an analyst with B. Riley & Company, who rates Rambus shares a buy and said he owned them. Rambus shares rose $7.07, to $25.80. The shares have more than tripled since the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit ruled in its favor on Jan. 29, overturning a jury's fraud verdict.

title: Spinal Device Approved
description: The Encore Medical Corporation, a maker of orthopedic products, said yesterday that its device for spine fusions won federal approval and that third-quarter revenue might have exceeded estimates.

title: Saturn's Biggest Moon Starts to Divulge Some of Its Secrets
description: Something on Titan, Saturn's largest moon, is very flat, possibly as flat as the surface of an ocean.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a coalition of groups opposed to a City Charter proposal that would eliminate party primaries in New York City misstated an organization name. It is the Asian American Legal Defense and Education Fund, not Asian American Defense and Education.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Utility Takeover
description: Denmark's largest power producer, Elsam, agreed to pay 8.27 billion Danish kroner ($1.3 billion) for Nesa, the country's largest utility. Nesa's main owners, the municipalities of Copenhagen and Gentofte, accepted an offer of 7,777.78 kroner a share for their 78.8 percent stake, Nesa said. Elsam will extend the offer, which is 6.5 percent more than Nesa's closing price on Friday, to other shareholders. Nesa, rejected an offer of as much as 11.6 billion kroner last month.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Willingboro: Teenager Charged In Shooting Death
description: Maurice Howard, 18, whose handgun the police say discharged inside a car and fatally wounded a passenger, surrendered to the police yesterday. He is charged with reckless manslaughter. On Friday, the police said, Mr. Howard was riding with Latrice Logan and several friends when the gun discharged and a bullet hit Ms. Logan in the abdomen. Mr. Howard drove her to Lourdes Medical Center in Burlington County and then left. She later died. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Investigates El Paso's Accounting
description: The El Paso Corporation, the largest United States pipeline company, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating its accounting treatment of some power contracts.
