description: In the villages of Afghanistan, they call it the sadness sickness. Some say it is the water that causes the disease. But few people in Afghanistan really know what causes goiter, the big, bulging, swelling of the neck that is a sign of an iodine deficiency afflicting an alarming number of Afghans.

description: It was undoubtedly the best sight the Jets had had on the field during this 0-4 season.

title: Players Keep Eyes Front As Cubs Fans Celebrate
description: The Cubs collected themselves at Wrigley Field this afternoon, after having mostly insulated themselves from the celebrating in this city. Posters on the streets are pushing for them, the bars and concessions stands outside the 90-year-old stadium were hawking suds and memories Monday afternoon and the police had cleared the area of revelers by early Monday morning. Most of the players avoided the area by arranging their own rides back from the airport instead of taking the team bus.

Mass of Christian Burial at Cathedral of St. Peter and Paul, St. Thomas Virgin Islands, Friday October 10th, 1:30PM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury NY, Tuesday October 14th, 11AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, attn. Dr. Jedd Wolchok's Research, 1275 York Ave, NY, NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EYER, GEORGE A. JR.
description: EYER--George A. Jr. Died at his NYC residence on October 2, 2003. He was 89 years old and died of natural causes. Mr. Eyer attended the Groton School and Yale University, and had a distinguished naval career in WWII. He was a candidate for Congress in 1958. In recent years Mr. Eyer divided his time between his apartment on Park Avenue and his farm in Pawling, NY. He leaves behind his wife of many years, Lisa Auchincloss Eyer, Diana Bohn of McLean, VA, Lisa Ryan of East Hampton, NY, and NYC, Alexandra EyerMartinez of Gold Beach, OR, as well as six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, October 8th, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Cha pel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the NYC Fire Department Widows and Orphans Fund.

title: Israeli Soldier Shot to Death Near Lebanon
description: Lebanese Hezbollah guerrillas shot and killed an Israeli soldier during a brief but intense firefight across a chain-link border fence on Monday afternoon, the Israeli military said, a sign of the heightened tensions between Israel and its Arab neighbors to the north.

title: Ferry Passenger Held in Friend's Stabbing
description: Officer Raul Delpozo, who regularly patrols the Manhattan terminal of the Staten Island Ferry, knew who his suspect was: witnesses told him that Shorty had stabbed a friend of his, leaving blood spattered all over the pavement outside the terminal. But Shorty was on the ferry, and the ferry was on its way to Staten Island.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New Rochelle: College Student Missing One Week
description: A young woman who was last seen seven days ago and whose sport utility vehicle was discovered abandoned six days ago with the keys inside is now the subject of a widening search by New Jersey and New York police officers. The woman, Danielle McGuinn, 21, of White Plains, is a student at Iona College in New Rochelle, where she was last seen before midnight Sept. 30 at a Mobil gas station on North Avenue. On Oct. 1, Ms. McGuinn's vehicle, a 2002 white Ford Explorer, was discovered on the shoulder of the New Jersey Turnpike southbound between Exits 16 and 17, near Paramus. Ms. McGuinn's father, Noel, died at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001. The police described Ms. McGuinn as white, 5 feet 7 inches tall, 145 pounds with red hair and brown eyes. She has a heart-shaped tattoo on the back of her neck and several piercings. She was last seen wearing a beige sweater, black jeans, a black hooded sweatshirt and black boots. Anyone with information is asked to call the White Plains police at (914) 422-6006. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Graham, Citing Slim Chance of Victory, Quits Presidential Bid
description: Senator Bob Graham of Florida ended his bid for the White House on last night after months of struggling to attract enough money and support to mount a competitive campaign. He is the first of the 10 Democrats in the race to drop out.

title: A New Artistic Director For Los Angeles Theater
description: Michael Ritchie, the producer of the Williamstown Theater Festival in Williamstown, Mass., has been named the new artistic director of the Center Theater Group in Los Angeles, the group's board said yesterday.

title: Dissatisfaction on Economy Is Strong, Voters Say
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7  In an emphatic end to an extraordinary campaign, Californians voted overwhelmingly to recall Gov. Gray Davis and chose as his replacement Arnold Schwarzenegger, an Austrian-born body builder and movie actor making his first run for office, according to exit polls.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Raises Forecast
description: The Japanese banking company Mizuho Financial Group raised its profit outlook for the six-month period that ended Sept. 30. Mizuho, the second Japanese bank to indicate that it had higher-than-expected earnings for the period, said it expected a profit of 230 billion yen ($2.1 billion), more than twice its original forecast. The banking group, Japan's largest in terms of assets, said rising stock prices, fewer write-offs for bad loans and a special tax rebate were behind the increase. The Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group raised its outlook last week. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: BearingPoint To Alter Results
description: BearingPoint, the computer consultant that in August said that it would restate results because of accounting errors, trimmed its net for the first three quarters of fiscal 2003 by $13 million, or 7 cents a share.

title: After a Star's Death, Hard Choices for ABC
description: The sudden death of the actor John Ritter on Sept. 11 put ABC executives in the unusually delicate position of dealing quickly with an event that had left them stunned, grieving and perplexed about the future of his popular sitcom, ''8 Simple Rules for Dating My Teenage Daughter.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUFF, VICTOR
description: HUFF--Victor. Of Alexandria, VA. on Sunday, October 5, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Sophie (nee Cohen). Devoted father of Martin and Edward. Also survived by two grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Graveside service Tuesday, October 7, 11 AM in the Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ.

title: Palestinian Cabinet Is Sworn In
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Oct. 7 — A pale Yasir Arafat swore in a Palestinian emergency government on Tuesday, a move seen as reducing the likelihood of Israeli action against the Palestinian leader.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Work Permits For Smuggling Accident Survivors
description: Forty survivors of a smuggling accident in which 19 other Hispanics died of heat exhaustion have been granted permission by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to remain in the country for one year to try to find work. As many as 100 illegal immigrants were in an enclosed trailer in May when the driver abandoned it near Victoria, 80 miles north of Corpus Christi. Fourteen people, including five still at large, were charged in the smuggling case, which is scheduled for trial in June. The immigrants given work permits were considered potential witnesses for the government. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Obstacles for U.S. Youth Team
description: Thomas Rongen's world was disrupted in February when the world youth championship for players under age 20, to be played in the United Arab Emirates, was postponed by FIFA because of the impending war in Iraq.

title: Pope Prays in Pompeii, Allaying Some Concerns on Health
description: POMPEII, Italy, Oct. 7  Pope John Paul II visited a shrine and prayed for world peace here today, completing the final part of his scheduled travel plan for the year. He spoke in relatively strong tones, allaying some concerns about his health.

title: Bank of America to Review Trading Practices at Its Funds
description: In moves aimed at repairing damage done by its role in a mutual fund trading scandal, Bank of America named two outside executives and a consulting firm today to look at its fund businesses.

Loving father of Abigail Reingold (Daniel), Jane Coppotelli (Frank), Lisa Perez (Robert) and David Petersen. Cherished grandfather of Evan, Jared, Sarah, Rachel, Rebecca, Amanda & Robert. Private family service was held. Contributions may be made to the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale.

title: A Combustible Combination: Exotic Cats in Private Hands
description: In Yann Martel's 2001 novel ''Life of Pi,'' an Indian teenager survives a shipwreck to find himself sharing a lifeboat with a 450-pound Bengal tiger. He quickly realizes that he must tame the tiger or be killed by it. And slowly, boy and tiger carve out a peaceful nautical existence.

title: New Doctor, New Diet, But Still No Cookies
description: Theories abound as to what has propelled the South Beach diet to the center of the weight-loss universe since the book bearing its name was published in April. Is it the image it conjures, of bikini-clad models picking at tropical fruit salad between sun-drenched photo shoots? Is it the aqua shimmer of the book jacket, as eye-catching as the surf off Ocean Drive?

description: Curses, if one chooses to believe in them, cannot be erased with taking a single step in baseball's three-step postseason. The Boston Red Sox, after all, still have plenty of work to do.

title: Weighing Pain, Gain and Risk in Replacing a Hip
description: A runner for 20 years, Nancy Webster of Western Springs, Ill., unknowingly suffered from congenital hip dysplasia, causing her hip joints to develop abnormally. The years of running took a toll on her compromised hips, and four years ago, when she was 50, she had to have hip replacement surgery, performed at Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago.

title: Taliban May Be Planning Larger Attacks, U.S. Envoy Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Oct. 7  The Bush administration's special envoy to Afghanistan, Zalmay Khalilzad, warned today that the Taliban movement and its Al Qaeda partners in the region may be planning larger or "more spectacular attacks" in Afghanistan as part of a campaign against the reconstruction process.

title: Homeland Security Dept. Planning 7 Offices Overseas to Screen Visas

description: The Turkish Parliament voted by a large margin today to approve the dispatch of peacekeeper forces to Iraq, a big victory for the Bush administration in its effort to broaden the foreign role in pacifying postwar Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROCKLIN, RALPH J.
description: ROCKLIN--Ralph J. Died on September 13, 2003, in the hospital. We thank you for sharing with us your love of New York City, libraries and museums, painters of light, prints, music and poetry, kittens and puns. He is survived by his children, Edward Rocklin of California, Peter Rocklin of New Jersey, Arthur Rocklin of Maryland, Dorothy Rocklin of Massachusetts, and by his granddaughter Rachel Rocklin.

title: A Top Republican Says He Will Not Seek New Term
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 — Senator Don Nickles, the Oklahoma Republican and Budget Committee chairman known for his crusades against taxes and government spending, announced today he would retire rather than seek a fifth term, a decision that opens up opportunities for Democrats to reclaim his seat.

title: Forget Clothes. These Rumors Are Really Hot.
description: For all that was reassuringly predictable about this Fashion Week with its giddy spring colors, its welcome triumphs by designers and their handmaidens (if the stylist Katie Grand was not considered golden before, her Prada and Miu Miu shows were a kind of career apotheosis), its postshow debauchery -- the most compelling trends spoke of uncertainty and flux. In other words, dinner table conversation here last week turned less often to the cocaine habits of models and the usual bedroom prattle than to the more weirdly compelling issue of personnel.

title: SOCCER: Soccer Analysis; Cup Defeat Reflects End of Era
description: They had the resolve of pioneers, traveling to soccer outposts like China and Haiti in the early days, living on candy bars, bathing in hotel pools when there was no running water or electricity. At first, they played in front of their friends and parents, but later they filled stadiums and, one of them, Mia Hamm, became the most widely known soccer player in the country.

title: Big British Brewer Sheds Its Pubs for $4.2 Billion
description: After weeks of frenzied deal-making, Scottish & Newcastle, Britain's biggest brewer, agreed on Monday to sell its chain of 1,400 pubs and lodges to the privately held Spirit Amber group for $4.2 billion in cash, becoming one of the last big brewers to shed its traditional retail outlets.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Oil Pipeline
description: The Canadian energy group Enbridge announced plans to broaden the market for oil from Alberta in the United States by building a $600 million pipeline from northern Wisconsin to southern Illinois. The line, scheduled for completion in 2007, will connect with an existing pipeline between Chicago and Oklahoma, whose flow is being reversed to southbound from northbound. Canada's output of crude oil is expected to grow from 2.7 million barrels a day to 3.4 million over the next decade as it extracts more oil from deposits of oil sands. Enbridge said that the pipeline, with an initial capacity of 250,000 barrels a day would give it access to the St. Louis area and to Kentucky. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: PeopleSoft Again Raises Its 3rd-Quarter Forecast
description: PeopleSoft Inc. on Monday once again raised its earnings forecast for the third quarter, indicating to some analysts that a hostile takeover of the company by the Oracle Corporation was likely to prove ever more difficult.

title: Tough Questions Are Raised On Fen-Phen Compensation
description: The trust set up to compensate people injured by fen-phen, the formerly popular diet drug, says that an alliance of doctors and lawyers filing invalid claims threatens to drain its coffers. Some plaintiffs' lawyers contend that the trust simply wants to delay making payments to deserving people who are sick.

title: For Youth, Downside to Dieting
description: For boys and girls in early adolescence, dieting may do more harm than good, a study released yesterday concluded.

title: Tyson Refund Is Rejected
description: Mike Tyson will not receive a $5.9 million tax refund from Ohio, where he claimed he was not a resident in 1995 and 1996. He made the claim even though a condition of his parole from Indiana on a rape conviction in 1995 was that he live at his mansion in Southington, Ohio.

He spotted a couple of New York police officers standing at their sidewalk post and ambled over.

description: A federal appeals court let the Federal Trade Commission enforce its do-not-call program against telemarketers yesterday, while the agency appeals a judge's ruling that declared the rule unconstitutional.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Terayon Says 3rd-Quarter Loss Narrows
description: Terayon Communication Systems, a maker of cable modems, said yesterday that its third-quarter net loss narrowed because of higher sales. Shares rose 24 percent. The net loss of 10 to 12 cents a share compares with a net loss of 22 cents in the period a year earlier, the company said in a preliminary earnings estimate. Revenue for the quarter rose to $37 million to $38 million, from $24.5 million a year earlier. Terayon, which has not reported a quarterly profit in two years, wants to improve sales of its so-called headend products, or central control equipment for high-speed cable Internet providers. Last week it said Comcast would test its equipment. Neither company commented on any possible sales agreements. Shares of Terayon rose $1.50, to $7.71.

While the G.D.P. helps measure the current economic performance, it is not a leading indicator -- one that predicts conditions.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Scrum Money
description: The World Rugby Cup will expand the economy of Australia by about one billion Australian dollars or about $685 million, according to a report from Citigroup. The report said that the competition, which will involve teams from 20 nations, will take place in 10 cities, starting Friday and continuing until Nov. 22. The games are expected to increase the nation's economic growth by 0.2 percent in the quarter. Two million tickets have been sold for the 48 games. John Shaw (NYT)

Livestock graze in pastures, and fields of watermelon and tomatoes bake in a climate that is faultlessly Mediterranean. Acres of golden grain form the primary and secondary residence for more than 140 species of aquatic waterfowl and wildlife.

description: THE BRONX: WOMAN DIES IN HOUSE FIRE A 64-year-old woman was killed in a house fire yesterday in Edenwald, the authorities said. The woman, Francise Davis, of 1165 East 226th Street, was pronounced dead at her home, where the fire broke out, the police said. Another person was taken to Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center and treated for smoke inhalation, the police said. The cause of the fire is under investigation, a Fire Department spokesman said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Explosion in Bogot Raises New Fears of Bombing Campaign
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 8  A car bomb exploded this morning in a crowded commercial district here in the country's capital, killing six people and injuring 19, the metropolitan police said. The explosion  the deadliest in Bogota since 36 people died in February in a bombing at an elite social club  raised new fears of an urban bombing campaign in the country's simmering civil conflict.

description: To the Editor:

title: REGENERON DRUG FAILS TO SHOW BENEFIT IN STUDY
description: Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology company, failed to find a significant benefit from its experimental rheumatoid arthritis medicine in a study. Improvements seen in patients taking Regeneron's IL-1 Trap drug were so small that they could have been the result of mere chance. Stock in Regeneron, which is based in Tarrytown, N.Y., fell $3.81, or 21 percent, to close at $14.59. Regeneron, which has no products on the market and four drugs in development, said it considered the findings positive and plans to keep working on the drug with Novartis of Switzerland. The study was part of the second of three phases generally required for regulatory approval.

title: Seattle Paper Seeks Appeal of Ruling
description: The Seattle Times asked a state appeals court on Tuesday to review a lower court's ruling that prevents the newspaper from dissolving its 20-year-old operating arrangement with The Seattle Post-Intelligencer.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: SARS REPORT URGES NEW AGENCY A federal government report on the SARS outbreak last spring said the public health care system in Toronto was unable to manage the crisis effectively because of prior budget cuts and shortages of hospital staffing. The report focused most of its criticism on what it described as a lack of cooperation among health officials in the city, provincial and federal governments. Its main recommendation was for the creation of a federal agency similar to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: State Payments To Religious Groups
description: Gov. Sonny Perdue said he would propose an amendment to the state Constitution in the next legislative session allowing the government to give money to religious groups that provide services. In a provision that Mr. Perdue said originated from 19th-century anti-Catholicism, the state Constitution specifically prohibits the direct or indirect financing of religious groups. The governor would add the line ''except as permitted or required by the United States Constitution, as amended.'' Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Tacos, Burritos and Tortas To Devour on the Fly
description: The back of Pampano, 209 East 49th Street, has been turned into Pampano Taqueria, a counter that opens into the food court of the Crystal Pavilion, 805 Third Avenue (50th Street). It offers alluring Mexican tacos, burritos, quesadillas and tortas (sandwiches) at downscale prices. You can do no better than the camern, a taco made with shrimp and a sauce of forceful chile de rbol mellowed with black beans and avocado ($3.50 for one, $8.50 for three). The pork and tomatillo taco al pastor ($3 or $8 for three) is almost as good. The seasoned tortillas are handmade daily. Most of the items on a menu of dozens cost less than $9.

title: U.S. to Appeal Ruling on 9/11 Terror Suspect
description: The Justice Department announced on Tuesday that it would appeal a judge's ruling that would bar federal prosecutors from seeking the death penalty against Zacarias Moussaoui and from trying to convince a jury that he was linked to the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Banana Republic Seeks New Agency
description: Banana Republic, the retail chain owned by Gap Inc. , said yesterday that it was seeking an agency to help handle the creative duties on its account, which had been handled internally since 1997. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: A Baritone's Serious Recital, Laced With a Little Attitude
description: For several years the young baritone Nathaniel Webster has been touted and heard around New York: in a Christa Ludwig master class, a small part in ''Carmen'' for his City Opera debut, a Brooklyn Philharmonic concert. Last season, he joined the ensemble of the Frankfurt Opera, and the experience seems to have helped settle the lanky singer and ripen his voice.

title: Graffiti Artist Who Created Dean Mural Is Held
description: The graffiti artist who created a controversial background for a speech by Howard Dean, the Democratic presidential hopeful, was arrested Monday, after a police officer who had been looking for him since 1999 recognized him in a newspaper photograph, the authorities said.

title: To See and to Be Seen, Perchance to Dine
description: IT took nerve to put a restaurant in Lever House, one of Manhattan's Modernist jewels. The name is pure magic, a guaranteed draw, but great architecture can be tough on a restaurant. Think of the wretched designer, who can only approach such a project with trembling hand. And pity the poor chef who tries to keep diners focused on their plates. It's a little like opening for the Rolling Stones. No matter how good you are, all the people out there are shifting in their seats.

title: Fresh Baked Pie Warms Autumn's Chill
description: EVEN on rainy days, the parking lot at Rose Orchards in North Branford, Conn., looks like a drive-in theater, with cars lined up side by side in neat rows. The occupants are not looking up at a big screen, but down into their plates, digging into slices of the farm's latest treat, fresh baked pie  la mode.

title: How Blair Lost by Winning
description: On BBC radio the other morning, there was a poignant moment when the Pentagon adviser Kenneth Adelman was talking about the war in Iraq. ''It bothers me that people in Britain don't see it as people in America see it,'' he said. ''We did a beautiful thing.''

title: Off the Menu
description: LUCY MEXICAN BARBECUE will open tomorrow in ABC Carpet & Home, 35 East 18th Street. PHIL SUAREZ, above, an owner of Patria nearby, has named the restaurant, his newest, for his wife, and has put ANDREW DICATALDO, the chef at Patria, in charge of the kitchen. The house specialties will be meats and fish rubbed with chilies, wrapped in banana leaves and slow-roasted in his wood-burning oven. The room, formerly Chicama, has been brightened and lightened with lots of pale linen. Mr. Suarez and Mr. DiCataldo are also making menu changes at Pipa, the adjacent tapas bar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBBINS, HON. ALFRED S.
description: ROBBINS--Hon. Alfred S. The Board of Directors, Administration and Medical Staff of Winthrop-University Hospital are deeply saddened by the passing of Judge Alfred S. Robbins, a good friend and great leader. Admitted to the New York State Bar in 1957, Judge Robbins' abilities were evident early in his career in the legal profession and he rose to the position of Justice of the New York State Supreme Court in 1979. Elected to the Board of Directors of Winthrop-University Hospital in 1974, he was often recognized for his analytical skills, personal commitment and integrity. The Judge's leadership qualities were exhibited during his tenure as Chairman of the Board from 1988-1994. His many achievements included the construction of an Ambulatory Surgery Center, MRI Center, and the opening of Long Island's largest hospital-based Dialysis Center. He was named Trustee of the Year in 1994 and in 2003, in recognition of his three decades of service to Winthrop, Judge Robbins was elected to the esteemed position of Honorary Director. His loyalty and devotion will never be forgotten. Our sincere condolences to his wife Louise and his family. Patrick K. Long Chairman of the Board Daniel P. Walsh, President, & Chief Executive Officer Steven Carsons, MD, President, Executive Committee of the Medical Staff Robert Bartolomeo, MD President, Medical Staff Organization

title: Broker for Stewart Seeks Separate Trial
description: Peter E. Bacanovic, the former Merrill Lynch & Company broker indicted along with Martha Stewart on charges of obstructing a federal investigation into insider trading, wants a separate trial, according to court records.

title: Even in Magic Acts, Tigers and Bullets Can Be Lethal
description: ''I think they have to be the most beautiful animals on the face of the earth,'' Rick Thomas said during his magic act at the Tropicana here on Monday. He was talking about white tigers (he uses five in his stage show), the kind of animal that on Friday night critically injured Roy Horn of the longstanding Las Vegas act Siegfried & Roy. But in Las Vegas, as on Broadway, the show must go on.

title: Russia and Germany: A Reunion of Bookworms
description: The word here is that Russia's publishing industry is back on its feet, after languishing for years amid the country's economic collapse and political dislocation. But more interesting than that bit of news, perhaps, is that Russia chose the Frankfurt Book Fair, which opened Tuesday, to trumpet its literary comeback.

title: Accused of Abuse, Jesuit College Leader Quits
description: The president of Loyola University New Orleans resigned yesterday after he was accused of sexual abuse by a former student at a high school where he once was the principal.

title: Arafat Swears In New Palestinian Cabinet
description: A visibly pale Yasir Arafat swore in an emergency Palestinian government on Tuesday, a move seen as reducing the likelihood of Israeli action against the Palestinian leader.

title: Corrections
description: A letter on Sept. 15 about music file sharing misstated a phrase in a quotation from the singer Huey Lewis. Mr. Lewis said Bruce Springsteen ''probably earned more in 10 nights at the Meadowlands last month than he did from his [current] record'' -- not ''in his entire recording career.''

title: Israel Increases Troops in Palestinian Territories
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 8  Faced with dozens of warnings of possible Palestinian attacks, Israel ordered additional troops to the West Bank and the Gaza Strip today and maintained tough restrictions on Palestinian movements in those areas.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Foreign Exchange Rate
description: Trading in some foreign-exchange instruments involving the Chinese currency, the yuan, suggest that the government might be ready to let the currency appreciate in value. The United States Treasury secretary, John W. Snow, has been encouraging China to be more flexible regarding the value of its currency to reduce the United States' trade deficit with China. James Malcolm, a currency strategist at J.P. Morgan Chase & Company in Singapore, wrote in a report that he expected China to widen the limits on its currency gradually. Currency traders said an increase in the value of a derivative known as the 12-month forward contract rate indicated that a change might be possible in the next year.

description: WALSH--James E. 10/8/342/18/03. Your 1st Birthday and your Dear Mother Elizabeth's 15th Anniversary in Heaven. It has been a painful, lonely eight months for your family and all who had the honor of your caring friendship. Happy Birthday, Big Jim. We send you love and kisses, Darling Husband, Loving Dad and Wonderful Poppi

description: Fox, ESPN and ESPN2 set viewership records for Major League Baseball's division series, led by Fox's average of 11.2 million viewers for its five games.

title: Cubs Keeping Legacy of Caray Ever Present
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 7  Dusty Baker has battled the Cubs' mystique from the other side. In 1998, as the Giants' manager, Baker's team lost to the Cubs in a one-game playoff at Wrigley Field. Now that he is managing the Cubs, Baker can laugh about the circumstances that day.

title: Market Place; Dollar Weakens Again (No U.S. Tears Are Shed)
description: The dollar's fall accelerated yesterday, dropping below 110 yen, reaching an eight-year low against the Canadian dollar and slumping against the euro. But the decline is still small compared with previous episodes of weakness and, for now, is still a positive for the struggling American economy.

title: Salads by the Pound and Meatloaves in Miniature
description: A platter of pale, creamy salad flecked with green caught my eye. ''That's the best tuna salad in New York,'' said Dennis Dessauer, who is a partner with Key Winstead in Winstead's, a new takeout shop at 451 Amsterdam Avenue (81st Street).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KING, WOOD, DAVID
description: KING-WOOD--David. A memorial program will be held for David King-Wood at St. Bernard's School, 4 East 98 Street, NYC at 5:30 PM on Thursday, October 9, 2003.

title: Hey, Somebody Moved The Polling Place
description: For this former New Yorker, accustomed to the convenience of voting in a nearby school, the California recall election proved daunting. Though he had voted for years in Los Angeles at the Paul Revere Middle School, a sprawling junior high on 26th Street and Sunset Boulevard, when he drove there on Tuesday afternoon, the parking lot was oddly empty. It took several seconds to realize that there was no voting going on.

title: PHILIP MORRIS PARENT BUYS GREEK TOBACCO COMPANY
description: The Altria Group, the parent company of Philip Morris, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay 18.02 euros a share ($21.22) to buy 76 percent of Papastratos, Greece's biggest maker of cigarettes, valuing the company at 481 million euros ($567 million). The sale will be carried out within 15 days, Papastratos said. Altria has European Union approval for the plan to buy the stake and make a public tender offer for the rest of the stock. Philip Morris said in May that it would pay as much as 18.15 euros a share for the Papastratos stake. It said it would make an offer for the rest of the shares at a price that is at least as high as the one paid to the main shareholders.

title: Jeb Bush Files Brief in Case Of Woman on Life Support
description: For the second time this year, Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida is seeking to sway a contentious case involving an incapacitated person, this time trying to keep a brain-damaged woman alive against her husband's wishes.

title: Review/Fashion; For a Start, Seeing Double in Paris
description: Fashion's great broom swept away the posies and prints on Tuesday as the French spring 2004 collections opened with an impudent fury of avant-garde clothes as inspired as they were disturbing. Between Jun Takahashi of Undercover and the Belgian design team of An Vandevorst and Filip Arickx, there was enough soul and conceptual wit to counterbalance disappointing collections by those perennial providers of maverick design, Martin Margiela and Yohji Yamamoto.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: F.B.I. Looking For Bias In Assault
description: The F.B.I. has joined the investigation of the beating of a mentally disabled black man in east Texas to determine if he was the victim of a hate crime. The man, Billy Ray Johnson, 42, suffered injuries to his brain and face and has been hospitalized since he was found on Sept. 28 beside a highway near Linden, about 40 miles southeast of Texarkana. Linden police say they believe Mr. Johnson was attacked by a group of white men who took him to a party and then assaulted him before abandoning him in a ditch. No one has been arrested in the incident. Steve Barnes (NYT)

His role as Boston's closer had ended in 2001 after he had one meltdown too many, and that was among the many reasons fatalistic Red Sox fans were gripped with terror when he entered the decisive game of the American League division series on Monday against Oakland. Scott Williamson had walked two batters and the Red Sox' 4-3 lead seemed destined to evaporate, more fodder for the multitudes convinced that the franchise is cursed.

description: A roadside bomb in this farming community about 25 miles south of Baghdad killed two American soldiers and an Iraqi translator on Monday night, the United States military said Tuesday. Two more soldiers were wounded.

title: Dream Teams
description: The Boston Red Sox' nail-biting victory over the Oakland Athletics on Monday night moves professional baseball one step closer to the Dream Series: the Red Sox versus the Chicago Cubs. With all due respect to our New York readership -- Yankee fans among them -- to George Steinbrenner and to the Yankees themselves, we find it hard to resist the emotional tug and symmetrical possibilities of a series between teams that seem to have been put on earth to tantalize and then crush their zealous fans. Together they account for 180 years of futility. The Cubs have not won a World Series since 1908. The Red Sox have not won one since 1918, a little more than a year before they shipped Babe Ruth to the Yankees, a famously bizarre transaction that ushered in the era of Yankee domination.

title: KB TOYS TO EXPAND OPERATIONS AT SEARS FOR HOLIDAYS
description: Sears, Roebuck and Company said yesterday that KB Toys would be sold at 600 Sears stores in the United States and Puerto Rico this holiday season. Terms were not disclosed. The deal extends the relationship between Sears and KB Toys, which is privately held and is based in Pittsfield, Mass. Sears, which has 860 department stores, sold KB Toys at 29 stores in 2001 and 77 in 2002. KB Toys will sell at Sears from mid-October through early January. KB Toys has more than 1,300 stores nationwide. Sears is based in Hoffman Estates, Ill.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: TERAYON SAYS 3RD-QUARTER LOSS NARROWS Terayon Communication Systems , a maker of cable modems, said yesterday that its third-quarter net loss narrowed because of higher sales. Shares rose 24 percent. The net loss of 10 to 12 cents a share compares with a net loss of 22 cents in the period a year earlier, the company said in a preliminary earnings estimate. Revenue for the quarter rose to $37 million to $38 million, from $24.5 million a year earlier. Terayon, which has not reported a quarterly profit in two years, wants to improve sales of its so-called headend products, or central control equipment for high-speed cable Internet providers. Last week it said Comcast would test its equipment. Neither company commented on any possible sales agreements. Shares of Terayon rose $1.50, to $7.71. (Bloomberg News)

title: Songs of Love Gone Wrong And Rejection Never Ending
description: ''I'm in love again,'' Howie Day sang as he opened his concert at Irving Plaza. ''Brace yourself now.'' Actually, he should be bracing himself, since in most of his songs he is the one who ends up lonely and pining for lost love.

title: Newcomers to the Devils Get With the Program
description: When the Devils begin defense of their Stanley Cup championship tonight in Boston against the Bruins, do not expect this season's squad to be radically different from the previous dozen or so Devils teams.

title: Conditional Approval Given To British Broadcast Merger
description: British regulators gave conditional approval on Tuesday to a merger between the broadcasting companies Granada and Carlton Communications, paving the way for the creation of a company that would control more than half of Britain's television advertising market.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Dengue Fever Detected
description: Officials reported a case of dengue fever in a man who had not traveled outside Hong Kong recently. While the mosquito-borne disease is a problem across Southeast Asia, it has not been one in Hong Kong. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Fear of Cooking
description: To the Editor:

title: One Victim When Jobs Go Overseas: U.S. Office Space
description: Operating out of a 200-square-foot, three-employee office in Times Square, Chris Graham tries to persuade companies to take their cue from Wall Street firms like Morgan Stanley and J.P. Morgan Chase and farm out some of their research needs to a developing country where educated employees usually earn a fraction of what Americans are paid.

title: Uranium Enrichment to Continue, Iran Says
description: The foreign minister, Kamal Kharrazi, said on Tuesday that Iran would continue to enrich uranium despite international opposition, the Islamic Republic News Agency quoted him as saying.

title: N.C.A.A. Adds Academic Investigators
description: The N.C.A.A. has increased its investigative and enforcement staff and is prepared to begin taking scholarships from athletic programs that underachieve academically as early as the 2004-5 school year.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Report On Indian Tobacco Raid
description: An independent panel charged with investigating a July 15 state police raid on the Narragansett Indian tribe's tax-free tobacco shop reported that muddled instructions on both sides, unclear plans and a longstanding animosity between the state and the tribe contributed to the violent incursion that sent seven tribe members to the hospital. The panel recommended that Gov. Donald L. Carcieri create a position to foster relations with the tribe, and that the state and tribe reach an agreement on cigarette taxes. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: White House Seeks to Minimize Iraq Differences With Rumsfeld
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 — The White House and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld sought today to knock down the impression that Mr. Rumsfeld was angered about being left in the dark about a change in the handling of postwar Iraq.

title: California Insurrection Puts Other Politicians on Notice
description: The voter revolt in California sent a jolt through national political circles on Tuesday night, raising the possibility that other embattled governors could face similar insurrections in an atmosphere of rising animosity toward incumbents and increasingly anger-driven campaigns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOWLING, WILLIAM C., JR.
description: DOWLING--William C., Jr. On October 3, 2003 at age 77. Owner of Cardow Jewelers, the Carib Beach Hotel and the Emerald Beach Resort. Son of the late William C. and Marion Dowling. Mass of Christian Burial at Cathedral of St. Peter and Paul, St. Thomas Virgin Islands, Friday October 10th, 1:30PM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury NY, Tuesday October 14th, 11AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, attn. Dr. Jedd Wolchok's Research, 1275 York Ave, NY, NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PETERSEN, FRITHJOF R.
description: PETERSEN--Frithjof R. Died peacefully with his children by his side. Beloved husband of the late Harriet Nadel Petersen. Loving father of Abigail Reingold (Daniel), Jane Coppotelli (Frank), Lisa Perez (Robert) and David Petersen. Cherished grandfather of Evan, Jared, Sarah, Rachel, Rebecca, Amanda & Robert. Private family service was held. Contributions may be made to the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale.

title: Viktor & Rolf: concept to concrete
description: PARIS  Disembodied bows and collars shine bright white in the inky darkness. Then the eye adjusts to bold, classic, black silhouettes in the showcase  and to a catwalk show running on a video screen. Welcome to the eerie universe of neo-surrealists Viktor & Rolf.

title: Our Towns; In Frayed Slice Of a Tidy City, Red Flags Rise
description: OVER there, not far from a buckled fence and the punched-out windows of an abandoned unit in the old Southfield Village public housing complex, was where a stray bullet killed a 7-year-old girl who was eating cake at a birthday party.

title: Little League Fathers With Two Views of the Field
description: Sporting events, those scriptless dramas, often provide greater suspense and more profound human insight than the stage does. And there's no comparison between the current baseball playoffs, with the thrilling games of last weekend, and ''Rounding Third,'' Richard Dresser's amiable, toothless new comedy set in the diminutive arena of Little League.

title: Afghan Envoy Warns U.S. Of Possible Major Attacks
description: The Bush administration's special envoy to Afghanistan, Zalmay Khalilzad, warned Tuesday that the Taliban and Al Qaeda might be planning ''larger'' or ''more spectacular attacks'' in Afghanistan as part of a campaign against the reconstruction process.

title: O'Neal Wants to Do His Thing
description: Shaquille O'Neal is taking umbrage with Phil Jackson again, wondering if Jackson, his coach, truly understands his talents and how he fits into the evolving portrait of the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: New Model of the Universe: Its Shaped Like a Soccerball
description: In an unusual logjam of contradictory claims, a revolutionary new model of the universe, as a soccerball, arrives on astronomers' desks on Thursday morning at least slightly deflated.

title: Corrections
description: A pop review on Monday about a performance by Sting in Manhattan misstated the site in some copies. It was the Hammerstein Ballroom, not the Roseland.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: No Appeal On Dismissal Of Terror Charges
description: Federal prosecutors will not appeal the dismissal of the most serious charges against Lynne F. Stewart, the lawyer representing accused terrorists who was herself accused of aiding terrorism. United States Attorney James B. Comey, through a spokesman, declined to elaborate on the decision, which was made on Monday and disclosed yesterday. Ms. Stewart still faces charges for making false statements and defrauding the government, and a trial on those counts is set for January. In July, Judge John G. Koeltl dismissed the terrorism counts as unconstitutionally vague. Ms. Stewart was indicted in April 2002 after she and a translator visited Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, who was convicted of plotting to blow up New York landmarks. The authorities accused Ms. Stewart of helping to pass messages from the sheik. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Jazz Sits In on the Curriculum and Moves a Young Audience
description: Before Billie, Dizzy and Miles melted the hearts of the sixth graders at Public School 156 in Brownsville, Brooklyn, the students viewed jazz as old people's music, their parents' music, as unhip as Beethoven and Brahms.

title: A New College Ranking System Arrives, Wanted or Not
description: The ranking of top colleges has become a multimillion-dollar industry for magazine and book publishers, fueled by anxious parents looking for guidance and by the institutions themselves, which spend lavishly to raise their standings in such surveys.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Outlook Improves
description: One of Japan's largest banks, the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company, said that profit in the first half would probably reach 41 billion yen ($369 million), two and a half times the forecast. The bank had expected to earn 16 billion yen in the six months ended Sept. 30, but rising stock prices and a tax refund aided its balance sheet. The bank also plans to spend less writing off or making provisions for nonperforming loans. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Gauging Rollovers on a Track, and Not Just on Paper
description: Federal regulators demonstrated their new vehicle rollover test on Tuesday, hoping to better gauge the effectiveness of technologies like electronic stability systems that are available on some cars, sport utility vehicles and light trucks.

title: NATO Agrees to Widen Role In Afghanistan Beyond Kabul
description: NATO has decided in principle to expand its force in Afghanistan beyond Kabul, senior alliance officials said Tuesday. American officials said final approval could come as soon as this week.

title: When Israel Acts Against Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Trial Opens In Journalist's Death
description: The trial began for Muhammad Reza Aghdam Ahmadi, an intelligence agent accused of taking part in the suspicious killing of an Iranian-Canadian journalist in July, when she was in custody. He denied the charges. The journalist, Zahra Kazemi, died of a brain hemorrhage caused by a blow to the head sometime when she was in custody. She was arrested for taking unauthorized pictures outside the Evin prison in Tehran. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Stamford; An Empire Of Offices Fades Out
description: High Ridge Park, a 38-acre harbinger of the suburban office campus boom of the 1970's and 1980's was sold this week to the George Comfort & Sons Real Estate Company in Manhattan for $86 million. It was the last remaining piece of a 4.4-million-square-foot real estate empire created in Stamford from the mid-1960's to the mid-1980's by the F.D. Rich Company. Much of the rest was lost during the real estate debacle of the late 1980's and early 1990's.

description: To the Editor:

title: New Lives For Old Knives
description: NO matter how keen an edge a knife has when new, sooner or later it will need to be sharpened -- a job that most home cooks tend to neglect. Guilty of this myself, I recently cast a critical eye on my two sharpeners, one a sharpening steel for knives that need just a bit more edge and the other a bulky and noisy electrical machine for those due for a serious workover. What I lacked was something in between, a simply designed sharpener I could keep handy to bring a slightly dull knife back to life.

description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Cranbury Township: Two Killed In Crash
description: Two men were killed late Monday on the New Jersey Turnpike in a chain-reaction pileup, the police said yesterday. Four people were hurt in the 11:30 p.m. collision near Exit 8, which snarled the northbound lanes of the turnpike for six hours. The dead were identified as the driver of a 1992 Buick, Lloyd Provost, 52, and Jerry Lavalley, 53, who was in the front passenger seat. Mary McKee, 44, was lying down in the rear seat and survived, largely unhurt, but was taken to an area hospital. Mr. Provost was apparently transporting several motorcycles when a tractor-trailer hit the Buick's trailer. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: U.S. CAN'T LOCATE MISSILES ONCE HELD IN ARSENAL OF IRAQ
description: The United States military has been unable to locate a large number of shoulder-fired antiaircraft missiles that were part of the arsenal of Saddam Hussein, officials say, compounding the security risks for airports and airlines in Iraq and around the world.

title: 3 Killed in 90-M.P.H. Crash on West Side, and Friends Are Mystified
description: Two teenagers from New Jersey and a man from Manhattan were killed in a fiery crash early yesterday when their 2002 Mercedes-Benz, speeding down the West Side Highway at more than 90 miles per hour, hit a concrete barrier near the entrance to the Chelsea Piers sports complex, the police said.

description: There are changes involving two senior creative executives at DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group.

description: KORNETZ--Norman S., 90, of Southbury, CT. Loving father of Maxwell E. Kornetz of Southbury, CT & Juliet Kornetz of Secaucus, NJ. Dear brother of Mildred (Mitzi) Kornetz of Southbury, CT (formerly of Brookline, MA), & the late Emmaline Kornetz. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to a charity of your choice. For service information please call 800-367-3708.

title: Bowl Bid Competitor For Giants Stadium
description: National Football League Commissioner Paul Tagliabue yesterday appeared to reduce expectations of a Super Bowl coming to Giants Stadium in 2008.

title: Based Loosely on a Traditional Tale From Greece
description: FEW genres are as frustrating to me as the moderately priced Greek restaurant. I love Greek food, maybe too well. Each year, predictably around spring, I begin to crave Greek food in its modest taverna form -- lively grilled fish and roasted meats, zesty dips and salads, perhaps a bowl of tiny fried fish or octopus, seasoned simply with little more than good olive oil and lemon juice.

title: U.S. May Drop Attempt at Vote On Iraq in U.N.
description: The Bush administration has run into such stiff opposition at the United Nations Security Council to its plan for the future government of Iraq that it has pulled back from seeking a quick vote endorsing the proposal and may shelve it altogether, administration officials said Tuesday.

title: Smart Money Is on Two For Nobel in Economics
description: If the bettors are correct, a man named Ed is likely to win the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science this morning.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Soccer Stake Sold
description: The British Sky Broadcasting Group, the satellite television company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, sold its 9.99 percent stake in the Manchester United soccer team to an investment company that is owned by two Irish horse racing magnates for $103 million. The two buyers, John Magnier and J.P. McManus, increased their stake in the team to 23 percent. The sale by BSkyB -- 26 million shares -- came four years after the regulatory authorities prevented BSkyB from acquiring the team for $1 billion. Mr. Magnier and Mr. McManus, who bought the shares through their Cubic Expression Company, have said that they are not planning a takeover bid. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about an experiment by Google that places a counter on its home page to track the number of searches performed by some of its most frequent users misstated the working of the software ''cookie'' underlying the process. A cookie, a type of small text file, identifies the user's computer when the person next returns to a Web site. It does not transmit information to a site.

title: Packaging and Pollution
description: To the Editor:

title: Oversight Plan of Lenders Is Criticized
description: President Bush will not support legislation aimed at strengthening oversight of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac unless it gives the new regulator authority to block new products, a Bush administration official said yesterday.

title: Recall Just Who Started This Thing, If You Will
description: The party at the Los Angeles Century Plaza hotel got rolling at 4 p.m. Tuesday. It was a party for Arnold Schwarzenegger, but Darrell Issa, the millionaire congressman who bankrolled the effort to oust Gov. Gray Davis, was greeted as recall royalty.

title: A Staten Island Cheerleader, With an O, Not an I
description: ENSCONCED in the wood-paneled office on the second floor of Staten Island's Borough Hall that for years was the power base of Guy V. Molinari and his family, the current borough president, James P. Molinaro, contemplated Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's approval ratings.

title: Praise God and Raise the Roof
description: Gospel and the blues grew up as neighbors and faced the same hardships, so it's no wonder that they share a musical language. While their perspectives seem different - the positive thinking and hope for eternal reward in gospel versus the hard-headed realism and subversive ironies of the blues - in practice both call for survival through sheer determination. Many musicians worked both sides of the boundary, and one of the most extraordinary was Sister Rosetta Tharpe, the guitar-wielding gospel belter, who died in 1973 and whose old performances have provided some peaks in the PBS series ``The Blues.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Welcome home. All is forgiven. We have a lot to discuss.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buffalo: Nursing-Home Allegations Settled
description: The owner of two Buffalo-area nursing homes has agreed to pay $3 million to settle allegations of inadequate patient care and staffing, as well as falsification of records, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer said yesterday. Between 1999 and 2001, state inspectors said, staff members at the homes left patients' bed sores untreated and falsified records to indicate that patients had received care when they had not, Mr. Spitzer's office said. Under the civil settlement, Neil Chur, who owns Waters of Orchard Park, a 202-bed home, and Waters of Aurora Park, a 320-bed home, did not admit wrongdoing but must appoint an independent monitor for the homes for the next two years. Since the investigation, both residences have come into compliance with state health codes, a spokesman for Mr. Spitzer said. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Balancing Cattle, Land and Ledgers
description: HARD by the three small streams that tumble together here to form the headwaters of the Missouri River, George Kahrle tends to a herd of 50 or so bawling raven-black cattle.

title: Knicks Drawing Closer To Obtaining Mutombo
description: The Knicks are getting closer to adding the 7-foot-2 center Dikembe Mutombo to their center-deprived roster when he clears waivers, and Knicks Coach Don Chaney is looking to upgrade at point guard.

title: A Few Wrinkles in Shrivers Marriage to NBC News
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  Maria Shriver, who has at times acted as a shock absorber for her husband, Arnold Schwarzenegger, in his campaign for governor, plans to return to her job as a correspondent and occasional anchor at "Dateline NBC."

title: Knife in Shoe Is Found at Newark Airport
description: A California man trying to board a morning flight to Los Angeles was arrested on Monday at Newark Liberty International Airport when security officers found an eight-inch dagger in a hollowed-out compartment in his sneaker.

title: DAVIS IS OUT, SCHWARZENEGGER IS IN BY BIG MARGINS IN CALIFORNIA RECALL
description: In an emphatic end to an extraordinary campaign, Californians voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to recall Gov. Gray Davis and chose as his replacement Arnold Schwarzenegger, the Austrian-born bodybuilder and movie actor making his first run for office.

title: Carrier Layoffs Spotlight Syracuse's Battle to Rise From Dependence on Manufacturing
description: Since the late 18th century, when its first settlers turned brine sucked from deep wells into salt, Syracuse has been a city that made things.

title: 2 Envoys Urge West to Stay Course in Balkans
description: War and bloodshed are much more riveting than peace, a basic fact of geopolitics that haunts the land that once was Yugoslavia.

title: Mass brands hone their lines
description: PARIS  In luxury goods, company directors ask the gods for a hit handbag. More than any other product, a coveted leather bag swinging through business lounges from Heathrow to Los Angeles signals to consumers  and financial analysts  that the company is hot.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 29 about renewed criticism of the Bush administration for its handling of intelligence before the Iraq war misstated the circumstances under which international weapons inspectors left Iraq in 1998. They were withdrawn by the United Nations, not expelled by Saddam Hussein.

title: Money Troubles at Ground Zero
description: There is an astonishing array of talent ready to rebuild the World Trade Center site. Six of the world's best architects have been asked to help design the project, with the possibility of other creative voices yet to come. What may not be easily available is the money for all their phenomenal creations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIOVE, WILLIAM V.
description: GIOVE--William V. A greater passion for life and living no man ever had. A better friend and business associate will be hard to find. Our relationship over 45 years irreplaceable. To Rose, Billy, Jr., DiDi and Lorraine our hearts are with you at this time of sorrow. Allen Schultz and Family

title: Poetry, Concrete and Cosmic, in a World of Losers
description: It's shameful, isn't it, what people will do these days to get their hands on a juicy piece of poetry? Deception, betrayal, kidnapping and assorted acts of violence are enlisted in the pursuit of things poetic in ''The Night Heron,'' the teasing, brooding new play from Jez Butterworth.

title: U.S. Auditing Oversight Board Begins Policing Role by Settling on Procedure
description: After a rocky start, the government's accounting oversight board is getting down to the business of policing the nation's most important accounting firms.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Seeks Dismissal Of Cancer Cases
description: I.B.M. said yesterday that it would ask a California appeals court to dismiss the cases of two former employees who say they contracted cancer at a hard-disk-drive plant. An I.B.M. lawyer, David DiMeglio, said the Court of Appeal for the Sixth Appellate District ''ought to weigh in'' on whether there is enough evidence for cases brought by two former workers, James Moore and Alida Hernandez, for a jury trial. Judge Robert Baines of Superior Court in Santa Clara County yesterday denied I.B.M.'s motion to delay the cases pending the appeal. The workers' cases would be the first of hundreds of similar cases filed in California, New York and Minnesota that accuse I.B.M. of not warning workers that toxic chemicals used at the company's plants could cause cancer. Mr. Moore has non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and Ms. Hernandez has breast cancer. Their lawyer, Richard Alexander, said I.B.M. was trying to stall. ''I.B.M. does not want this case in front of the public because of their outrageous treatment of their workers,'' he said. Judge Baines ruled last week there were ''triable issues'' in the five-year-old case. The trial will begin next Tuesday.

title: U.S. Sees Gas Heating Costs Roughly at Last Year's Levels
description: The natural gas price spikes of last winter will not be repeated in the coming months if temperatures are normal, the Energy Department predicted on Tuesday.

title: Holocaust Fund Official Says Many People May Not Be Paid
description: Five years after a landmark settlement of a Holocaust class-action suit making claims of lost or looted Nazi-era accounts in Swiss banks, a court-appointed official now says many survivors and heirs may never receive compensation.

title: A Sea Scallops Picnic in the Woods
description: NYTHING can be scalloped," Rebecca Charles said, rattling a stack of scallop shells in her hands. "It just has to be in a scallop shell, according to the French."

title: And to Go With That Nifty New Sharpener
description: COOKWARE, like shoes, lends itself to fetishes. There is always a new copper sauteuse, a catchy set of poppy-colored plates, a novel pepper grinder to be had. Knives offer endless possibilities, too. There are shapes for every task and weights for every preference, and there is a wide variety of handles.

title: Sometimes the Best Route To Progress Is a U-Turn
description: It is essential for performing arts institutions to challenge and change themselves regularly to foster artistic growth. But the collapse of the proposed merger between the New York Philharmonic and Carnegie Hall is one instance when a return to the status quo may be the best result for everyone involved.

title: F.B.I. Agents Are Examined For Tactics With Hamas
description: The Justice Department is examining the conduct of F.B.I. agents in Phoenix for possible improprieties related to their use of front companies to gather intelligence on China, the Middle East and the activities of the Palestinian militant group Hamas, an F.B.I. spokesman said Tuesday.

title: Boston vs. Yankees
description: PITCHING

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Charged With Stalking Singer
description: A man was arrested Monday on charges that he stalked the singer-songwriter Sheryl Crow at a concert hall in Midtown, the authorities said. The police said the man, Ambrose Kappos, 37, of Queens, was charged with burglary, stalking, harassment, aggravated harassment and criminal possession of marijuana after he entered the Manhattan Center, at 311 West 34th Street, which houses the Hammerstein Ballroom. ''She was playing at the Hammerstein Ballroom, security recognized the man as being a stalker -- based on past, documented history -- and therefore he was placed under arrest,'' said Sgt. John Grimpel, a police spokesman. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, BERNARD
description: MILLER--Bernard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Bernard Miller, associated with The Times from 1950 until retiring in 1982.

title: INSIDE
description: Marlins Edge Cubs in 11; A Storied Rivalry Is Renewed

title: Russian and 2 Americans Win Nobel Prize
description: A Russian and two Americans, one originally from Russia and one from England, won the Nobel Prize in Physics yesterday for their insights on how electricity can flow through some materials without resistance and some fluids can flow without friction.

title: Sports of The Times; It's Win or Else for the General in a Turtleneck
description: EVEN in the rank-and-file employ of General George Steinbrenner's Yankees, there is apparently an allowance for life's small pleasures. Brian Cashman dared exercise this extraordinary perk Monday night, while critical Yankees-related matters were playing out in Oakland.

title: Israel H. Asper, 71, Creator Of Media Giant in Canada
description: Israel H. Asper, the driving force behind Canada's largest media group and a prominent philanthropist, died on Tuesday in Winnipeg, Manitoba. He was 71.

title: Pope Appears Strong At Pompeii Shrine
description: Pope John Paul II visited a shrine and prayed for world peace here on Tuesday, completing his final bit of scheduled travel for the year with a relatively strong voice that allayed some concerns about his health.

title: Pride in Austria on Schwarzenegger, but Less Joy Elsewhere
description: BERLIN, Oct. 8  The party went all night in Graz, the town in Austria where Arnold Schwarzenegger was born, and a great deal of apple strudel was consumed  it is reportedly Mr. Schwarzenegger's favorite Austrian dish. In the wee hours, when news reached the revelers that Mr. Schwarzenegger would be California's next governor, the mood, as in the rest of Austria, was joyous, amazed, and prideful.

title: Food Takes Center Stage, With Chefs in the Wings
description: JOSEPH LYLE TAYLOR, an actor, was getting tired of Alfred Portale's food. Not that there was anything wrong with it, but as Jeff, a firefighter in ''Omnium Gatherum,'' a polemical dinner-party-as-play, which opened off Broadway last month, he had to eat from the same menu eight times a week.

title: What the Well-Undressed Woman Wears to Concede
description: What to wear, what to wear on election night? ''Stripper shoes'' with five-inch heels, or simple stilettos? A tiny denim miniskirt, or liquid latex?

title: Bryant Out, So Giants Sign Conway
description: The question that went unasked at the Giants' kicker tryout on Tuesday was whether the five players vying to replace the injured Matt Bryant for three to four weeks really wanted to take the risk of playing on special teams for the Giants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINKELSTEIN, ELAINE
description: FINKELSTEIN--Elaine. Beloved wife of Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein. Devoted mother of Dr. Harvey and Miriam Finkelstein, Rabbi Joshua and Elana Gershen Finkelstein and Adina Finkelstein and Marc Legman. Died Monday afternoon, October 6. Sister of Claire Zurbel and sister-inlaw of Ann Samuels. She was the devoted grandmother to Rachel, Adam, Eytan, Sarah, Arik, Eli, Elias, Rebecca and Gabriel. She was also beloved aunt and great-aunt. A proud Jewess and dedicated teacher, she informed her community, her students and she encouraged their parents. An outstanding Rabbi's wife and an exemplary mother, she devoted her life to her family and her profession. She blessed those who knew her and were touched by the beauty of her presence. She will be missed by those to whom she linked her life. Services Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday, October 8, 11:30AM. Shiva at 340 Riverside Drive. Services 7:30 AM and 6 PM.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review on Monday, about ''Dude, Where's My Country?'' by Michael Moore, misstated the year of his antiwar comments at the Academy Awards presentation. It was this year, not last.

title: The message is all in the bag
description: PARIS  Will handbags always be the iconic epicenter of luxury fashion? One thing's for sure, they are now. In the autumn ad campaigns for Europe's top brands, the bag comes first, followed closely by the shoe and  never mind the weather  sunglasses.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Monday, about a contract dispute between Enron and a Nevada utility, Sierra Pacific Resources, referred incorrectly to Sierra's ability to terminate long-term power contracts after Enron filed for bankruptcy protection in December 2001. Sierra did retain that right, but did not exercise it, according to an opinion in the case by Judge Arthur J. Gonzalez of Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York. Once Sierra continued to accept deliveries of power after the bankruptcy filing, the judge ruled, it waived its right to void the contracts.

title: Eleanor Lambert, Empress of Fashion, Dies at 100
description: Eleanor Lambert, whose tireless promotion of American fashion gave the industry an international presence and helped to elevate it from rag trade to respectability, died yesterday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 100.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Portugal: Foreign Minister Quits
description: Foreign Minister Antnio Martins da Cruz, a friend of Prime Minister Jos Manuel Duro Barroso, resigned amid accusations that he used his influence to have his daughter accepted into a medical school although she did not have the required grades. Mr. Martins da Cruz, who denied asking favors for his daughter, said he was stepping down because he could not ''accept more insults and dishonor'' to his family. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: 'Making Sense' Still Making Sense
description: MOST wine books have the shelf life of cheap muscatel. And it's not always the fault of the books. The wine world is changing so rapidly that yesterday's sage advice is irrelevant today. There are exceptions: Hugh Johnson's World Atlas of Wine, now in the hands of Jancis Robinson, has become a true classic. Kevin Zraly's ever youthful ''Windows on the World Complete Wine Course'' is another.

title: Fast Isn't So Marvelous
description: To the Editor:

title: Bids for Nets Due Today
description: Four groups are expected to bid to buy the Nets on Wednesday in the first round of an auction that could result in the team's relocation.

title: Muslims in European Schools
description: The question of whether Muslim women can wear head scarves in European state schools keeps coming back. A French school recently suspended two girls for covering their heads, while Germany ruled in favor of a teacher who insisted on wearing her head scarf in class. Cases like the one in France have been portrayed as a defense of the secular state -- the need to keep overt religious symbols out of state schools. This seems a false pretext. Following the dress or dietary codes of one's faith is an exercise of freedom of conscience so long as the exercise does not amount to proselytizing or otherwise infringing on the freedoms of others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TWEEDY, ANNE E. (NEE BRACKEN)
description: TWEEDY--Anne E. (nee Bracken) of Floral Park on October 6, 2003. Beloved wife of James E. Mother of Edwin (Eileen), James (Janet), Thomas (MaryAnn), Anne Marie Brancella (Thomas), Patrick, Timothy (Colleen). Grandmother of 11. Former member Actors Equity & AFTRA appeared on Stage, Radio and Television, Graduate Dominican Academy 1950. Past President Floral Park Women's Club, LI Federation Women's Club, NYS Women's Club 2nd District Director, NYS 2nd District President. Recipient Spirit of Floral Park Award recognizing her exemplary service to the community. Past President Rosary Altar Society, Catholic Daughters of America, Director Our Lady of Victory Choir. Director Floral Park Town of Hempstead Music Department 25 years. Wrote, directed and produced 40 original senior shows. Reposing Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue, Floral Park Wednesday, Thursday 2-5 & 7-9:30PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Victory 9:30AM Friday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Jets Start to Look at Next Year
description: One of the most dreaded words in sports was finally raised at the Jets' training complex this week: rebuilding.

title: New Products Help PepsiCo To 13% Rise In Earnings
description: PepsiCo said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 13 percent on the strength of new products at its Frito-Lay division and strong sales in its domestic beverage and international businesses.

title: When Israel Acts Against Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; Torre Sees No Problem For Clemens at Fenway
description: Roger Clemens was apparently so dispassionate about whom the Yankees would play in the American League Championship Series that he watched ''Monday Night Football,'' not an epic baseball ending. After disclosing this nugget, Clemens tried to soften his comments by saying that he had bagged baseball only after the Boston Red Sox rumbled ahead of the Oakland Athletics by three runs.

title: House Panel Votes to Impose Sanctions on Syria
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  The House International Relations Committee voted overwhelmingly today to impose economic and diplomatic sanctions on Syria to force it to take tougher steps against anti-Israel militant groups, after the White House, deeply frustrated by its diplomatic contacts with Damascus, dropped its opposition to the bill.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Cars Vandalized On Yom Kippur
description: The tires on dozens of cars in a predominantly Jewish section of Crown Heights were slashed on Monday evening, the holy day of Yom Kippur, the police said yesterday, adding that the incidents might have been hate crimes. The police said about 35 cars were vandalized around Montgomery Street and Kingston Avenue; neighborhood residents said more than 50 cars were involved. ''This happens a lot over here, but not on this scale,'' said Yaakov Sufrin, 37. The police are also investigating another possible bias crime in Brooklyn, where six homes on East 26th Street near Avenue S in Sheepshead Bay were spray-painted with swastikas. That incident, reported about 5 p.m. yesterday. was not believed to be related to the Crown Heights incident, said Detective Carolyn Chew. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: New Leader, New Tumult
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger won an extraordinary victory on Tuesday, riding a wave of voter rebellion. But he will quickly have to show that he has the ability to pull together a fractured state facing many of the same problems that stoked Gov. Gray Davis's immense unpopularity.

title: Are markets for local advertising recovering? Yes, no, maybe: pick an answer, any answer.
description: HOW fast the market for local advertising is recovering -- or even if it is recovering -- has become a subject of intense speculation along Madison Avenue. For those arguing whether or not there is evidence of a comeback, the answer echoes that from the old Certs commercial: Stop, you're both right.

title: A U.S. Gas Tax To Help Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: Haifa Bomb Blurs Family's Fine Line
description: When Mattar Mattar got the call about his brother's restaurant in Israel getting attacked by an Arab suicide bomber on Saturday, his family's extensive network went into overdrive. Brother called brother, and they in turn told sisters and nephews and cousins from here in northwestern New Jersey to Lebanon to Germany and even in Israel.

title: Shaping the Nation, In Corsets or Pantsuits
description: AMERICA'S WOMEN

title: Family Whose Flower Might Be a Venus' Flytrap
description: Claude Chabrol has been dissecting the middle class with his coldblooded deliberation for so long that he could do it in his sleep. With ''The Flower of Evil,'' his newest tale of family and sexual complication bloodied by murder, you may feel as if he's doing it in our sleep.

title: Tales of Decline With Opulence and Humor
description: There's no clear explanation why majestically bemused rock often arrives with goofy animal costumes in tow. It's not just the Flaming Lips, whose touring show features dancers dressed as rabbits. At Irving Plaza on Friday night, Grandaddy, from Modesto, Calif., performed with videos projected behind the band that showed, among other things, a bouncy human-sized bee.

title: Conference Centers on Fate of the Tories Lackluster Leader
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 8  The storm clouds rolling in from the Irish Sea and people along Blackpool's promenade struggling to make headway against lashing gales offer apt symbols for this year's Conservative Party conference.

title: Bank Widens Offer to Repay Fund Holders Amid Inquiry
description: Bank of America took steps yesterday in yet another attempt to put regulators' scrutiny of its mutual fund business behind it.

title: What the Well-Undressed Woman Wears to Her Concession
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7  What to wear, what to wear on election night? "Stripper shoes" with five-inch heels, or simple stilettos? A tiny denim miniskirt, or liquid latex?

title: Making Yanks Laugh? It's a Bit Dodgy, Mate
description: On Monday night Andy Zaltzman, a 29-year-old British comic, took the stage at the Comic Strip comedy club on the Upper East Side and tried to do something that few of his countrymen can do consistently: make Americans laugh.

title: The Life of the Mind, or the Good Life? (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Television Calls Winner as Polls Close
description: The major television networks named Arnold Schwarzenegger the new California governor as soon as the polls closed in California at 8 p.m. Pacific time, their confidence in their data from polls of voters overriding any fears of an erroneous coronation.

title: DUKE ENERGY NAMES SUCCESSOR TO CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The Duke Energy Corporation announced yesterday that it had named a former chief executive of BHP Billiton, Paul M. Anderson, to succeed Richard B. Priory as chairman and chief executive. Mr. Priory, 57, plans to retire early next year and will help Mr. Anderson, 58, during the transition, Cathy Roche, a spokeswoman for Duke, said. Mr. Anderson, who was president of Duke before becoming the chief executive of BHP in 1998, will start his new job on Nov. 1. BHP is one a leading mining company. Duke is based in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Lowell Wins Game in 11th And Negates Sosa Heroics
description: Sammy Sosa was trying to end the murmur of boos that have followed his extended postseason slump. Mike Lowell was just trying to be useful.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Court Lets U.S. Enforce Do-Not-Call Program

title: Carnegie Abandons Merger Discussions With Philharmonic
description: The New York Philharmonic and Carnegie Hall announced yesterday that they had abandoned their plan to merge in 2006, attributing the collapse to irresolvable conflicts over which organization would dominate performance time.

title: Unfinished Business For Yankees And Red Sox
description: The Boston Red Sox are not used to success, so there was not much sleeping on their red-eye flight from California on Monday night. After holding on for a frantic one-run victory to eliminate the Oakland Athletics from the playoffs, the Red Sox joy ride touched down in Newark at 7:01 a.m. yesterday. The players arrived at their Midtown hotel at 8:30 and took buses to Yankee Stadium at 3 p.m., seeming more buoyant than weary.

title: The Life of the Mind, or the Good Life?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An architecture review on Sept. 30 about the new football stadium at Soldier Field in Chicago misspelled the name of the historic Manhattan houses that adjoin the modern Palace Hotel the way the classical shell of the old football stadium meets the modern design of the new one. They are the Villard Houses, not Vuillard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, ELAINE (LIPTON)
description: ADLER--Elaine (Lipton). Of Jenkintown, PA, formerly of New York, died September 29, 2003. Beloved wife of Edward B., mother of Tony and Joe, loving grandmother and sister. Elaine will be remembered as a master potter, for her love of family and an unparalleled approach to life. As she said in her final days, ''I fought a good fight.'' A memorial will be held in New York. Donations can be made in her name to the Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, NYC 10002.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: ORANGE: 3 ACCUSED OF MURDER IN BEATING DEATH Murder charges were filed yesterday against three teenagers accused of beating a delivery man to death. The teenagers, a 16-year-old and a 17-year-old from Orange, and a 15-year-old from Woodbridge, were initially charged with aggravated assault, robbery, weapons offenses, carjacking and conspiracy in connection with the Sept. 27 attack on Nabeel Siddiqui, 24, of Kearny. He was delivering a pizza when he was struck in the head with a baseball bat and left on the ground, the authorities said. He was taken to University Hospital in Newark, where he died Monday, Acting Essex County Prosecutor Paula T. Dow said. The prosecutor's office will seek to have the teenagers tried as adults. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about technical ways to deter unsolicited commercial e-mail, or spam, misstated the name of the organization that sponsored the Anti-Spam Research Group. It is the Internet Research Task Force, not the Internet Emerging Issues Task Force.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CROWN, PAUL
description: CROWN--Paul, Age 75, of Boynton Beach, FL, born and raised in Pittsburgh, PA, formerly of Long Island, NY, died October 6, 2003. Long time business owner in New York City, active member of Community Reform Temple of Westbury, NY and Congregation B'nai Israel in Boca Raton.
