Survivors include his wife of 52 years, Joanne (nee Newman); daughters, Nancy Crown of Boca Raton, Valerie Crown of New City, NY; grandchildren, Rebecca, Adam, David and Elizabeth; three sisters, Jeanette Goldreyer, Annabelle Weissman, and Leatrice Blesser. Funeral services will be 11:00 AM Thursday at Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 7500 N. State Road 7, Coconut Creek, FL (954) 427-6500. Entombment will follow at Eternal Light Memorial Gardens, Boynton, Beach, FL. The family respectfully requests contributions in his memory be made to the Center for Justice at Congregation B'nai Israel, 2200 Yamato Road, Boca Raton 33431. ''He will be missed by those he loved and those who loved him.''

title: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Anti-Aristide Protest
description: Protesters demanding the resignation of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide paralyzed the northern city of Cap Haitien for a second day. Organizers in the city, the country's second largest, staged the protest, which closed schools and businesses, despite fears of clashes with pro-Aristide groups. The protests came as Amnesty International issued a report warning of increased human rights violations in the face of political unrest. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Time and a Half in the Capitol
description: In a rare Republican rebellion against pro-business priorities, the House has rejected a controversial plan to overhaul the rules covering overtime for millions of American workers. The House initially approved the plan last July, but several members of the G.O.P. majority, clearly sensing voters' concern about hard economic times, switched sides last week. That gave the second round to the Democrats, who were warning that many white-collar workers would be stripped of their overtime rights.

title: Justices Consider Dispute On Use of Potomac River
description: The phrase ''Virginia versus Maryland'' may bring to mind a college football game, but at the Supreme Court, at least, it identifies a centuries-old grudge match over rights to the Potomac River, which forms most of the boundary between the two states.

title: Clark Campaign Manager Quits, Signaling Rift
description: Wesley K. Clark's campaign manager resigned on Tuesday, exposing a rift within the retired general's camp just three weeks into his fledgling bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, campaign aides said.

title: Arnold Ain't Al: Networks Name Victor
description: The major television networks named Arnold Schwarzenegger the new California governor as soon as the polls closed in California, their confidence in their data from polls of voters overriding any fears of an erroneous coronation.

title: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Senator's Wife Abducted And Released
description: The wife of Senator Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire, was abducted at knife-point from her house in McLean by robbers who held her for more than an hour, the police and Mr. Gregg's office said. After forcing Mr. Gregg's wife, Kathy, left, to take them to a bank and withdraw money, the men fled by car and left her behind. She was not harmed, the police said. A police spokeswoman said it appeared that the two men had not realized that Mrs. Gregg was the wife of a senator. James Dao (NYT)

title: Mesa Air Pushes Bid for Atlantic Coast
description: The Mesa Air Group said yesterday that it would take an unsolicited $512 million offer for Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings to that company's shareholders unless the board agreed to discuss the proposal.

title: Grass Is Green for Amazon Farmers
description: Jos Mateus has placed his hopes for the future in the sweet-scented grass now reaching shoulder height in the fields he farms not far from where he lives with his family of four sons and over a dozen grandchildren in this poor dusty community on the Amazon delta.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Borland Cuts 125 Jobs
description: The Borland Software Corporation, whose products are used to customize software, cut 125 jobs yesterday and said that third-quarter sales missed the company's expectations. The shares fell as much as 17 percent. Third-quarter revenue totaled $69 million to $71 million, the company, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., said in a statement. Borland had said sales will be unchanged or will fall slightly from $76.3 million in the second quarter, and analysts on average expected $75.3 million, according to Thomson Financial. Profit, excluding some costs, was break-even to 2 cents a share, compared with a forecast of 3 cents to 5 cents. On that basis, the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a 4-cent profit. Borland shares fell as much as $1.62, to $8.07, in extended trading after the report. They had gained 28 cents in regular trading.

title: Report Cites Persistent Bias Among Cabbies In Washington
description: Taxicab drivers in the nation's capital routinely refuse to pick up blacks, and the city has done little to stop the discrimination, according to a study released on Tuesday by a civil rights group.

title: The Sad Before and After Of a Hostage Crisis in Rio
description: ''Bus 174'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films Series. Following are excerpts from A. O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 27; the full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. The film, in Portuguese with English subtitles, opens today at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Telecom Forecast Raised
description: Japan's second-largest telecommunications company, the KDDI Corporation, raised its profit forecast for the year by a third because of better-than-expected demand for its cellphones with high-speed connections. KDDI expects to earn 95 billion yen ($864 million) in the fiscal year ending next March, 34 percent above initial estimates. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: For These, Spend Like A Sailor
description: THAT we don't celebrate the arrival of native bay scallops with the pealing of church bells and the setting off of fireworks -- as the first asparagus is heralded in Germany, or the first cloudberry near the Arctic Circle -- says more about our history than about these scallops.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: LeRoy Neiman Dined Here With Pen and Fork
description: Diners with long memories might have a field day at an exhibition of paintings and drawings that LeRoy Neiman did of restaurants, often while dining in them.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHEVRONTEXACO CORP., San Ramon, Calif., said it had awarded a $250 million contract to a unit of the Halliburton Company, Houston, for maintenance and construction work at its North Sea fields.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Heat Hurt Retailer
description: The British retailer Marks & Spencer Group said yesterday that revenue growth slowed in its second quarter as a heat wave hurt demand for ready-made meals and sweaters. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 0.6 percent in the 11 weeks ended Sept. 27 from the period a year earlier, the chief executive, Roger Holmes, said, slowing from a 3.8 percent first-quarter gain.

title: Dour Postwar Glasgow Breeds a Sexy Antihero
description: ''Young Adam,'' which will be shown tonight and tomorrow at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, takes place on the waterways in and around Glasgow sometime after the Second World War. Fuel rationing is still in effect, and a grim weariness hangs in the air, as palpable as the dust and damp that form the main elements of the atmosphere.

title: In Brand Names, a Bow to Japan
description: THOUGH they are California-grown, the finest short-grain rice varieties sold in the United States originated in Japan and still carry their Japanese names, like Akita Komachi and Koshihikari.

title: American and Briton Win Nobel Prize for Economics
description: An American and a Briton have won this year's Nobel award in economics for developing statistical methods that allow researchers to better understand stock prices, consumer spending and other long-running series of data.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Gemstar To License Technology To Time Warner
description: Gemstar-TV Guide International, publisher of TV Guide magazine, said yesterday that the Time Warner cable unit of AOL Time Warner would use Gemstar's technology and content to create interactive programming guides. The agreement lets Time Warner Cable use Gemstar's interactive programming guide or create a custom guide of its own, the companies said in a statement. Financial terms were not disclosed. It was the first time that Gemstar, based in Pasadena, Calif., has signed an agreement with Time Warner Cable, the nation's No. 2 cable company, said Whit Clay, a Gemstar spokesman. Time Warner can combine Gemstar's service with programming guides from other companies like Microsoft, which in July said Time Warner Cable would try its interactive guide software. Shares of Gemstar rose 49 cents, or 10 percent, to $5.30.

title: Oklahoma Republican Is Retiring From Senate
description: Senator Don Nickles, the Oklahoma Republican and chairman of the Budget Committee, announced on Tuesday that he would retire next year instead of seeking a fifth term. The decision opens opportunities for Democrats to claim his seat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUDKO, SAMUEL
description: RUDKO--Samuel. Of Riverdale, NY. Died October 6th, 2003 in his 94th year. Beloved husband of the late Bess Rudko for 67 years. He leaves his two sons, Robert Rudko and his wife Nancy of MA, and Andrew Rudko and his wife Joyce of NYC. He had four grandchildren, Susan Listman, Rebecca Rudko, Jane Rudko and Michael Rudko. Great-grandfather to Lauren Rudko. He was Works Service Manager at Otis Elevator and was a Director of The Riverdale Senior Services. After retiring, he spent his time giving lectures, travelling and enjoying his family. He will be remembered forever. Funeral will be held, Thursday, October 9th, at 11:30AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave and 76th St. Donations may be made to Riverdale Senior Services, 2600 Netherland Ave, Bronx, NY 10463.

title: To Young, a Russian Enclave Is Too Much the Old Country
description: For New Yorkers, Brighton Beach is a charming curiosity, a little bit of Russia in their own backyard. They go to shop for food, mill among the stout old-timers and hear the exotic language. Even the occasional financial swindle in the news is regarded, at least by those who are not prosecutors, as more cultural quirk than grave crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PARKER, THOMAS R.
description: PARKER--Thomas R., 86 years. Of Armonk, N.Y. Died October 1, 2003 at home. Husband of the late Josephine. Survived by his five children and five grandchildren. Funeral service at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, Armonk, N.Y. on Saturday, October 18 at 1 PM. Interment private.

title: When Israel Acts Against Terror (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Acusphere Raises $52 Million in Offering
description: Acusphere Inc., a pharmaceutical company backed by Thomas Weisel Partners L.L.C., raised $52.5 million yesterday in an initial public stock offering to finance research and development.

title: Just Off the Vine and Snug in Their Pods
description: Speckled cranberry, ivory cannellini and ruddy borlotti beans are usually sold dried, but there's a fleeting autumn season for beans fresh from the field. They are called shell beans because, like fresh peas and fava beans, they have to be shelled from their pods. Fresh beans require no more than a 20-minute simmer in water to become tender. Once cooked, they can be seasoned and glossed with butter or oil or added to soups and salads.

title: JETBLUE AIRWAYS ANNOUNCES 3-FOR-2 STOCK SPLIT
description: JetBlue Airways said yesterday that it would issue a 3-for-2 split of its common stock. The split will be given out on Nov. 20 to people and institutions holding shares at the end of business on Nov. 10. After the split, the company, based in Queens, will have about 101 million outstanding shares of common stock, an increase of 50 percent. The company has remained profitable since its start, even as larger, more traditional airlines have suffered huge losses during the economic downswing and in the aftermath of the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. JetBlue closed at $67.70 a share yesterday, up from $27 when the stock was first offered to the public, a year-and-a-half ago. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: North Korea Wants Japan Out of Future Talks
description: North Korea said Tuesday that it would not ''tolerate'' Japanese participation in future talks about its nuclear weapons ambitions.

title: Chefs Have Rights, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Schwarzenegger Starts Preparing for His New Role
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8  Arnold Schwarzenegger moved quickly today to prepare to take over as California's governor, naming a prominent Republican congressman as his transition chief and reaching out to the state's most influential Democrat, Senator Dianne Feinstein, who was among Gov. Gray Davis's staunchest supporters.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 29 about renewed criticism of the Bush administration for its handling of intelligence before the Iraq war misstated the circumstances under which international weapons inspectors left Iraq in 1998. They were withdrawn by the United Nations, not expelled by Saddam Hussein.

title: Leaker May Remain Elusive, Bush Suggests
description: President Bush said on Tuesday that he was not sure whether the Justice Department would determine who had disclosed the identity of an undercover C.I.A. officer to journalists, but he promised to provide investigators with ''everything we know.''

title: Banana Republic Seeks New Agency
description: Banana Republic, the retail chain owned by Gap Inc., said yesterday that it was seeking an agency to help handle the creative duties on its account, which had been handled internally since 1997. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: When Israel Acts Against Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Facing Opposition, Hong Kong Delays Harbor Dumping Plan
description: Retreating in the face of public opposition for the third time in less than five weeks, the government here said on Tuesday that it would dredge part of the harbor in front of the downtown business district but would postpone plans to fill in a large expanse of water to build a highway.

title: From Elf Queen To Journalist
description: When Cate Blanchett talks, it's a bit surprising to hear the broad vowels of her native Australia creep back into her speech. Lately filmgoers have seen her as an Italian (''Heaven''), a Scot (''Charlotte Gray''), a Southerner (''The Gift'') and a resident of Middle Earth (''Lord of the Rings'' trilogy). In her new film, ''Veronica Guerin,'' Ms. Blanchett is Irish -- a crusading journalist for a Dublin newspaper who takes on the local drug trade and pays the ultimate price. (The film, directed by Joel Schumacher, opens nationally on Oct. 17).

title: Leetch Skates on Sore Ankle
description: Rangers defenseman Brian Leetch skated the last two days on his bruised left ankle. ''It's still sore, but it's better than a week ago,'' Leetch said. ''The reality is, if I'm playing in October, that would be great.'' The Rangers open the season Friday night at Minnesota and play Saturday night at Columbus. Leetch's ankle was reinjured on Sept. 5 in an impromptu workout. Jason Diamos

title: Chicago's Hockey Appeal Is Rejected
description: The Supreme Court decided Monday not to hear a case involving a Chicago hockey fan's right to sell his muckraking book on the Chicago Blackhawks' owner, William Wirtz, outside the team's home arena, the United Center.

title: How to Be the McCain of '04, by John McCain
description: Some days, it seems as if every Democrat running for president is vying to be the next John McCain.

title: China Promises More Investment in Southeast Asia
description: The prime minister of China, Wen Jiabao, making his first appearance before Southeast Asian leaders Tuesday, announced that his government would encourage greater investment in the region by Chinese companies.

title: Star Witness Is Questioned In Bank Case
description: The legal case of Frank P. Quattrone crystallized yesterday when his lawyer attempted to get the government's star witness to say that Mr. Quattrone, the former Credit Suisse banker, was not fully aware of the scope of federal investigations of the bank when he asked that his bankers clean out their files.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Woman Dies In House Fire
description: A 64-year-old woman was killed in a fire at her apartment yesterday in Edenwald, the authorities said. The woman, Francise Davis, of 1165 East 226th Drive, was pronounced dead at her home and another person was treated for smoke inhalation, the police said. The cause of the fire is under investigation, a Fire Department spokesman said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: What the Leak Reveals
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions as N.H.L. Season Begins
description: When he left the Anaheim Mighty Ducks for the Colorado Avalanche as a free agent last summer, Paul Kariya took a pay cut that reduced his salary to $1.2 million from $10 million. Because he wanted to play with a friend, Teemu Selanne, on a strong team, he did not try to maximize his value on the market.

title: When Prudery Kills
description: Here on the ground where President Bush's big anti-AIDS program is supposed to unfold, it looks as if the program was drafted more to win American votes than to save African lives.

title: Net Income Up at Apollo
description: The Apollo Group, which runs the largest private university in the nation, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose 43 percent as student enrollment increased.

title: And the Winner Is . . . (See the Movie)
description: It was the perfect backdrop for the California story of the century, and Tuesday night the MSNBC news program ''Hardball With Chris Matthews'' came to viewers live from the beaches of Santa Monica. Giant klieg lights shined on palm trees, blinding a few in-line skaters, dog walkers and one cat walker and drawing people out of their oceanfront apartments onto the sand to see what was going on.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Turkish government plan to send peacekeeping troops to Iraq misstated an American request for help that was defeated by the Turkish parliament in March. The United States had asked to base American troops in Turkey in preparation for an attack on Iraq to oust Saddam Hussein, not for Turkish troops to take part.

title: After Record Rally, Dungy Has the Colts Believing Again
description: Now Tony Dungy knows what Serena and Venus Williams go through when they must compete against each other. On Monday night, Dungy, the coach of the Indianapolis Colts, got a taste of competing against his former team, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, and even a dramatic victory left him feeling drained.

title: As It Tries To Cut Costs, Wall Street Looks to India
description: Global companies have long taken advantage of India's large college-educated, low-cost work force. Now Wall Street firms, including J.P. Morgan, Lehman Brothers and Morgan Stanley, are joining the chase for more highly skilled Indian labor.

title: Lady Donaldson, 82, Lord Mayor (Not Lady, Please!) of London
description: Lady Donaldson, the first woman to be lord mayor of London in the 800-year history of the office, died on Saturday at a hospice near her family home in Lymington, England. She was 82.

title: OWNER OF U-HAUL FILES PLAN TO EMERGE FROM BANKRUPTCY
description: Amerco, the owner of the U-Haul truck-rental business, said yesterday that it had filed a bankruptcy recovery plan that would fully pay its creditors the $1.38 billion it owes them, and would not cut the value of the company's shares by using stock to pay debts. Amerco, which also owns Amerco Real Estate and two insurance units, sought bankruptcy protection in June after failing to obtain refinancing for $866 million of debt. U-Haul was not included in the filing. Court approval of the plan would permit Amerco to emerge from bankruptcy in less than seven months. Amerco, which listed $1.04 billion in assets and $884 million in debts in its bankruptcy filing, said in the recovery plan that it owed secured creditors $227 million and unsecured creditors more than $798.1 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAZICK, DAVID
description: KAZICK--David. Survived by his wife, Evelyn, daughter, Soozin Kazick and granddaughter, Ashley Rosen.

title: 5 of 10 Top Women Plan to Run in New York
description: Five of the top 10 ranked American women in marathons will compete in the New York City Marathon on Nov. 2, the New York Road Runners, sponsors of the race, announced yesterday.

title: Ex-Energy Executive Settles Futures Case
description: A former vice president of Avista Energy, William H. Taylor, has agreed to pay a $155,000 fine to settle claims that he manipulated the electricity futures market, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SULTAN, MAX
description: SULTAN--Max. Age 96, died at his home in Brooklyn, on October 3th, 2003. Private services and burial were held October 5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLONIM, MICHAEL L.
description: SLONIM--Michael L. Zeichner Ellman and Krause LLP mourns the loss, much too early in life, of its longtime counsel and friend, Michael Slonim. Michael, an intellectual lawyer's lawyer, served as a pillar of the firm. He was always a resource for difficult cases and at the same time, a mentor to many junior attorneys. His wit, humor and knowledge of music will be missed by all. We extend our deepest condolences to his dear wife, Diane, and to his beloved children Max and Alex. May his family at home draw strength from knowing that his family at work loved and appreciated him and will always continue to do so.

title: Recipe: Scalloped Scallops
description: Adapted from Rebecca Charles

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POSTMAN, NEIL M.
description: POSTMAN--Neil M., 72, on October 5, 2003. University Professor at New York University, pioneer in the field of media ecology. Former Chair of the department of Culture and Communication, author of more than 20 books including ''Amusing ourselves to Death,'' ''The Disappearance of Childhood,'' and ''Teaching as a Subversive Activity.'' Cherished teacher, renowned lecturer, and incisive observer of culture and technology. Born March 8, 1931, raised in Brooklyn, earned his BA at SUNY Fredonia, his junior year he was one of the nation's top scorers in college basketball. He received his doctorate from Teachers College Columbia University. Loving and devoted husband of Shelley, father of Marc, Andrew and Madeline, grandfather of Alyssa, Claire, Sam and Charlie. Brother of Saul, Jack and Ruth. Son of Bea and Murray. A man of generosity, humor and intellect, he will be profoundly missed by his students, colleagues, friends and family. Contributions may be made to the Neil Postman Fellowship Fund, Dean's Office, School of Education, NYU, 82 Washington Square East, New York, New York 10003.

title: How a Good School Can Fail on Paper
description: KIM WELLONS, principal of Micro-Pine Level Elementary School, knows it takes special patience to teach special education children. Before Ms. Wellons became the principal in this farm community, she was a special education teacher for 15 years. And she was inspired to do this work because two of her cousins, now middle-aged and both borderline retarded, never learned the skills in school they needed to live independently.

title: Syrian Leader Says Israel Aims to Stir Region
description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, speaking for the first time about an Israeli air raid near Damascus over the weekend, blamed Israel for trying to provoke Syria and the region at large in a wider conflict.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Priest Who Married Men Is Defrocked
description: A Russian Orthodox priest who broke church law by performing a wedding for two men last month in the city of Nizhny Novgorod has been defrocked, and another priest who was involved was barred from holding church services, an official church news agency reported. A church investigation gave this account: On Sept. 1, one priest, Mikhail Kabanov, gave the keys to his church to a man and woman who said another priest was going to marry them secretly against the wishes of their parents. They then brought the second priest, Vladimir Enert, to the church, where by prior agreement he performed the ceremony for two men. The woman turned out to be a reporter for the daily Komsomolskaya Pravda, which published her report and photographs of the wedding. Father Enert, who had earlier said he was tricked, has dropped out of sight. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: The Alchemist at Work
description: Dror Benshetrit's studio in the meatpacking district celebrates objects at rest and in motion.

title: A Tour of Satchmo's Castle
description: Opening for the first time, Louis Armstrong's home is a shrine to Satchmo and a glimpse of midcentury life.

title: Rugs for Kids
description: Children's rugs are not just about keeping the quiet. They are also essential to comfort and dcor.

title: Gadgets Go Beyond a Man's World
description: Aiming beyond a man's world, gadget makers seek an allure for both sexes.

title: Conquering History
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: LIMIT SEEN ON USE OF IRAQ AID FUNDS
description: A team of World Bank economists has concluded that, as a practical matter, Iraq can absorb only about $6 billion in aid next year for its infrastructure needs. That conclusion sets a target that Bush administration officials said Wednesday could be met from American and international assistance.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 25 about the arrival of Mongolian peacekeeping troops on American transports to serve in Iraq misstated the number of people killed by the armies of the general Hulegu in a past Mongol operation -- the sacking of Baghdad in 1258. Historians generally agree that it was 80,000, not 800,000.

title: More Likely to Cheat
description: To the Editor:

title: VERIZON WORKERS APPROVE FIVE-YEAR CONTRACT
description: The five-year labor contract for 60,000 workers at Verizon Communications has been ratified by members of the Communications Workers of America. The agreement received 89 percent support, the union said yesterday. Verizon, the nation's biggest local-telephone company, reached a contract with union leaders on Sept. 4 after three months of talks. Verizon agreed to a 3 percent bonus for union workers this year and an 8 percent wage increase over four years. The company, based in New York, also agreed to limits on relocating or laying off existing employees. In return, Verizon got limits on health care cost increases and won powers to lay off new workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARROW, JENETTE A.
description: BARROW--Jenette A. We share the sorrow of our partner, Jenette A. Barrow-Bosshart, on the passing of her mother, Jenette A. Barrow, who fought her illness with dignity, and with the support of her family. We extend our deepest condolences to Jenette, her husband, William, and the entire family. Otterbourg, Steindler, Houston and Rosen, P.C.

title: People
description: * Gary Topolewski, chief creative officer at Chemistri, Troy, Mich., part of the Publicis Groupe, will also serve as chairman. He succeeds Roger Haupt, who continues as president and chief operating officer at Publicis. Chemistri handles all General Motors accounts for Publicis.

title: Snarls of Traffic and Politics Amid Freestyle Design
description: ''No Handguns Allowed in Meeting'' cautions a sign outside the City Council's Art Deco chamber here. Maybe it is just as well, with Houstonians on edge from monster traffic jams, budget woes, bitterly partisan politics, police scandals and the sting of being called too ugly for company.

title: Decoding the Subtle Dance of Ordinary Movements
description: COMPUTERS are becoming sophisticated enough to identify people by the patterns of their voices, fingerprints and irises, but they cannot yet distinguish individuals by the subtle quirks in the way they move.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KING, WOOD, DAVID
description: KING-WOOD--David. A memorial program will be held for David King-Wood at St. Bernard's School, 4 East 98 Street, NYC at 5:30 PM on Thursday, October 9, 2003

title: City Comptroller Raises Questions on Deal to Put Snapple Products in Schools
description: The New York City comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., is questioning the deal that gave Snapple the exclusive rights to sell beverages in city schools and other municipal properties, citing concerns about a possible conflict of interest on the part of a marketing firm that helped broker the deal for the city.

title: SOCCER: Soccer Analysis; Disparities in Women's Game
description: Despite creeping parity and the absence of the United States from the final of the Women's World Cup, power in women's soccer remains concentrated in North America and in northern Europe.

title: Rugs Invite a Hop and a Skip
description: NOISE control is a must for neighborly relations in the city, especially when children are involved. In that vein, most landlords and co-op boards require that 75 to 80 percent of floors be covered by rugs.

title: Even the Best Ideas Don't Sell Themselves
description: So what if she had limited business experience, a shoestring budget and a low-technology product? In 2000, Carol Skonberg thought she had struck entrepreneurial gold with her wineglass jewelry. In her first year, she signed up 90 stores in Texas to carry the product and racked up $35,000 in sales, all on an initial investment of $4,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FIELDING, BENJAMIN
description: FIELDING -- Benjamin. Be loved husband of Anne. Devoted father of Seth and Eliot. Adored grandfather of Jenny and Stephanie. Dear brother of Harry, Harriet and Anita. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' 1895 Flatbush Ave (at Ave L), Brooklyn, today at 1:15 PM.

title: Luck Smiles as the Devils Hold On for a Tie in Boston
description: The Devils began the defense of their Stanley Cup championship Wednesday night, skating to a 3-3 tie against the Boston Bruins at the Fleet Center in a game that had two distinctly different halves to it.

title: Bush, Campaigning in N.H., Defends Record on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  Visiting the only Northeastern state he carried in 2000, President Bush campaigned today in New Hampshire, calling for lower federal taxes and continued vigilance against terrorism.

title: SCHWARZENEGGER LAYS FOUNDATION FOR A TRANSITION
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger moved quickly Wednesday to prepare for governing, naming a prominent Republican congressman to run his transition and strongly suggesting that he would call on President Bush to provide federal aid to California, now in Republican hands.

title: Shock Waves From a Political Earthquake
description: To the Editor:

title: Mortgage Index Rises
description: An index measuring the number of applications for mortgages rose for a second week as a decline in interest rates since an August high sparked more home purchases and refinancing, an industry report showed.

title: Abraham Likely to Sit Out Despite Offering Apology
description: Jets defensive end John Abraham apologized to his teammates Wednesday for being arrested for driving after drinking last week. But his contrition may not be enough.

title: Illinois Narrows Tourism Review to 6
description: The Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity in Chicago has narrowed a review for its tourism advertising account to six semifinalists.

title: LORAL REJECTS ECHOSTAR TAKEOVER BID AS INADEQUATE
description: Loral Space and Communications, a satellite maker that filed for bankruptcy protection in July, said last night that it had rejected a $1.85 billion takeover offer from EchoStar Communications. The offer by EchoStar, the satellite television company, undervalues Loral's assets, Loral said in a statement. Loral wants to keep its satellite services and manufacturing businesses and only sell its North American satellites as part of its bankruptcy organization. The company has an agreement with Intelsat to sell six satellites for about $1.1 billion. Earlier this month, Loral won a $220 million order to build satellites for DirecTV, EchoStar's larger rival.

title: A Boy From Graz
description: While Californians were voting on Tuesday, Finance Minister Karl-Heinz Grasser of Austria ended a television interview here about budget deficits and European Union economics with an emphatic ''Good luck to Arnold Schwarzenegger.''

title: For a King of Jazz, a Castle in Queens
description: TWENTY THOUSAND visitors would probably not travel every year to Corona, Queens, to see the Lucille Armstrong House.

title: TIAA-CREF Cuts Review to 3 Finalists
description: TIAA-CREF, the financial services company, said yesterday that it had narrowed a review for its account to three finalists. The account, with billings estimated at more than $20 million, has been handled for more than 15 years by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAMBERT, ELEANOR
description: LAMBERT--Eleanor. The International Immigrant Foundation, officers and Board of Directors, express our deepest condolences to the family of Eleanor Lambert on her passing. We will always remember her inspiring leadership to our mission of helping immigrants. Edward Juarez, President

title: Signaling Voter Unrest, Schwarzenegger Cut Deep Into the Democrats' Base
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger pulled together a vast coalition of dissatisfied voters from across all demographic groups in California's recall election on Tuesday, winning among all age groups and, perhaps most ominously for Democrats, appearing to make inroads into their traditional base, surveys show.

title: Minor Accident Leads to Charge For Torricelli
description: Robert G. Torricelli, the former New Jersey senator, has been charged with leaving the scene of a minor auto accident, police officials in Lambertville, N.J., said on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POSTMAN, NEIL
description: POSTMAN--Neil. The Faculty of the Steinhardt School of Education at New York University deeply mourn the loss of Neil Postman, our beloved colleague and founder of our program in Media Ecology, longtime Chair of the Department of Culture and Communication. Neil was an education reformer, humanist, social visionary, media critic who developed a wide audience for his writing and speaking. Our professor for nearly 40 years, a mentor to hundreds of students and dozens of faculty, a story teller and man of wisdom, and a dear friend to many. He wrote more than 20 books, among them Teaching as a Subversive Activity, Amusing Ourselves to Death, The Disappearance of Childhood, and Technopoly. He was named University Professor in 1993 and the Paulette Goddard Professor of Media Ecology in 1998; he received the University's Distinguished Teaching Medal in 1988. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Shelley, and his three children, Mark, Andrew, and Madeline.

title: S.&P. to Test Amex Prices In Calculating Its Indexes
description: In a rebuke to the Nasdaq stock market, Standard & Poor's announced yesterday that it would begin calculating its indexes by using the American Stock Exchange prices for some Nasdaq stocks.

title: Rivera Is the Yankees Ace in the Hole
description: Closer Mariano Rivera is looming over the American League Championship Series as the pitcher who gives the Yankees the most prominent edge over the Boston Red Sox at any position. Hovering in the bullpen, waiting for the Yankees to grab a lead by the eighth inning, and anticipating, always anticipating, that he will be the final man standing after securing those final, difficult outs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAMIR, NIRA
description: SHAMIR--Nira. SAR Academy mourns the loss of a talented artist and art teacher whose beautiful works adorn our building. Beloved wife of Ami and adoring mother of our alumnae Adi, Pami and Ruby. May the family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President

title: Still a Bit Fragile and Foggy, Damon Rejoins the Red Sox
description: Johnny Damon, still banged up and woozy after colliding with second baseman Damian Jackson in Game 5 of the American League division series on Monday in Oakland, rejoined his Red Sox teammates last night, but he will miss at least the first two games of the American League Championship Series against the Yankees.

title: This Year the Cubs Don't Stink, but Something Sure Does, and Chicago's Mayor Wants It Gone
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley's vision of his city, fussily and stubbornly enforced, is many things: rooftop gardens, wrought-iron fences, waterfront parks, bicycle trails, beds of blooms beside every road.

title: Pettitte Eager to Start Game 2
description: Andy Pettitte, who is scheduled to be the Yankees' starting pitcher today in Game 2 of the American League Championship Series, has lost only one game in his last 10 starts. That was to Boston on Sept. 5, and the Red Sox battered him.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Drug Figure Sentenced
description: A man who is a member of what prosecutors described as a violent family of drug dealers, which included his 78-year-old uncle, has been sentenced in federal court to 17 1/2 years in prison. The man, David Burden, was convicted in February on racketeering and narcotics conspiracy charges. Kevin J. O'Connor, United States attorney, said David Burden was also found guilty of conspiring and attempting to murder members of the Hill Crew, a rival drug gang. Prosecutors say Mr. Burden, who was sentenced on Monday, is part of the Burden Family, run by Kelvin Burden. Kelvin's father, Barney Burden, 78, stored drug revenues for his son. In July, Barney Burden was sentenced to 46 months in prison. Kelvin Burden and other Burden relatives await sentencing for murder. David Burden is a cousin of Kelvin. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the arrest of a man who tried to board a plane in Newark with a dagger in his sneaker misstated the location in some copies for his hometown, Murietta, Calif. It is 81 miles south of Los Angeles, not in the San Joaquin Valley.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Murdoch Seeks TV Job
description: James Murdoch, the 30-year-old son of Rupert Murdoch, chairman of the News Corporation, has applied for the top job at British Sky Broadcasting Group, someone close to BSkyB said. BSkyB, which is 35 percent owned by News Corporation, has been searching for a chief executive since Tony Ball said on Sept. 23 that he would step down. James Murdoch currently runs the Star Group, the News corporation's wholly owned Asian satellite business. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Face-Lift and Body Work
description: This month Cultureshock Media, an English publisher, will send out a revamped V&A Magazine to members of the once-fusty Victoria and Albert Museum. ''It will be a big surprise,'' said the graphic designer Bruce Mau, right, who worked with Rem Koolhaas on the book ''S,M,L,XL.'' For a sense of immediacy, Mr. Mau used digital video stills to illustrate a story about London. Because of the museum's English Gothic exhibition, Mr. Mau put a 14th-century gilt effigy on the cover and used blood-red calligraphy on an inside page, both above. Another story describes Goth lifestyle today. ''To show the relevance of something that happened hundreds of years ago,'' Mr. Mau said, ''you have to build a bridge.'' Museum membership is $76; www.vam.ac.uk. CRAIG KELLOGG

title: The 50's Sinatra, Spliced With Digital Razzmatazz
description: AS enviable as Frank Sinatra's life might have seemed, he never achieved his youthful ambition: to attend Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J. The lack was noted by the college in 1985 when it awarded the singer an honorary doctorate in engineering.

title: Selective Intelligence On Road to Baghdad
description: There is no critique more stinging than one wrapped in sympathy. Tonight, PBS's ''Frontline'' examines the Bush administration's rationale for the Iraq war in a tone of puzzled sorrow that somehow enhances, rather than mutes, the righteous indignation of the reporting.

title: With Palms, Fewer Is More
description: DEARLY beloved, we are gathered here to mourn the passing of a whole big bunch of palmtops.

title: U.S. Bug in Mayor's Office Roils Philadelphia Race
description: Philadelphia and federal officials said on Wednesday that a listening device found in Mayor John F. Street's office in City Hall had been planted by F.B.I. agents in an investigation.

title: Dominicans Gaining on Puerto Ricans in City
description: If present population trends continue, Dominicans will surpass Puerto Ricans as the city's largest Hispanic group before the end of the decade, a study has found.

title: Shock Waves From a Political Earthquake
description: To the Editor:

title: G.E. Finishes Vivendi Deal, Expanding Its Media Assets
description: General Electric, owner of television's most profitable network, NBC, completed its agreement yesterday to acquire the entertainment assets of Vivendi Universal in a deal that executives said would create a new entertainment conglomerate better able to compete with media giants like Viacom, Time Warner, the Walt Disney Company and the News Corporation.

title: Yankees Take Game 2
description: Here it was, the matchup the Boston Red Sox might have anticipated last December at Hotel Campo Real in Managua, Nicaragua. It was their marquee player against the Yankees' money pitcher, with everything on the line.

title: Charges Believed Imminent Against Brooklyn Leader
description: The lawyers for the Brooklyn Democratic leader, Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., and for one of his top aides have been told that their clients should be ready to surrender to the authorities in Brooklyn as early as tonight to face possible criminal charges, according to people involved in the case.

title: In a Nod to Lush Film Scores, Game Music Gains Texture
description: CHANCE THOMAS, a composer, traveled to Salt Lake City last spring to conduct his version of the Ring, that epic tale of a powerful ring, clashing warriors and curious creatures.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 321 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Shock Waves From a Political Earthquake
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Pivotal To Sell Business To Oak Investments
description: The Pivotal Corporation, an unprofitable Canadian software maker, agreed to combine its business with Talisma, a Web services provider, and sell all its shares to Oak Investments Partners for $45 million. Oak Investments, a closely held investor in new businesses, will pay $1.78 for each of Pivotal's 25.5 million outstanding shares, 2.2 percent less than Pivotal's closing price on Tuesday. Oak Investments, based in Palo Alto, Calif., may pay as much as 3 cents a share more, depending on the company's financial performance to Oct. 16, Pivotal said. Oak Investments' participation will strengthen Pivotal's financial stability, Bo Manning, the chief executive, said in a statement. Pivotal, which is based in Vancouver, has had a loss for the last nine quarters and sales slumped 25 percent in the second quarter to $14.5 million, from $19.4 million a year earlier. The sale awaits approval by shareholders and the Supreme Court of British Columbia.

title: War on Carbs
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including testimonials from converts to the South Beach diet.

title: Three Groups Submit Initial Bids to Buy Nets
description: The tug of war over the Nets was in full swing yesterday as three groups each submitted an initial bid of about $250 million to buy the team, two with an eye toward moving it to New York, people involved in the sale said.

title: Tyco Workers Are Witnesses In Fraud Trial
description: Three Tyco International employees were the first witnesses yesterday in the trial of the former executives L. Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H. Swartz, who are accused of looting the company of $600 million through theft and stock fraud.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a television review of the ABC comedy ''It's All Relative'' on Oct. 1 misstated the name of the pub owned by two characters. It is O'Neil's, not the Hub.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: National Briefing | Washington: 2 Cities Ask For Convention Security Aid
description: The federal government has been asked for $20 million to $30 million, as estimated by a Congressional aide, to help pay for security at the Democratic and Republican conventions next year in New York City and Boston, members of Congress and officials of the host cities said. Washington has never paid any convention costs. But since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, it has paid for some security costs at events like the Super Bowl and the Olympic Games in Salt Lake City. The Democratic convention will be in July in Boston. The Republicans are to meet in August in New York. John Files (NYT)

title: Modern Twists on a Japanese Classic
description: Three filigree teahouses of bamboo and spruce, far left, by the Japanese designer Shigeru Uchida, have landed in Manhattan. Two will be tucked into the lobby of the Japan Society (www.japansociety.org), on Oct. 22 and 23, for a tea demonstration and will be open to visitors. The interior of one, Room of Observation, is at left. The third will be installed in the Japanese art galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (www.metmuseum.org), for a show focused on 16th-century Oribe ceramics, opening Oct. 21. The teahouses will be scantily furnished, in keeping with Japanese tradition, but are modern and structurally sophisticated. ''They dismantle to be stored away,'' Mr. Uchida said. EVE M. KAHN

title: Market Place; A modest proposal by the S.E.C. might increase the influence of activist institutional investors.
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commission made a modest proposal yesterday that is unlikely to lead to many, if any, insurgent directors being elected at large American companies.

title: Judge Says Minnesota Cannot Regulate Internet Calls
description: A federal judge in Minnesota has ruled that the state's Public Utilities Commission cannot apply its telecommunications regulations to the Vonage Holdings Corporation, a start-up company that allows consumers to place phone calls over the Internet.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Eyes, and Noses, On the Prize
description: Sometimes those sports bets that politicians make with one another actually get paid. And the payoff can smell. Just ask Robert De Niro, who stopped by City Hall yesterday just as Council Speaker Gifford Miller collected on a bet with Mr. Miller's Minneapolis counterpart. The Yankees beat the Minnesota Twins in the playoffs. The prize? Lutefisk, a form of codfish prepared with lye with a taste that is typically described as acquired. Mr. De Niro, at City Hall for a celebration of Italian heritage, joined Mr. Miller over a tray of the Scandinavian delicacy. Each braved a forkful. ''Light,'' Mr. De Niro said. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; In the Playoffs, the Thrills Just Keep On Coming
description: SO Lynn Dickson was home in Wonder Lake, Ill., some 80 miles north of Chicago, when she began screaming and hollering.

title: Neil Postman, 72, Mass Media Critic, Dies
description: Neil Postman, a prolific and influential social critic and educator best known for his warning that an era of mass communications is stunting the minds of children -- as well as adults -- died on Sunday at a hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 72 and lived in Flushing.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Terrorism Interrogation
description: The authorities are questioning a suspected smuggler of immigrants for possible connections with Al Qaeda. Officials refused to release any details but said American and British intelligence had been called into the investigation. The state-run NET television identified the suspect as a Pakistani and one of three smugglers arrested last month by the Greek Coast Guard. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Rumsfeld Quick to Dismiss Talk Of Reduced Role in Iraq Policy
description: The White House and Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld moved quickly on Wednesday to contain an unusual public breach over Iraq policy, a day after he testily told European reporters that he was not consulted before a reorganization intended to give the White House more control over the occupation of Iraq.

title: Company Sues Investor Over Settlement
description: M&F Worldwide , a company controlled by the billionaire Ronald O. Perelman, has filed a lawsuit claiming an investor violated a $10 million settlement involving Mr. Perelman's failed bid to sell his stake in Panavision, which makes movie cameras.

title: The Free-Range Mouse Points the Way
description: People making multimedia presentations can roam free with Iogear's new Phaser, a wireless, trigger-action mouse with a laser pointer. The mouse can be used in midair to control a computer from distances of as much as 50 feet.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain/France: Roundup Of Basques
description: The police in Spain and France have arrested 34 suspected members of the violent separatist group ETA in a sweep ordered by Judge Baltasar Garzn of Spain and Judge Laurence Le Vert of France. The 29 people arrested in Spain are accused of recruiting new ETA members and passing information to France on targets for assassination. The five arrested in France are thought to belong to a banned Basque youth group that provided logistic support to ETA, which has killed more than 800 people since 1968 in its quest for a Basque state. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Cosmic Soccer Ball? Theory Already Takes Sharp Kicks
description: In an unusual logjam of contradictory claims, a revolutionary new model of the universe, as a soccer ball, arrives on astronomers' desks this morning at least slightly deflated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, SOLOMON
description: SILVER--Solomon. On October 5, 2003 at age 90. Dental practice in Bronx and clinical instructor at Lebanon Hospital. Loving husband of Florette, father of Janet and Kenneth. Beloved Poppy of Mariel and William. Devoted uncle, caring friend. Funeral Thursday, October 9, 1:15 PM at Beth Israel Cemetery Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Official Says Airport Trainees Knew Questions Before Tests
description: Most of the questions on an examination to become an airport screener were rehearsed with the trainees before the test, according to the inspector general of the Transportation Security Administration, who called the practice ''extremely disturbing.''

title: A Male Lesbian Whose Appeal Is Mainly Cerebral
description: Eddie Izzard, the exhaustingly funny stand-up comic, certainly looks more at home than most men would in fishnet stockings, stiletto-heeled boots and a thigh-flashing skirt. But even given his ease with femme fatale accouterments, is ''Sexie'' really an appropriate title for his new touring show, which runs at City Center through Saturday?

title: Complaints of Abuse by the Police Have Increased 25 Percent
description: The number of civilian complaints of police abuse has climbed nearly 25 percent in the first nine months of this year, compared with the same period last year, according to the independent city agency that investigates the complaints.

title: Summoning The Ocean, In Sounds Old and New
description: The U Theater of Taiwan was a hybrid from the start. Liu Ching-Ming, the Taipei-based actress who founded it in 1988, trained in part in New York University's Performance Studies program and with Jerzy Grotowski. But she sought a deeper relevance for her art, according to program notes, in indigenous Taiwanese and Chinese cultural traditions and in nature. ''The Sound of Ocean,'' performed by the group on Tuesday night at the Harvey Theater in the Next Wave Festival and repeated tonight through Saturday, uncomfortably straddles the new and the old.

title: The Charm From Beijing
description: In his first major outing with his Asian colleagues, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China this week unfurled what has clearly become a basic tenet of Beijing's foreign policy: friendly, even superfriendly, relations with the neighbors.

title: Prison Term For Guardian Who Stole From Clients
description: A Queens lawyer who bought a bungalow in Hawaii and a world-class wine collection while stealing from the accounts of disabled and mentally ill people he had been appointed to represent was sentenced yesterday to three to nine years in prison.

title: Bomb in Colombian Capital Kills 6, Wounds 19
description: A car bomb exploded in a crowded commercial district here in the country's capital on Wednesday morning, killing 6 people and injuring 19, the Metropolitan Police said. The explosion, the most deadly in Bogot since 36 people died in February in a bombing at an elite social club, raised new fears of an urban bombing campaign in Colombia's simmering civil conflict.

title: Long Spoon Diplomacy
description: There is an old proverb that says, ''If you're going to sup with the devil, use a long spoon.'' Does the White House pantry have any long spoons? I ask because if President Bush really wants to achieve his objectives in Iraq, he may have to sup a little with Yasir Arafat, the Iranian leader Ali Khamenei and Syria's president, Bashar al-Assad.

title: In Austria, Pride; Elsewhere, Reserve
description: There seemed little doubt, as Le Monde, the French daily, put it some days ago, that Mozart is no longer the most famous Austrian.

title: Root, Root, Root for the Home Team!
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: GUILTY PLEA IN BRIBERY CASE A former construction official for the Port Authority pleaded guilty yesterday in federal court to taking bribes in return for arranging faster payments from the authority to an environmental-testing contractor. The ex-official, Mark A. Jakubek, worked for a division of the authority that oversees construction and renovation projects and is the former manager of environmental field operations. He faces up to 10 years in prison and a fine of $250,000. Prosecutors said Mr. Jakubek, 44, of Monroe, N.Y., took bribes of nearly $20,000. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Harnessing the Power of Whimsy
description: Special black ink on the cover of the new monograph ''Extra Spatial'' by Kim Colin temporarily disappears when warmed, right. The effect is magical -- and surprisingly low-tech. ''It's not the technology, but what you do with it,'' said Tim Brown, the chief executive of IDEO, a design consultant that has created products for Palm and BMW. ''Extra Spatial'' presents some whimsical IDEO projects like the digital mirrors at the Prada store in SoHo and Spyfish STV, an 18-inch robot submarine that probes underwater landscapes with video cameras. ''Go diving without having to get wet,'' Mr. Brown said. Spyfish is $15,000 at www.spyfish.com, and the monograph (Chronicle Books, $35) is available at www.ideo.com. CRAIG KELLOGG

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications

Microsoft is trying to take market share from Nokia , the world's biggest handset maker, which uses the Symbian operating system. Nokia accounted for 78 percent of the 1.07 million so-called smart phones shipped in the second quarter in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, Canalys.com said yesterday. The Voq handset, which allows users to check e-mail and listen to music, will carry the network operator's brand and is aimed at business users, Todd Heintz, Sierra's director of marketing, said in an interview. The company is "well down the line" to signing agreements with European carriers, he said. Sierra farmed out the manufacturing of the device to Flextronics International , the world's largest maker of electronics for other companies, Mr. Heintz said. He declined to disclose sales goals for the handset.

title: Separate Paths
description: Well, it was a good idea. If the New York Philharmonic Orchestra had returned, as planned, to Carnegie Hall -- its home for more than 70 years until it moved to Lincoln Center in 1962 -- it would have been a nearly perfect marriage of orchestra and concert hall. But this week the merger, which was announced in June, fell apart irrevocably in a decision reached by the chairmen of the two organizations and endorsed by their boards. To some observers, the short, fatal arc of this plan will be proof that there was never enough substance in the merger, which would have taken place in 2006. To others it will reflect poorly on the leadership of both institutions. It demonstrates that merging cultural institutions is no easier than merging corporations. The issues that scuttled the deal were not artistic in nature. They were matters of power and control.

As editor, she won many awards from the NY Press Association, including first prizes for general excellence and editorial pages. After retiring from the newspaper, Mrs. Reagan held a variety of communications and public relations positions with Cazenovia College for several years. Born in NYC, daughter of the late Gustav Richard Stahl and Kathleen Allan George, she attended public schools in Larchmont and was a graduate of the Northfield Schools and Syracuse University. Before moving to Cazenovia in 1966, she had been a national account copywriter for the BBD&O advertising agency in NY. Her professional memberships included the National Press Club in Washington, DC, and Sigma Delta Chi, the national society of professional journalists. Mrs. Reagan is survived by her husband of 52 years, Allan L. Reagan of Georgetown, TX, formerly of Cazenovia; a son, Allan L. Reagan, Jr, of Leander, TX; a daughter, Kathleen A. Houghton, of Preston, England; a grandson, and four nephews. A funeral service will be held at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Cazenovia, at 2:00 pm on October 15, 2003. title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: SAP REVENUE BEATS ANALYSTS' FORECASTS SAP, the world's largest maker of business-management software, yesterday reported third-quarter license revenue that beat analyst forecasts, as it signed more contracts in the United States. License sales in the period totaled 430 million euros ($508 million), the company, based in Walldorf, Germany, said in a statement. SAP, which had license sales of 435 million euros last year, was expected to report 380 million euros, according to the median forecast of analysts in a Bloomberg survey. The better-than-forecast license revenue at SAP, whose customers include Volvo and the Defense Department, indicates recovering demand for the technology industry after a three-year slump. SAP depends on license revenue because that generates future support business. The company had 447 million euros in such sales in the third quarter of 2001, and 480 million euros in 2000. American depository receipts of SAP, each equal to one-quarter of a regular share, rose $4.83, or 14 percent, to $38.55 in New York Stock Exchange composite trading.
