title: Goldman to Buy $9.1 Billion in Sumitomo Loans
description: The Goldman, Sachs Group will set up an investment fund to buy as much as 1 trillion yen ($9.1 billion) in nonperforming loans from the Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, the latest effort by a foreign firm to help a Japanese bank strengthen its balance sheet.

title: Panel Approves Sanctions on Syria With White House Support
description: Congress stepped up pressure on Syria on Wednesday when a House panel endorsed diplomatic and economic sanctions against the country, accusing it of sponsoring terrorism and fostering turmoil in Iraq. The White House dropped its previous opposition to the sanctions plan.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: STATES EXAMINING CAREMARK BID FOR ADVANCEPCS
description: Caremark RX, which plans to buy AdvancePCS to expand its operations in managing pharmacy benefit programs, said yesterday that Florida and other states were conducting an antitrust review of the proposed acquisition. Last month, Caremark offered about $5.6 billion in cash and stock for AdvancePCS, which is based in Irving, Tex. The companies act as middlemen, making large purchases from wholesalers or drug makers to get discounts for customers like General Motors. The combined company would trail only Medco Health Solutions. ''We are watching to see what happens in the marketplace'' and monitoring the federal review, said JoAnn Carrin, a spokeswoman for the Florida attorney general's office. The state has not started a formal investigation, she said.

title: Closed Captions, Refreshed Without a Racing Typist
description: For deaf users, the Internet was initially a great leveler. But that is quickly changing. ''With broadband and multimedia, the Internet is moving away from being a level playing field,'' said Thomas Wlodkowski, the director of accessibility for America Online.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Inquiry Starts On Changed Grades
description: The attorney general's office is investigating whether records of the 32 schools in Scottsdale were manipulated to let teachers earn bonuses based on enrollments and academic progress. District auditors said one elementary-school principal had advised the teachers to inflate their attendance reports and alter the scores on achievement tests. The officials said false enrollment figures could result in misallocated aid. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: A Moment in the Spotlight For One 18-Year-Old Fan
description: He would identify himself only as Josh. No last name. He said he was 18. He lives in Fair Lawn, N.J. He went to the Yankees game against the Boston Red Sox last night with his father. They are Yankees fans.

title: Osaka Journal; Tokyo's Rival Says 'the Real Japan' Is Right Here
description: The rivalry between Osaka, the capital of western Japan, and Tokyo over the soul of Japan has survived even though Osaka was eclipsed economically and politically by its enemy out east.

title: The File-Sharing Debates
description: Last week in this space, I wondered why the RIAA (Recording Industry Association of America) and movie studios get so worked up about online file swapping, when public libraries distribute their works freely without a penny of compensation.

title: Chaney Apologizes To His Point Guards
description: Knicks Coach Don Chaney realized he had inadvertently maligned his two veteran point guards Tuesday when he said that the Knicks were still looking for a ''great point guard.''

title: Torre Opts for Almonte, Leaving Out Hammond
description: Joe Torre went against his instincts in the division series and carried 11 pitchers instead of 10. For the American League Championship Series, Torre reverted to his preferred roster makeup, adding infielder Erick Almonte to the roster and subtracting the left-hander Chris Hammond.

title: State Lowering Bar On Regents Exams Needed to Graduate
description: New York State's education commissioner, Richard P. Mills, said Wednesday that the state would loosen the demanding testing requirements it has imposed for high school graduation in recent years, including the standards used to judge math proficiency.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 25 about the arrival of Mongolian peacekeeping troops on American transports to serve in Iraq misstated the number of people killed by the armies of the general Hulegu in a past Mongol operation  the sacking of Baghdad in 1258. Historians generally agree that it was 80,000, not 800,000.

title: The Philadelphia's New Conductor In a Risky Debut
description: Inevitably, Tuesday night's concert by the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, its first appearance in New York since Christoph Eschenbach took over as music director last month, was going to be viewed as a statement of the conductor's artistic intentions. Mr. Eschenbach, 63, might have played it safe by offering the tried-and-true. Instead, to his great credit, he conducted Messiaen's huge (at 75 minutes), ecstatic and daunting ''Turangalila Symphony,'' composed between 1946 and 1948 and revised in 1990. This was a shimmeringly brilliant and viscerally exciting performance of an enigmatic and knockout masterpiece.

title: Congressional Memo; Adjusting to the Senate After Aiming for More
description: Senator Bob Graham and the other presidential candidates who follow him back to Capitol Hill after their campaigns founder should brace for re-entry. By past accounts, it can be scorching.

title: Funny Cide to Skip Breeders' Classic
description: Funny Cide, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes, will skip the $4 million Breeders' Cup Classic and instead run against other New York-breds in the $250,000 Empire Classic at Belmont Park on Oct. 18.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Bond Rating Raised
description: Russia's bond ratings were raised two levels to investment grade by Moody's Investors Service, underscoring an economic turnaround five years after the government defaulted on $40 billion of domestic debt and the banking system collapsed. Moody's lifted the ratings for Russia's international and domestic bonds to Baa3, the lowest investment-grade level, from Ba2, citing President Vladimir V. Putin's progress in reducing debt and spending. It's the first time the Russian debt has been lifted above junk grade by Moody's or Standard & Poor's.

title: Priest Charged With Gun Possession and Harassment
description: A man arrested on charges that he made harassing telephone calls to a Catholic high school in Brooklyn turned out to be a Roman Catholic priest whose Queens apartment contained guns, pornographic magazines, Nazi memorabilia and thousands of dollars he said he stole from a church, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Is Condi Gaslighting Rummy?
description: It's easy to see why the Bush crowd is getting so tetchy.

title: Archie, Model of Sobriety, Fights Teenage Drinking
description: To save Westchester County teenagers from a world gone complicated, Westchester County officials have enlisted the services of four timeless teenagers they say are perfect for the job: Archie, Betty, Veronica and Jughead.

title: CABLE BILLER IS TOLD TO PAY $120 MILLION TO COMCAST
description: CSG Systems International, a provider of billing services for cable companies, said yesterday that an arbitrator had ordered it to pay the Comcast Corporation $120 million to settle a contract dispute. The ruling will reduce quarterly revenue from Comcast, the largest cable television operator in the country and CSG's biggest customer, by as much as 38 percent, CSG said. CSG said its quarterly earnings could decline as much as 16 cents a share. CSG said that Comcast had accused it of blocking Comcast's efforts to use another billing service. CSG, based in Englewood, Colo., said it would ask the arbitrator to reduce the payout by as much as $50 million. But its executives said yesterday that it would be able to pay the entire $120 million fine. CSG's stock fell $6.22, or 40 percent, to $9.28 a share.

title: All's Fair During a Foul Night for the Yankees
description: The Yankees, as always, had the Boston Red Sox right where they wanted them. Yes, there are the championships, the decades of bragging rights, the logo on Babe Ruth's cap in Cooperstown. But on the eve of this epic American League Championship Series, there were more relevant reasons for the Yankees to be confident.

title: Delicate and Complex Music Played With Little Care
description: Talk about backhanded compliments. On the one hand, any composer must be gratified to have a whole evening devoted to his or her work, as happened on Oct. 3 for Peter Lieberson, the first of 14 composer portraits at the Miller Theater this season. On the other hand, no composer could have been very happy to hear his work given such indifferent performances as members of the Eos Orchestra turned in.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MAINE: 1970'S LAW BANS SUNDAY LIQUOR SALES It is illegal to buy liquor on Sundays in 135 municipalities because of a 1970's law that the state rediscovered in June, after taking over liquor licensing. In the 1970's, most towns decided that stores could sell liquor on Sundays only if allowed by referendums. Until municipalities act, stores in many cities, including Augusta, Bangor and Portland, cannot sell liquor on Sundays. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Designers and Architects Are Wagging the Doghouse
description: Bowhaus, an exhibition and auction, will show 17 doghouse prototypes by designers and architects. Michael Bird of Adirondack Design made a turreted cottage with porches. Dan Wood, of WORK Architecture Company, envisioned an aluminum exercise pen (right) with video screens showing images of butterflies and mailmen in flight. ''It would give urban dogs a whole new range of experiences and aid their self-esteem,'' Mr. Wood said, deadpan. The sale benefits Puppies Behind Bars, which trains prison inmates to raise dogs for the blind. The doghouses will be at Steelcase, 4 Columbus Circle, Oct. 16 through 20; www.puppiesbehindbars.com; the auction is Oct. 20. EVE M. KAHN

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: P.O.W. Camp To Be Preserved
description: The remains of a World War II prison camp in northeast China where Japanese soldiers forced Americans and other Allied prisoners to work as slaves is to be preserved as a historical site. The authorities in Shenyang, China, decided in late September that what is left of the former Mukden camp would be protected and opened to visitors. The decision came after former American P.O.W.'s visited the camp, partly to bring attention to the need to preserve it. The decision also comes as tensions are rising between China and Japan over a host of issues. More than 1,500 P.O.W.'s were held at Mukden from 1942 until the end of the war. The camp had one of the highest death rates of any concentration camp. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Symbol Posts Lower-Than-Expected Results
description: Symbol Technologies Inc. posted lower-than-expected second-quarter results yesterday, and said restatements of results for the last five years reduced revenue by $223 million for that period. Symbol also said it had not filed its annual report for 2002 and audited quarterly results with the Securities and Exchange Commission and did not provide a timetable for the filings. Symbol, which provides mobile computing technologies and bar-code products, said net earnings for the quarter that ended in June were $9 million, or 4 cents a share, lower than analysts' expectation of 6 cents a share, according to Reuters Research, a unit of the Reuters Group. Symbol, whose accounting practices are being investigated by securities regulators and federal prosecutors, said the pending restatements would reduce revenue over the period, from 1998 to 2002, by $223 million, to $6.116 billion. Symbol, based in Holtsville, N.Y., also said operating expense, excluding the impact of variable plan accounting on stock options, over the period was increased by a cumulative $237 million, to $2.26 billion. Symbol also said restatements would reduce shareholders' equity at the end of 2002 by $255 million, to $956 million. Symbol shares rose 9 cents, to $13.14.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: PORTUGAL: NEW FOREIGN MINISTER Teresa Gouveia was named foreign minister, replacing Antonio Martins da Cruz, who resigned on Tuesday after being accused of using his position to gain a place for his daughter in medical school. (He denies any wrongdoing.) Ms. Gouveia, the first woman to become foreign minister, served as environment minister from 1993 to 1995.

title: A Bit of the Emerald Isle In a Florida Backyard
description: A DOZEN men and women, most in their 50's and 60's, chat near the bar of a small Irish pub. A couple is sitting on a hand-carved mahogany bench, upholstered in a brightly patterned weave and separated from the bar area by stained-glass screens. The man and woman hold their pints of Guinness and gaze out the window at the searing summer sun and the 18th hole of a Florida golf course.

title: Young Man And Horn, With Buzz
description: Jazz trumpeters aren't meant to be obscure: they're the brash battlers in the family, announcing themselves until they run out of air. But this isn't the 1950's, when jazz was nearly popular, or the 1980's, when jazz was widely proclaimed to be reborn. Substantial jazz record labels aren't looking for trumpeters, they're looking for singers whose appeal crosses the entire field of adult music.

title: Pixar-Disney Talks Said to Show Progress
description: Pixar Animation Studios, the maker of hits like ''Toy Story'' and the summer blockbuster ''Finding Nemo,'' and the Walt Disney Company have agreed in general on a compromise that could clear the way for Disney to continue distributing Pixar's films, according to two people close to the negotiations.

title: Bush Plans Appearance With Schwarzenegger
description: President Bush will appear at the side of California's governor-elect, Arnold Schwarzenegger, during a fund-raising trip to the state next week, a Republican close to the White House said on Wednesday, even as some religious conservative supporters of Mr. Bush said they were troubled by accusations that Mr. Schwarzenegger had engaged in sexual misconduct.

title: Islanders Roll Out New System For New Era
description: In Peter Laviolette's first season as the Islanders' coach, in 2001-2, Michael Peca shared rides home with him from the airport. It was not a big deal. The giddy Islanders were winning, and Laviolette was seen as the next Al Arbour.

title: Stopping Sexual Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Putin's Democratic Present Fights His K.G.B. Past
description: There is a question that irritates President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, and it is the one about his past as a foreign intelligence operative of the K.G.B.

title: BOISE CASCADE EXPECTS HIGHER THIRD-QUARTER EARNINGS
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation, the lumber maker that is buying OfficeMax, said yesterday that third-quarter profit surged as prices for building materials rose. Profit climbed to as much as 44 cents a share from 9 cents a year earlier, the company said, with final results set for release on Oct. 21. Analysts had expected a profit of 29 cents, according to a survey by Thomson First Call. Shares of Boise rose 56 cents, to $28.17. Boise said its paper business would be little changed from the second quarter, when it had operating income of $1 million, and would ''continue to be lackluster'' in the fourth quarter.

title: Metro Matters; Say You Want A Revolution? Well, Um, No
description: FEELING overshadowed, New York? Relax. You have your own identity, reflected in what could be a new state slogan that, we submit, captures New York's political reality as validly as the recall election captured California's: ''Leave bad enough alone.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEEKS, DONNA JOYCE (JOY)
description: WEEKS--Donna Joyce (Joy), would have been 50 on October 8th, passed away on September 30th in Houston, Texas, capping a gallant six year battle with breast cancer. Mom to Max, her loving Cat companion. Daughter of the late William Donovan (Pappy) Weeks & the late Norma Jean Weeks. Sister of Nola Burgess. Niece of Lucy W. King and Jack & Jenelle Taylor. Aunt to Melanie, Jessica & James. She was a Loyal, Loving, Laughing and Wonderful Friend to a Lucky many of us. Joy, originally of Florence, South Carolina, attended the University of South Carolina at Columbia, then some years in New Orleans and Loyola University School of Law--and, lastly, a proud resident of New York City since 1978, a Yankee fan, and a very proud New York City Marathon finisher. Member of the Bars of the States of New York and Louisiana. A Memorial service will be held in Central Park, New York City, at 10:00 AM on Saturday, October 18th. Details at 203-783-2076, and for memorial contributions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLD, KEITH CLINTON, MD,
description: WOLD--Keith Clinton, MD, 79, passed away at his home in Boca Raton on October 1, 2003, after a lengthy illness. Dr. Wold was born in St Paul, Minnesota, in 1924, the son of Karl Christian Wold, M.D. and Maybelle Lundgren Wold. He graduated from St. Paul Academy in 1942, received his B.S. in Medicine from the University of North Dakota in 1948, and graduated from the University of Vermont College of Medicine in 1951. During World War II, Dr. Wold served in the U.S. Army Medical Corps and his tour of duty included the South Pacific. In 1949, he married Elaine Johnson of New Brunswick, NJ and had two children, Keith C. Wold, Jr and Diana J. Wold. In 1955, Dr Wold moved his family from Minnesota to Fort Lauderdale, Fl. where he maintained an active practice in ophthalmology, specializing in eye surgery. Dr Wold was an avid yachtsman and participated in numerous ocean sailing races. He also had a passion for Floridabred thoroughbreds and was involved in breeding and racing. Many of his horses raced at Calder Race Course, Gulfstream Park and Hialeah. Dr. Wold and his wife, Elaine, formed The Bay Branch Foundation in 1961 and the Wold Charitable Trust to support education and research projects. His primary focus was providing assistance to the handicapped and disabled. Their philanthropic efforts have spread throughout the South Florida community and beyond. Wold Corporation was formed in Florida in 1976 to manage business investments in agriculture, real estate and transportation. Dr. Wold was honored with the Sioux Award as the Alumnus of the Year in 1990 by the University of North Dakota for his outstanding dedication to the field of medicine. Dr and Mrs Wold have served as chairpersons for the Boca Raton Community Hospital Ball and numerous charitable events in Palm Beach and Broward counties. Dr Wold is a past Co-Chairman of the Grace Commission Self-Study of Government for the City of Boca Raton and served on the Board of Trustees of Boca Raton Community Hospital for many years. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Elaine; his son, Keith C. Wold, Jr.:(Clio Pavlantos) of New York City; and daughter, Diana J. Wold (Donald S. Marszalek) of Boca Raton, Fl; two granddaughters, Diana Elaine Marszalek of Boca Raton, and Mary Lea Ruth Wold of New York City. He is also survived by his sister, Betty Wold Johnson of Princeton, NJ; his brother, Sidney R. Wold, MD of Danville, Kentucky; and numerous nieces and newphews. Dr Wold was predeceased by his sister, Mary W. Strong, of Boca Raton, Fl. A memorial has been established in the name of Dr. Keith C. Wold at Boca Raton Community Hospital Foundation, 745 Meadows Road, Boca Raton, Fl 33486; and Hospice by the Sea, Inc., 1531 West Palmetto Road, Boca Raton, Fl 33486.

title: Genentech Posts 70% Increase in Profit
description: Genentech, the biotechnology company, said yesterday that third-quarter profit surged 70 percent as sales of its cancer drugs climbed and it received payment from Amgen for a legal settlement.

title: Fiscal Monitors Give Nassau High Praise for 2004 Budget
description: Nassau's fiscal oversight board, which the state imposed in 2000 to avert bankruptcy, praised county officials on Wednesday for achieving a turnaround in the county's finances.

title: Corrections
description: The Metro Matters column on Monday, about plans to sell the Board of Education's WNYE radio and television stations, misstated the founding date of the radio station. It was 1938; the television station opened in the 1960's.

title: L.I. Coaches Say They Tried To Prevent Student Hazing
description: Five coaches for the Long Island high school whose football players are accused of assaulting teammates told investigators yesterday that they had taken steps to try to prevent hazing, their lawyer said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He is extraordinarily enthusiastic, as I think comes through, wants to get cracking, wants to do the job.''

title: Cubs' Power Overwhelms the Marlins
description: The Cubs finally displayed their vaunted pitching Wednesday night, sending Mark Prior to the mound in an attempt to even their National League Championship Series against the Florida Marlins. Prior and Kerry Wood may separate the Cubs from the rest of baseball this month, but Sammy Sosa could make them even more imposing.

title: Economic Scene; For those who live by buzz, it's important to know who's doing the talking.
description: THE fall television season is upon us. As viewers check out the new shows, producers, writers and actors anxiously await their reactions. What do the critics say? Do ordinary viewers agree? Which programs will survive the season, and which will die after only a few episodes? Are there any hits?

title: Live From Satchmo's Den
description: LUCILLE ARMSTRONG lived in the brick house in Queens for 12 years after her husband's death, and when she died, during a trip to Boston in October 1983, the first person into the house was Phoebe Jacobs. Mrs. Jacobs, 85 and a woman of some dash, had worked with Louis Armstrong since 1956, and is now the executive vice president of the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: All Kales Are Not Equal

title: Pennington Back on Oct. 26
description: Jets quarterback Chad Pennington intends to return on Oct. 26 against Philadelphia, a week sooner than expected, according to a person familiar with his thinking.

title: Lawmakers Are Insisting Money for Iraq Be Loans
description: In the last week or so, Representative Zach Wamp, a conservative Republican from Tennessee, has said no to Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, to Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, and to Joshua B. Bolten, the White House budget director.

title: Outfitting the Teenager's Dominion
description: MY offspring have conditioned me to believe that it's normal to be addressed in a tone most accurately described as accusatory, as in ''Are you sure these brown flecks in the meatballs aren't mushrooms?''

title: The Alchemist at Work: Objects at Rest and in Motion
description: Dror Benshetrit (above left and bottom left) operates a studio in the meatpacking district that sits below the Yigal Azroul Boutique, for which he did the interiors, above. It was the first such project for Mr. Benshetrit, a native of Israel and a recent graduate of the Design Academy Eindhoven in the Netherlands. ''Most of my work has something to do with movement,'' he said. ''Often it adjusts or transforms.'' The Pick chair (below, on the left) hangs on the wall until it is folded into a chair, which can hold 350 pounds. The secret is the fabric -- the same as in bulletproof vests -- which runs the length of the chair sandwiched between two layers of wood. A limited edition will be ready in about a month and will sell for $1,000 each. The F chair (below right) takes its name from its shape when opened.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: CONGO: U.N. TROOPS TO EXPAND PATROL Peacekeepers will begin to deploy next week deeper into Ituri Province, in the northeast, to try to stop further ethnic bloodshed, said William Swing, head of the United Nations mission. At least 65 people, including 40 children, were shot and hacked to death on Monday in Katshelli, 38 miles from Bunia, the province's main town, where peacekeepers have already deployed. Fighting between militias for control of the mineral-rich region has killed more than 50,000 people since 1999.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Guilty Plea In Bribery Case
description: A former construction official for the Port Authority pleaded guilty yesterday in federal court to taking bribes in return for arranging faster payments from the authority to an environmental-testing contractor. The ex-official, Mark A. Jakubek, worked for a division of the authority that oversees construction and renovation projects and is the former manager of environmental field operations. He faces up to 10 years in prison and a fine of $250,000. Prosecutors said Mr. Jakubek, 44, of Monroe, N.Y., took bribes of nearly $20,000. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Dozens Killed as Afghan Factions Clash
description: Heavy fighting left dozens dead in the north on Wednesday as factional militias battled for control of a local district, officials there said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SULTAN, MAX
description: SULTAN--Max. Age 96, died at his home in Brooklyn, on October 3, 2003. Private services and burial were held October 5.

title: For Devils, a Double Debut Will Test a Pair of Rookies
description: BOSTON, Oct. 8  The Devils rookies David Hale and Paul Martin spent Tuesday night in their Boston hotel room watching television and trying not to talk about their season opener Wednesday evening against the Boston Bruins in which both young defensemen were set to make their National Hockey League debuts.

title: Car Bombing and 2 Other Attacks in Iraq Leave at Least 10 Dead
description: BAGHDAD, Oct. 9  A station wagon packed with explosives exploded inside a police station compound in one of Baghdad's biggest slums early today, killing at least 8 people and wounding more than 40.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMMERMAN, MURRAY
description: HAMMERMAN -- Murray. Age 93 on October 4 at home. Served on the City College Centennial Comm. with Justice Frankfurter, Bernard Baruch & Mayor Beame. Exec. Dir., N. Atlantic Milk Processor's Assoc., VP Council of Talmud Torah Edu., officer, Washington Hts. Cong. with Sarah (z''l), parents of Dr. Ira (& Ellen), Daniel (& Charlotte) & Rabbi Richard (& Sharon). Nine grandchildren and 15 great grandchildren.

title: Ortiz Continues To Bedevil Yankees
description: The battle between the Yankee killer and the one Yankee pitcher who had been able to handle him went to David Ortiz. Even Mike Mussina could not stop him last night.

title: From Blurry Type to Tagalog, The Scanner Is Unfazed
description: Typing skills may be as useful as ever, but the need to retype has diminished considerably as optical-character recognition software has improved. The programs, referred to as O.C.R. software, can analyze a page of type scanned from a magazine, manuscript or memo and reproduce the text for use in a word-processing or other editing program. The new FineReader 7.0 Professional program from Abbyy Software House offers a 25 percent gain in accuracy over the previous version of the software, and several other improvements to reduce the amount of time spent fussing with scanned documents.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Sniper Suspect to Argue Insanity
description: Lee Malvo, the younger suspect in the Washington area sniper shootings last fall, is not guilty because he was insane, his lawyers argued in a court filing today. They asserted that Mr. Malvo, 18, had been subjected to extensive indoctrination by the other suspect, John Muhammad, who is 42.

title: It's Even Worse Than You Think
description: Last week the federal government ended the fiscal year with a reported deficit of approximately $400 billion, pushing the federal debt held by the public to nearly $4 trillion. Sobering though these numbers are, they actually understate the problem. Through an accounting sleight of hand with far greater consequences than the corporate scandals of recent years, the federal government distorts public debate, threatens social programs and impoverishes future generations.

title: W.N.B.A. Stars Are Selected
description: There may be other young and talented female basketball players who could represent the United States at the Summer Olympics in Athens next year. But USA Basketball announced yesterday that it had selected seven internationally experienced veterans from the Women's National Basketball Association for the 2004 team.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALPERIN, BERNARD
description: HALPERIN--Bernard, 77, on October 8, 2003, of Saddle River, NJ. An innovator in the retail clothing industry and pioneer in import industry from China. A great supporter of Israel and Jewish causes. Devoted husband of Linda, loving children David and Michael, and cherished grandfather. Services today, 1 PM, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: With Union Talks Nearing, N.H.L. Is Citing Big Losses
description: With its labor agreement expiring in 11 months, the National Hockey League now says it has lost $1.5 billion over the last nine seasons largely because of spiraling player costs and the union's exploitation of contract loopholes.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the At the Movies column yesterday about Cate Blanchett and various roles she has played misstated the nationality of her character in ''Heaven.'' She was British, not Italian.

title: Awnings and Billboards
description: To the Editor:

title: Adding Weight to Suspicion, Sonar Is Linked to Whale Deaths
description: Scientists have long suspected a link between mass whale strandings and the Navy's use of powerful sonar systems, but the evidence -- dying whales washing ashore when sonar exercises occur -- has been mostly anecdotal.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: New Emergency Radios Approved
description: Westchester County plans to equip police, fire and medical workers in 45 municipalities with new radios that allow them to talk to one another without worrying about incompatible signals. The new radio system, which was approved by the County Legislature on Tuesday, may be operating in as little as a year. In emergencies that require crews from many towns, many of the radios are incompatible, said County Legislator William Ryan. Under the legislation, which passed 17 to 0, the county will spend $7.8 million for the new radios, which will complement the municipalities' existing systems. The bill now goes to the county executive, Andrew J. Spano, who is expected to sign it. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Shock Waves From a Political Earthquake
description: To the Editor:

title: MAGELLAN HEALTH WINS APPROVAL FOR RECOVERY PLAN
description: Magellan Health Services, a manager of mental health care plans, has received a bankruptcy judge's approval for its recovery plan that will shed $600 million of debt and hand control to creditors and a new investor. The Onex Corporation, a holding company in Toronto, will pay as much as $200 million in stock and cash to buy a controlling interest in Magellan. Onex will receive from 34.4 percent to 49 percent of Magellan's new shares and 50 percent of the voting rights. It will also appoint four of Magellan's nine directors. Judge Prudence Carter Beatty of Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York approved the plan at a hearing. Magellan, based in Columbia, Md., filed for bankruptcy protection in March to restructure about $1.5 billion in debt.

title: EBay Founder Raises Foundation Endowment to $300 Million
description: Jeffrey S. Skoll, a founder of eBay, the online auction company that is one of the few still successful Internet icons, has raised the endowment of his foundation to $300 million from $117 million.

title: Currency Rumors in China Shake Hong Kong
description: Speculation that China will be forced to let its currency rise has sent a flood of money into the Hong Kong dollar, pushing up its value and inflicting heavy losses on traders while driving short-term interest rates here almost to zero.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOR, BENNY
description: DOR--Benny. Beloved husband of Bobby. Loving father of Gal, Orna (Shimi), Rachel, Howie (Liz) and Josh. Adoring grandfather of Liam and Oliver. Dear brother of Batsheva (Moshe). Cherished son-in-law of Estelle and Eugene Ferkauf. Loving nephew of Flo Thorn. Services today 11:15 AM, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Poor Showing Clouds Prospects of State's No. 2
description: A referendum on the state's top Democrat may also have dealt a severe blow to the party's second-ranking leader. Some political experts here say that Lt. Gov. Cruz M. Bustamante, the lone big-name Democrat on the recall ballot, emerged greatly diminished and left the future leadership of the party in doubt.

description: THE PLEASURE OF MY COMPANY

title: Computer Associates Fires 3 Amid Inquiry
description: Computer Associates International, the software company, fired its chief financial officer and two other executives yesterday after a company investigation into how it recorded sales.

title: A Rested Pettite May Have an Edge on Lowe in Game 2
description: The most important thing about Game 1 of the ALCS was that the Red Sox won a game without needing Derek Lowe or Pedro Martinez to start it. Those 2 pitchers will start 4 of the next 6 games, and that has to be important for Boston. The game was intense, because that's the way every game is between the Red Sox and Yankees, but for me, Tim Wakefield took a lot of the energy out of it. The Yankees put runners on base in only two innings, and it's hard to get too analytical when they just can't get anything going.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Jail Planned For Soccer Violence
description: Under a new penal code to take effect this month, violent fans at soccer games and other sports events may face prison sentences of up to four and a half years plus a three-year ban on game attendance after jail. The interior minister announced the tougher measures the day after a spectator was beaten to death by a soccer fan in northwest Spain. The spectator, Manuel Ros, 31, had tried to break up a fight between members of a soccer club and a young man wearing a T-shirt for the opposing team, a local government spokesman said. Soccer violence has killed 10 people in Spain since 1984, the national daily El Mundo reported. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Judge Says Minnesota Cannot Regulate Net Calls

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Man Sentenced In Music Copyright Case
description: A New York man was sentenced yesterday to six months in prison on copyright infringement charges for selling pirated compact disc compilations over the Internet, prosecutors said. Judge Reggie B. Walton of Federal District Court in Washington also said that Alvin A. Davis of Brooklyn should pay $3,329.50 in restitution and serve a year of supervised probation. He was also barred from using a computer for a year. Mr. Davis's sentence is the first for such an offense, according to the Recording Industry Association of America, which said the ''piracy is especially harmful to record stores and other legitimate music retailers.'' The music industry, in an effort to stem more than three years of falling sales that analysts attribute to piracy and companies' failure to spur demand, has filed hundreds of lawsuits against people who have illegally distributed music files. The suits followed cases against file-sharing services like Napster. The industry is also promoting its own fee-based online services. Mr. Davis, 42, operated www.empirerecords.com, a Web site that is now defunct. The site sold more than 100 different CD and cassette compilations of rap and rhythm and blues music. He was arrested after an undercover Federal Bureau of Investigation agent bought 209 CD's over four months.

title: Stephen Jay Rose, 77; Started Ad Agency
description: Stephen Jay Rose, a founder of AC&R Advertising, which specialized in fashion, retail and high-end brands like Este Lauder, the cosmetics maker, and Foot Locker, the athletic shoe retailer, died on Sept. 30 at his home in St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands. He was 77.

title: It's Enough To Give A Gator A Complex
description: Now it is time to look at things from the alligator's point of view.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINTER, CLAIRE
description: WINTER--Claire. Temple Sinai of Bergen County deeply mourns the passing of our longtime member Claire Winter. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the family. Dr. Bruce S. Block, Rabbi Stuart Himmelfarb, George Bean & Barry Zeveloff, Presidents

title: A Mezzo Poised for the Heights
description: Oh, noble Jocasta, what a mess you are in! Unwittingly married to your own son, who is also the murderer of your husband, his father. Stephanie Blythe, playing Jocasta in the Metropolitan Opera's current production of Stravinsky's ''Oedipus Rex,'' glides across the stage, full-bodied, graceful, every inch a queen, her mezzo rich and plush, effortlessly dipping, then rising with a flutelike purity. ''Ne probentur oracula,'' she sings (''Let not the oracles be proved true''). Unfortunately, the oracles are right -- the worst has come to pass.

title: Big Retailers Are Upbeat On Prospects For Holidays
description: In whispers, perhaps not quite daring to believe their own words, retailers have begun to say that this year's holiday season is more promising than those in the recent past.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: 1970'S Law Bans Sunday Liquor Sales
description: It is illegal to buy liquor on Sundays in 135 municipalities because of a 1970's law that the state rediscovered in June, after taking over liquor licensing. In the 1970's, most towns decided that stores could sell liquor on Sundays only if allowed by referendums. Until municipalities act, stores in many cities, including Augusta, Bangor and Portland, cannot sell liquor on Sundays. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRAISTED, ANDREW CHARLES, PHD.
description: BRAISTED--Andrew Charles, PhD. Dr. Braisted died suddenly, on October 4, 2003, of suspected heart failure, leaving his wife Joelle Morrow, M.D. and their unborn son. Born in New York City in 1964, he resided for much of his adult life in San Francisco. He was a graduate of Bates College and the University of California at Berkeley, where he earned a doctorate degree in Organic Chemistry. After post-doctoral work in Protein Engineering at Genentech, Inc. he was a founder of Sunesis Pharmaceuticals, Inc. where he specialized in the discovery of small molecule drugs. He held several patents in the field, notably for tethering, Sunesis's core drug discovery technology. He is also survived by his parents, Gayl and Charles Braisted, and his sisters Christina Braisted Rogers and Melissa Braisted. Andrew will be remembered by all who have known him for his incredible dedication to everything he did. He was admired and loved so much; he was an inspiration, a leader, and a support for every individual and group he has touched. He was a passionate friend, husband, brother, and son; a patient teacher, a brilliant scientist, an extraordinary cook and SAAB enthusiast, and someone who has made us all feel lucky to have known him. He will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, you may make contributions to the Andrew Braisted Memorial Fund. For information, please contact Robert McDowell at Sunesis Pharmecuticals, rsm@sunesis.com

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the dangers of close relationships between people and tigers used a misspelled given name in some copies for an animal expert with the International Exotic Feline Sanctuary in Dallas, and misstated his title. He is Louis Dorfman, not Lewis, and he is an animal behaviorist, not the sanctuary's director.

title: Simon Group Gives Up Hostile Bid for Taubman Centers
description: The mall brawl appears to be over. After a year of trying to wrest control of the Taubman Centers mall empire from A. Alfred Taubman and his family, the Simon Property Group and Westfield America said yesterday that they had withdrawn their hostile bid.

title: A Case of Now You See It, Now It's a Blank Slate
description: To a child, a wall looks like a blank piece of paper. To an adult, that child's crayon drawing may indicate it is time for a paint job -- or at least a good talking to. But a new product from Mr. Clean, the Magic Eraser, below, really works. It removes crayon and other marks, stains and smudges from walls and floors. Simply dampen the white pad with tap water and use it like an eraser -- there are no chemical smells and there is no need to wear gloves. And like any eraser, it wears out with repeated use.

title: And the Winner Is . . . Refreshingly Unknown
description: On Sunday night a brand-new statuette called the Shorty was handed out at the Wiltern here as part of the Shortlist Music Prize show. Though this was the third year for the Shortlist, this is the first year it was accompanied by its own statuette (a gold-colored profile of a person wearing headphones). The awards concert was also filmed for television for the first time, and is scheduled to be shown on Oct. 25 on MTV2. (Hey, you have to start somewhere.) The winner was Damien Rice. If you've never heard of him, that's the point.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Caterer's Profit Falls
description: The French catering company Sodexho Alliance said its revenue fell 7.3 percent in fiscal year 2003, which ended Aug. 31. Sodexho's sales reached 11.7 billion euros ($13.8 billion), growing 3.1 percent excluding acquisitions compared with the previous fiscal year. But the company posted a 10 percent decline in revenue because of the fall of the dollar against the euro and was affected by slower sales in Britain and Ireland. Almost half of Sodexho's business is in the United States, where its food-service customers include the Marines, Hewlett-Packard and the Atlanta Public School District. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: 3-Month-Old Twins Found Dead In an Apartment in the Bronx
description: Twin three-month-old girls were discovered dead in a Bronx apartment yesterday, prompting an investigation by the police and the medical examiner's office.

title: Lyle Bettger, 88, Film Villain In Westerns and Noir Dramas
description: Lyle Bettger, a character actor who became one of the movies' most recognizable villains in the 1950's and 60's, died on Sept. 24 at the home of his son Lyle in Atascadero, Calif. He was 88 and lived in Paia, Hawaii.

title: With Friends Like These, Who Needs Book Agents?
description: A WRITER'S lot can be a lonely one, since churning out pages usually means hours spent alone at a keyboard. It seems natural, then, that many contemporary authors are turning to the Internet for companionship and support, and even taking over a Web site that was not originally intended as a writers' forum.

title: Ruling Roils Philippine Bid To Regain Disputed Money
description: A Philippine antigraft court issued a ruling Wednesday that complicates the government's efforts to reclaim control of money it says was used illegally under former President Ferdinand E. Marcos to buy control of San Miguel, the country's biggest brewer.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sierra To Sell Phone With Microsoft System
description: Sierra Wireless, a Canadian maker of wireless access cards for laptop computers, will start selling an advanced mobile phone that uses Microsoft's operating system before next July. Microsoft is trying to take market share from Nokia, the world's biggest handset maker, which uses the Symbian operating system. Nokia accounted for 78 percent of the 1.07 million so-called smart phones shipped in the second quarter in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, Canalys.com said yesterday. The Voq handset, which allows users to check e-mail and listen to music, will carry the network operator's brand and is aimed at business users, Todd Heintz, Sierra's director of marketing, said in an interview. The company is ''well down the line'' to signing agreements with European carriers, he said. Sierra farmed out the manufacturing of the device to Flextronics International, the world's largest maker of electronics for other companies, Mr. Heintz said. He declined to disclose sales goals for the handset.

title: Mayor Goes 550 Feet Below to Note Start of Tunnel Construction
description: The immense water tunnel -- known officially as City Tunnel No. 3 -- has been so long in the making that its construction has already outlasted five mayors, inspired thousands of news stories and killed 23 tunnel workers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WILLIAMS COS., Tulsa, Okla., a natural gas pipeline operator that has been selling businesses to raise cash and stay solvent, offered to buy back $1.64 billion of its debt to cut borrowings and reduce interest costs.

title: Tear Out a Check, Then Watch It Vanish
description: ALTHOUGH banks and billing companies have tried in recent years to convince consumers to pay more of their bills over the Internet or through electronic payments, most people still write paper checks. American consumers use checks for three of every five noncash payments, according to the Federal Reserve.

title: California's Day After; Overshadowed Blessings
description: At least the voters' fixation with the recall probably helped defeat two harmful propositions to extend California's penchant for hobbling elected officials with budget and governance restraints. Proposition 53, a feast for the construction industry, would have mandated that 3 percent of the state tax pool be dedicated to building things like roads and bridges, regardless of more pressing needs. And Proposition 54, driven by conservative opponents of affirmative action, would have blocked the state from collecting the ethnic and racial data that now figures vitally in everything from antidiscrimination studies to health research.

title: To Make Sure Votes Count, Sensor Device Goes Back On
description: New York City has agreed to reactivate a feature on its 7,200 voting machines that is intended to keep people from mistakenly failing to cast a ballot before leaving the booth.

description: The storm clouds rolling in from the Irish Sea and people along Blackpool's promenade struggling against lashing gales offer apt symbols for this year's Conservative Party conference.

title: As the Music Swells, Soak It Up in the Hot Tub
description: Nobody would deny the restorative powers of a dip in a hot tub. But for the true connoisseur of indulgence, even the most perfectly situated tub tends to have one glaring shortcoming: the music-listening issue. Now SpAudio, a new system manufactured by Hot Spring Spas, sends sound waves through the spa's shell, essentially transforming the tub's surface into a giant high-fidelity stereo speaker.

description: Perhaps Jay Leno was right. ''Tonight is a testament to just how important one appearance on the 'Tonight Show' can be,'' he said on Tuesday night, before introducing Arnold Schwarzenegger at his victory party.

description: Prosecutors rested their case yesterday against Frank P. Quattrone, the former Credit Suisse First Boston banker accused of obstructing a government investigation by sending an e-mail message to his staff members endorsing a colleague's directions to ''to clean up those files.''

description: The Yankees, as always, had the Boston Red Sox right where they wanted them. Yes, there are the championships, the decades of bragging rights, the logo on Babe Ruth's cap in Cooperstown. But on the eve of this epic American League Championship Series, there were more relevant reasons for the Yankees to be confident.

description: An article on Thursday about the medical ordeal and rescue of Barry McCue, an American worker at the South Pole, misstated the light conditions at the time of his evacuation, on Sept. 21. Visibility was low, but darkness was not total.

title: Delta to Meet With Pilots in Hopes of Restarting Salary Talks
description: The top executives of Delta Air Lines will meet with leaders of the union that represents its pilots on Oct. 17 to talk about the airline's financial condition and possibly work out a way to restart negotiations over wage cuts, Delta's president said yesterday.

title: NATO Officials Play Out Terrorism Scenario at Colorado Talks
description: NATO's defense ministers and military chiefs locked themselves away at a top-secret American base on Wednesday to play out a fictional scenario involving civilian evacuations, terrorist strikes and the threat of chemical or biological attack to test the Atlantic alliance's planned rapid-reaction force.

title: A Moment in the Spotlight for One 18-Year-Old Fan

description: Facing dismal poll numbers himself and tough budget decisions ahead, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday criticized the election process in California that allowed voters to recall Gov. Gray Davis less than a year into his second term.

title: Europe Criticizes U.S. Move to Impose Sanctions on Syria
description: The European Union criticized an American move toward imposing diplomatic and economic sanctions on Syria, saying today that efforts to isolate Syria were "not the most productive" and that the union would instead continue to seek closer cooperation with Damascus.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Border Patrol Releases Immigrants
description: The Border Patrol released scores of illegal immigrants from its detention center in Laredo, citing a lack of space and money. Up to 100 people, mostly from Central and South America, will be assigned dates for deportation hearings. Federal officers acknowledged that they had little means of compelling the people to appear. Mayor Elizabeth G. Flores of Laredo said local officials had been given a few hours' notice of the release, a move, she added, that ''makes a mockery of our nation's immigration laws.'' Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Supervalu Profit Rises in Quarter
description: Supervalu Inc., a food distributor and owner of the Shop 'n Save supermarkets, said yesterday that second-quarter net income rose 5.8 percent because of higher sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ASPER, ISRAEL
description: ASPER--Israel. The Shalem Center of Jerusalem mourns the untimely loss of Israel Asper. A bold visionary and passionate defender of Israel, he worked tirelessly on behalf of the Jewish people around the world. We offer heartfelt condolences to Babs, Gail, David, Leonard, and the entire Asper family. May his memory serve as a blessing for his family and all of Israel.

title: Schwarzenegger Wants Davis to Stop Filling Posts and Signing Bills
description: California's governor-elect, Arnold Schwarzenegger, asked Gov. Gray Davis on Thursday to suspend action on all pending bills and to stop appointing judges and members of state boards and commissions.

title: U.S. EQUITY FIRM BUYS STAKE IN GERMAN PUBLISHER
description: A San Francisco-based private-equity firm, Hellman & Friedman, said yesterday that it had bought 19 percent of the German publisher Axel Springer from Deutsche Bank for 350 million euros ($414 million) and had agreed to buy as much as 5 percent more. Hellman & Freedman plans to sell its holding in Springer, the publisher of Europe's most widely read paper, Bild Zeitung, in the years ahead, Hellman & Friedman's managing director, Patrick Healy, said in a conference call.

title: Facing Risks, Turkish Leader Defends Decision to Send Troops to Iraq
description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey on Thursday brushed aside objections to his country's decision to send thousands of soldiers to Iraq for the first time since Turkish troops were driven out of the former Ottoman territory in 1917.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, CHARLES EDWARD
description: LEVINE--Charles Edward. On October 9, 2003 at 52 years of age. Much loved son of Hillel Levine and Renee (Goldstein), loving brother of Steven, Lauren and Michael, cherished brother-in-law of Nora and Keith. Loving uncle of Shari and Jenna. Charles died from complications of his recent bypass surgery. He will be loved and missed by his loving family. Service today 10 AM ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York (near Avenue V).

title: CAR BOMB KILLS 8 AT POLICE STATION IN BAGHDAD SLUM
description: A white Oldsmobile station wagon packed with explosives blew up inside a police compound in one of Baghdad's poorest slums Thursday morning, killing the car's occupants and at least 8 others and wounding more than 40.

title: Mexico's New Energy Chief Faces Entrenched Monopoly
description: Mexico's new energy minister, Felipe Caldern, faces the same challenges his predecessors did in the struggle to overhaul the decaying government-owned oil and electricity monopolies and open these industries to more foreign investment.

title: Shopping List | Soccer Moms
description: FOR soccer moms, fall means filling the car trunk with special supplies. No tailgating grills or cocktail blenders are necessary -- this spectator sport is serious business, with blustery winds, sudden downpours and endless overtimes to endure. In this survival kit: tools to save backs, throats, clothes and memories. NANCY M. BETTER

title: Audit Faults Past Spending At City Agency
description: A quasi-public city agency has been used to pay for everything from sport utility vehicles for top city officials to $6,000 in ceremonial keys to the city for athletes, according to an audit released yesterday.

title: The Man in Schwarzenegger's Corner
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger was still on the set of the ''Tonight Show'' with Jay Leno when, having just declared himself a candidate for governor of California, he telephoned a Washington politician. The politician was Representative David E. Dreier, who says Mr. Schwarzenegger opened the conversation with five simple words: ''David, I need your help.''

title: Big Board Ponders Pay Disclosures
description: John S. Reed, the interim chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, spent much of yesterday poring over the details of the compensation arrangements of the exchange's executives to make sure the extent of their pay is disclosed correctly.

title: Music Industry Sues Flea Market Over Sales of CD's
description: As shoppers at the Columbus Farmers' Market browsed through table after table of battery-operated nose-hair trimmers, $10 bras, Spice Girls posters, athletic socks and smoked pigs' ears on Thursday, there were few signs that they were on the front lines of the recording industry's latest effort to discourage music piracy.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the composition of the California voter coalition that made Arnold Schwarzenegger the governor in the recall election misstated the number of votes he won. It was 3,744,132, not 4,358,000.

title: Energy Bill Could Be Stalled Until '04, Senate Aide Says
description: With energy talks in Congress mired, Senate officials warned on Thursday that talks on a national energy plan could go into next year, even as President Bush called for an accord this year.

title: All Even
description: Andy Pettitte survived a shaky start to beat Derek Lowe, 6-2. Nick Johnson's two-run homer woke up New York's offense. The stage is set for an all-Cy Young Game 3 tomorrow in Boston, with Pedro Martnez facing Roger Clemens.

description: HOCKEY

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Lloyds Sells Bank
description: The British banking company, Lloyd's TSB, has agreed to sell its Brazilian operations to another British financial services company, HSBC Holdings, HSBC said. The acquisition includes all the shares of Banco Lloyds TSB SA-Banco Multiplo and its assets and liabilities, and the consumer finance company Losango, which has seven million customers, the bank said. It put the value of the combined assets involved at $2.7 billion. The sale is subject to approval by Brazil's regulators. The sale ends Lloyds TSB's 140-year presence in the Brazilian market, while for HSBC, it means immediate customer growth. HSBC entered Brazil in 1997 and has about 1,500 branches. But it has not grown enough to challenge, Bradesco, Itau and Unibanco, all Brazilian-owned. Michael Geoghegan, above, HSBC Group's general manager for South America, said the purchase brought HSBC's total number of clients worldwide to more than 100 million and fit well with its recent acquisition of American consumer finance company, Household. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Sports Briefing: Baseball; Tejada-Howe Reunion Unlikely
description: The Mets need many things, but with Jos Reyes held in such high regard, a shortstop is not one of them. Still, Miguel Tejada, the Athletics shortstop and the American League's most valuable player in 2002, said this week that he would like to play again for Art Howe, Oakland's former manager now with the Mets.

title: More Agents Are Added To Leak Case
description: As Democrats accused the White House of trying to improperly influence an inquiry into a leak, officials said on Thursday that the F.B.I. was doubling the number of investigators on the politically charged case.

title: Newsstands to Give Way To New Kiosks With Ads
description: After more than a year of negotiations, the City Council moved forward yesterday with a plan to refurbish more than 300 sidewalk newsstands as part of an ambitious campaign to spruce up the city's streetscape.

title: HALLIBURTON SAYS PROFIT FELL SHORT IN QUARTER
description: The Halliburton Company said yesterday that third-quarter profit was less than it had forecast because of rising legal fees and lower-than-expected results from ventures. Profit from continuing operations was at least 27 cents a share, down from a previous estimate of 32 cents, Halliburton said. Analysts had expected profit of 33 cents, based on a survey by Thomson First Call. Halliburton, the oil field services company, is seeking approval for a preliminary settlement of about 425,000 asbestos-related health claims. It assumed liability for some asbestos claims when it bought Dresser Industries for $6.2 billion in stock and assumed debt in 1998. The company said it would report full results for the quarter on Oct. 29.

title: Lessons In Civility
description: It's the season of the angry liberal. Books like Al Franken's ''Lies and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them,'' Joe Conason's ''Big Lies'' and Molly Ivins's ''Bushwhacked'' have become best sellers. (Yes, I've got one out there, too.) But conservatives are distressed because those liberals are so angry and rude. O.K., they admit, they themselves were a bit rude during the Clinton years -- that seven-year, $70 million investigation of a tiny money-losing land deal, all that fuss about the president's private life -- but they're sorry, and now it's time for everyone to be civil.

title: Teaming up from arena to runway
description: PARIS  Not so long ago, designers and sports brands were the oil and water of the fashion business. It was thought that the two would always be headed in opposite directions. That was before the hip-hop crowd started accessorizing sweatpants with diamond stilettos, office workers took laptops home and fashion sport discovered co-branding.

title: Vinyl Tops Endure, Stylish Or Not
description: ON a recent Saturday at Brogan Cadillac-Oldsmobile in Totowa, N.J., shoppers surveyed the latest models and foraged through a free buffet of coffee, fruit and pastries. A big truck had rolled in from Detroit, and under a tent projecting from its side stood displays of the new XLR convertible and the SRX sport wagon, and the high-tech electronics engines in the cars.

title: WALGREEN SAYS CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER IS RETIRING
description: Walgreen said yesterday that its chief financial officer, Roger L. Polark, would retire effective Jan. 14 and be succeeded by William Rudolphsen. Mr. Rudolphsen, 48, is the controller and divisional vice president for accounting, the company said. Mr. Polark, 55, told company executives several years ago that he planned to take early retirement. Mr. Rudolphsen joined Walgreen in 1977 as an accountant. He will be succeeded by Mia Kreis, 37.

title: National Briefing | Washington: What's Being Spoken At Home
description: Nearly one in five Americans say they speak a language other than English at home, the Census Bureau reported. Most of those people say they speak Spanish at home, followed by Chinese, French and German. The number of Americans who say they speak Russian increased the most during the last decade, nearly tripling to more than 700,000. Census officials said the spike in Russian speakers reflected an overall rise in Russian immigration since the fall of the Soviet Union. In 2000, about 18 percent of the population aged 5 and older, or about 47 million people, said they spoke a language other than English at home -- up from 14 percent, or nearly 32 million in 1990.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Is Charged In a 1981 Gangland Killing
description: A former F.B.I. agent who worked with underworld informants here was arrested on Thursday and charged with helping arrange the 1981 gangland-style killing of a wealthy Oklahoma businessman, lawyers and law enforcement officials said.

title: Henry Giordano, 89, Head Of Narcotics Bureau in 60's
description: Henry L. Giordano, a pharmacist who went undercover as a federal drug agent and eventually surfaced to take charge of the Treasury Department's narcotics bureau in the 1960's, died on Sept. 19 in Olney, Md. He was 89 and lived in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Patriots' Cloud Runs for Glory And His Brother
description: As he snaked through the Tennessee Titans' defense last Sunday, New England running back Mike Cloud stiff-armed the negativity of his four-week substance-abuse suspension and shook off the mothballs from an anonymous four-year stay in Kansas City.

title: Artists Who Realized Beauty in the Ordinary
description: No society, not even this city's Beltway political culture, has ever been more obsessed with rank than France in the early 18th century. In its top-down cosmological view, hierarchy equaled harmony. All was right with the world as long as nothing moved, and civilized life was a kind of stately fete, with the king and the court in the V.I.P. lounge and general admission closely policed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILBERT, DR. HARRIET S.
description: GILBERT--Dr. Harriet S. On October 8, 2003 at age 73. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Paul Gilbert. Loving mother of Laura, David and Daniel Gilbert. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Jena, Aidan, Zachary, Olivia and Layla. Interment private. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, October 14th, at 5:00 PM.

title: Abbott Posts 5.7% Quarterly Profit Increase
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP)  A 20 percent surge in sales of prescription drugs and a strong showing from a new rheumatoid arthritis treatment, Humira, helped Abbott Laboratories post a 5.7 percent increase in third-quarter earnings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOR, BENJAMIN
description: DOR--Benjamin. The Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology of Yeshiva University is deeply saddened by the loss of Benjamin Dor, husband of Barbara Ferkauf Dor. Bobby and Benny have supported many initiatives at FGS, including an alumni program and a ''spirituality'' conference. Bobby is the daughter of Eugene and Estelle Ferkauf, whose generosity resulted in the naming of the Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology. Our heartfelt condolences to the beloved children and adored grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman Board of Trustees Katherine Sachs, Chairman FGS Board of Governors

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Retailer Posts Profit
description: Japan's largest retail chain, the Ito-Yokado Company, said yesterday that profits in the first six months of its fiscal year nearly tripled, to 23.2 billion yen ($211 million), helped by strong sales at its 7-Eleven convenience stores. However, Ito-Yokado also trimmed its full-year profit target by 7.7 percent because of slow spending this summer and at stores open more than a year. The company now expects to earn 48 billion yen ($436 million) in the period. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: French Genre Painting
description: Watteau's ''Iris,'' left, is in the National Gallery's new show of French genre painting.

title: Sports of The Times; Cloninger Gives Boston A Touch of New York
description: THE Yankees and the Red Sox seldom mix their baseball bloodlines. Of all the Yankee players in this American League Championship Series, only Roger Clemens has a Red Sox background, but he arrived by way of Toronto. Coach Don Zimmer managed the 1978 Red Sox, who were crushed by Bucky Dent's home run, but he managed the Rangers and the Cubs before joining Joe Torre's staff in 1996.

title: U.S. Team's Ironwoman Nears the End of the Road
description: If she is the oldest member of the United States national team at age 35, Joy Fawcett is also its ironwoman, the only player not to miss a minute of the past three Women's World Cups or both Olympic soccer tournaments.

description: Pope John Paul II emphasized the necessity of celibacy for Roman Catholic priests and, in remarks to visiting bishops from the Philippines, denounced the ''scandalous behavior'' of priests who had broken their vows. The pope was apparently referring to cases of child sexual abuse by priests in the United States and other countries. Although some progressives have cited the dynamics of a celibate culture as one cause for such crimes, John Paul told the bishops that ''celibacy is to be regarded as an integral part of the priest's exterior and interior life.'' Almost half the job cuts will take place this year. Mr. Alierta, who is also cutting 15,000 jobs in Spain, is trying to counter slowing growth in traditional phone services. In Latin America, where Telefonica expanded to tap higher growth prospects than at home.

title: Why America Needs Turkey in Iraq
description: The decision by the Turkish Parliament on Tuesday to dispatch up to 10,000 troops to Iraq is being greeted by many inside and outside the region as more of a problem than a solution. Turkey's peacekeeping area would most likely encompass the volatile Sunni region north of Baghdad, covering such hot spots as Falluja and Ramadi and stretching toward the porous Syrian border. The Turks, who left Iraq with the Arab revolt against the Ottoman Empire in the early 1900's, would curiously find themselves returning to the heart of Arab nationalism -- this time at the request of Washington to counter the anti-American resistance.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Appeals Court Rules Against Genzyme
description: The Genzyme Corporation, a maker of treatments for rare hereditary diseases, lost an appeals court decision in its legal battle with Transkaryotic Therapies over drugs for a rare metabolic disorder. The ruling comes less than a day after the companies said they had agreed to end the dispute. The Federal Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington upheld a ruling that Transkaryotic did not infringe on a patent related to the enzyme replacement therapy for the treatment of Fabry disease. Fabrazyme from Genzyme is the only drug with federal regulatory approval to treat the disease, although Transkaryotic sells a rival product, Replagal, in Europe. Late yesterday, the companies said that they had agreed to end their patent litigation. Genzyme agreed to withdraw the lawsuit over Replagal. In return, Transkaryotic agreed that it would not sue Genzyme for patent infringement over Aldurazyme, Genzyme's treatment for another disorder.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Grows
description: The current account surplus expanded a greater-than-expected 34 percent in August from the same month a year earlier as exports grew sharply. The trade surplus, which makes up three-quarters of the current account, grew 20 percent. The deficit in services also narrowed because of a decline in the number of Japanese traveling overseas.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Four Arrested In Beating
description: Four white men have been arrested in the beating of a retarded black man who was found in a ditch near Linden on Sept. 28. The victim, Billy Ray Johnson, 42, suffered facial and brain injuries and remains in a hospital, where he regained consciousness only this week. The four men are residents of the area, including a Cass County jailer who was fired after he belatedly acknowledged that he was present at a party where Mr. Johnson was attacked. The F.B.I. is trying to determine whether the assault should be designated a hate crime. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Jobless Rate Falls
description: The unemployment rate in Germany fell to 10.5 percent in September, reaching the lowest level since February after smaller declines in the two previous months. In seasonally adjusted terms, the number of jobless dropped by 14,000, to 4.39 million, the Federal Labor Office said. The unexpected decline, combined with recent increases in business and consumer confidence and manufacturing orders, raised hopes for Germany's economic recovery.

title: Bush Vows to Stay Course on Policies

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: O.A.S. Criticism
description: Less than a month before presidential elections, the Organization of American States took the unusual step of directly criticizing last summer's mob violence by supporters of Efran Ros Montt, a former dictator and now a presidential candidate. The group said the July protests that led to the violence were meant to pressure judges who later approved Mr. Ros Montt's candidacy despite a law that bars anyone who took power in a coup from serving as president. It also warned of growing dangers to rights, citing threats against activists, political murders and impotent law-enforcement groups that do not stop organized crime. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Sewage Limits Expanded For Hudson River
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday that a ban the dumping of treated sewage from boats in the Hudson River was being extended to cover 153 waterway miles from Manhattan to Troy. Since 1995, treated discharge has been banned in two zones, measuring approximately 60 miles, that are part of municipal drinking supplies. Supporters of the ban had argued that chemicals used to treat sewage harmed fish and other aquatic life. The extended ban will go into effect immediately, with a one-year exemption for commercial vessels longer than 225 feet or 20 feet in draft, which need to install special holding tanks. Boats may lawfully discharge treated waste at 35 stations spread along the 153-mile ban zone. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Review/Fashion; The Sneaker Plays Dress-Up
description: A lifetime ago, back in the 1980's, when American women marched off to new working lives wearing white Reeboks and broad-shouldered suits, one had to assume that the rest of the world was having a bit of fun at their expense. Pairing sneakers with clothes not meant for tennis made women look ridiculous. It made them look hurried. And what, Europeans must have wondered, was so terrific about looking as if you only had 12 minutes for lunch?

description: The federal No Child Left Behind Act was modeled partly on reforms developed in New York, which jumped to the forefront of the standards movement during the 1990's with a sweeping plan that raised graduation requirements, improved teacher training and instituted annual tests to determine whether students were being taught according to the new standards. The New York experience has been encouraging. But recent glitches in the tests also show that programs setting standards need to be retooled periodically as they go forward.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl Raped In Stairwell
description: A 14-year-old girl was raped at gunpoint yesterday afternoon in Coney Island, the police said. At around 4 p.m., a man followed the victim into a building on Neptune Avenue near West 34th Street, put a gun to her head, dragged her into a stairwell and raped and sodomized her, the police said. The girl was taken to Coney Island Hospital for treatment. The man, described as in his 30's, fled. No arrests have been made. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: National Briefing: South
description: LOUISIANA: SPILL CLOSES HIGHWAY FOR NINE HOURS About 40 miles of one of the state's main highways, Interstate 10, was closed for nine hours between Lafayette and Baton Rouge because of a hazardous chemical leak. A trucker hauling acetic anhydride for the chemical distributor Univar noticed a leak about 2 a.m. while traffic on the highway was stopped for an accident, the police said. The 30-gallon spill was cleaned up by a hazardous-materials team, the state police said. The chemical is a colorless liquid with a strong vinegary odor and can cause burns or death. The highway reopened just after noon. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Lieutenant Governor Named
description: Gov. Joseph E. Kernan, who has led the state since Gov. Frank L. O'Bannon died in September, has chosen Katherine Davis, state controller, as his lieutenant governor. Ms. Davis, 47, previously served as head of the Family and Social Services Administration and as state budget director. She will be the first woman as lieutenant governor in Indiana history when sworn in on Oct. 20. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Court Blocks Appeal On Gay Marriage
description: The Supreme Court rejected a bid by religious and family groups to appeal a provincial court ruling that legalized same-sex marriage in Ontario in June. The conservative groups had hoped to appeal the decision after the federal government chose not to and instead drafted legislation that would legalize same-sex marriage across the country. Gay rights groups called the unanimous ruling a major victory. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Officers Accused Of Dereliction
description: Four police officers assigned to Yankee Stadium were suspended from duty after they were accused of leaving their posts for a poolroom, officials said yesterday. The officers were assigned to watch for scalpers outside the stadium before the Yankees-Red Sox game on Wednesday night. Police investigators were told that several officers repeatedly left the Bronx for the Billiards Cafe on West 181st Street in Washington Heights, an official said. Members of the Bronx investigations Unit put the pool hall under surveillance and found the four officers there, the official said. The officers -- Michael Mulqueen, 40; Michael Kelerchain, 41; Eugene Gagliano, 32; and Edward Arnold, 39 -- face administrative charges for leaving their posts and, if convicted, face the loss of vacation time, officials said. Their lawyer, Stuart London, said the department had overreacted by suspending them. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

DeFeo worked in a studio at 2322 Fillmore Street in San Francisco, where other artists and musicians lived. She was 29 and already somebody among the Beat poets and painters in the Bay Area: smart, gifted, outgoing, pretty, free-spirited, a bright light on the local scene whom everyone recognized as talented, and, not incidentally, a woman who held her own with the guys.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: Talks With Serbia Threatened
description: A United Nations plan to hold talks between Kosovo's ethnic Albanian leaders and the Serbian government were put on hold after the Parliament failed to approve a debate on the talks. The meeting, scheduled for Vienna next week, has been widely seen as a first step toward resolving whether the former Yugoslav province that is now a United Nations protectorate should be given independence from Serbia and Montenegro. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: If It's Sunday It Must be American, but Not Anymore
description: The American Composers Orchestra has presented its series at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoons in recent seasons, but Steven Sloane, the conductor who took over as music director last year, has said he would like the orchestra to have a more flexible schedule. Mr. Sloane opened the orchestra's new season on Wednesday evening. Its next concert is on a Friday in February. The orchestra's regular listeners may follow along in time, unless there is simply a large body of concertgoers who find Sunday afternoons most congenial for contemporary American music and will resist the change. On Wednesday, the audience was surprisingly small -- a pity, since this orchestra still gives polished, energetic performances of its specialized repertory, and it is too important an institution to squander.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ILARDI, FRANCES M. (NEE SALMERI)
description: ILARDI--Frances M. (nee Salmeri), of Bay Shore, LI, formerly of Lake Success, 91, passed on October 9, 2003 following a brief illness. Frances was predeceased by her husband of 60 years, Onofrio Ilardi, MD. She is survived by her sons, Vincent C. of Edgewater, NJ and Carl F. of Bay Shore, LI, and by her granddaughter, Kathryn Ilardi of Edgewater, NJ. She was a 1932 graduate of the Columbia School of Pharmacy. Reposing at the Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Highway (1/4 mile west of the Robert Moses Causeway). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial Monday, 10:00 AM, at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Bay Shore, LI. Interment to follow at Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, LI. Visiting Sunday, 2-7:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made on behalf of Frances to the Lighthouse International, 111 East 59th Street, New York, NY 10022.
