title: A Birthday Party Burnout
description: FUNNY thing about birthday parties: you live for them when you're young and avoid them like SARS when you're an adult. Me, I've never been one to shy away from celebrating creeping mortality; any occasion that lavishes me with gifts is O.K. in my book. No, it's children's birthday parties that I have issues with. Not those of my 5- and 7-year-old girls, mind you, but other kids' parties, mainly because there are so many of them. Whether school is in session or not, there is at least one a weekend, on average, and sometimes two or more during the busy spring months.

title: Hard Sell On Iraq
description: The United States has tried again and again to get help from the United Nations as a way of legitimizing its tragic misadventure in Iraq. But the U.N., which was founded in 1945 to foster international cooperation as a way of promoting peace, is following the quiet guidance of its secretary general, Kofi Annan, whose response to the latest U.S. entreaty has been a polite but firm no.

title: A Lawyer's Good Teeth Help in Court and Love
description: Between a lethargic trailer propped up by ''Gimme Some Lovin' '' and the mainstream-sentimentalist producer Brian (''A Beautiful Mind'') Grazer's name on the credits, there's plenty of reason for an involuntary recoil toward the Coen Brothers' fearsomely titled new movie, ''Intolerable Cruelty.'' But the film is not shudder-worthy. Instead, it's something not seen in movie theaters for a long time: an intelligent, modern screwball comedy, a minor classic on the order of competent, fast-talking curve balls about deception and greed like Mitchell Leisen's ''Easy Living'' and Billy Wilder's ''Major and the Minor.''

title: Silent Martinez, Spirited Red Sox: A Different Kind of Team

title: The U.N.'s Better Idea on Iraq
description: The Bush administration is having a frustrating time at the United Nations again. After all these months, the world's senior diplomats are still not willing to perform from Washington's script. When Secretary of State Colin Powell circulates a Security Council resolution, he wants other countries to endorse its main provisions, and to understand that the White House allows him to negotiate only over secondary details, not matters of substance. In the administration's oddly inverted logic, when this does not happen, as is now the case, it is the U.N. that is failing the test of multilateralism by not rallying around America's nonnegotiable positions. As a senior administration official put it to The Times this week, ''They can be multilateral and be part of it, or they can tell us to do it ourselves.''

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: TOXIC WASTE BILL BECOMES LAW /> Gov. George E. Pataki signed a bill into law yesterday that replenishes financing for the state's program to clean up toxic waste sites and creates new incentives for developers to build on defunct industrial sites. The signing follows two years in which the Legislature and the governor appropriated no new funds for the Superfund program because they could not agree on cleanup guidelines. The legislation provides $120 million a year to clean up the state's 800 polluted sites still awaiting action, as well as $15 million a year to start a program to encourage the development of defunct industrial sites. The money would come from a combination of bond sales and fees on industry. The new law establishes tax credits and relief from liability for pollution to urge developers to take on projects in blighted areas. In addition, the new law alters cleanup standards for some old industrial sites to take into account the future use of the land, rather than holding developers to a pristine standard. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Madison, Wis.
description: ON an isthmus sandwiched by Lakes Mendota and Monona, Madison, the capital of Wisconsin, is a progressive university town noted for the good life: sailing, paddling and windsurfing in the summer; cross-country skiing, hiking and ice-skating in the winter (which can be so cold, in fact, that bundled-up Madisonians take on a unisex look); good old Midwestern values all year-round. In 1948, Life magazine featured Madison as its pick for the best place to live in America; thankfully, not much has changed. It's the kind of place where you will find well-maintained (and well-used) bike paths, an abundance of locally grown organic food at the weekend farmers' market and bed-and-breakfasts with ecological and historical awareness. But don't let Madison's fresh-scrubbed face fool you -- its radical 1960's past may have mellowed into more of a fervor for football, but it is all balanced with a sophisticated cultural life comparable to that of a much larger city. Frank Lloyd Wright buildings dot the landscape, and thriving theater and arts communities can be found on and off campus, along with a competitive culinary scene and a diverse population that includes punk-rock students and die-hard conservatives. What could be finer? BONNIE TSUI

title: Oui, Art Tips From Perfidious Albion
description: It is almost de rigueur that definitions of Romanticism start with the claim that it is inherently indefinable. Its followers fervently cleaved to the principle of individual freedom unleashed by the French Revolution, which by extension redefined art as personal expression and perpetual rebellion against accepted norms. Some of Romanticism's most prominent practitioners, Delacroix among them, denounced the movement all together. It was always more an attitude than a coherent style: some of its broadly common characteristics included spurning neo-Classical standards and practices, embracing ordinary reality, contemporary events and nature in all forms, and employing assertive, emotionally charged brush strokes. But even these attributes break down under closer scrutiny.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERKIN, RICHARD TALMAGE
description: PERKIN--Richard Talmage. Of New York City, on October 9, 2003. Age 72. Loving husband of Leslie Manning Bergesch, devoted father of Kristina, Nicolas and Caroline, and proud grandfather of Olympia Talmage Davison. Born on July 13, 1931, Mr. Perkin was the son of the late Richard Scott Perkin, a founder of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, and the late Gladys Frelinghuysen Talmage Perkin. He was a descendant of Captain Thomas Talmage, a founder of East Hampton in 1648, and Philip Rhinelander, an 18th century New York merchant. A graduate of Milton Academy (1950) and Harvard University (1954), where he was a member of the Spee Club, Mr. Perkin was chairman of the VZV Research Foundation, which he founded in 1991. The New Yorkbased foundation is the world's only nonprofit organization solely fostering research and education on infections caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), including chickenpox, shingles and post-herpetic neuralgia. Mr. Perkin was also chairman of The Perkin Fund, a family foundation that supports scientific research and the arts. He was a trustee of The Juilliard School and the Wildlife Conservation Society, and a member of the Executive Committee of the Rockefeller University Council. He also served on the New York Weill Cornell Council of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, the Visiting Committee of Harvard University's Department of Astronomy and the Committee for Planetarium Policy at the American Museum of Natural History. Prior to devoting his life to furthering scientific research and education on VZV, Mr. Perkin was active in public media, including television documentary syndication. In addition to his wife, children and granddaughter, Mr. Perkin is survived by a brother, Robert S. of Darien, CT, and a sister, Winifred Perkin Gray of Wenham, MA. Another brother, John Thorne, died in 1997. A memorial service will be held at St. Thomas Church, 1 West 53 Street, New York City, at 3:00 P.M. on Wednesday, October 15, 2003. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Mr. Perkin's memory may be sent to the VZV Research Foundation, Inc., 40 East 72 Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2 Accused In Insurance Fraud
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn charged a Williamsburg clothing manufacturer yesterday with a multimillion-dollar insurance fraud that they said involved filing inflated claims after five fires at his businesses between 1987 and 1999. The manufacturer, Nat Schlesinger, 65, was also charged with arson for a fire in 1998 at one of his companies, Goodmark Industries. A lawyer for Mr. Schlesinger, however, said the 1998 fire had been ruled unsuspicious. Also charged with insurance fraud was a Goodmark officer, Herman Niederman, 51. Both men pleaded not guilty. William Glaberson (NYT)

description: Western diplomats joined the Afghan interior minister and senior military officials on Thursday to try to halt some of the worst fighting the country has seen in almost two years.

title: Barclays Shuffles Managers and Names Its Next Chief
description: The British bank Barclays shuffled its top management on Thursday, and named a finance officer to be chief executive, ending almost two years of speculation about who would fill the role.

title: Corrections

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ethiopia: Demarcation To Go Ahead
description: The United Nations intends to go forward with the demarcation of the disputed border between Ethiopia and Eritrea despite reservations by Ethiopian officials about the line recommended by an independent border commission. The countries signed a peace deal in 2000, ending a two-year war that began when both nations claimed the remote town of Badme. The commission said Badme was on the Eritrean side, infuriating officials in Ethiopia. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Toms River: Ex-Officer Pleads Guilty In Killings
description: A retired Newark police officer, John W. Mabie, pleaded guilty yesterday to murdering his granddaughter and three neighbors in a house-to-house shooting rampage in February 2002. In an interview outside the court yesterday, Mr. Mabie's lawyer, John Furlong, said that his client had abandoned his defense of diminished capacity because of ''gut-wrenching'' appeals from members of his family to spare them the anguish of a trial. Mr. Furlong said that psychiatric experts for both the defense and prosecution had found that Mr. Mabie, now 72, had suffered from ''acute delusional disorder'' for years and was convinced that neighbors, family members and former co-workers wanted to kill him. A hearing is set for Nov. 21, and under a plea agreement with the Ocean County prosecutor's office, Mr. Mabie faces a 30-year prison term, with no possibility for parole until the full sentence is served. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Shelter Island Surprise Is Likely an Indian Grave
description: The who and why remain a mystery, but what is known for certain is that the skeletal remains of at least five people, most likely American Indians buried in a communal grave more than a century ago, were uncovered this week by a homeowner here.

title: Witness Testifies Tyco Board Objected to $20 Million Fee
description: The former chief executive of Tyco International, John F. Fort, told a jury yesterday that his successor, L. Dennis Kozlowski, lost the support of the company's board after the disclosure of a $20 million payment to another director.

title: Construction Was Spotted at Syrian Camp Hit by Israel
description: The Syrian target that Israeli warplanes struck last weekend had been the site of recent construction, possibly to prepare it for use by the Palestinian militant group Islamic Jihad, senior American officials briefed on intelligence reports said Thursday.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Bugging Philadelphia's Mayor
description: The nip-and-tuck mayoral campaign in Philadelphia has suddenly become a cloak-and-dagger affair with the discovery of federal eavesdropping devices hidden in the office of Mayor John Street, the Democrat running for a second term. ''I would like to know what's up,'' the mayor said angrily after the police found the bugs in the ceiling above his desk, only weeks from the election.

title: Hip-hop on a roll
description: LONDON  Fashion just can't help being dazzled by the not-so-discreet charms of hip-hop's "bling-bling ka-ching" culture. John Galliano won't produce a Dior collection without a little ghetto in the mix while Dolce & Gabbana routinely samples the urban music scene for its D&G label. The bombastic swagger of rap style oozes cool and everyone from Versace to Gap wants a piece of the action.

title: Orchestra for Hire: No Strings Attached
description: How should we feel about the New York Philharmonic and its botched grab for imperial glory? As everyone now knows, the orchestra's plan to merge with Carnegie Hall collapsed this week. The problem, it seems, was that Sanford Weill, the fabled deal-maker who assembled Citigroup and chairs Carnegie Hall, overlooked a small detail: artists are not investment bankers. Their goal is not to maximize income, and in fact the converse is true -- honoring their priorities requires financial sacrifice. Mr. Weill wooed the Philharmonic away from Lincoln Center only to decide that he does not love it enough to give it exclusivity and cancel dates with the world-class orchestras that have been parading through his hall for years.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: INSURER REVERSES PLAN TO DROP CUSTOMERS State Farm Indemnity, profitable again in New Jersey after three years of losing money, has reversed for now its plan to drop insurance coverage for 4,000 New Jersey drivers per month. The decision applies to drivers who would have been randomly selected for "nonrenewal" starting Dec. 1, said Ryan Salonia, a company spokesman. But State Farm Indeminity may still leave the state completely in 2005, as it had announced, depending on its profitability. The policy of dropping customers has been in effect since September 2002. Since that time, about 48,000 customers have received notice that their coverage would be dropped. Gov. James E. McGreevey, above, appeared with company officials and told reporters that State Farm's decision showed his insurance reforms were working. Jessica Bruder (NYT)

title: NEWSPRINT MAKER REPORTS WIDER QUARTERLY LOSS
description: Bowater Inc., the newsprint maker, said yesterday that it would report a wider third-quarter net loss because of higher-than-expected costs at a South Carolina mill. The net loss was 80 to 90 cents a share, Bowater said. The company, based in Greenville, S.C., had a net loss of 57 cents a share a year earlier. It will report final results later this month. Gains from price increases for newsprint, coated paper and lumber were lessened by costs to convert a mill in Catawba, S.C., from making newsprint to a more expensive paper used in magazines. Bowater has been trying to trim its dependence on newsprint amid a two-year slump in newspaper advertising.

The purchase includes OrthoLogic's SpinaLogic, an instrument to aid healing after spinal-fusion surgery, DJ Orthopedics said. DJ Orthopedics is also buying OrthoLogic's products for fractures that do not heal properly.

title: U.S. Set to Review Use of Silicone Gel In Breast Implants
description: For the first time in 11 years, women in the United States may be on the verge of gaining unrestricted access to silicone breast implants. Women who blame implants for chronic medical problems are fighting to keep them off the market, while plastic surgeons are expecting brisk demand.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Toxic Waste Bill Becomes Law
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed a bill into law yesterday that replenishes financing for the state's program to clean up toxic waste sites and creates new incentives for developers to build on defunct industrial sites. The signing follows two years in which the Legislature and the governor appropriated no new funds for the Superfund program because they could not agree on cleanup guidelines. The legislation provides $120 million a year to clean up the state's 800 polluted sites still awaiting action, as well as $15 million a year to start a program to encourage the development of defunct industrial sites. The money would come from a combination of bond sales and fees on industry. The new law establishes tax credits and relief from liability for pollution to urge developers to take on projects in blighted areas. In addition, the new law alters cleanup standards for some old industrial sites to take into account the future use of the land, rather than holding developers to a pristine standard.

It was through drawing -- especially drawing nudes -- that artists learned how to fine-tune their visual perceptions and mirror truthfully with handmade marks the mercurial vagaries of psychological experience. It was the foundation that no career in painting or sculpture could be securely built without.

''I wanted them to see the most dramatic color,'' she said. ''I thought using the Web I'd be guaranteed accurate information about where and when to go.''

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobless Rate Steady
description: Reinforcing recent evidence of an upturn in the Canadian economy, Statistics Canada estimated that 46,000 new jobs were created in September. The unemployment rate was unchanged at 8 percent. Manufacturing bucked the trend, bringing job losses in the sector to more than 100,000 since last November. The employment data was stronger than most analysts had expected, causing a surge in the Canadian dollar and buttressing a widely held view that the Bank of Canada will hold its trend-setting interest rate at 2.75 percent at its next monetary policy review on Wednesday. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: F.T.C. REQUESTS INFORMATION ON ADVANCEPCS DEAL
description: Caremark RX Inc. said federal antitrust enforcers requested more information about its proposed $5.6 billion takeover of AdvancePCS, signaling that the combination will get close scrutiny by the government. Caremark, which would become the No. 2 pharmacy-benefit manager behind Medco Health Solutions Inc. after the acquisition, said in a joint statement with AdvancePCS that the companies received a request for additional information from the Federal Trade Commission. The F.T.C. had until yesterday to seek more information and open a full investigation or to allow the transaction to proceed. Caremark said Wednesday that Florida and other states were also reviewing the transaction.

description: ''Now I know why they call this 'Isla de la Muerte,' '' says the grizzled fishing boat captain (Jrgen Prochnow), as he stands looking out over a landscape of corpses. Among the bodies are innocent victims -- nubile teenagers lured to this unpromisingly named island off the coast of Seattle for a rave party -- and quite a few moldering carcasses belonging to the zombies who form the island's principal population.

title: FASHION / A SPECIAL REPORT: 'Vive Chanel!' Even the models cheer a whiff of Coco
description: The energetic and excellent collection that Karl Lagerfeld sent out Friday for Chanel bore the imprint of a master. From the first moment that a duo of models sauntered down the wooden boardwalk, as if on a brief encounter on a Paris street, the show took off. And not least because it showed the designer's lacy, airy, flowery clothes refreshing that old Coco magic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ISTOMIN, EUGENE
description: ISTOMIN--Eugene. Manhattan School of Music mourns with profound sorrow the passing of Eugene Istomin, esteemed pianist and humanitarian, dear friend and longtime faculty member, and beloved husband of our president, Marta Casals Istomin. For more than 50 years, Mr. Istomin was an inspiration to concertgoers worldwide through his extraordinary performances in recitals, chamber music concerts and as an orchestral soloist. A mentor to generations of pianists and chamber musicians, support, encouragement and incomparable musical knowledge will be missed. Mr. Istomin's unprecedented artistry benefited from his extensive intellectual pursuits. A great lover of the written word, he read widely on a broad range of subjects including history, politics, literature, poetry and the visual arts. For these pursuits he maintained an extensive library in his home and enjoyed sharing his books and his observations with his friends and students. A passionate American, he shared his musical gifts across the country, touring in his famous piano van. His love of baseball was confirmed when his beloved Detroit Tigers made him an honorary team member. On November 26, 2000, Manhattan School of Music was honored to celebrate his 75th birthday with a special concert and dinner creating the endowed Eugene Istomin Scholarship for Piano. The entire Manhattan School of Music family -- Board of Trustees, faculty, staff and students--extend our most heartfelt sympathies to Mrs. Istomin and her family. We will always be grateful for his music, teaching, and warm friendship, all enduring legacies that will continue to enrich us. David A. Rahm, Chairman Bella Linden, Vice Chairman Board of Trustees

title: The Real Face of Indonesian Islam
description: A year ago tomorrow, Islamic terrorists blew up two crowded nightclubs on the Indonesian island of Bali, killing 202 people. Last August, a bombing suspected to have been organized by the Indonesian group Jemaah Islamiyah killed 12 people at the J. W. Marriott Hotel in Jakarta. Surely, with attacks like these, politically militant Islam is on the rise in Indonesia?

title: Travel by the Book

That trip shaped a view Ive maintained ever since: hardly anything is more worthwhile than going to a place youve never been. And, a corollary: occasional discomfort is a fair trade-off for discovery.

title: In Chicago
description: Chicago is one of the world's great cities, sure of itself and in better shape than it has been for generations. Many old-timers attribute its revival to Mayor Richard M. Daley, who has been in office since 1989 and is routinely referred to as "mayor for life." Detractors complain about his bare-knuckle tactics, but admirers say his record is an argument for the benevolent-dictator form of government.

Since February, four books have dragged the daily, and particularly its ruling triumvirate, through the mud. And to make things worse, much of the rest of the French press has been enjoying the spectacle.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Output Rises
description: India's industrial production rose 5.2 percent in August, helped by consmer spending, but declined from the rate a month earlier and a year earlier as a strong rupee pared exports, the government said. In a monthly report, the government said consumer spending on durable products like televisions and refrigerators rose 3.9 percent, and on nondurable products, like soaps and shampoos, rose 8.6 percent. Analysts said the peak spending period of the year is approaching and retail demand should bolster the manufacturing sector. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: LA-Z-BOY SAYS PROFIT WILL DROP BY ALMOST HALF
description: La-Z-Boy Inc., the furniture maker, said fiscal second-quarter profit will drop by almost half because of declining sales and increased discounting. Profit will be 26 cents to 29 cents a share in the quarter ending Oct. 25, the company said. It forecast profit of as much as 43 cents in August; in the 2002 period, it earned 50 cents. Sales will fall as much as 9 percent as increased promotions failed to spur demand. Profit will also be hurt by the previously announced closing of three manufacturing plants. Stock in La-Z-Boy, which is based in Monroe, Mich., fell $3.07, to $19.98.

The claim had already been rejected by a lower court and the Court of Appeal, and the case is now closed.

description: Rye and Harrison, high schools in Westchester County that have been playing each other since 1929, will meet today in a battle of unbeaten teams for the fifth time in their storied history.

title: Secrets Of the Scandal
description: Like any good spy story, the outing of Valerie Plame Wilson is far more complex than it seems on the surface.

title: Tapestry of a Family and Its Home State
description: To describe Ross McElwee's documentary film ''Bright Leaves'' as a study of the tobacco industry in his native state of North Carolina would be a little like calling a Virginia Woolf novel a manual of etiquette. By the end of this reflective, wise, often hilarious movie, you feel as though he has slapped a huge chunk of raw, palpitating life onto the screen.

title: Rikers Officer Charged With Raping Inmate
description: A New York City correction officer was indicted on Thursday on charges that he raped a female inmate on Rikers Island and then altered a jail logbook to conceal the assault, said the Bronx district attorney, Robert T. Johnson.

title: Lottery Numbers
Inside Pitching, the Cowboy Way
description: Driving to Boston yesterday, the electronic traffic signs on the Mass Pike said nothing about construction or congestion. "GO RED SOX," they said, before flashing to a new screen. "COWBOY UP," the second screen said.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN TO MAKE COMPONENTS FOR FORD FUTURA
description: The Collins & Aikman Corporation said it was selected by Ford Motor to provide interior systems for the Futura sedan. Collins & Aikman will be responsible for designing and making instrument panels, front- and rear-door panels and other interior components, the company said. Revenue from the contract ''will exceed several billion dollars over the life of the program,'' a spokesman, David Youngman, said. Ford will start producing the Futura, which will be its primary midsize car, in 2005. Stock in Collins & Aikman, which is based in Troy, Mich., rose 34 cents, or 12 percent, to $3.09 a share.

title: CREE SAYS FORMER CHIEF EXECUTIVE DROPS FRAUD CLAIMS
description: Cree Inc., which makes semiconductors that light up cellphones and dashboards, said its former chief executive, Eric Hunter, dropped securities fraud claims against the company and the chairman, Neal Hunter, his brother. The claims, filed in federal court in Greensboro, N.C., were dropped Thursday night, Cree said. Eric Hunter and his wife, Jocelyn, filed the suit in June seeking $3 billion in damages. The complaint claimed Cree defrauded shareholders from 1995 to 2003, inflated operating income, misled auditors and made false statements related to share sales. A committee of Cree directors found no truth to the claims, Cree said. Eric Hunter did not drop all claims, Cree said. In June, he also filed a $200 million defamation claim and a $1 million claim charging that Cree violated the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RESNICK, IRVING
description: RESNICK--Irving. The members of Shelter Rock Tennis Club record with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Irving Resnick. He was a friend to all and will be sorely missed. Our sincere condolences to his wife and to his entire family.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: SOFTWARE PROFIT RISES The software exporter Infosys Technologies reported a 33 percent increase in its quarterly earnings, aided by increased outsourcing by global corporations. The company raised its full-year earnings forecast by 6 percent from an estimate announced in July. Infosys, a bellwether for the country's flourishing software industry, said its revenue would top $1 billion this year. The company reported a profit of 3 billion rupees ($66.3 million) up from 2.3 billion rupees ($49.9 million) a year earlier. The results beat market expectations but Infosys said recent gains in the rupee, India's currency, might affect profit margins in the future.

title: Try It, It's Good for You
description: FOR parents like mine, who were born in Europe and live in the United States, it's a dream to be able to take one's children to see the Continent. Inspire their young minds with the elegance of Paris and the faded glory of Vienna, the lyricism of the opera and, when they are old enough, the earthier pleasures of French wine.

title: Baker Says He Had Nothing Against Mets
description: MIAMI, Oct. 10  Before Dusty Baker turned around the Chicago Cubs, he guided the San Francisco Giants to the World Series last year.

title: In Tokyo, More Steps Toward Fixing the Economy
description: Japan announced some steps to address several of its economic and financial problems on Friday when the Bank of Japan agreed to pump more money into the economy and one of the country's largest banks, under pressure from regulators, disclosed the full extent of its bad-loan problems.

description: To the Editor:

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 326 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Republicans Debate Merits of Following Schwarzenegger to the Center
description: In Arnold Schwarzenegger, the national Republican Party now has a magnetic movie star in charge of the most populous state in the union, a governor-elect who has already emerged as an articulate, media-savvy and earnest figure who does not play by the conventional rules of politics.

description: To the Editor:

description: BASEBALL

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINER, ELIZABETH (BETTY) GUGGENHEIMER
description: STEINER--Elizabeth (Betty) Guggenheimer, of Great Neck, NY on October 9, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Malcolm Steiner, mother of the late Susan (Betty) Steiner. Survived by her loving son Lawrence and daughter-inlaw Nanci, and grandchildren Jennifer and Jeffrey. The family will be at home Friday, following a private memorial service. Contributions may be made to the Service Guild of Long Island Jewish Medical Center.

title: Making Art Young
description: CHILDREN may be natural artists, but they are not always natural art lovers. Travelers often want to make an art museum one of their first stops in a new city, only to see their children yawn at Impressionist landscapes or declare, after a bored glance at an abstract canvas, that they can paint better. But museums know that young visitors can become passionate about art. It's all a question of relating the work to the children's experience, and many institutions nationwide have programs that do exactly that.

title: Stoops Wins Games and Influences Oklahoma Fans
description: They appear together on a Technicolor mural in the Kerr-McGee Stadium Club and leap lifelike from portraits hung reverently in the Legends' Lobby. Of the 21 coaches who have led Oklahoma on the football field, three of them comprise the Sooners' holy trinity.

title: Diagnosis Goes Low Tech
description: Endoscopy. Sigmoidoscopy. Electromyography. M.R.I. These days, the main interaction between doctor and patient is often technological, with doctors relying on complex diagnostic tests that make use of the latest advances in medicine.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about a hotel owner's accusations of mismanagement by Marriott International misstated the forum in which they were made. It was a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing, not a lawsuit.

title: Beliefs; For a frail Pope John Paul II, a Nobel Peace Prize this year would have been deserved and timely.
description: The Nobel Peace Prize is not awarded posthumously. That is why, with all respect to Shirin Ebadi, the inspiring Iranian defender of women's rights, the failure to give it to Pope John Paul II this year may eventually reflect badly not on the pope but on the prize.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about relief among smaller classical music groups that play at Carnegie Hall over the collapse of its merger talks with the New York Philharmonic misstated the title of John Schaefer of WNYC radio, who commented on the hall's cachet. He is host of the ''Soundcheck'' and ''New Sounds'' programs, not the station's executive director.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the F.B.I.'s decision to double the number of agents investigating the disclosure of an undercover C.I.A. officer's name misidentified the state represented by Senator Joseph R. Biden, who wrote to President Bush to criticize the White House's handling of the case. He is from Delaware, not Maryland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISELBERG, CECELIA (NEE NADDELMAN)
description: WEISELBERG--Cecelia (nee Naddelman). On October 10, 2003, of Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved wife of Dr. Martin. Beloved mother of Ted and Christine, and Alan and Joanne. Loving grandmother of Ali, Tara, Dara and Mark, Scott and Danielle, and Jennifer. Cherished great grandmother of Brandon, Jake, Andrew, Jonathan and Brett. Service Sunday 10 AM, GuttermanMusicant, Hackensack, NJ. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to Hospice at Englewood Hospital. Information: 1-800-522-0588

title: Navarre Brings Michigan All the Way Back
description: Trailing by three touchdowns after three quarters, the Michigan Wolverines seemed certain to sustain a third defeat, which would have left their season in shambles. They were in a hostile Metrodome and they appeared to be unraveling against the undefeated Minnesota Golden Gophers, who were about to change the look of the Big Ten in a big way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PLACA, ROSE
description: PLACA--Rose. Of Clifton Park, NY formerly of Farmindale, NY. Died peacefully at the age of 81 on Friday, October 10, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Adolph who died in 1979. She is survived by her son, Monsignor Alan Placa and her daughter Adeline Burkitt and her husband Raymond. Cherished grandmother of Heather Shea and Raymond Burkitt and great grandmother of four. Reposing on Sunday and Monday, October 12th and 13th from 25 PM and 7-9:30 PM at The McCourt and Trudden Funeral Home Inc, 385 Main St, Farmingdale, NY. Mass of Christian burial, Tuesday, October 14, 11:00 AM at St. Kilian RC Church, Farmingdale. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, East Farmingdale.

title: Officials Due $133 Million At Big Board
description: Two months after disclosing that its chairman was owed nearly $200 million, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that its other top executives were due $133 million in retirement payments.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Representative David E. Dreier and his new job leading the transition team for Gov.-elect Arnold Schwarzenegger in California misstated the party affiliation of Representative Thomas M. Reynolds of New York, who called Mr. Dreier "a consummate student of government and politics." He is a Republican.

title: Cheney Lashes Out at Critics of Policy on Iraq
description: Vice President Dick Cheney lashed out on Friday at critics of the Bush administration's Iraq policy, ridiculing their arguments against the war as nave and dangerous in a speech that was a culmination of a campaign by the White House to regain support for the postwar effort.

title: In Two Brothers' Lives, a Portrait of Italy
description: One subject of ''The Best of Youth,'' a six-hour film that will be shown in two parts tomorrow at the 41st New York Film Festival, is the transformation of Italy into a modern consumer society. In the montage of newspaper images that introduces Part 1, the major symbol of this change is television, and one of the first things we see as the story begins is a boxy old set being hauled up the stairs of a Rome apartment building.

title: INTERPOOL SAYS S.E.C. IS INVESTIGATING RESTATEMENTS
description: Interpool Inc., which leases cargo containers, said that the Securities and Exchange Commission had opened an investigation into the company's restatement of results, and that its chief operating officer had resigned. Raoul J. Witteveen quit as president and chief operating officer after an internal investigation found he authorized transactions that would have improperly increased profits, Interpool said. Interpool may seek waivers from lenders if it cannot file restated results by Oct. 31. The company said in March that it would restate results for three years after finding errors in its accounting for leases that were audited by Arthur Andersen.

title: In Game of Comebacks, Cubs Get Last One
description: Kerry Wood's postseason infallibility ended Friday night at the hands of the Florida Marlins comeback machine. But the Marlins ran out of rallies, and the Cubs took another step toward their first World Series appearance since 1945.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: ELECTION CALLED Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi called a general election for Nov. 9 after dissolving the lower house of Parliament. He had been expected to make such a move, especially after his overwhelming victory last month as leader of the Liberal Democratic Party. The party, which now governs in a coalition with two other parties, will face the Democratic Party, which recently merged with the Liberal Party. Campaigning for the 480 seats in the lower house, which is entrusted with selecting the prime minister, will start on Oct. 28.    Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: A Prize, Laureate Says, 'Good for Democracy'
description: As a judge in Iran before the revolution of 1979, Shirin Ebadi stayed away from politics.

title: Giants Have Become Wary of Deceptive Plays
description: As a rule, the Giants like their defensive players fast and relentless. The coaches value aggression. A good pass rush is a must.

title: 3 Plead Guilty in Inquiry Into Fatal College Hazing
description: Three of the 11 young men charged in a fatal hazing at the State University of New York at Plattsburgh have pleaded guilty and have agreed to cooperate in the prosecution of the others, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Medicare Drug Bills Assailed by Clinton
description: The bills in Congress to add prescription drug coverage to Medicare would actually raise costs for millions of New Yorkers and result in poorer coverage for many of them, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said on Friday.

title: 3 Families, 3 Strategies: Paris
description: Here's a combination of the Divide and Conquer and Quick Hit strategies to get a peek in the Louvre. I knew it would be impossible to see Italian Renaissance paintings there with our 5-year-old, True, in tow, but with my 8-year-old, Sky, it was possible. The draw? Leonardo da Vinci's "Mona Lisa," of course, as familiar to a third grader as Pikachu or Darth Maul.

title: Lack of Teachers, Lack of Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Revisiting McNamara and the War He Headed
description: If there's one movie that ought to be studied by military and civilian leaders around the world at this treacherous historical moment, it is ''The Fog of War,'' Errol Morris's sober, beautifully edited documentary portrait of the former United States defense secretary, Robert S. McNamara. Mr. McNamara, who was 85 when the interviews that make up the bulk of the film were conducted two years ago, served under Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson from 1961 to early 1968. He has been widely vilified as a major architect of the Vietnam War, which cost more than 58,000 American lives and, according to Mr. McNamara, the lives of 3.4 million Vietnamese.

title: AIDS Patients in Zambia Face Stark Choices
description: Clad in capri jeans, her shoulder-length hair in cornrows, Kabaso Kasango is just 10 years old and in the fourth grade. But she knows the telltale signs of AIDS, and she worries deeply that she is infected.

title: Sports of The Times; Perhaps the Sox Try Too Hard
description: THERE is a rising hue and cry across the nation -- outside New York, that is -- for a World Series between two of baseball's most cursed franchises: the Cubs and the Red Sox.

title: Carolyn Heilbrun, Pioneering Feminist Scholar, Dies at 77
description: Carolyn G. Heilbrun, a retired Columbia University literary scholar whose extensive writings included pioneering books and essays in the feminist canon and a dozen highly erudite detective novels under the pseudonym Amanda Cross, died at her home in Manhattan on Thursday. She was 77.

title: Iranian Lawyer, Staunch Fighter For Human Rights, Wins Nobel
description: Shirin Ebadi, an Iranian lawyer little known outside her country, became the first Muslim woman to win the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday, recognition for her work promoting the rights of women and children in Iran.

title: Birkenstock Stereotype
description: To the Editor:

title: Bigger Than The Nobel
description: I can't imagine he cares, but Pope John Paul II, who has had a more profound influence on more people than any other living human being, is never going to win the Nobel Peace Prize. For years, prize watchers have felt that the Norwegian committee would have no choice but to give him the award, even if he does have unfashionable views on abortion. And this, oddsmakers predicted, was his year. His health is fragile, and his fervent opposition to the war in Iraq would have pleased the impeccably liberal committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALPERN, JOHN S.
description: HALPERN--John S. Of New York City died October 8th after a brave and valiant battle. Husband to Kate, father to Duncan, Alison and Cynthia, grandfather to Hope and Eva, friend to many. He will be missed greatly for among other things, his humor, wisdom and passion. In lieu of flowers please make donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Fly swiftly John. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, Monday, October 13 at 3:30.

title: Ex-Chaplain With Detainees Is Charged
description: A former Muslim chaplain at the American prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, has been charged with disobeying orders by taking classified materials home, the military said on Friday.

title: Babes on Broadway
description: LATELY a small but growing number of those clutching Playbills and filing into the red plush seats on Broadway have been 18 or younger. About half of them are visitors to New York. My daughters, New Yorkers, were among that carefully counted young demographic most recently on a visit to the Shubert Theater, shepherding their out-of-town grandparents (along with their father and me) into mezzanine seats for a matinee performance of "Gypsy."

title: It's a Ballgame, a Mind Game, in 0-for-85 Boston
description: Jay Pinkham, a salesman from Nashua, N.H., has a two-inch tattoo of two red socks, the logo of his star-crossed baseball team, on his right calf. In his heart is something even more indelible: an emotional bond to the team and its community of fans, who have loved and lost, and loved again -- and lost again -- every single summer, and the occasional fall, for 85 years.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: AIRLINE TO CUT JOBS Europe's third-biggest airline, Lufthansa, plans to cut 2,000 jobs over the next few years, the company said. About 1,000 jobs will probably be dropped from the catering unit LSG Sky Chefs, while other divisions affected include flight clearance as well as cargo and buildings management. Lufthansa, which is based in Cologne, Germany, said it intended to avoid layoffs.

title: U.S. STEEL TO REPORT HIGHER EXPENSES
description: The U.S. Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would report as much as $700 million in third-quarter pretax expenses, mostly for retirement costs and severance payments that were higher than it expected. About $620 million of that amount covers costs to cut jobs and pay benefits to early retirees, U.S. Steel said. The company is eliminating 20 percent of its work force, including management posts, after its purchase in May of the National Steel Corporation's assets. U.S. Steel said in August that it would have $500 million in pretax charges in the second half, most in the third quarter, for retiree costs. The company, which is based in Pittsburgh, will report third-quarter earnings on Oct. 28.

title: Asking Price of Fame: $12 Million; What Can Beat Location? Hepburn, Hepburn, Hepburn
description: To her fans, she will always be the actress who went from Bryn Mawr to Broadway and then on to Hollywood, where she earned four Oscars for best actress and starred in 43 films. But in her last will and testament, she identified herself simply as ''I, Katharine Hepburn, of Fenwick, Connecticut.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This prize gives me energy to pursue my combat for a better future.''

description: An article yesterday about Representative David E. Dreier and his new job leading the transition team for Gov.-elect Arnold Schwarzenegger in California misstated the party affiliation of Representative Thomas M. Reynolds of New York, who called Mr. Dreier ''a consummate student of government and politics.'' He is a Republican.

title: Democrats In Brooklyn Fear for Image
description: The indictment this week of the Brooklyn Democratic leader, Clarence Norman Jr., has left many Democratic officials in Brooklyn worried about the tarnished image of their party when, they say, they should be working on organizing for the presidential primary next year.

title: Sports of The Times; The Stars Light Up A Gripping Postseason
description: THIS could be the best set of postseason games since baseball went to the triple-tier playoffs in 1995.
