title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILBERT, DR. HARRIET S.
description: GILBERT--Dr. Harriet S. On October 8, 2003 at age 73. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Paul Gilbert. Loving mother of Laura, David and Daniel Gilbert. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Jena, Aidan, Zachary, Olivia and Layla. Interment private. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, October 14th, at 5:00 PM.

title: FASHION / A SPECIAL REPORT: Selfridges discos into Birmingham
description: BIRMINGHAM, England  "One has no great hopes from Birmingham," Jane Austen wrote in "Emma." "I always say there is something direful in the sound."

title: Vincent P. Brennan -- Executive, 84
description: Vincent P. Brennan, a retired executive of Bloomingdale's, died on Oct. 4 at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 84.

title: Doctor Disputes Winners of Nobel in Medicine
description: An inventor who feels he was unfairly excluded has mounted an unusual and vigorous protest against the award this year of the Nobel Prize in Medicine.

title: With the Chips Down, It's Time for the Aces
description: Mel Stottlemyre has probably tutored more elite pitchers than any other coach of his time. Stottlemyre knows how pitchers think, knows what drives them. When one ace opposes another, both pitchers notice.

title: Mutombo Works Out; Knicks Hope It Works
description: Dikembe Mutombo sweated through his first Knicks practice Friday afternoon, energized by the opportunities -- financial and competitive -- the team had offered him.

title: A Board Game Built on Stereotypes Stirs Up Opposition
description: The Monopoly man, with his top hat, cane, mustache, rosy cheeks and bowtie, has a decidedly different look in Ghettopoly, David Chang's new take on the classic game.

title: Eugene Istomin, 77, Pianist Known for German Repertory
description: Eugene Istomin, the American pianist who was as renowned for his chamber music performances as he was for his individualistic, deeply considered solo playing, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 77.

title: Seeking Common Ground on Iraq (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: G.E. Earnings Decline 11%; Key Product Lines Are Sluggish
description: General Electric, still hobbled by high costs and sluggish sales in formerly stellar industrial businesses like power systems, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings were 11 percent lower than those of last year, and that full-year earnings would be $1.55 to $1.57 a share, the lowest range of analysts' estimates.

title: Disclosing Pay Of Executives Often Leads To Raises
description: If, as expected, the latest disclosure of pay packages at the New York Stock Exchange leads to a reduction in compensation there, it may start a trend.

title: Would-be princess 'didn't tell all facts' : Love or duty ? Dutch prince chooses
description: AMSTERDAM:  In any other country on the European Continent this might be a story consigned to the society pages or gossip columns. But the Dutch take their royal marriages seriously, and disclosures that a prince's fiancee once had a relationship with a gangster has been front-page news here for two weeks.

title: PERELMAN COMPANY TO BUY 24% STAKE IN SCIENTIFIC GAMES
description: The billionaire investor Ronald O. Perelman agreed to buy 24 percent of the Scientific Games Corporation, the largest supplier of instant-lottery tickets, for $194 million to become its largest shareholder. Mr. Perelman bought the stake through his investment company, MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings. The company, which is based in New York, is purchasing Series A convertible preferred stock and Series B preferred stock, Scientific Games said. The sale is expected to close by Dec. 5. The investment is the first in the gambling industry for MacAndrews, a spokesman, James Conroy, said. Scientific Games is based in New York.

title: BIZTECH: Telecom 'mood is not so good'
description: Yoshio Utsumi, 61, is secretary general of the International Telecommunication Union, which operates within the UN to help governments and the private sector regulate the communications industry. His term began just as the industry was peaking, and he presided over the last ITU World Telecom conference in 1999. Utsumi also served as director general of the Japanese Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, where his initiative led to Japan's first reform of its telecommunications market. He recently spoke with Victoria Shannon of the International Herald Tribune ahead of the 2003 ITU World Telecom.

title: The Strains of War, Here and There
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Vending Rules Put Sidewalks In a Muddle
description: RETIRED Marine Sgt. William O'Conner, a veteran of combat in Korea and Vietnam, sits most every day in his motorized cart in Times Square, selling handbags in summer and heavy-duty gloves in winter. He also has a stash of umbrellas stored in the milk crate that fits snugly between his weakened legs, just in case it rains.

title: Walter Payton's Son Makes Move at Miami
description: Stay calm. Those words are entrenched in Jarrett Payton's psyche, put there by his legendary father, Walter Payton, the Hall of Fame running back.

title: M&T Bank Posts 42% Profit Increase
description: The M&T Bank Corporation, whose largest shareholder is Berkshire Hathaway, said yesterday that third-quarter profit rose 42 percent, mostly because of its acquisition of Allfirst Financial.

title: Endorsement By Mayor Brings Cries Of Betrayal
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg endorsed the Republican candidate for Speaker Gifford Miller's Council seat yesterday, prompting Democratic council members who voted for the mayor's unpopular tax increase to accuse him of going back on his word to support them in next month's election.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHEVYS INC., Emeryville, Calif., operator of Chevys Fresh Mex and Rio Bravo restaurants, said it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and planned to reorganize its business.

title: Typical Greenpeace Protest Leads to an Unusual Prosecution
description: Three miles off the Florida coast in April of 2002, two Greenpeace activists clambered from an inflatable rubber speedboat onto a cargo ship. They were detained before they could unfurl a banner, spent the weekend in custody and two months later were sentenced to time served for boarding the ship without permission.

title: Democrats Promote Themselves to N.A.A.C.P.
description: With the South Carolina primary widely viewed as an early barometer of Southern and black support, Democratic presidential hopefuls used a forum here on Friday to promote their views on civil rights, as well as the economy and Iraq war, to the South Carolina N.A.A.C.P. convention.

title: After a Fast Start, the Bills Are Singing a Different Tune
description: In the glory days of the early 1990's, when Buffalo had a standing reservation for the Super Bowl, the Bills ended almost every game here with a song: ''I've gotta feeling. I've gotta feeling. Buffalo's goin' to the Super Bowl.''

title: Student Is Found Dead in N.Y.U. Library
description: The police are investigating the death of a New York University freshman whose body was found at the bottom of the atrium of the Elmer Holmes Bobst Library yesterday afternoon. The student newspaper, the Washington Square News, noted that four weeks ago, on Sept. 12, a junior had jumped to his death from the library's 10th floor.

title: N.F.L. Is Sued Over a Crash That Left a Child Paralyzed
description: The family of a 6-year-old girl who was paralyzed in an accident involving a football fan who drank 14 beers at Giants Stadium has sued the National Football League, alleging that the league had a role in the crash because it promotes drinking before and during games.

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; Martnez's Unlikely Nemesis
description: The maddening, mystifying domination of Enrique Wilson, a decent reserve player for the Yankees, over Pedro Martnez, the Red Sox pitcher who exists on his own planet, will create repercussions beyond the green walls, the green and red seats, and the Green Monster at Fenway Park on Saturday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economy Expands
description: Singapore's economy grew in the third quarter at its fastest pace in six years, rebounding from a record contraction. Gross domestic product grew at an annual 15 percent pace from the previous three months, after shrinking 11 percent in the second quarter. The rebound allowed the government to reiterate a forecast for the economy to grow as much as 1 percent this year. Growth in the second quarter was hurt as the spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome emptied stores and kept tourists away.

title: After Delays, U.S. Prepares To Enforce Do-Not-Call List
description: After nearly two weeks of court-ordered delays, the Federal Trade Commission began taking complaints today from people who have placed phone numbers on the national do-not-call registry but have continued to receive pitches from telemarketers. The Federal Communications Commission has been taking some complaints in recent days, as well, but because it does not manage the registry, its enforcement efforts are more limited.

title: Injury Delays Sprewell's Homecoming
description: Without controversy, Latrell Sprewell is getting his wish.

title: Kenseth's Title Drive Runs Into Potholes
description: Two weeks ago, with a seemingly insurmountable 436-point lead in the Nascar Winston Cup championship race, Matt Kenseth said his team realized that ''the only one who can beat us is ourselves.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Newspaper Editor Killed
description: A year and a half ago someone killed the editor of a crusading newspaper in Togliatti, in the southern region of Samara. On Thursday night, someone killed his successor, Aleksei Sidorov. Investigators linked the killing to his work at the newspaper, Togliatti Review. Russia's first deputy press minister called the killing an outrage. The interior minister said he was dispatching federal investigators to solve the case. Mr. Sidorov's predecessor, Valery Ivanov, was shot to death in April 2002 after a series of articles on a local crime group and its links to the police. His murder has never been solved. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: The High Cost of Voting No
description: Students of the partisan divide in Congress find it heating up to the level of kickboxing this year. In the annual spending bills now passing below the public's radar, House Republican leaders are coolly threatening to deny Democrats hundreds of millions of dollars in local projects in retaliation for their block-vote protest against the flawed majority bill on spending for health and education. Republicans note that cross-aisle vendettas are nothing new in the Capitol. But the G.O.P. would be elevating strong-arming to a whole new level by taking meat-and-potato projects from dissenting Democrats and serving this election-year bacon to Republicans.

title: The Boston Globe; Rocket's Last Ride Could Be Today
description: THIS might be the last game Roger Clemens ever pitches.

title: Is It Miracle or Illusion? Everyone Can Say Yes
description: A bulky woman dressed in synthetic pink walks into a bleached, splintery church, her head covered in white lace. Kneeling in the sanctuary, she crosses herself before an alabaster statue of Jesus, then kisses her rosary. The statue's eyes are cast to heaven; its features look heavy. As the woman observes with growing awe, there are two wet-looking red stains from its left eye down its cheek.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERKIN, RICHARD T.
description: PERKIN--Richard T. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Wildlife Conservation Society mourn the death of our friend, Richard Perkin. He was elected a Trustee in 1978 and served on a number of committees with particular interest in furthering the work of the Wildlife Health and Sciences Committee. Dick was devoted to conserving wildlife and wild places. He will be deeply missed. We extend our condolences to his wife Leslie and the Perkin family. David T. Schiff, Chairman Steven E. Sanderson, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENNEFELD, EDMUND B.
description: HENNEFELD -- Edmund B. On October 9, 2003 at age 971/2. Married for 72 years to Lillian. Survived by his children Erica Abeel and Julien Hennefeld, and four grandchildren. During the 70s, he was one of the Premier Appellate Lawyers in New York City's Corporation Counsel. He was also a lawyer in private practice in the firm Hennefeld and Riposanu. He was the author of a novel ''The World Tour'', as well as numerous plays. His play ''The Deputy of Paris'', presented at The Henry Street Playhouse, was praised by New York Times Critic, Brooks Atkinson. He was loved and admired by those who knew him for his brilliant, wide-ranging mind, civility and wit.

title: Clark Puts Clinton Veterans in High Posts
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark announced a raft of top appointments to his presidential campaign on Friday, just days after simmering tensions inside the fledgling organization led to the resignation of his campaign manager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIFFORD, MARJORIE OTIS
description: GIFFORD--Marjorie Otis. The Board of Trustees of Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts notes with deep sorrow the loss of its dear friend Marjorie Otis Gifford, whose devotion to Caramoor dates back many years to her friendship with its founders Walter and Lucie Rosen. She was a strong advocate and supporter of Caramoor's programs for school children to develop an appreciation of classical music and to aide in instrumental training. An asset to the community, Mrs. Gifford will be sorely missed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Howard Dean's candidacy for the Democratic presidential nomination and his assertion that President Bush is ''setting the stage for the failure of America'' referred incompletely to the medical deferment Dr. Dean received during the Vietnam War. While he did indeed request a physical examination, he said he did so after receiving a low number in the draft lottery, to determine his options for the military, not explicitly to avoid service.

title: Tigers and Trouble
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Raid on Palestinian Camp in Gaza Leaves 7 Dead
description: Seven Palestinians, including three boys, were killed and more than 40 were wounded after Israeli forces, backed by helicopters and dozens of tanks and armored cars, poured into the Rafah refugee camp in the Gaza Strip during the night, hospital officials said on Friday.

title: Finding Grandeur In the Everyday
description: ''I am an American, Chicago born,'' famously proclaims the opening of ''The Adventures of Augie March,'' while at its close, its narrator dubs himself ''a sort of Columbus.'' These invocations are hardly subtle, and 50 years ago, when Saul Bellow's exuberantly stuffed and ecstatically picaresque novel was published, its ambition caused as much a sensation as its prose.

title: A Soviet Victim Works to Shape a New Russia
description: ELENA NEMIROVSKAYA had a lot of reasons to hate the Soviet Union. It sent her father to a labor camp and forced her mother, an enemy of the state by association, out of her factory job. She survived, in part, by sewing mittens. It mangled her young daughter's health. It terrorized her husband with interrogations.

title: A 'Cosmic Jerk' That Reversed the Universe
description: Astronomers said on Friday that they had determined the time in cosmic history when a mysterious force, ''dark energy,'' began to wrench the universe apart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEBINER, LIOVA
description: GEBINER -- Liova. Loving husband of 56 years of the late Lee Gebiner, adored father and father-in-law of Rhea and Norman Friedman, and admired uncle. Remembered fondly by many family and friends. Services were held yesterday at Parkside Memorial Chapel.

title: Presidential Warrior?
description: To the Editor:

title: Are Jews Who Fled Arab Lands to Israel Refugees, Too?
description: For all its military aspects, the Middle East conflict is also typified by clashes of narratives, different accounts of flight and dispossession that are used to justify political goals today. Now comes another competing variation of this complicated history, one involving the nearly 900,000 Jews who left Arab nations amid an anti-Semitic backlash after the creation of Israel in 1948.

title: Police Fire 21 Shots, Injuring Suspect in Drug Bust Gone Awry
description: The police shot and seriously wounded a man early yesterday during an undercover drug buy on a Harlem street corner, firing 21 shots, police officials said.

title: VALUECLICK TO BUY COMMISSION JUNCTION FOR $58 MILLION
description: ValueClick Inc., an online advertising company, agreed to buy the closely held Commission Junction for $58 million in cash, stock and options, gaining a marketing company with clients that include eBay Inc. The purchase has been approved by the board of each company and should be completed in November, ValueClick said. ValueClick is based in Westlake Village, Calif., and Commission Junction is based in Santa Barbara, Calif. It is the eighth acquisition by ValueClick since the company went public in March 2000.

title: B.C. to Agree to Join A.C.C.
description: Boston College will agree to leave the Big East Conference to become the 12th member of the Atlantic Coast Conference when an official invitation is offered tomorrow, an A.C.C. university official said yesterday.

title: Television Ratings Increase
description: Fox's postseason baseball coverage continued to show large gains Thursday night when Game 2 of the Yankees-Red Sox American League Championship Series attracted an average of 13.2 million viewers. That represented a 47 percent increase from Game 2 of the San Francisco-St. Louis series last year.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: PRINCE GIVES UP CLAIM TO THRONE FOR LOVE Prince Johan Friso, second in line to the throne, gave up his right to succession, saying he would marry the woman he loves despite failing to win government approval. Prime Minister Jan Peter Balkenende said he could not back the marriage of the prince and his fiancée, Mabel Wisse Smit, both 35, because she had misled the government about her close relationship with a mobster who was shot dead in a gangland killing in 1991. Last week one of the mobster's former bodyguards said Ms. Wisse Smit had been the mobster's lover. Under Dutch law, royals who aspire to the throne must receive permission from the government and Parliament to marry.    (Reuters)

title: FASHION / A SPECIAL REPORT: 'Vive Chanel!' Even the models cheer a whiff of Coco
description: The energetic and excellent collection that Karl Lagerfeld sent out Friday for Chanel bore the imprint of a master. From the first moment that a duo of models sauntered down the wooden boardwalk, as if on a brief encounter on a Paris street, the show took off. And not least because it showed the designer's lacy, airy, flowery clothes refreshing that old Coco magic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALPERN, NETTIE
description: HALPERN--Nettie. Rye, N.Y., October 9, 2003. Survived by daughter Rennie Halsband, son-in-law Jerry, grandson Craig Hansen-Sturm, sisterin-law Ruth Jaffe and four great grandchildren.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Pakistani Response Commended
description: Amid reports that members of the Taliban and Al Qaeda are preparing larger attacks from Pakistan into Afghanistan, the Afghan government acknowledged an improvement in cooperation with Pakistan after the fourth meeting of a United States-Pakistani-Afghan military commission to resolve border and counter-terrorism issues. ''We have seen a visible and quantifiable change in the way Pakistan has been handling the cross-border activity,'' one Afghan official said. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Tuesday about the actor Denis Quilley misidentified the city in which he appeared in revivals of ''The School for Scandal'' and ''The White Devil.'' It was London, not New York.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Suspect Leaps Onto Road And Dies
description: A drunken driving suspect, 27, was killed when he leaped on a highway in suburban Dallas after kicking out the windows of two police cars and jumping from one. Officers said the man resisted arrest at a traffic accident, was handcuffed and put a patrol car. When he kicked the car windows, the police said, they added restraints and put him in the second car. En route to the jail in Arlington, the police said, the man, whose name was not released, slipped his shackles, smashed a window and jumped on Interstate 20, where another patrol car struck him. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: 4 FORMER GEMSTAR OFFICIALS SUBJECT OF FRAUD INQUIRY
description: Four former officials of Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc. were notified that they are targets of a criminal securities raud investigation, prosecutors said in a court filing yesterday. The United States attorney's office in Los Angeles did not name the officials. The filing was made as a motion to intervene in a Securities and Exchange Commission case against Henry C. Yuen, the former chief executive, and Elsie M. Leung, the former chief financial officer. The S.E.C. in June charged Mr. Yuen and Ms. Leung with inflating revenue at the Los Angeles-based company by $223 million over two years.

title: Outside Lawyers Question Bryant's Defense Strategy
description: Two New York lawyers with years of courtroom experience said yesterday that they thought Kobe Bryant's defense against a sexual-assault charge in Colorado was hurt by the first day of a preliminary hearing, held on Thursday.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Columbus Day

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Telephone Stock Buyback
description: Telefnica, Spain's biggest phone company, will spend 10 billion euros ($12 billion) on dividend payments and buying back about 7.6 percent of its own stock in the next three years to increase shareholder returns. Telefnica, which paid a dividend this year for the first time since 1998, will distribute 6 billion euros in cash to shareholders through 2006 and use at least 4 billion euros to buy back its stock, its chairman, Cesar Alierta, told investors in Madrid.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Champion of Iranian Freedom
description: Shirin Ebadi, who won the Nobel Peace Prize yesterday, is not particularly well known outside Iran, where she is one of the country's most persistent champions of human rights. Yet the selection of this courageous Muslim woman by the Nobel committee will probably have worldwide impact. Ms. Ebadi was one of the first women to serve as a judge in Iran, before Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini banned women from the bench. Throughout her distinguished career she has upheld the principle that Islamic faith is compatible with the rule of law, and in particular with the rights of women, children and outspoken intellectuals. Honoring her will encourage millions in the Islamic world who share that belief.

title: Ex-Banker Seems to Alter Earlier Denial
description: Frank P. Quattrone appeared to contradict his earlier testimony yesterday, acknowledging for the first time that he participated in the allocations of shares of initial offerings to investors when he was a banker at Credit Suisse First Boston.

title: INSIDE
description: Muslim Chaplain Charged

title: The City Life; Gotham City, Knee-Deep in Paper
description: New York is a city of space-starved apartment dwellers who complain constantly about cramped conditions. A woman I know inherited some space when her daughter left for college, but was forced to use the room as a storage bin for old magazines and newspapers. Such recyclable paper has been piling up in tiny apartments all over town since New York changed the recycling schedule this summer.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Skoal On Sundays
description: Sunday liquor sales are legal again, two days after the state reinstated a ban from the 1970's. The law, which officials recently found, required that towns approve Sunday sales by referendum. Officials had notified stores in 135 municipalities of the change but backed off after the attorney general's office found that a revision in 1991 overrode the referendum requirement. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: IRAQI SHIITE ANGER RAISES NEW FEARS FOR U.S. SOLDIERS
description: Shiite Muslim anger against Americans spilled into Friday Prayers in Sadr City, the poor Baghdad district where two Iraqis and two American soldiers were killed Thursday night.

title: Back to Business in Avery Fisher Hall
description: There was no dramatic reunion between Lincoln Center and the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night in Avery Fisher Hall. Nor did anyone look bleary-eyed from unpacking all those Carnegie-bound suitcases. Rather, there was a pleasantly business-as-usual feeling at the concert, the first performance since the orchestra announced that it would not be merging with Carnegie Hall.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the beginning of an article in Business Day yesterday about the first six months under the new chief executive of AMR, the parent company of American Airlines, was omitted from some copies. It is online at www.nytimes.com/corrections, and copies may be requested from Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: Sports Briefing
description: PRO FOOTBALL

title: Inmate-Inflicted Injuries Are Increasing in City Jails
description: The rate of serious injuries, excluding stabbings and slashings, inflicted on inmates by other inmates within the city jail system has quadrupled this year compared with the four previous years, city officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about rising violence against public school employees referred imprecisely to the school statistics compiled by the New York Police Department. They are for all complaints made to the police that could result in arrests and criminal charges, not just crimes in which students are arrested and charged.

title: Rockets Last Ride Could Be Saturday
description: BOSTON

title: The Strains of War, Here and There
description: To the Editor:

title: Guns on the Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: Musical Chairs In Disney Suit
description: The company suing the Walt Disney Company over royalties from Winnie-the-Pooh merchandise is looking for new lawyers for the second time this year.

title: Following New York Signs Is Long Way to Nowhere
description: The seasoned motorist or indefatigable road-tripper, even the operator of a taximeter cabriolet, must at some point face that dark, despairing moment of hapless reckoning, staring dumbfounded at some of New York City's street signs.

title: Ernst & Young Chief Leaves After Holding Post a Year
description: The global chief executive of Ernst & Young, whose efforts to hide his wealth during divorce proceedings backfired with the disclosure of the privately held firm's financial details, retired yesterday after a little more than a year in the job.

title: Company Making Case To Allow Breast Implants
description: Yesterday morning, the breast implant documents appeared on the Food and Drug Administration Web site, voluminous files constituting one company's arguments for bringing silicone breast implants back on the market.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Software Profit Rises
description: The software exporter Infosys Technologies reported a 33 percent increase in its quarterly earnings, aided by increased outsourcing by global corporations. The company raised its full-year earnings forecast by 6 percent from an estimate announced in July. Infosys, a bellwether for the country's flourishing software industry, said its revenue would top $1 billion this year. The company reported a profit of 3 billion rupees ($66.3 million) up from 2.3 billion rupees ($49.9 million) a year earlier. The results beat market expectations but Infosys said recent gains in the rupee, India's currency, might affect profit margins in the future. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: In Show, Limbaugh Tells of a Pill Habit; Plans to Enter Clinic
description: Rush Limbaugh, the nation's most popular radio talk-show host with an audience of 20 million people a week, announced yesterday that he was addicted to prescription painkillers and would check into a rehabilitation center.

title: G.E. to Buy British Medical Company
description: General Electric announced yesterday that it would buy Amersham, a British medical company, for $9.5 billion in stock, expanding its presence in the health care industry, including the growing medical imaging business.

title: Rights in Nigeria
description: To the Editor:

title: Deficit Falls Below Prediction, But the Year Still Sets a Record
description: As the government closed the books on the 2003 fiscal year this week, the Bush administration received a modest piece of good news: the 2003 budget deficit, while still the largest in history, was smaller than predicted.

title: Review/Fashion; At Chanel, a Subtle Sense of Luxe
description: ''Twenty years, and I've never thought to do a trench coat for Chanel,'' said Karl Lagerfeld, sounding as amazed as a baker who has never tasted his own bread. ''But it's not really Chanel.'' A chain is, though, and in working up some embroidered trimming that looks at a distance like chain and tracing it around the collar and flaps of a trench, Mr. Lagerfeld found yet another way to make a classic pay.

title: College Football | Kickoff; TODAY'S TOP MATCHUPS
description: 2 Miami (5-0) at 5 Florida State (5-0)

title: Pitchers Duel Draws Crowd, and Yanks Escape
description: BOSTON, Oct. 11 - Roger Clemens had tried to dismiss the idea that Game 3 of the American League Championship Series would be a showdown between him and Pedro Martinez. ``We are not in a boxing ring,'' Clemens said on Friday. Nobody knew he would be so wrong.

title: New fears on Southeast Asia terror ring
description: HONOLULU, Hawaii:  Jemaah Islamiyah, the network of Islamic radicals linked to Al Qaeda and accused of a number of deadly terrorist attacks in Southeast Asia, has become the greatest threat to the region, according to senior U.S. military officials. Its influence and strength, they said, are far more significant than initially thought.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Election Called
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi called a general election for Nov. 9 after dissolving the lower house of Parliament. He had been expected to make such a move, especially after his overwhelming victory last month as leader of the Liberal Democratic Party. The party, which now governs in a coalition with two other parties, will face the Democratic Party, which recently merged with the Liberal Party. Campaigning for the 480 seats in the lower house, which is entrusted with selecting the prime minister, will start on Oct. 28. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Seeking Common Ground on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Promises Cuban-Americans to Keep Up Pressure on Castro
description: President Bush announced Friday that the government was tightening a ban on travel to Cuba and making it easier for more immigrants to enter the United States. Mr. Bush said the measures would ''hasten the arrival of a new, free, democratic Cuba,'' adding that ''clearly, the Castro regime will not change by its own choice.''

title: Waksal's Father Named in S.E.C. Suit
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday sued Jack Waksal, the father of Dr. Samuel D. Waksal, the founder of ImClone Systems, contending that he sold more than $8 million worth of ImClone shares in late 2001 after his son told him the company was about to announce bad news.

title: Rangers Revert to Bad Form
description: Only a period and a half into their 78th National Hockey League season Friday night, the Rangers reverted to form, allowing the last four goals and suffering a 5-3 loss to the Minnesota Wild.

title: FASHION / A SPECIAL REPORT: fashfile: Sonia Rykiel:
description: The designer seemed in her element taking her bow amid a lineup of hunky guys who had grabbed the models for a clinch. It was a stunt to launch the new Rykiel Woman fragrance. But even without the antics, this was a sparkling show  literally  as belts winked "Elvis" in rhinestones, bikini tops twinkled and glittering graphics of yachts sailed across sweaters. This refreshed Rykiel had few of the signature striped sweaters but pretty dresses with poppy prints and feminine touches from ribboned espadrilles or shoes with bows through a lingerie spirit that was never overplayed.

title: Party Chief In Brooklyn Denies Guilt Over Funds
description: Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., the leader of the Brooklyn Democratic Party, was arraigned in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday on felony financial misconduct charges, then was released on $25,000 bail.

title: 3 Families, 3 Strategies: Zurich
description: My husband and I realized we needed to change our tourism strategies the day our daughter, Sarah, who was 11, glared at the paintings as we toured the Ducal Palace in Venice.

title: G.O.P. Leadership Interceding in Energy Talks
description: The top Republicans in the House and Senate will intercede in talks about a new energy policy to keep consideration of the legislation from slipping into next year, Congressional aides said on Friday.

title: Ex-Suffolk Officer Gets 5 Years for Abuse of 4 Women
description: A former Suffolk County highway patrol officer was sentenced yesterday to five years and three months in prison for detaining and sexually abusing four women he had stopped while on duty, on the pretense that they had violated traffic laws.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Mandatory Military Service
description: The lower house of Parliament overwhelmingly passed draft legislation that would restore the Soviet tradition of mandatory military training in schools. President Vladimir V. Putin said last week that such training ''is not bad, it's necessary and useful.'' Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: How to Get to Rivera? Go Right With Contreras
description: Jos Contreras was a headache for the Boston Red Sox before he threw a pitch in the major leagues. They coveted him, offering $27 million, and booked every room in the Nicaraguan hotel he was staying in after defecting from Cuba, hoping no other team could get to him.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Airline To Cut Jobs
description: Europe's third-biggest airline, Lufthansa, plans to cut 2,000 jobs over the next few years, the company said. About 1,000 jobs will probably be dropped from the catering unit LSG Sky Chefs, while other divisions affected include flight clearance as well as cargo and buildings management. Lufthansa, which is based in Cologne, Germany, said it intended to avoid layoffs. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Thalia Mara, 92, Ballet Educator
description: Thalia Mara, a ballet educator who helped found the USA International Ballet Competition in Jackson, Miss., died on Wednesday at St. Dominic/Jackson Memorial Hospital. She was 92 and lived in Jackson.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first day of Sukkot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Conan the Green
description: The actor who owns Hummers that average 10 miles to the gallon has now been elected governor of a state that has long provided national leadership on environmental issues, especially those like clean air and more fuel-efficient automobiles. Can Arnold Schwarzenegger and California's environmental impulses coexist?

title: Iranian Lawyer, Staunch Fighter for Human Rights, Wins Nobel
description: OSLO, Oct. 10  Shirin Ebadi, an Iranian lawyer little known outside her country, became the first Muslim woman to win the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday, recognition for her work promoting the rights of women and children in Iran.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GELLMAN, ARCHIE
description: GELLMAN--Archie. 10/11/60. Beloved father, eternally missed. Gloria and Howard

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 21 about the television show ''Law and Order'' referred incorrectly to cast changes over the years. Some regular characters have indeed died, and departures of others have indeed been acknowledged. The article also misidentified the company for which Dick Wolf, the show's creator, wrote a slogan -- ''I'm Cheryl. Fly Me'' -- when he worked in advertising. It was National Air Lines, not Braniff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YABLON, MELVIN
description: YABLON--Melvin. On October 11, 2003. Beloved husband of Lynda. Adored brother of Shirley Tahler. Wonderful father of Perry and Jonathon. Loving grandfather of Taylor and Travis. Dear brother-inlaw of Jeff Furman and sonin-law of Sally Furman. Wonderful uncle and great-uncle to many. Service Monday, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. He was the kindest, most gentle, giving person in the world.

title: Israelis Kill Palestinian In Search For Tunnels
description: One Palestinian was killed and at least five were wounded as Israel troops traded sporadic gunfire with militants and searched for smuggling tunnels in the southern Gaza Strip for a second day on Saturday.

title: Emily Gold, Daniel Waldman
description: Emily Rachel Gold, the daughter of Janet and Sanford Gold of Irvington, N.Y., is to be married today to Daniel Jason Waldman, a son of Joan and Lawrence Waldman of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Michael White is to officiate at Tarrytown House, a hotel in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEICHTMAN, PAUL
description: LEICHTMAN--Paul. On October 8, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Frances Simmons Leichtman. Brother of Carl and Allie. Devoted father of Gail Macht-Martin (Alvin) and Jane Freeman (Stuart). Adoring grandfather of Hilary Macht Felgran (Steven), Timothy Macht (Laurie Abraham), David Freeman and Todd Ewan. Special great-grandpa to Mikey, Olivia, Edie, Harry and Tess. His joy of life brought light wherever he went warming all those who knew him. He will be loved and missed always and ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALL, ROSS HUME, PH.D.
description: HALL--Ross Hume, Ph.D. On October 9, 2003 in Danby, VT, age 76. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Distinguished biochemist and writer. Information: donaldhall@tweedsmuir.com

title: Sir, to Whom May I Direct Your Free Call?
description: IN the fall of 2000, Niklas Zennstrom and Janus Friis had not yet earned any powerful enemies, at least so far as they were aware. They were just two obscure Swedish entrepreneurs who had worked with three Estonian programmers to write a file-sharing application called Kazaa. At the time, the free program was merely one of Napster's several weak stepsisters, lumped together in news reports with the likes of Snarfzilla and ToadNode.

title: Investing; Balancing the Seesaw With Commodities
description: WHILE commodities can be extremely volatile in price, investing in them can help smooth out the performance of an investment portfolio, some financial advisers say, because commodities tend to do well when stocks and bonds decline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICH, HARRY M.
description: RICH--Harry M. 80 years old. Died peacefully on October 9th. Beloved father of Jeffrey (Olivia), Marc (Debra) and Lisa (Richard). Adored grandfather of Blake, Kelly, Wyatt, Jackson, Mackenzie, Alec. He will be missed.

title: On the Front Lines
description: THE blackout of 2003 further demonstrates that our hospitals are the epicenter for civilian defense.

title: East Village Journal; Baying at the Moon . . . Reverently
description: Sky gazers hoping to see Friday night's full moon were most likely disappointed by the heavy cloud cover hanging over the city just after sunset. But in a garden in the East Village there was no shortage of surrogates. Nine white paper globes of varying sizes hung alongside a glittering silver disco ball, all suspended from the roof of a wooden stage at the rear of the garden, at Avenue B and Sixth Street. Affixed to the back of the stage was a five-foot-tall photograph of the moon. One man suggested that a powerful floodlight on the roof of the Earth School, opposite the garden on Avenue B, could serve as an emergency substitute for the moon. Even three tambourines with white skins that reflected the light of a wood fire elicited lunar comparisons.

title: Cathy Riva, Marc Bloomgarden
description: Cathy Maria Riva and Marc Howard Bloomgarden were married last evening by Rabbi D. Stephen Henriques at Oleander Terrace in Montego Bay, Jamaica.

description: THE BOY FROM OZ'

title: Executive Life: THE BOSS; A Hands-On Life
description: I GREW up one of four children in Texarkana, deep in the piney woods of East Texas. My father owned a bowling center and a small furniture store in town, and I began working at the furniture store at age 12. I worked there on Saturdays and during summers all the way through college.

title: No Room to Vroom: New Memories of Gridlock Past
description: IT'S little more than a mile from 34th Street to 57th Street, but the other day it took Muhammad Zamir, a taxi driver of five years, nearly an hour to cover that distance up the Avenue of the Americas. At first he blamed last month's presidential visit to the United Nations, which brought parts of Midtown traffic to a standstill. But in Mr. Zamir's opinion, traffic has yet to improve.

title: Sports of The Times; Cubs Fans Have Been Close Before
description: IT is part of the wretched patrimony of the Chicago Cubs. Even the children who were not yet born know this terrible tale.

title: Anglicans in Angry Split Over Homosexuality Issue
description: For years, the 38 national churches that make up the worldwide Anglican Communion have been distinguished by their eagerness to coexist despite their differences over such issues as the ordination of women, how bishops are selected and whether worship should be conducted in formal ''high church'' tradition or the evangelical ''low church'' style.

title: Cunningham's Surprise Party for Himself
description: FOR the finale to the yearlong celebration of his dance company's 50th anniversary, Merce Cunningham has chosen to look forward, not back. There will be no retrospective, no self-aggrandizing parade of greatest hits. In fact, half his audience may not know who he is.

title: Bill Shoemaker, Jockey With Winning Touch, Dies at 72
description: Bill Shoemaker, the 4-foot-11, 98-pound dynamo who was among horse racing's most renowned figures and who rode the winners of 11 Triple Crown races, died yesterday at his home in San Marino, Calif. He was 72.

title: In a Move for Speed, Amtrak to Eliminate Stops in New Haven
description: Amtrak is trying to make its much-heralded high-speed Acela service faster, and New Haven riders will be affected.

title: Amy Briggs, Charles Adomanis Jr.
description: Amy Christine Briggs, the daughter of Karen Henry Briggs and G. Scott Briggs of San Jose, Calif., is to be married today to Charles James Adomanis Jr., a son of Dr. Ann Lawrence O'Sullivan of Philadelphia and Mr. Adomanis of Ardmore, Pa. The Rev. Cheryl Cavalconte, a member of the Catholic Apostolic Vicariate of the Good Shepherd, will officiate at the Kay Chapel in Newport, R.I.

title: 3 Families, 3 Strategies: Paris; A Ferris wheel outside, the 'Mona Lisa' inside
description: Here's a combination of the Divide and Conquer and Quick Hit strategies to get a peek in the Louvre. I knew it would be impossible to see Italian Renaissance paintings there with our 5-year-old, True, in tow, but with my 8-year-old, Sky, it was possible. The draw? Leonardo da Vinci's ''Mona Lisa,'' of course, as familiar to a third grader as Pikachu or Darth Maul.

description: A BLADE OF GRASS

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Holiday Tomorrow -- Columbus Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about footwear and politics misspelled the brand name of boots that seem closest to President Bush's personality. It is Tony Lama, not Llama.

title: In the Eyes of Artists: Responses to Kennedy
description: JOHN F. KENNEDY fascinated and inspired artists in a way no other American president has done. Partly this was because of his youthful good looks, beautiful family and extraordinary charisma, and partly because he carried with him so many hopes for a brighter, better future. To many Americans, including artists, he seemed like the model president.

title: Editorial Observer; A New Kind of Minority Is Challenging Louisiana's Racial Conventions
description: The election-night blowout at the Astor Crowne Plaza in the French Quarter last weekend was something rare in Republican politics: a truly biracial event. But even though 33 percent of Louisiana -- and 67 percent of New Orleans -- is black, there was scarcely a black reveler there. The mix of people celebrating Bobby Jindal's first-round win in this year's governor's race was an unusual one: whites and Indian-Americans.

title: The Personal Is the Antipolitical
description: New Jersey readers of Michael Lewis's fascinating article (Sept. 28) may have recognized the two shock jocks flaming the California recall. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIN, CYNTHIA, PHD
description: LEWIN--Cynthia, PhD, 76, passed away in Berkeley, CA. on October 2, 2003 after a lengthy illness. Dr. Lewin was born in New York City in 1927, the loving daughter of Louis and Goldie Fried. Cynthia graduated from LaGuardia High School of Music and Art, majoring in voice and piano. She graduated from Connecticut College and received a PhD in Educational Psychology from New York University in 1951. She married Warren Lewin of Mt. Vernon, N.Y. in 1950 and had two children Nancy and Wendy. She was divorced in 1963 and moved back to New York City where she worked in educational publishing for many years. Dr. Lewin was an avid tennis player, organizing matches in Central Park and other venues. She was a active member of the Ileostomy Association of New York, serving as its President and Editor of its newsletter. Dr. Lewin spent many years working as a volunteer in liaison psychiatry under the direction of Dr. James Strain at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York. Cynthia was a lifelong member of Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York, as were her parents. She maintained a part time residence in Longboat Key, Florida, where she became a Bat Mitzvah in 1997. Dr. Lewin is survived by her two daughters Nancy Potter Tompkins and Wendy Lewin Fitch and five grandchildren Jeremy Potter, Serena Potter Gay, Chaska Potter, Alison Fitch and Rebecca Fitch, all of whom live in California. A private Memorial Service will be held on October 19, 2003. Anyone wishing to contact the family may call 650-329-7104.

title: SoHo Grand
description: The first time I walked into the SoHo loft of the decorator Thomas Jayne and his partner, Rick Ellis, I was furious. Jayne, after all, was the man who had encouraged me to ''pare down'' and ''think modern.'' And now here was his own space, cluttered with busts and books (more than 5,000 of them), antlers and skulls, bugs (dead ones) and a stuffed bat flying from the ceiling. There were also a pair of white sphinxes, piles of Old Paris porcelain and Chinese vases, not to mention a reliquary containing a piece of the ''true cross.'' title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Opera is a genre usually associated with over-the-top plots and outsize emotions. Soap operas are television (originally radio) dramas that play like bad librettos without music. Space operas are science fiction stories that use the entire universe (and sometimes several universes) as backdrop for over-the-top plots -- often without any recognizably human emotions in view. It has been Catherine Asaro's genius to combine space and soap opera to produce a heavy-breathing series called the Saga of the Skolian Empire. This series has attracted many fans, both of science fiction and of the genre known as romance fiction. The sixth Skolian novel, ''The Quantum Rose,'' was recognized in 2001 with a Nebula Award for best novel, a prize granted by the Science Fiction and Fantasy Writers of America.

title: Rauschenberg's American Beauties
description: NOW 77, Robert Rauschenberg has been -- to employ the understatement of the year -- a working artist for well over a half-century. His encyclopedic oeuvre ranges from newspaper photographs splashed with lighter fluid and rubbed onto drawing paper, to electronically squawking junk sculpture and huge but delicate works made from exotic textiles wafting in the breeze. Playfully embracing automobile tires and images of astronauts, J.F.K. and Roger Maris, taxidermicized animals and the architecture of brick-and-fire escape New York, Rauschenberg's work is about nothing if not America itself. And Rauschenberg's America is primarily the freewheeling, optimistic and inclusive (well, compared to other countries) U.S. of A. we knew back in the 1940's, 50's and 60's. Compared to Jack Kerouac's Beat wilderness or Tennessee Williams's Gothic humidor or Arthur Miller's dark moral tribunal, it's a relatively happy place.

title: Jamesland
description: Alice lived in her great-aunt's large bungalow on Wren Street in a desirable neighborhood known as Los Feliz. A hundred and fifty years before, Corporal Jose Vicente Feliz was awarded a Spanish land grant for his role in civilizing the unruly new pueblo of Los Angeles. Rancho Los Feliz-or the Happy Farm as it was often called-was a small, wealthy fiefdom with two thousand acres of mountainous wooded terrain teeming with game, a thousand more in flat arable fields and pastureland, and several miles of riverbed. Corporal Feliz enjoyed this windfall for eight short years. His savvy widow, Dona Verdugo, remarried and held on for decades, establishing legal title to the land once Mexico gained independence from Spain. Her heirs were less tenacious; several daughters sold their holdings at a dollar per acre, and the primary heir, Antonio, bequeathed his major holding to the family lawyer.

In an instant, a place to lunch with families and friends, Arabs and Jews intermingling, had become a charnel house. Of the more than 100 suicide bombings of Israeli targets in the past three years, with 430 people killed, the location seemed particularly grotesque, and redolent of how violence for political ends quickly reaches extents that defy humanity's every code.

description: PARIS 1919: Six Months That Changed the World, by Margaret MacMillan. (Random House, $16.95.) When the leaders of Britain, France, Italy and the United States met in Paris from January to June 1919 to decide the outcome of the Great War, four old empires had fallen and the fate of hundreds of millions of people was unclear. This account of the making of the Treaty of Versailles -- which dictated a new world order and produced a recipe for decades of political disorder -- was chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2002. title: You'd Think Columbus Discovered New Jersey
description: In the rivalry between the Garden and Empire States, New Jersey is the clear winner in one arena: it has more monuments to Columbus than New York -- or any other state for that matter, according to Peter van der Krogt, a map historian from the University of Utrecht, who tracks Columbus monuments around the world. Specifically, Mr. van der Krogt said New Jersey had 32, and that New York was second with 24. The first monument to Columbus was created in Genoa in the 16th century, said the Dutch historian, while the first to appear in the United States was in Baltimore in 1792. The first statue of Columbus in New Jersey was erected in Phillipsburg in 1892. Hoboken and Jersey City came next, and others followed, including one by Gaetano Federici that was erected in Paterson in 1953. Federici, who was Paterson's favorite sculptor, created about 40 public sculptures and reliefs within a two-mile radius of city hall in Paterson, including a statue of Senator William Hughes outside the county courthouse and ''America,'' a war memorial in Westside Park. His larger-than-life statue of Columbus in Paterson's Federici Park portrays the explorer on his triumphant return to Queen Isabella and King Ferdinand in 1493. There is also a plaster model of the same statue at Passaic County Community College's Hamilton Club Building, which has several art collections, including the Federici Studio Collection of more than 500 objects -- including plaster sculptures, molds, tools, furniture, photographs and other items associated with the sculpture, along with a re-creation of Federici's studio. At 1 p.m. next Sunday, Federici's descendants will be honored at a ceremony at the Hamilton Club Building. The event, ''Celebration of Paterson, Words, Sights and Sound'' -- to support arts programs and scholarships for youths in Paterson -- will honor several native sons and daughters, including the jazz guitarist Bucky Pizzarelli and the poet Maria Mazziotti Gillan. The Hamilton Club Building is at 32 Church Street, and the phone number is (973) 684-5656. Marge Perry

title: The 50-Year Hoffman-Hackman History
description: LONG before they'd made the acquaintance of Warren Beatty and Mike Nichols, and long before they'd won enough Oscars and Golden Globes to play a nice game of chess, Gene Hackman and Dustin Hoffman were a mismatched pair of struggling, idealistic actors who found solace in each other's company -- first in classes at the Pasadena Playhouse in 1956, where they played bongos on the roof, and then later in a cold-water flat in Manhattan, where Mr. Hoffman crashed in Mr. Hackman's kitchen until he was banished to the couch of some unwitting dupe named Robert Duvall. Though Mr. Hackman and Mr. Hoffman (now 73 and 66, respectively) have been friends for nearly half a century, they never worked on a film together until ''Runaway Jury,'' the latest installment in the John Grisham franchise. On a recent publicity stop in New Orleans for the film, opening Friday, the two men met with the writer Jennifer Senior to reminisce, gossip and reveal Marlon Brando's secret weapon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEGALL, JOEL E.
description: SEGALL--Joel E. On October 9, 2003. Cherished husband of Joan; loving father of Patricia and son - in - law Michael; proud and devoted grandfather of Samuel, beloved brother of Sandra and Arlyne. An internationally known economist, he had successful careers in both government and higher education. He received his MBA, MA and PhD from the University of Chicago. After receiving his first graduate degree, he was appointed to the faculty of the University of Chicago Graduate School and ultimately became its Director of Doctoral Programs. During his 20 year tenure at Chicago, he held visiting appointments at various colleges including Stanford and Royal College of Science and Technology in Scotland. He left teaching for public service to hold key positions as Deputy Assistant Secretary for Tax Policy in the Treasury Department, then as Deputy Undersecretary for International Affairs in the Department of Labor. In both posts, he received departmental and secretarial awards. In 1977, he returned to higher education as President of Baruch College, a senior college in the City University of New York. In addition, Dr. Segall was a former Trustee of the United Nations Institute for Training and Research, a Director of Globe Security Insurance Company, a former member of the Board of Managers for Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York and former Chairman of Independent Trustees of the PIMCO Advisors Family of Mutual Funds. He has also directed many professional programs for the General Electric Foundation, Ford Foundation, McKinsey Foundation, and others. In 1995 he received the Professional Achievement Citation from the University of Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROZEL, SAMUEL J.
description: ROZEL--Samuel J., who recently retired as senior vice president, general counsel, and a member of the executive committee of North American Philips, died suddenly at his home in New Canaan, CT, Saturday morning, August 30th. He was 68 years old. Mr. Rozel had been vice president, general counsel, and secretary of Magnavox Corp. prior to its acquisition by Philips in 1975. Previously he had been a staff attorney at the Federal Trade Commission and special assistant to former Commissioner Mary Gardiner Jones. He had also served as antitrust counsel to Honeywell. Mr. Rozel was born in Louisville and received his BSL and LLB degrees from the University of Louisville. He entered the Army as a PFC in 1958 and left active duty as a captain in the Judge Advocate General's Corps. He graduated from the advanced management program at the Harvard Business School in 1979. He married Jeanne Foulkes, who survives him, in 1965, and they moved to New Canaan in 1975. He was the son of the late Sam and Anna Rozel of Louisville. He is survived by two children, Brooke Kalter and her husband Noam of Vernon, CT, and Dr. John Samuel Rozel and his wife Beth of Pittsburgh, PA. He is also survived by his brother, Richard Rozel of Louisville, a sister Ruth Silverman of Palm Desert, CA, and numerous nieces and nephews.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Edgewater; A Former Factory Town, Transformed

After half a century in which its population inched up by less than 25 percent, the community, covering nine-tenths of a square mile, grew by 55 percent in the decade from 1990 to 2000, and borough officials estimate that its population has gained an additional 15 percent in the three years since the latest United States census. Incomes also soared between 1990 and 2000, to $63,455 from $44,087, with more than one-fourth of the households now earning more than $100,000 annually.

MonacoAuction.com allows users to bid on travel packages to the principality, with a chance for significant savings. Among the first items on the block: a two-night stay at the Monte Carlo Grand Hotel anytime from Nov. 1 to Dec. 29 with in-room Continental breakfast (listed retail value $875) and two nights in a junior suite in the Htel de Paris with buffet breakfast (retail price $1,908). The starting bids in each case were well below half price. The site lists the number of packages available for each auction, as well as the current highest bid. It is operated by the Monaco Government Tourist Office's Club Diamant Rouge de Monaco, a cardholder program with such travel benefits as admission to Monaco's museums (worth $60) and a free helicopter transfer to or from Nice's airport. title: Ms. Macbeth and Her Cousin: The Women of 'Mystic River'
description: ONE of the most haunting scenes in Clint Eastwood's ''Mystic River'' -- a film that consists almost entirely of haunting scenes -- comes just before the end. The main dramatic action, we have every reason to suspect, is complete: a murder has been solved, another life has been taken in a misguided attempt at retribution and the fates of the three main characters, boyhood friends bound together by old trauma and fresh tragedy, have been sorted out. A long, climactic night of revelation and confrontation is over, and the weary streets of Boston are flooded with hard autumnal light. The break of day brings a new insight, one that has less to do with the facts of the story than with its meaning. All along, ''Mystic River'' has seemed, most obviously, to be about those three men -- Dave, Sean and Jimmy -- who still live in the shadow of Dave's abduction and molestation as a boy years before. But it turns out to be just as much about three (or more) damaged families, about the terror and mystery of marriage and about the fateful actions of two women. (Their place in ''Mystic River'' will be hard to discuss without revealing some of the movie's many secrets; I'll try to be circumspect, but you may want to finish reading this after you've seen the movie.)

title: What Price Music?
description: Since the introduction of vinyl records after World War II, recorded music has assumed many shapes and sizes, each one coming with a higher price tag than the last. Eight-track tapes cost a dollar more than LP's when they rose to popularity in the early 1970's, and cassettes commanded a premium over eight-tracks. And when CD's made their debut in the mid-1980's, record labels sold the shiny discs for $18, more than double the price for the same music on LP's and cassettes that cost more to manufacture. Unlike those formats, which the industry adopted voluntarily and marketed vigorously, the latest shift-- to digitized versions of songs that can be distributed online-- have been thrust upon it, the outgrowth of a technology it could not control. Battered by a sales slump it attributes largely to digital piracy and heartened by a limited test with Apple computer owners, this fall the record industry is trying to catch up with its file-swapping customers: the major labels and many independents have agreed to deconstruct the album, allowing anyone with a computer to buy any of hundreds of thousands of individual songs. Soon huge catalogs of every genre of music will be available for sale on the Internet from over a dozen retailers, bearing the blessing and license agreements of the major record labels.

title: Full Disclosure
description: Southern California is full of concrete and glass houses: immaculate, slick, sparely furnished and often cold as ice. At first glance, the architect Ron Radziner's own house in Venice, Calif. -- which he designed for himself; his wife, Robin Cottle, a graphic designer; and their two small children, Asher and Lexi -- might seem like just another of these minimalist boxes. But look again. Sure, it's meticulously designed, with pared-down, dark-toned furniture carefully arranged in its open, high-ceilinged living-dining-kitchen space. But that space looks, through a wall of sliding glass doors, into a deep green, lushly planted garden. And what appears from a distance to look an awful lot like a carport projecting from the house's side is actually an outdoor dining room, complete with an enormous fireplace, topped by a master bedroom that hovers over the garden like some kind of elegant treehouse. In the evening, you can dine outside by the fire and look into the living area, a generous space glowing in the dark. Cool it is; cold it's not.

She is 48, and she had her first heart attack in her late 20's. One of her brothers died of heart failure at 50, and another died of kidney failure at 45, as did a sister who was 35. title: A Religious Experience In Silver and Gold

Made from the same fabric used to make the pope's robes, the metallic brocade contains real gold and silver threads twisted together in an elaborate pattern. Intermix says the cloth comes from a fabric mill in New York's garment district, which is purportedly the world's sole purveyor of ecclesiastic materials. The same mill weaves religious tapestries, braids and sashes used by the Vatican. Because of Intermix's longstanding relationship with the mill (which also produces custom fabrics for retailers), the store was allowed to purchase 50 yards of material cut from the borders of the Trinity pattern, since the body of the fabric pictures crosses and other religious symbols that are off limits to the public. This shakes out to 80 skirts ($265) and 80 matching tops ($255, both at Intermix stores). Heaven only knows how long supplies will last.

title: The Agile Ambassador at Large
description: Globalization was supposed to incite not just the clashing of cultures but the creation of dazzling new forms. In the case of the Anglo-Bangladeshi choreographer and dancer Akram Khan, it actually has. Khan, 29, would have easily earned notice for his preternatural grace and stunning athleticism. But it is his polished, utterly novel meld of East and West that has made his fledgling company's performances among the most talked about in the dance world. His startling innovations are on virtuosic display in ''Kaash,'' his first full-length work, which has its New York premiere at the Joyce Theater this week. The piece begins in near darkness with an explosion of movement as Khan leads a column of four dancers lunging across the stage, their arms scything the air at electrifying speed.

title: McHistory
description: John Delano, the harried narrator of Tom Piazza's first novel, MY COLD WAR (ReganBooks, $24.95), is a professor of cold war studies at a small college in New England. His courses are popular with students but are ridiculed by his colleagues, who dismiss Delano's gimmicky and postmodern obsession with ''surfaces'' as ''History McNuggets.'' When a major New York publisher signs Delano to write a new book on the cold war -- and to participate in an accompanying mini-series for public television -- his career seems to be skyrocketing. But as he struggles with the book, his life begins to fall apart all around him. As Delano sits in his office, blocked and floundering in midlife dread, his faith in himself and the value of his life's work evaporates; his marriage begins to fail and his own personal history, long suppressed, is gaining on him. Praying that he can get a different kind of book out of his family experiences, he travels to Iowa, attempting to reconcile with his younger brother, Chris, whom he broke with eight years earlier, fed up with Chris's drifting from one dubious movement to another. The trip is good for Delano, and it's good for this novel. ''My Cold War'' works better when it's not in academic satire mode; there's a painful, penetrating authenticity in Delano's memories of growing up in a Long Island suburb during the cold war and in his portraits of his relationships with his volatile, loner father and emotionally fragile brother. It's in these sections that Piazza -- whose previous work of fiction was a story collection titled ''Blues and Trouble'' -- reveals the depth of his perceptiveness and talent. Sherie Posesorski

title: From the Days When the Western Still Mattered
description: ''THAT'S my kind of western'' was the reaction of Henry Fonda to ''The Hired Hand,'' according to his son, Peter, who directed and starred in it. Thirty-two years after the film's initial theatrical release, Peter Fonda, speaking by phone from his Montana home, still sounds slightly amazed by his father's response to this odd, gentle, lyrical little picture, which seemed, at the time, to be almost nobody's kind of western: it wasn't hip enough for the younger Fonda's counterculture following, who probably expected something closer to the biker-outlaw epic ''Easy Rider'' (1969); it wasn't square enough for moviegoers of the elder Fonda's generation, who preferred the more straightforward storytelling -- and morality -- embodied by, say, ''True Grit'' (1969); it wasn't violent enough to satisfy devotees of Sam Peckinpah and Sergio Leone; and it didn't have as many jokes as the synthetic pop western ''Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid'' (1969).

title: In Praise Of Follies
description: Like the man who never forgets a pretty face, Clay Lancaster never forgot a facade. The follies of his youth -- and those of his old age -- didn't involve chorus girls or public apologies, because Lancaster's follies were the kind with shapely turrets and balustrades, come-hither doors and winking windowpanes. Many of the gleams in his architectural eye survive only as images on paper, and yet the bevy of buildings he touched with his imagination presents the spectacle of a life well spent.

title: Lady in Spain
description: Last year, I packed a bag of books and a bag of clothes and took off for Spain. I had never just taken off before, not as a student, not in my early 20's like most of my friends, not ever (unless you count my freshman year in college, when, under the influence of lust and other stimulants, I disappeared a few times to Maine). I went, ostensibly, to learn Spanish -- my Presbyterian upbringing wouldn't allow me to classify such an extended trip as pure escape, so I came up with an actual reason to go. Also, since two-thirds of the Western Hemisphere speaks the language, I figured it wouldn't be a bad thing to do. (In school, I'd chosen sophistication over practicality and studied the French I barely remember.)

title: Ministering to the Enemy
description: There are serious charges laid out in the case against Senior Airman Ahmad I. al-Halabi, the Air Force translator at the Guantnamo prison camp -- among them espionage, punishable by death. But the charge that stands out is unlawfully delivering baklava to detainees. Apparently, al-Halabi was being nice to these people. Apparently, he liked some of them. And this, in the eyes of military prosecutors, stands as damning evidence. Al-Halabi showed sympathy for the Devil. As did, supposedly, Capt. James J. Yee of the Army, the West Point graduate who served as Muslim chaplain at Guantnamo during some of the same period that al-Halabi was a translator. Yee told me that he had arranged for detainees to be served dates during Ramadan, a traditional way to break the daily fast. But he did it officially, and that, I imagine, is why he could admit to it. We don't know yet what Yee is accused of having done wrong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZAPHIROPOULOS, DORIS SLAWSON

A gracious woman, elegant in body, mind and spirit, she nurtured and saw come to flower generations of therapists and their patients while serving as Administrator of the Clinical Services of the William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute for thirty-three years and beyond. She was the loving and loved wife of Miltiades, stepmother of Lela and Leigh, and stepmother-in-law of Jan Van Assen and Bryn McCornack, forever to be remembered as a cherished presence and a compassionate human being whose laughter was precious, and whose words were never unkind. Also remembered by all those who were fortunate enough to feel her steadfast and beneficent touch. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Contributions in her memory may be made to the William Alanson White Institute, 20 West 74th Street. New York, NY 10023-2401.

title: The New Tupacs, Good and Bad
description: DEATH CAB FOR CUTIE -- Benjamin Gibbard sighs and swoons more prettily than just about anyone. Earlier this year, he released an album of picturesque electronic pop with his side project, the Postal Service. Now Mr. Gibbard's band, Death Cab for Cutie, returns with a gorgeous, subtle new CD, ''Transatlanticism'' (Barsuk). He's a sharp lyricist, with a knack for intriguing opening lines; one song begins, ''This is the moment that you know/ That you told her that you loved her but you don't.'' And yet the real star of this disc is the producer Chris Walla (also the band's guitarist), who has created perhaps the best-sounding indie-rock album of the year by eliminating almost everything -- all that's left is a series of glimmering skeletons. On the song ''Passenger Seat,'' Mr. Gibbard is accompanied only by a stately piano line and a bed of ambient sound; the last song, ''A Lack of Color,'' is a marvelously gentle account of lost love, with a tune that unfolds one note at a time.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE

Neville, British Chief Protector of the Aborigines in the 1930's. This ''help'' takes the form of stealing half-caste children from their mothers and taking them to an orphanage-style settlement 1,200 miles away to be trained for domestic service. Three particular girls, ages 8 to 14, won't sit still for this. One day, while the others are at church, they escape and begin a long walk home, depending on the kindness of strangers as they go. Everlyn Sampi, Tianna Sansbury and Laura Monaghan play the girls in this inspiring true story. Phillip Noyce directed -- Thursday at 5:30 p.m. on Starz.

title: It's Illegal to Own Automatic Firearms
description: Re the Oct. 5 article [''Security Questions at Shooting Ranges''] about shooting ranges: A photograph shows a man firing an Uzi firearm at the Calverton range. The caption states that the Uzi is a submachine gun. Such guns fall into the category of fully automatic firearms, meaning they can fire multiple shots with one pull of the trigger. It is illegal to own fully automatic firearms in New York State; the scene shown would have been legal only if the gun had been modified to fire only one shot per trigger pull, and therefore was no longer a submachine gun, or if the shooter were a law enforcement officer.

title: Maid in Moscow

I'm not sure that I understand the message correctly, even though I've been studying Russian since my husband's law firm transferred him here five years ago. Sergei is Larisa's 16-year-old grandson. How could he have died? Not knowing what else to do, I call Larisa.

The Division of Cardiology, Department of Medicine of Montefiore Medical Center and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine is saddened to learn of the death of Dr. Julian Frieden. Dr. Frieden was a professor of clinical cardiology at the medical school and longtime associate of the Montefiore Medical Center. He was an expert electrocardiographer who published numerous scientific publications on both electrocardiography as well as general cardiology. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ISTOMIN, EUGENE
description: ISTOMIN--Eugene, international concert pianist, (November 26, 1925-October 10, 2003), beloved husband of Marta Casals Istomin, loyal and generous friend, and mentor to many. He was celebrated and respected as a recitalist, orchestral soloist, chamber musician and teacher for more than half a century. His distinct musical tone combined with his extraordinary technical mastery and musicianship, made him a unique and well-renowned artist. His erudition and life-long passions for literature, arts, politics, current affairs, history, sciences and sports were an integral part of his elegant and sensitive personality. Beyond his musical talent and keen intellect, his friends and colleagues admired him for his wisdom and integrity, as well as his devotion to many human causes. His music and his quiet acts of kindness touched the lives of many. Mr. Istomin is survived by his wife Marta, his mother-in-law Angelica Montanez and the Montanez family, his cousins Mrs. Marjorie Brenner and Dr. Steven Chavin and their families. He is also mourned by many friends and colleagues. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Eugene Istomin Scholarship at the Manhattan School of Music, NY or the Eugene Istomin Endowed Piano Chair at the Great Lakes Chamber Music Festival in Southfield, Michigan. Private funeral. A memorial service will be announced at a future date.

title: QUICK BITE/Millburn; Have a Seat (for a While) and Enjoy
description: Everything about Tinga says sit down, pop the top off a Mexican soda, and stay for a while. Tejano music, wood floors, and walls rag-rolled in rich earth tones set a mood that nobody who has known the pleasures of a fiery cool pico de gallo can resist. And it is enhanced by a host who waves you to the table of your choice. (''A.C. too much? It's warmer in the back.'') But once you are situated with menus, the haute-cantina vibe fizzles a bit when you are directed to order at the counter. What happens next, you wonder, in anticipation of the blackened catfish tacos, which sound too delicious to be tossed onto a plastic tray alongside a paper napkin. Mercifully, the servers, always pleasant and tolerant of inquiries about its confusing system, take over. Portions are huge and tasty, and the prices could not be much fairer: For $8 you can get char-grilled steak tacos with doughy soft shells tucked inside crisper ones; $4 buys a Texas hot dog or rice and beans for the children, and $7 covers you for any salad option, including a guacamole-dotted Mexican taco, which arrives in a salty, oily, red shell. Vegetarian choices, including tofu ''sour cream,'' abound, and desserts, and specials show up daily. The Millburn location is an offshoot, though it dwarfs the original Tinga, a 12-table setup with the same menu at 215 Bellevue Avenue in Montclair opened in June 2002. Tammy La Gorce

title: A Religious Experience in Silver and Gold
description: Shoppers who worship at the altar of fashion may appreciate the influence of an even higher order in a new limited edition Trinity skirt and bustier by Intermix. Made from the same fabric used to make the pope's robes, the metallic brocade contains real gold and silver threads twisted together in an elaborate pattern. Intermix says the cloth comes from a fabric mill in New York's garment district, which is purportedly the world's sole purveyor of ecclesiastic materials. The same mill weaves religious tapestries, braids and sashes used by the Vatican. Because of Intermix's longstanding relationship with the mill (which also produces custom fabrics for retailers), the store was allowed to purchase 50 yards of material cut from the borders of the Trinity pattern, since the body of the fabric pictures crosses and other religious symbols that are off limits to the public. This shakes out to 80 skirts ($265) and 80 matching tops ($255, both at Intermix stores). Heaven only knows how long supplies will last. A Full-Court Press For a Fur Wardrobe

title: Beach Coif Upstages Dry Days
description: Beach season is over, but beach hair -- frizzy, fuzzy and flyaway -- is just catching on. Perhaps an augur of thermal-straightening backlash, the coif appeared last month on fashion show runways like DKNY and Lacoste and has been seen recently on stars like Katie Holmes and Kirsten Dunst. Oscar Blandi, a hair stylist who has given the look to Ms. Holmes (as well as other celebrities like Brittany Murphy), said: ''Beach hair is clean with dirty-freshness with imperfection. It's a great contradiction of styles.'' To achieve the high-humidity effect in winter's arid grip, Mr. Blandi suggests dividing freshly washed, dried, product-free hair into sections at the crown. Take each section between your palms and rub vigorously to create a static charge; then, as if peeling cards from a deck, separate the strands of hair all the way to the head. Finish with a spritz of aerosol hair spray to freeze the halo illusion and add a light serum on ends for control.
