description: IN the summer of Y2K, Rae Jacobson, then 16, the daughter of the journalist and novelist Mark Jacobson and his wife, Nancy Cardozo, an editor, embarked with her parents and siblings, Billy, then 9, and Rosalie, then 12, on a third-millennium version of the old hippie/backpacker trail through Nepal, Katmandu, Cambodia, Thailand, India and more.

title: Baseball, Dulce de Leche and Ballet
description: BRILLIANT young dancers appear to be the norm in the Ballet Nacional de Cuba, which regularly produces international stars, like Carlos Acosta. Among the latest crop is Joel Carreo, who will be dancing in just about everything during the Cubans' six-performance season at City Center, opening on Wednesday.

title: Keeping the Home May Mean Taking Others as Tenants
description: Dwight and Purisima Culdice view their garage as more than a repository for two cars, a treadmill, two desks, empty suitcases and countless piles of paper. They hope it will be their financial future.

title: In Downpour and in Blowout, the Top Two Powerhouses Prove Their Points
description: Two years ago, Bob Stoops brought undefeated Oklahoma here for the Red River Shootout against Texas, its hated rival. It was only his second year as coach, and he did not know what to make of his team.

title: Sprewell Takes a Few Shots
description: Dressed in a caramel suit, Latrell Sprewell strode casually into Madison Square Garden 40 minutes before game time yesterday, stopped on the court to talk to his former teammate Allan Houston, hugged Garden employees in the hall and made his way into the visitors' locker room without a glance at the Knicks' locker room.

title: Business; In Search of Savings, Companies Turn to the Sun
description: JOHNSON & JOHNSON, an icon of American corporate culture, is showing a growing interest in a technology once associated with backwoods cabins and pocket calculators. Like a number of other large companies, Johnson & Johnson has begun to generate its own power from the sun.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-20

title: Officers Say Bosnian Massacre Was Deliberate
description: Eight years after the massacre of more than 7,000 Bosnians, doubts have lingered about the degree to which the killings were coldly planned, or were improvised in chaos.

title: INSIDE
description: California Economy Not Bad

title: Talking Comedy With the 'Office' Manager
description: RICKY GERVAIS is the co-creator (with Stephen Merchant) and star of the hit BBC comedy ''The Office,'' a mock documentary series that does for England's middle managers what ''This Is Spinal Tap'' did for its rock stars. On camera, Mr. Gervais plays the role of David Brent, an embarrassingly unfunny boss who spends much of the series showing off for the unseen camera crew and inadvertently humiliating himself in front of his employees. A DVD of the show's first season was released last week; the second season begins tonight on the cable channel BBC America. Mr. Gervais recently spoke with Robert Mackey by phone.

title: Why the Secrecy About Financial Covenants?
description: MANY companies have increased their financial disclosure recently, responding to shareholders' cries for greater details about their operations.

title: Adrienne Bohlin, David Thayer
description: Adrienne Danielle Bohlin, the daughter of Joan Taylor of Greenville, S.C., and Col. Daniel Bohlin of Ottawa, Ill., was married yesterday to David Bruce Thayer, a son of David L. Thayer of Springfield, Pa., and the late Audrey Thayer. The Rev. Albert Keller, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Circular Congregational Church in Charleston, S.C.

title: Neither There Nor There
description: TERRY J. O'CONNELL of Tolland thought he had reared his son, Brian, the right way. He bought him all the right memorabilia: a Red Sox baby cap to warm his head when he was born, a Pedro Martinez T-shirt when he turned 3. He taught Brian names and dates never to forget. Carlton Fisk. 1975. Bucky Dent. 1978. Bill Buckner. 1986.

title: Madame Chairwoman
description: If chairs are shaped like the human body, why not dress them in the trends of the season? We asked 10 design pros to do just that.

title: Palestinian Crisis Deepens as Premier Hints He Might Leave
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Oct. 12  The Palestinian political crisis deepened today when the recently installed prime minister, Ahmed Qurei, said he might leave the position when the current term of the emergency government expires in three weeks.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Pearl River, a store in SoHo that sells goods from China, referred incorrectly to Oct. 10, a day on which anti-Communists staged protests outside the store in the 1970's. Since 1912 this has been the official national day of the Republic of China and is still observed as such on Taiwan. It is not the anniversary of the founding of Taiwan.

title: Atkins Diet Through the Aisles or the Ether
description: TO help melt the pounds away, April Rosenberg and her friend Diann Rook go food shopping every two to three weeks. Ms. Rosenberg drives from her home in East Northport and Ms. Rook from Dix Hills. But they don't meet at the supermarket; neither are salad bars on the agenda. To satisfy their cravings but still watch their weight, the two women meet at the Atkins Nutritionals outlet in Ronkonkoma.

title: With Little Incentive, MetroStars Settle for Tie
description: After they were assured of a playoff berth, the MetroStars had little incentive against the Dallas Burn on Saturday night and settled for a scoreless tie before a crowd of 13,567 at Giants Stadium.

title: Hempstead Moves to Shut Down a Hotel
description: BOB RABEY remembers that when the Courtesy Hotel in West Hempstead opened on Hempstead Avenue in the 1960's, it was a benefit to the community. But over the years, he said, it has become a magnet for drug dealers and prostitution.

title: The Hottest Spot
description: SOWING THE WIND

title: The Battle Within
description: Suppose you're an architect, ambitious and eager to build. You're teaching theories of design at a university. You push your students to think and ask questions. You see yourself as an activist, aware of and inspired by ideas of civic responsibility. One day the department chairman tells you that he has received a report about your ''subversive activities.'' You have a choice: you can join the ruling party or leave the university. A high-powered friend advises you to leave and recommends you for a job with a government development project. Soon you're working alongside the biggest names in architecture, who have flown in from around the world to refashion your capital. The years go by. Slowly the budget money dries up. The famous names move on. Yet you are still toiling for the dictator.

title: Minnesota Watches Its 6-0 Start Fade in 15 Minutes
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 11  Perhaps the Minnesota Golden Gophers were prematurely thinking about drinking from the Little Brown Jug late Friday night when they entered the fourth quarter with a 21-point lead over the Michigan Wolverines.

title: Susan Jhun, Adam Balkin
description: Susan Jhun, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. U-Jin Jhun of Fulton, N.Y., was married on Thursday on the Greek island of Santorini to Adam David Balkin, a son of Robin Balkin of Livingston, N.J., and Jeffrey S. Balkin of New York. John Kavallaris, the civil registrar on Santorini, officiated at the Heliotopos Hotel in Imerovigli, Greece. On Nov. 27, Rabbi Dennis Tobin will lead a religious ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's mother.

title: At a Hartford Seminary, a Military Matter
description: SOMETIME this fall, Major Shareda Hosein, 42, an Army reservist and student at Hartford Seminary, will find out if the Army has accepted her application to become the first female Muslim chaplain in the history of the United States military.

title: Wind Energy Boosters Make Another Foray On East End
description: LIKE Don Quixote, advocates of wind energy on the South Fork are not giving up their fixation on windmills. Their latest proposal for clean electricity, presented last month to the Amagansett Citizens Advisory Committee, calls for a 100-foot-tall windmill on the Quail Hill Farm in that hamlet.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: MY COLD WAR

title: Fame = Power = Fame; Government by Celebrity Is Already Asserting Itself
description: AT the 1997 Vanity Fair Oscar party, perhaps the world's biggest annual pound-for-pound accumulation of celebrities, a tall, pale, perfectly coiffed man worked the edges of the room. He was already one of California's longest-serving politicians -- and its lieutenant governor. But his was hardly a household face, so he handed out business cards embossed with his name: Gray Davis.

title: Play Date With Destiny
description: I pose a question to those who will undoubtedly respond to Margaret Talbot's article (Sept. 21) by dubbing the parents the Mama Roses of sports: Do you believe these children developed a passion for their sports on their own? Or do you see the parents as having forced them into it? If the answer lies in the former, then perhaps the endorsements allow the kids to spend more time doing what they love than they could if their adventures had to be financed out of their parents' pockets.

title: Rangers Follow Bad Loss With One That's Worse
description: Like old dogs, it appears, the Rangers either will not or, more likely, cannot learn new tricks.

title: Paperback Advice
description: This

title: A Little Fascist Architecture Goes a Long Way
description: IF, as some say, writing a book is like having a baby, then the architect Peter Eisenman might just feel as if he has been pregnant for 40 years. Now 71, he first contemplated writing about the Italian architect Giuseppe Terragni when he was just a graduate student. Decades passed when the project was all but ignored -- but through all those years, a book was quietly gestating. This month, it entered the world, bearing the name ''Giuseppe Terragni: Transformations Decompositions Critiques.''

title: Ads on Parking Meters: An Idea Whose Time Has Expired
description: Ads on bus shelters? No problem. Taxis? O.K., especially if it means up-to-the-minute sports scores. But hawking wares on parking meters, it would appear, took things a bit too far.

title: A Son's Own Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Sales: Tax Law Confusion
description: CHANGES in the way the New York tax law applies to nonresidents that went into effect on Sept. 1 have resulted in confusion in some real estate closings, real estate lawyers say. And while the Assembly acted last Wednesday to join the Senate to resolve some the confusion, some issues remain, specialists say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JAFFE, NORMA
description: JAFFE--Norma. Died October 2, 2003. Beloved wife of David and loving mother of Paul, and the late Daniel. Graduate of Harvard (Radcliffe) and Columbia School of Social Work. Many years practicing and teaching psychiatric social work at NYC agencies.

title: Rooms Of Their Own
description: Helena Rubinstein was so crazy about design that she commissioned a wildly flamboyant etched and illuminated acrylic bed (above) from Ladislas Medgyes in the 1930's. Acrylic furniture was a new idea back then, but Rubinstein was nothing if not a confident patron. She knew her own style -- bold -- and stuck with it. But then, the same is true of all the designers featured in this issue. The architect Ron Radziner designed a house for himself and his family that is much more minimalist than the Neutra and Schindler houses his firm is known for restoring, but that perfectly channels their spirit of casual, California indoor-outdoor living. The decorator Thomas Jayne's own New York loft is eccentric rather than opulent, but its educated elegance is the product of someone who knows exactly what he is doing and doesn't need to impress anyone. It's never too late to discover your own style, as William Norwich found out (albeit the hard way). And once you've found it, don't let go. As my mother used to say, Why look like everybody else?

title: THE GUIDE
description: Shows at Silvermine

title: Less Police Presence Because of Fewer Officers
description: Re ''Mineola Wonders, Where Are the Police?'' [Sept. 28]: As a retired Nassau County police lieutenant, it is clear to me that the Nassau County Police Department can no longer provide the level of service that county residents have enjoyed in the past. The loss of almost 800 sworn personnel through attrition in the past four years has resulted in the department becoming a mostly reactive force instead of the ''service-oriented'' department that it once was. One has only to drive down any county road to see the results of the lack of any sustained police enforcement of the traffic laws and parking regulations. Routine, nonemergency calls for police service are being held for hours until an officer becomes available for assignment.

title: WHERE THE TRAIL LED: Between Evidence and Suspicion; Unclear Danger: Inside the Lackawanna Terror Case
description: The journey into the heart of Al Qaeda began here, in the frayed Yemeni-American neighborhood of this former steel town just south of Buffalo. For Sahim Alwan, a 28-year-old youth counselor, husband and father of young children, it led to a house in the Afghan city of Kandahar, where he came face to face with Osama bin Laden.

title: In the Age of Upscale, Garage Sales Lose Some Grunge
description: LOTS of us enjoy pawing through other people's junk now and again. Not many of us can get a television show out of it.

title: Sasha Schamber, Alex Chriss
description: Sasha Rose Schamber and James Alexander Chriss were married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Sarah Buteux performed the ceremony at the Cambridge Swedenborg Chapel.

title: Camilla Enders, James Bernfield
description: Camilla Valentine Enders, an actress, and James Brian Bernfield, who makes political commercials, are to be married this evening at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, in Manhattan. Judith Wank, the assistant leader for adjunct services at the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, will officiate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MERLIS, PHOEBE
description: MERLIS--Phoebe. On October 10. Wife of the late Lawrence. Mom to Barbara Malkoff, Andrea Hill, Laura Drubin and their spouses. Grandma of six. Finally comfortable.

title: Try It, It's Good For You
description: FOR parents like mine, who were born in Europe and live in the United States, it's a dream to be able to take one's children to see the Continent. Inspire their young minds with the elegance of Paris and the faded glory of Vienna, the lyricism of the opera and, when they are old enough, the earthier pleasures of French wine.

title: Giving Art a Hand
description: A friend purchased a painting from a professional artist. When she realized that the hands were poorly executed, she hired another artist to alter them. No legal document forbade her to do so. My instinct says this is wrong and probably illegal. My husband says the painting can no longer be considered a work by the original artist. What do you say? Marla Faith, Nashville

title: Remains Of the Day
description: ''FLAMBOYAN.'' ''OCK.'' ''HARLOW.'' The letters are brushed in white paint on a red brick wall in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, facing the playground of Public School 38. They are older than any student at the school; they have been there longer than any of the teachers. They are etchings from another era, fashioned by a hand that long ago grew too big to squeeze through the chain link fence to paint them.

title: Saratoga
description: To the Editor: It seemed a bit of serendipity that we saw ''What's Doing in Saratoga,'' by Joe Drape (Aug. 10), because we were going to be there Aug. 13 and 14. Indeed, the map with the article proved invaluable, as did the information about reserved grandstand seating at the Saratoga Race Course.

description: Local Talent

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 28 about Aretha Franklin referred incorrectly to her current relationship with the actor Glynn Turman, her second husband. They divorced in 1982, and Mr. Turman has remarried; they do not spend time together at her home in Detroit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILBERT, DR. HARRIET S.

Cherished grandmother of Michael, Jena, Aidan, Zachary, Olivia and Layla. Interment private. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, October 14th, at 5:00 PM.

title: Ideas & Trends; Tongue-Tied by Physics: The Ineffable Lightness of Being
description: IT was sometime early in the 1920's when words began to fail us. Whether one spoke and thought with the sharp granularity of German or the mellifluousness of French -- or in some hodgepodge like English -- it was impossible to translate the strange new ideas of physics into language. Not even Japanese was spacious enough.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in this section on Sept. 14 about Columbia University's relations with its neighbors misspelled the name of a residence for law students that opened this fall. It is Lenfest Hall, named for Gerry Lenfest, a Columbia Law School benefactor, not Lentfast.

title: Old Movie Palaces: Can They Be Saved?
description: LINDENHURST and Northport have two of the last few single-screen movie theaters left on Long Island. But both are closed, and their future is in doubt.

title: Introduction
description: Michael Lewis's portrait of the California political climate inspired spirited conversation on the roots of the recall. The article about tiny athletes who sport hefty endorsements prompted some to say: You go, boys! And no backstories on the leads in ''Law and Order''? No way.

title: When the Credit Check Is Only The Start
description: IN the old days, way back when faxing seemed innovative, selecting the right tenant for a vacant apartment usually required a building owner or manager to phone the previous landlord, talk with the applicant's employer, scan letters of recommendation, closely study the standard credit report and, sometimes, simply sit across the table and look the prospect in the eye.

description: THE MUSIC OF YOUR LIFE

title: Page Two: Oct. 5-11 -- The Week Ahead; GAY BISHOP RIFT
description: Church leaders representing the 38 branches of the worldwide Anglican Communion will meet in London to confront a growing crisis over homosexuality. Conservatives from Africa, Asia and Latin America are expected to demand that the Episcopal Church USA be disciplined for approving an openly gay bishop and for failing to forbid the blessing of same-sex unions. The conservatives are likely to seek recognition for the American churches that want to break away from the Episcopal Church. Laurie Goodstein

title: Taliban Suspects and Others Escape From an Afghan Prison
description: Up to 40 Taliban suspects and other prisoners escaped from a prison in the southern city of Kandahar, Afghan officials said Saturday. The prisoners, among them the brother of one of the country's most wanted men, had dug a well-constructed 30-yard-long tunnel from their cell and made a clean getaway at midnight Friday, said the deputy provincial governor, Muhammad Anas.

title: POSTINGS: The Gatehouse, a Landmark, Is to Be Converted; Performance Spaces Planned In Old Water Plant in Harlem
description: For years after it was built in 1890, the building with a prominent tower at West 135th Street and Convent Avenue in Harlem was used to distribute water from the Croton Aqueduct in Westchester to New York City. Eventually that system became obsolete, and the building, known informally as the Gatehouse, began to deteriorate over time. Nevertheless, in the 1980's it was designated as a historic landmark and listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

title: F.Y.I.
description: City and Country Birds

title: Revelations About Dutch Prince's Fiance Rattle Royal Family
description: Ordinarily so meticulous that she checks everything right down to her golden carriage, Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands was blindsided this week by a scandal involving her family and an organized crime figure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FULLER, JOSEPH SR., AIA
description: FULLER--Joseph Sr., AIA. Of Westport, CT, died peacefully at home on Sunday, October 5, 2003. Mr. Fuller was born on November 18, 1926 in Czechoslovakia. He was a member of American Institute of Architects and founder of Fuller and D'Angelo, Architects in Elmsford, NY. He is survived by his wife Zdenka, son Joseph, and his wife Susanne, daughter Victoria, and her husband Howard, grandchildren Elizabeth and Alexandra.

title: The Changing Church
description: The past 25 years have brought enormous changes for the Christian faith in Europe and Africa.

title: Patents; A fireplace log made of recycled coffee grounds burns brighter and hotter than sawdust logs.
description: Fake logs made of sawdust and paraffin, invented in the 1950's, are a popular alternative to real firewood. But ersatz logs have also been fashioned out of cardboard, almond shells, corn cobs, peach pits -- and now, recycled coffee grounds.

title: South Korean President to Put His Job to a Vote
description: President Roh Moo Hyun of South Korea, besieged by a faltering economy, a corruption scandal involving a former aide and declining support from the public, offered Monday to hold a national referendum to see just how much his countrymen trusted him.

description: Moviegoers who recently saw the Johnny Depp film ''Once Upon a Time in Mexico'' at the Pacific Sherman Oaks Galleria 16 cinema here may have noticed that something was different. Instead of the traces of dust and scratches, and the slight shaking of the image that is perceptible at many screenings, they were looking at a picture that is pristine, sharp and steady.

title: Rain Fails to Temper Game 3 Backdraft
description: Joe Torre stood in the middle of the visitors' locker room at 8 p.m. Sunday, ready to leave Fenway Park. He was supposed to be in the dugout, waiting for the first pitch of Game 4 of the American League Championship Series. But the game was rained out, and a reporter asked Torre if the Yankees and the Red Sox could use the break.

title: Seeking Support at U.N., Bush Offers Concession on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 — The Bush administration, yielding slightly in its opposition to diluting American authority over the Iraqi occupation, proposed today that the United Nations recognize the American-picked Iraqi Governing Council as a unit that "will embody the sovereignty" of Iraq until the country returns to self-rule.

title: In 30 Hours of Surgery, Twin Boys Joined at Head Are Separated
description: Two-year-old twin brothers from Egypt, joined at the head, were separated yesterday during 30 hours of surgery at Children's Medical Center in Dallas. Surgeons had spent more than a year planning and preparing for the operation, which required a medical team of 60 people working in shifts.

title: Review/Fashion; At This Dance, McQueen's The Last Man Standing
description: That fashion is so often equated with change has always seemed a funny notion, given how much it remains always and forever the same. Since the dawn of cloth, for instance, runway shows have followed an unaltered course. They begin with comparatively simple pieces meant to telegraph the designer's particular conceit (''Dorothy Hamill meets Dorothy Day'') and end with the most fantastic and costly iterations of the idea in play. By the time the mango-dyed sheared sable ball skirts come down the runway, the message of each and every fashion show is clear: the more you acquire, the greater the chances the world will treat you as if you rule over your own empire.

description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

Funny Cide's trainer, Barclay Tagg, decided to run in the Classic on Oct. 25 at Santa Anita after his New York-bred gelding turned in an impressive mile workout yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: The Snowmobile Quagmire
description: In mid-December the snowmobiling season is scheduled to open in Yellowstone National Park -- another winter of health risks for park workers and visitors, pollution haze over the west entrance and Old Faithful, the din of a fleet of noisy machines in an otherwise silent park and daily harassment of winter-stressed animals. By siding with the snowmobile industry and overturning a Clinton-era plan to phase out snowmobiles, the Bush administration would continue a practice that violates the conclusions of its own Environmental Protection Agency, the better judgment of many National Park Service employees, the public will and common sense. In its own small way, the snowmobile issue demonstrates once again that when it comes to public lands the administration is always willing to sacrifice public good for private interest.

In the first two there's an outright wail, a throb signaling both dark emotions and the struggle to subdue them; the CD of reimagined Beiderbecke music contains a pretty good representation of Beiderbecke's artistic mood -- serenity, with sadness advancing on it like a cold front.

Lee was born in Poland and her family left for Palestine in 1933. In 1938 she went to New York City with her father for the World's Fair and was joined by the balance of the family shortly thereafter. She was a member of the Standard Club and the Ahavath Achim Congregation in Atlanta until her husband Henry's death in 1979 and of Temple Emanuel in West Palm Beach for the remainder of her life. title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: PANAMSAT REPORTS 1.4% RISE IN 3RD-QUARTER PROFIT The PanAmSat Corpo- ration, the nation's largest commercial satellite operator, said yesterday that third-quarter profit rose 1.4 percent after it sold more satellite capacity to government agencies. Net income climbed to $21 million, or 14 cents a share, from $20.7 million, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 5.5 percent, to $210.1 million from $199.1 million. PanAmSat, which is based in Wilton, Conn., set up a new unit this year to serve federal agencies and bought two companies that provide communications services for the government. The chief executive, Joseph R. Wright Jr., is trying to win contracts from the Defense Department as sales to television broadcasters have been reduced by competition. PanAmSat shares rose 30 cents, or about 2 percent, to $16.06.    (Bloomberg News)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERKIN, RICHARD TALMAGE
description: PERKIN--Richard Talmage. Of New York City, on October 9, 2003. Age 72. Loving husband of Leslie Manning Bergesch, devoted father of Kristina, Nicolas and Caroline, and proud grandfather of Olympia Talmage Davison. Born on July 13, 1931, Mr. Perkin was the son of the late Richard Scott Perkin, a founder of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, and the late Gladys Frelinghuysen Talmage Perkin. He was a descendant of Captain Thomas Talmage, a founder of East Hampton in 1648, and Philip Rhinelander, an 18th century New York merchant. A graduate of Milton Academy (1950) and Harvard University (1954), where he was a member of the Spee Club, Mr. Perkin was chairman of the VZV Research Foundation, which he founded in 1991. The New Yorkbased foundation is the world's only nonprofit organization solely fostering research and education on infections caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), including chickenpox, shingles and post-herpetic neuralgia. Mr. Perkin was also chairman of The Perkin Fund, a family foundation that supports scientific research and the arts. He was a trustee of The Juilliard School and the Wildlife Conservation Society, and a member of the Executive Committee of the Rockefeller University Council. He also served on the New York Weill Cornell Council of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, the Visiting Committee of Harvard University's Department of Astronomy and the Committee for Planetarium Policy at the American Museum of Natural History. Prior to devoting his life to furthering scientific research and education on VZV, Mr. Perkin was active in public media, including television documentary syndication. In addition to his wife, children and granddaughter, Mr. Perkin is survived by a brother, Robert S. of Darien, CT, and a sister, Winifred Perkin Gray of Wenham, MA. Another brother, John Thorne, died in 1997. A memorial service will be held at St. Thomas Church, 1 West 53 Street, New York City, at 3:00 P.M. on Wednesday, October 15, 2003. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Mr. Perkin's memory may be sent to the VZV Research Foundation, Inc., 40 East 72 Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: fashfile

The result were elegant dresses incorporating this season's favorite crochet as well as lacy stitching and cutwork. The seductive and streamlined dresses included braiding worked into tropical flowers and even string to give textural interest.

Technology Briefing | Software: Electronic Data To Sell Part Of Software Unit
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said yesterday that it might sell part of a unit that makes software that General Motors and Ford Motor use to design, build and deliver cars. A public share sale or minority investor may be sought for the PLM Solutions unit, Electronic Data said in a statement. PLM, whose name stands for product life-cycle management, employs 5,000 people. Electronic Data is selling some operations to raise cash and focus on its main business of managing computer systems for other businesses. PLM's second-quarter sales fell 10 percent, to $205 million, while companywide revenue rose 2.4 percent to $5.52 billion with help from the dollar's falling value. Electronic Data, based in Plano, Tex., said in June that it would eliminate 2,700 jobs and sell some businesses to trim $5.83 billion in long-term debt. Shares of Electronic Data rose 28 cents, to $21.84.

title: FITCH CUTS WEYERHAEUSER'S CREDIT RATING TO JUNK STATUS
description: Fitch Ratings cut the Weyerhaeuser Company's credit rating to junk yesterday, saying the company, a producer of lumber and paper, was not generating cash fast enough to pay down debt. Weyerhaeuser's unsecured debt rating was cut to BB+ from BBB-, while the commercial paper ratings of Weyerhaeuser and the Weyerhaeuser Real Estate Company were cut to B, also a speculative rating, from F3, the lowest short-term investment grade rating. The rating outlook was changed to stable from negative. ''It is becoming increasingly difficult to see a sustainable improvement in the company's markets,'' Dennis Ruggles, a director in Fitch's forest products, mining and metals group, wrote. Moody's Investors Service rates the company's unsecured debt Baa2 while Standard & Poor's rates the debt BBB, both investment- grade ratings.

title: Kucinich, Declaring for President, Takes Populist Stance

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Survey Questions Product Freshness
description: A new statewide survey has found that dozens of convenience stores, discount drug stores, supermarkets and pharmacies sell expired over-the-counter medications, Eliot Spitzer, the state attorney general, said yesterday. State law requires that outdated medications be removed from store shelves. Last summer, the attorney general's office surveyed more than 100 stores and found about a third of them selling at least one expired product. Products included cough medicine, nasal sprays and allergy medicines. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Unit Sale Investigated
description: The chief executive of Deutsche Bank, Josef Ackermann, is being investigated by the Dsseldorf prosecutor over the sale of the bank's German insurance unit to Zurich Financial Services, a prosecutor, Bernhard Englisch, said. The prosecutor started the investigation after a complaint filed by an unidentified person, Mr. Englisch said. The investigation is at a ''very early stage'' and initial suspicion is ''relatively small,'' he said. Deutsche Bank said the allegations were ''unsubstantiated.'' Deutsche Bank sold its Deutsche Herold business to Zurich Financial in April 2002 in return for the Swiss insurer's Scudder fund management unit. The asset swap allowed Deutsche Bank to expand in asset management in the United States and Zurich Financial to expand in Germany.

title: A Disability Law Catch-22
description: The Social Security Administration has been not only mean-spirited but also illogical in handling Pauline Thomas's disability claim. It is an absurd decision, but one fully in keeping with the Bush administration's drive to cut back on spending for the needy. The Supreme Court, which hears her case today, should strike a blow for common sense by upholding her claim.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: LIBERATE TECHNOLOGIES TO TRIM WORK FORCE Liberate Technologies, which makes software to run cable television set-top boxes, will cut its work force to about 150 by December as part of a plan to sell its OSS division. Liberate, based in San Carlos, Calif., said the sale would help reduce expenses. The OSS division, which is based in Toronto and makes software to provide telephone and Internet service over cable television lines, will now be accounted for as a discontinued operation, Liberate said. Liberate reported that its fiscal first-quarter net loss narrowed $12.6 million, or 12 cents a share, in the period that ended Aug. 31, from $249.3 million, or $2.35 a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue fell to $1.55 million from $9 million a year earlier. Greg Wood, Liberate's chief financial officer, did not immediately respond to a voice mail message. The company announced last month that it spent $17.9 million on an insurance policy to cover legal expenses related to a restatement of financial results. The restatement reduced the company's revenue in the last three quarters of the fiscal year that ended on May 31, 2002, and in the first quarter that ended on Aug. 31, 2002. The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating Liberate's accounting.   (Bloomberg News)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Vehicle Seizure Law To Be Challenged
description: The state's highest court next week will hear a case that challenges a Nassau County law allowing the seizure of vehicles whose drivers are charged with drunken driving. The Nassau County law is similar to those in New York City and in Suffolk and Rensselaer Counties. The case involves Michaele Canavan, whose 1995 Saturn was seized by the authorities in 2000. Ms. Canavan later pleaded guilty to speeding and driving while impaired, but was unable to get her car back because of the county law. Her lawyers argue that the Nassau law is unconstitutionally vague and amounts to excessive punishment. The Court of Appeals is scheduled to hear arguments next Tuesday. Earlier this year, an appellate court ruled the law unconstitutional because it did not provide sufficient notice, was inconsistently applied and was limited to drunken-driving offenses. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAGADORN, BEULAH
description: HAGADORN--Beulah. Died on Thursday, October 2, 2003, after a long illness, at St. Joseph's Nursing Home in Yonkers. Dr. Hagadorn was born in North Ferrisburgh, VT, on January 11, 1918. She was a 1938 graduate of Middlebury College, and receieved an M.A. from the New York State College for Teachers, Albany, in 1939. Her first career was in banking; later she was a consultant and speaker. She was one of a number of business women recruited for leadership positions in the Schenectady school system and taught briefly before being appointed Principal of the Franklin Elementary School. During her time there, she commuted to New York on weekends and during summers to earn an Ed.D. at New York University in 1961. She was Principal of Van Corlaer Junior High School in Schenectady when the Board of Education in Bronxville asked her to come to Bronxville. She was Principal of The Bronxville Elementary School from 1970-1978. A memorial service will be held at The Reformed Church of Bronxville on Saturday, November 15, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Reformed Church for Church School Education would be appreciated.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Agrees To Drop Objection To Worldcom Bankruptcy Plan
description: The AT&T Corporation agreed yesterday to drop its objection to WorldCom's plan to exit bankruptcy and will seek to pursue allegations of improper call routing in another court. The companies announced the agreement in a filing with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, which is overseeing WorldCom's restructuring. WorldCom also won approval for the plan from creditors, who were entitled to vote on it again after the company settled with dissident bondholders. AT&T, which said it was duped into paying network-access fees owed by WorldCom, wants to press its claims outside the bankruptcy proceedings. Judge Arthur Gonzalez will rule on Oct. 21 whether a racketeering lawsuit AT&T filed against WorldCom last month can proceed in a Federal District Court in Virginia; WorldCom is based in Ashburn, Va. WorldCom is seeking to exit Chapter 11 protection around the end of 2003, pending the approval of Judge Gonzalez, who is expected to conclude hearings this week. Each of the nine groups of creditors entitled to weigh in on WorldCom's restructuring plan had to approve it by a vote of more than two-thirds. They represent $23 billion in claims.

Witnesses told the police that Ms. Henry had a green light at the time. Ms. Henry and her infant daughter were not injured. A Louisville police spokeswoman said no charges were expected though an investigation was continuing.    (AP)

He died in Durham, NC, October 10, 2003 in the presence of his loving partner Mark Ludwig. He is survived by two brothers, Houston and Philip, in Charlotte, NC, and many cousins in the Milton, Spangler, Van Hoy, and other families. He attended Duke University, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the Hazelden Graduate School on Addiction Studies in Minnesota; taught English at Clemson University, designed interiors and gardens in central NC, recently worked as a patient counselor at Hazelden, and was a very active member of the Episcopal Church, Alcoholics Anonymous and Democratic Party for many years. title: Lunch at 9:21, and Students Are the Sardines
description: John F. Kennedy High School, a sprawling eight-story building in the Bronx, has 4,590 students this year, 1,200 more than last. Lunch starts at 9:21 a.m., and all three of the cavernous cafeterias are packed until it ends more than five hours later.

title: Krone Will Ride Funny Cide in Breeders' Cup
description: Funny Cide, winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, will be ridden in the $4 million Breeders' Cup Classic by Julie Krone, the Hall of Fame jockey who has made a strong comeback on the West Coast after a three-and-a-half-year retirement.

title: Playwright Maps Limits Of the Best Intentions
description: Readers were supposed to feel superior to Mrs. X, the stay-at-home Park Avenue mother in ''The Nanny Diaries,'' last year's barbed, witty novel about the rich and callow. Long on fashion sense, short on maternal instinct, Mrs. X spared no expense on herself but was cheap with the help she hired to take care of her child. An easy target, perhaps, she was so much fun to disdain that the book -- by two young women, Emma McLaughlin and Nicola Kraus, who had been nannies -- became a best seller.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Join in Peace Draft
description: A group of prominent Israeli and Palestinian politicians, working outside official channels, have written a symbolic peace agreement that they hope could be a foundation for future negotiations.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the debate among astronomers over the shape of the universe misspelled the name of a Harvard scientist whose research helped rule out the possibility that it is shaped like a torus, or bagel. He is Dr. Matias Zaldarriaga, not Mattias Zaldarriago.

title: Study Links Prescriptions To Decrease In Suicides
description: Suicide remains a leading cause of death for American adolescents, but over the last decade, the rate of suicide among teenagers has declined. In a new study, researchers at Columbia University suggest that this drop may be linked in part to the increasing use of antidepressant drugs in young people.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Liberia: New Leader Is Celebrated
description: On the eve of what many Liberians imagine to be a new era after 14 years of war, Charles Gyude Bryant, the businessman charged with leading a new government, arrived in the capital, Monrovia, went to church and prayed. Mr. Bryant is to be sworn in this morning. At the airport, he was led through a phalanx of well-wishers, given a live chicken as a traditional gesture of welcome and whisked off to a prayer service. Thousands lined the streets to welcome his convoy into the city, cheering and shouting. They waved banners and handkerchiefs and yelled, ''No more war!'' One man said he hoped Mr. Bryant would usher in a new age. ''Tomorrow, it shouldn't be like old wine in a new bottle,'' he said. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Intelligence Puzzle: North Korean Bombs
description: New intelligence estimates that North Korea may have produced one or two nuclear weapons in recent months -- or perhaps more -- have immersed the administration in another internal debate about the quality of intelligence about illegal weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCDONOUGH, LORRAINE D.
description: McDONOUGH--Lorraine D. On October 11, 2003, of Garden City, NY, and Stuart, FL. Beloved wife of the late Donald J. McDonough. Devoted mother of Donald J. Jr. (Janet), Jane Tuck (John), Mary Anne Angst (Chuck), Francis J. (Harriette), Cornelius J., Timothy J. (Cindy), and Lorraine Kelly (Gregory). Also survived by 15 cherished grandchildren. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St, Garden City, 79 PM, Monday, and 2-4 and 79 PM, Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, 10 AM, Wednesday. Interment to follow at Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Miracle Foundation, P.O. Box 7338, Garden City, NY 11530, appreciated.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tory Leader Denies Wrongdoing
description: Iain Duncan Smith, the Conservative Party leader trying to fend off an effort by mutinous party members to remove him for what they say is ineffectiveness, faced charges of having paid his wife $30,000 in public money for a no-show post. Calling the claims malicious, Mr. Duncan Smith said, ''I completely and absolutely rebut any allegation about wrongdoing.'' The charges will be investigated by the Parliament's commissioner for standards. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Panamsat Reports 1.4% Rise In 3rd-Quarter Profit
description: The PanAmSat Corporation, the nation's largest commercial satellite operator, said yesterday that third-quarter profit rose 1.4 percent after it sold more satellite capacity to government agencies. Net income climbed to $21 million, or 14 cents a share, from $20.7 million, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 5.5 percent, to $210.1 million from $199.1 million. PanAmSat, which is based in Wilton, Conn., set up a new unit this year to serve federal agencies and bought two companies that provide communications services for the government. The chief executive, Joseph R. Wright Jr., is trying to win contracts from the Defense Department as sales to television broadcasters have been reduced by competition. PanAmSat shares rose 30 cents, or about 2 percent, to $16.06.

title: NASD Fines Firm Over Conferences
description: Wells Investment Services Inc. and its president, Leo Wells, were fined $150,000 for violating regulatory restrictions on conferences held for broker-dealers, NASD announced yesterday.

title: On Diamond, Immaturity Is Forever
description: IN some quarters of this city, Boston seems to be the new France. See how bad things can get when a sports rivalry goes off the rails?

title: Joan B. Kroc, 75, Owner of the Padres And Philanthropist
description: Joan B. Kroc, a prominent philanthropist, a former owner of the San Diego Padres and the widow of Ray A. Kroc, the founder and chairman of the McDonald's Corporation, died on Sunday at her home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. She was 75. The cause was brain cancer, a spokesman said.

title: Unsafe on the Field, And in the Stands
description: To the Editor:

title: Anesthesia and Its Effects
description: To the Editor:

title: Scaling Back Changes On Regents Standards
description: When the New York State Board of Regents voted last week to delay holding all students to higher standards for at least two more years, they portrayed it as a simple ''mid-course correction'' that was to be expected.

title: Gilding not-so-golden oldies
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Bring out your old, your tired, your droopy clothes, from the back of the closet, and Monique Montgomery will make them look like a million dollars.

title: Wells Hurt Groin Muscle in Fracas
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre confirmed Monday that pitcher David Wells tweaked a groin muscle while ascending the dugout steps to participate in the bench-clearing incident in Game 3 on Saturday. Torre said Wells felt fine and added that Wells would have pitched on Sunday if the game had not been rained out. Details of Wells's injury were first reported in Newsday on Monday.

title: MEMO PAD
description: Every business traveler who stays at midlevel to top-shelf hotels has noticed the trend in recent years: in many hotels, the mattresses and sheets are often of better quality than customers have in their home bedrooms.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Prosecutor Criticizes Federal Officials
description: A prosecutor in the state case against Terry L. Nichols in the Oklahoma City bombing wrote to Attorney General John Ashcroft to say, ''The unwillingness of the federal government to allow federal witnesses to talk to the defense has brought this case to the brink of dismissal.'' The letter was prompted by a ruling by the judge in the case, Steven W. Taylor of District Court, indicating that he might dismiss it or strike the state's request for the death penalty based on the federal government's lack of cooperation. Mr. Nichols is serving a life sentence on federal charges for this role in the bombing of the federal building in Oklahoma City in 1995. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Not-for-Profit Credit Counselors Are Targets of an I.R.S. Inquiry
description: The Internal Revenue Service is investigating the business practices of nonprofit credit counseling services, which advise millions of people in debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEILBRUN, CAROLYN G.
description: HEILBRUN--Carolyn G. Her neighbors at the Kenilworth Apartments mourn her passing, and extend to her family our deepest sympathy. John F. Geer, President

title: China's Long March Into Orbit
description: When Moscow put the first humans into space 42 years ago, Soviet officials raised a veil of secrecy. They made sure the genius behind the feat was a nonperson, awarding his medals in private. They lied about the spaceport's location. And they said the heroic astronaut had landed his spacecraft, when in fact he had ejected from his capsule high in the atmosphere and parachuted back to earth.

title: It's Gas vs. Heritage in Navajo Country
description: The Navajo revere this remote area around a tabletop mesa in northwestern New Mexico as the place where the mythical figure Changing Woman gave birth to two warrior sons who made the universe safe.

title: Presenting a Prostitute With a Photograph of Jupiter
description: 'Touch'

title: Pregnancy Created Using Egg Nucleus Of Infertile Woman
description: Doctors in China have become the first to make an infertile woman pregnant with an experimental technique devised in the United States for women who have healthy genes but defects in their eggs that prevent embryos from developing.

title: You Can Keep Reloading 'The Matrix Reloaded'
description: Wachowski fever breaks out today, and three small films arrive with little fanfare (and few extras). Sol Hurok and Rudolf Bing spar in the early days of television, and Godfrey Reggio and Philip Glass explain their third ''qatsi.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHOEMAKER, BILL
description: SHOEMAKER--Bill. The Officers and Trustees of the New York Sports Museum & Hall of Fame regret the passing of a charter member of the New York Sports Hall of Fame on October 12 in San Marino, CA. Bill Shannon, President Jordan Sprechman, Sec'y

title: Miscellany
description: * The Aegis Group, London, acquired Isis Research, London, which sells health care research to pharmaceutical companies in Europe and Japan, for cash and stock worth as much as 23.8 million ($39.6 million). Isis becomes part of Synovate, the market research unit of Aegis.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Liberate Technologies To Trim Work Force
description: Liberate Technologies, which makes software to run cable television set-top boxes, will cut its work force to about 150 by December as part of a plan to sell its OSS division. Liberate, based in San Carlos, Calif., said the sale would help reduce expenses. The OSS division, which is based in Toronto and makes software to provide telephone and Internet service over cable television lines, will now be accounted for as a discontinued operation, Liberate said. Liberate reported that its fiscal first-quarter net loss narrowed $12.6 million, or 12 cents a share, in the period that ended Aug. 31, from $249.3 million, or $2.35 a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue fell to $1.55 million from $9 million a year earlier. Greg Wood, Liberate's chief financial officer, did not immediately respond to a voice mail message. The company announced last month that it spent $17.9 million on an insurance policy to cover legal expenses related to a restatement of financial results. The restatement reduced the company's revenue in the last three quarters of the fiscal year that ended on May 31, 2002, and in the first quarter that ended on Aug. 31, 2002. The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating Liberate's accounting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEWCOMB, LOUISE BLASER
description: NEWCOMB--Louise Blaser. Louise Blaser Newcomb died on Saturday, October 11, 2003, in her home in Salisbury, Connecticut at the age of 96. She was the widow of Russell Ladd Newcomb. Mrs. Newcomb was born in Somerville, Massachusetts in 1907. She attended local schools and graduated from Thayer Academy in Braintree, Massachusetts. She worked in the Boston area following graduation at a number of companies including AT&T, and married Russell on Thanksgiving Day, 1937. Together they lived in New York City, Tarrytown, New York and Chappaqua, New York, where she founded the Chappaqua Dancing School. In 1955, the Newcombs moved to Norwich, Vermont, where they created Norwich Enterprises, which had real estate and retail holdings. For many years, Mrs. Newcomb managed the North Country Store in Norwich, VT. Following Russell's death in 1980, Louise moved to Kent, Connecticut and subsequently Salisbury, Connecticut. She was passionately interested in helping provide community-wide access to books of all types and was a trustee of the Norwich, VT public library, the Kent, CT public library, and more recenty, was active in expanding the library at Noble Horizons in Salisbury, CT. She is survived by her two sons, Danforth and Jonathan, her sister Harriet Buckley, and four grandchildren. A reception for family and friends will be held at her home in Noble Horizons in Salisbury on Sunday, October 19. Memorial contributions may be made to the Louise B. Newcomb Book Fund, Noble Horizons, Salisbury, CT. 06039. For more information contact The Kenny Funeral Home, 41 Main Street, Sharon, CT.

description: N.B.A.

title: A Pianist Glances Back At Russian Tradition
description: Despite the deserved acclaim that Evgeny Kissin has won for his technically incomparable and deeply communicative playing, a minority of listeners, I among them, have had qualms about its sometimes exaggerated expressivity, a throwback to the Russian Romantic tradition.

title: Looking for Answers After the Dust Settles
description: A STRANGE thing happened last night at Fenway Park. Before Game 4 of the American League Championship Series, Joe Torre and Grady Little sat around and answered several baseball-related questions. Some guys just don't get it, huh?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CURTIS, LAURA E.
description: CURTIS -- Laura E. died peacefully in her sleep October 10, 2003. She was the daughter of James Freeman Curtis, a New York attorney who was the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury under President Taft. Her mother was Laura Miriam Curtis Gross founder of the exclusive 1925 F Street Club in Washington, D.C. Her brothers, James F. Curtis, Jr. and Frazier Curtis died in World War II. Her sister, Pauline Hollingsworth, and her stepsister, Gloria Horn, predeceased her. She married George H. (Pete) Bostwick in October 1933. He was a leading amateur steeplechase rider and polo player. She had two sons, George H. Bostwick, Jr. and James F.C. Bostwick who were former world open court tennis champions and outstanding amateur golfers. Her daughter, Laura Bostwick of Wanchese, North Carolina was a world class angler. Laura Curtis was divorced in 1949 and soon after went on to qualify for the U.S. amateur golf championship. Her aunts, Margaret and Harriot Curtis won four U.S. amateur golf championships. In 1908 Margaret also won the U.S. doubles amateur lawn tennis championship with Evelyn Sears. The Curtis sisters went on to donate the Curtis Cup to foster an international golf match between the United States and England. Burial will be private. Donations may be made to the Alzheimers Disease and Related Disorders Association, Long Island Chapter, 66 South Street, Patchogue, New York 11772.

title: Ex-Banker Has a Chance To Explain Testimony
description: Frank P. Quattrone's fate will soon be placed in the hands of 12 jurors who have spent the last two weeks listening to witnesses recreate events in the days and hours before he pressed the ''send'' button on an e-mail message to his staff at Credit Suisse First Boston, endorsing a colleague's directions to ''clean up those files.''

title: No Easy Homecoming For the Philharmonic
description: Lincoln Center, while publicly welcoming the New York Philharmonic back to the fold, is expected to argue that the orchestra has voided its contract and must renegotiate it. In particular Lincoln Center is seeking more advance notice about the orchestra's programming -- three to five years instead of the current two -- to give Lincoln Center more flexibility in planning its own presentations in Avery Fisher Hall when the Philharmonic is not playing.

title: You, Too, Could End Up In the Presidential Suite
description: In a recent commercial for Lexus car dealers, a desk clerk tells a weary traveler his room is not available because the hotel is overbooked, but he can have one on another floor at the same rate. When the guest opens the door, he finds himself in the presidential suite, complete with floor-to-ceiling windows, a piano, ice sculpture and hors d'oeuvres, the last two obsequiously delivered by the clerk who checked him in.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the settlement of a software copyright lawsuit involving Lineo, a former sister company of the SCO Group, misstated the name of the plaintiff. It was MontaVista, not Monte Vista.

title: AIDS and Abstinence
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: SEARCH ENDS FOR 4 FISHERMEN The Coast Guard has called off a search for four Maine fishermen who disappeared off the coast of Nantucket over the weekend. The men were fishing on the Candy B II, a 46-foot wooden scallop boat, when it set off a radio beacon without a distress call on Friday morning, a Coast Guard spokeswoman said. The spokeswoman, Petty Officer Amy Thomas, said two cutters, helicopters and jets spent more than 60 hours searching for the fishermen. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: The Rumbling of the Esophagus
description: People with obstructive sleep apnea, a disorder that disrupts sleep, often suffer from acid reflux, a generally painful gastrointestinal disorder.

title: Two Stories of Dead Brothers Give a Peek at Conrad's Heart
description: 'Tales of Unrest: Joseph Conrad on Stage'

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; Sharper Mussina Is Pierced Again By Wakefield
description: Mike Mussina's forehead was resting on a large, green exercise ball as he sat in the trainer's room at Fenway Park late Monday night. He would lift his head every couple of seconds or minutes, stare at the wall or rub his fingers across the ball and then put his head back down on it. Mussina was like a sleepless infant trying to find a comfortable spot on a pillow.

title: Swine and Dining
description: To the Editor:

title: The Colors of Paradise As Imagined by Gauguin
description: When Paul Gauguin sailed from Marseille for Tahiti on April 1, 1891, he was confident of finding a terrestrial paradise with natives living in sensual harmony with nature and ancient deities. That image had been reinforced by early travelers and by a book published to coincide with the 1890 Colonial Exhibition in Paris. The Tahitians ''know only a life of sweetness,'' it noted, adding, ''For them, to live is to sing and love.''

title: Our Way: Root And Hoot
description: Last week I visited Tucson, and then flew back to attend a Yankees-Red Sox playoff game. It occurs to me that some of my friends in the Southwest may be watching the series on TV, and may be alarmed by some of the behavior they are seeing on the field and elsewhere. They may think it impolite to grab a 72-year-old man by the head and toss him to the ground, or throw hard objects at people's faces, or hold dueling press conferences calling each other names.

title: Overstock.com Adds Travel to Its Wares
description: Overstock.com, an Internet retailer that sells surplus merchandise from other companies, will add travel to its list of products.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Mother Charged In Fatal Fire
description: The mother of two children who died Sunday in an apartment fire in Canarsie was arraigned yesterday on two counts each of reckless endangerment and endangering the welfare of a child. The woman, Kim Brathwaite, 35, had left her daughter, Justina Mason, 9, and son, Justin Brathwaite, 17 months, home alone in the family's basement apartment on Saturday night, the police said. A Fire Department official said the fire was set deliberately, though investigators had not determined whether it was set by the children, or by someone else. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Kittles Is Simply Taking Care of Business for the Nets
description: Kerry Kittles sat on the bench and watched the Nets' season collapse during the fourth quarter of Game 6 of the N.B.A. finals last season.

title: Calling for Peace, Bryant Is Sworn In as Liberian President
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Oct. 14 — Charles Gyude Bryant, until recently a little-known entrepreneur, was sworn in today as the head of a power-sharing provisional government that is intended to unite Liberia's warring factions and help bring peace to a country torn by 14 years of sporadic warfare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DARVIN, LEONARD
description: DARVIN--Leonard. A retired general counsel for the Comics Magazine Association of America, died October 13, 2003 of natural causes in Albany, NY. He was 94. Mr. Darvin was born in Poland, but grew up in Baltimore, MD. During his early teens, he won the Maryland State Championship in track and was also a member of a prominent group of literary scholars. At 18, he published a well-received volume of poetry, entitled ''Little Portraits.'' At this time, he was editor of a literary quarterly, called the ''Adolescent.'' He earned a law degree from the University of Maryland in 1936 and after practicing law in Baltimore for several years, moved to New York City in 1945. He was a lobbyist and counsel to the Dental Laboratory Association of NY for 11 years. Following his retirement, after 25 years at the Comics Magazine Association of America, he continued to serve as a consultant for another 10 years. In addition, he was an accomplished artist with a special interest in portraiture. His wife, Dorothy, two daughters, Marcia Spada and Iris, two grandchildren, Justine and E.R. (wife Kim), and great grandson, E.R., survive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILBERT, HARRIET S., M.D.
description: GILBERT--Harriet S., M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of a beloved colleague, teacher and friend. Dr. Gilbert was an outstanding member of our staff for more than forty years. A world-renowned hematologist, she was a pioneer in describing the Myeloproliferative Diseases. She demonstrated extraordinary concern for her patients and was a valued ''mother figure'' and mentor for generations of students and residents. She was an executive officer of the Polycythemia Vera Study Group and chaired the Biomedical Advisory Committee of the New York Academy of Sciences. Harriet and her late husband Dr. Paul Gilbert were dedicated supporters of Mount Sinai. We extend our sincere condolences to her entire family. Anthony Squire, M.D.-Pres. Vicki Lopachin, M.D.-Sec'y. Amy Weinstein-Admin.

title: New Pill Fuels Debate Over Benefits of Fewer Periods
description: Kristy Sokoloski, 32, has chosen not to menstruate.

title: Scares are back in style this Halloween as marketers pump up the ghoulishness quotient.
description: MARKETERS are again grappling with the best tone to strike in Halloween advertising, but seem to have agreed that this year there is nothing for them to fear but missed sales.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Body Found In Van
description: The body of a man was found yesterday in the front seat of a van in Ridgewood, Queens, the police said. The van attracted attention after it had been parked for two days in front of an auto body shop on Irving Avenue, said the shop's manager, Alberto Rodriguez. He called the police about 11 a.m. after peering in and seeing the body of a man who appeared to be in his late 30's. Mr. Rodriguez said the body was covered in blood and was partially naked. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: NORTHERN IRELAND: LEADERS PUSH ELECTION PROCESS Substantial progress in the Northern Ireland political stalemate, but no breakthrough, was reported after talks between Prime Minister Tony Blair; his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern; Richard N. Haass, President Bush's special envoy; Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army; and David Trimble, leader of the province's largest Protestant party. They are working against a deadline this week for rescheduling elections to a power-sharing assembly.    Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Hearing On Media Curbs
description: The Constitutional Court began hearing a complaint filed by nearly 100 legislators and journalists who say an election law passed in June restricts press freedom. Under the law, news organizations can be shut down during an election campaign for critical coverage of a candidate. Elections to the lower house are set for Dec. 7, and the head of the commission that wrote the law said its goal was to rein in smear tactics like those of the parliamentary campaign in 1999. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Suit Over Injury to Whales Ends In Deal to Limit Navy Sonar Use
description: The Navy has reached an agreement with environmental groups that restricts the use of a powerful new sonar system that could injure marine life to an area in the western North Pacific Ocean.

title: Report Finds Faults With Medicaid Managed Care Program
description: People are dropped from the Medicaid rolls in New York too frequently, only to re-enroll later, hindering the program's ability to cut costs and provide high-quality health care to millions of poor people, a report says.

title: New Draft of U.S. Resolution Gives Iraqi Council a Deadline
description: The Bush administration, seeking broader support for a United Nations resolution on Iraq, made small changes in its proposed language on Monday, including setting a date, Dec. 15, for the Iraqi Governing Council to begin taking on more power. But there were also new snags in the drive to get more troops and aid to Iraq.

title: People
description: * Jon Mandel, co-chief executive at MediaCom U.S., New York, part of the MediaCom Worldwide division of the Grey Global Group, added the duties of global buying officer for MediaCom Worldwide, a new post. Ariadne Callas, co-chief executive at MediaCom U.S., will also be its president, a new post.

title: Where Faith Grows, Fired by Pentecostalism
description: For many, this highway leads to the future of the Christian faith, and at 9 o'clock on a Friday night, traffic is heavier than a Los Angeles rush hour.

title: An Ethnic War That Still Rages
description: Today in Vienna, the first-ever talks will begin between the autonomous government of Kosovo and its former rulers in what we now call Serbia and Montenegro. Although the participants say they will cover only ''technical matters,'' others have hinted at higher stakes. Bill Clinton last month told cheering crowds here -- there is a Bil Klinton Boulevard in Pristina -- that the talks could ''create for the world a model of positive interdependence.'' Richard Holbrooke, the Clinton administration's point man on the Balkans, and Bernard Kouchner, the founder of Doctors Without Borders, wrote in The Wall Street Journal that today's meeting ''is the beginning of something that could be very important.''

title: Daschle Signals More Scrutiny for Bushs $87 Billion Request
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  Some Democrats are taking a much harder look than first anticipated at President Bush's request for $87 billion for American efforts in Iraq and Afghanistan, with Senator John Edwards of North Carolina saying this afternoon that he will vote against it.

title: Ship of Glass for Chelsea Waterfront
description: The proud city sails on. Frank Gehry has designed a New York headquarters for Barry Diller, the media and e-commerce mogul. The new building will be opposite the Chelsea Piers sports complex, on the West Side Highway between 18th and 19th Streets. It will also be on the East Side of Bicoastal City, the dual metropolis that has emerged from the symbiotic cultural competition between Los Angeles and New York. Buda, meet Pest.

title: The Rangers Aren't Planning Any Changes
description: The Rangers opened their season over the weekend by sputtering through two defeats by a combined score of 10-3, but Coach Glen Sather is not about to start recalling players from the minor leagues or waiving high-profile players.

title: S.E.C. Examining Funds Trading At Another Firm
description: Wilshire Associates, the investment advisory firm, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was examining trades in mutual funds made by its chief executive. It joins a growing list of financial services companies that have acknowledged that their employees had some role in the rapid trading of mutual funds.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Economy Grows
description: Industrial production in Italy rose unexpectedly in August for a third month as record temperatures led to a surge in energy use. Production at factories, mines and utilities rose 0.1 percent from a revised 1.8 percent in July, which was the biggest gain in more than a year, the Rome-based national statistics office Istat said. Analysts said the data show that Italy's economy is stabilizing and may be emerging from a recession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAY, ESTHER
description: KAY--Esther. Our deepest condolences to Kenny, Robin, Alexis, and Austin. Our thoughts are with you during this difficult time. Linda, Peter, Alex, Caroline

description: WHENEVER tons of money is being spent on astonishingly conspicuous consumption, someone always has a story of a Middle Eastern moneybags.

title: She Sees Art, and You're Walking on It
description: In the modern life of New York City, the subway grate has played many worthy roles. It has wafted Marilyn Monroe's skirt. It has provided a pond in which to fish for stray quarters. It has served as a heater for the homeless and, in Washington Heights, where the trains run deep and cool, as air-conditioning for the people.

description: HER HUSBAND

title: G.I. Mailbag: Form Letters To the Editors
description: At least 11 American newspapers have inadvertently published identical or nearly identical letters from soldiers serving in the same unit in Iraq, each signed by a different person, as a result of a coordinated effort in the unit to get positive news about the war printed in their hometown papers, an Army spokesman traveling with them said yesterday.

title: For the One That Got Away
description: Part breath, part smoke, part sob: that's the voice of Beth Gibbons, who has made it her mission to reinvent the torch song. Her 1990's band, Portishead, helped define the bleak, slow-dancing languor of trip-hop. And fans of Portishead filled St. Ann's Warehouse in Brooklyn on Friday night to hear her new collaborations with Rustin Man, the nickname for Paul Webb, who played bass in Talk Talk. They have just released an album, ''Out of Season'' (Sanctuary), which provided all the material for Friday's hourlong set.

title: Delluccis Patience at Plate Gives Him Nod Over Garcia
description: BOSTON, Oct. 13  David Dellucci did not know he would be starting in right field and batting against the knuckleball pitcher Tim Wakefield in Game 4 of the American League Championship Series until he arrived at Fenway Park on Monday, but he quickly put the assignment in perspective.

title: Farmers Help Deliver Modified Crops to Brazil
description: Brazil's decision in late September to legalize the planting of genetically modified soybeans may have infuriated environmentalists and some in the government, but it has caused much rejoicing and relief in the farming community here in Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil's southernmost state, where farmers have been planting transgenic soybeans illegally for years.

title: Accounts
description: * Atlantis Foods, Lantana, Fla., a supplier to the food-service industry, to Zimmerman Partners Advertising, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., part of the Omnicom Group, to handle the national introduction of Fresh Soup, a line of ready-to-eat refrigerated soups that Atlantis will sell directly to consumers. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $7 million.

title: William Bennett, 49, Guitarist Who Was a Mentor to Many
description: William Bennett, a rock guitarist and entrepreneur whose studio near ground zero provided a haven to frustrated performers with day jobs on Wall Street who dreamed of playing live rock and roll, died on Oct. 7 at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was 49.

title: Motorola Releases Earnings in Rebuff to Debt-Rating Cut

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: MOTHER CHARGED IN FATAL FIRE The mother of two children who died Sunday in an apartment fire in Canarsie was arraigned yesterday on two counts each of reckless endangerment and endangering the welfare of a child. The woman, Kim Brathwaite, 35, had left her daughter, Justina Mason, 9, and son, Justin Brathwaite, 17 months, home alone in the family's basement apartment on Saturday night, the police said. A Fire Department official said the fire was set deliberately, though investigators had not determined whether it was set by the children, or by someone else.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Executive To Resign
description: The German bank WestLB said its chief executive, Johannes Ringel, will step down in March. Mr. Ringel, 62, took over only in July from Jrgen Sengera, who had to step down after the state-owned bank posted a record loss of 1.7 billion euros ($1.9 billion) in 2002 because of bad loans. WestLB, which is based in Dsseldorf, said Mr. Ringel's revamping efforts would be continued by his successor. Mr. Ringel, left, plans to step down on March 31. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Ford Expanding Venture
description: The Ford Motor Company said that it and its affiliate Mazda Motor would invest 21 billion baht ($533 million) in their Thai manufacturing joint venture, AutoAlliance Thailand, to expand its production capacity to 200,000 units annually from 135,000. The eight-year-old Thai factory produces pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles for sale in Thailand and for export to more than 130 countries, Ford said. Thailand, it said, has become the second-largest market for pickup trucks outside the United States. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Turk Cautions on Peril From Kurds
description: A senior Turkish Army officer said Monday that military leaders are considering basing peacekeeping troops they are sending to Iraq in the central or western part of the country. To get there, however, they would need to cross through the Kurdish north.

title: Army Is Studying Suicide in Ranks
description: Army officials sent mental-health experts to Iraq last month to study cases of suspected suicide among ground troops and determine whether sufficient counseling was available, a Defense Department official said Monday.

title: WebMD Says Profit Will Be Below Forecast
description: WebMD, which manages transactions between health care providers and insurers, cut profit estimates yesterday as it spent more to conform to new privacy rules and had lower-than-expected software sales. Its shares fell 9 percent.

title: The Collections / Paris: YSL: shooting for the hip
description: The quiet death of feminist fashion is the overall message of four weeks of international collections, which close in Paris on Tuesday. The most noteworthy change is the eclipse of the formal pantsuit in which a generation of women fought for equality in the world of work. Although there are still many variations on pants and even tailored suits with shorts, skirts  and especially dresses  have been given prominence.

Professor Joe's love of life, literature, and of others is treasured and celebrated by countless friends, family, colleagues and students.

title: Bolivian President Remains Defiant as Protests Intensify
description: Thousands of demonstrators marched in Bolivia's capital and other nearby cities on Monday, calling for the president's resignation. But they were dispersed by military units firing tear gas canisters, and at a midafternoon news conference President Gonzalo Snchez de Lozada was defiant and pugnacious.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Accused In Apartment Fire
description: A man whom the police described as intoxicated was arrested and accused of setting a fire outside the door of his estranged girlfriend's fourth-floor apartment in Sunset Park yesterday morning. The police said the residents of the apartment building, at 570 Seventh Avenue, fled and no one was hurt. After firefighters put out the blaze, the stairs from the third floor to the fourth collapsed, a Fire Department official said. The man, Carlito Perez, 52, was arrested on charges of arson and violating an order of protection that required him to stay away from his girlfriend, whom the police did not identify. The girlfriend was not in the apartment when he set the fire, the police said, but the two had argued earlier in the street. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YELIN, DOROTHY

Profit excluding some items will be $2 to $2.10 a share, down from an earlier forecast of $2.20 to $2.30. The forecast excludes about 10 cents in revamping costs, Lubrizol said.

Died on October 8, 2003 at the age of 83. He was a Californian, raised in San Francisco, graduated from The Phillips Exeter Academy, Yale University and Harvard Business School. During WW II, he served with the U.S. Marines in the Pacific Theater and North China. As President and Director of The Interocean Oil Companies and other independent international oil exploration companies, his career in the petroleum industry spanned fifty years. A Memorial Service will be held at Christ Memorial Chapel, 52 South Beach Road, Hobe Sound, Florida on Saturday, November 22, 2003 at 4:00 PM. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his memory to Jupiter Island Clinic, P.O. Box 375, Hobe Sound, Florida 33475 or to a charity of your choice.

description: MetLife said yesterday that it had it formed a joint venture to sell policies in China with the the Capital Airports Holding Company. ''There's a great untapped market in China for life insurance,'' Mr. Calagna said. International insurers like MetLife are entering China as the government eases restrictions on investment after decades of dominance by state companies.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: ELLINGTON: CHEMICAL LEAK PROMPTS EVACUATION About 1,000 people were evacuated from their homes early yesterday after a leak at a juice processing plant sent a cloud of ammonia gas into the surrounding neighborhood in north central Connecticut. No serious injuries were reported. The leak, reported about 2 a.m., occurred in the refrigeration tanks at Natural Country Farms, off Route 83, officials said. The leak was stopped about 9 a.m. Assistant Fire Chief Gary Feldman said firefighters evacuated the area and called in hazardous-materials teams, which entered the building just before 6 a.m. Tests found that even in areas of heavy concentrations of the ammonia, there were no dangerous levels of the gas in the air, officials said.   (AP)

title: Ram Gopal, Dancer, Is Dead; Opened Western Eyes to India
description: Ram Gopal, one of the greatest Indian dancers of the 20th century and a pioneer in acquainting Western audiences with traditional Indian dance, died on Sunday in a nursing home in southwest London. He was believed to be in his 80's or early 90's.

title: Profit Increases at Polaris
description: Polaris Industries said yesterday that third- quarter profit rose 6.5 percent, helped by sales of its off-road products and Victory motorcycles.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Drugs From Canada
description: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich is asking consumers to help lobby federal officials to change a policy that makes it illegal for Americans to buy prescription drugs from Canada. Mr. Blagojevich, a Democrat who, along with the governors of several other states, is studying the possibility of buying medicines for state employees from Canada, began an online petition drive. The Web site is affordabledrugs.il.gov. Mr. Blagojevich and others say drugs bought in Canada could help spare Americans from mounting prescription bills. Monica Davey (NYT)
