description: The Israeli Army raided the southern Gaza Strip town of Rafah again on Tuesday in a search for smuggling tunnels, while the military revived a contested tactic by expelling 15 Palestinian detainees from the West Bank to Gaza.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: HUGHES 3RD-QUARTER LOSS WIDENS Hughes Electronics, owner of the DirecTV satellite television service, said its third-quarter loss widened to $23 million as the company wrote down the value of two Latin American units. Sales rose 17 percent. The net loss was $13.6 million a year earlier, Hughes said. Revenue rose to $2.57 billion from $2.19 billion as DirecTV added subscribers in the United States. Hughes said it would have earned $41.6 million before a $64.6 million charge for an accounting-rules change. The News Corporation agreed in April to buy a 34 percent controlling stake in Hughes from General Motors for $6.6 billion in cash and stock. As Hughes awaits government approval of the purchase, it is adding customers in the United States with the N.F.L. Sunday Ticket program package and by offering local TV channels in more cities. Hughes shares fell 8 cents, to $15.46.

title: Financing Unit Leads General Motors to 3rd-Quarter Profit

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Reaction Mixed On U.N. Vote
description: The Afghan government and the United Nations mission in Afghanistan welcomed the decision of the Security Council to allow peacekeepers to be deployed beyond the capital, Kabul. President Hamid Karzai said he was ''glad the voice of Afghans for better security has been heard by the international community,'' and the foreign minister, Abdullah, above, said it would send a strong message to the ''enemies of peace'' that the commitment of the international community was long-term. But Afghan military and police officials reacted warily to the news, showing the age-old Afghan aversion to foreign troops on Afghan soil. Many representatives of nongovernmental organizations were also critical, saying that the world was short-changing Afghanistan with a deployment that that was inadequate for the job. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

They thought it was all, perhaps, more about power on earth than power in heaven.

title: For a Genius of the Off-Cut, Lunch Time Is the Right Time
description: FOR nine years, St. John in the Smithfield district here has sailed along, lending dignity to the esoteric and overlooked -- dishes like marrowbones and parsley salad, deviled lamb's kidneys and bakewell tarts. It has thrilled some and has sent others running back to their steaks. It has been well liked, yet has never gained the credit it deserves. It is one of the world's great restaurants. And you know it, not just because the food is extraordinary, but because it is impossible to think of another restaurant like it.

title: Baseball as Theater, Starring the Yanks
description: Unfair as it is to review a production before the curtain comes down, the 2003 season of the New York Yankees has already been epic in its narrative arc. An ambitious comic drama, unpredictable in its streakiness and sharp turns, its sine curve of climaxes and nadirs, it began with a clownish subplot (David Wells's book) and a brush with tragedy (Derek Jeter's freakish opening-day shoulder injury), and it has approached its conclusion the same way.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Plea Agreement For Informant
description: An F.B.I. informant who was a chief lieutenant of the fugitive Boston gangster James J. Bulger pleaded guilty to 10 murders and racketeering charges in a plea agreement with the government. In exchange, prosecutors in the federal case will recommend life in prison for the defendant, Stephen J. Flemmi, 69. Mr. Flemmi will also plead guilty to first-degree murder charges and cooperate with Oklahoma investigators, who say he was involved in the 1981 killing of a Tulsa businessman, Roger Wheeler. A former F.B.I. agent who supervised Mr. Flemmi, H. Paul Rico, was charged last week with helping arrange Mr. Wheeler's killing. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Cargill Earnings Decline
description: By Reuters

title: Carl Fontana, 75, Trombonist Who Improved Jazz Technique
description: Carl Fontana, a jazz trombonist whose effortless-sounding virtuosity became widely known through his tenure with the Woody Herman and Stan Kenton bands, died on Thursday in Las Vegas, where he lived. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRISCHLING, IRVING
description: FRISCHLING--Irving. Our sincere condolences to Rosely, Steven, and their families. To our dear friend, Cuppy: The love, caring and devotion you, Delly and your children showered on ''Pop'' surely was the reason he was happy and fulfilled these past several difficult years. In Pop's Washington Heights grocery store Cuppy, working side-byside his Dad throughout the 40's and 50's, learned from Pop's example the importance of kindness, consideration and caring for people of every station in life without distinction, and how to live one's life always acting as a ''mensch.'' You and Delly have now passed on this important legacy to your own children. No wonder your Dad was so proud of you, Cuppy. Audrey, Harvey, Eric and Mark Feuerstein

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REINING, HELEN JOYCE
description: REINING--Helen Joyce, on October 13, 2003, of Pelham Manor, N.Y. and Littleton, MA. Wife of the late Francis Lowery Reining, mother of Francis E. Reining of Narragansett, R.I. and Marco Island, FL., Elizabeth Schmidt of Littleton, MA, and Mary Reining Winters of New York City. Sister of Alice McCaddin and the late Harry Joyce, Rita Gleeson and John Joyce. Grandmother of eight. Reposing at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham, N.Y. (914-738-1060). Visiting hours Thursday 3-5 and 7-9PM. Mass at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Pelham, N.Y. Friday at 10AM. In lieu of flowers contributions to Life Care Center, Nashoba Valley Resident Activity Fund, C/O L. Mountain, 191 Foster St, Littleton, MA 01460 or local animal shelter.

title: Cubs Handed One More Cruel Twist
description: The next ghost for the Chicago Cubs to conquer was supposed to be the World Series, not one seated down the left-field line.

title: Police Think Deadly Fire Was Arson
description: A fire that killed two children left home alone in Canarsie, Brooklyn, on Sunday appears to have been deliberately set by a third person, Fire Department officials said yesterday. Investigators had at first been considering the possibility that the children, 9 years old and 17 months, had started the fire themselves.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Killer On Suicide Watch
description: Andrea P. Yates, 39, convicted last year of drowning her five children in the bathtub of their Houston home, has been placed under a suicide watch at the state psychiatric facility where she is serving a life sentence. A lawyer for Mrs. Yates, George Parnham, said she had shown signs of improvement in recent months but had relapsed into psychosis and was being kept in isolation as a precaution. At Mrs. Yates's trial, defense psychiatrists testified that she suffered from schizophrenia and depression at the time of the killings, in 2001, but a jury decided that she had sufficient understanding of her action and convicted her of murder. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: On Bashing Bashar
description: At a sandwich lunch at The Times, Howard Dean was asked what his message would have been to Israelis about their recent strike into Syria to destroy a terrorist camp after a suicide bomber's atrocity in Haifa.

title: Pataki's Controversial Federal Judge
description: Dora Irizarry's nomination to be a Federal District Court judge in Brooklyn has drawn unusually intense opposition. Most recent battles over judicial nominees have been over ideology, but Ms. Irizarry has drawn fire for a lack of judicial temperament, and for the degree to which her selection smacks of political debt-paying. The people who appear in Brooklyn's federal court deserve better.

title: Hoping for a Waterfront Makeover Just South of Chelsea Piers
description: For the last three decades, Pier 57, a hulking three-story structure that juts more than 700 feet into the Hudson off 15th Street in Manhattan, has functioned as a parking garage for New York City Transit buses. And for the last three decades, the pier has not changed much, even though the landscape around it has been overhauled, most notably by Pier 57's next-door neighbor, the recreational behemoth Chelsea Piers.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Everything's been great so far, Mom. And it ain't over yet.''

title: Schumann to Spiritual, Expression in the Details
description: Words seem an ineffective medium through which to convey the complete satisfaction afforded by Thomas Quasthoff's song recital at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. Really to echo what went on, each word would have to be invested with nuance, tone and color, giving it the same power of direct communication and expressiveness that Mr. Quasthoff gave his song texts. There would also have to be a lot of words to convey the evening's length, extended by encores because the audience didn't want to let this singer go.

title: On Furlough, Soldier Savors Every Moment
description: Juan Castillo just came home from war. Now he is going back.

title: A Quiet Entrance By Italian Companies
description: The oddly titled Tuscan Dance in Movement series crept into New York almost unannounced. And audiences eager to learn something about modern dance in Italy and about the five participating companies, all new to New York, got no help from the Italian government agencies presenting the mini-festival as part of the promotional Tuscan Dream in New York.

title: Stock Exchange Chief Backs Smaller Board
description: John S. Reed, the interim chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, endorsed a report that recommends that the exchange shrink its current board from 27 to 17, with directors representing nonsecurities companies becoming the majority, state pension fund officials said yesterday.

title: Giants' Defense Now Waits For the Offense to Improve
description: In the past two weeks, the Giants' defense has gotten better, but the team's record has gotten worse. It is a turn of events that has Michael Strahan, their defensive leader, as baffled as anyone.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HIRSCHSPRUNG, ABRAHAM
description: HIRSCHSPRUNG--Abraham. ''Yoselle'' June 9, 1929-October 15, 1998 Some may forget you, but not I. To live on in the heart of even one person, is not to die. Your sister, Sylvi

title: Trade Center Wrangling
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Exactly Felix and Oscar, but an Odd Couple All the Same
description: I have to admit that ''Distant,'' the director Nuri Bilge Ceylan's wry, modest meditation on pettiness that opens tonight at the New York Film Festival, didn't initially grab my attention. It was on a second viewing that the minimalist scale of the Turkish comedy-melodrama, which received the grand jury prize at this year's Cannes International Film Festival (admittedly, not always an indicator of worthiness), began to work its spell on me. The cinematography was always striking -- the marble grays and cobalt blues of Mr. Ceylan's palette are at first calming and initially maddening -- and rendered in a series of long shots, with a sure hand. (The director was also director of photography, in addition to writing and producing the film.)

title: DiPietro Helps the Isles Salvage a Tie
description: The Islanders thought their biggest obstacle Tuesday night would be playing against an emotional Atlanta team. But their toughest task was playing through their own sloppy, disjointed performance, and only some brilliant goaltending by Rick DiPietro helped them to a 2-2 tie.

title: Duck Honors Its French Kin
description: A FEW years ago, Robert Rosenthal, the owner of Stone Church Farm in Rifton, N.Y., came across a reference to the prized Duclair duck of Normandy. He found that it was a cross between a wild male and a domestic female, and little else. But that was enough to get him crossing his own ducks.

title: Expendable to Pirates, Indispensable to Cubs
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 14  If the Cubs win the World Series, they can thank the Pittsburgh Pirates. Sammy Sosa has already planned to send a note of gratitude.

title: What a Building Says About Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets in Brooklyn? These Stars Support It
description: Some of Brooklyn's finest homegrown basketball talent gathered at Junior's Restaurant yesterday to support Bruce Ratner's attempt to buy the Nets and move them to Brooklyn.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer's Profit Falls
description: The British department store chain Debenhams, which is up for sale, said pretax profit for the year ended Aug. 30 fell nearly 2 percent from the year before to 151 million ($252 million). Sales increased 6.7 percent in the year, but the company spent 17.4 million on ''bid related costs.'' Separately, British regulators said that bids would not be accepted for the retail chain after Nov. 4. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: WorldCom Names Chief Ethics Officer
description: WorldCom, seeking to rebuild its image after an $11 billion accounting scandal, yesterday appointed Nancy Higgins to the new position of chief ethics officer. Ms. Higgins, 52, will report to the chief executive, Michael D. Capellas, the company said. Ms. Higgins most recently served in a similar position at Lockheed Martin, WorldCom said. WorldCom, the nation's second-biggest long-distance telephone company behind AT&T, was suspended in July from winning new contracts with the federal government, its biggest customer. With the help of New York University and the University of Virginia, WorldCom is providing ethics training for its 55,000 employees and contractors in the United States. The company has also hired more than 400 accountants. WorldCom filed for bankruptcy in July of last year after the disclosure that it hid losses by disguising billions of dollars of costs as capital investments. Before her tenure at Lockheed Martin, Ms. Higgins was a corporate lawyer at Boeing.

title: Clark Wants Civilian Reserve To Provide National Service
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark called yesterday for a national service program, envisioning a voluntary civilian reserve that would allow people to be activated in times of national need.

title: Bomb at Turkish Embassy In Baghdad Kills Bystander
description: A car bomb exploded outside the Turkish Embassy here on Tuesday, killing the bomber and one bystander, witnesses said, wounding several people and sending another message to those who would assist the United States-led occupation.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Locked Out, Queens Truck Drivers Are Angry
description: It was still pitch-dark outside the Star Corrugated Box manufacturing plant in Queens yesterday morning when Dominick Jacino, a 59-year-old trucker, showed up for work. A supervisor had told him and the plant's other 20 drivers to arrive at 4 a.m. for a drug test, Mr. Jacino said.

title: Sure They're Cans, but They Have Class
description: Would you dare give a dinner party by just opening some cans and slicing up salami and cheese? Josh Cohen and Maio Martinez, who own Biscuit, a Brooklyn barbecue spot, have opened a restaurant with a menu of just such food.

title: Fire Dept. Drill On Bioterror Is Set for Today
description: The Fire Department will simulate its response to a bioterror attack today on Staten Island, conducting practice smallpox vaccine inoculations on every firefighter and emergency service worker in the borough.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Hughes 3rd-Quarter Loss Widens
description: Hughes Electronics, owner of the DirecTV satellite television service, said its third-quarter loss widened to $23 million as the company wrote down the value of two Latin American units. Sales rose 17 percent. The net loss was $13.6 million a year earlier, Hughes said. Revenue rose to $2.57 billion from $2.19 billion as DirecTV added subscribers in the United States. Hughes said it would have earned $41.6 million before a $64.6 million charge for an accounting-rules change. The News Corporation agreed in April to buy a 34 percent controlling stake in Hughes from General Motors for $6.6 billion in cash and stock. As Hughes awaits government approval of the purchase, it is adding customers in the United States with the N.F.L. Sunday Ticket program package and by offering local TV channels in more cities. Hughes shares fell 8 cents, to $15.46.

title: What Can a Million Buy in Manhattan? Something Average
description: The Census Bureau says that the typical American household made $42,409 last year. At that rate, this family could buy an average-priced Manhattan apartment after just a little more than 21 years, if luxuries like food and clothing were skipped and entire incomes were forked over. And then there's the maintenance.

title: C.D.C. Adjusts Anti-Obesity Campaign
description: The Centers for Disease Control is changing an anti-obesity campaign aimed at children that was criticized for being too vague.

title: AURORA FOODS TO MERGE WITH PINNACLE FOODS
description: Aurora Foods and the Pinnacle Foods Corporation will be combined as part of Aurora's plan to file for bankruptcy protection and reduce debt. J. P. Morgan Chase, which owns Pinnacle, and J. W. Childs Equity Partners will contribute $83.8 million to the company, Aurora said. Aurora, which has had $596.3 million in total losses since 1999, said in July that it planned to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Holders of Aurora notes due in 2007 and 2008 will exchange their debt for shares of the combined company, giving them a 42 percent stake. J. P. Morgan and J. W. Childs will get a 49 percent stake. Senior loans will be paid in full.

title: Misguided Faith on AIDS
description: In August, the United States Agency for International Development abruptly canceled bids for a program to market condoms to gay men and others in Brazil. When the decision was criticized publicly, the agency reinstated most of the program. This was the right choice. Preventing the spread of AIDS means working with the groups most at risk.

title: What a Building Says About Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Say Doctors May Not Be Punished for Recommending Medical Marijuana
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 - The Supreme Court, in a silent rebuff on Tuesday to federal policy on medical marijuana, let stand an appeals court ruling that doctors may not be investigated, threatened or punished by federal regulators for recommending marijuana as a medical treatment for their patients.

title: About New York; Tales Sweet As Ice Cream, Salty as Tears
description: ''YOU tell the ice cream story.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about Rush Limbaugh's broadcast disclosure of his addiction to prescription painkillers gave an incorrect year in some copies for the impeachment of President Bill Clinton, an action for which Mr. Limbaugh mobilized support. It was 1998, not 1999.

title: What a Building Says About Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Whale Deaths Linked to Sonar
description: Even as Congress is poised to exempt the Navy from many environmental restrictions on the use of sonar in the oceans, along comes new evidence that the acoustic signals may be causing severe damage to sensitive whales. A report by British and Spanish scientists suggests that midfrequency sonar from an international naval exercise last year may have caused a disorder similar to decompression sickness, or the bends, in 14 whales that died after beaching themselves in the Canary Islands.

title: Trail of Clues Preceded New York Testing Fiasco
description: IN recent years, as New York introduced its new exams required for high school graduation, there were many signs of trouble in the state testing program.

title: Baseball Fans, Behave!
description: To the Editor:

title: The N.R.A.'s List
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEILBRUN, CAROLYN G.
description: HEILBRUN--Carolyn G. A Memorial Service will be held today, Wednesday, October 15 at the Fourth Universalist Society, 160 Central Park West (76 St.) at 4:00 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELDCHTEIN, NAUM
description: FELDCHTEIN--Naum. President of Kings International. On October 13, 2003. Beloved husband of Sarita. Loving father of Debra, Grace and Ernesto. Cherished grandfather of Brandon, Maria Eugenia and Luciana. Services Wednesday, 11:15AM ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Lawsuit Says Manhattan High School Illegally Discharged Students Without Hearings
description: A New York advocacy group has filed a class-action suit against Martin Luther King Jr. High School in Manhattan, charging that it is illegally turning away students because of their age, poor grades, poor attendance or pregnancy.

title: Coca Culture
description: There has been rioting in Bolivia for nearly four weeks now. News reports say that the riots have been over the construction of a pipeline to ship natural gas to the United States. That's true, but there's a deeper anger at work: anger toward the United States and its war against a traditional Bolivian crop, coca.

title: Guidelines Issued For E-Mail Advertising
description: In an effort to help preserve e-mail messages as an advertising medium, three organizations representing advertisers, agencies and direct marketers issued guidelines yesterday to encourage responsible use.

title: A Right-to-Die Battle Enters Its Final Days
description: Ever since Terri Schiavo's heart temporarily stopped beating one winter night in 1990, leaving her severely brain damaged, she has been a woman without a voice.

title: Wakefield Is Joker In Manager's Deck
description: John Burkett is rested and is a veteran pitcher not likely to crack under the pressure of what could be the concluding game in the American League Championship Series. But he is not as good as Tim Wakefield, or at least the Tim Wakefield whose knuckleball has been dipping, dancing and diving, much to the bafflement of the Yankee lineup.

title: Key Players for Knicks Are Among the Missing
description: The Knicks went west without the cavalry, the sounds of veteran leadership staying faint in the distance.

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; Garciaparra's Fall of Discontent
description: Nomar Garciaparra has actually claimed that he does not get immersed in the ancient, fascinating rivalry between his Boston Red Sox and the Yankees because he is from California. So he apparently wants millions of passionate fans, some who slept outside Fenway Park for a fleeting chance to attend Tuesday's game, to believe that this is just another series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOBLE, JOHN DARCY
description: NOBLE--John Darcy. Friend, mentor and inspiration for Kiki's Doll House where Gertrude Stein and Man Ray toast him at midnight over a loaf of pain bleu. Salut! Judith Mallin

title: The Atlantic Oil Boom Proves Slow in Coming
description: As oil and gas began flowing from wells off Newfoundland and Nova Scotia in the late 1990's, hopes arose of an offshore energy bonanza to rival the North Sea or the Gulf of Mexico. Now, after a string of disappointing drilling results, prospects of a major new source of energy on North America's doorstep are fading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, ANN
description: GOLDSTEIN--Ann. We are deeply saddened over the death of Ann Goldstein, beloved mother of our good friend, Dr. Matthew Goldstein, esteemed Guest of Honor for the forthcoming American Friends of The Open University of Israel Annual Gala, later this month in New York. The loss of one's beloved mother is more than merely heartfelt; it is painful to the very core in each of us who cherishes the unique and unconditional love, comfort and guidance bestowed by one's mother, from infancy and childhood into adult life. We extend our deepest sympathy to Matthew and the entire Goldstein family. We know the unique educational leadership and accomplishments of Matthew Goldstein imbued her life with motherly pride and fulfillment. May her memory be for a blessing. Jeffrey S. Wiesenfeld, Gala Chair Irwin Hochberg, Chair Sen. Seymour Lachman, VP Eric Heffler, Exec. VP American Friends of The Open University of Israel

title: HOST MARRIOTT BUYS HOTEL IN HAWAII FOR $321 MILLION
description: The Host Marriott Corporation has agreed to pay $321 million for the Hyatt Regency Maui Resort and Spa in Lahaina, Hawaii, its first hotel in the state. The 806-room hotel sits on 37 acres of oceanfront land and has a 9,000-square-foot spa. The purchase price equals $398,000 a room, the company said. An affiliate of Blackstone Real Estate Advisers, a unit of the buyout firm Blackstone Group, is selling the hotel. Hawaii is a difficult market in which to build hotels, keeping competition for the Hyatt low, Host Marriott said. Host Marriott said it was buying the hotel for 20 percent less than its replacement cost and that the purchase would add to earnings immediately.

title: Panel Seeks to Oust Justice For History of Improper Acts
description: A state panel that oversees judges recommended that a Mount Kisco town justice be removed from the bench after it found that he had ''detracted from the dignity of his office'' by railing against a prosecutor from the bench and improperly handling his private law clients' money.

title: Trumpets, Diaries and Cocktail Jiggers
description: Louis Armstrong did not catalog his possessions according to the rules of library science. For example, though he kept song indexes for his collection of 650 reel-to-reel tapes in neat three-ring binders, he curiously alphabetized titles by their last word. So ''The Girl That I Married,'' on side one of reel No. 44, is cataloged on the line above ''In the Mood.''

title: Blind Jews Accuse a Publisher of Discontinuing Braille Texts
description: Jewish members of the National Federation of the Blind yesterday accused the major producer of Jewish texts and scripture for the sight-impaired of abandoning Braille publishing and undermining their ability to worship.

title: CALENDAR
description: Food for Scholarship

title: Bush's $70 Million War Chest Dwarfs That of Democrats
description: President Bush's re-election campaign reported on Tuesday that it had more than $70 million in the bank as of the end of last month, an amount that dwarfs anything amassed by the Democratic candidates and that is expected to pay for a huge advertising and get-out-the-vote effort starting early next year.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PEPSICO, Purchase, N.Y., formed a joint venture with Unilever, London and Rotterdam, to increase sales of Lipton tea overseas.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Deborah C. Brittain; Tacos, Stir-Fries and Cake: The Junior League At 102
description: ''THEY say the most popular books are the Bible and cookbooks,'' Deborah C. Brittain said. ''And we know that our books sell.''

title: Calling for Reconciliation, New Liberian Leader Takes Office
description: Urging forgiveness and rebuking lawlessness, Charles Gyude Bryant, a businessman, took power on Tuesday afternoon, charged with leading a government of national reconciliation for this war-weary nation.

title: Serena Williams Mending, But Return Is Not Yet Set
description: Serena Williams won't say when she will return to the women's tennis tour.

title: Support for Irradiating Beef
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLERGAN TO BUY DRUG COMPANY FOR $230 MILLION
description: Allergan, the maker of Botox antiwrinkle treatments, has agreed to buy Oculex Pharmaceuticals for $230 million to add drugs for treating eye diseases. Allergan has been shifting its focus to pharmaceutical sales after spinning off a business last year that makes eye-surgery devices. Oculex, which is closely held, develops products to treat eye diseases, Allergan said. The company expects to complete the purchase by the end of November. Allergan, which is based in Irvine, Calif., said it would record 75 percent to 90 percent of the purchase price as a research and development expense in the fourth quarter of 2003. Oculex is based in Sunnyvale, Calif.

title: Beijing Vows To Aid Poor And Deepen Market Policy
description: The new leaders of China's ruling Communist Party closed a secretive annual planning session on Tuesday with a broad pledge to deepen market reforms and help the poor, but they did not detail any new economic or political policies.

title: Ireland Has Large Stake in Horses
description: Things were moving slowly at the annual yearling sale at Goffs, Ireland's largest auctioneer of thoroughbreds. Breeders wandered through a sprawling complex of stables to cast their eyes over majestic animals that in the hands of the right trainer could become racetrack legends. But by late afternoon on the first day, no horse had fetched more than 300,000 euros ($351,000).

title: What a Building Says About Us
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SERBS AND KOSOVO ALBANIANS MEET Serbian and Kosovo Albanian leaders met in Vienna and began their first direct talks since the war in 1999, under Western pressure to reconcile by tackling practical problems like power supply and missing persons. But the two sides remain bitterly divided, with Serbia insisting that Kosovo remain part of its territory while Albanians demand independence from Belgrade. European Union leaders who have pushed the sides to talk hailed the initial three-hour meeting as a first step, although Kosovo's ethnic Albanian prime minister stayed away.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Gold Stake Acquired
description: The Barrick Gold Corporation has agreed to pay $152.8 million for a 29 percent stake in Highland Gold Mining, Russia's fourth-biggest gold producer. Barrick is initially acquiring a 10 percent interest from Harmony Gold Mining of South Africa, and will later raise its stake by buying newly issued Highland stock. Harmony has sold its remaining 21.7 percent interest in Highland, which is based in London, to unidentified institutional investors. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Living Longer and Larger: It's in the Size of Cholesterol-Carrying Molecules
description: Scientists trying to figure out why just 1 person in 10,000 lives to be 100 have found an important clue in the blood.

title: E.P.A. Nomination Advances but Senators Vow Tough Vote Ahead
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15  Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah won the bipartisan endorsement of a Senate committee today to head the Environmental Protection Agency. But he still faces a delay on his confirmation vote.

title: WINE CALENDAR
description: October Fests

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Web Service Bidder
description: Seeking to thwart a $500 million bid by a consortium that includes the American International Group, the LG Group of South Korea said it would soon announce a joint investment plan with a United States fund to gain control of the country's second-largest broadband Internet service provider. LG is the largest shareholder in the Internet service provider, called Hanaro Telecom. LG, which already owns subsidiaries involved in mobile and fixed-line phone services, seeks to gain control of Hanaro to expand its telecommunications business. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: China Sends a Man Into Orbit, Entering the U.S.-Russian Club
description: The Chinese spacecraft Shenzhou 5 blasted off from the Gobi Desert on Wednesday carrying a single astronaut. The launching left government leaders jubilant yet also anxiously awaiting his safe return so China can stake its claim as one of the world's elite space-faring nations.

title: Survivor in Gay Union Appeals Denial of Benefits to Boy
description: Eva Kadrey and Camille Caracappa had been a couple for five years before they decided to have a family together.

title: Hard-Rock Clown Finds His Inner Softie
description: The moment that the self-titled debut CD from To My Surprise wins the listener over is when the guitar solo kicks in on the first track, ''The World's Too Small.'' This is chiefly because it is not played on an instrument, but is sung with nonsense words like ''bwaaa bwa bwa.'' Beyond that, the song is a quirky alternative-rock hit-to-be in the tradition of bands like Cake, the Presidents of the United States of America and Harvey Danger.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Opposition Leader Against Vote
description: President Roh Moo Hyun faced a hurdle in his plan to call an unprecedented national referendum on his rule as opposition lawmakers said they would not tolerate such a vote if it did not directly address a bribery scandal involving a former top aide to the president. The leader of the opposition Grand National Party, which controls Parliament, also said that Mr. Roh should step down if any link to the scandal is found. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: Trade minister fears economic backlash : Iraqi urges caution on free markets
description: SINGAPORE:  Iraq's economic restructuring risks failure at the hands of free-market ideologues, the country's interim trade minister warned on Monday.

title: Wells Channels Ruth to Keep Curse Alive
description: There is a road sign here on an overpass above Storrow Drive, a few long fly balls from Fenway Park. It is supposed to say ''Reverse Curve,'' but a zealous Red Sox fan with a can of spray paint found it too much to resist. Now the sign says ''Reverse the Curse,'' the battle cry of a region starved for a championship.

title: Meet Bourbon's Cousin, A Real Smoothie
description: Michter's US*1 Small Batch Unblended American Whiskey is not a bourbon, though it is made in bourbon country (Bardstown, Ky). While bourbon must contain 51 percent corn and be aged in new charred white oak barrels, Michter's uses other grains in addition to corn and is aged in used bourbon barrels, which give it a sweet vanilla bouquet.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: SARA JENKINS, left, whose rustic Italian food first gained attention at I Coppi, is now the chef at 50 CARMINE, the three-month-old restaurant at that address (near Bleecker Street) owned by PAOLA BOTTERO, who also owns Paola's on the Upper East Side. Ms. Jenkins cooked in a more Mediterranean style at Il Buco and tried to do even less Italian food at Patio Dining, all in the East Village. But at 50 Carmine, the food she said she likes best, rustic Italian, has won out, including what might be her signature touches of bread crumbs and croutons in dishes like cast-iron squid with garlic and parsley; wilted escarole salad with anchovy dressing; and bucatini with black cabbage. ''It would be nice to stay here for a while,'' she said.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: And They Say He Lacks Dimension

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINBERG, ALFRED J.
description: FINBERG -- Alfred J. Of Brooklyn and East Brunswick, NJ, on October 12, 2003. Food technologist. Beloved husband of Bernice (nee Aks), and loving father of Stephanie Graham and Charles Finberg. His first wife Edna (nee) Miller, predeceased him.

title: EQUITY FIRM BUYS CAT FOOD COMPANY FOR $425 MILLION
description: The Cypress Group, a private equity firm that manages more than $3.5 billion, has acquired the Meow Mix Company, the maker of Meow Mix and Alley Cat brand cat food, for about $425 million. The Cypress Group bought an 80 percent stake in Meow Mix, with the rest owned by the company's management and an investment firm, J.W. Childs Associates, said the managing director of the Cypress Group, Christopher Harned. Meow Mix was founded in February 2002 after Nestl bought it from the Ralston Purina Company. The company, which is closely held, is based in Secaucus, N.J.

title: Death Shares Commuter Tracks; New Jersey Suicides Illustrate Morbid Lure of the Rails
description: In Manville, N.J., last Friday a killer apparently tried to disguise his crime by placing the victim's body on the freight rail tracks, where it might be viewed simply as another suicide under the wheels of the 6:20 train.

title: Free of Marx, but Now in the Grip of a Dynasty
description: It is a touching scene, on huge posters all around the city: the eager, respectful son, his hand on his chin, listening to the wisdom of his father, President Heydar Aliyev, the man who has held Azerbaijan in his grip for the past three decades.

title: For Wine That Puts Up a Fight, a Meal That Bites Back
description: OF all wines, I find lean, sharp whites like muscadets, pinot blancs and chenin blancs the most difficult to pair with foods. They are excellent wines to sip before a meal, when you want something that shakes the palate with bright acidity, and wakes it from its occasional slumber.

title: Fewer Students Are Enrolling For Tutoring
description: For the second year in a row, tens of thousands of New York City public school students who qualify for free tutoring under federal law will not get the extra help, companies that provide the tutoring said yesterday. The companies and some advocates said that information about the program was poorly disseminated and that parents once again were not given enough time to enroll.

title: Witnesses Say Ship Was Moving Faster Than Usual
description: AStaten Island ferry struck a pier while trying to dock in Staten Island this afternoon, and officials said at least 10 people were dead and about three dozen were injured. Witnesses said the ferry appeared to be moving faster than usual when it hit the dock and pilings crashed through the side of the boat.

title: Inside the City That Never Stops Eating
description: Myra Alperson, who leads bicycle and walking tours in New York City and writes a newsletter called Nosh News, has logged thousands of miles while eating her way around the city. ''Nosh New York'' (St. Martin's Griffin, $16.95) is her latest guidebook, crammed with a neighborhood-by-neighborhood survey of places to eat in every borough but Staten Island.

title: Jets Share the League Lead In Sacks, and Look for More
description: Even in the bleakest days of the 0-4 start in the season's first month, the Jets' defensive line was free of the lukewarm assessments of the linebackers, or the speculation about which players would disappear in an off-season purge, as the secondary was hearing.

title: Sports of The Times; From Fringe, Yankee Joins List of Heroes
description: THE starting lineups had already been distributed in the press box, but suddenly, just before the game, attendants were passing out new lineup cards. Instead of having David Dellucci in right field and batting ninth, the Yankees were going with Karim Garcia.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, JUDGE EDWARD
description: SCHWARTZ--Judge Edward, 68, of Livingston, NJ, October 13. Funeral will be held October 15th at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Funeral Chapel at 12 noon. For information, please call 1 (800) 938-6372

title: INSIDE
description: In First Trial in Sniper Case, Defendant Denies Killing

title: J.C. PENNEY DISCUSSING SALE OF ECKERD TO JEAN COUTU
description: The J. C. Penney Company has hired Credit Suisse First Boston to shop its Eckerd drugstore chain to potential buyers. The Jean Coutu Group, a Canadian drugstore chain, is interested, and Credit Suisse ''is sending us the package'' outlining a proposed sale, Franois J. Coutu, the chief executive, said in an interview from Longueuil, Quebec, where the company is based. Jean Coutu would want Eckerd to expand in the United States, where Coutu owns 332 Brooks Pharmacy stores. J. C. Penney, based in Plano, Tex., said it would decide by the end of the year whether to sell Eckerd or merge it with another company. Last month, Penney said that third-quarter profit at Eckerd would decline about 30 percent as larger drugstore companies opened more convenient locations in states including Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRUN, ANN KISSEL
description: GRUN--Ann Kissel, a former resident of New York City and East Hampton, NY, died at her home in Palm Beach, FL on Monday, October 13, 2003. The widow of Otto Grun and S. John Reisman, M.D., Mrs. Grun was a former vicepresident of McCampbell & Company in New York City, a large organization of selling agents for textile mills. In that position, she was the first woman vice-president named among the textile selling agents in New York. Later, she was president of Ann Kissel Associates where she was consultant on fabric development for American Viscose Corp., Waverly Mills, and other textile companies. Mrs. Grun was a lecturer-consultant at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York; Washington Associate Merchandising Editor Harper's Bazaar magazine; and Regional Director of Washington Fashion Group. She is survived by nieces, nephews, grandnieces, and grandnephews, and her stepdaughter Ellen Grun Himes. A graveside funeral service will be held at 2:00 P.M. today, Wednesday, October 15, 2003 at Union Field Cemetery on Cypress Avenue, Ridgewood, NY. For information Wasmund-Sorice Funeral Chapel (718) 821-2255.

title: Bush to Press Asians on Currency Rates
description: President Bush said Tuesday that he would press the leaders of China and Japan during his coming Asian trip to let the markets determine exchange rates for their currencies, taking the issue to the top level in the name of protecting American manufacturing jobs.

title: Walking Off a Loss
description: Mike Mussina was so upset with himself, with the Yankees and over losing to Tim Wakefield and the Red Sox on Monday that he walked the nearly two miles from Fenway Park to the Yankees' team hotel after the 3-2 loss. It was after midnight when Mussina trudged with Mike Borzello, the batting-practice pitcher.

title: One-Pot Pasta Robed in Blue
description: THE pasta recipe here may flout certain rules of pasta making, or at least be untraditional. But it's delicious and ludicrously easy, something you can throw together in no time flat, and that's what matters most.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: SILVER OPPOSES NEW TAXES Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said yesterday that he would oppose raising taxes to close a projected revenue shortfall of $5 billion to $6 billion in the fiscal year that begins on April 1, 2004. Mr. Silver, a Democrat from Manhattan, said the state should look elsewhere to balance its books. After a temporary tax increase was passed recently, Mr. Silver said, "I don't think we should be going back to the well again." This year, over the vetoes of Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, the Legislature imposed nearly $2.5 billion in tax increases in the $93 billion spending plan, chiefly through raising the state income tax on higher-earning New Yorkers, rescinding a state sales tax waiver on clothing costing less than $110 and increasing the state sales tax by one-quarter of a percentage point.   (AP)

title: Last Picture Show: Lives Pass in the Darkness of a Taipei Theater
description: ''Do you know this theater is haunted?'' That is one of about a half-dozen lines of dialogue spoken in Tsai Ming-Liang's ''Goodbye Dragon Inn,'' a movie about the dreamy pleasures of moviegoing that is itself both haunting and haunted. The theater is a cavernous movie palace in Taiwan on the verge of shutting down; it has attracted a handful of patrons for a showing of King Hu's 1966 sword-fighting epic ''Dragon Inn.''

title: Heroes, Good and Bad
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court to Consider Case on Under God in Pledge to Flag
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  The Supreme Court added the Pledge of Allegiance to the docket for its new term on Tuesday, agreeing to consider whether public schools violate the Constitution by requiring teachers to lead their classes in pledging allegiance to the flag of "one nation under God."

title: Hey, Po' Boy, Meet Some Real Heroes
description: WE are a city of heroes. The rest of the country may clamor for po' boys and hoagies, grinders, subs, wedges or torpedoes, but New York knows what really constitutes a gigantic sandwich, and what raises the hero above those pretenders; what makes it gastronomic royalty.

title: Surrounded by the Drama Of Monteverdi's Echo Effects
description: A few weeks before, the Handel and Haydn Society of Boston had presented a staging of Monteverdi's 1610 Vespers, directed by Chen Shi-Zheng: a preposterous notion for an ancient liturgical work, you might have thought, but one with provocative, sometimes enchanting and occasionally even amusing results. In contrast, Andrew Parrott looked for drama only in that work itself with the New York Collegium on Friday evening, and he found a ton of it.

title: Joel Edwin Segall, 80, Economist And President of Baruch College
description: Joel E. Segall, an economist and former president of Baruch College whose master plan helped make the business-oriented school a major presence in Manhattan, died on Thursday at a hospice in Branford, Conn. He was 80 and lived in Branford.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Monument To Nobel Winners
description: A monument dedicated to American winners of the Nobel Prize was unveiled yesterday in a ceremony attended by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Crown Prince Haakon of Norway and dozens of past Nobel Prize winners. The monument, a four-sided monolith of red Swedish granite, is engraved with the names of 271 American winners. It is behind the American Museum of Natural History in Theodore Roosevelt Park. In 1906, Mr. Roosevelt, who won the Nobel Peace Prize, became the first American to win the Nobel. Space has been left on the monument for the names of future winners. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Prigord To Broadway, In a Shell
description: Walnuts in the shell from the Prigord region of southwestern France deserve to be served at the end of a dinner with a piece of aged manchego, farmstead Cheddar or Comt and a glass of oloroso sherry or tawny port. The meat of the nut is darker in color than the more widely available California walnuts, and it has a somewhat earthier flavor. The shells are fairly thin, making them easy to crack.

title: Qualities Named Frailty, Cattiness and Desire
description: Tennessee Williams's out basket never seems to empty. This is no complaint. Even in the service of a small idea, the musical idiosyncrasies of Williams's language are almost always refreshing at the very least. But just when you think the staging of obscure or previously unproduced work has reached its natural end, here comes another company with some new play (or plays) by Williams that you either forgot about a long time ago or never heard of in the first place.

title: F.D.A. Panel Reconsiders Silicone Implants
description: Silicone breast implants cause fewer complications than the saline-filled ones already on the market, said a company that is trying to reintroduce the silicone devices. And, it added, the consensus among medical experts is that the silicone implants do not cause systemic diseases, like cancer or lupus.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: War On Yobs
description: The government unveiled a plan to crack down on a range of antisocial behavior -- from begging and graffiti-writing to terrorizing one's neighbors through vandalism and intimidation -- which it says costs taxpayers in England and Wales $5.6 billion a year. Among other things, the government will set up ''nuisance neighbor panels'' in four pilot areas in which aggrieved residents can air concerns. David Blunkett the Home Secretary, called the idea that people should tolerate even violent neighbors ''garbage'' left over from the social programs of the 1960's and 70's. ''You can't be nonjudgmental when you live next door to the family from hell,'' he said. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISBERG, JEROME L.
description: WEISBERG--Jerome L. On October 13th, 2003 at age 79. Beloved husband of Norma. Loving father of Lauren and Brodie Seagrave. Adoring grandfather of Reed. A friend to many. Graveside services today, at 11 AM, Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I.

title: Reading Dean On the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Recalling in Innocence To Make the Past Fresh
description: CITY ROOM

title: Name Sources, Judge Orders Five Reporters
description: A federal judge has ordered five reporters, including two from The New York Times, to disclose the confidential sources they used in preparing articles about Dr. Wen Ho Lee, the former scientist at the nuclear weapons laboratory in Los Alamos, N.M.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Pakistani Seeks Access To U.S. Prisoners
description: Lawyers for a Pakistani man accused of aiding Al Qaeda told a federal judge in Manhattan yesterday that to mount a proper defense, they need access to a former senior officer of Al Qaeda who is in American custody. In a similar case involving, Zacarias Moussaoui, who is accused of being involved in the Sept. 11 attacks, prosecutors are resisting granting access to Qaeda prisoners because, they said, doing so may compromise national security. In the case of the Pakistani man, Uzair Paracha, 23, who is accused of trying to help a Qaeda member get into the United States, defense lawyers want to interview prisoners with ties to Al Qaeda, including Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the former Qaeda operations chief suspected of planning the attacks. Mr. Paracha's lawyer, Anthony Ricco, said the defense would file motions similar to those in the Moussaoui case. The motions are due by Nov. 25. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Dutch Grocer Names Chief For U.S. Unit After Scandal
description: Royal Ahold said yesterday that it had chosen Lawrence S. Benjamin, the chief executive of the NutraSweet Company, to lead its U.S. Foodservice division, which nearly crippled the company by overstating profits by hundreds of millions of dollars for three years.

title: MESA AIR TO MAKE BUYOUT BID TO ATLANTIC COAST HOLDERS
description: The Mesa Air Group said yesterday that it would go to shareholders of Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings with a buyout offer, and that it was proposing a slate of directors for Atlantic Coast. Mesa said it acted because the board of Atlantic Coast had not responded to its Oct. 6 unsolicited offer of $512 million in stock. The combined company, with almost 300 planes and routes covering much of the nation, would be the largest regional airline.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: EMC To Buy Documentum In Stock Swap
description: The EMC Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Documentum, a management software company, in a $1.7 billion stock swap, in a bid to secure a top spot in the market for helping companies keep track of disparate information ranging from Web pages to X-rays. Documentum's shares surged $3.95, or 16 percent, to $28.37. EMC's shares fell $1.17, or more than 8 percent, to $13.28. But EMC said Documentum, which is based in Pleasanton, Calif., was perfect for EMC's strategy of looking for growth on its software side -- rather than from the big data-storage hardware devices it also sells. EMC purchased Legato Systems in July in a deal valued at $1.2 billion -- its first major purchase in years after a period of retrenchment -- and said at the time another similarly sized deal was on the horizon. Under the agreement, Documentum stockholders would receive 2.175 shares of EMC common stock for each share of Documentum common stock -- valuing each Documentum share at $28.88 based on yesterday's prices.

title: Selection of Jurors Begins In Trial of Sniper Suspect
description: On the first day of the first trial in one of the most highly publicized shooting sprees in history, John A. Muhammad declared on Tuesday that he did not kill a 53-year-old Maryland man at a gasoline station last fall, one of 10 sniper killings that terrorized Washington and its suburbs.

title: Where Intrigue Is an Unspoken Part of the Menu
description: POSSIBLY because of their French colonial heritage, Vietnamese restaurants swing easily into the cosmopolitan bistro mode that you can find on just about any street corner in North America or Europe. It's a happy marriage of cultures, capitalizing as well on notions of intrigue that permeated wartime Saigon in the romantic imagination.

title: 2 Publishers Report Increased Earnings
description: Gannett and Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose because advertising sales increased at their flagship newspapers, USA Today and The Wall Street Journal.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Proview Raises Capacity To Make Flat Panels
description: Proview International Holdings, which became one of the world's biggest makers of flat-panel computer monitors this year, plans to triple capacity after Motorola picked the company to help make liquid-crystal display panels for televisions and computers. Proview will add a factory in the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen to raise annual capacity of flat-panel displays, optical drives and traditional TV sets to 45 million units in three years, the executive director, Luffer Wong, said. Proview expects unit sales of liquid crystal displays and cathode-ray tube TV's and monitors to rise by more than half for a second year. Proview, whose clients include Fujitsu and Acer, joins competitors like AU Optronics in seeking a bigger share of the $23 billion flat-panel market. Proview was No. 6, with 4.7 percent of market share, in the second quarter, according to the researcher DisplaySearch. Motorola shares fell 30 cents, to $13.57.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEILBRUN, CAROLYN
description: HEILBRUN -- Carolyn. The Women Writing Women's Lives seminar of biographers and memoirists will sadly miss our co-founder, Carolyn Heilbrun. Her inspiring writing about women's lives has helped reshape our work. Her example as a woman of courage will continue to influence us. We extend our sympathies to her family and all who knew and loved her. Kathy Chamberlain, Chair of the Steering Committee of W.W.W.L.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, JONATHAN
description: COHEN--Jonathan. Of Nyack, N.Y. Life-long activist for peace and social justice, passed away October 13 at age 40. Loving son of Carole and Richard. Cherished life partner of Liz Roberts. Devoted brother of Deborah and Laura. Services Thursday, 12:30PM at ''The Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, N.Y.

title: What a Building Says About Us
description: To the Editor:

title: As Health of Pope Declines, His Inner Circle Is Tightening
description: For the next week, a more intense spotlight than usual falls on the headquarters of the Roman Catholic church as Pope John Paul II celebrates his 25th anniversary in office. The pope himself will occupy center stage.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 329 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Gauguin exhibition in Paris misstated the year of a colonial exhibition there that coincided with the publication of a book that helped shape Gauguin's views of Tahiti. It was 1889, not 1890.

title: Fighting the War at Home
description: Letters home from the war front are some of the revered aspects of history, a treasury of soldiers' impressions and firsthand narratives that hold a value apart from the individual lives put firmly on the battle line. It's all the more disturbing, then, that an apparently orchestrated campaign of letter writing has arisen among some of the American forces in Iraq to highlight what are alleged to be overlooked success stories. What amounts to a warmly worded form letter telling of open-armed welcomes and rebuilt infrastructure was printed by hometown newspapers in the mistaken belief that it was the individual composition of the undersigned soldier in Kirkuk, a relatively peaceful city in Iraq. According to the Gannett News Service, which uncovered the deception, one soldier said his sergeant had distributed the letters to the squad, while another traced his to an Army public affairs officer.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about new Congressional district lines in Texas misstated the shift of African-American voters who are now in the Dallas area district of Representative Martin Frost, a Democrat. They would be dispersed in largely white and Republican districts, not reassigned to the district of Representative Eddie Bernice Johnson, a Democrat.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of winning lottery numbers on Monday carried incorrect dates. The numbers in the first group were from Sunday, Oct. 12, not Oct. 13. The rest were from Saturday, Oct. 11, not Oct. 12. A corrected listing is online today at www.nytimes.com/corrections.html.

title: Recipe: Aztec Hot Chocolate Pudding
description: Time: 45 minutes

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about a fire in Brooklyn that killed two children reversed the identities of two fire officials at the microphones during a news conference. Assistant Chief Peter Hayden, wearing a hat, was speaking in the center of the picture, and Chief Fire Marshal Louis Garcia was standing at his left.

title: KNIGHT TRADING GROUP AGREES TO PURCHASE DONALDSON
description: The Knight Trading Group, the biggest market maker of Nasdaq stock market securities, agreed to purchase Donaldson & Company for an undisclosed amount of cash to add services for institutional investors. The purchase is expected to close before the end of the year, Knight said. Knight, which is based in Jersey City, said it had decided to buy rather than build services like Donaldson's soft-dollar program, which helps investment managers track commission credits that brokerage firms offer to attract customers. Donaldson's 16 employees will remain with the company. John Donaldson, 62, who founded the firm in 1984, will be a consultant.

title: A Dignified March Through the Life of a Statesman
description: Droning and soporific, ''Churchill'' is nevertheless the true three-part story of Winston Churchill, so you might e-mail your father and let him know that it's time to tune in for more lullabies about the last century's bulldog war hero.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: EMC TO BUY DOCUMENTUM IN STOCK SWAP The EMC Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Documentum, a management software company, in a $1.7 billion stock swap, in a bid to secure a top spot in the market for helping companies keep track of disparate information ranging from Web pages to X-rays. Documentum's shares surged $3.95, or 16 percent, to $28.37. EMC's shares fell $1.17, or more than 8 percent, to $13.28. But EMC said Documentum, which is based in Pleasanton, Calif., was perfect for EMC's strategy of looking for growth on its software side — rather than from the big data-storage hardware devices it also sells. EMC purchased Legato Systems in July in a deal valued at $1.2 billion — its first major purchase in years after a period of retrenchment — and said at the time another similarly sized deal was on the horizon. Under the agreement, Documentum stockholders would receive 2.175 shares of EMC common stock for each share of Documentum common stock — valuing each Documentum share at $28.88 based on yesterday's prices.   (Bloomberg News)

title: Dean Spares No Opponent As He Sprints Across Iowa
description: Howard Dean, who is increasingly giving his presidential candidacy an anti-Washington cast, cranked up his rhetoric on Tuesday, saying that if he won, members of Congress were ''going to be scurrying for shelter, just like a giant flashlight on a bunch of cockroaches.''

title: Honor the Uprooted Germans? Poles Are Uneasy
description: Even as the idea of Europe is inexorably pushing Germany and Poland, those ancient neighbors and enemies, into the same club, the European Union, a different way of looking at history has been pushing them apart.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Retailer Posts Loss
description: The retailer Seiyu Ltd. had a second consecutive first-half loss as declining consumer spending and an extended rainy season hurt sales of clothing and household goods. The company reported a group net loss of 8.4 billion yen ($77 million), or 14.53 yen a share, for the six months ended Aug. 31, an improvement from a loss of 22.4 billion yen, or 61.73 yen a share, a year earlier. Its sales fell 3.9 percent, to 557.9 billion yen. Wal-Mart Stores is Seiyu's biggest shareholder and raised its investment in August to provide more capital for the Japanese retailer.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Awards Stake In Unit To 8 Employees
description: Palm Inc. said yesterday that ''eight key employees'' had been awarded 8 percent of the software operating unit that it planned to spin off later this month. The 932,965 shares of restricted common stock of PalmSource are worth about $14 million, Palm, which is based in Milpitas, Calif., said in a quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The eight employees, who were not identified, were given the stock in August, the filing said. Palm shareholders will vote on Oct. 28 on whether to spin off PalmSource, which will sell operating systems for hand-held computers. If shareholders approve, Palm will also change its name to PalmOne and purchase Handspring, a maker of combination cellphones and hand-held organizers. Shares of Palm rose $2.35, or about 9.7 percent, to $26.70.

title: Sopranos Muscle In on the Red Hook Waterfront
description: Word on the street was that some big-shot wiseguys from New Jersey were going to be doing a little business down by the Brooklyn waterfront yesterday, so Joseph Fazzia stepped out in front of his warehouse to scope things out.

title: Morgan Stanley May Face Legal Action on Fund Sales
description: Morgan Stanley said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission staff had recommended legal action against the company over its failure to disclose incentives related to mutual fund sales.

title: Transmeta Sees a Way To Cut Chips' Leakage
description: Transmeta, a troubled Silicon Valley chip maker, described an unusual software technique on Tuesday that it said would help solve a problem bedeviling the semiconductor industry. It is that tiny transistors tend to leak increasing amounts of current as they shrink to sizes that can be measured in terms of handfuls of atoms.

title: Embassy Is Bombed
description: A car bomb exploded outside the Turkish Embassy in Baghdad, killing one bystander. Turkey's plan to contribute 10,000 troops to the coalition has stirred anger among Iraqis.

title: Sox Storm Back to Force a Seventh Game
description: The Yankees have tried for months to build the perfect baseball team. They traded for players, claimed players off waivers, signed players who defected from Cuba and migrated from Japan. Despite the constant shuffling, or maybe because of it, the Yankees won the most games in the American League in the regular season. Yesterday, they nearly won the pennant.

title: Accuser Asks For Privacy in Bryant Case
description: With a preliminary hearing scheduled to resume Wednesday, prosecutors in the sexual-assault case against Kobe Bryant requested Tuesday that part of the hearing be closed to the public.

title: Killing Gravano Is Hard, Witness Explains to Jury
description: They had options. They could blow up the most famous Mafia informant ever, Salvatore Gravano, known as Sammy the Bull, or shoot him from a sniper's perch.

title: White House Memo; Fast Lane for President: 6 Nations, 6 Days, Safely
description: When George W. Bush arrives in Manila for a state visit on Saturday, there will be no time to luxuriate in Gen. Douglas MacArthur's old suite at the sumptuous Manila Hotel, the usual overnight spot for presidents.

title: U.S. SEEMS ASSURED OF U.N.'S APPROVAL ON PLANS FOR IRAQ
description: The Bush administration is virtually assured of gaining Security Council approval of a revised United Nations resolution on Iraq's future, diplomats here said Tuesday, but it remains unclear whether the measure will be adopted overwhelmingly or in a less convincing, abstention-riddled vote.

title: Schools and the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Say Doctors May Not Be Punished for Recommending Medical Marijuana
description: The Supreme Court, in a silent rebuff on Tuesday to federal policy on medical marijuana, let stand an appeals court ruling that doctors may not be investigated, threatened or punished by federal regulators for recommending marijuana as a medical treatment for their patients.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a tour at Gracie Mansion referred incorrectly in some copies to the Manhattan street on which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg actually lives in his own town house. It is East 79th Street near Fifth Avenue, not West 79th. The article also omitted the name of the sponsor of the tour, which was part of a weekend exhibition of New York architecture. It was Open House New York.

title: Questions on Irradiated Food
description: WHEN the European Parliament decided last year to put a moratorium on the irradiation of almost all food, it was influenced by studies suggesting that substances formed when fat is irradiated may promote colon cancer.

title: High Court Considers Murky Area of Criminal Search Law
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15  When the police arrived at a Las Vegas apartment to execute a warrant to search for drugs, they knocked on the front door and called out: "Police search warrant." But LaShawn L. Banks, the apartment's resident, was taking a shower and did not hear them. After waiting 15 or 20 seconds, the officers used a battering ram to knock the door down. Entering the apartment, they found crack cocaine, three guns and $6,000 in cash.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: The N.R.A.'s List
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Vetoes Resolution Condemning Israeli Barrier
description: The United States vetoed a Syrian-sponsored resolution late Tuesday that declared illegal the barrier Israel is building in the West Bank to deter terrorist attacks.

title: Dark Nights, Sharp Pens; Art Spiegelman Addresses Children and His Own Fears
description: Art Spiegelman will be known forever as the creator of ''Maus,'' the Pulitzer Prize-winning comic-strip book about his parents as Holocaust survivors. But that is only one aspect of an artist whose talent is so diverse that he regards himself as ''multiphrenic.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMANN, JULIE B.
description: KAUFMANN--Julie B. On October 14, 2003. Wife of Edward, mother of Samara and Davie, daughter of Nathan Schneider. Funeral services, Thursday, October 16, 11:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell--The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Greece Refuses To Extradite Tycoon
description: A court in Athens rejected Russia's request for the extradition of a Russian media magnate, Vladimir A. Gusinsky, on fraud and money-laundering charges. He was arrested in Athens in August on an international warrant and contends that the Russian charges are politically motivated. With the ruling, Russia once again found itself rebuffed by a European court in another case involving a high-profile businessman. Earlier this month Britain granted asylum to another Russian media tycoon wanted in Russian, Boris A. Berezovsky. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Chenin Blancs From the Loire and Beyond
description: EVEN as august a body as the Dining section's wine panel can sometimes get mixed up. Or maybe it's just me. I was eagerly awaiting a tasting of Vouvrays, made from the versatile and vastly underrated chenin blanc grape. But when I arrived at the blind tasting, I discovered that nine of the bottles were chenin blancs from the United States and South Africa. I love chenin blancs from the Loire Valley, which can range from steely dry to lusciously sweet. But chenins from elsewhere? Their range is narrower, from unremarkable to insipid.

title: New York City Reaches Deal to Extend Lease on Airports
description: New York City will continue to lease its two airports to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in exchange for a $700 million upfront payment and a hike in annual rent payments, giving the city a much-needed infusion of money, according to an agreement announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANKIN, JANEY
description: MANKIN -- Janey. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Beth, Mitchell and Howard. Cherished grandmother of Joshua, Elliot, Samuel, Matthew, Paige and Brent. Loving daughter of Lillian and the late Morris. Best friend and sister to Debbie. Services Wednesday, 10:30AM, at Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Rd., Great Neck, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RENCKENS, JAMES R.
description: RENCKENS--James R. With deep sorrow the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, its Board of Directors and staff mourn the passing of James Renckens. Jim joined the NMSS Minnesota Chapter Board of Trustees in 1991, serving as Chair from 1993-1996; he was elected to the National Board in 2003. He was awarded the Norman Cohn Hope Award in 2001, in recognition of his volunteer leadership service to the Society, and was to receive the Philanthropist of the Year Award in November 2003. Jim's commitment and dedication to the MS cause will be truly missed. Jim is survived by his wife Debbie and children Denise, Elizabeth, Stephanie, Cathleen, Richard and Michael. Memorials may be sent to the National MS Society, Minnesota Chapter, 200 12th Avenue South, Minneapolis, MN 55415. We extend our sincere sympathy to his entire family. Edward A. Kangas, Chairman of the Board Mike Dugan, President and CEO

title: Bolivia Leader Loses Allies As Demonstrations Spread
description: Despite moves by the military to tighten its control of the capital, President Gonzalo Snchez de Lozada's hold on power grew more tenuous on Tuesday, as demonstrations demanding his resignation spread to provincial cities, and important political allies scrambled to distance themselves from him.

title: Study Says Lighter Cars Would Cost More Lives
description: Federal regulators, poised to overhaul fuel economy rules, released a study on Tuesday that asserts that reducing vehicle weights would have a deadly effect over all. But the study said that putting the heaviest Hummer-size vehicles on diets could save lives.

title: Sports of The Times; Certain Victory Turns Into Harsh Reality
description: FOR fans who have been following the Chicago Cubs for a long, long time, what happened could hardly come as a shock. But it was, nonetheless. No matter how many times you get knocked on the head, the one before still doesn't prepare you for the shock of the next blow.

title: Senate Plans Inquiry On Credit Services
description: The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations said yesterday that it would hold hearings later this year to examine the activities of nonprofit credit counseling agencies, which assist millions of people with their debts.

title: Rivera Finishing Whatever He Starts
description: All season, the Yankees searched for a reliable setup man for Mariano Rivera.

title: No-Fuss Fusion on Clinton Street
description: MODERN chefs seem to divide into two species. The first want to build a brand name and create a global empire of restaurants, frozen foods, flatware and kitchen gadgets. The second dream of running a little place, a quiet spot with perhaps a dozen tables, and stand over the stove night after night, sending out the food they love, improvising and inventing as they go along.

title: Sports of The Times; Without Exorcism, an Exercise in Futility
description: BOSTON fans wake up this morning with their team in a demoralizing predicament. The Red Sox must win two games at Yankee Stadium to avoid being vanquished by the Yankees and having another postseason dream crushed.

title: Cellphone Cameras
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BASS, LEON
description: BASS--Leon. The law firm of Ledy-Gurren & Blumenstock mourns the loss of Leon Bass, loving father of our partner and friend, Debbie Bass, and the late Gwen Bass. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Debbie and his beloved wife Ruth, who have now twice suffered inestimable loss. Our thoughts and hearts are with you.

title: Where the Big Attraction Is a Big-House Museum
description: Museum directors are supposed to be experts in their fields, but few can claim as ideal a background as Jim Willett, the silver-haired director of the Texas Prison Museum here.

title: Intel Says Net Doubles, With Sales Up Overseas
description: The Intel Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter profit more than doubled and exceeded its own forecasts based on strong sales to Asia and Europe.

title: Restoring a Landmark Hotel in Downtown Detroit
description: The long-empty Book-Cadillac Hotel, which for half a century had been this city's leading place to stay, has been acquired by an arm of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation that specializes in restoring once-grand hotels in central cities and that sees a promising future both for its new acquisition and for parts of the surrounding downtown area.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about new Congressional district lines in Texas misstated the shift of African-American voters who are now in the Dallas area district of Representative Martin Frost, a Democrat. They would be dispersed in largely white and Republican districts, not reassigned to the district of Representative Eddie Bernice Johnson, a Democrat.

title: Backers of Medical Marijuana Hail Ruling
description: Ever since voters in California approved a 1996 ballot measure that legalized some medicinal uses of marijuana, the state has been locked in a legal and cultural battle with the federal government.

title: The Mild and the Fiery: Sweet Harmony
description: ANYTHING that is true out of the kitchen is also true in the kitchen. What matters most is balance. And believe me, in cooking you have it easier. In the novel ''Heartburn,'' Nora Ephron wrote of the comforting certainties of the culinary world. When all else feels stunningly out of control, you know -- to paraphrase her -- that if you mix flour and butter over heat you will have a roux; and when you stir in milk you will have a sauce that thickens.

title: The N.R.A.s List (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: So Little Time
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Show House Sampler
description: There is something for everyone at the American Hospital of Paris Foundation's 2003 International Designer Show House.

title: Red Sox Rally to Reach Game 7
description: The Red Sox stormed back to force a Game 7 between starters Pedro Martinez and Roger Clemens.

title: A Stunning Rally
description: The Chicago Cubs hoped to close out the N.L.C.S. in Game 6. But in a stunning turn of events, the Florida Marlins won, 8-3.

title: From Europe to Your House by Way of a Bargain
description: You can buy European furniture on the Internet at discount prices and have it delivered to your door. Julie Edwards, an American banker, moved to London and started Europe by Net, which sells, among other things, furniture by B&B Italia, Cappellini, Edra and Poltrona Frau; lighting from Flos, Artemide and Ingo Maurer; drink trolleys ($400 to $4,880); and kitchen taps ($132 to $286).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KASS, SOPHIE
description: KASS--Sophie. 94. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Mother of Lee and the late Allan Hilton, Lucille and John Wright, Linda and Arthur Rogers. Grandmother of Marty and Susan, David and Jeromine, Richard and Jennifer, Barbara, Susan and Lane, Ian and Maria, Daniel. Great grandmother of Branden, Jason, Matthew, Perry, Marlee, Isabel, Kayla. Community leader and active in philanthropy. Graveside service Thursday, October 16, 2003. Shiva Monday, October 20 through Friday October 24 at Rogers, 315 West 70 St, NYC. Contributions please to SHARE (Breast and Ovarian Cancer), 1501 Broadway, Suite 1720, NYC 10036

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Popular for Good Reason

title: The Pledge: Recite, or Rewrite?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Yankees Hop Onto the Hot Seat
description: IT was a lovely dream that the Yankees had convinced themselves was all too real. They came to believe Jos Contreras was their sturdy bridge to Mariano Rivera and therefore beyond Boston and on to the World Series. This made so much sense because Contreras symbolically was the prized Cuban cigar the Yankees had snatched from under the Red Sox's noses and his October emergence fit the storyline so snugly, like a lyric in an 83-year-old tune that sounds something like, ''I Got You, Babe.''

title: Edward Breathitt Jr., 78, Ex-Governor of Kentucky
description: Edward T. Breathitt Jr., a former Democratic governor of Kentucky who made civil rights his theme at a time when few politicians below the Mason-Dixon line would do so, died on Tuesday at the University of Kentucky Hospital in Lexington. He was 78 and lived in Lexington.

title: The Pledge: Recite, or Rewrite?
description: To the Editor:

title: Feeding Tube Is Removed In Florida Right-to-Die Case
description: Terri Schiavo received what was supposed to be her final feeding on Wednesday, but Gov. Jeb Bush told her parents that he would again try to stop her court-approved death.

title: Bush and Schwarzenegger to Meet in California
description: The meeting between the nation's two most prominent Republicans on Thursday will very likely be brief, cordial and largely confined to generalities.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: SYRIA: U.S. HOUSE APPROVES SANCTIONS Under legislation easily adopted by the House of Representatives, Syria could face economic and diplomatic penalties unless it ceases support of terrorist groups and withdraws its forces from Lebanon. The measure illustrates the hardening line American lawmakers of both parties are advocating. "It is time to tell Syria that the game is over," said Representative Eliot L. Engel, a Democrat of New York and a chief author of the sanctions bill, which also has bipartisan support in the Senate. Penalties available under the measure include a freeze on Syrian assets in the United States, a halt in American business investment, a ban on United States exports to Syria except for food and medicine, and a reduction in diplomatic contacts.    Carl Hulse (NYT)

title: Giuliani and Ernst Start Tech Venture
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani has worn many hats. He has served as a federal prosecutor, a mayor of New York, a national healer after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and a business consultant. Now add one more: cybersecurity expert.

title: Investigation Begins Into Ferry Crash That Killed 10
description: Federal, state and city officials said today that they had started an investigation into the Staten Island ferry crash that killed 10 people and injured up to 42 on Wednesday when the boat, moving at a rapid clip in gusting winds, slammed into a concrete-and-wood pier.

title: Sports of The Times; Roller-Coaster Ride Is Over for the Cubs
