description: THE signs around town read, ''We Believe in 2003.'' This year was going to be different, it was going to turn history on its head. Suspend disbelief? The magician's tricks are all real? The ventriloquist's dummy can actually speak? The amazing, the impossible, the utterly stupendous, it was hoped, would take place here last night, and the Cubs would be going to, of all places, the World Series.

title: Bittersweet Celebrations for a Pope and His 25-Year Reign
description: VATICAN CITY, Oct. 16  With a twilight Mass that drew thousands of people to St. Peter's Square, Pope John Paul II celebrated his 25th anniversary at the head of the Roman Catholic Church tonight, a milestone at once joyful and somber.

title: Apple Reports $44 Million Profit for the Quarter
description: Apple Computer reported on Wednesday fourth-quarter results that exceeded analysts' estimates. Those results were driven by a surge in sales of the iPod music player and Apple's newest generation of desktop computers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEIFERHELD, JAMES DAVID
description: SEIFERHELD--James David, on October 13, at his home in Hagerstown, MD. Son of the late Elizabeth Fitzpatrick and David Seiferheld. Father of Andrew Gage (Geri) and Scott Seiferheld. Native New Yorker. Graduate of the Browning School. Tennis player, photographer and avid memorabilia collector. Funeral private.

title: A Collage of Sly Tricks In Honor of a Collagist
description: Who knows whether Charles L. Mee and the SITI company have accurately reflected the mind of Robert Rauschenberg in ''bobrauschenbergamerica,'' which opened on Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. But one thing is certain: what unfurls on the stage of the Harvey Theater is brashly, unapologetically entertaining.

title: On Listening
description: There was a headline that grabbed me in The Times on Saturday. It said, ''Cheney Lashes Out at Critics of Policy on Iraq.''

title: Investigation Begins Into Ferry Crash That Killed 10
description: AStaten Island ferry moving at a rapid clip in gusting winds crashed into a pier at the St. George ferry terminal yesterday afternoon, killing 10 people and injuring dozens of others as the concrete and wood pier sliced through its side, mowing down tourists and commuters.

title: Bruce Goff's Bachelor Pad on the Prairie
description: TWO young architects, Scott Specht and Louise Harpman of the Manhattan firm Specht Harpman, are die-hard fans of Bruce Goff. So much so that they were married in 1995 at Goff's most famous building, Shin'en Kan, in Bartlesville, Okla.

title: Black and Hispanic Students Lag on Regents, Group Says
description: Black and Hispanic students are passing the Regents exams required for graduation in New York State at rates far below those of their white and Asian classmates, according to data presented on Tuesday by Time Out From Testing, an antitesting advocacy group.

title: Tiny (Sticky) Works of Art, Created Digitally
description: AUSTRALIA has glow-in-the-dark postal stamps. Switzerland has stamps that look and smell like chocolate. Britain has a do-it-yourself stamp in which hats, eyes and glasses can be affixed to fruit, Mr. Potato Head style. Not all stamps are as flashy, but whether they portray tiny lizards or a thumbnail-size Impressionist painting, digital technology is increasingly influencing their design. Digital tools have eased the tricky process of creating art for a product that can be smaller than one square inch.

title: For Pope, a Milestone on Road of Epic Events
description: The immediate trigger for the grand ceremony that will be held here on Thursday is a number, a broad span of years: 25 of them.

title: A Coach's Digital Tools Take Center Court
description: THE serve explodes off Jeff Salzenstein's racket. It is a round yellow missile, traveling 130 miles per hour and capable of freezing the world's top tennis players in their Reeboks. But this rocket underscores its server's consternation. If he can hit a ball like this, Salzenstein wonders until it hurts, why must he toil only on the outskirts of greatness?

title: A big donation of time and space to fight the drug Ecstasy.
description: THE Partnership for a Drug-Free America will introduce today an ad campaign focusing on the drug Ecstasy and backed by the largest donation of media time it has received.

title: 2 More Indicted In Bribery Case In New Jersey
description: A prominent waterfront developer was indicted on federal bribery charges on Wednesday, in the latest reverberation from the federal investigation of Robert C. Janiszewski, the former Hudson County executive. One of Mr. Janiszewski's closest friends, who investigators said had served as his ''bag man,'' was also indicted, the United States attorney here said Wednesday.

title: For Clemens, Its Dj Vu in a Different Uniform
description: The American League Championship Series has not arrived at this point since 1986, when a 24-year-old power pitcher named Roger Clemens lifted the Red Sox to the World Series with a victory over the Angels. Now, Game 7 has returned to the A.L.C.S., with a 41-year-old Clemens, a power pitcher to the end, trying to extend his career by keeping the Red Sox out of the World Series.

title: The First Home-Front Battle in the War on Terror
description: One of the many nightmares that followed the Sept. 11 attacks was the thought that more terrorists might be hiding in the United States, ready to strike at a moment's notice. The possibilities were endless -- and frightening. Millions pass through America's open doors every day, many disappearing without much of a trace. After the attacks the F.B.I. discovered that no fewer than 70,000 Saudi men, their ages ranging from 18 to 35, had entered the United States between December 2000 and August 2001. None were likely to pose a threat, but how could you really know?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Movers Sentenced To Prison
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn sentenced two operators of a Brooklyn moving company yesterday to 12 years and 7 months in prison. Both men were convicted of defrauding customers and ordered to pay more than $400,000 in restitution. Avinoam Damti, the owner of the company, was fined $1 million. Mr. Damti and Ofer Yosef were convicted in May of essentially holding customers' belongings hostage and demanding up to four times the original estimated price. The judge in Federal District Court, Nicholas G. Garaufis, said the men were shameless in exploiting their customers when they were at their most vulnerable. The company was known variously as On-Time Van Lines, Starving Students Moving and Storage, New Start Moving and Official Moving and Storage. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SUPERVALU INC., Eden Prairie, Minn., a food distributor and owner of Shop'n Save supermarkets, said it would sell four stores and a warehouse near Denver to Kroger Co., Cincinnati, the U.S.'s largest grocery chain. Terms were not disclosed. Supervalu plans to sell another five stores in the area.

title: The High Cost Of Staying in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Hold the Champagne
description: There will be a Game 7 at Yankee Stadium tonight for the first time in American League Championship Series history, but for the fifth time in Yankee history. Judging from the other four results, all in the World Series, Yankees fans should curb their enthusiasm.

title: After 21 Hours, Chinese Spacecraft Lands Safely
description: With parachutes braking its swift fall to Earth, the Shenzhou 5 spacecraft made a safe, early morning landing on the grasslands of Inner Mongolia on Thursday, official news organizations reported, completing an apparently successful mission that established China as only the third nation to send a person into space.

title: Universal Music to Cut 11% of Work Force
description: The Universal Music Group, the largest music company in the world and home to acts like U2, Eminem and Mariah Carey, is expected to announce a restructuring Thursday that will eliminate 11 percent of its work force.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: U.S. House Approves Sanctions
description: Under legislation easily adopted by the House of Representatives, Syria could face economic and diplomatic penalties unless it ceases support of terrorist groups and withdraws its forces from Lebanon. The measure illustrates the hardening line American lawmakers of both parties are advocating. ''It is time to tell Syria that the game is over,'' said Representative Eliot L. Engel, a Democrat of New York and a chief author of the sanctions bill, which also has bipartisan support in the Senate. Penalties available under the measure include a freeze on Syrian assets in the United States, a halt in American business investment, a ban on United States exports to Syria except for food and medicine, and a reduction in diplomatic contacts. Carl Hulse (NYT)

title: Rangers Set for Home Opener
description: After an 0-2 start in which they have been outscored by 10-3, the Rangers will find out how frustrated their fans are Thursday night, when they play the Atlanta Thrashers in their home opener.

title: To Bomb Or Not To Bomb? A Question
description: In October 1973 a 75-year-old woman who grew up in Milwaukee nearly initiated a nuclear holocaust. There was one long night when she paced, sleepless, pondering her simple alternatives like a lovesick teenager picking petals off a daisy: Do I or don't I? Do I or don't I?

title: Curses, Old and New, Haunt the Cubs' Fans
description: The longtime fans, those toughened by generations of losing, had warned their city.

title: Diageo and Pfizer Expand Alliances
description: Two advertisers are expanding relationships with roster agencies.

title: Intense Matchup Seems a Fitting Way to Finish Off This Series
description: They are grown men now, millionaire baseball players, but they, too, used to be little boys who dreamed about playing in a Game 7 with everything on the line and with two of the best pitchers in the game on the mound. Tonight at Yankee Stadium, the Red Sox and the Yankees will play that kind of game. It will be more than the Yankees versus the Red Sox for the American League championship, it will be Roger Clemens-Pedro Martnez redux, in all its greatness and heightened emotions.

title: Pilots Uneventful Routine Ends in Terrible Mystery
description: As he has for the last 15 years, Richard J. Smith left for work yesterday, making his way from his brick Tudor home in a stylish Staten Island neighborhood to the metal door of his storied office: a pilot's house atop the Staten Island Ferry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARGOLIN, HENRIETTA
description: MARGOLIN--Henrietta. The Board of Trustees, Administration & staff of Parker Jewish Institute deeply mourn the passing of Henrietta Margolin, beloved mother of our dear friend, Jesse Margolin. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Jesse and his wife Toni, sister Evelyn, and the entire Margolin family. May your time of grief be eased by the warm love you shared and the fond memories you hold. Jerry Landsberg, Chairman, Board of Trustees Barbara N. Kurshan, Immediate Past Chair Michael N. Rosenblut, Acting Chief Exec. Officer

title: Big Projects To Develop Natural Gas In Qatar
description: Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch/Shell are expected to announce significant investments in separate natural gas projects in Qatar in the coming days, underscoring a vast and accelerating shift within the oil industry to capitalize on the growing demand for cleaner-burning fuels the world over, particularly in the United States.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Pittsburgh's Bond Rating Plummets
description: Standard & Poor's Rating Services slashed Pittsburgh's A- bond rating to junk bond status, BB. Pittsburgh started its fiscal year in January with a $60 million budget gap, City Controller Tom Flaherty said, and the deficit is thought to have increased to about $80 million. He said the Legislature had not approved a request by Mayor Tom Murphy, a Democrat, for a new gross payroll tax and an increase in the commuter tax. As a result, 730 city workers were laid off in August, and some city services were reduced or eliminated.

title: A Bullpens Undesirable Trait: Unpredictability
description: The Yankees' bullpen phone buzzed in the fifth inning yesterday because Andy Pettitte was laboring and Manager Joe Torre understands that this is the postseason and you manage these games as if every precious out is the last out. Torre knows one out could be the difference between surviving for another day or watching another team play on television, so he quickly dialed for some help.

title: Corrections
description: An article in late editions yesterday about a party in honor of George Plimpton, who died on Sept. 26, misspelled the given name of a novelist who attended. He is Allan Gurganus, not Alan. In some copies the article also misspelled another writer's surname. (That error also appeared in Mr. Plimpton's obituary on Sept. 27.) The writer is Peter Matthiessen, not Mathiessen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GALLAGHER, REVEREND WILLIAM PATRICK
description: GALLAGHER -- Reverend William Patrick, 64, died October 13, 2003. Born June 9, 1939. Predeceased by his parents Francis D. and E. Rose (McGovern) Gallagher and his stepmother Kay Gallagher. Survived by a twin brother, John, an aunt, Ann Sheridan of Rutland, VT, several nieces, one nephew, many cousins. Following cremation, a Liturgy of Christian burial will take place at Our Lady of the Snows, Woodstock, VT on Saturday, October 18, at 11 AM. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Fr. Gallagher to Tepeyac Association of NY, 251 W. 14 St, NYC 10011.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WEISS, DORIS T.
description: WEISS--Doris T. October 16th. Always remembered with love, never to be forgotten. Bernie

title: Shares Slip After Some Earnings Reports Disappoint
description: Stocks declined slightly yesterday as third-quarter results from companies like General Motors failed to reassure some investors that profit growth in future quarters would meet estimates.

title: U.S. Commerce Chief Tells Investors Iraq Strife Is Isolated
description: At a heavily guarded warehouse at the Baghdad airport, which ordinary Iraqis cannot enter without American permission, Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans said on Wednesday that violence in Iraq is isolated and that foreign investors should seize opportunities here.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the police investigation into the killing of a Fairfield University student in Brooklyn misidentified the neighborhood where his body was found. It was Prospect Park South, not Ditmas Park.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WEINTRAUB, SHEILA
description: WEINTRAUB--Sheila, 10/16/ 40-10/20/90, cherished mother. Your absence is my loss...still. Allison

title: Market Place; I.B.M. Earnings Don't Impress Wall Street
description: I.B.M. reported solid quarterly profits yesterday, expressed measured optimism about the outlook for technology spending and announced plans to hire 10,000 employees next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, ANN
description: GOLDSTEIN -- Ann. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved mother of Dr. Matthew Goldstein, a respected member of our Board of Overseers. To Dr. Goldstein and his family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dr. Dominick P. Purpura The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

title: Taxpayers Are Restless On Billions in Aid for Iraq
description: Wil LaVergne and Chad Cannon argue regularly about politics. But on Tuesday, over heaping plates of fish, shrimp and softshell crab at Poor Boy Lloyd's, a popular downtown lunch spot, the two men, co-workers at an air-conditioning service company, had a rare meeting of the minds.

title: No Joy for Cubs; Showdown in the Bronx
description: The Florida Marlins advanced to the World Series last night, putting the finishing touch on a Chicago Cubs collapse for the ages with a 9-6 victory at Wrigley Field in Game 7 of the National League Championship Series.

title: Form Follows Inspiration, Echoing the Allegheny Bridges
description: The three suspension bridges on the Allegheny River in downtown Pittsburgh are known as the Three Sisters bridges. When Rafael Violy, the Manhattan architect, designed the David L. Lawrence Convention Center on the Allegheny there, he created a building that was modeled on a bridge, with a suspension-cable roof. The convention center, which cost $365 million and opened last month, has a low profile at the riverfront and swoops up on the city side. Exhibitors can show their wares under natural light, right, as they do in many European convention centers. With natural light, Mr. Violy said, ''You save a lot of energy.''

title: Jets Will Mix and Match in Secondary Against Texans
description: The Chiefs' secondary was such a mess the week before the 1993 American Football Conference championship game that Kansas City's 38-year-old defensive backs coach -- Herman Edwards -- played safety in practice. Ten years later and nearing 50, Edwards, a former N.F.L. cornerback, probably wishes he could step in for the Jets right now.

title: Cafe Con Leche: A Recipe
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAW, DAVID BUCHANAN
description: LAW--David Buchanan, 65, died at his home on Friday, October 10th after a 6-month battle with cancer. He is survived by his wife, Jane Cullen Law; their two children; Christopher and Peter; his former wife Kathleen Marion Law and their children Laura Law Ney, Eric Law, Jennifer Law, all of Los Angeles; brother Peter Law of Los Angeles; sisters Susan Hoogs of Tucson, AZ and Diana Palmer of Kinnewick, WA; two grandchildren Chloe and Dillon Ney. Memorial celebration is Monday, October 20th, 6PM at Barge Music, Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn; reception afterwards at the Law residence.

title: Some Rough Days in October, in Microscopic Detail
description: THEY MARCHED INTO SUNLIGHT

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Gucci's Sales Rise
description: The luxury goods maker Gucci Group said sales from August to early October rose at the fastest rate in two years. The Italian company, which is registered in the Netherlands, said fiscal second-quarter profit fell 47 percent, to 22.7 million euros ($26.6 million), in the three months ended July 31 from 42.8 million euros a year earlier. Sales, led by the company's handbags and by Yves Saint Laurent sandals, rose 1.1 percent, to 583.7 million euros. Excluding currency exchange factors, revenue rose 20 percent in the United States and 14 percent in Japan, the chief executive, Domenico De Sole, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAMBRA, JOSEPH PAUL
description: DAMBRA -- Joseph Paul. Passed quietly, in the presence of his son, on October 11, 2003. He was 53, and is also survived by a treasured daughter, along with her loyal son. Cherished husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, nephew, cousin, and friend. Family and friends mourn with unspeakable sadness the untimely loss of this deeply loved man. His spirit continues to brighten and nurture the lives of the many whom he touched. He was surrounded ever and until the end, in sickness and in health, by his devoted and loving wife, Mary. Memorial wake will be held on Thursday, October 16, 1-4 and 6-9; and Friday, October 17, 12-5 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, October 18, 9-11 at Saint Paul the Apostle Church, 59th Street and Columbus Avenue.

title: 2 in House Question Halliburton's Iraq Fuel Prices
description: Two senior Democratic congressmen are questioning whether Halliburton is overcharging the United States government in the procurement of gasoline and other fuel for Iraq, which is now importing oil products to stave off shortages.

title: Digital Jukebox Ties the Knot With a Reformed Napster
description: Napster, the Internet service that made downloading songs addictive, has emerged from legal limbo, and this time it comes with authorized hardware, courtesy of Samsung Electronics. Just as the iTunes Music Store is intended to foster a relationship with the Apple iPod, the Samsung Napster YP-910GS, a digital jukebox with a 20-gigabyte hard drive, is meant to work closely with the reborn Napster 2.0 music service.

title: Ford Narrows Its Losses as It Exceeds Wall St.s Estimates
description: DETROIT, Oct. 16  Buoyed by its financial operations and cost cutting, the Ford Motor Company reported today that it had narrowed its losses in the third quarter, and it handily beat Wall Street estimates for the second time in two quarters.

title: After Gaza Attack, Bush Rebukes Arafat
description: President Bush condemned the assault that killed three Americans in Gaza on Wednesday and blamed Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestinian Authority, for blocking security reforms that could thwart such attacks.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Share Buyback
description: The Japanese telecommunications company Nippon Telegraph and Telephone spent 39 billion yen ($358.3 million) to buy back 72,381 of its own shares. Most of those shares were sold earlier by the government, which raised 45.9 billion yen by selling some of NTT shares. The remaining shares were bought by investors. Over all, NTT plans to spend as much as 100 billion yen to buy back as many as 200,000 of its own shares. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: City's Worst Transportation Disasters
description: The worst accident on a Staten Island ferry was the explosion of a boiler on the Westfield II, which killed 125 passengers as the boat departed South Ferry on July 30, 1871.

title: Bush Re-asserts Pre-emptive Strategy in Speech
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Oct. 16 - President Bush embarked today on his longest trip to Asia by re-asserting America's right to take pre-emptive action against its enemies, and with a warning that the world cannot allow Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim nation, to be ``defined'' by Islamic extremists.

title: Corrections
description: An article in late editions yesterday about a party in honor of George Plimpton, who died on Sept. 26, misspelled the given name of a novelist who attended. He is Allan Gurganus, not Alan. In some copies the article also misspelled another writer's surname. (That error also appeared in Mr. Plimpton's obituary on Sept. 27.) The writer is Peter Matthiessen, not Mathiessen.

title: DUKE UNIT TO BUY OIL PRODUCTION AND PIPELINES IN TEXAS
description: Teppco Partners, a United States pipeline owner controlled by the Duke Energy Corporation, agreed to buy oil production and pipelines in Texas from Genesis Energy for $21 million to increase deliveries to Houston refineries. The acquisition includes 150 miles of small-diameter trunk lines that handle about 24,000 barrels of oil a day, Teppco said. The company, which is based in Houston, also acquired rights to sell about 12,000 barrels a day of oil production. The lines will be integrated with Teppco's existing South Texas system, the unit vice president, Sam Brown, said.

title: Features; When Is a Phone Like a Pizza Slice?
description: The N-Gage, the Game Boy-like portable console that Nokia delivered last week after months of speculation and expectation, is also a full-fledged cellphone. Now it is up to consumers to decide whether it fulfills its promise to deliver both fun and function.

title: Primedia Names New Chief After Looking for 7 Months
description: After a search of nearly seven months, Primedia yesterday named Kelly P. Conlin, a former head of the world's largest technology publisher, its president and chief executive.

title: USED-CAR CHAIN LOWERS EARNINGS ESTIMATES
description: CarMax Inc., the used-car chain, lowered its earnings estimates for its latest quarter because of poor sales, setting off an 18 percent decline in its stock price. The company, which is based in Richmond, Va., said it expected to post earnings of 16 to 18 cents a share for the third quarter, down from a September forecast of 19 cents to 21 cents a share. The boys are down, 6-4, in the seventh inning, and it's the Yankees they're playing, which means closer Mariano Rivera is just about ready to glide to the mound and obliterate your dreams. So you start thinking that maybe this wonderful ride is about to end, and then it happens. The alarm clock goes off, and it's 6 o'clock in the morning all over again, as the Boston Red Sox sit up, stretch their arms and spring into action, ready to live another day, to play another game in the American League Championship Series.

He said Russia hoped to have official observer status soon at the organization, which represents 57 nations with Muslim populations or large Muslim minorities. Mesa said on Tuesday that it would start a hostile bid to get shareholders of Atlantic Coast to replace that company's board in hopes that a new board would approve a takeover by Mesa Air. Last week, Mesa offered to swap 0.9 share of Mesa for each share of Atlantic Coast. At the time, the stock swap was valued at more than $512 million. Mesa operates mostly in the West and Midwest, while Atlantic Coast operates on the East Coast and in the Midwest. A merger would form the country's largest regional airline.

Germany has strict laws banning Nazi symbols, slogans and salutes. The dog, a German shepherd crossbreed named Adolf, is said to have performed the trick at its master's request -- ''Adolf sit. Give me the salute.'' -- in front of policemen. The man, identified only as Roland T., is accused of wearing a T-shirt with Hitler's picture and shouting ''Heil Hitler!'' on various occasions. If convicted, Adolf's owner faces three years in jail. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: ICN TO CUT DRUG MANUFACTURING TO FOCUS ON RESEARCH

The manufacturing work force at ICN will be reduced to 1,300 to 1,400 people, the company said. ICN has 3,200 manufacturing employees, compared with about 8,000 at the end of last year. ICN sold a radiation-exposure detection services business this month and in June sold its Russian factories and pharmacy chain. The company is selling plants in Bryan, Ohio, and in Mexico, Brazil, Poland, Canada, Spain and Argentina.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Ex-SanDisk Employee Said To Steal Stock
description: A former employee of the SanDisk Corporation's Taiwan law firm stole $100 million worth of stock from SanDisk, the company said yesterday. SanDisk, a maker of memory cards based in Sunnyvale, Calif., had given the Taiwanese firm, Lee & Li, about 121 million shares of the United Microelectronics Corporation to hold in trust. A former senior legal staff member, who was not named, reportedly sold the shares on the Taiwanese stock exchange. A Sandisk spokesman, Mike Wong, said the person's whereabouts were unknown. SanDisk said it had been assured by Lee & Li that it would not suffer any loss as a result of the crime. It is sending a team to Taiwan to investigate. Officials at Lee & Li and U.M.C. were not immediately available to comment. Shares of SanDisk rose $3.21, to $78.65.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Releases First Security Update
description: Microsoft released its first monthly security update yesterday, following a new schedule that attempts to ease the load on overburdened system administrators. The first update consists of five vulnerabilities Microsoft deems ''critical,'' the top rating the company assigns to security flaws. The ranking is used to designate security flaws that could allow online vandals to take control of a user's computer or create an Internet worm that could spread from system to system. ''All of the five critical vulnerabilities are, of course, critical, so that means they are wormable,'' said Jeff Jones, senior director of Microsoft's security business unit. Three of the critical flaws affect all of the Windows operating systems currently supported by Microsoft, including various editions of Windows NT, Windows 2000, Windows XP and Windows Server 2003. Another critical flaw affects only Windows 2000, and the fifth such flaw affects Microsoft's Exchange Server 5.5 and Exchange 2000 Server products. More information on the flaws -- numbered MS03-041 to MS03-047 -- can be found on Microsoft's security Web page.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: GROKSTER PRESIDENT JOINS OPTISOFT Wayne Rosso, a colorful music business veteran who became one of the industry's most verbal critics, has resigned as president of the file-sharing network Grokster to lead Optisoft, a maker of peer-to-peer networks promising users more privacy. Optisoft SL, based in Madrid, is the creator of file-sharing programs like Blubster, Piolet and the underlying MP2P technology that enables users to exchange data more securely and anonymously, Mr. Rosso said. He became chief executive officer yesterday. These newer stealth services are just now gaining ground as peer-to-peer users look to swap songs and other content on the Web without risking legal action from the Recording Industry Association of America, which recently sued about 260 people for illegal file-sharing. Mr. Rosso, 54, served as a publicist and marketing professional in the music business for 34 years. (Reuters)

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: County Gives In On Landfill

The commissioners, Charles Ware, Evelyn Kendricks and Jane Hubert, agreed under protest to sign a letter ordered by Judge E. Purnell Davis saying an Atlanta developer's 1,030-acre landfill would meet county zoning rules, said their lawyer, Albert Dallas. The landfill still needs approved by the state environmental agency. The county is about 80 miles east of Atlanta. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Genzyme Says Profit To Exceed Forecast
description: The Genzyme Corporation, the biotechnology company, said yesterday that this year's profit would exceed an earlier forecast amid surging sales of its drugs for rare diseases, after it posted a quarterly loss. Revenue jumped 60 percent to $437 million in the third quarter as sales of its Renagel dialysis treatment more than doubled, the company said. Genzyme, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., had a net loss of $95.7 million in the third quarter on the purchase of the SangStat Medical Corporation, it said in a statement. Genzyme shares gained $1.59, or 3.2 percent, to $51.58. The company had a net loss of 43 cents a share in the quarter, compared with net income of $53.4 million, or 25 cents a share, a year ago. Genzyme said it expected a profit for the full year of as much as $1.39 a share, excluding some costs.

Puzzled, I checked the manual and learned that to put a game in the N-Gage, I had to open up the back, remove the rechargeable battery, slide in the card and replace the battery and cover.

description: Radiohead may have cheated when it accompanied the Merce Cunningham Dance Company in ''Split Sides'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday night. For most of his 50-year career, Mr. Cunningham has treated music and dance as simultaneous but independent parts of the performance. Radiohead and Sigur Ros, the two art-rock bands that performed music for ''Split Sides,'' were instructed to provide only 20 minutes of music each.

description: CONSERVATIVE and liberal political commentators alike have wondered why most Americans have enthusiastically supported two of the largest tax cuts in history even though most benefits will flow to upper-income families. Adding to the conundrum, in public opinion surveys Americans routinely express support for spending more on government programs like education, opposition to government budget deficits, and disappointment that the gap in income between rich and poor has widened -- all of which are in conflict with regressive tax cuts.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Criticism Follows Concert Riot
description: The police in Montreal said they were caught by surprise by a riot that erupted Tuesday night after hundreds of punk-rock fans waiting outside a downtown hall were told that two bands would not be performing and that the show was canceled. Several shop owners and onlookers were critical of the police for the time it took them to arrive at the riot, in which 42 cars were damaged, with some turned upside down and left burning, and 11 shops vandalized. A music store was looted. The concertgoers were told that some members of the bands, Total Chaos and The Exploited, had been denied entry from the United States by customs officials. Seven people were arrested in the rampage. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPANGENBERG, EDITH
description: SPANGENBERG--Edith. Died peacefully in her sleep October 13, 2003 at New York Presbyterian Hospital after a long illness. Edith was born in Lucerne, Switzerland on January 10, 1925. Her parents were Judge Otto Lauber and Inez de Charriere Lauber. Her husband Lester and daughter Dr. Maya Lauber Spangenberg predeceased her in recent years. Living in NYC for over 40 years, she was a registered nurse, affiliated with the office of Dr. Isadore Rosenfeld of New York Presbyterian Hospital. An active member of Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, she is survived by a twin brother Rene Lauber, a brother Eric Lauber and a nephew Mark Lauber of Switzerland. A memorial service will be held at Central Presbyterian Church on Park Ave at 63 St, Monday, October 20, at 11 AM.

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: COUNTY GIVES IN ON LANDFILL After being jailed overnight for contempt of court, members of the Taliaferro County Commission ended more than a year's resistance to the zoning of a proposed landfill in their county, the second-poorest in the state. The commissioners, Charles Ware, Evelyn Kendricks and Jane Hubert, agreed under protest to sign a letter ordered by Judge E. Purnell Davis saying an Atlanta developer's 1,030-acre landfill would meet county zoning rules, said their lawyer, Albert Dallas. The landfill still needs approved by the state environmental agency. The county is about 80 miles east of Atlanta. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCGEE, DOROTHY HORTON
description: McGEE--Dorothy Horton, on October 12, 2003, resident of Locust Valley, L.I. Beloved daughter of Col. Hugh H. and Dorothy Brown McGee. Funeral service at Christ Church, Oyster Bay, Long Island, Monday, October 20th at 10:30 AM. Burial at U.S. Military Academy, West Point, NY. For further information Oyster Bay Funeral Home.

title: Justice Obstruction Charges Called Possible in Fund Case
description: The New York attorney general and the Securities and Exchange Commission are planning to take action against a former senior executive of Fred Alger Management in the latest chapter of the investigation into the improper trading of mutual fund shares, persons briefed on the case said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Party Merger Closer
description: Two conservative parties, the Progressive Conservative and the Canadian Alliance, appeared close to reaching an agreement to run together in federal elections next year. ''Clearly negotiations have reached a point where we feel we have something in principle,'' the Progressive Conservative leader, Peter MacKay, said. Polls indicate that even if the parties merge, they would still trail far behind the governing Liberals. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Houston Returns to Practice
description: In the city of glitzy excess, Allan Houston's first practice since recovering from June knee surgery could not be an understated event for him or for the Knicks.

description: CHICAGO

title: Clark's Campaign Releases Glowing Accounts of His Military Career
description: The campaign of Gen. Wesley K. Clark, who has based his Democratic presidential bid on his career in the United States Army, this week released 200 pages of internal military evaluations from his commanding officers, who repeatedly used superlatives to describe his skills, energy and leadership abilities.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BOSNIA: U.N. RAIDS SECURITY OFFICES United Nations war crimes investigators backed by NATO troops raided Bosnian Serb security offices around the country searching for documents, a United Nations official said. The raid came a week after Carla Del Ponte, chief prosecutor at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, accused Bosnia, along with Croatia and Serbia, before the Security Council of a lack of cooperation, especially regarding the arrests of war crimes suspects.    (Reuters)

title: Ozone May Offset Capacity Of Trees to Sop Up Carbon
description: Scientists have long identified forests as a potential buffer against rising concentrations of carbon dioxide, the main smokestack and tailpipe emission linked by most scientists to global warming.

description: THE landscape architect Michael Van Valkenburgh stood by the 10 red maples he planted years ago near his modest 1849 white shingle farmhouse on Martha's Vineyard, and talked about something so subtle I had to pay close attention.

title: Something to Agree On: It Was Windy Out There
description: As if the field needed any more litter, enough plastic grocery bags to stock an express checkout line were dislodged from the upper deck at Yankee Stadium yesterday when Nomar Garciaparra swung at a pitch from Jos Contreras in the seventh inning.

title: Yet Again, There's No Joy In Wrigley
description: As their team's outs ran out, Cubs fans at Wrigley Field stood, some for a better view, some to show they had not given up hope and others refusing to accept that this could happen again. Outside, hundreds more were chanting ''Let's go Cubs!'' as they watched on television.

title: Agreement Reached on Asbestos Bill
description: Asbestos manufacturers and their insurers, which have been at bitter odds over a bill that would create a trust fund to compensate hundreds of thousands of victims of asbestos exposure, reached an important agreement Wednesday afternoon. The deal removed a major obstacle to Senate action on the measure.

description: In percent

description: A Senate committee on Wednesday approved the nomination of Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah, the administration's choice to head the Environmental Protection Agency.

description: An article yesterday about a Florida court order to remove a woman's feeding tube referred incorrectly to Pinellas Park, where she resides in a hospice. It is not a Tampa suburb; it is across the bay in Pinellas County, north of St. Petersburg.

title: China and Russia Leaning Toward U.S. Stand in U.N.
description: China and Russia offered their support on Wednesday for the latest version of the draft Security Council resolution on Iraq's future, putting heavy pressure on Germany and France to vote in favor of the measure, rather than join Syria in abstaining, Council diplomats said.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; In the Old Cities, Bitterness and Fleeting Joy
description: THERE is bitterness in Chicago today, with no redemption for the ancient franchise on the North Side.

title: Is This New York's Idaho Potato?; Entrepreneur Has Grand Plans for Black Currants
description: Greg Quinn thinks he has seen the future, and it is black currants. Millions of them, actually. Enough to save the ailing agricultural industry in New York State, enough to improve the health of the entire nation, enough to give weekend homeowners in the Hudson Valley a tax break and a sense of purpose.

title: Experimenting With Human Fertility
description: Doctors in China have achieved the first pregnancy in an infertile woman using a technique that was devised in the United States but dropped here when its chief advocate shied away from seeking regulatory approval. The case raises the perplexing question of whether tough regulation in this country is driving promising work abroad or is simply protecting American women from experimental procedures that could endanger their health or that of any resulting offspring.

title: Milestone for China: Dragon Has Landed
description: The technology is vintage Kennedy and Khrushchev, the secrecy is reminiscent of the cold war and the popular reaction is a bit of a fizzle, but China's seemingly successful effort to put a man into orbit is a sign that it intends to become a peer of the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HENLINE, DARRELL
description: HENLINE--Darrell. Memorial for Darrell Henline, founder of Cabaret Scenes Magazine, St. Thomas Church, tomorrow 6:30PM, 53rd & 5th.

title: Unheard Voices on Planning New Trade Center
description: THE faces staring up in horror that morning from the streets of Lower Manhattan were every color. So were the faces staring out from the ''missing'' fliers around the city. But the hands drawing the plans for the new World Trade Center are almost all white.

title: Keeping Tabs on Baby And Her Toasty Blanket
description: Chilly fall weather often means a good night's sleep for adults, but the seasonal effect on an infant's room may keep some new parents awake and obsessing. To reduce the need for trips down the hall to check on climate conditions in the nursery, Philips Electronics has come up with its SBC SC769 Read-and-Rest Easy baby monitor, which has a built-in room thermometer and temperature display.

title: Saudi Arabia's Big Leap
description: Saudi Arabia's announcement on Monday that within a year it will hold elections for municipal councils could be the first tremor in a slow-moving Middle Eastern earthquake.

title: A Blues Artist at the National Gallery
description: This country changed radically when the Great Migration carried millions of black people out of the rural South and into the Northern cities on legendary trains with names like the Panama Limited, the City of New Orleans and the Black Diamond Express. The great blues musicians wrote countless songs about these trains and actually tuned guitars to mimic the whistle of a train as it came roaring by.

title: President Bush's Run for the Money
description: Flush from the golden A.T.M. called incumbency, President Bush's money-raising conglomerate has just rung up a record $49 million in political donations for the latest quarter, with not a party opponent in sight. This prodigious tote was raised in large part by business leaders and lobbyists -- eagerly vying to be dubbed campaign Rangers and Pioneers. With the ''soft money'' that distorted American politics outlawed, the hard money -- individual donations of up to $2,000 per person -- continues to pour into an overflowing war chest that could easily reach $200 million, or twice the record amount that George Bush spent four years ago, when he actually had primary opponents.

title: P. & G. Weighs Buying German Maker of Nivea
description: A new corporate bidding war may be about to erupt in Germany, but it is likely to follow an old script.

title: City Offers Longer Airport Leases For $700 Million and More Rent
description: Ending a feud that has lasted nearly a decade, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that New York City would extend its lease of La Guardia and Kennedy Airports to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey until 2050 in exchange for a $700 million upfront payment and a steep increase in annual rents.

title: Bolivian Leader Offers Vote to End Protests
description: In an effort to placate the organizers of growing street demonstrations who have been demanding his ouster, President Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada announced late Wednesday that his government would call a referendum seeking approval of natural gas exports, the main cause of the unrest.

title: A Reader's Haven
description: To the Editor:

title: Dean Outpaces Competitors In Fund-Raising and Spending
description: Howard Dean not only raised three times as much money in the last three months as his nearest rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination, but he outspent them as well.

title: This Old Home Theater
description: HEY, kids -- now you can set up a home theater in your own home! Why hire expensive professional installers when you can do it yourself? It's as easy as 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7!

title: An Invitation To Groove On the Move
description: LIKE the herds of ever-smaller personal cassette players that roamed the earth in the 1980's, droves of tiny devices that play music in digital form are peeking out from pockets, purses, briefcases and backpacks everywhere you turn these days.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Friday described the insanity defense being planned by lawyers for Lee Malvo, the younger suspect in the Washington-area sniper killings, as well as a ruling involving the other suspect, John Muhammad.

title: A Labor Leader by Nature Tests His Political Muscle
description: AS confirmed by a bone-bruising handshake, his brawny palms are bone dry: look, Ma, no nerves, not even when the badgering about running for mayor starts up. And though Brian M. McLaughlin politely permits an interlocutor to steer the conversation, his agenda is on the tip of his tongue -- the magic words being ''Labor for Democracy,'' a euphemism for the highly organized backlash against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's hankering to vanquish party primaries with a charter referendum proposal on the Nov. 4 ballot.

title: I.M.F. Official Is Named President of New York Fed
description: Timothy F. Geithner, an International Monetary Fund official with experience in financial crisis management, was named president and chief executive of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business yesterday about President Bush's plan to urge Japan to stop intervening in the currency markets misstated the recent Japanese action. The country has been buying dollars -- not selling them -- to weaken the yen. The article also misstated a word in a comment from Peter Morici, a professor of business at the University of Maryland. He said said a weaker yen, not a stronger one, was damaging to the American economy.

title: Several Suspects Arrested in Bombing of U.S. Convoy in Gaza
description: GAZA CITY, Gaza Strip, Oct. 16  Facing criticism from the United States, Palestinian authorities arrested several suspects today in the bombing of an American diplomatic convoy that killed three American security workers in the Gaza Strip.

title: New I.R.S. Chief Plans to Focus on Enforcement
description: The new Internal Revenue Service commissioner, with an emphasis different from his predecessor's, says effective enforcement of the tax laws rather than further improving customer service would be the main focus of his administration.

title: France Backs Off Deal to Settle Bank Case
description: The French government has backed away from a tentative agreement reached last month to pay $575 million to avoid criminal charges related to the Crdit Lyonnais purchase of assets from a California insurance company.

title: Dealers in U.S. Suspected In Prewar Arms Sales to Iraq
description: American officials in Baghdad have identified at least 30 businesses and individuals in the United States that investigators said they suspect sold tens of millions of dollars in military technology to Iraq before the war.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Three Leaders Disagree On Deficit
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and the two top legislative leaders met behind closed doors in the State Capitol yesterday, but failed to agree on budget strategies or even the size of next year's projected deficit. Nor did the governor, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, left, address how the state will pay for the cost of complying with a court order to improve New York City schools. The Pataki administration has already predicted a gap of $5 billion to $6 billion for the fiscal year beginning April 1, 2004. Though all three men agree that the deficit requires early negotiations, no one committed to a date for a possible special legislative session before January. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Shepherding Your Files Into Their New Home
description: Q. How can I transfer documents and other important information from my current computer to a new one? Also, how can I clear out the old one before I give it away?

title: The American Prison Camp
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross recently took the unusual step of publicly criticizing the United States over the confinement of the roughly 660 detainees at the Guantnamo naval base in Cuba. After visiting the base, Red Cross officials said there was a ''worrying deterioration'' in the mental condition of the detainees, largely because they have no idea how long they will be held or what will happen to them.

title: At Vatican, a Time for the Faithful
description: VATICAN CITY, Oct. 16  It was a time for the faithful, the doubts set aside. If there were critics, they kept their own counsel.

title: Can't Even Boil Water? Your Mouse Can Help
description: IMAGINE you are in your kitchen, preparing a recipe that calls for homemade mayonnaise. You have never made it before, and the process as described in the cookbook seems daunting.

title: G.M. Profit Beats Estimates, With Aid of Finance Unit
description: General Motors, which sells more cars and trucks than any other company in the world, continues to make more money as a bank than as an automaker.

title: Game 7 for Sox and Yanks, Curses for Cubs
description: Jorge Posada has been there enough to know the feeling. If a World Series is within reach, Posada knows when to seize it, when to stomp on the other team and get there. As he caught Jos Contreras's fastballs and forkballs in the sixth inning at Yankee Stadium last night, Posada felt it. The Yankees were going to win the pennant.

title: F.D.A. PANEL BACKS BREAST IMPLANTS MADE OF SILICONE
description: In a 9-to-6 vote, an advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration recommended on Wednesday that silicone breast implants be allowed back on the market after an 11-year hiatus.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday showing properties owned by Freedom Communications, whose controlling family reached a deal to retain ownership, misstated the call letters for TV stations in Albany and Medford, Ore. (The errors also occurred in a list of company holdings on Aug. 19.) The Albany station is WRGB, not WGRB. The Medford station is KTVL, not KTLV.

title: Senior Federal Prosecutors and F.B.I. Officials Fault Ashcroft Over Leak Inquiry
description: Several senior criminal prosecutors at the Justice Department and top F.B.I. officials have privately criticized Attorney General John Ashcroft for failing to recuse himself or appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the leak of a C.I.A. operative's identity.

title: Big Board Set To Fine Firms Over Trading
description: The New York Stock Exchange has decided to fine its five largest floor-trading firms about $150 million for trading in ways that deprived investors of the best price they could have received.

title: Anglican Leaders Work to Avoid a Split Over Gay U.S. Bishop
description: In an emergency meeting called by the archbishop of Canterbury, 37 Anglican church leaders from around the world met at Lambeth Palace on Wednesday and struggled to avoid a schism over the election of an openly gay bishop in the United States.

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: PENNSYLVANIA: PITTSBURGH'S BOND RATING PLUMMETS Standard & Poor's Rating Services slashed Pittsburgh's A- bond rating to junk bond status, BB. Pittsburgh started its fiscal year in January with a $60 million budget gap, City Controller Tom Flaherty said, and the deficit is thought to have increased to about $80 million. He said the Legislature had not approved a request by Mayor Tom Murphy, a Democrat, for a new gross payroll tax and an increase in the commuter tax. As a result, 730 city workers were laid off in August, and some city services were reduced or eliminated. (Dow Jones)

title: Passage to India In Cotton Prints
description: Mary Mulcahy of Tucson and Liz Dougherty Pierce of Manhattan together own Les Indiennes, a company that designs and imports hand-printed cotton fabrics from southern India. The prints (red, indigo or gold on a white background) are based on traditional patterns, but the scale has been made larger.

title: Nets Haven't Named Starting Center Yet
description: Center Alonzo Mourning is a seven-time All-Star and a two-time N.B.A. defensive player of the year, but he has not yet earned the starting job in the middle for the Nets. Mourning insisted yesterday that he didn't mind.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The beams are coming directly at you, and the side of the boat is disappearing. They're ripping up steel, glass, chairs. People were falling. At one point I was in a pile, and I just got up and kept running. It kept coming and coming. If you didn't keep running, you were dead.''

title: Democrats Focus on Health Plans at Iowa Forum
description: The Democratic presidential candidates competing for Iowa's votes jabbed at each other Wednesday over their support for tax cuts and Medicare and their plans for health insurance before an audience of elderly voters.

title: Game Plans for Game 7: Work the Pitch Count
description: The Yankees and the Red Sox will take similar strategies to the plate in Game 7 of the American League Championship Series tonight. The Yankees always try to make Pedro Martnez throw a lot of pitches, knowing Martnez wears out when his pitch count rises. The Red Sox will try to do the same to Roger Clemens, with added incentive.

title: Drugs and Deceit Lead to Writing As Redemption
description: The annual Man Booker Prize banquet is the staidest of affairs, but occasionally it is jolted out of its late-night black-tie somnolence. In 1994 the Scottish writer James Kelman delivered a rousing denunciation of English imperialism. In 1985 Keri Hulme, home in New Zealand and informed by satellite phone that she had unexpectedly won for ''The Bone People,'' exclaimed, her voice amplified across the banquet hall, ''Aw, bloody hell!''

title: Where Sleeping Dogs Beg to Lie
description: NO one ever accused my husband or me of consistent parenting.

Pataki and the two top legislative leaders met behind closed doors in the State Capitol yesterday, but failed to agree on budget strategies or even the size of next year's projected deficit. Bruno, left, address how the state will pay for the cost of complying with a court order to improve New York City schools. The Pataki administration has already predicted a gap of $5 billion to $6 billion for the fiscal year beginning April 1, 2004. Though all three men agree that the deficit requires early negotiations, no one committed to a date for a possible special legislative session before January.   Al Baker (NYT)

title: Nipping at the Heels of a Celebrated Scooter
description: A MONTH ago, Trevor Blackwell was just another engineer, at work on the design for a walking robot to be produced by his small Silicon Valley start-up company, Anybots. On a lark, he decided to build a clone of the much-trumpeted Segway Human Transporter, and when he was done he posted the details at his Web site. Suddenly Mr. Blackwell was news, as the site attracted hundreds of thousands of visitors intrigued by the idea of a building a low-cost version of the $5,000 high-technology scooter themselves.

title: Yale Graduate Students Felt Pressure on Union
description: Many graduate students at Yale who have supported forming a union have felt threatened or intimidated by faculty members, a panel of professors and legal experts concluded in a report released yesterday.

title: Optimism Is No Substitute For Sophisticated Bidding
description: A player with a void often has trouble deciding whether to try for a slam when facing a one no-trump opening. Finding out the extent to which partner has wasted values opposite the void suit calls for sophisticated bidding, and there is a temptation to charge into slam and hope for the best. South did that on the diagramed deal and bid an optimistic six diamonds, a poor contract.

title: Capital for Companies That Aid Communities
description: As an experienced manager of call centers for a big financial information publisher in New York, Mark Wilson knew why turnover in the industry was so high: people tend to quit low-paying dead-end jobs as soon as something better comes along. A little extra investment in them might pay for itself by making them more productive, he reasoned.

title: Giving the Holiday Table a Cool Glow
description: ONCE fall arrives, it's time to think about holiday entertaining. For anyone in need of tabletop inspiration, an exhibition of 180 pieces of Viennese silver will open tomorrow at the Neue Galerie, at 1048 Fifth Avenue (86th Street). The show, which runs through Feb. 16, has pieces from 1780 to 1918 and includes early-20th-century designs by Josef Hoffmann and Koloman Moser. Originally produced by the Wiener Werkstatte in Vienna, several have been reproduced for sale in the museum's design shop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAMONT, DONALD BRECK
description: LAMONT--Donald Breck. Of Hobe Sound, Florida. Husband of Mary Ann Hamilton Lamont, father of Pamela J. Lamont of California and Susan R. Lamont of Connecticut. Died on October 8, 2003 at the age of 83. He was a Californian, raised in San Francisco, graduated from The Phillips Exeter Academy, Yale University and Harvard Business School. During WW II, he served with the U.S. Marines in the Pacific Theater and North China. As President and Director of The Interocean Oil Companies and other independent international oil exploration companies, his career in the petroleum industry spanned fifty years. A Memorial Service will be held at Christ Memorial Chapel, 52 South Beach Road, Hobe Sound, Florida on Saturday, November 22, 2003 at 4:00 PM. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his memory to Jupiter Island Clinic, P.O. Box 375, Hobe Sound, Florida 33475 or to a charity of your choice.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: A New Internet Bid
description: A South Kore-an conglomerate, the LG Group, and the Carlyle Group made a 736 billion won ($627 million) offer for control of Hanaro Telecom Inc., South Korea's second-biggest high-speed Internet service provider, challenging a bid by the American International Group and Newbridge Capital Ltd. LG, Hanaro's largest shareholder, and Carlyle would buy new shares to gain a 51 percent stake and help arrange $700 million in loans. LG, which includes the nation's biggest brokerage firm and chemicals company, and Carlyle, a Washington-based private equity fund, are trying to persuade Hanaro's shareholders to reject a $1.1 billion financing plan from American International and Newbridge. Hanaro said yesterday that it preferred the American International deal. Its shareholders will vote on the proposal on Tuesday.

title: Bank of Canada Decides To Leave Rates Unchanged
description: Shrugging off calls from exporters and labor groups to put a brake on the soaring Canadian dollar, the Bank of Canada has for now shelved its policy of cutting interest rates to stimulate the domestic economy.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 331 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Bush Makes Hand-Kissing a Laugh Line
description: When President Jacques Chirac of France made a show of kissing Laura Bush's hand on the first lady's recent trip to Paris, there was rampant speculation about what the rather un-French gesture meant.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Drug Maker's Rating Raised
description: The credit rating of the Chugai Pharmaceutical Company was raised one level, to A2, by Moody's Investors Service, which cited the benefits of the company's alliance with F. Hoffmann-La Roche Ltd. Moody's said Chugai, which merged with Roche's Japanese subsidiary, is ''better positioned to respond to the Japanese pharmaceutical sector's increasingly difficult business environment'' helped by its stronger marketing and products. title: BIG GOLD MINE OWNER DOUBLES ITS DIVIDEND
description: Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold Inc., owner of the world's biggest gold mine, more than doubled its dividend and authorized a share buyback after investors urged the company to return some excess cash. The quarterly dividend will rise to 20 cents a share from 9 cents starting with the February payment, Freeport said. The company will spend $136.4 million a year on the dividend, less than the $279.1 million in cash Freeport generated in the first six months this year. No date was set for buying as much as 20 million shares. Gold production at the Grasberg mine, in Papua, Indonesia, reached a record high in the second quarter.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: EMC Earnings Surge
description: The EMC Corporation, the builder of data storage computers, said yesterday that third-quarter earnings were more than seven times those in last year's third quarter, with a 20 percent sales gain outpacing growth in costs and as demand rose for more profitable software. Net income grew to $159.1 million, or 7 cents a share, from $21.3 million, or 1 cent a share, a year earlier. A tax resolution added 2 cents to profit. Sales rose to $1.51 billion from $1.26 billion, EMC said on its Web site. The chief executive, Joseph M. Tucci, has cut costs and demanded more sales of software and services after losses in 2002 and 2001. Dell, which sells the company's gear, produced more than 10 percent of EMC's third-quarter sales, Mr. Tucci said. Revenue grew faster than the cost of sales in the third quarter, and expenses like research and development fell. EMC shares rose 52 cents, to $13.36.

He served under the former chief executive, Kent Kresa. Mr. Kresa retired as chief executive at the end of March and as chairman last month. Ronald D. Sugar now holds both jobs.

According to the text that appears onscreen at the end of Joel Schumacher's new biopic, in which Cate Blanchett plays Guerin, her death incited public outrage and spurred the passage of new laws, which helped to ease the drug trafficking and related crimes that had plagued Ireland for so long.

description: Carlisle Floyd knows how to write an opera. Historically, critics have not been all that crazy about the way he does it. His idiom is a clear if reasonably sophisticated tonality, and he lays out his ideas in big, solid blocks: a rhythmic gesture setting the tone for a whole scene; a melody planted so that it can be brought back later. What critics have found simplistic or shallow, audiences have found effective and affecting.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Penalty Toughened For Serial Stalking
description: A bill that toughens penalties against stalkers who threaten 10 or more people was signed into law yesterday by Gov. George E. Pataki. The law was prompted, legislators said, by a 2001 case in Nassau County in which a serial stalker telephoned 72 women and threatened their families with violence if the women did not perform sex acts before a mirror. Under the law, the penalty for stalking 10 or more people will be raised from a misdemeanor to a felony punishable by up to four years in prison for each stalking crime. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: WIDESPREAD BIAS REPORTED AFTER 9/11 More than two-thirds of Muslims, Arabs and South Asians responding to a New York City survey say they were victims of discrimination in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terror attack. The city's Commission on Human Rights distributed 11,800 written surveys in six different languages throughout the city. Of the 956 that were filled out and returned, 659, or 69 percent, reported being the victims of discrimination. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that New York is "defined by its tolerance" and will not tolerate acts of discrimination or bias.

title: Staten Island Ferry Tragedy
description: Among the many ways of getting to work in New York, the Staten Island Ferry is unique, offering free rides and one of the most spectacular commutes in America. But the ferry's image took a dark turn on Wednesday with the crash that left at least 10 dead and dozens injured, the first fatal accident since the city took over the ferry service 98 years ago. Still, ferry riders returned yesterday morning. According to Iris Weinshall, the city's transportation commissioner, ''It was an eerily normal rush hour.''

title: Bush to Face Asian Fears of New U.S. Unilateralism

Boone danced around the bases, raising his arms, beaming, grinning wildly. And there was Rivera, overcome with joy, the kind of mystical October euphoria that has sometimes seemed out of reach for these Yankees, celebrating in his own way.

title: CIMA SAYS ANOTHER SUITOR HAS TOPPED AAIPHARMA'S BID
description: The drug maker Cima Labs, which agreed to be bought by AaiPharma in August, said yesterday that it had been approached by an unnamed pharmaceutical company about a takeover and had begun talks. Cima said the offer would be worth about $30 a share in cash and stock, valuing the company at $435 million, compared with the AaiPharma bid of about $340 million. Cephalon has also made an offer. Cima's process that allows medicines to dissolve quickly in the mouth so patients do not have to swallow pills with water would allow drug makers to create patent-protected versions of medicines facing generic competition. Shares of Cima rose $3.49, or 13 percent, to $31.37.

title: ASTRAZENECA BUYS $100 MILLION STAKE IN ABGENIX
description: The drug maker AstraZeneca said yesterday that it had bought a $100 million stake in Abgenix, a California biotechnology company, to gain rights to as many as 36 experimental cancer treatments. The company will buy Abgenix convertible preferred stock, which can be exchanged at $30 a share, AstraZeneca's chief executive, Tom McKillop, said. AstraZeneca, based in London, will get a stake of about 4 percent and may buy an additional $60 million in stock if Abgenix meets certain goals. ''This gives us a chance to expand our scope quickly, which is what we wanted to do,'' Mr. McKillop said.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: F.C.C. Sets New Rules On Wireless Technology
description: The Federal Communications Commission has adopted new rules to promote wireless technology using high-frequency spectrum bands previously reserved for the government. The technology, which is still under development, would work like wireless fiber optic cables, officials said. Data would be transmitted on narrow ''pencil beams'' that can operate in close proximity while avoiding interference. ''The highly advanced technology used here may encourage a broad range of new products and services, such as high-speed wireless local area networks and broadband access systems for the Internet,'' said Michael K. Powell, the F.C.C. chairman.

description: CHICAGO, Oct. 16 — Florida catcher Ivan Rodriguez and closer Ugueth Urbina could not wait. Paul Bako's fly ball to left had barely reached its apex when Rodriguez and Urbina began leaping on the infield grass at Wrigley Field on Wednesday night. Then they looked to make sure that Jeff Conine had squeezed the last out of the National League Championship Series, and the moshing resumed.

title: Drug-Testing Agency Tells of a Steroid Scheme by U.S. Athletes
description: A previously undetected steroid has been identified and a new test indicates that as many as a half-dozen athletes in track and field have recently used the performance-enhancing drug, American drug-testing officials said yesterday.

title: Interim Chief Details Exchange Overhaul
description: John S. Reed, interim chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said that he intended to overhaul the exchange's board soon, removing most of its directors and having its regulatory apparatus report only to directors with no ties to the securities industry or listed companies.

title: Mahathir tells Muslims to unite against Jews
description: SINGAPORE:  Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad of Malaysia lashed out Thursday against what he described as the Jewish subjugation of Muslims, urging a gathering of Muslim leaders to help harness the Islamic world's collective brainpower to turn the tide.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fidelity Increases Bank Stake
description: The mutual fund operator Fidelity Investments increased its stake in the Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group to become its largest holder of common shares. Fidelity Investments Japan now has 5.16 percent of Sumitomo Mitsui, Japan's second-largest lender, according to documents filed with Japanese financial regulators. The shares are held by funds run by Fidelity, which manages about 2 trillion yen of investor money ($18.2 billion) in Japan. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Ferry Was Moving at Full Throttle, Investigators Say
description: The Staten Island ferry that crashed on Wednesday, killing 10 people and injuring dozens, was moving at full throttle when it slammed into the wood-and-concrete pier at the end of its run from Lower Manhattan, investigators said today.

title: A Dcor Collection, From Bill Blass
description: Bill Blass may have been a legendary fashion designer, but he never considered himself a collector. ''I'm not that pretentious,'' he told his friend John Richardson, the Picasso biographer who helped him buy pictures in London.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERN, DINAH SAND
description: STERN--Dinah Sand. Born May 27, 1908 in New York City. Daughter of the late Jacob and Anna Sand. She was the devoted wife of the late Abner Stern, beloved mother of Elinor Gollay, adored sister of Miriam Sand Siffert and the late Harry and Joseph Sand. Dinah was a creative, dedicated and energetic educator. She was particularly innovative in the development of programs in reading techniques. She worked throughout the City for The New York Public Schools as a teacher and principal. She died in St. Petersburg Florida on October 15, 2003. Services will be private.

title: Flash Of 70's Sequins
description: HUGH JACKMAN'S shoulders must ache like the devil when he wakes up in the morning. After all, this able-bodied, infinitely appealing young man is spending most of his nights engaged in the heaviest lifting this side of a Mr. Universe training camp. No shoulders, no matter how broad, should be asked to heft such a burden.

title: Evoking Staten Island in Miniature, a World of Work and Close Ties
description: They were tradesmen and office workers, a security guard and a cook, either building ''the city'' that gleamed across the bay or working in it. One took the ferry on his commute from New Jersey because it was cheap and he needed money for college. Another loved the boat so much he had a pastel of it in his living room.

description: Two exceptional young dancers, Joel Carreo and Viengsay Valds, led the exuberant version of ''Don Quixote'' that opened a run by the Ballet Nacional de Cuba on Wednesday, continuing through Sunday at City Center.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Apartheid Spy Inquiry
description: A government-appointed commission convened briefly this week to investigate whether senior members of the governing political party, the African National Congress, spied for the former apartheid government. Two allies of the vice president, Jacob Zuma, have accused Bulelani Ngcuka, the director of public prosecutions, of spying for apartheid authorities. Mr. Ngucka denied the charges. Supporters of the African National Congress say the allegations are simply an attempt to draw attention away from the prosecutor's own investigation into whether Mr. Zuma accepted a $71,000 bribe from a French arms company. The commission will reconvene next month. Sharon LaFraniere (NYT)

description: Facing criticism from the United States, Palestinian authorities arrested several suspects Thursday in the bombing of an American diplomatic convoy that killed three American security specialists in the Gaza Strip.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about suicides and other deaths on New Jersey Transit tracks misstated the day that a woman was killed by a train in Millington. It was last Friday, not Sunday.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Judge Says Vonage Is A Data Provider
description: A federal judge who ruled without explanation last week that Minnesota was not to regulate Vonage's voice-over-the-Internet service said in a written opinion published yesterday that Vonage is not a phone company but an information provider that uses the phone network. Judge Michael J. Davis said that Minnesota's effort to make Vonage submit to its telecommunications regulations conflicted with Congress's clear intent in federal legislation not to allow states to regulate Internet services. The opinion left open whether state efforts to regulate voice-over-Net companies might violate the commerce clause of the Constitution, which restricts states from interfering with interstate commerce. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Giambi Dropped to 7th in Lineup
description: It had been more than five years since Jason Giambi batted seventh in the order, but Joe Torre picked the biggest game of Giambi's life to put him there last night.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: POLLUTION PERMITS Timber companies that engage in forest logging should be required to obtain federal storm-water pollution permits, a federal judge ruled. The judge, Marilyn Hall Patel of Federal District Court in San Francisco, said the Environmental Protection Agency misconstrued the 1972 federal Clean Water Act by exempting logging companies from going through the permitting process for storm-water runoff. Runoff of dirt, debris and chemicals is a major pollutant in rivers. The ruling, on Tuesday, came in a suit by the Environmental Protection Information Center and other groups against the E.P.A. and a Pacific Lumber Company logging operation in Humboldt County. (AP)

title: Hobbling the Oscars
description: Piracy is bad, whether it's with a DVD, a CD or a Spanish galleon. But one effort to combat piracy -- banning the sending of movie DVD's and videocassettes to those voting on the Oscars -- feels like a Hollywood feint. The heads of some of the biggest movie studios have sent out Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, to explain why there will be no free DVD's this year for the 6,000 people who decide on the Oscars. As Mr. Valenti puts it, ''I'm trying to save an industry.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Mixing Catchy Pop Images To Make Haiku Writ Large
description: IT seems oddly fitting that the hospital in Grand Forks, N.D., where James Rosenquist was born in 1933, turned into the Happy Dragon Chinese Restaurant. Some years ago, when he gave a lecture at the University of North Dakota, he was introduced as ''the most famous artist ever born at the Happy Dragon Chinese Restaurant.'' He laughed, and made a joke that he thought it was really ''the Happy Hour Restaurant, but it's the Happy Dragon.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Danone's Sales Rise
description: The food and water company Groupe Danone said third-quarter sales climbed 5.2 percent and predicted full-year growth would be at the high end of its target after a heat wave lifted demand for drinks. Sales rose to 3.49 billion euros ($4.04 billion) in the quarter from 3.32 billion euros a year earlier.

title: Rowland's 18-Year-Old Stepson Is Arrested on a Drug Charge
description: The 18-year-old stepson of Gov. John G. Rowland was arrested on Monday night on charges of possession of marijuana and interfering with the police, after officers broke up a party at a friend's house in Newington, the police said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Widespread Bias Reported After 9/11
description: New York City survey say they were victims of discrimination in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terror attack. The city's Commission on Human Rights distributed 11,800 written surveys in six different languages throughout the city. Of the 956 that were filled out and returned, 659, or 69 percent, reported being the victims of discrimination. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that New York is ''defined by its tolerance'' and will not tolerate acts of discrimination or bias. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Steps In as Fines Are Planned on 5 Firms
description: Federal regulators are playing a significant role in determining the fines and penalties that New York Stock Exchange regulators said yesterday could be imposed on five firms for improper trading, according to executives briefed on the cases.

title: For Kate and Anna McGarrigle, Music Is a Family Affair
description: The English mezzo-soprano Monica Sinclair once told a friend of mine that more than 50 years ago, after she had finished her duties as a Flower Maiden, she had watched from the wings of the Royal Opera House as the great German bass Ludwig Weber sang the part of Gurnemanz in the third act of Wagner's ''Parsifal.'' At every performance, he had tears rolling down his cheeks during the ''Good Friday Spell.'' You can hear those tears, or imagine you do, in Weber's singing in the live recording of ''Parsifal'' from the 1951 Bayreuth Festival.

title: With One Swing, Boone's Season Is Sweet
description: Aaron Boone remained on the bench for seven and a half innings last night. He knew he deserved to be there. He had struggled in the playoffs for the Yankees, managing only five hits in 31 at-bats, and Enrique Wilson could hit Pedro Martnez a lot better.

title: Police Focus on Last Hours Of Student Who Was Slain
description: An investigation into the Sunday-morning shooting death of a Connecticut college student has swung from the bars of Manhattan to the Brooklyn home where investigators think he spent his final hours at a party, the police said.

But consoles, bolted into place overhead, can get in the way when owners decide to customize their vehicles by adding still more equipment, like drop-down video screens.

description: Perhaps the Sacramento-Washington deep freeze has begun to thaw.

The company said the suspect was a former member of a Taiwan law firm it hired, not a former SanDisk employee.

title: The Poisoned Well
description: It was not so much the guns of Oct. 6, 1973, and the assault of the Egyptian and Syrian armies against Israel, that changed contemporary history and remade our world. It was the use 11 days later of the ''oil weapon,'' and the price increases that followed, which tipped the scales of history.

description: PALMER--Prudence Taylor, 72, wife of T.J. Palmer of Portland, Connecticut died October 16, of cancer. She was born in New York City.
