description: In percent

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Raises 2003 Forecasts Again
description: Nextel Communications, the mobile telephone company, yesterday raised its 2003 profit and subscriber forecasts for a second time this year after third-quarter sales and profit beat analysts' expectations. Net income fell to $348 million, or 32 cents a share, from $383 million, or 55 cents a share, a year earlier as expenses rose, said the company, which is based in Reston, Va. Third-quarter sales jumped 27 percent to $2.89 billion. Nextel is selling a wider range of products, like a nationwide version of a walkie-talkie service that lets users talk by pushing a button rather than dialing numbers. Shares of Nextel rose 24 cents, to $22.36.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Oil Profit Rises
description: The oil refiner and petrochemicals maker Reliance Industries said its quarterly income rose 26 percent, to 12.6 billion rupees ($278 million), on a 10 percent increase in sales. The company, which operates in petrochemicals, energy, textiles and telecommunications, said its sales rose to 127 billion rupees ($2.8 billion) in the period, which ended Sept. 30 and was the second quarter of its fiscal year. Reliance earned 10 billion rupees ($220 million) a year earlier. Saritha Rai (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: The Sweet Spot
description: ''What we have here is a form of looting.'' So says George Akerlof, a Nobel laureate in economics, of the Bush administration's budget policies -- and he's right. With startling speed, we've blown right through the usual concerns about budget deficits -- about their effects on interest rates and economic growth -- and into a range where the very solvency of the federal government is at stake. Almost every expert not on the administration's payroll now sees budget deficits equal to about a quarter of government spending for the next decade, and getting worse after that.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Flu Shots For Young Children
description: Federal health officials have recommended annual flu shots for all children from 6 months to 2 years old. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices voted unanimously to change its policy for that age group from encouraging shots to recommending them. Studies show children under 2 are in as much danger of being hospitalized for flu complications as people over 65. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: VeriSign Sells An Operation That Registers Net Addresses
description: VeriSign Inc., the company that controls many of the major functions of the Internet under government contract, sold off the part of its business that is best known to consumers to a private equity firm yesterday for $100 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Satellite Bid
description: Apax Partners Holdings and Permira Advisers, two private-equity companies, offered about $1.54 billion to buy Inmarsat Ventures, a London-based satellite operator. The offer will be $15 in cash for each Inmarsat share, Apax and Permira said. Inmarsat shareholders including Deutsche Telekom and Telenor, its largest with a 15 percent stake, have accepted the bid.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Early Runner
description: Shalva Natelashvili, a lawyer who heads the Labor Party, one of the country's most vocal parties, became the first declared candidate to succeed President Eduard A. Shevardnadze at the end of his second term in 2005. Mr. Shevardnadze said he expected there would be 40 candidates for his office. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: KENYA: JUDGES SUSPENDED Confusion gripped many courts in Nairobi, the capital, a day after after half the country's top judges were suspended while special tribunals investigate corruption allegations. Scores of people, most from rural areas, sat outside judges' chambers after being told their cases had been adjourned. "There is nothing going on here," a lawyer said. "The courts are dead." Six of the nine Appeals Court judges and 17 of 36 High Court judges were suspended by President Mwai Kibaki.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FASTENBERG, MILTON
description: FASTENBERG--Milton. Died on October 15, 2003 at the age of 91 in Phoenix, AZ. Milton practiced internal medicine on the Upper West Side for more than 40 years and dedicated his life to helping those in need, always studying so as to better serve others. He was cherished by his family and beloved by all who knew him. He was a most wonderful man. Devoted husband of 54 years of the late Hannah Werman Fastenberg. Adored father of Nathaniel and Francine Fastenberg of Phoenix, AZ. Beloved grandfather of Rachel, Bryan and Sara. Treasured brother of Leonard, Arthur, Abner, Marvin, Selma and William. Precious uncle to many. He will be sorely missed, but remembered with love by all. Services Friday October 17th, 11:45 at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: UNANIMOUS VOTE BY U.N.'S COUNCIL ADOPTS IRAQ PLAN
description: The Security Council unanimously approved Thursday an American and British resolution authorizing an American-led multinational force in Iraq. The measure also set a Dec. 15 deadline for the Iraqi Governing Council to lay out a timetable for creating a constitution and democratic government.

title: 101 Horses for Breeders' Cup
description: Funny Cide, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner who will have the Hall of Famer Julie Krone aboard, will be the sentimental favorite, but Perfect Drift is the logical betting choice when as many as 10 horses line up for the Breeders Cup' Classic on Oct. 25.

title: Slumping Sun Microsystems Posts Wider Loss
description: Showing continued signs of trouble, Sun Microsystems Inc. reported a wider loss yesterday for its fiscal first quarter and said that year-over-year sales declined for the 10th consecutive quarter. Company executives attributed the problem to continuing softness in corporate spending and said they had no plans to restructure or lay off workers.

description: The Diocese of Bridgeport announced an agreement on Thursday to pay $21 million to 40 people who claim they were the victims of sexual abuse in cases involving 16 local priests.

description: If the Internet were a century old and designed to carry water instead of electrons through its pipeline, it might look a lot like the creaking, corroding and infinitely complicated water distribution system beneath the streets of New York City.

title: Corrections

Tenet, the director of central intelligence, referred incorrectly to the comment in President Bush's State of the Union address that Mr. Tenet was blamed for not having deleted. The president said Iraq had been seeking to buy uranium in Africa. He did not specifically mention the African country of Niger, though it was identified several weeks earlier  along with Somalia and Congo  in the National Intelligence Estimate provided to members of Congress on Iraqi purchase attempts.

title: Elated, China Promises Another Space Flight in a Year or Two
description: Within hours of the safe return of the Shenzhou 5 early Thursday, China pledged to return to space within one or two years, as officials outlined a short-term space agenda that included space walks, space docking and the possible construction of a space lab or space station.

description: With his money, national Republican connections, political savvy and personal charm, Haley Barbour looked to many people last winter like a sure bet to be elected governor of Mississippi this year.

description: Maybe it is the image of a former banker, deeply tanned and dipping his toes in the surf on a Miami beach, while people here trudge windswept streets in dismal burgs. Or maybe it is the notion of a housekeeper, paid for by the German government, to keep the fellow's apartment tidy.

title: Japan Says Its U.S. Alliance Helps Maintain Asian Peace
description: With President Bush scheduled to arrive here on Friday to start a six-nation tour of Asia, Japan's defense minister said Thursday that a strong Japanese-American alliance was vital to the peace of the region at a time of great uncertainty and change.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Revises Pension Strategy
description: Four of the city's five pension funds have approved new investment policies, Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. announced yesterday. They will increase the amount invested in private equities and in real estate but continue to invest about 70 percent of their assets in equities and about 30 percent in fixed-income investments. The previous policies were criticized as out of date in a private study commissioned by Mr. Thompson, who serves as investment advisor to the pension funds. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: F.C.C. SETS NEW RULES ON WIRELESS TECHNOLOGY The Federal Communications Commission has adopted new rules to promote wireless technology using high-frequency spectrum bands previously reserved for the government. The technology, which is still under development, would work like wireless fiber optic cables, officials said. Data would be transmitted on narrow "pencil beams" that can operate in close proximity while avoiding interference. "The highly advanced technology used here may encourage a broad range of new products and services, such as high-speed wireless local area networks and broadband access systems for the Internet," said Michael K. Powell, the F.C.C. chairman.    (NYT)

title: Rose-Red City Carved From the Rock
description: Location, location, location! The scenery was sublime, but the desert terrain of Petra, an ancient metropolis at its height from the first century B.C. to the third century A.D., didn't make it the most accessible of spots. Still, an ambitious real estate developer of that time could have pushed Petra as one of the best places to prosper in the Middle East.

title: Jury Relays More Queries In Considering Banker's Fate
description: Eleven jurors spent yesterday holed up in a deliberation room debating the fate of Frank P. Quattrone, the former star technology banker, occasionally passing scrawled notes to the judge requesting clarification on the law and copies of testimony and evidence.

title: From Brink of Pennant to Brink of Despair
description: For several minutes, no one moved, not a sound was uttered, except for a few grown men unsuccessfully fighting back tears. Pedro Martnez, who fell apart in the eighth inning and probably stayed in the game too long, slumped in his chair in front of his locker, his head slumped in his hands. John Henry, the principal owner, went from player to player, issuing a comforting and paternal pat on the back. It was not the locker room of a beaten team, it was a wake.

title: A Pair of Romantics at Heart
description: It takes courage to remain an unflappable pop romantic at a time when popular culture is obsessed with the body and nasty words are bandied for male balladeers who play by the gentler, more courtly rules of the 1940's and 50's. Michael Feinstein and Jimmy Webb may represent different stripes of traditional pop romanticism; Mr. Feinstein's heart belongs to George Gershwin and Irving Berlin, while Mr. Webb's ballads come in flavors that range from country to psychedelia. But beneath the surface they are kindred spirits.

''If one of them doesn't work for me, it's history,'' he said.

title: Noguchi's Trips to Japan, Documented in Clay
description: Isamu Noguchi (1904-88) was a sculptor and designer of prodigious versatility, so it may surprise those just passingly familiar with his art that he did very little work in clay. The ceramics he did produce, however, are uncommonly interesting. Now, for the first time since 1954, a selection of them is on view in New York, along with pieces by a number of Japanese ceramists with whom Noguchi became acquainted, in an exhibition at Japan Society. This visually and intellectually exciting show was organized by Louise Allison Cort, ceramics curator at the Arthur Sackler Gallery of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.

title: Marlins Pitchers Need the Extra Day of Rest
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 16  A day after winning the National League pennant, the Florida Marlins were watching the Yankees play the Red Sox in the American League Championship Series to determine their World Series opponent. The Marlins planned to meet at 10 p.m. before flying to New York or to Boston.

title: Times Tower Is Delayed As Partner Awaits Loan
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it would delay construction of a new headquarters on Eighth Avenue until its development partner obtains financing for the 52-story project.

title: Light Verses With a Bittersweet Side
description: In ''Lost,'' a double-edged song with words by the cult lyricist Fran Landesman, a dithering eccentric reels off a rhymed list of personal items like combs and gloves that she keeps losing. Suddenly the song takes a dark turn as she adds memory, looks, a castle and a king to the list, and you're confronted by a woman helplessly throwing up her hands at everything time takes away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEEVERS, AGNES C.

title: 36 Hours | Manchester, Vt.
description: LINKED for four centuries of American history, you would think the six New England states would have more similarities than dissimilarities. But in typical old Yankee tradition, each state stubbornly refuses to go along with the crowd -- be it in dialect, diet or driving habits. The exception may be the southern Vermont village of Manchester because it boldly embraces New England eclecticism. At one time or another, the Manchester area has been known for its iron mines, marble mills, hunting lodges or mansion retreats for industrial barons. And now? Now it is known for hundreds of bustling, crowded retail outlet stores, and as the 157-year-old touchstone to the most easy-going sport on earth, fly-fishing. It is known for major ski resorts and as a place to kick back and take in fall foliage. It is both busy and peaceful. How can that be? Relax. Defying definition is classic New England. BILL PENNINGTON

You could call it deafening, but that wouldn't begin to describe the sheer overwhelming force at which it attacks you, drowning out all conversation, boring in on you with an almost physical presence. Then there is the smell, a combination of gasoline, burning rubber and stale beer. And finally there are the surroundings, a makeshift campground about the size of four football fields, home to some 500 trucks, mobile homes and R.V.'s, many separated by nothing more than a portable toilet. Thousands of people mill about, from middle-aged couples clutching ''I Got Wrecked on Redneck Hill'' T-shirts to florid-faced partygoers downing blackberry and lemon Jell-O shots while a band energetically plays ''Sweet Home Alabama.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'DONNELL, ALICE JENKINS
description: O'DONNELL--Alice Jenkins, of New York City, New York, died after a serious illness, on Thursday, October 9, 2003, at Calvary Hospital. Alice was born on October 17, 1912, in Westchester County, New York, to the late Peter and Harriet (Forbes) Jenkins. She was married to Charles S. O'Donnell, who predeceased her by many years. They had no children. Although at the time of her death Alice had no close living relatives, she was blessed with many close friends who will miss her dearly. For over 40 years, Alice worked for Ogilvy & Mather, an advertising agency in New York City, and, at 90 years of age, was a full time employee there until September of this year when she became ill. A very private person, modest and unassuming in her manner, Alice was a woman of diverse accomplishments and interests. She had a bachelor's degree from Wellesley College and a master's in psychology from Columbia University. An avid reader (especially of good mysteries), Alice was a regular visitor to the Mercantile Library. She took great pride in successfully completing the New York Times crossword puzzle every day. Alice was also an intrepid traveler and had been to many countries; she spent a lot of time in Greece and the Mediterranean. A favorite winter destination was Peter Island, where she could simply sit under a palm tree with a good book. More recently, as she became less mobile, Alice determinedly set out to see France by barge. Her final such excursion was in June. Alice generously supported many charities over her lifetime, especially The Fresh Air Fund, and devoted much of her time to helping other people. As Alice wished, there will be no reposing and no funeral service. Memorial donations may be made to the Fresh Air Fund, 633 Third Avenue, 14th Floor, New York, NY 10017 Attn. Lori Seader for Alice O'Donnell Memorial.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: EBay Shares Plunge In After-Hours Trading
description: Shares of eBay fell sharply in after-hours trading yesterday, as investors were not impressed enough by the company's financial projections for next year. EBay expects sales to grow 38 percent, to $2.9 billion. The company also expects its per-share profit to increase 50 percent, to 98 cents. But while the revenue projection matched analysts' expectations, the per-share profit estimate fell short of the $1.05 that Wall Street was looking for. In after-hours trading, eBay's shares were down $3.84 at $53.66. The company released its earnings after the close of regular trading. EBay said yesterday that its profit for the third quarter was $103 million, up 69 percent. Its sales were $531 million, up 84 percent. Excluding PayPal, the payment company that eBay acquired last October, the company's sales increased 46 percent. The company said its growth had slowed in the United States and Germany during the summer, but it expected to gain in the fourth quarter. Saul Hansell (NYT)

Dr. Simpson, 56, is a neurobiologist and is the executive vice chancellor and provost of the University of California at Santa Cruz, which has grown to 15,000 students from 11,000 in his five years there. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

A cluster of modest homes, auto-body shops and an imposing public school dot the brief stretch of Route 9G that runs through the center of the township. At the intersection of 9G and Main Street, three gas stations compete, evoking the feel of a strip mall more than a rural idyll.

title: A Poet's Death, A Death's Poetry
description: ''Dying is an art.'' These words, from Sylvia Plath's poem ''Lady Lazarus,'' are the first spoken in ''Sylvia,'' Christine Jeffs's emotionally rich life of the poet, who is played with radiant conviction by Gwyneth Paltrow. The assertion may be debatable, but there is no question that Plath's own death -- she committed suicide in 1963, at 30 -- has been subject to unending analysis and interpretation, framed by the kind of inquiry that usually guides classroom literary analysis. (The literary critic A. Alvarez, who was Plath's close friend and who is portrayed in the movie by Jared Harris, likened her death to a final unwritten poem.) What was Plath's intention? What did her suicide mean? What did it reveal about her family, her society, her time, her sex, herself?

Although the movie, tonight on USA, dramatizes the shooting spree that killed 10 people in the Washington area last year, it seems to repel attention. Maddeningly arbitrary murders and police bewilderment -- mostly staged in monochromatic scenes around highways -- do not make good drama.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Drugs From Canada
description: Gov. Tim Pawlenty, left, announced that he would set up a Web site to allow residents to buy prescription drugs from Canada, where they are cheaper. He said he also planned to hold a meeting by the end of the year for other governors to discuss the benefits of the plan. A spokesman for his office said he would establish the Web site in a matter of weeks. Mike Hatch, the state's attorney general, said he would gladly face off with the Food and Drug Administration, which opposes drug imports, if the federal government challenged the state plan in court. description: European leaders on Friday discussed ways to deepen Europe's combined defense, but sought to assuage American concerns that such plans would undermine NATO.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Profit In Software
description: India's third-largest software exporter, Wipro Ltd., said quarterly profit rose 4.4 percent on increased demand for its services to other companies. The company earned 2.3 billion rupees ($51 million) in the period, which ended Sept. 30, up from 2.2 billion rupees a year earlier. Wipro posted revenue of $222 million and forecast revenue of $241 million in the current quarter. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Presidential Ecospeak
description: President Bush's nominee to run the Environmental Protection Agency, Mike Leavitt, finally won committee approval this week, but not before a half-dozen senators had openly expressed exasperation at his habit of retreating behind ecofriendly phrases when asked about his record as Utah's governor. Which means, of course, that Mr. Leavitt will fit right in with the Bush administration. Indeed, Mr. Bush himself may fairly be said to have become the master of the ostensibly ecofriendly sound bite, offering oversimplified solutions to complex environmental problems and wrapping them in tempting slogans that hide their generally pro-business tilt.

description: Because of the Jewish holiday Shemini Atzeret, alternate-side parking regulations will be suspended today. Other regulations remain in effect.

description: Mariano Rivera had not slept enough minutes for it to matter, his valuable right arm was so sore that he was searching for prices on blocks of ice, and he felt as if someone had pummeled him in a fight. But he was smiling as he revealed his personal inventory of pain, smiling and saying that he will be poised to close another postseason game for the Yankees tonight. Obviously ready, always willing and incredibly able.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Hunters 64, Gators 0
description: In the state's first annual alligator hunting season, 64 of the 180 permitted hunters caught an alligator each, said John Bowers, a state wildlife biologist. The authorities allowed the hunt, which ran for two weeks in September, because alligators have been appearing in swimming pools, neighborhoods and on roadways since conservation efforts brought them from near-extinction in the state in the 1960's to a population of 200,000. Ariel Hart (NYT)

description: Two federal agencies, the Food and Drug Administration and the Drug Enforcement Administration, have formed a special task force to crack down on the growing tide of illicit sales of narcotics on the Internet.

description: Their ranks include a retired Navy pilot, a nurse, a bartender, a hardware-store employee and an eighth-grade teacher. They are mostly women and overwhelmingly white. Most are married and middle age. Several are retired, with grandchildren.

title: A Fair Fight in the Philippines
description: President Bush is in Manila today to visit his ally in the war against terror, President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo of the Philippines. Mr. Bush has already announced some $340 million in aid to the Philippines this year, and President Arroyo has said she plans to request additional military assistance to fight terrorism. There's only one problem with this alliance: American aid hasn't improved the Philippine military so far, and in many ways it has benefited the Islamic militants it seeks to combat.

Clayton Jones, the chief executive of Rockwell Collins, has been looking for small acquisitions in related areas of aviation equipment and electronics; it bought Airshow, a maker of climate, light and video controls for business jets, in August 2002.

title: Images of Light and Dark Connect East to West
description: Akram Khan has become a leading British modern-dance choreographer partly because of his seamless fusion of contemporary Western dance and the traditional Indian Kathak form he learned as a child in London. There are certainly identifiable Kathak elements in Mr. Khan's new work, ''Kaash,'' which opened on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, among them quick, thudding footwork and spoken rhythmic syllables.

title: Record Industry Warns 204 Before Suing On Swapping
description: The recording industry announced yesterday that it had begun its second round of lawsuits against people who swap music files on a large scale. But this time, there is a difference: the industry is notifying the 204 suspected pirates before suing them.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Investing Plan For Blacks
description: The Standard Bank Group, Old Mutual and other South African banks and insurers pledged to transfer a quarter of their ownership to black investors by 2010 as part of a 75-billion-rand ($10.7 billion) plan to loosen white control of the country's economy. The financial services charter program, includes targets for employment and training of blacks, banking services and investment in poor areas and procurement of goods and services from black-owned companies.

title: Instead of Dialogue, Bush Gives Senators Bottom Line
description: When a group of senators went to the White House this week to talk about President Bush's emergency spending bill for Iraq, they expected a dialogue on whether to rebuild the country with loan money, grants or a combination of the two. But President Bush, vehemently opposed to loans, told them flatly he was not interested in give and take.

description: Capping a week of distressing violence in this southern Westchester city, two football players have been arrested in connection with a gang sexual assault on a 15-year-old girl, the police said.

description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman told an Arab-American group here on Friday that Arabs and Jews had more similarities than differences, but he received a hostile response when he said Israel's treatment of Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank ''is not terrorism.''

title: Ex-Treasurer of Connecticut Tells of Life in Jail
description: As Connecticut's state treasurer, Paul J. Silvester had sole discretion over a $20 billion pension fund and a datebook filled with Manhattan meetings, Caribbean sojourns and Republican Party fund-raisers. These days, he testified Friday in federal court, he is a heavily medicated inmate in an overcrowded and dangerous cellblock in the Putnam County, N.Y., jail.

About 80 percent of its copies, not all of them, are distributed free.

title: Company Is Foreign at Tax Time, But Seeks Americans-Only Work
description: A big oil-well drilling company that has used one law to escape American taxes by taking addresses in Bermuda and Barbados is now trying to use another law to qualify for business open only to American companies.

description: As friends and family gathered at the funeral of a 19-year-old Connecticut college student shot to death in Brooklyn last weekend, the police arrested a man they thought might be a witness in the case on gun charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCNEILL, ELIZABETH
description: McNEILL--Elizabeth. The Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, Elizabeth (Betty) McNeill. Betty was a founding member of our organization, she began our first referral service, and was instrumental in arranging the move, many years ago, to our current location on 3rd Ave. Betty's love for psychoanalysis, her devotion to IPTAR, and her zest for life will be deeply missed.

title: GENERAL NUTRITION COMPANIES IS SOLD FOR $750 MILLION
description: Royal Numico, the European maker of baby food, agreed to sell its General Nutrition Companies to Apollo Management for $750 million and to exit the market in the United States as demand for nutritional supplements slumps. Apollo, an investment company led by the financier Leon Black, will probably complete the purchase in the next quarter. Royal Numico, which is based near Rotterdam, the Netherlands, will use the proceeds to reduce debt, said Jan Bennink, the chief executive, at a news conference. Apollo will pay less than a third of the $2.5 billion Numico paid for GNC in 1999.

Michael F. Easley asked local officials to tell Congress and the White House about the impact of federal trade policy in their communities. Mr. Easley, a Democrat, distributed a sample resolution to all county and municipal officials that said international trade agreements had been devastating, and called for a crackdown on what he called product dumping and smuggling by other countries. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Warning From Grocer
description: The Dutch grocer Royal Ahold warned investors that its 2003 results would suffer as a result of the $1.1 billion accounting scandal still plaguing the company. Ahold, which reported a 4.33 billion euro ($5 billion) net loss in 2002, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that accounting fees and legal costs would have a ''significant impact'' on 2003 results. The company added that competition in its home markets along with a worldwide economic malaise was cutting into sales, too. Some analysts speculate that Ahold will announce a sizable equity issue in the coming weeks as part of a drive to reduce debt. Ahold also said it had completed the sale of its Golden Gallon convenience store chain in the United States to the Pantry Inc. for $187 million. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: John Hawkesworth, 82, British Producer
description: John Hawkesworth, a British television writer and producer whose long-running nighttime soap opera, ''Upstairs, Downstairs,'' became an equally long-running hit on American public television in the 1970's, died on Sept. 30 in Leicester, England. He was 82.

title: Nets Smile in Looking Back At Trade With a Big Payoff
description: Eddie Griffin was AWOL from a Houston Rockets preseason game last week, then skipped the next practice, drawing an indefinite suspension. The Nets resisted the urge to tell Houston, ''I told you so.''

title: USA Track and Field Is Criticized
description: The United States Olympic Committee chastised USA Track and Field on Friday for its refusal to identify athletes who had tested positive for illegal drugs.

title: Suffolk and Nassau OTB System Failures Investigated
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board is investigating what was apparently a system failure in the processing of bets at the Suffolk Regional and Nassau Regional Off-Track Betting branches last Wednesday. Hundreds of thousands of dollars in wagers were made after races were run and the outcome already known.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about President Bush's condemnation of the assault that killed three Americans in Gaza referred imprecisely to comments by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who called the Israeli foreign minister and the Palestinian prime minister to express outrage. While he said he ''made clear to them, in the strongest possible terms, the need to move urgently to end terrorism,'' he did not call on ''both'' sides to end terrorism or otherwise suggest that Israel was supporting terrorist activities.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: NEBRASKA: JUDGE QUITS CASE A judge who told a man to speak to his daughter primarily in English stepped down from the visitation case on Thursday, accusing his critics of misinterpreting his comments. The judge, Ronald E. Reagan of Sarpy County District Court, told the father at a Sept. 15 hearing that he should communicate with the 5-year-old girl primarily in English for the sake of her education. Judge Reagan said his statement did not constitute an order because he had not formally signed off on his instructions to the father, Eloy Amador. Judge Reagan said he was stepping down because people might think any other action he took in the case had resulted from media pressure.   (AP)

title: Art and Science Meet With Novel Results
description: ''Radiant Cool'' has the makings of a gripping noir thriller: a missing body, a tough-talking female sleuth and a mustachioed Russian agent mixed up in a shadowy plot to take over the world. But the novel, by Dan Lloyd, a neurophilosopher at Trinity College in Hartford, is also a serious work of scholarship, the unlikely vehicle for an abstruse new theory of consciousness.

title: 'Angel' Meets Victim She Helped Save
description: A mystery nurse who saved the life of a man aboard the Staten Island Ferry on Wednesday stepped forward yesterday to receive the gratitude of the family of the man, Paul Esposito, whose legs were crushed when the ferry crashed.

title: After 7-Game Thriller, Yankees Prepare for Encore
description: Aaron Boone may never wake up from his dream, but Joe Torre roused him from his brief sleep around 10 a.m. yesterday. Torre did not plan to ask players to attend a morning rally at City Hall, but he reconsidered after a conversation with his wife, Alice. After what Boone did to send the Yankees to the World Series, Torre decided Boone should savor his magic moment.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''After Desert Storm, over a decade ago, the one complaint I still hear is that we went to war against Saddam Hussein but we never finished the job. Well, this finishes the job.''

title: BELLSOUTH AGREES TO SETTLEMENT IN RACIAL BIAS SUIT
description: The BellSouth Corporation agreed to pay $883,000 to end a government lawsuit that claimed the company unfairly withheld promotions for black workers in Alabama. The money will go to 23 employees in Mobile, who said they were passed up for promotion because of their race, according to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which sued on their behalf. The company agreed to improve training of managers and notify employees of any entry-level management jobs, the agency said. It sued BellSouth in 2001, contending the company discriminated against blacks working in Mobile area network and consumer services operations. BellSouth, which is based in Atlanta, did not admit any wrongdoing.

title: Sports Briefing
description: HOCKEY

title: Home Construction Up 3.4% As Builders Work on Backlog
description: The rate of home construction rose in September to its second-highest level since 1986 as Americans sought to lock in low mortgage rates and construction companies worked to fill a backlog of orders, a government report showed yesterday.

title: A Rock Impresario With a Downside
description: ''Mayor of the Sunset Strip,'' George Hickenlooper's wistful, soft-edged portrait of an elfin, vacant-eyed waif who presided for more than two decades as a social impresario of the Los Angeles rock scene, keeps its claws carefully retracted. That's probably for the best, since the documentary, which the New York Film Festival is showing tonight, still leaves a bitter aftertaste.

title: All-American Program Rooted in the Popular
description: In cities like this one, classical music's self-appointed mission to educate the public to its traditional standards of high art becomes more and more an unrealizable goal. Life has not been kind in recent years, pitting affluent suburbs against a devastated inner city. The Detroit Symphony, a creature of the first constituency but situated in the second, nearly went out of business 12 years ago, but now there is the new Max M. Fisher Music Center and the optimism it represents.

title: WESTPOINT STEVENS TO RENEGOTIATE ACCORD ON DEBT
description: WestPoint Stevens Inc., the bankrupt maker of Ralph Lauren Home, Martha Stewart and Joe Boxer bedding and bath products, said it would renegotiate an accord it had with Edward Lampert and other bondholders on a plan to restructure about $2.16 billion of debt. The company, which also makes Martex and Utica towels and bedding, filed for bankruptcy in June after posting more than $103 million of losses since 2001. WestPoint Stevens, which is based in West Point, Ga., listed $1.33 billion in assets in Chapter 11 papers filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. Mr. Lampert's ESL Investments Inc., Greenwich Street Capital Partners and Perry Capital hold a majority of the company's bonds, regulatory filings show.

title: Ready for Game 8
description: This is it. Winner takes all. Unless the Yankees win and force a Game 9. In which case the winner of that game goes to the World Series. Unless the Red Sox lose that game, too, thereby forcing a Game 10. Should the Yankees win, they'd move on to Game 11, giving Boston yet another chance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LISKA, IRENE (HENRY)
description: LISKA--Irene (Henry). Passed away on October 15, 2003. Devoted wife of Paul S. Beloved mother of Paul, Elaine and Stephen. Loving ''Granny'' of four grandchildren. Loved, respected, and adored by many. Celebratory services at St. Stephen of Hungary Church, 414 East 82nd Street on Saturday, October 25, 2003 at 11 AM.

title: An Old Memory, Not Just Revisited But Also Revised
description: For Shirley Hazzard -- not to mention her readers and her publisher -- it has been a long wait. Her last novel, ''The Transit of Venus,'' which won the National Book Critics Circle Award, was published 23 years ago.

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: PAROLE IN CHILD MOLESTATION CASE A man convicted in 1986 of molesting children at his family's day care center has been granted parole. The man, Gerald Amirault, 49, was sentenced to 30 to 40 years in prison. His mother and sister, who also worked at the center, were convicted in a separate trial. The board found that Mr. Amirault had a minimal criminal history and a good record in prison. It also found that he has "strong family and community support." Mr. Amirault will be released on April 30 at the earliest. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: College Football | Kickoff; TODAY'S TOP MATCHUPS
description: 13 Purdue (5-1) at 14 Wisconsin (6-1)

title: Clash With Shiites And Bomb Attack Leave 4 G.I.'s Dead
description: On a gritty street at the edge of town, a joint United States-Iraqi military patrol fell into a firefight with two dozen heavily armed guards of an ambitious and militant Shiite cleric near midnight on Thursday, leaving at least 10 people dead, including 3 American servicemen and 2 Iraqi security officers. Seven more Americans were reported wounded in the gun battle.

title: U.S. General Apologizes For Remarks About Islam
description: A top Pentagon general who has likened the war against Islamic militants to a battle against ''Satan'' said Friday that he wanted to apologize ''to those who have been offended by my statements.''

title: MALDEN MILLS EMERGES FROM BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: Malden Mills Industries, which makes Polartec fabrics for cold weather, said yesterday that it had left bankruptcy protection and that it would continue operations with its 1,200 employees. The company, based in Lawrence, Mass., filed Chapter 11 papers in November 2001 to reorganize more than $170 million in debt. It said its debt load was now less than $80 million. Senior lenders, led by GE Capital, and unsecured creditors will own most of the company.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the water main break in Upper Manhattan misattributed two comments about a hardware store's losses from the flood. It was the owner, Albert Taragano, not the assistant manager, Roberto Rosario, who said the store had lost $500,000 in inventory and also said: ''They shut off my electric, the phone stopped working. I'm out of business.''

title: Ferry's Crew Said to Indicate Captain Wasn't at Pilot's Side
description: Crew members have told investigators that the ranking officer of the Staten Island ferry that crashed on Wednesday apparently was not in the pilot house as it approached its dock, in violation of city procedures, according to two officials with knowledge of the investigation.

title: With a Series Yet to Come, No Rest for the Bleary
description: Because they wear the pinstripes and blue caps known the world over, because they devote their energies to that coquettish and temperamental mistress baseball, they happily sacrificed sleep and peace of mind until the last pitch was thrown early yesterday, and triumph rewarded their efforts.

title: A Century and a Half of Hope
description: One hundred and fifty years ago, the notion that street children could be rescued must have seemed out of reach. There were so many of them -- more than 10,000 in a city of fewer than a million inhabitants. The boys hawked newspapers to stay alive. The girls sang in the streets. Abuse of these children, orphaned or turned out of their homes by parents who could not afford them, was rampant.

title: Its High Hopes Dashed, Boston Reels as the Archenemy Triumphs Again
description: Could it have been any worse?

description: To the Editor:

title: For Marlins, Bandwagon Fills Up Fast
description: So pitiful was the attendance at Florida Marlins games in recent seasons that the desperate team tried out a pleading new slogan this year: ''Get back in the game.''

title: Asian Leaders Find China A More Cordial Neighbor
description: More than 50 years of American dominance in Asia is subtly but unmistakably eroding as Asian countries look toward China as the increasingly vital regional power, political and business leaders in Asia say.

title: Some Aggressive Bidding, Then the Vagaries of Chance
description: Playing accommodations for bridge tournaments vary widely. At one end of the scale is a dirty basement with no natural light. At the other end is the beautiful Hotel Cipriani in Venice, where 24 Americans played last week with Mary Jane Pool of Manhattan as the hostess. With them was the player and teacher August Boehm, who spotted a difficult defensive situation on the diagramed deal.

title: Foes of Idle Hands, Amish Seek an Exemption From a Child Labor Law
description: Over the din of a buzzing band saw, the Amish furniture maker complained that Uncle Sam was out to get owners of woodworking shops like his simply for trying to teach Amish youths a trade.

title: Lottery Numbers
Jurors Are Said to Reach Impasse in the Trial of Ex-Banker
description: The jurors in the trial of Frank P. Quattrone, the former star investment banker at Credit Suisse First Boston, appeared to reach an impasse yesterday after their deliberations led to a ''substantial disagreement,'' according to the judge in the case.

title: National Briefing | Washington: More Sludge As Fertilizer
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said it would continue to let sewage sludge be used as fertilizer despite concerns that dioxins, a class of organic chemicals found in the sludge, might cause cancer in humans. The agency said the risk of new cancer cases linked to the dioxins was too small to require federal regulation. The Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group that sued the E.P.A. to limit toxic pollutants in sludge, said the dioxins were ''among the most toxic substances on earth.'' Millions of tons of sewage sludge are used each year in the United States as fertilizer. John Files (NYT)

title: Gravano, Ever a Showman, Takes Stand Again
description: Salvatore Gravano, the Mafia informer and former hitman, was warming up. The jury was all ears in Brooklyn federal court, just as in the days when people would hang on every revealing word Mr. Gravano uttered when he was helping prosecutors convict one high-ranking mobster after another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHENE, ARMAND H.
description: CHENE--Armand H. Age 99, on October 17, 2003, passed away suddenly and peacefully. He left behind his wife Raymonde, his children Claude and Aenne, and his beloved grandchildren Jasper and Oliver, as well as a multitude of loving family and friends. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Memorial, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th St, Sunday, October 19, at 11:30 AM.

title: The U.N. and Iraq: Where's the Help?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FEDERAL SIGNAL CORP., Oak Brook, Ill., a maker of fire trucks and safety equipment, cut its quarterly dividend in half, to 10 cents a share, payable on Jan. 3 to shareholders as of Dec. 12, because of slumping sales to state and city governments.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank To Move Jobs
description: The British bank HSBC said late Thursday that it would move 4,000 jobs out of Britain to India, Malaysia and China over the next three years. Unions for the workers affected, which include data processors and call center employees, said on Friday that they would consider striking to protest the move. Five service centers in Britain will be shut, the bank said. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEVINE, VICTORIA GALEN
description: DEVINE--Victoria Galen, October 10, 2003, Hollywood, CA. Survived by her son, Galen Firestone Devine, cousins and friends; predeceased by her parents, Frank Galen and Natalie Firestone Galen, and her sister Judy Mitchell.

title: Hearts Incapacitated, Souls Wasting Away
description: ''21 Grams'' is a ruminative, stunned look at life after death -- that is, the existence of the living after they have been devastated by loss; it's the aftermath. The actors playing the characters who have been rocked by catastrophe don't sink to theatrical histrionics; instead they're linked by the red-eyed, unblinking stare of zombies, and they shamble through their day-by-day activities as if saddled with death wishes they are too enervated to act upon: American Existentialism.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about President Bush's condemnation of the assault that killed three Americans in Gaza referred imprecisely to comments by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who called the Israeli foreign minister and the Palestinian prime minister to express outrage. While he said he "made clear to them, in the strongest possible terms, the need to move urgently to end terrorism," he did not call on "both" sides to end terrorism or otherwise suggest that Israel was supporting terrorist activities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMSTER, SIDNEY
description: AMSTER--Sidney, age 84, of Enfield, CT, Marine Corps. veteran of W.W. II, died on October 15, 2003. Survived by sons David and Larry and five grandchildren. Made his mark on every life he touched. A truly gentle man.

title: The Giants-Eagles Duel Is Devalued
description: A Donovan McNabb jersey hung just a few feet from Kerry Collins's locker, pinned to a bulletin board next to an Eagles promotional poster.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SINGAPORE: EXPORTS RISE Singapore's domestic exports other than oil rose in September by 25.9 percent to 10.5 billion Singapore dollars ($6.03 billion), the biggest monthly gain in three years. A boom in pharmaceuticals and fast-growing demand from China led the increase. Electronics exports rose 15.3 percent, driven by disk drives and integrated circuits. Economists said the data could indicate that a global recovery in demand for electronics would help Singapore bounce back more quickly than hoped from the war in Iraq and the outbreak of the SARS virus. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: A Case Against Free Trade
description: Saying that the state has lost half its textile and apparel industry jobs, more than 138,000, since Nafta went into effect in 1994, Gov. Michael F. Easley asked local officials to tell Congress and the White House about the impact of federal trade policy in their communities. Mr. Easley, a Democrat, distributed a sample resolution to all county and municipal officials that said international trade agreements had been devastating, and called for a crackdown on what he called product dumping and smuggling by other countries. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Strong Economic Growth
description: The Chinese economy grew at a rate of 9.1 percent in the third quarter, up from 6.7 percent in the second quarter, the government said. Qiu Xiaohua, the deputy director of the National Bureau of Statistics, said rapid growth was likely through year-end, and analysts are concerned the economy might overheat. Declining to discuss the possibility of economic overheating, Mr. Qiu said economic problems included an increase in borrowing, growing unemployment, energy shortages and rising inventories. Data released this week, however, showed increases of 34 percent in exports and 40 percent in imports.

title: Injured Chrebet to Miss Texans Game
description: Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet will miss tomorrow's game against the Houston Texans with a sore upper back that hinders his ability to run. Chrebet, whose playing time was limited last Sunday after he was hit hard in the upper back during the second quarter, has also continued to have headaches during the week, Coach Herman Edwards said.

title: World Briefing: Australia
description: FRANCE: EMBLEM OF THE REPUBLIC TRANSFORMED The next "Marianne," the country's idealized embodiment of freedom and its ideal of womanhood whose sculpted bust stands in every town hall, is a 39-year-old television personality who likes to wear accessories like studded leather dog-collars and whose popular afternoon show, "It's My Choice," often descends into raucous debates over such topics as "I'm a male cross-dresser but I'm still virile." As the new "Marianne," Evelyne Thomas, above left, replaces the supermodel Laetitia Casta, right, after four years in the job and follows in the steps of Brigitte Bardot and Catherine Deneuve. She was chosen by a panel of 400 mayors and said she wondered if it was a joke when she first heard the news. It is flattering, she said, but "perhaps `Marianne' is being taken down from her pedestal."    (Reuters)

title: Sports of The Times; What Just Ended Was Not the End
description: WAKE up, Yankees fans. Put on a strong pot of coffee. Take a deep breath. Here is some jarring news for you: the baseball season is not over.

title: Woman Who Took Children to Mayor for Sex Gets 10 Years
description: The crack-addicted prostitute who repeatedly took her daughter and niece to Philip A. Giordano for sexual encounters while he was mayor of Waterbury was sentenced on Friday to 10 years in prison.

title: Islamic Anti-Semitism
description: It is hard to know what is more alarming -- a toxic statement of hatred of Jews by the Malaysian prime minister at an Islamic summit meeting this week or the unanimous applause it engendered from the kings, presidents and emirs in the audience. The words uttered by the prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, in a speech to the 57-member Organization of the Islamic Conference on Thursday were sadly familiar: Jews, he asserted, may be few in number, but they seek to run the world.

title: Palestinian Arrests: Where There's a Will . . .
description: To the Editor:

description: BASEBALL

title: Class With the 'Ph.D. Diva'
description: Tricia Rose's imitation of a white girl acting like a black girl -- hand on hip, an exaggerated swivel of her neck -- sent cascades of laughter through the class. It was Ms. Rose's first lecture of the year in an introductory African-American studies course, and her departure from professorial decorum was welcome after nearly an hour of sober statistics about slavery and rapid-fire provocations about race.

description: FRANCE: EMBLEM OF THE REPUBLIC TRANSFORMED The next "Marianne," the country's idealized embodiment of freedom and its ideal of womanhood whose sculpted bust stands in every town hall, is a 39-year-old television personality who likes to wear accessories like studded leather dog-collars and whose popular afternoon show, "It's My Choice," often descends into raucous debates over such topics as "I'm a male cross-dresser but I'm still virile." title: The Boston Globe; City's Pain Will Last, but Manager Won't
description: IT'S the Day After the Day After, and it still hurts, and it hurts in a way no other game can make you hurt because baseball is the Great Temptress of sport.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: New Trials For Convicts
description: The State Supreme Court ordered new trials for two men convicted of killing a Chicago police officer in 1995. The court cited prosecutorial misconduct by the Cook County state's attorney's office, which displayed the blood-soaked uniform of the slain officer, Daniel Doffyn, on a headless mannequin during the trial. Three years ago, the court overturned the conviction of the gunman in the case, Murray Blue. Mr. Blue was retried, convicted again and sentenced to life in prison. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Executive Charged
description: Russian prosecutors charged an executive of Yukos, Russia's largest oil company, with tax evasion. The executive, Vasily S. Shakhnovsky, president of Yukos-Moscow, was charged with trying to evade taxes totaling 29 million rubles, or nearly $1 million, from 1998 to 2000, according to the Interfax news agency. He was later released and ordered to remain in the country. A spokesman for Yukos declined to comment on the charge. Erin E. Arvendlund (NYT)

title: Federal Farm Loan Corporation Criticized
description: The Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation must continue to improve its risk management and corporate governance, the General Accounting Office has said in a review mandated by Congress.

title: Aging Swan, Young Duck And, Oh, Hello, Mr. Chips
description: Feminism and Jackie Collins do not mix. ''Hollywood Wives,'' a 1985 mini-series based on a Ms. Collins best seller, was a campy romp portraying women as catty and conniving. ''Hollywood Wives: The Next Generation,'' on CBS tomorrow night, is fairer to the female sex but far more insipid.

title: The Daily, Death-Defying Commute
description: The gruesome crash of the Staten Island ferry on Wednesday came as a shock. How could one of those lumbering ferry boats come to grief on a routine afternoon trip in a harbor that seems all but empty? But it was hardly unprecedented. As we tend to forget nowadays, New York was born a harbor town, and our waterways have historically been fraught with peril, even for commuters.

title: Bolivian Leader Resigns and His Vice President Steps In
description: Gonzalo Snchez de Lozada resigned as president of South America's poorest and most unstable country late Friday after nearly a month of increasingly violent clashes between army troops and predominantly Indian demonstrators that have left more than 80 people dead.

title: The Good, The Bad, The Ugly
description: When it comes to the future of Iraq, there's not just one Democratic Party; there are three.

title: Political Memo; A Wary Mrs. Clinton Runs a Perpetual Race
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton appears to be riding high these days. Democrats around the country are begging her to run for president. Her name is a huge draw at party fund-raisers. And her memoir is selling big around the world.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Wednesday about the disappointing results of drilling for oil and gas in the northwest Atlantic misstated the headquarters location of the El Paso Corporation, which has postponed construction of a natural gas pipeline from eastern Canada to New Jersey. It is Houston, not Dallas.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: First Donation Of Food Aid
description: In a sign of its growing prosperity, Vietnam became an aid donor, sending 1,500 tons of rice to Iraq through the United Nations. Until three years ago, Vietnam was on the receiving end of food aid. It had been dependant on help from the United Nations World Food Program for more than 25 years to meet routine shortfalls. It is now the second-largest exporter of rice in the world. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: A Loss For Retailer
description: One of Japan's largest retailers, Daiei Inc., said profit fell 98 percent in the first half of the fiscal year as the company booked fewer one-time gains. Daiei, which received large debt waivers from its main banks last year, earned 2.3 billion yen ($21 million) in the six months ended in August. Sales fell 15 percent because Daiei shut several businesses. The company plans to reduce its debts by selling its baseball stadium and a nearby hotel, but not the Fukuoka Daiei Hawks baseball team. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Sharon Appears to Pull Back on Threat to Expel Arafat
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon appeared to back away Friday from a threat to expel the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, saying in a newspaper interview that he had for years seen that step as bad for Israel.

title: Editorial Observer; New York's Native American Casino Contributes, but Not to Tax Rolls
description: Out on a flat stretch of cornfield in central New York, the Oneidas built a casino 10 years ago. They built it in the shape of a mall, just in case they opened the doors and nobody out there wanted to gamble.

title: Battle Lines Already Forming Against a Bush Court Selection
description: President Bush's nomination of Justice Janice Rogers Brown to an important federal appeals court post has received a sharply critical review from the Congressional Black Caucus and a lukewarm one from the American Bar Association.

title: Kmart Ads Stick With Stewart Despite Her Woes
description: A new ad campaign for Kmart, which is set to be broadcast tomorrow night during the World Series, features a beaming Martha Stewart as part of an effort to depict Kmart as a chic and attractive place to shop.

title: Mayor Financing Campaign to End Party Primaries
description: For months, a major question in local political circles has centered on what role Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg might play in advancing a proposal he has championed, the elimination of party primaries in city elections.

title: Religion Journal; Where Victims of the Clergy Try to Talk It Out
description: A lighthouse is meant to guide travelers safely on their way.

title: Court Papers Show Charges That Group Aided Terrorists
description: Federal law enforcement authorities said in court documents unsealed on Friday that they suspected a group of Islamic charities in Northern Virginia of laundering hundreds of thousands of dollars or more from Saudi Arabia to help finance terrorist attacks by Hamas and other militant groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLER, JUNE G.
description: KELLER--June G., 83 years old, died on October 16, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Devoted mother of Bill and Lynn, and Ed and Karen. Cherished grandmother of Isabel, Emma, Sean, Meredith and Jake. Services Sunday, 12:30PM, at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Community Chest of Port Washington, 382 Main Street, Port Washington, NY 11050.

title: N.F.L. Responds to Track's Drug Scandal
description: The National Football League said yesterday that it would begin testing players for a previously unidentified and undetectable steroid, in an effort to avoid the kind of scandal that has embarrassed professional track and field this week.

title: Pierre Is the Marlins' One-Man Hit and Run
description: Before he roamed the center fields of Coors Field and Pro Player Stadium, Juan Pierre had a smaller field to conquer. The distance of the outfield walls did not matter with Pierre's game, so he would swing down at the ball on the batting tee and begin racing.

title: German Parliament Votes to Cut Welfare Benefits and Taxes
description: The lower house of the German Parliament on Friday passed a major part of the economic reform package that Chancellor Gerhard Schrder has said is essential to reducing unemployment and prodding this country out of its prolonged economic stagnation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TECOTZKY, SYLVIA
description: TECOTZKY--Sylvia. Beloved wife of Mel. Devoted mother of Nan and Mark. Loving grandmother of Ethan, Julia, Sam, Henry and Alice. Dear sister of Dorothy Altschuler and Edy Comis. She exuded sweetness and fortitude, goodness and dignity. She withheld judgement, coveted little, shared what she had, and loved her family deeply and dearly. She is greatly missed. Services 11:15 AM, Sunday at ''the Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Azerbaijan: Opposition Under Fire
description: Cleaning up after an overwhelming victory for the status quo in presidential elections held Wednesday, government officials said the two main opposition parties should be banned and the chief opposition leader, Isa Gambar, should be put on trial, the Interfax news agency reported. Gadzhibala Abutalybov, the mayor of the capital, Baku, blamed Mr. Gambar for post-election rioting and said, ''I am confident that Gambar and others like him are enemies of the people who have lost their human faith and should be put on trial.'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer To Raise Capital
description: Munich Re, the world's largest reinsurer, plans to raise at least 3.8 billion euros ($4.4 billion) in a share sale to increase reserves that have been sapped by three years of declining stock markets and to repair its credit ratings. Shareholders will be able to buy two new shares for every seven held, the chief executive, Hans-Jrgen Schinzler, said.

title: Deutsche Bank Executive To Have His Day in Court
description: The embattled chief executive of Deutsche Bank, Josef Ackermann, now has a court date, Jan. 21, to face charges that he and other former directors of a German telecommunications conglomerate paid improper bonuses to its executives amid a takeover battle.

title: Walking It Off
description: Nobody lost.

description: INTERNATIONAL A2-6

title: Lowell, an Ex-Yankee, Still Wonders What If
description: Most of the Florida Marlins will be trying to win their first championship ring when they face the Yankees in the World Series. Mike Lowell already has a ring, as a reward for his contribution to the 1998 Yankees. The sum of Lowell's effort that season: 8 games, 4 singles, 15 at-bats.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 336 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 28 about the Defense Intelligence Agency's assessment of information provided by Iraqi defectors misstated the relationship between Khidir Hamza, the most senior Iraqi official ever to defect from Iraq's nuclear program, and Ahmad Chalabi, the head of the Iraqi National Congress. After fleeing Iraq in 1994, Mr. Hamza acted on on his own to make contact with American officials; he was not brought out of Iraq by Mr. Chalabi's organization.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about Dr. Michael J. Ryan, a University of Texas biologist who challenges widely held views of evolution, misstated his title. He is a professor of integrative biology. (The chairman of the integrative biology section is Dr. Robert Jansen.)

title: Principal Charged In Sex Assault Case
description: The principal of a middle school in Wayne, N.J., was released on bail yesterday after being charged with having improper sexual contact with an underage girl who accompanied him and others to the New York Jets game at Giants Stadium last Sunday.

title: So Your Boss Wants You to Exercise (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Deadline Missed, Congress Is Still Optimistic on Prescription Bill
description: House and Senate negotiators missed their self-imposed deadline for agreement on a bill adding prescription drug benefits to Medicare on Friday, but they said they had narrowed their differences on many issues, including a proposal to allow imports of less expensive drugs from Canada.

title: Finding Flamenco in Spain, A Jazzman Finds Himself

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Ruling In Terror Case

It is too bad that Terry Trucco did not mention how those tourists who visited the island the week of Sept. 14 were greeted. The Bermuda Industrial Union called a strike that basically shut down the island. My wife and I were on board the Norwegian Sea cruise ship, which was stuck at port in St. George's for our entire stay. No ships were allowed to reposition. Passengers saw very little of the island as there were no buses or ferries. In time of trouble you would think that Bermudans would find another way to solve their problems.

It's November 26, 1894, the Monday before Thanksgiving, a windy and clear evening, as men and women file into Faneuil Hall from all over Boston and from the suburbs of Cambridge, Watertown, Winchester, and as far out as Quincy and Andover. They have come to this public meeting place near the harbor to talk about the most pressing international human rights issue of the day.

title: What if There Is Something Going On In There?
description: If we presume that to answer yes when asked ''Are you happy?'' and ''Are you sad?'' one after the other is evidence of cognition, of ''being in the moment,'' then why does the same affirmative response to the questions ''Are you male?'' and ''Are you female?'' indicate the opposite? This judgment is indicative only of our own rather too self-conscious, human limitations. It seems to me that being in a minimally conscious state makes it quite likely that your perception of gender may differ -- no longer is the body at issue, nor are you preoccupied with bodily functions, body image, body awareness. Is it really so strange to believe that in a different consciousness, when the body is no longer relevant, that we can be happy, sad, man and woman?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, GEORGE
description: JOHNSON -- George. The Board of Directors, officers and employees of Mutual of America record with deep sorrow the passing of George E. Johnson. Mr. Johnson was a former acting president, member of the Board of Trustees, and a dear friend. In later years, he made his home in Tucson, AZ. For close to fifteen years, he shared with us his extensive knowledge of the insurance industry. Before joining Mutual of America, he served as Vice President and General Counsel of TIAA, as well as founder and president of both VALIC and EALIC. In 1961, Mr. Johnson wrote ''Variable Annuities and Variable Life Insurance, Variable Pensions, Investment Annuities, Economic Index Annuities, Separate Accounts: The Most Complete Book Ever Written on Variable Annuities.'' At the time, it was the most comprehensive book written on this subject. In 1967, along with Donald S. Grubbs, Mr. Johnson wrote, ''The Variable Annuity: A New and Exciting Financial Tool.'' Mr. Johnson was a member of the New York Bar Association, a Chartered Life Underwriter, a Fellow of the Life Office Management Association Institute, a Fellow of the Gerontological Society and a past member of the Life Insurance Council. George Johnson was a man of ideas. Through his work on the Long-Range Objectives Committee, he helped plan for the future needs of Mutual of America's clients. To him we owe a great debt of gratitude. His wife Elizabeth and son George E. Johnson, III, preceded him in death. We extend our sincere condolences to his children, Susan Hartdegan, and Robert A. Johnson. William J. Flynn, Chairman of the Board Thomas J. Moran, President and CEO Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

It has been extensively rebuilt over the centuries and opened to the public again this year after a renovation. It offers beautiful views of Prague and its many spires. title: Cosmopolitan
description: In the town of Eau Claire in northern Wisconsin, where my father lives, there is an old wooden saloon called the Joynt on Water Street, just a short block off the Chippewa River. The Joynt functions to this day as all things to all people in that city. It's an egalitarian space by necessity. There is a satellite college of the University of Wisconsin there, cheek by jowl with the old Uniroyal tire factory and myriad paper processing plants. The Joynt has been by turns, and sometimes all at once, a student hangout, a faculty bar, a cop coop, the town's only gay bar, the beer hall for all the sweaty workers getting off their shifts at the factories nearby, a makeshift canteen for the elderly of the area, the only place in town to see live music, a pickup bar, and a quiet place in the afternoon or early evening to sit in the dentist's chair up front by the plate-glass window and read the paper. Beer has gone up to seventy-five cents a tap, from the quarter it was when I was growing up. That will buy you a choice of Leinenkugel's (locally known as Leinie's), Point Special, Berghoff Dark, and Grain Belt Premium Lager, the outsider from Minnesota. There is a neon sign above the bar that reads frankly no light beer.

description: Today, Pope John Paul II is to beatify Mother Teresa, the final step before canonization, or official sainthood. Mother Teresa's path to beatification has been extremely quick, the shortest of its kind in the modern history of the Roman Catholic Church. She died in 1997 at age 87. The miracle that qualified her for beatification, the Vatican said, was her posthumous role in the curing of a Indian woman's cancer. The pope must approve a second miracle before she can become a saint. Critics have complained that the process of sainthood has become a rubber stamp.

title: House Parties Where No One Shrinks From Talking Politics
description: THE crowd -- nose rings, sweater vests, do-rags and all -- was thumping to an insistent bass beat. The D.J. was intently cutting between records on two turntables decorated with a Puerto Rican flag motif. A thin man spit verses rapid fire into the microphone:

title: L.I.@WORK
description: CosmoCom Again Tops List Of Fast-Growing Companies

title: A Crash Course In Slithering And Sliding
description: WHEN American Ballet Theater recently asked William Forsythe whether it could stage one of his ballets for the first time, it was a bid to enrich the company's repertory of dances and attract new audiences. But sometimes bringing in a dance-maker like Mr. Forsythe, one of the most creative talents working in ballet, also means bringing in an entirely different approach to movement. How, in a matter of weeks, do classical dancers learn a new style?

title: The Untouchables
description: Colapinto writes that the 197 firehouses of the F.D.N.Y. proved sufficient to handle all facets of this summer's blackout and subsequent emergencies. I wish this were true. Fortunately, the blackout struck just before a citywide shift change for firefighters. This allowed the brass to order all off-going firefighters to remain on duty, in effect doubling the size of the force. And even with the additional manpower, the force was stretched dangerously thin. Just ask the commuters who were trapped in dark subway cars for hours that day.

title: Corrections
description: A table last Sunday with a review of the Ford F-150 truck misstated the availability of antilock brakes on a competitive pickup, the GMC Sierra. They are indeed available, and are a standard feature.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: A Complete Conformist
description: Until now, it was unclear what exactly Vladimir Putin did as a KGB officer in Dresden. Now his former officemate is talking about their shared days of espionage. In a new book, he presents a character analysis of his former colleague, who since then has managed to become the Russian president.

title: An Asian Trek
description: IF you have a craving for Asian food but can't decide between sashimi, Thai curry shrimp or beef with broccoli, Sunny Garden is the place to go. Service is friendly, ingredients are fresh, preparation is skillful and there is a flair to the food that takes it beyond traditional.

title: DataBank; Stocks Leap Forward, Then Slide Back
description: A sour Friday turned what had been a sweet week for the stock market into a virtual nonevent, leaving major market averages little changed from where they stood on Oct. 10.

title: The Snapshot Aesthetic Goes to High School
description: HOW old do you have to be to take a good picture? If you define ''good'' by the standards of Look-Look, a new magazine conceived to showcase the work of young artists, there is no such thing as underage photography. To graze the magazine is to glimpse the world through the eyes of a teenager -- active, immediate, idiosyncratic, incomplete. The formal concerns of photographic image-making are less in evidence here than the coded sensibilities of adolescent expression. Maybe that's the point.

title: McMusic
description: To the Editor:

title: Vanderbilt Auto Race To Be Marked Next Year
description: The Nassau and Suffolk county executives, Thomas R. Suozzi and Robert F. Gaffney, said on Tuesday that they were considering staging an auto race next year to mark the 100th anniversary of the Vanderbilt Cup automobile races.

title: Business People; Sit Downs, Yes. Swimming, No.
description: What does the foul-mouthed, fictional mob boss Tony Soprano know about leadership? Plenty, said Deborrah Himsel, the vice president of organizational effectiveness for Avon Products Inc.

title: Anna Suh, Ross Garon
description: Hongkyung Anna Suh and Ross Anden Garon were married on Friday by Justice Harold Silverman of State Supreme Court in the Bronx, who officiated in his chambers. Yesterday Daniel Siff, a lawyer and a friend of the couple's, led a ceremony at Wave Hill, the public garden in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Spooked
description: Inspiring recreational fear is something that film, for the most part, does better than the written word, despite the rash of supposedly scary titles released at the end of every October. Even a merely competent movie can make its audience's knuckles go white on their armrests by showing a character blundering around a ramshackle house, a shadowy forest or an infested spaceship -- from which some beastie will pop out at any moment. Film reaches into our bodies, where fear at its most elemental lives. We feel at the mercy of the moving image, obliged to take events at its pace, and that vulnerability multiplies our anxiety. A book we can always set down. So horror novelists try harder, reaching for new extremes of gore or sadism; the monster is not only a scalpel-wielding serial killer, but he targets 4-year-olds. And he's a cannibal. And he's working for a demonic superbeing from another dimension! This is atrocity inflation and it's getting old.

title: A Sleep Study Group For Newtown Schools Presents Its Findings
description: Newtown has joined a growing number of school districts studying the effect of early school start times on its adolescent students.

title: To Make The Sale, First Fix The Roof
description: THE biggest issue in the rambunctious world of Co-op City politics the past few years has been privatization. Should Co-op City, which, with 50,000 residents, has more people than Scarsdale and Mamaroneck combined, remain within the state's Mitchell-Lama subsidized housing program? Or should residents be allowed to sell their shares at market rates? It has been a heated battle.

title: Corrections
description: Abrief review of recently released recordings by June Carter Cash on Sept. 28 misstated her relationship to the musician A. P. Carter. He was her uncle, not her father. The article also gave an incomplete attribution for the song "Wildwood Flower." Maud Irving and J. P. Webster were the original composers; A. P. Carter altered the lyrics slightly and copyrighted the song.

title: Jessica Burney, Bryan Cho
description: Jessica Lee Burney, the daughter of Rosalee M. Hagan of Opelika, Ala., and Dr. Robert E. Burney II of Naples, Fla., was married yesterday to Bryan Namho Cho, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Seong Koo Cho of New Albany, Ohio. The Rev. Javier A. Viera performed the ceremony at Fairhope United Methodist Church in Fairhope, Ala.

title: FILM: Authors of Their Own Demise; Gwyneth's Degree In Plathology
description: THERE is a big problem with making a movie about Sylvia Plath: it has to end with the main character sticking her head in the oven. The suicide of Plath, who gassed herself in a London flat in the winter of 1963, while her two small children slept in the room next door, lacked the melancholy dignity of, say, Virginia Woolf's stroll into the River Ouse near the end of ''The Hours,'' last year's big lit flick; and it wasn't even particularly dramatic, like the car crash, say, that ends ''Pollock,'' another recent film about an artistic career cut short. Plath's death was merely senseless and unnecessary, even selfish, and it dooms her story -- however you choose to tell it -- to a poor and unsatisfying end.

title: For Sippers And Crooners
description: Drinking Eric Texier's easy-sipping 2001 Ctes du Rhne red is like listening to a Bing Crosby record. A boon for low-voltage parties and casual meals, it is a seamless blend of six grapes (15 percent white, for lightness). Crossroads, 55 West 14th Street, asks $10. A 10 percent discount on 6 bottles and 20 percent discount on 12 (if not delivered) yield bargains.

title: Opera Divas, On the Stage And on the Page
description: OPENING the Metropolitan Opera season three weeks ago, Rene Fleming had a storybook triumph as Violetta in Verdi's ''Traviata.'' Everyone -- critics and public -- has been speaking about the performance in superlatives: ''dazzling,'' ''superb artistry,'' ''creamy voice.''

title: Stand-Up Women
description: Gail Collins (Oct. 5) recommends an Uptown location for Frances Perkins, F.D.R.'s secretary of labor and the first woman to serve in a presidential cabinet. A swell idea, along with many others in the article. Maybe she could join Eleanor Roosevelt, whose statue is installed at 72nd Street and Riverside Drive.

title: Jennifer Gregory, Stephen Ely
description: Jennifer L. Gregory and Stephen Ely were married yesterday by the Rev. Simon Foster at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, N.Y.

title: In Madrid, It's Now Chic to Dine at Your Hotel
description: TO experience Madrid's most stylish dining, head directly for the city's finest hotels, where innovative restaurants have opened in quick succession over the past three years. No longer are hotel dining rooms the domain of guests too weary to venture out. And Madrileos, overcoming any misgivings they once had, are patronizing them in force.

title: Corrections

It was Manhattan, not the Bronx. The Yankees were sharing the Polo Grounds with the Giants; Yankee Stadium did not open until 1923.

The title is ''Carmen,'' not ''The Tragedy of Carmen.'' The playwright is Peter Brook, not Brooks

title: Wedding Music That's Worth Listening To, For a Change
description: It's often hard for wedding musicians to make an impression. They mostly churn out the same ho-hum medleys of standard tunes, and if the party is loud enough, their music becomes mere sonic wallpaper.
