title: Some Stories Are So Jarring They Don't Go Away
description: ON the last Monday in September, about 5 p.m., my son and I were driving past the Short Hills train station when we noticed four men placing a white sheet over the tracks. We had just come from the orthopedist's office, which is why I had a book with me. For the third time, I was reading ''Anna Karenina,'' whose grim ending -- in which Anna throws herself in front of a train -- we had recently discussed. Perhaps that's why we guessed instantly what had happened.

description: DIRE--Dolores. On October 16, 2003. Beloved sister, cherished aunt and great-aunt. A remarkable woman who will be truly missed.

title: The Week Ahead; CONCORDE'S FINAL LANDING
description: The end, at least for now, of the supersonic age of commercial flight will take place on Friday, when British Airways' Concorde makes its exit off the stage of aviation. The final flight will leave from New York's Kennedy International Airport at 7 a.m. for London. Filling the 100 seats will be actors, corporate executives and other guests of British Airways.

title: Expanding the Mind With Yogi

These and other institutions had undisguised designs on the treasury of more than 300 works -- Rodins, Matisses, Picassos, Giacomettis, Mirs, Moores, di Suveros and such -- assembled by the Dallas real estate entrepreneur Raymond D. Nasher and his wife, Patsy.

The weather forecasters had been dead wrong, he said, taking some obvious delight in this pronouncement. Lunch would be served indoors.

title: For Peter Hall, Home Is Where the Rosalind Is
description: AT this point in a theater career spanning half a century, Peter Hall has directed all but a handful of Shakespeare's plays. ''King John,'' ''Titus Andronicus'' and ''Henry VIII'' remain among the few that Sir Peter, who will be 73 next month, has not yet touched. Some he has returned to time and again -- ''Hamlet'' on four occasions, ''Twelfth Night'' three, and the histories, he says, ''an awful lot, all of them.''

title: As Daughters Grow Up, How-To's for Mothers
description: TIMES are always trying for the mothers of adolescent girls, and yet it seems that these times are especially so. The mall has become a battleground. The dread ''whatever'' has emerged as the most frequently used word in the house. Surreptitious piercings and tattoos lurk around the corner. She's right: her parents just don't get it.

description: THIS fall, Carol Mendelsohn and Ann Donahue became the two highest-paid female writers in television drama. ''It's the kind of thing that if, when you were 25, someone told you this would happen, it would hold you in good stead,'' said Ms. Donahue, who is 48. ''But it didn't happen that way. And I still can't believe it. And the fact that no one told us is why we're here.''

To be even partly aware that you are in such a state is the worst torture I can imagine. I am profoundly grateful that there are people who care for me enough to pull the plug if I ever lose the ability to do it for myself.

title: Why Did They Go On a Killing Spree? You Figure It Out
description: WHEN Gus Van Sant's ''Elephant'' won both the Palme d'Or and the director's prize at the Cannes Film Festival this year, American critics were notably divided. It wasn't just that the streamlined, 81-minute movie beat out heavyweights like Clint Eastwood's ''Mystic River'' and Lars von Trier's ''Dogville,'' although that arched an eyebrow or two. The harshest responses were less aesthetic than moral, castigating the movie in terms ranging from ''vacuous and irresponsible'' to ''reprehensible'' and ''blood-boiling.''

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IF you want to understand the real dangers of picking up the wrong suitcase from the airport baggage claim area, consider Roman Polanski's FRANTIC (1988). Harrison Ford plays an American doctor who arrives in Paris for a medical conference, checks into the hotel, takes a shower and emerges to find his wife (Betty Buckley) missing. Everyone (the concierge, the police, et al.) thinks he's crazy, but yes, she has been kidnapped. In the process of figuring things out, the doctor meets a sexy young woman (Emmanuelle Seigner) who was traveling with the other suitcase. The frustration and anxieties of Mr. Ford's character feel all too real, thanks to Mr. Polanski, a master at building and sustaining tension -- Sunday at 1 p.m. on USA.

Far from existing for the affluent or the elite, these creations illuminate the human experience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERGER, ARTHUR
description: BERGER--Arthur. The directors and officers of The Aaron Copland Fund for Music, Inc. note with sorrow the death of Arthur Berger, Trustee of the Fund since its inception. Arthur was a composer of great vitality, integrity and aesthetic purity. He contributed greatly to the shaping and guidance of The Copland Fund. He was the author of the first biography of Aaron Copland and remained one of the primary experts on Copland's music. The Trustees honor his life in music, and are grateful for his contribution to our work. We extend heartfelt condolences to members of his family. The Aaron Copland Fund for Music, Inc. John Harbison, President

title: Curriculum Tracking
description: Dirk Olin's excellent coverage of tracking featured a picture of a one-room schoolhouse (Crash Course, Sept. 28). I attended one in Chester County, Pa., from 1947 to 1952. It had 25 pupils, in four grades, and provided students with the opportunity to participate with other grades in subjects at which they particularly excelled. In our open classroom, the teacher could spot individuals from one grade who were ''listening in'' on another grade's session and often simply move the student to sit in on that subject at the more advanced level. At least in my experience, all students in the same grade were not always on the same page.

Although Mr. Busch's family and neighbors strongly disputed the police account of the circumstances of his death, the prosecutors did not find enough evidence to bring criminal charges against the officers involved.

description: Alija Izetbegovic, the former Bosnian president whose dream of a Muslim-led independent Bosnia and Herzegovina was transformed by Balkan ethnic rivalries into a protracted war, died today in Sarajevo. He was 78 years old.

title: Pretty In Punk
description: When the English rocker Ian Dury wrote ''Sex and Drugs and Rock and Roll,'' who knew he would be creating the clich of the century? But he got it only two-thirds right: it should have been ''Sex and Clothes and Rock and Roll.'' The drugs part merely meant that a lot of cretins died before they got old. Some of the good died young, too, including Ian Dury. But clothes live forever; they're like vampires, hiding in closets, subsisting on new blood and the dream of eternal youth. Take the clothes of today: very Goth, very undead. How delightful that everything punk that has been buried in my crypt since the late 70's has been upgraded, aerated and decorated. Now all my shrouds have become vintage chic, wearable again. True, those early Gaultier bondage jackets need to be freshened with a nip and tuck, but, hey, so does my face. If memory serves, both face and jacket looked smashing at an Epic Records party for the Clash south of 14th Street. The bassist Paul Simonon was the most gorgeous white dope on punk I had ever seen, but F.Y.I.: it was better when he let Joe Strummer do the talking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MICHAELS, RICHARD
description: MICHAELS -- Richard, 65, stage director, died of heart failure Saturday, September 13 in his home in Kingston, NY. He was 65. Before his retirement and move to Kingston he directed well over one hundred musical and dramatic productions. His offBroadway revival of ''No Strings'' was heralded as infinitely better than the original production and prompted Richard Rodgers to invite him to direct the national company of ''Two By Two''. Critics and actors alike regarded him as one of the best directors in the business. He worked with such stars as Pat O'Brien, Bill Bixby, Harvey Korman, Vicki Lawrence, Tom Poston, Dom DeLuise and scores of others. One critic wrote of his work: ''Mr. Michaels does for the musical theatre what Hitchcock does for suspense.'' He donated his body to the Anatomical Gift Program of Albany Medical College, NY. He is survived by his long time companion.

Hurricane Isabel was looming and there was a possibility that the festival at Lighthouse Point Park would be disrupted.

title: Lincoln Center's Culture Gap
description: Deborah Solomon talked about a Lincoln Center most New Yorkers wouldn't recognize (Oct. 5). In order to take a meaningful look at Lincoln Center, she needed to consider the entire spectrum of presentations by all of its 12 resident organizations, not 1 or 2, particularly since 6 of them -- the Film Society of Lincoln Center, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, Lincoln Center Theater, the Juilliard School, the School of American Ballet and the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts (as well as its vibrant programming, broad ethnic and demographic reach and educational initiatives) -- either weren't acknowledged or were glibly dismissed.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. ''We are a major-chord band!'' says Johan Bengtsson, bassist for the Swedish new wave (and Blondie look-alike) group the Sounds. And that pretty much covers it. If Sweden is Europe's version of Minnesota, it's also the music world's Seattle, abrew with groups singing songs in Ikea life. They range from post-Abba perky, like the Cardigans, through the Hives, to the more tendentious (International) Noise Conspiracy, whose single ''United by Haircuts'' is off its EP ''Capitalism Stole My Virginity.'' Omigod, mine, too. Did you know that the word for bootleg in Swedish is smuggla?

title: Jamaica
description: In the 1970's and 1980's, Jamaica pioneered the concept of all-inclusive, self-contained resorts, which flourish there, catering to everyone: swinging singles cavort at Hedonism, couples relax at Couples, families play together at FDR Pebbles. But in the last few years, the Jamaica Tourist Board has actively encouraged visitors to venture beyond the compound gates -- to hike mountain trails, buy spicy boiled fish from roadside vendors, or tour a coffee plantation. There is an entire country to discover out there.

title: The Wifely Art of Standing By
description: THE disgraced former chairman of Tyco International, L. Dennis Kozlowski, might seem like a man alone in the world these days, the symbol of corporate greed, his extravagant taste in shower curtains a practiced punch line. But as he strolls the hallway outside the courtroom in Lower Manhattan where he is on trial for defrauding his company of $600 million, there is always someone at his side -- his wife, Karen.

title: Piecing Together a Network of Quilters
description: When the New Jersey Quilters Guild incorporated in 1996, one goal was to provide educational opportunities for quilters and those appreciative of the craft. Some day the group hopes to have a museum, but in the meantime it has taken its show on the road. The guild held the largest non-juried quilting show on the East Coast in June, and some of the money raised will go toward a pilot project to bring quilting -- a colonial craft with an obvious place in New Jersey's history -- into the schools in Middlesex and Ocean Counties this year. Melanie Normann, an artist and teacher who came up with the idea of bringing her love and appreciation of quilting -- whose geometric nature finds a logical place in both math and art instruction -- into elementary schools. The School House Project was two years in development as a community outreach educational experience. Teachers wishing to participate will receive a trunk loaded with a finished quilt, a quilt in progress, quilt facts, folklore, examples and more than 20 storybooks. Each teacher will receive a guide for encouraging creative design and a resource list. For more information or to schedule a visit of the trunk, teachers can contact the guild president, Lynn Liebenow, at (732) 946-8787, or Lynnquilter@aol.com. Christine Contillo

title: There's Nothing Overnight About This Tenor's Success
description: IT'S safe to say that except for his family and friends, no one noticed the Metropolitan Opera debut of the young American tenor Matthew Polenzani in 1997. Mr. Polenzani portrayed Boyar Khrushchov in Mussorgsky's ''Boris Godunov,'' singing just four words near the end of that five-hour evening. Moreover, he was also the cover, as an understudy is called in opera, for a tenor singing a small role in the opening scene. So he had to show up 30 minutes before the 7 o'clock curtain just in case, but he didn't go on as the boyar until 11:40.

title: The Neo-70's

title: James R. Lawson, 84, Dies; Tamed the Mighty Carillon
description: James R. Lawson, who climbed to perches in towers -- including one in Riverside Church on the Upper West Side of Manhattan -- to make exquisite music by ringing bells, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Cody, Wyo. He was 84.

title: With Rabbi Solomon, Kung Fu Master
description: If Rabelais had written a children's book, it probably would have looked something like LITTLE VAMPIRE DOES KUNG FU!, the second volume in the Little Vampire series by Joann Sfar, a French author and illustrator (Simon & Schuster, $12.95; age 10 and up). The boisterous tale begins when a young boy named Michael asks his grandfather the eternal question: how can I get back at the bully who has been humiliating me at school? Grandfather urges a policy of restraint, which, of course, leaves Michael unsatisfied. Enter the Little Vampire, who takes Michael to see Rabbi Solomon, kung fu master.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Contracting For Home Renovations
description: OVER a four-week period this summer, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs seized 12 vehicles from unlicensed contractors in Queens who had provided home improvement services without obtaining the necessary license. To get the vehicles back, the contractors each had to pay $1,000 in fines, resolve outstanding complaints filed by homeowners, pay into the department's Home Improvement Trust Fund and agree to obtain a license.

title: Report Cites Security Flaws at Plum Island
description: Officials at the Plum Island Animal Disease Center have failed to safeguard pathogens that could be adapted to become weapons of germ warfare, including an agent potentially ''as threatening as smallpox,'' a federal report says.

title: America Must Let Iraq Rebuild Itself
description: No Iraqi will ever forget the momentous April day when a crowd of hundreds of cheering Baghdadis, helped by an American armored vehicle, pull the huge statue of Saddam Hussein to the ground. With this act, we tore down three decades of tyranny and repression and began building in its place a foundation for freedom, democracy and a better future for our children.

title: Pettitte In Game 2 Is Yanks' Tradition

He has started the second game of the American League division series nine years in a row, and he started Game 2 of the Yankees' last World Series, against Arizona in 2001.

title: Dunham Saves Struggling Rangers
description: Four games into the season, the Rangers are still looking for their first victory and their first power-play goal. Last night at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers could not score on four power-play opportunities and had to settle for a 2-2 tie against the Carolina Hurricanes.

title: In New Jersey, Rogue Lawyers Are on the Rise

title: Deborah Scharf, Aaron Huppert

title: Still No Excuse To Own an S.U.V.
description: Re ''In Great Neck, New Front in S.U.V. War,'' [Oct. 12]: Yet another article detailing yet another angle of the contentious debate between the haves (the owners of ridiculously oversized vehicles) and have-nots (the rest of us). When will the haves ever learn? No matter how long you justify your right to own and drive one of these gas-guzzling behemoths, S.U.V.'s will remain only that, gas-guzzling behemoths, destined to cause havoc for the rest of us who choose to remain stuck in the last century, driving our little, in comparison, sedans and station wagons.

title: Investing; Famous Brands Can Bring Benefit, or a Backlash
description: A company's value can lie in the name as much as the bottle, sneaker or Happy Meal. But businesses with global brands, even the most highly regarded ones, face an especially challenging climate now.

title: A Brief Treatise on the Superiority Of Yankee Fans to All Others
description: IN his 1974 book on drugs and consciousness, ''The Natural Mind,'' Dr. Andrew Weil described two types of paranoia: one sees a hostile pattern in random events; the other, faced with the same events, feels that ''the universe is a conspiracy organized for their own benefit.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 24 about a lawsuit over a real estate development in Coram, on a site described as habitat for an endangered species of salamander, misidentified the company that sold the property in May. It was the Dexter Company, not the Heatherwood Organization; the two companies have no corporate ties. The article also misspelled the surname of a lawyer for the Beechwood Organization, the company that bought the property. He is Robert Calica, not Calico.

title: New York to Boston On a Fancy New Bus
description: For $60 less than round-trip business class fare on the Acela Express and with comparable riding time, travelers can now go between New York and Boston by LimoLiner, a luxury bus. Although the two buses now in service are approximately the size of a large transcontinental bus, they hold only 28 passengers in reclining leather seats with leg rests and tray tables (a light meal is served), and they have two conference tables in the rear, a kitchen, a toilet, eight TV sets (showing either a DVD movie or news channels), free Internet access, and free newspapers and magazines. The round-trip fare is $138. Travel time between midtown Manhattan and the Back Bay in Boston (the Hilton Hotels in both cities) is estimated at four hours. Departures are scheduled at 6 a.m., 10:50 a.m. 3:10 p.m. and 7:40 p.m. from both cities Monday to Friday.

title: Love and Hate in Jamestown

A middle-aged mathematician named Galileo Galilei, who had not yet built his first telescope, published a book of observations about the recent appearance of a supernova in the sky. Japan's first shogun, Ieyasu Tokugawa, had recently begun his rule. The Dutch painter Rembrandt was born. In Oxford, Cambridge, and Canterbury, forty-seven scholars appointed by the king were laboring over a new translation of the Scriptures, which would come to be known as the King James Bible. A new play called Macbeth opened in London. And in late December, in London's River Thames, three small ships were anchored, awaiting a voyage across the Atlantic.

And it's initially hard to forget that she is being portrayed, after all, by a man.

title: QUICK BITE/Hoboken; . . . And Don't Forget the Dessert
description: When the opticians moved out, Alex Via made his move. The focus of the 700-square-foot storefront quickly switched from eyes to ice cream, and Jordan's Homemade Frozen Desserts -- run by Mr. Via and his wife, Lisa -- opened in late July. They are expecting a daughter whom they plan to name Amanda Jordan, but since there was already an Amanda's restaurant on Washington Street, the minimally appointed ice cream shop became Jordan's. Since relocating to New Jersey from Minneapolis three years ago, Mr. Via had his heart set on starting his own business. An intensive workshop at New York's Ice Cream University followed for Mr. Via, a former marketing specialist for Pillsbury and General Mills. Hoboken, with its young, professional demographic, seemed like an ideal spot for Mr. Via to sell premium ice cream. On the premises, Mr. Via produces a rotating selection of flavors. On a recent day, the offerings included 19 standard ice creams, a fat-free vanilla, a sugar-free vanilla, and three sorbets ($2.50 for a small cup, $3.50 large, $4.50 pint, $7.50 quart, $2.50 sugar cone, $3 small waffle cone, $4 large waffle, $4 milkshake). I tried a cup of chocolate peanut butter, which was creamy and delicious. The next time I sampled the peanut butter chocolate chip. (a personal pattern here?) The Vias pride themselves on using fresh ingredients and avoiding artificial flavoring (like real rum in the rum raisin). In the coming months, they plan to add ice cream cakes, coffees and pastries to the menu. Jack Silbert

title: A Distant Shore
description: England has changed. These days it's difficult to tell who's from around here and who's not. Who belongs and who's a stranger. It's disturbing. It doesn't feel right. Three months ago, in early June, I moved out here to this new development of Stoneleigh. None of the old villagers seem comfortable with the term "new development." They simply call Stoneleigh the "new houses on the hill." After all, our houses are set on the edge of Weston, a village that is hardly going to give up its name and identity because some developer has seen a way to make a quick buck by throwing up some semi-detached bungalows, slapping a carriage lamp on the front of them and calling them "Stoneleigh." If anybody asks me I just say I live in Weston. Everybody does, except one or two who insist on writing their addresses as "Stoneleigh." The postman told me that they add "Weston" as an afterthought, as though the former civilises the latter. He was annoyed, and he wanted me to know that once upon a time there had been a move to change the name of Weston to Market Weston, but it never caught on. He was keen that I should understand that there was nothing wrong with Weston, and once he started I could hardly get him to stop. That was last week when he had to knock on the door for he had a package that wouldn't fit through the letterbox, and he said that he didn't want to squash it up ("You never know what's in it, do you, love?"). He told me that he had been instructed by head office to scratch out the name "Stoneleigh" if it appeared on any envelopes. Should the residents turn out to be persistent offenders, then he was to politely remind them that they lived in Weston. But he told me that he didn't think that he would be able to do this. That actually if they wanted to live in cloud-cuckoo land, then who was he to stop them? He didn't tell this to his boss, of course, because that would have been his job. There and then, on the spot.

title: They Didn't Do It
description: The 45 men and women whose portraits appear in the pages of THE INNOCENTS (Umbrage Editions, $34.95) collectively served more than 500 years in prison for crimes they did not commit. The photographer Taryn Simon found and interviewed her subjects by working with the Innocence Project, the legal clinic founded by Barry Scheck and Peter Neufeld at Cardozo Law School in New York. She provides summaries for each case with its accompanying image -- vividly stylized re-creations of the scene of the arrest or misidentification, portraits with alibi witnesses or vignettes from the newly free lives of the wrongfully convicted. They alone do not tell us much about their subjects -- and that is part of the point. Many of the people portrayed were convicted on the basis of flawed eyewitness testimony, stacked lineups and manipulated photo displays. ''Photography's ability to blur truth and fiction is one of its most compelling qualities,'' Simon writes. The best of the pictures have an ambiguous, dreamlike quality. For example, Walter Snyder, seen from the front, seems furious, but his profile, reflected in the mirrored wall behind him, is tragically sad. It is easy to see -- and believe -- that he would feel both ways. Jake Miller

title: Quick Getaway to a Slow Idyll
description: IF you live in the North temperate zone, February is the cruelest month, breeding viral infections and a desire for warmer climes. For my husband, Larry, and me, it's the perfect time for a quick Caribbean getaway. With us, the emphasis is on ''quick.'' We've learned from a lifetime of flunking relaxation, that any sybaritic vacation longer than five days is too much of a good thing. What we want is to trade cold weather for warm, gray skies for blue, our cooking for theirs and most especially, our chlorinated, concrete lap pool at the Westport Y for their buoyant turquoise waters and white, sandy beaches. If we could have all that and remember to pack the letters for our Scrabble set this time, we'd have a wonderful vacation.

Taylor then volunteered to ship her breast milk from her town of Paola, Kan., to the twins about 500 miles away. ''I wanted to give them a good start, like I did with my own,'' she says.

title: The Tax-Cut Con
description: You've heard from the taxpayers (Letters, Sept. 28, responding to Paul Krugman, Sept. 14). Now it's my turn: I'm one of the ''lucky duckies,'' as The Wall Street Journal calls us. I am a paraplegic and a dialysis patient. I was born with spina bifida. Our government paid my college tuition, and I went to work and paid my taxes. When further illness prevented my continued gainful employment, social services kept me living independently. I need help and make no apologies for it. Sometimes in our lives, we need help, but it's rarely a choice, and we don't deserve to suffer the scorn of ''starve the beasters.''

title: What if There Is Something Going On In There?
description: Your article laudably addresses the plight of severely brain injured patients. Unfortunately, it blurred critical differences between the vegetative and minimally conscious states. Vegetative patients show no evidence of consciousness. Some patients may improve and become minimally conscious or recover higher levels of consciousness, but there is no recovery of consciousness from the chronic vegetative state or any intervention to ''coax'' vegetative patients into consciousness. These are more than academic distinctions. They can help distinguish those who retain awareness with potential for further recovery from the permanently unconscious patient epitomized by Karen Ann Quinlan.

title: For Couch Potatoes, Delivery Diet Food
description: Crash dieters starved for a spoon-fed weight-loss plan can now turn to Event Zone, a 21-day program designed by ZoneChefs for last-minute slimming before a big occasion like a wedding or a reunion. The program ($24.95 a day, 800-939-0663) delivers three cold-packed main courses and two snacks to the doorsteps of customers -- Ben Stiller and Lorraine Bracco among them -- shortly before dawn. Calorie counts and portions are customized; the menu (which follows a formula of 40 percent carbohydrates, 30 percent protein and 30 percent ''favorable'' fats) includes blueberry blintzes, beef stroganoff, brownies and lobster ravioli. Gabrielle Woodworth, a makeup artist, said she shed 12 pounds in the three weeks before her sister's wedding, adding, ''The food tastes great and I haven't had any cravings.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAPIS, GEORGE M.
description: BAPIS--George M. On October 16, 2003, in New York City. Beloved husband of Helene and father of twin daughters Michaela and Maria. Brother of Nick (Elaine) and Jeannie (Peter) duPont. Uncle of Laura and Andrew duPont, and Michael (Eleni) and Alethia Bapis. Son of Michael and Maxine Bapis. Employed as Senior Vice President of Investments at Morgan Stanley, served as Treasurer and chaired the investment committee of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, and as Treasurer and President of the Board of Trustees of the American College of Greece. Visiting Monday, October 20, from 6 to 8 PM, at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th St, New York, NY 10021. Funeral services Tuesday, October 21, at 11 AM, at the Cathedral. Interment to follow at the Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity.

title: Losing A Church, Keeping The Faith
description: Last week, something quite banal happened at St. Benedict's Church in the Bronx. A gay couple were told they could no longer sing in the choir. Their sin was to have gotten a civil marriage license in Canada. One man had sung in the choir for 32 years; the other had joined the church 25 years ago. Both had received certificates from the church commending them for ''noteworthy participation.'' But their marriage had gained publicity; it was even announced in The New York Times. This ''scandal'' led to their expulsion. The archbishop's spokesman explained that the priest had ''an obligation'' to exclude them.

title: Commercial Property/TriBeCa; Neighbors Object to Tower's Emergency Equipment
description: THE million-square-foot building in TriBeCa has always been about communications. Originally a place where telegrams were sent for delivery by uniformed boys, today it is a telecommunications center capable of handling billions of telephone calls and Internet messages a day.

title: Softer Rents, but the Hunt Is Still Hard
description: ASKING rents in Manhattan have stopped falling but remain at least 10 percent below the levels of two years ago, brokers and building owners say. Yet when Jodie Welkes, a financial planner, returned to New York this summer, she found the search for an apartment a daunting and expensive experience.

title: The Longest Party
description: So80s

title: Make Money While the Sun Shines
description: PASS by a cornfield along the highway and it's quite natural to think it is nothing more than that -- a cornfield. In truth, though, what's growing there can also be a way to obtain cleaner air, promote energy independence, curb sprawl and create lots of jobs as well.

description: Back to Iowa, 28 Years Later

description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation: The Buck Stops Where?; For Better or Worse, It's Becoming 'Bush's War'
description: ALL may not be well at the White House if the president feels compelled to assert, as George W. Bush did in a television interview last week, that ''the person who is in charge is me.'' If a president has to state the obvious -- in 1995, Bill Clinton memorably announced that he was still relevant -- it is even more likely that something, somewhere, is wrong.

title: Tragedy and Farce in the Age of Ikea
description: SHE IS ME

title: Letters
description: Firehouse closings and sites for statues were topics in our New York issue that drew a spirited response. A report on curriculum tracking prompted some to make a case for the one-room schoolhouse. And ''lucky duckies'' snapped back at ''starve the beasters'' in the Paul Krugman letters.

title: Wild Thing
description: What on earth was he thinking, Siegfried & Roy's 7-year-old white Siberian tiger, Montecore, sequestered now ''in its usual quarters,'' as one report phrased it, at the Mirage hotel in Las Vegas, his future as an entertainer, indeed as a tiger, in serious question. Six and a half years of respectfully tame performances under his pelt -- six days a week, 45 weeks a year -- and then, in the course of a recent Friday-evening show at the Mirage's 1,500-seat Siegfried & Roy Theater, the 600-pound cat decides to act entirely out of -- or is that in? -- character, biting his longtime trainer Roy Horn in the neck, dragging him, near death, offstage.

title: Keeping Count
description: To the Editor: ''Who's Counting?'' (Oct. 5), by Judith H. Dobrzynski, certainly sounded too familiar. I often find myself thinking about returning to an unvisited part of Italy or France -- then catch myself. How can I do that when there are new countries to visit and savor?

description: VERDON--Gwen. Lovingly remembered. Pau

title: Fierce, if Fleeting, Attachments
description: FOR months, it was eyed with suspicion, tinges of rebellion and elegiac longings for an Upper West Side that has not existed for some time now. The signs promised Petco, the pet supply superstore, where Playspace, an indoor playground, and a beloved toy store, the General Store, had stood until early this year, victims of rising rents along the blocks of Broadway.

title: Streets Smarts
description: Warsaw is full of white people. Obviously, that statement applies to the capital of Poland, but the Warsaw I'm referring to is a club in Brooklyn. It's a Thursday night, and I'm standing alongside 800 Caucasian hipsters in a Greenpoint rock venue, waiting to see the Streets. The Streets is technically a group, but it's really a group of one: Mike Skinner, a 24-year-old from Britain who looks as if he's 15. Do not feel depressed if you've never heard of him; he is not famous. Except that he is, if you happen to be the kind of person who searches for potential pop geniuses. In certain circles, in certain clubs and pretty much anywhere in London, Skinner is one of those ''voice of a generation'' types; as the writer-rapper-producer for the Streets, he has experienced the kind of meteoric ascension (at least among critics) that changes a messenger into his own self-styled medium.

title: G.M. to Sell Wider Range of Vehicles in China
description: SHANGHAI, Oct. 16 - General Motors is expanding the range of models and brands it sells in China, with plans to offer a hierarchy of divisions from Chevrolet to Cadillac as it does in the United States, G.M. executives said here this week.

description: Green Bay Packers (3-3) at St. Louis Rams (3-2)

description: PROVING that the more things change, the more they stay the same, Wall Street analysts have their pompoms out again.

description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Private Sector; Going Beyond Mere Convenience
description: ALAIN BOUCHARD has few good things to say about American convenience stores. To Mr. Bouchard, a 54-year old Quebecer, many have outdated designs and all too predictable product lines, and they rely too heavily on low-margin gasoline and shrinking cigarette sales.

title: Bush Cites Philippines as Model in Rebuilding Iraq
description: President Bush told the Congress of this former American colony on Saturday that Iraq, like the Philippines, could be transformed into a vibrant democracy. He also pledged his help in remaking the troubled and sometimes mutinous Philippine military into a force for fighting terrorism.

description: Michelle Barbara Rodriguez and Alan Patrick Dowling were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York. The Rev. John A. Kamas performed the ceremony.

description: A PROGRAM aiding Westchester's growing Hispanic population is likely to fold at the end of the year, the victim of AmeriCorps's cutbacks.

title: Turning Her Camera on Their Backs
description: THOUGH she considers herself a portraitist, the Mexican photographer Eugenia de Olazabal is not interested in peoples' faces. How the camera might capture her subjects' eyes, what their expressions might convey -- all such conventions of portraiture are immaterial to her. What she's drawn to is backs: the backs of heads, necks and torsos, and what these body parts, perennially turned to the world, reveal about the person.

title: The Nation; Wal-Mart, Driving Workers and Supermarkets Crazy
description: IN February Wal-Mart will open its first grocery supercenter in California, offering everything from tires to prime meats, and that could be a blessing for middle-class consumers. The reason is simple: Wal-Mart's prices are 14 percent lower than its competitors', according to a study by the investment bank UBS Warburg.

title: Julie Brown, Ken Burns
description: Julie Deborah Brown, the founder of a nonprofit organization, and Ken Burns, the documentary filmmaker, were married last evening at their home in Walpole, N.H. Dayton Duncan, a justice of the peace in New Hampshire, officiated.

title: 2 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Iraq Ambush
description: FALLUJA, Iraq, Oct. 19  Crowds of young men danced in victory atop the smoking wreckage of a United States Army truck demolished in this unsettled city today, as attacks against United States forces elsewhere in Iraq over the last day killed two American soldiers and wounded several more.

title: The Fabric of Lubbock's Life
description: Lubbock is a rock-solid, conservative kind of place, located where northwest Texas meets the southernmost part of the great American plains. Its citizens like to think of themselves as self-reliant straight talkers. It seems strange, then, to think of this region as a sprawling welfare case.

title: New Lures on Caribbean Shores
description: EARLY on a September morning in Old San Juan, guests on a breeze-swept terrace at the elegant Hotel El Convento sipped coffee and ate freshly sliced mangoes, papayas and pineapple. A reception desk clerk stayed busy answering the phone, a honeymoon couple checked out and, behind a terrace door, guests admired the cozy library. September is the depths of the doldrums in the Caribbean, but on that day, El Convento was bustling, thanks in part to bargain room rates.

title: Bermuda
description: To the Editor: In response to ''Pink Beaches, Well Scrubbed'' (Sept. 28), Terry Trucco's article on Bermuda, I found no rooms available in other hotels for the five days in October that I had planned to spend at the Sonesta Beach Resort. And the hotel didn't offer any assistance in booking at another location. I have spent four or five days in the fall in Bermuda with my family for the past five years. But this year I'll be going to Florida.

title: The Two Worlds Of Justin Moore
description: JUSTIN MOORE, a 27-year-old transplant from Florida who came to New York nearly three years ago, talks about his goals as if he has already achieved them. All he has ever wanted to be is a rock star, and he may have what it takes. Slinky and lean, with silky dark hair and a mysterious scar on his left cheek, he radiates charm and a certain bad-boy mystique. There is something sweet about him, too.

title: A Salvadoran Renaissance On Dominican Streets
description: This past summer in Washington Heights, an overwhelmingly Dominican neighborhood that has a surprising abundance of Salvadoran restaurants, Benjamn Ramrez took the $50,000 he had saved during 26 years as a restaurant worker and made a bold business move.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sept. 28 about people with brain injuries or impaired consciousness referred imprecisely to the condition of Daniel Rios, one patient studied, a year after a blood vessel ruptured in his brain. He was minimally conscious, or had some level of awareness -- not vegetative, or showing no signs of consciousness.

title: Saving Your Plants From Cold Weather
description: FROST is on its way. I can see it coming in the heavy dew that settles every morning on the leaves of the peppermint pelargonium. As sure as the maple leaves begin blushing crimson, the temperatures will go below freezing one sparkling night soon.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Rodale, the publisher, included erroneous identifications from the company for the founders of Runner's World and Backpacker. Runner's World was started by Bob Anderson, and Backpacker was started by William Kemsley. Rodale acquired them; they were not started by Bob Rodale.

title: FILM: Authors of Their Own Demise; The Real Star of Stephen Glass's Movie
description: WHEN filmmakers depict journalism, they usually overcome the visual hurdles of the profession -- pasty-hued people, computer screens, badly lighted rooms -- by rendering journalists as heroic action figures. In ''All the President's Men,'' two hot-shot journalists relentlessly pursue a story until a corrupt president is forced from office, while ''The Insider'' follows a reporter who wields a cellphone like an Uzi to fell an evil corporate conspiracy.

title: Kerri Bauchner, Joshua Stone
description: Kerri Lynn Bauchner, a daughter of Donna and Ted Bauchner of North Woodmere, N.Y., was married last evening to Joshua Matthew Stone, the son of Phyllis and Robert Stone of New City, N.Y. Cantor Henry Weintraub officiated at Carlyle on the Green, a caterer in Bethpage, N.Y.

description: EACH afternoon as I shuttle my daughters to softball, tennis or Hebrew school, I stop at a red light at the intersection of Jericho Turnpike and South Oyster Bay Road, the commercial epicenter of Syosset, where we live.

Spyksma of Lisle, Ill., and Dr. Thomas E. Hoekstra of Grayslake, Ill. The Rev. David Stout performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

description: One victory was all it took to erase the lethargy that an 0-4 record produced. So Curtis Martin got his appetite back last week, after the Jets' victory Sunday over Buffalo.

title: EVERYTHING WAS POSSIBLE
description: AS a production assistant on the original Broadway version of ''Follies'' in 1971, Ted Chapin was lucky enough to witness the creation of one of the most important shows in the history of musical theater. And lucky for us, he kept a journal. In ''Everything Was Possible: The Birth of the Musical 'Follies,' '' published this month by Alfred A. Knopf, Mr. Chapin has turned his decades-old notes into a lively account of working with Stephen Sondheim, who wrote the music and lyrics; James Goldman, who wrote the book for the show, about the tragicomic reunion of former follies performers; and the musical's co-directors, Harold Prince and Michael Bennett. In this excerpt, Mr. Chapin, now the president of the Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization, muses about the musical's book two weeks before the first out-of-town performance in Boston.

title: What's Inside Those Packages
description: LATELY, it seems, everywhere you look, travel companies are promoting vacation packages: X nights in (fill in the destination) for some unbelievably low price.

title: Canadian Envisions New Role For Nation
description: Poised to take the reins of power as prime minister as early as January, former Finance Minister Paul Martin is beginning to articulate a bold foreign policy vision for Canada. He is outlining efforts to reduce American and European trade barriers, combat money laundering that finances international terrorism and pump up the Canadian military.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  The feminist leader Patricia Ireland has been dismissed as chief executive officer of the Y.W.C.A. less than six months after she was hired to lead the 144-year-old organization.

title: Tribute to the Grandeur and Turbulence of Callas
description: ''I have always felt that dance is an interior song,'' Micha van Hoecke wrote in the program note for ''Maria Callas: La Voix des Choses,'' which his Ensemble di Micha van Hoecke offered on Tuesday night at the John Jay College Theater. That enigmatic statement can easily prompt speculation about movement, music and emotion. The 75-minute production by this Belgian-born choreographer also stirred up thoughts and feelings.

title: General compares militants to 'Satan' : Comments on Islam irk the White House
description: WASHINGTON:  Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, on Sunday effectively rebuked a senior Pentagon officer for comments viewed as demeaning to Islam and Muslims, including a comparison of the war against Islamic militants to a battle with Satan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMONTON, JOHN THAYER, MD FACS
description: SIMONTON -- John Thayer, MD FACS, of Rye, New York, died peacefully on October 17, 2003. He is survived by his loving daughter Linda Simonton Goldstein, his son John Garnett Simonton, his son-inlaw Marvin Jerome Goldstein, his grandchildren, Frederick Beidler Simonton, Mariah Garnett Simonton and William Garnett Simonton Goldstein and his step-grandchildren Aimee Goldstein Beldock, her husband James Geringer Beldock and Andrew David Goldstein. A memorial service will be held at the Rye Presbyterian Church at 5:00 PM on Wednesday, October 22nd, Rye, New York. Contributions to the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, the United Hospital or the Osborn Retirement Home would be greatly appreciated in lieu of flowers.

title: Of Mice And Men
description: How can we best protect ourselves against the bioterror attack certain to come one day? The ultimate answer is personal self-defense -- arming the human immune system with the power to recognize, attack and defeat any germ or virus that a bioterrorist can create. Such an alliance between brain and immune cells would also defeat all other diseases now afflicting humanity.

title: Quiche Lorraine (Bacon and Cheese Tart)
description: The mother of all quiches. A truly classic French recipe that combines the saltiness of bacon with the tang of Swiss Gruyere and the richness of eggs and cream. Preferably eaten warm, but it can be refrigerated and reheated or eaten at room temperature. The pre-baking of the tart dough, known as "blind baking," guarantees a firm crust. Adapted from Andre Soltner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMAN, RABBI SAMUEL M.
description: KAUFMAN--Rabbi Samuel M., on October 19, 2003. Former Chaplain, NYC Veterans Hospital for 46 years. Retired Lt. Col., US Army. Teacher, NYC public schools for 25 years. Chaplain and Secretary of Harvest Lodge, B'nai B'rith. Beloved husband of the late Edith. Cherished and devoted father of Gary. Services Monday at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Call for service time, 212-362-6600.

But after the mighty Yankees were stymied by the underdog Florida Marlins, 3-2, in Game 1, they must have felt like Indiana losing to Cleveland State 17 years ago.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with a dance review of a Merce Cunningham program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music misidentifed the dancers in a rehearsal of ''Split Sides.'' They were Cdric Andrieux and Derry Swan. (Daniel Squire and Holley Farmer are also in the work.) The review also misidentified Jonah Bokaer's partner in the duet in ''Fluid Canvas.'' She was Jeannie Steele, not Ms. Farmer.

title: Sports of The Times; Ex-Yankee Robinson Returns as a Winner
description: WHEN the Florida Marlins arrived at Yankee Stadium for the World Series on Friday, they could see all the retired numbers out behind the left-field fence. A few even made a pilgrimage to the monuments to absorb the history of the place.

title: Divining the Wellspring of Rage That Incited Montreal Punk Riot
description: According to its publicist's Web site, the Exploited, a Scottish punk band, has been tear-gassed by the German police, banned from the Netherlands and ''caused more carnage than a multicar pileup'' during its 24-year career. But a few days ago the Exploited and another punk band, Total Chaos, were thwarted by no less a force than Canadian customs officials, who refused the bands entry to Canada from the United States on the grounds that some members had criminal records while others had lied to customs.

title: Waiting for Democrats on Iraq
description: With the future of America's postwar occupation of Iraq looking longer by the day, the political debate over the issue has taken on new urgency. As American soldiers continue to die and the cost to American taxpayers continues to mount, the Democratic presidential candidates have started to sense that Iraq could turn into a liability for President Bush's re-election campaign. Unfortunately, they have so far been mostly jockeying to produce the best sound bite about who was the first and loudest to denounce Mr. Bush's flawed policy. They need to do better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENWALD, RAYMOND J.
description: GREENWALD--Raymond J. Died October 18, 2003. Beloved husband of Pearl. Cherished uncle of James and Meryl Kaye, Marissa, Mathew and Sarah Kaye. Loyal friend and respected colleague of many. In lieu of flowers donations to Hatzolah. Services Tuesday, 1 pm, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: An Optimist Aims to Revive Red Herring
description: It is a truism of markets that a good time to invest is at the bottom of the business cycle.

title: Sports of The Times; Yankees and Owner Purged the 12 Losses
description: BELOW the big block blue letters identifying Yankee Stadium, the words ''26 World Championships'' stretch across the front of this baseball museum, the winning years from 1923 to 1949 on white panels on one side, from 1950 to 2000 on the other. On the stairway down to the team clubhouses, a framed poster proclaiming ''26 World Championships'' stares at the players when they arrive -- to inspire the Yankees, to intimidate the visitors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, KERMIT
description: MILLER--Kermit. 91 years old, died on October 17, 2003, in Southbury, CT. Served in combat with distinction as a Captain in the Yankee Division in World War II. Had a long, successful career in the carpet industry. Devoted husband of 59 years of Frances. Loving father of Ross. Adored grandfather of Sasha. Beloved brother of Arthur and Joan. Memorial service to be held.

title: Justices Decline to Hear Presidential Pardon Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 - The Supreme Court today sidestepped a chance to define the benefits of a presidential pardon. The justices refused to hear an appeal by a once-prominent member of the bar here who argued that because his bribery conviction had automatically led to his disbarment in 1983, his pardon by President Clinton in 2001 should lead just as automatically to his reinstatement.

title: A Little Restaurant Elbows the 4-Stars In Zagat's New List
description: Here, in order, are the seven best restaurants in New York City, according to food ratings in the 2004 Zagat Survey published today: Le Bernardin, Daniel, Peter Luger, Nobu, Bouley, Jean Georges and the Grocery.

title: G.I.'s Escape Roadside Bombing, but 2 Are Killed in Northern Iraq
description: Crowds of young men danced in victory atop the smoking wreckage of an American Army truck demolished here on Sunday, as attacks against United States forces elsewhere in Iraq over the last day killed two American soldiers and wounded several more.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHEVLIN, DR. ALEXANDER
description: SHEVLIN -- Dr. Alexander. March 2, 1917-October 20, 2001. It has been a sad two years without your wisdom and wit. We miss and think of you every day. All our love, Abbe, Sally, David and Ian

title: Quick Lecture From Rodriguez
description: Ivan Rodriguez, a longtime All-Star playing in his first World Series, has been the best player in this year's postseason, delivering repeated clutch hits and impressive defensive plays as well as offering guidance to some of the younger Marlins.

title: Pettitte Stops Marlins Cold in Their Tracks
description: The chant started when Andy Pettitte trotted out of the home dugout before the top of the ninth inning at Yankee Stadium last night. In a sing-song salute, the fans repeated Pettitte's first and last name, a chorus that grew when Manager Joe Torre finally removed Pettitte with two outs and one run in.

title: The New Europe: Czech Republic: A 'bad situation' is looking a lot better
description: PRAGUE  After a disastrous start to its privatization program and despite a tenuous political situation, things are looking up for the Czech Republic.

title: The New Europe: Czech Republic: Rise of Communists linked to social gap
description: CHEB, Czech Republic  To many foreigners, the Czech Republic stands for staunch opposition to communism led by Vaclav Havel, the former president and heroic dissident.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: State Spending Is On Track
description: Spending in New York State through the first half of the fiscal year, while less than anticipated, is consistent with the Pataki administration's plans, according to a report by the state comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, a Democrat. The comptroller's September cash report showed that state revenues, including tax collections, were $115 million less than anticipated, while overall state spending was $411 million less than projected. The state's budget is $92.8 billion. Al Baker (NYT)

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Football Analysis; Testaverde Lets Play Do Talking For Him
description: In the hyperintensity of a fourth quarter, some quarterbacks tell jokes. During Super Bowl XXIII, Joe Montana is said to have pointed in the crowd to the actor John Candy as a way to calm his teammates.

title: Bolivian Peasants' 'Ideology of Fury' Still Smolders
description: Down in the capital, a new president was settling into office and assembling a cabinet. Up here in the birthplace of the monthlong uprising that overthrew his predecessor, the residents, giddy with satisfaction at the change they had wrought, had but one message: don't get too comfortable in power.

title: Cotton Trade Group Narrows Choice to 4
description: Cotton Inc., the trade association for American cotton growers and importers, has narrowed a review for its account to four finalists. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Two Stab Man To Death, Police Say
description: A woman and her brother fatally stabbed her ex-boyfriend during an argument early yesterday morning in the South Bronx, the police said. Gloria DeLeon, 53, and her brother Norberto DeLeon, 50, both of 720 Westchester Avenue, were arrested in the stabbing of the man, whom the police did not identify. He died at Lincoln Hospital Center just before 6 a.m., the police said.

title: The Judge and the Banker
description: Conventional wisdom has it that the now-deadlocked jury in the trial of Frank P. Quattrone, the former star technology banker at Credit Suisse First Boston, is likely to benefit him with an outcome of an acquittal or a mistrial.

description: Known in France as pate brisee, this is a basic dough recipe that will go well with any savory tart, including the three quiches discussed here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FARRAND, REV. JOHN LIVINGSTON, S.J.
description: FARRAND--Rev. John Livingston, S.J. Faculty member of Brooklyn Prep and Loyola School. Dear brotherin-law of Angie Farrand. Reposing at the Loyola School Chapel, 980 Park Avenue, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9, Wednesday, 2-5. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 7:30 pm, St. Ignatius Loyola Church. Interment Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the Fr. Farrand, S.J., Scholarship, Loyola School, 980 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10028. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors 718-654-0500.

title: Snags Delay Final Version Of Energy Bill
description: Republicans trying to finish the first major energy legislation in a decade continued to hit obstacles in weekend talks and postponed a meeting scheduled for Monday afternoon that would have allowed a House-Senate negotiating committee to approve the measure.

title: Vote Machine Replacement Lags, Despite Age
description: James Parks, on his knees, struggled to find the one screw amid the 20,000 parts that would unjam the scraped and dented New York City voting machine he was repairing. Ray Crews, another mechanic, had a handful of thin metal straps, which he carefully threaded, one at a time, into the back of the 800-pound behemoth he was servicing nearby. And Jamie Wilkins used a screwdriver to flip back tiny copper switches in the endlessly complex guts of another battleship-gray machine.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; Disco, Alive and Dancing
description: Punk rock has died a thousand deaths, but its much-maligned cousin disco just keeps going. As long as there are dance clubs, people will need something to dance to; a quarter century after its commercial peak, the legacy of disco seems richer than ever. Two new releases carry on the disco tradition.

description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Metro Matters; On the Ferry, And Waiting For Answers
description: IT was pretty much back to normal on the Staten Island ferries yesterday. Kids in shiny baseball jackets argued about the Series; parents lined up at the snack counter to buy their children glazed doughnuts; tourists gazed, transfixed, at the Statue of Liberty, as did the occasional otherwise jaded New Yorker because the city's special beauty never gets old.

title: Alija Izetbegovic, Muslim Who Led Bosnia, Dies at 78
description: Alija Izetbegovic, the former Bosnian president whose dream of a Muslim-led independent Bosnia and Herzegovina was transformed by Balkan ethnic rivalries into a protracted war, died Sunday in Sarajevo. He was 78 years old.

title: The Heroes Amid the Goats In GTO History
description: IT is hard, though not impossible, to pick a clunker from the short run of the Pontiac GTO. Choosing the ideal example to acquire is a matter of setting priorities: early editions have the classic look; the next generation delivers more horsepower; and the final editions, though hobbled by emissions controls, at least have novelty and affordability in their favor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELBERG, YEHUDA
description: ELBERG--Yehuda, died on October 18, 2003, at the age of 91. Internationally renowned Yiddish author who turned his Holocaust experience in Poland into award-winning literature. title: Cable's New Giant Flexes His Muscles
description: Maybe the cable industry should have seen it coming. Everyone who knew Brian Roberts, the polite and apparently easy-going chief executive of the Comcast Corporation, understood that he had learned the cable business from his father -- Comcast's hard-bargaining founder, Ralph Roberts.

title: Bellmore Journal; Life Goes On but Is Altered After School Scandal
description: A pack of teenagers congregates across the street from Mepham High School, smoking their cigarettes and clowning. A minivan with two others whizzes by, music blaring. One student lifts up another and dumps him, legs flailing, in a bush. Everyone laughs.

title: Are Those Leaving Welfare Better Off Now? Yes and No
description: By many measures, the overhaul of welfare has been a success. Seven years after Congress rewrote the rules in an effort to end long-term dependency on benefits, hundreds of thousands of Americans have moved from welfare to work, many of them substantially raising their incomes. Some also credit the new law for a rise in marriage and cohabitation by single mothers and a decline in the teenage pregnancy rate.

title: The Wisdom of Unpredictability
description: The 92nd Street Y opened its season on Oct. 14 evening with an installment of its Chamber Music at the Y series, and quickly joined the list of musical organizations saluting Ned Rorem on his impending 80th birthday, Oct. 23. For the occasion, Jaime Laredo, the violinist who directs the series, chose one of Mr. Rorem's most recent scores, ``The Unquestioned Answer'' (2003), for flute, two violins, cello and piano.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUREASKO, H. RUSSELL
description: GUREASKO--H. Russell. On October 9, 2003, age 75. WW II veteran, USMC pilot, law school graduate, recordsmanagement professional. Mourned by his beloved companion Liljan Wunderman and her two children and two grandchildren. He is survived by two sisters.

title: The New Europe: Czech Republic: Do musicals reflect downward cultural drift?
description: PRAGUE  Pavel Zatloukal likes to assert that as head of the art museum in the northern Moravian city of Olomouc and as an expert on 19th-century culture, the 21st century isn't his field of expertise. But mention contemporary culture in the Czech Republic and this outspoken art historian bristles over what is on offer some 200 miles to the west in Prague  in particular the spate of musicals that has hit the capital city in the past 14 years.

title: Alsatian Ziwelawaa (Alsatian Onion Quiche)
description: Andre Soltner remembers this recipe, an Alsatian standby, from his childhood in an Alsatian village. "In Mulhouse, in some of the bistros, I remember there was a sign in the window: 'Onion Tart Ready at Four O'clock'," he recalls. "These places served no other food, just the onion tart, and at four oclock they filled up. When my mother was finished with her shopping, we would go too. We would each get a slice of onion tart, and my mother would have a glass of white wine  and I would take a sip."

title: Wherefore Art Thou The Son Of a D.A.?

title: New Look at Silicone Breast Implants
description: A key advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended last week that silicone breast implants be allowed back on the market more than a decade after they were largely banished over safety concerns. The decision was a close call, with nine panelists favoring reinstatement and six opposed because of worries about possible long-term dangers. Nevertheless, the verdict adds to a growing impression that the implants, once blamed for a range of serious illnesses in women, are relatively safe, or at least fit for resurrection under appropriate safeguards.

Dallas sent the game into overtime and pulled out the victory.

Cabrera fouled a ball off his lower leg in the seventh inning last night, hesitated momentarily and, unsure of whether the ball had been ruled foul, ran to first base. It was too late and Yankees third baseman had already begun a double play when the plate umpire Larry Young ruled it a fair ball. Television replays showed Cabrera hit the ball off his left leg, which meant it should have been called foul.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer Grazed In Shooting

The officer, whose name was not released, was driving home in his own car after working the night shift when he saw a crowd of people blocking the intersection of Putnam Avenue and Marcus Garvey Boulevard, the police said. The officer honked and someone in the crowd turned and fired one round through the windshield, which ricocheted off the seat belt and grazed the officer's chest, the police said. The officer was treated at Bellevue Hospital Center and released. A second off-duty officer in the car was unharmed, and the gunman has not been caught. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

description: In a new measure of local readership of newspaper Web sites, The Washington Post ranks first, according to data from the research firm comScore Media Metrix.

title: Bush Tells Malaysian Leader That Comments on Jews Were Wrong
description: BANGKOK, Oct. 20  President Bush ran into Malaysia's pugnacious prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, at the opening of the Asian summit meeting here today and told him out of the earshot of the other 19 leaders that Mr. Mahathir had been "wrong and divisive" when he declared last week that Jews run the world by proxy, the White House said.

title: Justices to Revisit Sentencing Powers of Judges and Juries
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  The Supreme Court significantly broadened its continuing examination of the role of judges and juries in criminal sentencing when it agreed today to decide whether judges alone can impose sentences greater than the normal range provided under state sentencing guideline laws.

title: Protesting Ban on Advance DVDs,Los Angeles Critics Cancel Awards
description: In a sharp rebuke to a new ban on "screeners"  the DVD and videocassete copies of new films meant for awards voters but often used by video pirates  the Los Angeles Film Critics Association has voted to cancel its 2003 awards.

title: The Show That Ate the Original Cast
description: Usually a show that gets killed out of town dies a quiet death, never to be seen or heard from again. But the producers of ''Little Shop of Horrors'' believed that the revival of the 1982 musical that they scrapped in Miami on the way to Broadway deserved another chance.

title: White House Letter; Trying to Bypass the Good-News Filter
description: President Bush set off a round of mad buzzing in Washington last week when he took a pop at the national news media. ''There's a sense that people in America aren't getting the truth,'' Mr. Bush said to a reporter for Hearst-Argyle Television, one of five back-to-back White House interviews he granted to regional broadcasters. ''I'm mindful of the filter through which some news travels, and sometimes you have to go over the heads of the filter and speak directly to the people.''

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Football Analysis; Weaknesses Are With Offenses
description: Brian Westbrook was explaining his view on the atmosphere Sunday just before he spun the Giants and their season into full-throttle reverse with a dagger 84-yard punt return that led the Eagles to victory.

title: Chinese President to Consider Methods to Float Exchange Rate
description: The Chinese president, Hu Jintao, under pressure from the United States to revalue his nation's currency, agreed on Sunday that Chinese and American experts would study how Beijing could move toward a floating exchange rate, Bush administration officials said.

title: Will the Space Race Move East?
description: Something that went up in the first Chinese manned spacecraft did not come down. The Shenzhou 5, which orbited Earth 14 times last week, left behind an orbital module carrying equipment capable of capturing images of the earth's surface. This satellite could be used for many purposes, including the monitoring of United States military forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACKSON, WILLIAM JACOB JR.
description: JACKSON--William Jacob Jr. 92, died in Laurel, MD, on October 9, 2003. Born June 16, 1911, in Hoboken, NJ. Survived by Ann Lee Jackson of Laurel and Elizabeth Jackson Berman of Durham, NC. Burial will be at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Locked Out at a Young Age
description: With the nation at war, the wretched state of millions of young people in America's urban centers is getting even less attention than usual.

title: MediaTalk; Maxim's 'Hidden' Cover Spoofs Breathless Headlines In Popular Magazines
description: Maxim, the men's magazine known for come-hither headlines on its cover, takes another tack in its November issue, which promotes ''25 Dazzling Kitchens and Baths!,'' ''Telecom: What's Next for This Key Sector'' and ''Savor the Flavor: The Incredible Edible Eggplant.''

description: Extending a Streak

title: AUTOS ON MONDAY/Collecting; GTO Is Still Flexing Its Muscle
description: THERE may never be a resolution to the argument over what traits define a muscle car or when Detroit's golden age of high performance began, but there is no question which car best embodies the spirit of the era: the Pontiac GTO.

title: Giants Lose a Lineman but Gain a Spark From Levens
description: As he sat propped on the cart taking him off the field, his broken right leg sealed in an air cast, Giants guard Rich Seubert took the towel that was covering his head and waved it at the Giants Stadium crowd. Seubert was trying, in the only way he could, to rally his struggling team.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: Emmylou Harris has always had an ear for songwriters with down-home roots and expansive ambitions. So before she performs at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, she has lined up some of her favorite songwriters and collaborators to appear this week at Zankel Hall. Kate and Anna McGarrigle, the Canadian sisters who wrote ''Heart Like a Wheel'' and wrote songs with Ms. Harris for her new album, ''Stumble Into Grace'' (Nonesuch), are scheduled for Zankel Hall tomorrow night at 7, followed by the scratchy-voiced, politically contentious Steve Earle at 10. On Wednesday night, Buddy and Julie Miller, songwriters who are husband and wife, are to perform at 7; Mr. Miller has been the guitarist in Ms. Harris's band, and Ms. Harris has recorded Ms. Miller's songs. Patty Griffin, whose songs have been sung not only by Ms. Harris but also by the Dixie Chicks, follows at 10. Ms. Harris will attend the concerts and may well add a harmony or two. JON PARELES

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FREIBERG, SYLVIA
description: FREIBERG--Sylvia. 7/15/11 10/20/98. Smart, funny, loving and compassionate, she hoped for a better world for future generations. Life's not the same without her. The Family

title: For Some Latino Music Stations, More Listeners, and More Critics
description: In the latest Arbitron ratings released this month, the Spanish-language radio station known as La Mega, WSKQ-FM (97.9), rose to No. 2 from No. 10 among New York's 40 top stations, reinforcing its reputation as a Latin music and morning talk powerhouse.

title: Both Profits and Political Battle Grow at Russian Oil Giant
description: Just as Russia's biggest oil producer is reporting rising profits, the company's battle with political authorities at home is escalating.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Red Cross Picks New Chief
description: The American Red Cross in Greater New York named Theresa A. Bischoff, former president of New York University Hospitals Center, as its new executive director, effective Jan. 1. Ms. Bischoff worked in corporate finance before going to the N.Y.U. medical center, where she served five years as president and oversaw significant fund-raising and expansion. She resigned this year, after concerns were raised that she might have had a conflict of interest in the hospital's contract negotiations after it was disclosed that she had a relationship with the head of the hospital's largest union. In a prepared statement, William Gray, the chairman of the Red Cross group, stressed her knowledge of business and fund-raising and the hope that she would improve the organization's financial standing. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Houston Likely to Start Tomorrow
description: The Knicks' open practice at Madison Square Garden yesterday was aimed at entertaining their young fans. But Allan Houston got plenty out of it, too.

title: U.S. SET TO CEDE PART OF CONTROL OVER AID FOR IRAQ
description: Under pressure from potential donors, the Bush administration will allow a new agency to determine how to spend billions of dollars in reconstruction assistance for Iraq, administration and international aid officials say.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: $3 Million For Homeless
description: A program to move the chronically homeless into permanent housing has won a $2.8 million federal grant. The grant, won by Project Renewal, was one of 11 awarded by the federal government to help end chronic homelessness. Project Renewal, based in Manhattan, is a nonprofit group specializing in sheltering homeless single people, many of whom are addicted to drugs or are mentally ill. Project Renewal plans to have a program in place in six months and to provide intensive social services. Leslie Kaufman (NYT)

title: Accounts
description: American Isuzu Motors, Cerritos, Calif., part of Isuzu Motors, expanded its relationship with Malone Advertising, Akron, Ohio, by naming the agency to handle media duties on its account. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

title: Tourte de Poisson  la Bire (Fish Quiche in Beer Custard)
description: An unusual recipe that adapts the idea of battering fish with beer to create a fluffy, rich quiche. Feel free to substitute other fish here, though nothing stronger than salmon.

title: The Wide World of Autos Converges in Tokyo
description: For sheer automotive spectacle, nothing beats the Tokyo Motor Show, a blend of the fantastic and futuristic. But as automotive types from around the globe descend on the Makuhara Messe this week, they can't ignore what's going on elsewhere.

description: In some ways, this was like any other Sunday at the Nirmal Hriday, or Pure Heart, home for the destitute, sick and dying.

title: Embracing and Fearing God, Love and Drugs
description: The British band Spiritualized is obsessed with cycles: building up and fading out, getting high and coming down. In 2001, the band released ``Let It Come Down,'' an expansive album made with the help of a gospel choir and a full orchestra. Then came the contraction: for the band's new album, ``Amazing Grace'' (Sanctuary/BMG), its leader, Jason Pierce (also known as J. Spaceman), stripped things down. Inspired in part by the success of the White Stripes, a duo, Mr. Pierce recorded with his version of a barebones rock band.

title: No Nobel Prize for Whining
description: The spectator sport of Nobel watching, especially for the science prizes, is a fall tradition, and this season has been unusually lively. On Oct. 6, the Nobel committee awarded the prize in physiology or medicine to Paul Lauterbur, of the University of Illinois, and Sir Peter Mansfield, of the University of Nottingham, for the invention of magnetic resonance imaging, the widely used diagnostic technology usually called M.R.I. Controversy erupted.

title: Finding a Way to 4 Hearts Upholds a Family's Honor
description: One of the world's great bridge families lives in Florida. Billy Seamon, who represented the United States and won five national titles, died in 1992, but his relatives are very active. His sister, Edith Kemp Freilich, is in the Hall of Fame and has an even larger collection of titles. His children are also at the top of the game: Michael Seamon just missed a world title in 1990, and Janice Seamon-Molson was second in the Venice Cup in 1999 and may do even better next month in the same event in Monte Carlo.

title: Electing Economies
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Yankees Even Series
description: Behind a strong outing by starting pitcher Andy Pettitte, the Yankees defeated the Florida Marlins, 6-1, in Game 2.

title: Moving Performances
description: Hollywood loves Detroit, and anyplace else where cars are dreamed up. Why not? Car power is star power. Where would movies be without the automobile?

title: The Iowa Bypass
description: There should be no doubting the self-serving motives of Senator Joseph Lieberman and Gen. Wesley Clark in dropping out of the Iowa Democratic presidential caucuses three months before voters gather there to ponder the crowded field. Senator Lieberman figured to be a moribund also-ran, so he is sending his staff off to greener primary pastures. General Clark is such a latecomer to politics, the Democratic Party and the presidential race that he decided he needed to become better organized somewhere further along to ever have a chance.

title: A Master Class for Divas From an Ebullient Personality
description: Voices as fervent as the bright, rich, gospel-schooled tenor of Billy Porter, who opened the fall season of Lincoln Center's American Songbook series on Thursday evening, are extremely rare, even in church. And when they coincide with a personality as ebullient as Mr. Porter's, every performance has the feel of an extravagant star turn.

description: Thankfully, Nobody Ever Demanded Coloratura

title: Anatomy of a $133,000 Ambulance; City Pays Premium, but Its Tough Specs Draw Few Bidders
description: Los Angeles buys them for $85,000 apiece. Detroit pays $84,000. Closer to home, a major New York hospital system spends less than $80,000.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Kisa Baumgartner was named account supervisor at Morey Evans Advertising, Denver. She had been account supervisor at Euro RSCG MVBMS Partners, New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas.

title: Cooking Broccoli, Out of the Box
description: Broccoli is prized as a healthy food in part because it contains high levels of chemicals believed to protect against heart disease and some kinds of cancer. Now a new study from Spain suggests that health lovers hoping to get those benefits keep their broccoli away from the microwave.

title: Accounts
description: HomeGoods, Framingham, Mass., a discount home dcor chain operated by the TJX Companies, began a review for a new agency to handle its account, which had been handled by Allen & Gerritsen, Watertown, Mass. Spending was estimated at $5 million. Pile & Company, Boston, has been named to manage the review. Allen & Gerritsen will not take part.
