title: Cendant Profit Declines 23%
description: The Cendant Corporation, the real estate and travel-services company, said yesterday that third-quarter earnings fell 23 percent because of an accounting change. The company raised its 2003 profit forecast for a second time.

title: Russian Oil Company Says Profit Is Up 26%
description: Yukos, Russia's No.1 oil company, reported a 26 percent surge in quarterly profit on Monday as the company's battle with political authorities at home continued to escalate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOYT, HELEN (NEE REILLY)
description: HOYT--Helen (nee Reilly). Of Ridgefield, CT, on October 19, 2003. Wife of the late Richard H. Hoyt, former Westchester resident and graduate of Brown University. Survived by two sons, Luke A. Nelligan, and Mark C. Nelligan, and two granddaughters, Katherine E. Nelligan, and Meghan M. Nelligan. Funeral mass Thursday 10:15 A.M. at St Mary's R.C. Church, Ridgefield, CT. Interment will be private. Memorials to Regional Hospice of Western CT, 405 Main St, Danbury, CT 06810.

title: New Clue on Which Came First, Tools or Better Diets
description: On a hillside in the badlands of Ethiopia, an ancestral home of the human family, an international team of scientists has uncovered the earliest known stone tools to be found mixed with fragments of fossilized animal bones. The scientists think the material, almost 2.6 million years old, is the strongest evidence yet that the primal technology was used to butcher animal carcasses for meat and marrow.

title: Powell, Pushing Peace for Sudan, Hints at Lifting Sanctions
description: NAIROBI, Oct. 21  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, seeking to prod the talks to end the long civil war in Sudan, suggested today that the United States would lift sanctions and provide economic aid if Sudan reaches a peace accord and acts further against terrorism in the Middle East.

title: For Giants, Slow Start Is Difficult To Take and Not Easy to Fix
description: Only a day removed from the Giants' catastrophic loss to the Eagles, the details were already fading. By Monday, the hows and whys of a game-killing punt return had become much less important than the realization that a season full of hope was in jeopardy so quickly.

title: Market Place; Improvement in Bottom Lines Pumping Up Investors' Hopes
description: After a long nightmare on Wall Street, the latest profit figures from corporate America have been the stuff of investors' dreams.

title: Farmers and Labor Press Global Trade as a Campaign Issue
description: When unions go on strike here, local farmers usually show up at picket lines with hogs and fresh produce to make sure the workers' families have food on their tables.

title: Group Names Most-Contaminated Produce
description: Apples, peppers, celery and cherries top a list compiled by an environmental research organization of the 12 fruits and vegetables it considers the most contaminated by pesticides.

title: JUDGE CLEARS $500 MILLION BANKRUPTCY LOAN FOR MIRANT
description: The Mirant Corporation, a power producer, has gained approval of a $500 million loan to help finance its Chapter 11 reorganization. Judge D. Michael Lynn of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Fort Worth, gave Mirant permission to borrow the money from the GE Capital Corporation and overruled the objections of some Mirant creditors who argued that terms favored the lenders at their expense. He set a hearing for Oct. 29 to address creditors' concerns about the borrowings. Creditors, including Citigroup Inc. and Credit Suisse Group, objected that Mirant has more than $1 billion in cash and failed to prove it needs a loan, which will trump almost all other creditors' claims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, LEON
description: SHAPIRO--Leon. On October 18. Husband of Ruth. Father of Celia, Martin, Alan, Eileen. Grand and great grandfather.

title: A Face-Lift for The Times, Typographically, That Is
description: Starting today, the front page and main news sections of The New York Times are receiving a gentle typographical face-lift.

title: MEMO PAD
description: Ever since business travelers began flying a lot more often on discount fares traditionally used by leisure travelers, the airlines and the rest of the business-travel industry have expressed frustration at not being able to determine just how much that important segment of travel has declined since 2000.

title: French-Accented Fraud Artist Is Sentenced in Hamptons Con
description: Christopher Rocancourt, who parted well-connected people from their money with a charming French accent and a story about being a Rockefeller, said he was sorry yesterday. Then a judge sentenced him to 3 years and 10 months in prison.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column on Oct. 13 about a James Rosenquist retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum misstated the timing of the artist's arrival in New York to pursue his career, and a correction on Saturday misstated the show's opening date. The artist arrived in the 1950's, not the 1960's. The show opening was Oct. 17; it is not this Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRILL, FREDERICK B.
description: GRILL--Frederick B. On October 19. Beloved husband of Barbara, devoted father of Mary Ellen, her husband Fred; Scott, his wife RoseAnna and Peter. Loving grandfather of Jason, Hayden and Rachel. Memorial services to be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHOEMAKER, ROBERT JEFFREY
description: SHOEMAKER--Robert Jeffrey, 56, a founding member of New York's Judith Shakespeare Company, died at home in Manhattan October 16th, 2003. The actor was born in 1947 in NYC. He was educated in Arizona and at the Menlo School in California. Shoemaker attended the University of Arizona before joining a Shakespeare troupe in San Francisco. In New York he played a number of leading Shakespearean roles for the Judith Company. He won acclaim for his roles in ''Inherit the Wind'', and ''All the King's Men''. His longtime companion, Jeanne LeBron, died in February 2000. Shoemaker is survived by his mother, Mary Shoemaker, a longtime resident of Tucson, AZ., his father, Robert Zumwalt predeceased him. His mother has been on the Board of the Arizona Thoroughbred Breeders Association for more than 50 years. She bred and trained horses at her Rillito Farm in Tucson. The deceased was the direct descendant of two pioneering shipping executives, Sir Roderick Cameron of the Australia pioneer line and Charles Mayer of the U.S. mail line. Besides his mother, he leaves an uncle, Juan Cameron of Washington, D.C., and six first cousins: Mark Cameron of Warwick, R.I.; Anne Cameron of New Milford, CT.; Elizabeth Cameron of Larchmont, N.Y.; Juan Cameron Jr., Nora Cameron and Roderick Cameron, all of Washington, D.C. A Memorial service is planned for December in New York.

title: In L.I. Town, Potty Politics Feeds Tension Over Ethnicity
description: On Sunday morning, East Hampton residents woke up to a bit of imaginative, if tasteless, political commentary scattered at about a half-dozen sites around town.

title: Sniper Suspect Is Own Lawyer As Trial Opens
description: John A. Muhammad, accused of being the mastermind of the Washington-area sniper shootings, fired his lawyers on Monday and took control of his own defense, telling the jury in a rambling but at times forceful opening argument that ''I had nothing to do with these crimes.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AQUILA, FRANK J.
description: AQUILA--Frank J. On October 19, 2003. Beloved husband of Evelyn (nee Farrell). Devoted father of Frank Aquila, Jane Malecki and James Aquila. Cherished grandfather of five. Frank Aquila was a resident of Brooklyn, NY and Harding Township, NJ. Visitation will be held on Thursday October 23, 2003. at Gallaway & Crane Funeral Home, 101 S. Finley Ave, Basking Ridge from 2-4 and 7-9. A Liturgy of Christian Burial will be held on Friday, October 24, 2003 at Christ the King RC Church in New Vernon at 10:30 AM. Interment will follow at Holy Rood Cemetery in Morristown. Those planning an expression of sympathy are asked to make donations to St. Athanasius Fund, 2154 61st St., Brooklyn, NY 11204, or The Philharmonic Orchestra of New Jersey, 50 Mt. Bethel Rd., Warren, NJ 07059. For directions or more information please call 908-766-0250 or go to www.gcfuneralhome.com

title: Series Promotions Send Wrong Message
description: Fox conducted a master class in how to diminish the dignity of the World Series by using two ill-advised, advertiser-coddling features during Games 1 and 2.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRANSCANADA CORP., Calgary, Alberta, a pipeline company, said it would buy a 29.6 percent stake in Portland Natural Gas Transmission System from El Paso Corp., Houston, for $56.5 million, to gain control of a pipeline that links Canadian gas fields to consumers in Boston.

title: Judge Rules Stewart Note to Lawyer Won't Be Evidence
description: A judge has ruled that an e-mail message Martha Stewart sent last year to a lawyer and to her daughter explaining her sale of ImClone Systems stock cannot be admitted as evidence in her coming trial.

title: White House Threatens to Veto Aid for Iraq in Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21  The White House threatened today, for the first time, to veto an $87 billion package for Iraq and Afghanistan if Congress converts any money for rebuilding Iraq into loans, as opposed to grants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FARRAND, REV. JOHN LIVINGSTON
description: FARRAND--Rev. John Livingston, S.J. Faculty member of Brooklyn Prep and Loyola School. Dear brotherin-law of Angie Farrand. Reposing at the Loyola School Chapel, 980 Park Avenue, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9, Wednesday, 2-5. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 7:30 pm, St. Ignatius Loyola Church. Interment Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the Fr. Farrand, S.J., Scholarship, Loyola School, 980 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10028. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors 718-654-0500.

title: Bryant Is Ordered to Stand Trial in Rape Case
description: A Colorado judge yesterday ordered Kobe Bryant, the Los Angeles Lakers star, to stand trial on charges that he sexually assaulted a 19-year-old woman, but he said the evidence against Mr. Bryant was minimal and conflicting.

title: 8 Rescued From Ferry Fire Near Verrazano Bridge
description: A fire aboard a commuter ferry going from New Jersey to Manhattan yesterday morning required the midharbor evacuation of eight passengers onto another boat, officials said. There were no injuries in the incident, which came on the heels of last week's fatal crash of the Staten Island Ferry.

title: For G.I.'s in Isolated Town, Unknown Enemy Is Elusive
description: Almost six months after the official end of hostilities in Iraq, United States forces are fighting for control of this gritty industrial town of 40,000, a main crossing point into Syria. In the past three weeks, an unidentified enemy deploying ever more sophisticated military tactics and powerful weapons, including mortars and land mines, has been hitting American troops, day and night.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Scientists Warn On Cod
description: Overfished cod are ''near commercial extinction'' in northern European waters, scientists warned, ratcheting up pressure on governments to ban fishing of the popular food fish until its numbers recover. The International Council for the Exploration of the Sea, which advises governments on fishing policy, said cod stocks in the North Sea, the Irish Sea and west of Scotland ''are at such low levels that we have to resort to recommending zero catches as a final line in the sand.'' The European Union ignored similar advice from the council last year, resorting to tighter quotas and a shortened fishing season instead of a blanket moratorium that would throw thousands of people out of work. European Union fisheries ministers will meet in December to set catch policy for next year. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Bait-and-Switch on Public Education
description: Congressional Republicans are nervous about a G.O.P. poll that shows them losing ground over education. But how could voters not be disappointed by the Bush administration's mishandling of education policy generally, and especially its decision to withhold more than $6 billion from the landmark No Child Left Behind Act, the supposed centerpiece of the administration's domestic policy?

title: Miscellany
description: The Association of National Advertisers, New York, has extended the terms of its chairman and vice chairman for an additional year each, to two years. James D. Speros, the 2002-3 chairman, will now serve through October 2004, as will James R. Stengel, the 2002-3 vice chairman.

title: B & Bs Ride Out The Travel Downturn
description: WHILE the last few years have been hard times for hotels, from plush palaces to mundane motels, bed-and-breakfasts have been doing comparatively well, according to hotel analysts.

description: The numbers on the scoreboard showed that the American Jennifer Don won the women's event at the Nebelhorn Trophy international figure skating competition in September.

title: U.S. Troops and Iraqis Arrest 32 Supporters of Shiite Cleric
description: BAGHDAD, Oct. 21  American troops assisting the Iraqi police during a raid on a mosque in Karbala today arrested 32 supporters of a fundamentalist Shiite cleric who has openly defied the United States.

title: Europeans to Meet With Iranian President
description: The foreign ministers of Britain, France and Germany are expected in Tehran to hold talks on Tuesday morning with President Mohammad Khatami.

title: Corrections
description: An article in late editions on Wednesday about a party in memory of George Plimpton misidentified the band that performed with Peter Duchin. It was the Bethune Big Band, not the Peter Duchin Orchestra.

title: Students Find $100 Textbooks Cost $50, Purchased Overseas
description: Richard Sarkis and David Kinsley were juniors at Williams College, surfing the net for a cheap source for their economics textbook, when they discovered a little known economic fact: the very same college textbooks used in the United States sell for half price -- or less -- in England.

title: At N.Y.U., Not All Want to Talk About Deaths, but Reminders Are Never Far Away
description: At the start of Tim Meyer's 8 a.m. history class at New York University yesterday, his professor offered to discuss the three recent student deaths on campus -- the latest one on Saturday evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AGNEW, WILLIAM H.
description: AGNEW--William H., 83, of Maplewood, formerly of Summit, NJ. On Saturday, October 18, 2003. He was a pioneer in the insurance business, as a Principal of Post and Kurtz Inc., NYC. He was a decorated Marine Corps Major in Okinawa, a dedicated volunteer to his alma mater Amherst College and a longtime Vestryman of Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit. Husband of the late Janet Elisabeth Gittinger Agnew. Father of P. Tomlin Agnew, Nancy E. Woodward, Susan Agnew-Huke and Elisabeth A. Thomson. Brother of Robert K.T. Agnew. Also survived by ten grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at Calvary Episcopal Church, 31 Woodland Ave., Summit on Thursday, October 30 at 11AM. Relatives and friends are invited to attend. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Remembrance Fund-Calvary Church, Summit, New Jersey 07901.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Arrested In Robbery
description: Two hospital security guards were robbed of $48,000 in cash and $7 million in checks as they deposited money at an Upper East Side bank yesterday, and two suspects were arrested 15 minutes later, the police said. When the guards, wearing uniforms, arrived at a Citibank branch at 69th Street and First Avenue at 2:25 p.m., they were approached by a man with a revolver and forced to hand over two bags of money, the police said. The gunman then ran north to 71st Street, where he met an accomplice, and the two fled on a bright red motorcycle, officials said. The suspects were caught about 2:40 p.m. after they became snarled in traffic near 125th Street and the Harlem River Drive and tried to lift the motorcycle over a median, the police said. The two men were charged with robbery, possession of stolen property and resisting arrest; weapons charges were also brought. One suspect will face additional charges because he was wearing a bulletproof vest during the robbery, the police said. The police would not release the name of the hospital where the guards worked.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Raid On Terrorist Hide-Out
description: Security forces on the island of Mindanao raided what police and military officers described as a safe house for Jemaah Islamiyah, the group blamed for the bombing in Bali that killed more than 200 people last year. Lt. Gen. Rodolfo Garcia, the vice chief of staff of the Philippine armed forces, said in a telephone interview that among the documents found at the house was a manual on bioterrorism, but that chemical residues also at the site did not initially appear to be biological weapons. The eight men renting the house fled before the raid, and no arrests were made. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about opposition to President Bush's latest judicial nomination referred incorrectly to Janice Rogers Brown, his choice for the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. If confirmed, she would be the second black woman on that court. (Judge Judith W. Rogers, who has served for 10 years, was the first.)

title: ICAHN EXTENDS DEADLINE FOR HALLWOOD REALTY PARTNERS
description: The financier Carl Icahn extended by a month his offer of $104.5 million for two-thirds of Hallwood Realty Partners, which owns 114 buildings with 5.1 million square feet of commercial and office space. The previous offer by Icahn's High River was set to expire today. About 60,986 units had been tendered as of the close of business Friday, High River said. That was fewer than the 62,269 units that had been tendered as of Oct. 1. Ina Kurcz, the counsel for High River, said she did not have any information on why the number of units tendered had dropped. Hallwood Realty said in August that High River's offer, which had been increased that month to $120 a unit from $100, was inadequate. Hallwood Realty's properties are in California, Georgia, Maryland, Michigan, Ohio and Washington.

title: Listening to Mahathir
description: ''The Europeans killed 6 million Jews out of 12 million. But today the Jews rule this world by proxy: They get others to fight and die for them.'' So said Mahathir Mohamad, the prime minister of Malaysia, at an Islamic summit meeting last week. The White House promptly denounced his ''hate-filled remarks.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Coughlin Is Recognized As Sportswoman of Year
description: The swimmer Natalie Coughlin was named the Women's Sports Foundation Sportswoman of the Year for individual achievement at a ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. From August 2002 to July 2003, Coughlin won titles in the 100- and 200-meter freestyle, the 100- and 200-meter backstroke, the 100-meter and 100-yard butterfly and the 100- and 200-yard backstroke. At the United States national championships in August 2002, Coughlin broke a 16-year-old American record in the 200-meter backstroke with a time of 2 minutes 8.53 seconds.

title: Hope Glimmering as War Retreats From Congo
description: After a calamitous war, Congo is at a fragile point of healing, with a whiff of hope now detectable in the humid air here.

title: People
description: Heide Gardner was named to the new post of director for diversity at the Interpublic Group of Companies, New York. She had been senior vice president for multicultural programs and strategies at the American Advertising Federation, Washington. Constance Cannon Frazier, a consultant and advertising teacher at Howard University, will succeed Ms. Gardner at the federation.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Free Trade Hope
description: In an interview Sunday with Australia's Channel 9 network, President Bush said he hoped the United States and Australia would complete a free-trade agreement by the end of the year. The United States is trying to persuade Australia to accept a compromise on its demands for the elimination of American agricultural subsidies within 10 years, particularly for sugar and dairy products. Calling Australia an important economy and an important friend of the United States, Mr. Bush suggested that he and the Australian prime minister, John Howard, above, could push their respective negotiators to resolve the details holding up an agreement. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Vendors Fight Back In The War On Smoking
description: Tobacco vendors staged their first ever strike to protest the second tobacco tax hike this year, which raised the price of cigarettes by as much as 20 percent. France increased tobacco taxes by 17 percent last January and it plans to increase taxes by about as much again in January of next year. The government hopes that by making the habit more expensive, fewer people will indulge. More than half of the country's 15- to 24-year-olds smoke, the highest percentage for the age group in Europe. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: INTERNATIONAL EDUCATION: Are foreign students turning away from U.S.?
description: Shortly before classes began for the autumn term, Penn State University learned that 13 male students from the Middle East whom it had admitted as freshmen had chosen instead to attend universities in Britain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PHILIP, REINALD
description: PHILIP--Reinald. On October 20, 2003 at the age of 86. Beloved husband of 56 years and cherished father and grandfather. Survived by his wife Victoria (nee deBurgos), his daughters Celeste and Claudia, and five grandchildren. Services Wed, 10:15AM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expy, Fresh Meadows, N.Y. Contributions may be made to any Parkinson's research foundation.

title: Experts Try Magnets for the Mind
description: Patients whose depression failed to respond to drugs showed improvement when treated with magnetic stimulation of their scalps, according to a new study.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Revisit Judges' Role in Sentences
description: The Supreme Court significantly broadened its continuing examination of the role of judges and juries in criminal sentencing when it agreed on Monday to decide whether judges alone can impose sentences greater than the normal range provided under state guideline laws.

title: Taking the Tedium Out of Filing Travel Expenses
description: For many business travelers, the worst part of a trip comes long after passing through airport security, enduring tedious meetings and recovering from a sleepless night in a stuffy hotel.

title: Remembering Hiroshima, In a Farewell Performance
description: Toshiko Akiyoshi has worked hard and efficaciously with her big band since 1973. Not just in the larger sense of creating lots of compositions, but also in the specific sense of what she does onstage: she leaps up to conduct with imposing authority, then steals over to her piano bench to improvise, usually in a hard-driving show of lean, stabbing harmony and long bebop lines.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Airport Adds Name
description: The Atlanta City Council voted, 12 to 2, to rename the city's airport Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, adding the name of the city's first black mayor, Maynard Jackson, to that of its longest-serving mayor, William B. Hartsfield. Mr. Jackson, who died in June, was a towering and controversial figure, overseeing the building of the international terminal in the 1970's and demanding a share of its contracts for blacks. Relatives of Mr. Hartsfield, who established the airport, the world's busiest, sought a different memorial for Mr. Jackson. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: CALL FOR INDEPENDENT FIRE INQUIRY The Cook County public guardian, Patrick Murphy, urged an independent investigation of a fire in a county building that killed six people on Friday, including three employees from his office. He said city or county officials would not be critical of their own departments and had ties to the building managers. Mr. Murphy called Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich a "politician in search of a backbone" for not pushing for an independent investigation. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Rangers Get Their First Victory But Lose Lindros to an Injury
description: The Rangers actually showed some signs of life at Madison Square Garden last night, but even when things go right, something still goes wrong.

title: Protesting Ban on Advance DVD's, Los Angeles Critics Cancel Awards
description: In a sharp rebuke to a new ban on ''screeners'' -- the DVD and videocassete copies of new films meant for awards voters but often used by video pirates -- the Los Angeles Film Critics Association has voted to cancel its 2003 awards.

title: Rise in Income Improves Children's Behavior
description: The notion that poverty and mental illness are intertwined is nothing new, as past research has demonstrated time and time again. But finding evidence that one begets the other has often proved difficult.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZUCKERMAN, BETTIE
description: ZUCKERMAN--Bettie. On October 18, 2003, at age 96. Survived by brother Saul and many nieces and nephews. Lived for four and half years at Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, NY, after a lifetime of office work and outstanding private art work. Services will be at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY, Thursday at 10 A.M

title: 'Regina,' With Music Restored
description: Grand opera does not come easily to American composers. They walk different streets from Verdi and Wagner and whistle different tunes. American opera is about a whole new set of people. The stories set in motion are not the same as European ones and need new shapes to fit them in. Conformity to old models has produced long streams of numbing competence in this country, but a few Americans have bent the model, or else dismembered it altogether.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OKUN, LEO
description: OKUN--Leo, 87. Died peacefully surrounded by his family on October 20, 2003. Husband of the late Eleanor. Beloved by his children Phyllis, Walter, Sharon, Marci, grandchildren Jared, Todd, Adam, Marney and siblings Harold, Arthur, Sybil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, FRANK
description: KLEIN--Frank. Died October 16, 2003, age 95. Beloved father of Richard Klein and Susan Bloom, grandfather of Deborah Klein, David Klein, Joanna Josephson and Erica Bloom, father-in-law of Beth Klein and Mark Bloom. Contributions may be made to UJAFederation.

title: NEW DVD's; Virus-Mad Zombies in London (Choose Your Ending)
description: Rage rules England, but how will it end? Indiana Jones runs into his dad, and the Douglases have their own family movie. South Africa moves to the freedom beat, and gay Jews face their own struggle.

title: Letters
description: Gearing Up for Flu Season

title: In Mongolia, a Tilt Toward a Free Market
description: Mongolia, once a remote Soviet satellite, is rapidly becoming a country hailed by investors for its openness to foreign capital and ideas -- not to mention its proximity to Asia's big play, China.

title: 2 Sides Sharply Split on How Israelis Killed 7 at Gaza Camp
description: NUSSEIRAT REFUGEE CAMP, Gaza Strip, Oct. 21  It is not unusual for Israelis and Palestinians to have opposing versions of reality. But it is unusual for both sides to display the kind of concrete, if conflicting, evidence that they presented today for the violence that convulsed these streets on Monday night.

title: Here You Can't Tell the Future From a Hole in the Ground
description: Frank Jezycki has seen the future of the subway.

title: INTERNATIONAL EDUCATION: Expulsions over veil intensify French debate on secularity
description: PARIS  When Lila Levy-Omari, 18, and her sister Alma, 16, were expelled from their public school earlier this month for refusing to remove the hijab, their Islamic headscarves, the story made headlines across France. The newspaper Le Monde even launched a three-day investigation into the "scarf that divides French society."

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 338 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: THE HAGUE: TOP SERBIAN OFFICERS INDICTED The United Nations war crimes tribunal has indicted four top officers of the Serbian Army and police force, including two ex-generals and the current police chief, for a campaign of terror against ethnic Albanians in the Kosovo war. The four were identified as former Chief of Staff Nebojsa Pavkovic; a former army commander, Vladimir Lazarevic; a former chief of police, Vlastimir Djordjevic; and the current head of the police, Sreten Lukic. The tribunal said they had cooperated in actions that resulted in the forced deportation of about 800,000 Kosovo Albanians. None of the accused have been arrested so far.

title: New Chief at Physics Lab Tries to Polish Faded Star
description: When Dr. Praveen Chaudhari was appointed director of the Brookhaven National Laboratory last winter, he took over a vast research organization that was at once distinguished and troubled.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Mount Laurel: Grandmother Charged
description: A woman whose 22-month-old grandson died when her sport utility vehicle caught fire surrendered to the police yesterday and was charged with child endangerment. She had waited 10 minutes to tell anyone that the boy was trapped inside, the authorities said. The toddler, Michael Malinowski, was pronounced dead at the scene. The Burlington County prosecutor said the woman, Pamela Dreadin, 41, was driving a Ford Bronco early Sunday when her car's engine caught fire. She ran to a nearby house, where she called 911, the authorities said. Prosecutors said she did not tell a 911 operator about her grandson. When rescue workers arrived about 10 minutes later, she mentioned the child. Ms. Dreadin's attorney did not return a call. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: A New Kind of Genomics, With an Eye on Ecosystems
description: Determining the complete DNA sequence of a single species has become almost commonplace. It has been done for humans, mice, rice plants and a host of microbes, among others. Now some scientists are moving to a more audacious challenge, sequencing ''metagenomes,'' the DNA of entire ecosystems.

title: Indicators Fall For First Time In 6 Months
description: The index of leading economic indicators fell in September for the first time in six months, a private research group said yesterday.

title: Signs of Progress in Ulster Are Dashed by Leading Protestant
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 21  The Irish Republican Army said today that it had dismantled a portion of its arsenal and planned to retire still more of it, and the British government scheduled elections to the Northern Ireland Assembly that it had postponed because of doubts about the I.R.A.'s resolve to disarm.

title: Equine Encephalitis Diagnosed in 2-Year-Old New Jersey Girl
description: TRENTON, Oct. 21  Equine encephalitis has been diagnosed in a 2-year-old girl in Burlington County, state officials said today, the first time in nearly 20 years that the dangerous, mosquito-borne disease has afflicted a person in New Jersey.

title: Treasury Chief Sees a Jobs Boom, But Most Don't
description: Expressing a confidence that goes well beyond the projections of many economists, Treasury Secretary John W. Snow has predicted that the American economy will add two million new jobs before next year's elections.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Foodmaker Trims Outlook
description: Unilever, the maker of Knorr soups and Lipton tea, cut its full-year sales forecast for the second time in four months as consumers bought fewer frozen meals and Slim-Fast shakes. The company expects sales of its 400 top brands to grow less than 3 percent, down from a previous forecast of at least 4 percent, a spokesman, Tom Gordijn, said. Unilever forecast in May that its sales would grow 5 to 6 percent. The heat wave in Europe hurt sales of frozen meals and leaf tea, and sales of Slim-Fast fell as dieters turned to competitive products.

title: Compromise Calls for U.S. to Guarantee Medicare Drug Benefit
description: House and Senate negotiators said on Monday that they had reached a tentative agreement on one of the most important issues in the Medicare bill. Under the agreement, the government would guarantee the availability of prescription drug benefits in any market where private insurers failed to do so.

title: Amex Sale to Be Discussed With Other Possible Buyers
description: The parent organization of the American Stock Exchange has decided to discuss a sale with more possible buyers -- including the members of the exchange -- because talks to sell it to a leveraged buyout firm have made no progress.

title: U.S. Believes Syrian Banks Hold $3 Billion In Iraqi Funds
description: American investigators have evidence that $3 billion that belonged to Saddam Hussein's government is being held in Syrian-controlled banks in Syria and Lebanon, Bush administration officials say.

title: Equine Encephalitis Diagnosed in 2-Year-Old New Jersey Girl
description: TRENTON, Oct. 21  Equine encephalitis has been diagnosed in a 2-year-old girl in Burlington County, state officials said today, the first time in nearly 20 years that the dangerous, mosquito-borne disease has afflicted a person in New Jersey.

title: Treatment for Addiction Meets Barriers in the Doctor's Office
description: While progress has been made in combating alcoholism and drug addiction in the United States, the medical establishment is still failing in large numbers to diagnose the disease in their patients, several experts said at a recent conference.

title: 11 DEAD, 90 HURT
description: Israeli warplanes and helicopter gunships struck Gaza five times Monday, killing at least 11 people and wounding more than 90, Palestinian hospital authorities said, as Prime Minister Ariel Sharon affirmed Israel's threat to remove Yasir Arafat.

title: College Student Is Charged With Hiding Hazards on Jets
description: A 20-year-old college junior and ham radio buff was charged on Monday with breaching airport security after having alerted the authorities that he had hidden box cutters, bleach and matches on two airliners.

title: Sony to Cut 10% of Work Force Worldwide, Newspaper Says
description: Sony will cut 10 percent of its global work force and overhaul its television division as part of a plan to increase profitability, according to a report published on Monday in Japan's largest business daily.

title: Series Ratings Up 8.5 Percent
description: Though ratings and viewership for the Yankees-Marlins World Series on Fox are higher than for last year's Series, they are still well below the stellar figures reached during the seventh games of this season's National and American League Championship Series.

title: A Hope for the Prostate Among the Rattlesnakes
description: On vacant lots and deep in swamps, beside the roads and scattered through cow pastures -- practically everywhere in the Deep South -- grows a wild berry that offers hope of relief to millions of men.

title: Seattle's Transit District Buys 235 Hybrid Buses
description: King County, Wash., which includes Seattle, plans to buy 235 diesel hybrid buses for its transit system, one of the largest orders for city buses with hybrid technology.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Brain Conditions 'Ideal' for Separating Twins, Doctors Say
description: Eighteen-month-old Filipino twins joined at the head underwent the first in a series of operations yesterday expected to end with their separation several months from now at a hospital in the Bronx.

title: Study Begins On Pollutants In Passaic River
description: Federal and New Jersey officials said yesterday that they had embarked on a $19 million partnership to study pollution in a heavily industrialized section of the lower Passaic River.

title: Microsoft decides this upgrade of Office merits five times the promotional budget of the last one.
description: THERE is marketing muscle and then there is Microsoft. After all, what other company would spend five times as much to promote a product upgrade as it did on an upgrade just two years before?

title: Opening Arguments in Triple-Murder Trial Center on Defendant's Mindset on Fateful Day
description: After breaking into a Lower East Side apartment building last year and shooting three people dead, Steven Santos stole from them, drank some whiskey, watched sex videos and then calmly climbed down a fire escape and walked away, a prosecutor said yesterday as Mr. Santos's trial got under way.

title: Ethics 101: A Course About the Pitfalls
description: To the uninitiated, ethics in science can sound as straightforward as the West Point honor code: a cadet will not lie, cheat, steal or tolerate those who do. Just substitute ''scientist'' for ''cadet,'' and that should be it.

title: Legal Analysis; Rights, and Wrongs
description: The Supreme Court held in 1975 that criminal defendants have an essentially absolute constitutional right to represent themselves, so long as they make the choice ''voluntarily and intelligently.''

title: A Break for E and V Riders At 53rd and Lexington Station
description: Queens-bound E and V trains stopped during the morning rush yesterday at the 53rd Street and Lexington Avenue station in Manhattan for the first time since a $59 million station rehabilitation project began in November 2002.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Stronger Yen Urged
description: Japan should stop deliberately weakening its currency and permit it to rise, John M. Devine, the vice chairman and chief financial officer of General Motors, said. By buying dollars to weaken the yen, Japan is making it easier for its auto parts makers and car assemblers to export goods to the United States, he said. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINARICK, GLORIA
description: WINARICK--Gloria. Good night, Sweet Princess, good night. There will never be another you. Annie (Coo) Ettinger

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERKIN, RICHARD
description: PERKIN--Richard. NewYork Weill Cornell Medical Center mourns the loss of its esteemed Weill Cornell Council member, Richard Perkin. We will miss his friendship and his commitment to the advancement of medical research. We extend our deepest condolences to his family.

title: U.S. Reaches Deal To Limit Transfers Of Portable Missiles
description: The United States has won agreement from governments across Asia and the Pacific Rim to sharply restrict the use and transfer of shoulder-fired missiles that could be used by Al Qaeda and other terrorist groups to shoot down passenger planes, senior Bush administration officials said Monday.

title: Halloween, for Skinnier Skeletons
description: Trick-or-treaters can be satisfied with something other than candy, say researchers who conducted an experiment last Halloween that arose from concern about the nation's obesity epidemic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERLMUTTER, AL
description: PERLMUTTER -- Al. The Merrick Jewish Centre mourns the passing of our dear member Al Perlmutter and extends heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Eve and family. We pray that they will be consoled with all the mourners of our people. Linda Altman, President Rabbi Charles A. Klein

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about two men who were asked to leave a church choir after they were married in Canada misstated the headquarters location of the newspaper that first reported the matter, The Journal News. It is based in White Plains; it circulates an edition in Rockland County.

title: John Podesta
description: The chief of staff to former President Bill Clinton answered readers' questions about his new Center for American Progress.

title: Trying Diplomacy on North Korea
description: President Bush is now taking a wiser and more sophisticated approach to the crisis caused by North Korea's reckless pursuit of nuclear weapons. In a proposal whose details are still being refined, Washington and four other nations would guarantee not to attack the North in exchange for its commitment to dismantle its nuclear weapons programs.

Adoring grandmother of Jared, Bari, Jason, Samuel, Matthew, Kiel, great-grandchild Jolie; and her brothers Nathan and Harry Langburt.

description: An interview of the Staten Island ferry captain whose vessel crashed into a pier last Wednesday, killing 10 people and injuring scores more, will not go forward today as planned, a lawyer for the captain said last night.

Bloomberg's proposals to change the City Charter take precedence over all other local ballot questions, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

title: Triangles Are Rampant In Rarity by Shakespeare
description: Attributed to Shakespeare and John Fletcher, ''The Two Noble Kinsmen'' contains, as Harold Bloom has said with the roll of a historical drum, ''the final writing of any sort by the author of 'Hamlet' and 'King Lear.' '' But the play is so infrequently presented that even Mr. Bloom has never seen it onstage. Of course, in ''Shakespeare: The Invention of the Human'' he goes on to confess that he doesn't ''especially want to, since Shakespeare's contributions to the play are scarcely dramatic.''

title: Parcells Sees Blemishes in Cowboys' 5-1 Record
description: Twenty-four hours after the Dallas Cowboys' most lopsided victory in three years, Bill Parcells instructed his players to find a place on the sideline for a drill that can bring tears to a grown man's eyes, or at least shortness of breath to his lungs.

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; Yankees' Chill After Game 1 Has Melted Away
description: Shivering at Yankee Stadium, his hands tucked deep into the pockets of his tan overcoat, Brian Cashman was thinking and preaching optimism before the Yankees played the Florida Marlins in the second game of the World Series on Sunday night. He had no choice.

title: Long-Term Questions Linger In Halted Breast Cancer Trial
description: Recently, scientists made the startling decision to halt a large multinational clinical trial that was testing a new drug regimen for breast cancer. The five-year trial was stopped after just two and a half years when results showed that the study drug cut the yearly rate of breast cancer recurrence by nearly half.

title: Gearing Up for Flu Season
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Details Effects Of Long-Term Sleep Pill
description: A newly published study has shown that a sleeping pill can be used effectively for at least six months, a finding some specialists said could lead to broader use of drugs for insomnia.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Bank One And EBay Settle Patent Suits
description: EBay Inc., the world's largest Web auctioneer, and the Bank One Corporation settled lawsuits asserting each other had infringed on patents for conducting financial transactions over the Internet. Bank One sued eBay on Sept. 6, contending patent infringement. EBay's PayPal unit sued Bank One on Sept. 29, claiming its online bill-payment system was being wrongly used. The suits were filed in federal court in Wilmington, Del.

title: Argentina and Brazil Align To Fight U.S. Trade Policy
description: A left-leaning statement of intent signed in Buenos Aires last week by the presidents of Argentina and Brazil might have been short on economic specifics, but it did send a clear message: the South American neighbors will resist efforts by the United States to undermine their unity in regional and global trade talks.

Loving nephew of Catherine Flannery and sister Annie Flannery. Also survived by nieces and nephews. Former employee of Cahill, Gordon & Reindel law firm. title: Oklahoma Is No. 1, for Now, in B.C.S. Ranking
description: For the third straight season, Oklahoma is No. 1 in the initial Bowl Championship Series standing, which was released yesterday, mirroring its status as the nation's top-ranked team in the Associated Press news media poll and in the USA Today/ESPN coaches poll.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: SAUDI ARABIA: SUSPECTED MILITANTS HELD The police said they had arrested Islamic militants and seized large amounts of weapons and explosives, including bomb belts used by suicide bombers. State television showed C-4 plastic explosives, homemade pipe bombs, assault rifles and ammunition belonging to what it called terrorist cells seized in raids in Riyadh, the capital, Jidda and four other locations. An Interior Ministry statement did not specify how many arrests had been made.    (Reuters)

title: After Many Flaws Are Detailed, Plum Island Security Is Stressed
description: After a federal investigation of the Plum Island Animal Disease Center detailed numerous security flaws on the island, the center's acting director said yesterday that the government's evaluation was fair and that the center was already addressing safety concerns.

title: 14-Year-Old Killed in Stunt Atop a Subway Train
description: A 14-year-old Harlem boy trying to impress his friends by climbing on top of a moving subway train was killed yesterday afternoon when he hit a steel girder, fell on the tracks and was struck by another train between the West Fourth Street and 14th Street stations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, LEO
description: SIMON--Leo. Of Boca Raton, FL, passed away peacefully surrounded by his family on October 19. Formerly of the Lower East Side and Queens, NY. Honest Leo was 87 and began his career driving a truck when he was 13 years old. He was the owner of Simon Haulage, a self made man and entrepreneur. Leo was preceded in death by his beloved wife Frieda Simon. He was widely adored and was greatly loved by his family, Marilyn and Alan Rothstein of Avon, CT, Sandra and Kenny Klein of East Meadow, NY, Debra Simon and Jay Johnson of Durham, NC, as well as his wonderful companion Doris Barkan and his sister Rebecca Horbund. Honest Leo was the loving Poppy of Sharyn and Marisa Rothstein. Funeral services Tuesday, October 21, 11:30 am, at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162 - 05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY. Interment to follow at Mt. Moriah Cemetery in Fairview, NJ.

description: ''Hearing Gesture: How Our Hands Help Us Think,'' by Susan Goldin-Meadow. Belknap Press, $29.95.

description: ''We're all courteous to each other. We shake each other's hands. But you can't say we trust each other yet. We are in a period of cold war.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHARFMAN, CARL W.
description: SHARFMAN--Carl W., age 91, formerly of Chicago, late of Hollywood & Plantation, FL, on October 10, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Lillian Wernick Sharfman. Loving father of Ruth Sharfman & Lois Nyren, & father-in-law of Neil Nyren. Cherished grandfather of Alexander Nyren. Former president of Congregation Ezras Israel, Chicago, IL. Funeral and burial services were held in Chicago.

title: INTERNATIONAL EDUCATION: China seeks ways to nurture creativity
description: BEIJING  For as long as it has basked in the glory of its ancient scholarly traditions, China has grappled with the widespread perception that it lacks the capacity for academic originality, and excels only at imitation rather than innovation.

title: Court Refuses Case on a Presidential Pardon
description: The Supreme Court sidestepped a chance on Monday to define the benefits of a presidential pardon. The justices refused to hear an appeal by a former prominent member of the bar here who argued that because his bribery conviction automatically led to his disbarment in 1983, his pardon by President Bill Clinton should also lead automatically to reinstatement.

title: Flaw Is Found In Plan to Bury Nuclear Waste
description: The Energy Department's design for burying nuclear waste at Yucca Mountain, near Las Vegas, would cause corrosion that would perforate the waste containers and allow leaks, an expert panel is preparing to advise the department.

title: Studios Are Killing (Bloodily but Carefully) for an R Rating
description: The color red is making a spectacular showing this fall, at least at the box office. Two violent and blood-soaked films, ''The Texas Chainsaw Massacre,'' a remake of the 1974 slasher film, and Quentin Tarantino's ''Kill Bill: Vol. 1,'' attracted the most moviegoers to theaters last weekend. Both are rated R, and both are illustrations of the lengths to which filmmakers will go to garner that more audience-friendly designation.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: The Great Pretender

title: Public Universities Tuition Rises by 14 Percent
description: Offsetting state budget cuts, tuition at public universities rose 14 percent to an average of $4,694 this year, the steepest increase in more than a quarter century, according to the latest annual survey by the College Board.

title: Continuing the Search For Kinder Executions
description: In Tennessee, it is a crime to euthanize a cat with pancuronium bromide, but this doesn't stop the state from using it to execute condemned criminals. Because the drug paralyzes muscles but does not affect nerves, it may leave its victims wide awake but immobilized as they painfully suffocate. So prisoners' advocates and medical experts are now trying to persuade Tennessee -- and the nearly 30 other states that use the drug -- to choose different poisons for lethal injection, thereby bringing euthanasia protocols for humans in line with those for domestic animals.

title: Next Hartford Archbishop Cites Need for New Priests
description: Bishop Henry J. Mansell, who was introduced as the next archbishop of Hartford, said on Monday that the most pressing issues he expected to face were the continuing challenge of attracting new priests and dealing with the fallout from the sexual abuse scandals of recent years.

title: The Knicks Are Still Jelling
description: Chemistry, identity and injury fly like buzzwords over the Knicks.

title: In Thorough Physicals, Athletes Must Perform
description: As many sports participants know from bitter experience, there is a risk of injury and, sometimes, serious injury associated with most vigorous activities, even running and swimming.

title: Credit Counseling
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Legislature Enters Feeding Dispute
description: Almost a week after the feeding tube of a brain-damaged woman was removed, the State House of Representatives passed a bill that would allow the governor to issue a ''one-time stay in certain cases'' involving the starvation of people in vegetative states. The vote was 68 to 23. Leaders of the Republican-controlled State Senate said their chamber would vote on the bill on Tuesday. The Senate president, James King, indicated earlier in the day that he would reluctantly support it. The woman, Terri Schiavo, can breathe on her own but had relied on the feeding tube since she suffered brain damage in 1990. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Pinstripes Amid Teal In Miami
description: With the Yankees and the Florida Marlins in the World Series, Merrill Lamb has been quizzed regularly since last weekend about which team he is rooting for. Lamb, who is a consultant, has lived here for 40 years, but he has not forgotten that he grew in the shadow of Yankee Stadium.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Science Times last Tuesday with a profile of Dr. Michael J. Ryan, a University of Texas biologist who challenges widely held views of evolution, carried an incorrect credit. The photographer was Frank Curry.

title: Army Investigates Treatment of Ill Iraq Veterans
description: The Army is investigating complaints that hundreds of sick and wounded soldiers who just returned from Iraq are languishing in crudely furnished barracks without proper medical care at the Fort Stewart military base, army officials disclosed on Monday.

title: Powell to Visit Kenya to Urge Success at Sudan Peace Talks
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell is to travel to Kenya on Tuesday to provide encouragement at talks to end the long-running civil war in Sudan, the State Department said Monday.

title: In Defense of Electroshock
description: ''Electroshock: Healing Mental Illness,'' by Dr. Max Fink. Oxford University Press, $12.95.

title: Off-Track on the Tenure Track
description: The real-world quandaries in Dr. Francis L. Macrina's course in scientific ethics at Virginia Commonwealth University have no ready answers. So Science Times posed one of them to Randy Cohen, who writes the Ethicist column in The New York Times Magazine. The question is adapted from Dr. Macrina's textbook ''Scientific Integrity'' (ASM Press, 2000).

title: Two-Sport Turf
description: As of next season, Pro Player Stadium and Network Associates Coliseum will be the only remaining grass fields to serve as the home to a major league team and an N.F.L. team. The Dolphins played the New England Patriots here on Sunday, and the football lines could be seen faintly on the grass on Monday.

title: A New Auditorium With Larger Goals
description: Los Angeles, a city of suburbs in search of a center, on Monday came one step closer to finding one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NICHOLS, FRED JOSEPH
description: NICHOLS--Fred Joseph. The Graduate Center community is saddened by the passing of Professor Emeritus Fred Nichols, a devoted teacher and dedicated scholar of the Renaissance and Classical literary tradition. Frances Degen Horowitz, President, The Graduate Center, CUNY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JORDAN, VANCE
description: JORDAN--Vance. 60 years of age died today after a brief illness. He is survived by his sister Jill and two nephews. Services will be private.

title: 3M'S QUARTERLY EARNINGS INCREASE 22 PERCENT
description: The 3M Company, the maker of Scotch tape, medical inhalers and thousands of other products, said yesterday that its earnings for the third quarter increased 22 percent, to $663 million, or 83 cents a share, from $545 million, or 69 cents, in the period a year earlier. 3M was expected to earn 79 cents in the quarter. 3M, based in St. Paul, also raised its 2003 profit forecast because of lower costs and higher sales. Sales rose 11 percent, to $4.62 billion. The company raised its 2003 forecast for net income to $2.98 to $3 a share, from $2.88 to $2.95. Profit before some costs will be $3.05 to $3.07, up from an earlier range of $2.95 to $3.02. 3M had net income of $2.50 a share in 2002. Sales in the third quarter of last year were $4.14 billion.

title: From Cosmos to Hall of Fame
description: When Steven J. Ross, the chief executive of Warner Communications, was desperate to retain the music executive Nesuhi Ertegun in 1971, stock options and corporate largess were not on the table.

title: Airlines Race to Provide More Luxury and Comfort
description: SOMEWHERE up there, people are living high. And I don't just mean on the Concorde, which pierces the stratosphere and is due to make its last trip this week when British Airways retires the supersonic fleet. (Air France retired its Concordes in May.)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about opposition to President Bush's latest judicial nomination referred incorrectly to Janice Rogers Brown, his choice for the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. If confirmed, she would be the second black woman on that court. (Judge Judith W. Rogers, who has served for 10 years, was the first.)

title: Panel Endorses U.S. Exemption On Ozone Pact
description: An international panel of experts has approved the Bush administration's request for broad exemptions to a ban on methyl bromide, a pesticide that is popular with agricultural businesses but damages Earth's protective ozone layer.

title: Prediction for Spring: Plenty of Color, Fullness to Match
description: By the time the twice-a-year collections wrap up, anyone whose livelihood depends on attending the hundreds of shows that take place across four countries in three weeks returns home primarily wanting to take a long nap. This is a wish not easily granted. Almost immediately upon arrival, such an individual is typically bombarded with questions from friends, mothers, neighbors and dentists who resoundingly want to know: ''What is the look of next season? What, please tell me, will I wear?''

title: Ivan Getting, 91, a Developer Of Global Positioning System
description: Dr. Ivan Getting, a major force behind the development of the Global Positioning System, the network of satellites that pinpoint locations on Earth within a range of feet, died on Oct. 11 at his home in Coronado, Calif. He was 91.

In Loving Memory, Everett and Winifred Farrell Ungemach & family.

description: President Bush told Malaysia's pugnacious prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, on Monday that he was ''wrong and divisive'' when he declared last week that Jews ran the world by proxy.

description: Vance Jordan, a leading dealer in American art and a pioneer in promoting the American Arts and Crafts Movement, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 60 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEILER, LORE E.
description: FEILER--Lore E. On October 19, 2003, of Haworth, NJ (formerly of West New York), beloved daughter of the late William, and the late Karline Feiler. Lore is survived by nieces, nephews, and many friends. The Rev. Gregory P. Fryer will officiate at services Wednesday 8:30 P.M. at The Frech Funeral Home, 161 Washington Ave., Dumont, NJ. Entombment private. Visiting will be on Wednesday 79 P.M. and Lore requested those who wish may make memorial gifts to The New York Emanuel Lutheran Church, 122 East 88th Street, New York, New York 10128.

title: Snails, Desired for Beauty and Venom, May Be Threatened
description: For centuries, cone snails have been objects of desire, their intricately patterned shells valued by collectors. More recently, the carnivorous snails have become prized for something else: their potent mix of toxins, which biomedical researchers say hold promise in drug discovery and medical treatment.

title: N.F.L. Network Will Not Carry Games
description: The head of the N.F.L. Network, which will make its debut on Nov. 4, said yesterday that he did not expect the channel to carry regular-season or playoff games during the league's next round of network contracts. The league has deals with CBS, Fox, ABC and ESPN through the 2005 season.

description: In percent

description: Norway has revolutionized a woman's right to breast-feed.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Call For Independent Fire Inquiry
description: The Cook County public guardian, Patrick Murphy, urged an independent investigation of a fire in a county building that killed six people on Friday, including three employees from his office. He said city or county officials would not be critical of their own departments and had ties to the building managers. Mr. Murphy called Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich a ''politician in search of a backbone'' for not pushing for an independent investigation. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: It Swallowed a Civilization
description: For decades, scholars have debated whether the eruption of the Thera volcano in the Aegean more than 3,000 years ago brought about the mysterious collapse of Minoan civilization at the peak of its glory. The volcanic isle (whose remnants are known as Santorini) lay just 70 miles from Minoan Crete, so it seemed quite reasonable that its fury could have accounted for the fall of that celebrated people.

description: US Airways said its pilots' pension plan was terminally ill earlier this year, but now the airline is changing the prognosis, in hopes of saving money.

description: Though the writing on the wall is still faint, to Nobuhiko Narita it is unmistakable: Toyota City and its 350,000 residents are on a collision course with industrial inevitability.

description: ELIZABETH COSTELLO

title: Rescuing The Democrats
description: In the current issue of The Weekly Standard, Fred Barnes argues that we have seen the birth of a Republican majority. In 1992, Barnes points out, Republicans held 176 House seats. Today, they hold 229. In 1992, the G.O.P. controlled 8 state legislatures; now it controls 21. In 1992, there were 18 Republican governors; now there are 27.

title: Grant Aims at More Healthful Crops
description: For about a decade, a project called HarvestPlus has been promoting an idea for fighting malnutrition in the third world: develop crops with higher levels of vitamins and minerals. Now HarvestPlus will get a chance to put its plan into action. It received a $25 million grant last week from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation giving it the money to jump-start its effort.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft To Upgrade Office
description: Microsoft plans today to start selling enhanced versions of its Office programs that link with the company's databases and network software in an effort to fend off competition from Linux software and the Oracle Corporation. Microsoft is upgrading Office for the first time in two years after the product had the slowest average sales growth rate among the company's three largest units in the last three years. Office, which includes word processing, spreadsheet and e-mail programs, accounted for more than half of Microsoft's operating income last year. Investors expect only a modest sales increase from the new programs. Bigger gains may come later, from sales of related products like Windows and SQL database software. Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash., has now connected those programs to Office to help fuel sales by getting companies to create more-complex programs based on Office. Microsoft shares rose 42 cents, to $29.35.

title: Mourning Prepares to Meet the Knicks
description: Alonzo Mourning is still finding his way, learning the inner workings of the Nets and acclimating himself to the peripherals, such as who the hated rivals are. He spent nearly a decade warring with the Knicks as a member of the Charlotte Hornets and the Miami Heat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENWALD, RAYMOND J.
description: GREENWALD--Raymond J. On October 18, 2003 at age 81. Ray left a beloved wife, Pearl, nephew James Kaye and his wife Meryl, his adored ''grandchildren'' Marissa, Mathew and Sarah Kaye, and loving cousins. Son of the late Samuel and Anne Greenwald, brother of the late Muriel Kaye. A life long resident of Manhattan and successful real estate entrepreneur whose fairness and humanity earned the respect and affection of colleagues, employees, tenants and everyone he met, and earned as well the devotion and friendship of his long-time assistant, Blanche Christian-Crawford. After WWII, when he served in the South Pacific as an Army Air Force Captain, he studied acting and directing before entering the real estate business, and becoming an owner of commercial real estate. He co-produced many Broadway and Off Broadway shows, most recently ''Enchanted April''. His intelligence, humor and generosity, even in illness will remain in the memory of all who knew him. Services Tuesday, October 21, 1 PM, at ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Shiva at his home Tuesday, 6-9 PM and Wednesday, 11 AM-9 PM.

title: Boat Carrying African Immigrants Reaches Italy With 13 Dead
description: Italian authorities reported Monday that at least 13 people died in a small wooden boat adrift in the Mediterranean trying to reach this country from North Africa. A rescuer described the 40-foot vessel carrying the dead and 15 survivors as resembling ''a scene from Dante's Inferno.''

title: Bush Gets Asian Trade Group to Join Terror and Proliferation Fights
description: SINGAPORE, Oct. 21  President Bush persuaded Asia's largest economic group today to adopt a series of commitments to crack down on terrorism and the proliferation of nuclear weapons, and to expand its authority beyond trade.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the Grocery, a Brooklyn restaurant where the food was rated seventh best in New York by the 2004 Zagat Survey, referred imprecisely to its alcohol policy. While it does not serve liquor, wine and beer are available.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   INKELES, FAY
description: INKELES--Fay. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Loving mother of Lila and Richard Holland and David and Margery Inkeles. Cherished grandmother of Leslie and Adam Holland and Charles, Barbara, John, and Laura Inkeles. Beloved great-grandmother of Zoe Holland. Services were held Monday, October 20th. Contributions in her memory to Women's League for Israel, 160 E 56th St, NY NY 10022 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZIRINSKY, NANCY S.
description: ZIRINSKY--Nancy S. On October 20, 2003 in Ann Arbor, MI at the age of 53. Treasured daughter of Helen and the late Lawrence. Beloved sister of John and Bill and the late Jane. Dear sister-in-law of Olga and Ruth and brother-inlaw the late Chuck. Cherished aunt of Sara, Hanna, Samuel, Jacob, Juliana and Leela. Services at Frank Campbell Funeral Home.

title: Boston Police Want Two Yankees Charged
description: The Boston police will seek assault and battery charges on Tuesday against the Yankees' Jeff Nelson and Karim Garcia, who were involved in a bullpen fight at Fenway Park during Game 3 of the American League Championship Series.

title: Abuse Settlement Is Approved, Lawyers Say
description: Lawyers for 552 people who accused Roman Catholic priests of sexual abuse say they have obtained the approval of 80 percent of plaintiffs necessary for a record-setting $85 million settlement with the Archdiocese of Boston to go into effect.

title: GOLDMAN SACHS TO BUY COGENTRIX FOR $115 MILLION
description: The Goldman, Sachs Group has agreed to pay $115 million for an electricity producer, Cogentrix Energy Inc., to augment its power-trading business. A spokesman for Goldman, Bruce Corwin, said the company would assume $2.3 billion in debt. The closely held Cogentrix, based in Charlotte, N.C., owns 26 power plants in 14 states and the Dominican Republic. The transaction is expected to close early next year.

title: Yearly Pap Tests? Not Necessarily
description: A study published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine lends new weight to the idea that many women can safely switch from annual Pap tests to one every three years.

title: Conflicting Views on Iraq's Oil
description: How well is the Iraqi oil industry faring? It depends on whom you listen to: the Iraqi oil ministry, or the Iraqi oil ministry.

title: Dallas Acquires Antoine Walker, Adding Even More Scoring Punch
description: From Run-TMC in Golden State to the Dirk Nowitzki/Steve Nash/Michael Finley/ Nick Van Exel show in Dallas, Coach Don Nelson has consistently put together some of the most exciting teams in the National Basketball Association. But now Nelson has outdone even himself, securing a lineup of go-to guys that seems capable of scoring 120 points a game.

title: Zeffirelli's 'Bohme': Any Complaints?
description: There was not much news made on Saturday afternoon when the Metropolitan Opera once again brought back Franco Zeffirelli's 1981 production of Puccini's ''Bohme.'' This grandly scaled and scrupulously realistic production has long been knocked by many critics and opera buffs. But it's inarguably a colorful and animated show and, judging by the reaction to this performance, Met audiences continue to adore it.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a news analysis article in Business Day yesterday about the trial of Frank P. Quattrone, the former star technology banker, misstated the day on which the judge instructed the jurors. It was Wednesday, not Friday.

title: Grumbling Trickles Down From Reagan Biopic; Some See Peril to Presidential Legacy From TV Movie Coming Next Month
description: When it comes to their entertainment shows, the major broadcast networks tend to shy away from political controversy, lest they offend viewers, sponsors or congressmen with sway over federal regulators.

title: Shop of Horrors
description: Anyone looking closely at the $20.3 billion Iraqi reconstruction package that the Bush administration sent to Congress may have been surprised by an item near the end with a comparatively modest price tag: a museum of Baathist crimes, $1 million. What was this doing on a list that included police training and the rebuilding of infrastructure?

title: A Traveler Showing Students a Different Path
description: THE bulletin boards at the Bronx Academy of Letters are neither especially cheery nor a quick study. Neither is Joan Sullivan, the principal and a founder of this new, four-room public high school in the South Bronx. But like her, the boards pique curiosity, challenge one to think and lead to the unexpected.

title: Musical Rebels Enlist Filmmakers
description: When the composers Michael Gordon, David Lang and Julia Wolfe founded the Bang on a Can collective 16 years ago, they wanted to turn classical music upside down: casual dress onstage, audiences that come and go during a performance, and music that throbs with the pulse of rock.

title: Disappointing Results for AT&T and SBC Communications
description: Reflecting continued turmoil in the troubled telecommunications industry, two giant telephone companies reported third quarter-earnings today that disappointed investors.
