title: Generals Statements on Islam to Be Investigated
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that he had agreed to a request by one of his top Pentagon officials for a review of remarks the official made comparing the war against Islamic militants to a battle of a Christian nation against Satan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TEITELBAUM, MARLA
description: TEITELBAUM -- Marla, 96. Loving mother to Laura and David. Beloved grandmother to Robin, Russ and Mark. Great - grandmother to Chaya. She will be greatly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ISENBERG, MORRIS
description: ISENBERG--Morris, MD, of Forest Hills, NY on October 19, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Frieda (Epstein) for 56 years. Devoted father of Edward, Elliott and Howard. Loving grandfather of Karen Clements and Paula Zuckerman. Great-grandfather of Lauren and Brian Clements and Emma Zuckerman. He worked as a Psychiatrist for 55 years. Services Wednesday, October 22, 2003 at 12 noon from ''Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapel'', 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Earthlink To Sell Web Access In Radioshack Stores
description: EarthLink Inc., the Internet-access provider, said yesterday that it would sell its services in more than 5,000 RadioShack stores as it tried to stem a loss of customers to phone and cable-television companies. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. EarthLink's high-speed Internet services are available in RadioShack stores, an EarthLink spokesman, David Blumenthal, said. Dial-up services will go on sale in the next two weeks, he said. EarthLink is losing customers for its regular or ''dial-up'' Web access service, as subscribers switch to high-speed services from phone and cable companies that offer faster downloads, analysts have said. EarthLink shares rose 19 cents, to $7.52. RadioShack rose 86 cents, to $30.56.

title: Net Income Rose 20% At Citigroup In 3rd Quarter
description: Citigroup reported a 20 percent gain in third-quarter profit yesterday as the company was able to set aside less money for potential loan losses.

title: Kerry Environmental Plan
description: Senator John Kerry, who bills himself as the strongest champion of the environment in the Democratic presidential field, issued a six-point plan today calling for ''environmental empowerment zones'' and a ''toxics task force'' to ensure that federal money is spent on the highest-priority cleanup projects.

title: Still Open for Business, at 72
description: In an earlier phase of Jack McKeon's life, when he was an adviser to the Cincinnati Reds in the mid-1990's, baseball's winter meetings had broken up one night and McKeon had an announcement to make.

title: U.S. Is Nearer Tax Credit Decision For Producers of Synthetic Fuel
description: The Internal Revenue Service is moving closer to a decision on how it will allow producers of coal-based synthetic fuel to continue to qualify for tax credits totaling billions of dollars.

title: A Target of Conservatives' Ire, Y.W.C.A. Chief Is Dismissed
description: The feminist leader Patricia Ireland has been dismissed as chief executive of the Y.W.C.A. less than six months after she was hired to head it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLARD, CHARLES E.F.
description: MILLARD--Charles E.F., of Fenwick, Connecticut and Hobe Sound, Florida, former Chairman and CEO, Coca Cola Bottling Co. of NY, former Chairman, Board of Trustees, College of the Holy Cross, former President, NY Urban League, father of eight, grandfather of 24, and husband of the former Marylou Slattery of Brooklyn, died peacefully at home on October 20th, 2003. Founder of Thends and of Fadamiso, Knight of St. Gregory, Knight of Malta. Winner, 1985 Morgan Cup. Survived by Marylou, wife of 49 years; children: Marylou Ferrara, Hopewell Township, NJ; Charles, Rye Brook, NY; Christopher, Atlanta, GA; Maureen, NYC; Margaret McGrath, Fairfield, CT; Suzanne Stanners, Old Saybrook, CT; Kathleen Rehm, Darien, CT; Gregory, Southport, CT. Memorial Mass, Saturday, October 25th, 10:30 AM, St. Pius X Church, Fairfield, CT.; a reception to follow. Donations: Visiting Nurses of the Lower Valley, PO Box 366, 61 Main Street, Centerbrook, CT. 06409.

title: Deficit Doubles but Falls Short of Forecast
description: The federal budget deficit more than doubled to $374 billion in the fiscal year that just ended, but the Bush administration took heart that the shortfall was less than it had predicted a few months ago.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: LEGISLATURE ENTERS FEEDING DISPUTE Almost a week after the feeding tube of a brain-damaged woman was removed, the State House of Representatives passed a bill that would allow the governor to issue a "one-time stay in certain cases" involving the starvation of people in vegetative states. The vote was 68 to 23. Leaders of the Republican-controlled State Senate said their chamber would vote on the bill on Tuesday. The Senate president, James King, indicated earlier in the day that he would reluctantly support it. The woman, Terri Schiavo, can breathe on her own but had relied on the feeding tube since she suffered brain damage in 1990.

title: A.& P. TO SELL EIGHT O'CLOCK COFFEE UNIT FOR $107 MILLION
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, the owner of A.& P. and Food Emporium supermarkets, agreed to sell its Eight O'Clock coffee division for at least $107.5 million to Gryphon Investors to reduce expenses and debt. The agreement calls for Gryphon, a private equity firm in San Francisco,, to pay as much as $20 million more for the unit depending on its performance, A.& P. said. The sale concludes A.& P.'s plan to sell assets to help reduce the company's debt and costs after three years of losses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHERR, WALTER
description: CHERR--Walter. On Sunday October 19, 2003, 74, of Scotch Plains, NJ. Husband of Sallie (nee Coleman). Father of Diane Leslie Cherr-Bachman (Richard) and Peter Cherr. Brother of Dr. Donald Cherr. Grandfather of Kimberlee and Rebecca Bachman. Long time friend of Bill Wilson. Walter was a Graduate of NYU and The Training Program of Cluett Peabody. His gentleness, kindness, loving nature, and wonderful, irrepressible sense of humor will be missed by all. Services will be held at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union, NJ today Tuesday, October 21, 2003 at 3:30 PM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Alina Lodge, Box G, Blairstown, NJ 07825

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Meningitis Shots For Gays
description: Chicago health officials are asking gay and bisexual men on the North Side who have been in close contact with others to be vaccinated for bacterial meningitis after the deaths of three men from the disease in a week. Six gay and bisexual men have been given diagnoses for the disease, an infection of fluid in the spinal chord and fluid surrounding the brain. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Giambi Doesn't Fear Subpoena
description: Yankees first baseman Jason Giambi said he did nothing wrong and was only vaguely aware of the details surrounding his subpoena by a federal grand jury investigating a company that prescribes nutritional supplements for top athletes.

title: With 30 New Cardinals, Church Focuses on Popes Successor
description: VATICAN CITY, Oct. 21  Giving signature red hats to 30 new Roman Catholic cardinals, Pope John Paul II today put what may be the finishing touches on the group of men who will elect his successor.

title: Intelsat's Offer of $1.1 Billion Wins Bidding for Loral Fleet
description: Loral Space and Communications said yesterday that Intelsat had won an auction for its domestic communications satellites with an offer to pay $1.1 billion for the fleet and to place an order for a new satellite from Loral's manufacturing arm. Intelsat will pay an additional $100 million as a down payment for the new satellite.

title: Judge Sentences U.N. Gunman, but Bemoans Federal Limits
description: The postal worker who fired seven shots at the United Nations last year to protest North Korea's treatment of its citizens was sentenced yesterday to two years and three months in prison, fined $6,000 and ordered to pay $1,700 in restitution to the United Nations.

title: A Model City in Nonpartisan Correctness
description: In making a case for nonpartisan elections, the Bloomberg administration has argued that the change in New York City's electoral system would draw more people to the polls, increase the number of minority group members in elective posts and weaken the iron fist of party bosses. Just look at Jacksonville, officials say.

title: Through the Lens, the Severe Beauty of Nuclear Test Blasts
description: These mushroom clouds, rising bug-eyed over the desert, spreading like an alien sun over the ocean, are the nagging headache behind what passed for reality for a generation.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Software Acquisition
description: One of Europe's biggest computer services companies, Cap Gemini Ernst & Young, made an offer to buy a French software maker, Transiciel, for about 244 million euros ($285 million) in new stock to add to its services for small businesses in Europe. Cap Gemini offered one new share for three Transiciel shares, valuing the stock at 12.96 euros ($15.12) a share, a 23 percent premium to Transiciel's average price over the last month, Cap Gemini's chief executive, Paul Hermelin, said at a news conference. Cap Gemini is based in Paris.

title: Comptroller Cancels Deal On Erie Canal
description: The state comptroller on Monday rescinded his office's 2002 approval of a contract granting a developer exclusive access rights to the Erie Canal, saying officials of the state's Canal Corporation had made false, misleading and incomplete statements on the deal.

title: Beckett Lacks Experience, Not Brashness
description: Josh Beckett has never faced the Yankees, and he has never been available to them in trades. But Beckett's reputation has preceded him to Game 3 of the World Series on Tuesday, and the Yankees know what they are up against.

title: An Architect's Plea: Bring Us to the Table
description: To the Editor:

title: Pooh-Bah's Metamorphosis, From Kimono to Top Hat and Tails
description: The last time I wrote about Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Mikado,'' I noted that its ethnicity was less Japanese than British. Jonathan Miller evidently thinks the same way. In his 1986 production for the English National Opera, which came to City Opera in 2001 and which the company brought back on Saturday night (performances continue through Nov. 22), he removed every trace of Japanalia.

title: Granada Journal; Where the Moors Held Sway, Allah Is Praised Again
description: Muslims are back in this ancient Moorish stronghold, the last bastion of Islam in Spain before the 15th-century emir Boabdil kissed King Ferdinand's hand and relinquished the city with a legendary sigh.

title: As Opposed To Numbness, Pain Is Good
description: IF there is a glimmer of hopefulness in the Staten Island ferry disaster, and you have to mine pretty deep to find it, it may be the horror that New Yorkers felt. Repeated pain had not deadened their feelings.

title: POZEN'S MIGRAINE TREATMENT FAILS TO GAIN APPROVAL
description: Pozen Inc., which is seeking federal approval for its first drug, said regulators had rejected the company's migraine treatment because it did not treat some symptoms. The company's shares fell 33 percent. The Food and Drug Administration agreed in a letter that the MT 300 drug helped with pain but did not treat nausea or sensitivity to light, the company said. Agency and company officials plan a meeting to discuss the application, Pozen said. About 28 million Americans get migraines, which may last as long as 72 hours and cause sharp, throbbing pain and other symptoms. MT 300 is an injectable form of a migraine medication that has been used for 50 years, Pozen said. Stock in Pozen fell $5.83, to $11.94 a share.

title: Under Pressure, Iran Agrees to Constraints on Nuclear Program
description: TEHRAN, Oct. 21 - Iran agreed Tuesday, after months of resistance, to accept stricter international inspections of its nuclear sites and to suspend production of enriched uranium, which can be used to develop nuclear weapons.

title: War on Sprawl In New Jersey Hits a Wall
description: Nine months after Gov. James E. McGreevey promised to wage the nation's toughest anti-sprawl campaign in its most crowded state, his bold growth-control proposals are all but in tatters.

title: U.S. Voices Optimism on Foreign Aid for Iraq
description: Senior Pentagon officials said Monday that they would be looking to Persian Gulf states for significant contributions, in the billions of dollars, at a conference of international donors this week.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Indianapolis; Known for Its Speedway, But a Fine Place for a Walk
description: INDIANAPOLIS, best known for its Motor Speedway and Conseco Fieldhouse, also has a healthy convention business, a rapidly expanding life-sciences industry backed by the Roche Diagnostics Corporation and Eli Lilly & Company, and a solid base of manufacturing companies, including Rolls-Royce. It has also experienced a building boom in recent years. ''We term it the little big town, because it has all the conveniences of a major metropolis, but it's easy to walk between areas of entertainment, hotels and restaurants,'' said Ryan Akers, a marketing communications associate at Baxter Pharmaceutical Solutions in Bloomington, Ind., 50 miles away, who commutes to work from his home in Indianapolis.

title: Scientist Fears Athletes Are Using Unsafe Drugs
description: Don Catlin, the scientist who identified a previously undetected steroid and oversaw tests indicating that as many as a half-dozen athletes in track and field had used the drug, said yesterday that he thought athletes were probably using similar unidentified drugs.

title: Judge Rejects Mistrial in Ex-Banker Case
description: The judge in the trial of Frank P. Quattrone, a former star technology banker at Credit Suisse First Boston, denied a request by the defense for a mistrial yesterday after postponing jury deliberations because a juror's wife had gone into labor.

title: Big Board Said to Hire Former U.S. Prosecutor
description: John S. Reed, the interim chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, has hired a former federal prosecutor to investigate governance and compensation policies at the Big Board, a lawyer close to the exchange board said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMONTON, JOHN T., M.D.
description: SIMONTON--John T., M.D. The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary mourns the passing of a distinguished, long-time member of the medical staff, former Surgeon Director and Chairman of the Medical Board. Affiliated with the Infirmary for more than 30 years, ''Sarge'' was a renowned innovator in the field of ophthalmic plastic and reconstructive surgery and a dedicated teacher and surgeon. Our sincerest condolences to the entire family. Joseph B. Walsh, M.D. Chairman, Department of Ophthalmology Thomas O. Muldoon, M.D., Chairman, Medical Board Robert C. Della Rocca, M.D., Chief, Oculoplastic Service

title: Complaints mushroom at airports in Milan and Rome : Where baggage doesn't connect
description: MILAN:  Ask any frequent flier to Italy about travel confusion and be prepared for epic narrations making Ulysses' travels to the peninsula seem like a stroll in the park.

title: Ralph Salerno, a Police Expert on the Mafia, Dies at 78
description: Ralph Francis Salerno, a highly decorated New York City policeman and an authority on organized crime, died last Wednesday in Scranton, Pa. A former resident of Woodside, Queens, he was 78 and had lived in Lake Ariel, Pa., since 1988.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Novartis Posts A Profit
description: The Swiss drug maker Novartis said its third-quarter profit rose 7 percent, helped by sales of the hypertension drug Diovan and the leukemia pill Gleevec. Net income rose to $1.28 billion from $1.19 billion a year earlier. Sales rose 16 percent to $6.21 billion, the company said. Novartis said profit margins would be squeezed by spending to replenish its pipeline of new drugs.

title: Legal Abuses in the Sniper Case
description: It takes nothing away from the horror of the Washington-area sniper attacks last year to say that the government should follow the law in prosecuting the suspects. But the prosecutors have been so intent on getting the death penalty that they have repeatedly bent the law. John Muhammad, whose trial began yesterday, may be guilty of murder, but the prosecutors diminish our justice system when they try to convict him of capital murder, a crime that the facts do not support.

title: Victoria's Secret Reaches A Data Privacy Settlement
description: There's private, and then there's private.

title: Honors
description: Sherry Lansing, chairwoman and chief executive for the Motion Picture Group at Paramount Pictures, Los Angeles, part of Viacom, has received the 2003 Parade All-America Award for Advertising at the 2003 annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers, New York. Parade is the Sunday supplement newspaper owned by Advance Publications. Also at the conference, James J. Garrity, executive vice president and chief marketing officer at the Wachovia Corporation, Charlotte, N.C., was presented the 2003 Robert V. Goldstein Award for his work helping the Advertising Council, New York, with an uncompensated campaign for the US Freedom Corps, a volunteer initiative.

title: Pennington Is Ready, but Testaverde Will Start
description: Concerned about Chad Pennington's stamina and the fear of another injury -- Jets Coach Herman Edwards announced Monday that Vinny Testaverde would start at quarterback Sunday at Philadelphia but that Pennington would play the bulk of the game.

title: Lawmakers Question Review of Discipline For F.B.I. Employees
description: Leading members of Congress from both parties voiced concerns on Monday over an inquiry on the F.B.I.'s system for employee discipline. The lawmakers said the review could be tainted by questions about its independence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICE, MRS. PAULE
description: RICE--Mrs. Paule, 86, died on October 17, 2003 of congestive heart failure. Beloved mother of Danielle Brackett. Service Thursday, October 23, 6 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' Amsterdam and 76th Street.

title: Senate Approves Ban on Abortion Procedure
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21  The Senate on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved the first federal ban on a specific abortion procedure, ending eight years of divisive debate and clearing the way for President Bush to sign the measure into law.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Unemployment Falls
description: As the economy continues to rebound from last spring's outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate dropped to 8.3 percent from July to September. It was 8.6 percent from June to August. The number of jobs declined, but the work force declined faster. The rate of underemployment, people who take part-time jobs because they cannot find full-time work, slipped to 3.6 percent from 4 percent. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Surveying New Territory
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Latest Luxe Sensation: Muscle Cars for the Middle-Aged
description: THIS is not the way he normally conducts a test drive, explains Nicholas DeFelice, a salesman at BMW of the Main Line, a dealership in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. As his passenger, I have already figured this out. Through both side windows, the suburban greensward is a blur as the jet-black M5 sedan rushes along a two-lane back road.

title: Of Kurds and Madrid
description: My old buddies the Kurds, a long-mistreated people we freed from Saddam, are now looking a gift horse in the mouth. I hope somebody explains that American expression about shortsighted suspicion to a key leader, Massoud Barzani.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Political Points column on Sunday about Tim Kraft, the architect of Jimmy Carter's 1976 Iowa campaign who is now helping Howard Dean gather support in that state, misidentified the Democratic candidate who finished fourth in the 1976 Iowa caucuses. He was Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma, not Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona. (''Uncommitted'' won the most votes, followed by Mr. Carter and then Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana.)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Couple Sentenced In Prostitution Case
description: A Suffolk County couple who netted more $1 million from prostitution by advertising their Exotic Escorts agency on the Internet were sentenced to prison. The couple, Ronald and Melissa Grab, also forfeited $1 million in cash that investigators recovered, $700,000 of it found buried in two plastic buckets under the concrete basement floor of a friend's home. Investigators said they learned the details of the operation by posing as prospective buyers of the business. Judge Joseph Farneti of County Court sentenced Mr. Grab, 39, of Brentwood to two and a half to five years for money laundering. Mrs. Grab, 33, was sentenced to nine months for promoting prostitution. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Lindros Expected to Miss Two to Four Weeks
description: The Rangers said yesterday that Eric Lindros, their first-line center, sprained the left side of his chest in their 3-1 victory over the Florida Panthers on Monday night and was expected to miss two to four weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PERROTTA, EDWARD J.
description: PERROTTA--Edward J. Two years after September 11, 2001, we have found the remains of my husband. Please join us in sharing our memories of Edward J. Perrotta. A Visitation will be held on Friday, October 24, 2003, from 25 and 7-10 p.m. at Moloney's Hauppauge Funeral Home, Route 111, Hauppauge, NY, 631-361-7500. A Funeral Mass will be Saturday, October 25, St. Thomas More R.C. Church, Hauppauge, New York. Interment will follow at Queen of All Saints Cemetery, Central Islip, NY.

title: Pope Confirms Cardinals, As Talk Turns to Succession
description: Giving signature red hats to 30 new cardinals, Pope John Paul II on Tuesday put what may be the finishing touches on the group of men who will elect his successor.

title: Corrections
description: A fashion review on Oct. 7 about collections shown in Milan by Cavalli, Dolce & Gabbana and five other designers, misstated the name of one whose offerings included printed shifts peeking out from polka-dot lined coats as well as lantern sleeves, pouch pockets and a full-body apron in clear plastic It is Marni, not Marini.

title: Guys Mod Up to Solve Their Midlife Minivan Minicrisis
description: JIM NYE was not what you would call a minivan kind of guy. Mr. Nye, a 47-year-old special education teacher from Ventura, Calif., spent his free time tinkering with cars like Porsches or the Mini Cooper. With his first two children, he chose a sedan over a van.

description: Will the World Series go seven games?

title: Wide Range of Tax Shelters Draws Senate Inquiry
description: Major companies have leased parts of the subway systems in Washington, Boston and Chicago, to be joined soon by water mains in New York City, in deals intended to cut the companies' tax bills and to get around rules prohibiting abusive tax shelters, said a witness at a Senate Finance Committee hearing on Tuesday.

title: The Kid Who Left the Star in the Virtual Dust, and Other Tales
description: SCOUR the official Nascar results from the Talladega Motor Speedway in Alabama in late September and you will not find a word about Derek Wood. But everyone in racing knows that he beat Dale Earnhardt Jr. fair and square.

title: Bush, in Bali, Injects Himself Into Indonesias Political Fight
description: DENPASAR, Indonesia, Oct. 22  President Bush injected himself directly into Indonesia's struggle between democratization and Islamic fundamentalism today, telling the country during a lightning visit that both peace and economic growth in Asia depends on its success "as a pluralistic and democratic state."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, WILLIAM
description: GOLDBERG--William. The entire Yeshiva University/ Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary family is deeply grieved by the passing of our cherished member of the Yeshiva College Board of Directors who was a YU Guardian and RIETS Fellow with Lili, his beloved wife and partner in mitzvot. He was widely admired for his charisma, warmth of personality, compassion for his fellow man, his generosity, and his selfless devotion to all who were privileged to share his friendship. Our heartfelt condolences to: Lili; their children Saul (and Dale) Goldberg, Deborah (and Barry) Berg, and Eve Goldberg; to his eight grandchildren who share his devotion to Torah and to the Jewish people; and to his sisters, Bernice (and David) Weiss and Beatrice (and Samuel) Kauder. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton,Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees Joshua L. Muss, Chairman YC Board of Directors

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Call For A Force To Stop Immigrants
description: Italy, which currently holds the European Union presidency, wants the bloc to create a maritime agency to fortify control of its sea borders. The proposal came only days after dozens of Africans died trying to reach Italian shores. Foreign Minister Franco Frattini told Italian radio that the long Mediterranean coastline should be protected by a European body formed specifically to deal with traffickers of people and supply aid to the countries from which desperate migrants come. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: ROBOT SALES SURGE Record sales of industrial robots in the first six months of 2003 have reversed a two-year downturn, and point to a revival in the global market for the machines, according to a United Nations report. Sales of domestic robots to mow lawns or vacuum carpets fueled the sales. North America led the way, with sales up 35 percent. The European Union posted a 25 percent increase in sales, and Asia registered an 18 percent increase — with Japan remaining the world leader in industrial robot use — in figures released by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe and the International Federation of Robotics.    Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: OFF THE MENU
description: LAURENT TOURONDEL , above, who was the chef at the highly rated Cello on the Upper East Side until it closed about a year ago, has been traveling the world but is now returning to the kitchen. He plans to open a restaurant, as yet unnamed, with JIMMY HABER in the space that Mr. Haber owns at 106 East 57th Street, formerly Pazo. They hope to open before the end of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLARD, CHARLES E.F.

description: IMPERIAL AMERICA

title: Family Stunned After Son Takes Niagara Falls Plunge and Lives
description: For weeks, a Michigan man told his family he could do something no one else had ever accomplished -- intentionally go over Niagara Falls, without a barrel, and survive.

title: Pennington Returning; Martin Is Already Back
description: The collective sigh of relief coming from the Jets this week is not only for the impending return of quarterback Chad Pennington on Sunday against Philadelphia. It also recognizes the return to form of Curtis Martin.

title: The Kid Stays in the Cartoon, Still Having His Fun, Baby
description: Some say genius is the ability to hold two contradictory ideas at the same time. Maybe, but that is certainly one definition of the contemporary notion of cool: something or someone at once wrenchingly embarrassing and deeply admirable.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bar Opposes Nonpartisan Elections
description: The City Bar Association plans to release a report this week that opposes the Nov. 4 ballot proposals championed by Mayor Bloomberg and the Charter Revision Commission, including one that would eliminate party primaries in citywide elections. The report asserts that the commission has not shown that the change to nonpartisan elections would benefit voters. Paul Elliott, a spokesman for the charter commission, responded, ''I can't recall the last time that working New Yorkers were moved by anything that the bar association had to say.'' Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: SENATE APPROVES BILL TO PROHIBIT TYPE OF ABORTION
description: The Senate on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved the first federal ban on a specific abortion procedure, ending eight years of divisive debate and clearing the way for President Bush to sign the measure into law.

title: Victim of Equine Encephalitis Is a 2-Year-Old, Officials Say
description: State health officials said on Tuesday that the person stricken with eastern equine encephalitis in the first New Jersey case of the mosquito-borne disease in nearly 20 years was a 2-year-old girl in Burlington County.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: State and Wine Business In New Campaign
description: Governor Pataki announced an unusual ally against drunk driving yesterday -- New York state wineries that provide glasses of wine at their 120 wine-tasting rooms. In the fall, tasting-room hopping is an especially popular tourist activity. In July, a new law lowered the blood-alcohol threshold for a charge of driving while intoxicated to 0.08 from 0.10. As part of the campaign announced yesterday, The New York State Wine and Grape Foundation, a trade group, will supply informational literature on the drunken-driving law along with wine samples. The literature will also mention the importance of designating a nondrinking driver. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Some Green Machines Swim in the Mainstream
description: LAWRENCE ANG never intended to be environmentally correct. He wanted a new car with an economical price tag, good gas mileage and looks he liked. By choosing a Ford Focus, he also got a car with tailpipe emissions so low they are often cleaner than the ambient air in smoggy urban areas.

title: Book Magazine Will Be Closed
description: Book magazine, which profiles authors and their works in much the way that People magazine reports on celebrities, said yesterday that it would cease publication after its November/December issue because its co-owner, Barnes & Noble, was withdrawing financial support.

title: Corrections
description: The Reverberations column in Weekend on Oct. 10, about Lars von Trier's film ''Dogville,'' which is to open commercially in the United States in March, referred erroneously to plans for two sequels. Nicole Kidman, who stars as Grace in ''Dogville,'' will not appear in the sequels.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola Chip Unit To Announce New System
description: Motorola's semiconductor products group is set to announce today that it is developing a family of multimedia components and software that will allow electronics manufacturers to rapidly design a wide range of devices from a postage-stamp-size core. The newest ''system on a chip'' will combine functions that are currently handled by as many as 300 components, according to Motorola. It is expected to cut power demand and manufacturing costs for cellphones, hand-held entertainment gear and mobile computing equipment and allow manufacturers to develop numerous variations in their products quickly and efficiently. The new system, called MXC, is the first major product initiative announced by the semiconductor group since Motorola's announcement two weeks ago that it planned to spin it off. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inflation Edges Upward
description: Canada's consumer price index rose by an annual rate of 2.2 percent in September, up from 2 percent in August, Statistics Canada reported yesterday. The core index, which excludes the eight most volatile items, moved up 1.7 percent in September, the third consecutive month that it was below the Bank of Canada's target inflation rate of 2 percent. Last month's increase, which matched analysts' expectations, was propelled by higher tuition and clothing costs. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, PETER E.
description: SIMON--Peter E. was born on September 23, 1926 in Passaic, NJ. He attended Passaic High School where he was a star player for the school's basketball team. He attended the University of Nevada Las Vegas as well as the Naval Academy. His business career started in Passaic where he and his father, Irwin, owned a successful insurance company. He left the insurance business in 1967 and, along with partners, Melvin S. Taub, Herbert Kay and Samuel Brodie, founded the hotel company, Prime Motor Inns, Inc. The Company started out as a regional hotel real estate company until 1969 when it was listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Between 1969 and 1992, the Company grew into a national chain, expanding through key acquisitions and internal development. In 1984, Prime acquired the Howard Johnson hotel company and in 1989 it acquired the Ramada Inn chain. Mr. Simon was Chairman of the Board, President and CEO of the Company from 1969 through his retirement in 1992. Not one to stay away from deal making or the hotel industry for too long, Mr. Simon started another hotel venture in Florida in 1997 with close friend and partner Patrick Guarini. They currently have a group of 5 hotels throughout South Florida. Mr. Simon was a private person who never took glory in the many successes he achieved throughout his career. He was devoted first and foremost to his wife, Susan, and his four children from a previous marriage and their spouses: Dale and Robert Ploshnick, David and Joy Simon, Lori and Steve Silverman, Jane and Steven Reichel. He was a loving grandfather to his 11 grandchildren: Lisa, Marc, Lindsay, Adam, Scott, Drew, Daniel, Gregory, Samantha, Matthew and Michael. He was adored and admired by his four stepchildren and five step granchildren: Liz, Jennifer, Carolyn, Jonathan, Gabriel, Charlie, Arthur, Daniel and Abigail. Funeral service will be held today 12 noon at the Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ. (201) 843-9090

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Swindler Sentenced Again
description: It was the second day of reckoning for Christopher Rocancourt, the urbane French confidence man who separated acquaintances in Hollywood and the Hamptons from their money. Mr. Rocancourt, who once claimed he was a Rockefeller, was sentenced yesterday in Suffolk County Court on state charges of grand larceny. Mr. Rocancourt received a sentence of one and a third to four years in prison for bilking Long Island residents out of $188,000. Prosecutors said Mr. Rocancourt sweet-talked people out of a total of $1.3 million. On Monday, in federal court, he was sentenced to 3 years and 10 months on fraud charges, and he will serve his sentences concurrently. Mr. Rocancourt apologized in both courts. His memoirs (''I, Christopher Rocancourt, Orphan, Playboy and Convict'') were published last year. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Yukos Investigation
description: Russian prosecutors threatened to widen an investigation of the Russian oil producer Yukos, possibly with criminal charges against its top executives, the Interfax news agency said. Investigators searched a bank in St. Petersburg affiliated with Yukos and the offices of Sibneft, a smaller oil company that is merging with Yukos. The chief executive of Yukos, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, has condemned the investigation as being politically motivated. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ISENBERG, MORRIS, MD
description: ISENBERG--Morris, MD, of Forest Hills, NY on October 19, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Frieda (Epstein) for 56 years. Devoted father of Edward, Elliott and Howard. Loving grandfather of Karen Clements and Paula Zuckerman. Great-grandfather of Lauren and Brian Clements and Emma Zuckerman. He worked as a Psychiatrist for 55 years. Services Wednesday, October 22, 2003 at 12 noon from ''Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapel'', 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: DISPUTED INSURANCE RULE UPHELD The state's highest court yesterday let stand an administrative rule that the Pataki administration said helps reduce insurance fraud, but that some groups, including doctors, said makes it more difficult for auto-accident victims to get benefits. In 2001, the state superintendent of insurance, Gregory Serio, shortened deadlines for filing no-fault claims to 30 days from 90 days. A coalition of groups, led by the Medical Society of the State of New York, a doctor and patient advocacy group, sued to stop the change. In a 6-0 decision, the Court of Appeals affirmed two lower court decisions supporting the change. In the decision, Chief Judge Judith Kaye acknowledged that the new deadline might hurt some claimants, but concluded that the superintendent had the authority to make such a change. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Low-Cost Supercomputer Put Together From 1,100 PC's
description: A home-brew supercomputer, assembled from off-the-shelf personal computers in just one month at a cost of slightly more than $5 million, is about to be ranked as one of the fastest machines in the world.

title: Yanks See Loophole For Return Of Clemens
description: Roger Clemens recognizes the symmetry. Clemens will make his final major league start here on Wednesday night in Game 4 of the World Series. Twenty years ago, he made his first professional start in this state, for the Boston Red Sox' minor league team in Winter Haven.

Silvester, a government witness imprisoned while awaiting sentencing. Mr. Andrews is married to the sister of Mr. Silvester's mistress, Lisa A. Thiesfield; the men are not brothers-in-law. The cash rebates are climbing higher and higher, and the interest-rate offers are dropping to nothing.

title: Let Someone Else Do the Talking
description: In the latest debate over leaks of classified information, wisdom begins with a distinction: leaks elicited by a reporter while investigating a story often serve the public interest -- and merit the journalist's protecting the identity of that source. Leaks initiated by self-serving antagonists in the political process -- and calculated to exploit journalists as convenient mouthpieces -- rarely serve the public interest and deserve less protection.

Kinney, President Julia Brown, Director

title: ELECTROLUX MAY MOVE PLANT TO MEXICO FROM MICHIGAN
description: The Swedish appliance maker Electrolux reported a decline in quarterly profit for a fifth consecutive quarter yesterday and said it might close a plant in Michigan. Net income fell 38 percent, to 767 million kronor ($99 million), and sales fell 4.3 percent, the company said. Electrolux, based in Stockholm, said it might move manufacturing operations in Greenville, Mich., to Mexico and take a charge of 1.2 billion kronor to close the plant, which employs 2,700 people.

title: 15 Design-Studio Heads Must Know Something
description: THINK about cars that are most likely to be driven in California, and a flock of images come to mind, like convertibles, hot rods and brightly colored paint jobs -- automobiles fit for sunny days and sea-breeze nights.

title: Dining Out? Let Your Friend Be Your Guide
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Treffinger Associates Sentenced
description: Three men who were once close to James W. Treffinger, the former Essex County executive sentenced to prison last week, were spared prison time yesterday after cooperating with prosecutors. Mr. Treffinger, once a leading Republican politician in the state, was convicted on corruption charges growing out of his efforts to use his county post to propel himself to higher office. The three men were each sentenced by Judge John W. Bissell to three years' probation. Michael DeMiro, 57, of Verona, a Treffinger aide, was also sentenced to two months house arrest and 300 hours of community service. Rajashekar Ravilla, 40, of Denville, a former Essex County engineer, was sentenced to five months of house arrest and a $10,000 fine. Matthew Kirnan, 43, of Verona, a lawyer who managed Treffinger's 2000 Senate campaign, was sentenced to 300 hours of community service and a $3,000 fine. Jane Allande-Hession (NYT)

title: Another Fund Faces Inquiry Over Trading
description: Putnam Investments could face a civil action within days for permitting improper trading in its mutual funds, William F. Galvin, the secretary of the commonwealth of Massachusetts, said yesterday.

title: Decoding a Mystery Chemical
description: If one does not count oysters, bull's testicles, mead or a thousand other nostrums that warriors and athletes have gamely swallowed, the first known performance-enhancing drug was trimethyl, which became well known because of a side effect: in 1886, an overdose killed an English cyclist racing from Bordeaux to Paris.

title: Judge's Instructions Draw Criticism in Quattrone Case
description: Over the objections of defense lawyers, the judge in the trial of Frank P. Quattrone decided yesterday to remove several references to the government's need to prove its case beyond a reasonable doubt from the instructions he will issue to the deadlocked jury.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 339 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: FREDDIE MAC COULD FACE A $750 MILLION TAX BILL
description: Freddie Mac said that the accounting for derivatives trades that led it to understate income for the last three years may result in a $750 million tax liability. The Internal Revenue Service has inquired about the trades as part of the company's earnings restatement, which may total about $4.5 billion, the company said. Derivatives are financial contracts tied to financial instruments, currencies and interest rates. Freddie Mac, based in McLean, Va., uses them to protect itself from sharp swings in interest rates.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Firefighter Pleads Guilty To Starting Fire
description: A firefighter has pleaded guilty to starting a fire that merged with another wildfire in 2002 to create Arizona's largest and most devastating wildfire. The 31-year-old contract firefighter, Leonard Gregg, confessed before a federal judge on Monday to two counts of arson. Mr. Gregg said he started the fire, later called the Rodeo fire, on June 18, 2002, so he could make money fighting it. Eventually, the Rodeo fire merged with the Chediski fire to burn a total of 470,000 acres and 467 homes. Mr. Gregg faces up to 10 years in prison when he is sentenced in January.

title: Bush, in Bali, Listens to Leaders Complaints
description: DENPASAR, Indonesia, Oct. 22  President Bush made a three-hour visit to the world's most populous Muslim nation today, a visit that was restricted for security reasons to Bali, the Hindu part of the country, and just to the airport area of the resort island.

title: General's Words Under Scrutiny
description: A senior military officer who likened the battle against Islamic terrorists to war against ''Satan'' has asked the Pentagon to begin an official review of his remarks, and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said Tuesday that such an inquiry would begin.

title: Powell Tries to Nudge Sudan Toward Peace
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, seeking to prod the talks to end the long civil war in Sudan, suggested Tuesday that the United States would lift sanctions if Sudan reached a peace accord and acted further against terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRILL, FRED
description: GRILL--Fred. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our member, Fred Grill. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his beloved wife, Barbara and their children, Peter Grill and Mary Ellen Lawrence, and Roseanna and Scott Familant and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Nancy Solomon, President

title: White House Threatens a Veto Of Its Own Spending Bill for Iraq
description: The White House threatened Tuesday to veto its own spending bill for Iraq and Afghanistan if Congress made reconstruction aid a loan, taking its most forceful stand on the issue even as more lawmakers supported a reimbursement by Iraq.

title: Revolt of Shareholders at a British Broadcaster
description: In most mergers, one of the top executives of the combining companies is designated as the new chief.

title: Marlins Take Game 4 With Walk-Off Homer in 12th Inning
description: MIAMI, Thursday, Oct. 23 - All season long, Roger Clemens has been a man with a retirement plan, a pitcher on a recurring mission, a legend trying to leave the game he has dominated over the last two decades as a champion. Clemens has been pitching powerfully to help the Yankees snatch one more World Series title this season, to allow himself to slip one more ring on his thick finger.

title: Bush Meets Indonesian President in Bali
description: President Bush landed Wednesday morning in the world's most populous Muslim nation, and immediately headed into a meeting with President Megawati Sukarnoputri, beginning a three-hour visit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOCHBERG, IRWIN
description: HOCHBERG--Irwin. On Tuesday, October 21, 2003 at the age of 73. Survived by his loving family, wife Ilene, children Carolyn, Steven and Gail, and Seth and Lindy, sister Sandra Lewen, grandchildren Hayleigh, Alex, Rachel and Daniel. Services Thursday, October 23 at 12:45PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St & Amsterdam Ave, NY, NY. Contributions in his memory to American Friends of Hebrew University, 11 East 69 St, Suite 400, NY, NY, 10021.

title: Husband Sues Liza Minnelli, Citing Drinking and Violence
description: David Gest sued Liza Minnelli yesterday, claiming that while they lived together she went into numerous alcohol-induced rages and beat him so badly that he ''suffers from virtually constant, unrelenting pain'' in his head.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Telecom Bidder Approved
description: A consortium led by the American International Group has won shareholder approval to take a controlling stake in Hanaro Telecom, the No.2 high-speed Internet provider in South Korea, for $500 million. The consortium won the support of 64 percent of Hanaro's shareholders, topping an offer made by a rival consortium led by a South Korean conglomerate, the LG Group, which already holds an 18 percent stake in Hanaro. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: New Information May Bolster Questions on Halliburton
description: The head of an Iraqi oil agency said yesterday that his group had been trucking in gasoline and other fuel to Iraq for considerably less money than Halliburton, which has so far received more than $700 million from the Army Corps of Engineers to stave off shortages there.

title: The Restaurants That Time Forgot
description: NOT long ago, a stylish South American woman walked into Le Veau d'Or, a small French bistro near Bloomingdale's. She had not set foot in the place for 40 years, but looking around, all seemed in order. The dcor remained intact, with the painting of a calf sleeping in bed, the covers pulled up under its chin. The menu, a rote recitation of bistro classics, certainly hadn't changed. But something was not quite right. ''Have you changed some of the waiters?'' she asked suspiciously. Robert Treboux, the owner, tried to break the news gently. ''I told her, 'Some have died, some have gotten rich,' '' he said. ''It was a very funny question.''

title: Bottles That Come With a Rsum
description: IN Europe, it is where the wine comes from that matters; in the United States, it is the grape. But it hasn't always been so, and given what's happening in the global market these days, it may not be that way much longer.

title: G.E. TO LAY OFF 1,000 WORKERS AT TURBINE FACTORIES
description: General Electric said it would cut 1,000 jobs at turbine factories in South Carolina and New York as deliveries of turbines for power plants decline. About 600 jobs will be cut in Greenville, S.C., and 400 more in Schenectady, N.Y., company executives said. GE Power Systems, the company's biggest industrial unit, has about 34,000 employees worldwide. The number of large turbines shipped from Greenville is forecast to drop to 120 this year from 241 last year, a spokesman, Mark Reilly, said.

title: Living With Scarcity in California
description: Population growth, suburban sprawl and episodes of stubborn drought have meant that what was once largely a Western phenomenon -- scarce water -- has begun to afflict other parts of the country, especially the Southeast and cities like Atlanta, creating unexpected tensions among competing users. The granddaddy of all water wars, however, has always been the century-old struggle over the Colorado River, and the recent announcement of an armistice in that epic battle could provide a template for compromise elsewhere.

title: N.F.L. Network Will Not Carry Games
description: The head of the N.F.L. Network, which will make its debut on Nov. 4, said yesterday that he did not expect the channel to carry regular-season or playoff games during the league's next round of network contracts. The league has deals with CBS, Fox, ABC and ESPN through the 2005 season.

title: Rights Group Exposes Conditions in North Korean Prison Camps
description: A new report on human rights in North Korea says hundreds of thousands of prisoners work in often life-threatening conditions in at least 36 camps hidden in isolated valleys and mountains of the closed Stalinist country.

title: Stanley Kaplan Donates $2 Million For CUNY Math Education Program
description: Stanley Kaplan, founder of the test preparation service, has donated $2 million to the City College of New York to finance a new program in math education, the college said yesterday. The donation is the largest from a living donor in the history of the college, officials said.

title: I.R.S. Drops Inquiry Into Fuel Tax Credit
description: Progress Energy, a utility, said yesterday that the Internal Revenue Service was dropping its inquiry into whether the company was meeting a crucial requirement for receiving lucrative tax credits for making synthetic fuel based on coal.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Delay Urged In Opening Of Jail
description: A union representing Essex County corrections officers has asked a federal judge to delay the transfer of prisoners to a new jail because it may contain hazardous substances, including cancer-causing chemicals. The union wants the prisoner transfer delayed until an environmental safety study is done. The union, Local 157 of the Police Benevolent Association, filed suit in federal court on Monday against county officials and the State Department of Corrections. The jail was built on the former site of a Hoechst-Celanese, chemical plant that produced formaldehyde. The site was once zoned for heavy industrial use, union officials said. The area was later rezoned to permit building of the jail. The Essex County executive, Joseph N. DiVincenzo Jr., said that his office was working to ensure that the jail is safe.

title: Luis A. Ferr Dies at 99; Pushed Puerto Rican Statehood
description: Luis A. Ferr, a dominant force in the politics, economy and culture of Puerto Rico for much of the last century and a tireless proponent of statehood, died yesterday in San Juan. He was 99.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Pentagon Says It Will Call Up Added Reserves
description: Senior Pentagon officials said Tuesday that more National Guard and Reserve forces would be notified in coming weeks that they might have to serve in Iraq next year. The announcement was made amid complaints from Congress and the families of part-time troops about the stress of lengthy deployments.

title: Drive Right Up and Don't Get Out
description: THE REV. VERLYN D. VERBRUGGE does not know for sure if his congregants at the Reform Church of America in Grand Rapids, Mich., are listening raptly to his sermon or idly to their radios.

title: U.S. SAYS IT HAS PROOF WILLIAMS COS. GAVE FALSE DATA
description: Federal prosecutors have evidence that the Williams Companies, the natural gas pipeline company, gave false trading data to an industry newsletter, lawyers for the publication told a judge yesterday. The United States attorney's office said it had evidence that Williams submitted false reports to the McGraw-Hill Companies after the publisher objected to the government's request for documents it received from Williams, a lawyer for McGraw-Hill told Federal District Judge Vaughn Walker in San Francisco. Brad Church, a spokesman for Williams, said the company, based in Tulsa, Okla., was cooperating with the investigations.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Friday with an article about a water main break that caused flooding in Washington Heights misstated the name of a street west of Broadway. It is Fort Washington Avenue, not Washington Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENDLER, DORA (NEE PERRES)
description: KENDLER -- Dora (nee Perres). Born in Bobruisk, Russia, in 1916. At age 13, she emigrated to the United State with her mother, two sisters and brother, to be reunited with her father, in escape of the pogroms against Jews. Beloved wife of the late Irving Nathan Kendler, dearly loved mother of her surviving daughters, Paulette and Helene, and their respective partners, Arthur Rudy, and Patricia Grossman, and her late son, Joseph, loving grandmother of Brian and Ilene, and great grandmother of Noah and Rachel. Dora's love of family and the Jewish faith, great joy in playing classical piano, and vivid charm toward all who knew her will be missed always. Donations in her memory may be made to The New York City Chapter of The Alzheimers Association, Development Dept, 360 Lexington Avenue, 5th Flr, New York, New York 10017.

title: Alfa Male Assembles Alfa Car, Piece by Piece
description: THE midlife crisis hit shortly after my 50th birthday, manifesting itself in the purchase of a little red Alfa Romeo two-seater. My wife couldn't argue with the price, $375. But with a bargain comes compromises. I had to build the car myself. Once I did, I could not drive it; from bumper to tailpipe, it was only 19 inches long.

title: Ashcroft Briefed Regularly On Inquiry Into C.I.A. Leak
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft's top aides have regularly briefed him on key details in the investigation into the disclosure of a C.I.A. officer's identity, including the identities of those interviewed by the F.B.I., a senior Justice Department official told members of Congress on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLAHER, ANNA B.
description: KELLAHER--Anna B. On October 19, 2003, of Forest Hills, NY. Associated with Equitable Life Insurance Company for 45 years. Devoted sister of the late Edward, the late John, and Kathryn Miller of Florida. Dear sister-in-law of Eleanore Kellaher. She will be missed by her many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, NY, Wednesday, 7-9 PM, Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church Friday, October 24, 10:15 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: The Loss of Relationships Under Mao's Rough Revolutionary Hand
description: The documentary ''Morning Sun'' does a thoughtful job of streamlining the bloody realities -- both literal and psychological -- of China's Cultural Revolution into roughly two hours of film. The movie, which opens today at the Film Forum, begins with clips from a 1964 ''musical extravaganza'' -- as the narrator, Margot Adler, puts it -- called ''The East Is Red.''

title: Coming Soon: Smarter Ways to Stop, Turn and Cruise
description: YOUR car is becoming a much better driver.

title: Encouraging Words From Iran
description: Iran made a series of important promises yesterday about its nuclear activities. If it carries them out fully and promptly, they could go a long way toward easing international concerns. Yet Iran has been less than candid about its nuclear activities in the past and appears to have used the cover of a civilian nuclear power program to develop weapons-building capacity. Therefore, it bears the burden of convincing the world that it has no intention of producing nuclear weapons, now or in the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DURFEE, CARDER HAZARD
description: DURFEE--Carder Hazard, 87, prominent and well known artist, survived by Charles F. Hickey of Tiverton, RI and NYC, his sister Constance St. John of Providence, his nieces, Julia Ballerini of New York, Anne Aldrich of Florida and Jane Aldrich of Montana, five great nieces and nephews, four great-great nieces and nephews. His memorial service will be held at the Newport Art Museum on Sunday, December 14th, 2003 at 11 AM. Burial is private. Donations may be made to the Exhibitions Fund, Newport Art Museum, 76 Bellevue Avenue, Newport, RI 02840. For online guestbook www.saundersdwyer.com

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSOFSKY, JOSEPH
description: OSOFSKY--Joseph. Beloved husband of Nettie. Devoted father of Marsha Freeman (William Jones) and the late Gerald. Dear brother of Minnie. Services Thursday, October 23, 1:15PM at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162 - 05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: S.E.C. Pursues Time Warner Investigation
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has subpoenaed Stephen M. Case, the former chairman of AOL Time Warner; Richard D. Parsons, the chairman and chief executive; and several other top executives for questioning as part of its investigation into the company's accounting for an advertising deal with Bertelsmann, two people involved in the investigation said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Report Says Many Inmates In Isolation Are Mentally Ill
description: Nearly one of every four New York State prisoners who are kept in punitive segregation -- confined to a small cell at least 23 hours a day -- are mentally ill, according to a new report by a nonprofit group that has been critical of state prison policies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COSTELLO, TIMOTHY W.
description: COSTELLO -- Timothy W. Adelphi University mourns the passing of our former President Timothy W. Costello. For 13 years he served with distinction as the University's sixth President, sharing his knowlege and commitment to educational excellence with the Adelphi community. Under his leadership, the University formed several new departments, launched its adult degree program, added the Derner Institute for Advanced Psychological Studies and built new facilities including the Olmsted Theatre and a new home for the School of Social Work. We will build upon his legacy through our commitment to the highest academic standards and civic-minded initiative. Our thoughts are with his son Peter, a member of our faculty, and the entire Costello family. Robert A. Scott, President Steven N. Fischer, Chairman The Adelphi University Board of Trustees

title: Living Large at Zankel Hall
description: Chamber music doesn't have to be small. It could be a credo, if an unspoken one, of Carnegie's new Zankel Hall, a spacious chamber that seats more than 600 people, and it was supported by the opening program of the Jerusalem Chamber Music Festival's three-concert series there on Oct. 16. The young festival, founded in 1998, staked out an ambitious terrain with four intense and solid pieces of music in an evening that was nothing if not large, for all the modesty of its forces.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Harvard President Plans Land Use
description: Lawrence Summers, the Harvard president, has outlined possible uses for more than 200 acres of land that the university acquired in the Allston neighborhood of Boston. The ideas, outlined in an open letter, include building new scientific laboratories, moving some museums and graduate schools there, and constructing housing for undergraduate and graduate students. The Graduate School of Education and School of Public Health have expressed interest in moving to Allston, the letter said. The university will begin ''some limited building'' in the next few years, and hopes to pursue additional development in the coming decade, the letter said. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Behind a Pink Storefront on East 82nd Street, A Dark and Seductive Secret
description: There's a new Schiaparelli-pink storefront at 400 East 82nd Street, where Martine Leventer has installed Martine's Chocolates Too, a gilded boutique, in her former antiques store.

title: Yankee Fans Living in Florida Following Tradition and Hearts
description: MIAMI, Oct. 21  Guy Gillis has not lived in Westchester County in 25 years. But Gillis, a longtime resident of Margate, Fla., came to Tuesday night's World Series game at Pro Player Stadium wearing a Yankees jersey and in a mood to talk to Marlins fans about tradition.

title: U.N. Resolution Condemns Israeli Barrier
description: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 21 - The General Assembly overwhelmingly approved a resolution late on Tuesday demanding that Israel tear down the barrier it is building in the West Bank to deter terrorist attacks.

title: Market Place; Traders Worry, And Seat Price On Big Board Takes a Dip
description: The value of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange plunged by $500,000 yesterday, providing a strong indication that traders are nervous about the Big Board's future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ESSES, MARSHA ZWEIG
description: ESSES--Marsha Zweig. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Marsha Zweig Esses, beloved sister of Rivalyn Zweig. We extend our condolences to Rivalyn and her family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TIMKEN CO., Canton, Ohio, the nation's largest maker of automotive and industrial bearings, said it would sell its unit that makes parts for aircraft frames to the Roller Bearing Co. of America Inc., Fairfield, Conn. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bob for This, and You Might Need a Neck Brace
description: Like a state fair prizewinner, the Honeycrisp, a newcomer, dwarfs all other apples. It is selling for $1.50 to $2 a pound. That's one apple.

title: Mitsubishi Falters as Other Makers Thrive
description: While Toyota, Honda and Nissan prosper, Mitsubishi continues to stumble.

title: Unlikely Converts to the Tuner Look, Far From San Diego
description: WHEN Patrick Dean first began posting photos of his black Saturn SC2 on the Internet four years ago, he knew that it would be no easy task to attract the notice of the import tuner crowd.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Sale Of Hospitals
description: An Australian health care company, the Mayne Group, said it planned to sell its network of 53 hospitals to a Singapore government investment trust for about 830 million Australian dollars ($580 million). Official Singapore agencies, including pension funds, have already invested about 20 billion Australian dollars in retail centers, hotels, electricity distribution and telecommunications. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Ways to Keep Schemers From Beating the System
description: John E. Madden, a turn-of-the-19th-century horseman, possessed an eye for horseflesh and a hold-his-nose-disdain for sharpies trying to get rich on his horses. He referred to the colts and fillies in his barn by numbers and refused to answer inquiries about how they might run in any given race. If anyone was going to take down the bookies with insider information, it was going to be Madden himself.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Yahoo Japan's Profit Rises
description: Profit at Yahoo Japan, Japan's largest Internet portal, more than doubled in the July-to-September quarter because of higher demand for the company's auction services. Yahoo Japan earned 5.9 billion yen ($54 million) in the quarter, 111 percent more than the same period a year ago. Sales grew 61 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Dining Out? Let Your Friend Be Your Guide
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: South
description: LOUISIANA: DISMISSAL OF JUDGE FOR MISCONDUCT A judge who forced his employees to work on his re-election campaign and then lied about it has been dismissed by the State Supreme Court. In a 7-to-0 decision, the court removed Judge C. Hunter King of Orleans Parish from State District Court and barred him from running for a judicial office for at least five years. Judge King said the pressure of campaign debt made him personally accept donations and enlist his staff to raise money, both of which are forbidden under the Code of Judicial Conduct.    (AP)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Robot Sales Surge
description: Record sales of industrial robots in the first six months of 2003 have reversed a two-year downturn, and point to a revival in the global market for the machines, according to a United Nations report. Sales of domestic robots to mow lawns or vacuum carpets fueled the sales. North America led the way, with sales up 35 percent. The European Union posted a 25 percent increase in sales, and Asia registered an 18 percent increase -- with Japan remaining the world leader in industrial robot use -- in figures released by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe and the International Federation of Robotics.

title: Competition Among the Well-to-Do Is Good Business for Tutors
description: Allan Schneider, 59, is a laid-off engineer, unlikely to find another job that commands $175,000 a year in this economy. Laura Inman, 42, is a stay-at-home mother dusting off a Ph.D. in English as a ticket back to the workplace. Addi Feinstein, 23, is a recent Yale graduate, scrambling to pay her share of a five-roommate apartment.

title: The absence of television viewers has network executives scratching their heads.
description: AS the ratings have rolled in for the first three weeks of the new television season, one question has dominated the conversations inside the industry's executive suites: what the heck is going on?

title: Our Towns; Disagreement: It's the Nature Of the Species
description: AS interspecies introductions go, Lynda Smith remembered it as being rather unremarkable. ''The moving van is literally in the driveway,'' Ms. Smith said of the first day in her West Milford, N.J., home and her first encounter with the bears that are a source of controversy in New Jersey. ''And lo and behold, there's a sow and a cub in the backyard.''

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Earthlink Posts First Profit In 5 Years
description: EarthLink Inc.,the nation's No. 3 Internet service provider, yesterday posted its first profit in five years in the third quarter as it added high-speed Internet subscribers and reduced costs. Net income of $3.5 million, or 2 cents a share, reversed a year-earlier loss of $30.1 million, or 20 cents. Revenue rose 2 percent, to $347.4 million, the Atlanta-based company said in a statement. EarthLink ended the quarter with a total of 953,000 high-speed, or broadband, customers, up almost 40 percent from a year earlier. The gain in high-speed users helped counter a 3.4 percent decline in dial-up subscribers. EarthLink shares rose $1, or 13.3 percent, to $8.52. EarthLink has cut 2,171 jobs, or 38 percent of its work force, in the last year. Those reductions, along with a decline in sales and marketing expenses, helped the company earn a profit in the latest quarter, analysts said.

title: Guilt Reduction for Moms
description: To the Editor:

title: Take Back the Erie Canal
description: Heads up. We have action in Albany. The New York State comptroller, Alan Hevesi, has rescinded the approval of a deal allowing a Buffalo developer to pay $30,000 for the development rights along 50 prime miles of the Erie Canal and its tributaries. The comptroller labeled the competitive process for this agreement a ''sham.'' He said the state's Canal Corporation, which approved the contract, made ''false and misleading'' statements 18 months ago to get validation from the comptroller's office. So Mr. Hevesi removed the comptroller's seal of approval, voided the contract and passed his findings along to the attorney general for more investigation.

title: When to Change the Oil, An Enduring Mystery
description: ON a Saturday morning in early August, my wife and I loaded up our 2002 Honda Odyssey with our four children and pointed northeast on Interstate 95 for the start of a three-hour trip to a vacation home in Cape Cod, Mass.

title: Not Much to Look At, but the Food Is Another Thing
description: THE restaurant 50 Carmine looks at first glance like the kind of place not worth a second glance. You could call the boxy dining room generic, but that would be giving too much credit to a room without a hint of character. Glossy brick walls and plate-glass storefronts are the modular components for countless restaurants, and without a single atmospheric cue, you can barely tell whether you are sitting down for corn bread, corned beef or a pedicure.

title: Rock Celebrities by Stealth; Without Trying Too Hard, the Shins Have Become an Indie Phenomenon
description: The Shins have achieved an odd, furtive kind of popularity in the last few years: they are secretly famous. Last month the Shins, an indie-rock band, played three sold-out shows at the Bowery Ballroom on the Lower East Side: a coming-out party not for the musicians but for their fans, some of whom seemed startled to learn that they weren't alone.

title: Reminders That Manhattan Is Still an Isle of Joy
description: Steve Ross's airy new cabaret show, ''My Manhattan,'' is the musical equivalent of an elegant photography exhibition that contemplates roughly a century of New York life (mostly upscale) and encompasses material from Broadway's toddler years (Victor Herbert's ''Streets of New York'') through Stephen Sondheim (''Another Hundred People''). Mr. Ross's thumping, frilly pianism and spirited singing unite songs by infusing them with a Champagne-giddy ballroom-dancing gallop.

title: Army Reports Some Absences From a Trial Leave Program
description: Pentagon officials disclosed on Tuesday that 28 soldiers who were granted a 15-day leave from the war in Iraq as part of an experimental program had not reported back to duty.

title: CALENDAR
description: Autumn Greenmarkets

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Helped by Pricing Strategy, Amazon.com Reports Profit
description: Amazon.com yesterday reported its first profit outside of the fourth quarter, which includes the holiday season, as its strategy to reignite growth with lower prices continues to pay off.

title: China's Boom Adds to Global Warming Problem
description: China's rapid economic growth is producing a surge in emissions of greenhouse gases that threatens international efforts to curb global warming, as Chinese power plants burn ever more coal while car sales soar.

title: Governor of Florida Orders Woman Fed In Right-to-Die Case
description: Six days after the feeding tube of a brain-damaged woman was removed in a case that pitted her husband against her parents, Gov. Jeb Bush ordered it reinserted on Tuesday after the Legislature empowered him to do so. The extraordinary step overrides years of court rulings.

title: Syria's Options
description: To the Editor:

title: Baffled Occupiers, or the Missed Understandings
description: Pollsters and journalists have been busy asking Iraqis how they feel about the Americans on their streets, but there is a potentially more important issue. How do the Americans here feel about the Iraqis? Will they ever feel comfortable enough in this alien culture to finish the job they started?

title: Mourning Finds Niche As Nets' Starting Center
description: It was a moment usually reserved for an empty gym in the off-season. Alonzo Mourning was on one side and Dikembe Mutombo was on the other, with elbows and hook shots the weapons of choice.

title: How Many Birds to Bake in a Pie? One Will Do
description: Each of Bob Carmack's hand-painted ceramic pie birds -- chickens, robins and sandhill cranes, among others -- has a personality of its own. But Mr. Carmack, a ceramist in Grand Blanc, Mich., does not stop at the nest: his menagerie also has circus elephants, pigs and donkeys. And Grand Pappy, above.

title: Mixing Rough Roads With Home Comforts
description: WHEN most people dream about rumbling down back roads, cutting through canyons and climbing mountains, they usually fantasize about doing it in a Hummer or a Land Rover -- something big and brawny, tested on the Serengeti Plain or in a Middle Eastern desert. For a small, dedicated group of outdoor enthusiasts, though, the preferred way to go off-road is in a four-wheel-drive Sportsmobile van camper.

title: Appealing to Youth, Selling to the Not-So-Young
description: THE vehicle rumbles down a traffic-free city street, a trail of fast-flying papers in its wake. It is a Cadillac Escalade, turning the heads of 30-somethings, as rock music -- not too loud, mind you -- plays in the background.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- New Jersey; Relic Gets New Life In Makeover
description: Nearly half-vacant just two years ago, the two-million-square-foot factory where Curtiss-Wright once manufactured airplane engines and parts looked like an industrial relic. But since then new owners have filled the 1942 plant with tenants as part of a plan to transform the entire 150-acre, mostly desolate, site into a new neighborhood with the old building at its core.

title: Tale of the Tape: Different Sizes, Similar Passions
description: HUMMERS and Minis. These specialty cars, which are relatively new to the marketplace, are driven by two very different kinds of customers, right? After all, the Hummer H2, which is like SpongeBob SquarePants on steroids, is not playing the same game as the Powerpuff Girl of the Mini Cooper.

title: A Troubled School's TV Milestone
description: This is the aspect of national attention that Dennis Dunn enjoys. The head football coach of Evangel Christian Academy, Dunn sits forward in his office chair and peers into the lens of a television camera. On cue, he explains what it means to play a team from California in the first high school football game broadcast live on national television. He talks of measuring sticks and challenges and his team's evolution into a program so dominant it must roam the country in search of competition.

title: More Thoughts on Apples New Operating System
description: In todays "State of the Art" column, I reviewed the new version of Apples operating system, Mac OS X 10.3, code-named Panther. But there are 150 new features in Panther, and theres only so much you can say in 1300 words.

title: Full Disclosure on Leaks
description: Secrets are created every day in the federal government: when National Security Agency personnel create codes, when C.I.A. case officers talk to their spies, when F.B.I. agents speak to their sources, when the Joint Chiefs of Staff discuss troop movements. When these secrets are revealed to the press, it is known as a leak. Not all leaks are created equal, however. Just as the motives for leaking differ, so do the consequences of a leak.

description: DaimlerChrysler eked out a thin profit in the third quarter at its troubled Chrysler division, citing stringent cost-cutting and a calmer-than-expected market for costly sales incentives.

description: MILAN:  Ask any frequent flier to Italy about travel confusion and be prepared for epic narrations making Ulysses' travels to the peninsula seem like a stroll in the park.

He received his Masters Degree from Case Western Reserve. Lawrence worked as an advertising executive and was the Executive Vice President of Dancer, Fitzgerald and Sample. description: Josh Beckett stood along the steps of the Florida Marlins' dugout at Pro Player Stadium on Tuesday night, a steady drizzle continuing on the field as his teammates batted in the bottom of the seventh inning in a game tied at 1-1.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Ex-Taliban Minister Offers Help
description: The former Taliban foreign minister, Wakil Ahmed Muttawakil, has offered to cooperate with the government of President Hamid Karzai in a deal struck while in American custody, a senior aide to the president said. Mr. Muttawakil, regarded as a moderate who reportedly led an attempt to persuade the Taliban leaders to hand over Osama bin Laden to avert a war, has been in detention since January 2002 and made his offer in a letter. The government has not yet replied. The aide said Mr. Muttawakil was still in custody in Afghanistan. Officials have been nurturing contacts with Taliban moderates for some months in an effort to undermine an increasingly violent insurgency in southern and eastern Afghanistan and to persuade influential figures to abandon violence. Umar Daudzai, the presidential chief of staff, said in a telephone interview that a number of Taliban want to leave the fighting lines and ''want to have a normal life.'' Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: A City Tale of Daring Death, and Losing
description: If Eric Alvarez had grown up in the country, he might have played a game of chicken on the railroad tracks. If he had grown up in the suburbs, he might have sneaked a joy ride in his parents' car.

title: A Father-vs.-Umpire Fracas Will Test Youth Sports Law
description: A New Jersey father arrested last summer on charges that he punched an umpire while coaching at an all-star baseball game for 10-year-old boys has been indicted under a recent state law intended to curb rowdy adult behavior at youth athletic events.

He watched the Yankees and the Florida Marlins throw and hit baseballs with the keen awareness of a man who has evaluated players for more than three decades.

description: California Democrats, for the time being at least, are no longer talking about the possibility of initiating a retaliatory recall against the governor-elect, Arnold Schwarzenegger.
