description: Track and field's governing body confirmed yesterday that it planned to retest urine samples from August's world championships for a recently identified designer steroid, and the president of the World Anti-Doping Agency called on other sports organizations to retest their samples.

title: Want Me to Slow Down From 25 Miles an Hour? That's Not a Problem
description: I LEFT the San Francisco Bay Area 15 years ago because it was too crowded. I hated getting stuck in traffic trying to get out of the city or back into the city or just from one side to another. It seemed like rush hour lasted all day. It was impossible to pick a time to travel when I wouldn't get waylaid.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: ORBITZ EXPECTS TO SELL SHARES AT $22 EACH Orbitz Inc., an Internet travel company that has planned a public share sale for more than a year, said yesterday that it expected its initial public offering to be priced at $22 a share. Orbitz, which is based in Chicago, is owned by the nation's five biggest airlines. It did not indicate in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing when or how many shares it planned to sell. In July 2002, it filed to sell as much as $125 million of stock. Initial stock sales in the United States are picking up, encouraged by the 31 percent gain in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index since March 11. There have been 26 public offerings worth $3.97 billion in the second half of the year, compared with 12 worth $2.94 billion in the first half. Orbitz had a net loss of $5.3 million on revenue of $107.8 million in the six months to June 30, the filing said; in the period a year ago, it had a net loss of $16.5 million on revenue of $74.7 million. American Airlines owns 26 percent of Orbitz; Continental Airlines owns 14 percent; Delta Air Lines has 18 percent; Northwest Airlines owns 15 percent; and United Air Lines, a unit of UAL, has 26 percent. (Bloomberg News)

title: Abstraction in a Celestial Palette, Courtesy of Robots and Outer Space
description: While images of Mars, Jupiter and Saturn filled a giant screen in the background, speakers ruminated on the topic of interplanetary photography. It resolves specks of distant light into places of astonishing form and beauty, it opens the eyes of science to discovery, but is it art?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JORDAN, VANCE
description: JORDAN--Vance. The Board of Directors and Shareholders of 1220 Park Avenue Corporation mourn the loss of their fellow Director and neighbor. A longstanding memeber of the Board, his wise counsel will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family.

title: Singing the Unspoken: A Tale of Forbidden Love
description: The Red Sox aren't the only Boston team that can fill a house in New York. Just like ticketholders going into Yankee Stadium last week, those entering Carnegie Hall on Monday night for the Boston Symphony Orchestra's concert performance of Debussy's ''Pellas et Mlisande'' had to walk through a crowd of hopefuls milling outside, all bartering for a spare ticket to this sold-out event.

title: Moves by Britain and I.R.A. Toward Peace in Ulster Hit a Last-Minute Snag
description: David Trimble, Northern Ireland's most prominent Protestant leader, turned aside an overture on Tuesday by the Irish Republican Army, which said it had dismantled a portion of its arsenal. Mr. Trimble said the I.R.A. move did not go far enough.

title: Study Finds Hundreds of Thousands of Inmates Mentally Ill
description: As many as one in five of the 2.1 million Americans in jail and prison are seriously mentally ill, far outnumbering the number of mentally ill who are in mental hospitals, according to a comprehensive study released Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAY, GORDON L., III (''LARRY'', ALSO KNOWN AFFECTIONATELY AS ''GROOVY'')
description: GRAY--Gordon L., III (''Larry'', also known affectionately as ''Groovy''). Resident of St. Barthelemy, French West Indies, died in Charleston, South Carolina on October 13, 2003. Predeceased by his mother, Louise Twogood Gray, and survived by his father, Gordon L. Gray, Jr., his sisters, Sherry Beckett and Joanie Burns, his brothers, John Gray and Jimmy Gray, and his beloved daughter, Montana and her mother, Caroline. Also, survived by Janine (''Darling'') Leclercq, Jacques and Odile Leclercq, Philippe Leclercq, and by Sally, Nicki, Elizabeth, JT and Roscoe. Founder and President of Air Mango, a Caribbean charter company, and Moonlight Fireworks. He is sorely missed by his many dear friends in St. Barth's, the United States and France. Funeral services were held at sunset on the beach in St. Barth's on Saturday, October 18, 2003. A memorial celebration of Groovy's life will be held at Louie's Backyard in Key West on Monday, October 27, 2003 from 4-7 P.M. Donations in Groovy's memory may be made to a children's charity of your choice. By his example, he taught his family and friends to love life. He will be loved and dearly missed forever.

title: A Nice Place to Have a Snack or Catch Up on Your Reading
description: CELLPHONES are everybody's favorite example of a distraction that is most likely to cause a car crash. But recent research shows that they are not the most common distraction, and may not be the most serious. A study completed this summer suggests that their use in cars is also nearly impossible to regulate.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 — Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld has told the nation's military commanders that the Defense Department is ill-suited to combatting terrorism and suggested that a new, more agile security agency may be needed to overcome the global terror threat.

description: The Dow Jones industrial average declined yesterday, led by AT&T after it said that earnings slid 13 percent and that it had fired four workers for understating costs. SBC Communications dropped as profit fell short of estimates.

description: When a young and radical Shiite cleric discussed plans here last week to set up his own government of Iraq, he challenged more than the American-led occupation.

description: Completing the largest biotech-related lease of the last year in the area of Berkeley and Oakland, a research unit of Bayer HealthCare moved into a 180,000-square-foot building in the Aquatic Park Center here this year. The lease, as well as the story of the business park that surrounds the building, mirrors some of the tensions surrounding biotech development in a city notable both for its political activism and its resistance to development.

description: Fendi, an old and worthy name in Italian leather goods and furs, but one whose label has become a bit shopworn, is rushing to refashion itself.

title: Online, Used Car Lots That Cover the Nation
description: STEFAN ROSEN of Huntington, N.Y., had given the chassis and transmission of his 1993 Dodge Dakota a thorough going-over long before he saw it. He spotted his $4,000 pickup among more than two million car listings on AutoTrader.com and flew to Detroit, where a representative of Extreme Dodge in Jackson, Mich., picked him up at the airport. Mr. Rosen test-drove the truck he had studied in high-resolution photographs online, bought it and drove it all the way home.

title: Experts Urge Tightening Of Safeguards In SARS Labs
description: An expert panel convened by the World Health Organization called on all countries yesterday to stringently oversee laboratory safeguards, to prevent another escape of the SARS virus like the incident that infected a research worker in Singapore in August.

title: U.N. Resolution Condemns Israeli Barrier
description: The General Assembly overwhelmingly approved a resolution late on Tuesday demanding that Israel tear down the barrier it is building in the West Bank to deter terrorist attacks.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEWARK: TREFFINGER ASSOCIATES SENTENCED Three men who were once close to James W. Treffinger, the former Essex County executive sentenced to prison last week, were spared prison time yesterday after cooperating with prosecutors. Mr. Treffinger, once a leading Republican politician in the state, was convicted on corruption charges growing out of his efforts to use his county post to propel himself to higher office. The three men were each sentenced by Judge John W. Bissell to three years' probation. Michael DeMiro, 57, of Verona, a Treffinger aide, was also sentenced to two months house arrest and 300 hours of community service. Rajashekar Ravilla, 40, of Denville, a former Essex County engineer, was sentenced to five months of house arrest and a $10,000 fine. Matthew Kirnan, 43, of Verona, a lawyer who managed Treffinger's 2000 Senate campaign, was sentenced to 300 hours of community service and a $3,000 fine. Jane Allande-Hession (NYT)

title: Coast to Coast, Across the Atlantic
description: SOMEWHERE deep in the kitchen of Mix in New York, a chef is struggling to get some attention. His name is Douglas Psaltis, and he has talent. His instincts are wholesome and honest. But he has a lot of visual and conceptual clutter to break through, courtesy of Alain Ducasse and Jeffrey Chodorow, two overheated imaginations working at full throttle to make Mix a nonstop thrill ride.

title: Sweet Sounds, Sinister Message
description: Over the last few years the indie-rock band Beulah, based in San Francisco, has gotten better and nastier. Once upon a time, this was a gently psychedelic group known for its sweet vocal harmonies, but Beulah's excellent new album, ``Yoko'' (Velocette), is one of the creepiest discs you'll hear all year, full of resentful (but still sweet-sounding) songs about breaking up.

The numbers reflect what Wall Street analysts have been saying for months: the company's cupboard of new blockbuster drugs is currently bare.

title: Hollandaise With Texture
description: HOLLANDAISE SAUCE, an emulsion of egg and butter, is supremely tempting, but it has two problems: It is overly rich and a bit of a hassle to produce. Fortunately, its flavor and spirit are captured in a leaner, more contemporary sauce that has its roots in the often bland but usually homey cooking of Eastern Europe, a sauce made with hard-cooked eggs, a relatively small amount of butter and some stock. Over plain steamed fish, it's a winner.

title: Washington Talk; Some Wholly New Work For Old Washington Hand
description: All last week, a stocky white-haired man could be seen prowling the corridors of the Capitol, a can of Diet Coke stuffed in his coat pocket, an American flag made of safety pins on his lapel. As he lumbered about, mingling with senators and reporters, he evoked an air of familiarity, as if he had been there a long, long time.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: FOOD GIANT BANS BIO-CROPS The Co-op, Britain's largest farmer, said it had decided to ban the growing of genetically modified crops and the use of altered feed on its 85,000 acres, even if the government insists they are safe. It will also ban the sale of altered food and ingredients at its supermarkets and make no investments in biotechnology companies through its bank. The company said a survey of its customers found that almost 80 percent said they would not knowingly buy food containing altered ingredients. "On the strength of current scientific knowledge and the overwhelming opposition of our members, the Co-op is saying `no' to the commercial growing of g.m. crops in the U.K.," said Martin Beaumont, the chief executive. (Agence France-Presse)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOURIHAN, MARGARET
description: HOURIHAN--Margaret. Died Monday October 20, 2003, at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Born in Hells Kitchen, NYC on August 24, 1907, daughter of Cornelius and Dora Hourihan. Sickly as a child, she was sent to Trudeau Sanitorium where she became interested in nursing and where she would later do her nurses training and work. Margaret joined The Army Nurse Reserve and was called to active service during World War II, where she distinguished herself and rose to the rank of Lt. Col. She retired after 20 years but remained active in her love of God, The U.S. Army, and nursing. Margaret returned to New York City continuing her nursing career at Memorial Sloan - Kettering Hospital from 1959 to 1969. She then worked for Dr. Chen in private practice until she moved to her family home in Grasmere, S.I., to take care of her ailing sisters, Mary and Julia, until their deaths. She was a generous member of St. Sylvester's R.C. Church. Her younger brother, Corneilious moved to the city with her while she was nursing him through his illness and death in 1997. Margaret was an avid stamp collector and member of charitable and mission organizations all over the world. She was also an active member of The Womens Overseas Service League, The American Nurses Association, The Knickerbocker Chapter and Manhattan Chapter of The NY Archdiocesan Council of Catholic Nurses. She was The Financial Secretary for The Retired Nurses until she was over 88 years of age. A generous member of St. Catherine of Siena R.C. Church, she made cancer pads for the comfort of the cancer patients at area hospitals. Margaret's life personifies the meaning of ''giving service.'' She will be waked at Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue between 69th and 70th Street on Thursday, October 23, 2003 from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, October 24 at 10 A.M. at St. Catherine of Siena R.C. Church. Interment Cemetery of The Resurrection, Staten Island, New York.

title: The Station Master; An Architect's Grand Vision for a Trade Center Transit Hub
description: In hiring Santiago Calatrava to design the new transit hub at the World Trade Center, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey thought large. And in his first public words about the project, Mr. Calatrava made it clear that he, too, would think large -- on the scale of Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station. Old Pennsylvania Station.

title: Is a Recall By Any Other Name Still a Recall?

The reason, they say, is that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, the federal agency responsible for protecting consumers, is allowing automakers to bypass the requirements of a standard recall in favor of a less-stringent procedure called a ''service improvement'' or a ''safety improvement,'' in which the carmaker does not admit to a safety-related defect.

description: The Yankees found themselves in another close game Tuesday night when third baseman Aaron Boone took a big swing at a ninth-inning slider and drove it into the left-field seats. Sound familiar?

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; On a Rainy Night, Jeter Lets the Sun Shine In
description: Josh Beckett pumped a 97-mile-an-hour, shoulder-high fastball past Derek Jeter in the first inning, making him look uncomfortable and whiffing him on three pitches. But, when Jeter returned to the dugout, he spotted Luis Sojo, the coach in waiting, and made a bold prediction.

title: Do-It-Yourself Lobster Pot Pies From Maine
description: Prolonging the taste of summer, a box arrives from Hancock Gourmet Lobster in Cundys Harbor, Me., via overnight express. Inside is a feast: fresh lobster meat and split-top buns, enough for six lobster rolls. Hancock also ships lobster pot pies, left, with a creamy sauce, chunks of lobster and buttery pastry in ceramic ramekins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KORNER, GESELEVITSH, ERNA
description: KORNER - GESELEVITSH -Erna. Died peacefully at home at age 102. Beloved wife of the late Solomon Korner, and the late Emanuel Geselevitsh. The last of the redheads. We will miss you. Barbara, Steven and Corey Lambert

title: Ohio's Turnpike Plazas Get A Mall-Like Makeover
description: ONE recent sunny afternoon, Max and Nelly Jaegar were sitting at the Vermilion Valley service plaza, drinking coffee and eating pastries from the Panera Bread restaurant.

title: The Times Announces Two Appointments
description: Stefano Tonchi, fashion creative director of Esquire magazine, has been appointed style editor of The New York Times Magazine. He succeeds Amy M. Spindler, who was named critic at large for culture and style.

title: A Mystery of Language, A Mystery of Murder
description: Frannie, the heroine of Jane Campion's ''In the Cut,'' is a writer and teacher who collects curious scraps of language: pungent specimens of slang, wayward metaphors, provocative jargon. When a homicide detective on the trail of a serial killer describes the body of a murder victim as ''disarticulated,'' Frannie's ears perk up. She jots the word down in a notebook and later on pesters him for a precise definition.

title: RadioShack Posts 27% Earnings Increase
description: The RadioShack Corporation, the electronics retailer, said yesterday that third-quarter earnings climbed 27 percent as the company reduced costs and sold more wireless phones and service contracts.

title: After Duel and Delay, Yankees Pour It On
description: Mike Mussina had earned his freedom of choice. There were two outs in the bottom of the seventh inning On Tuesday night, with a runner on second base for the Marlins, when the Yankees' pitching coach, Mel Stottlemyre, came to the mound to see Mussina.

title: 10 of the Movies' Most Memorable Roll Players
description: HOLLYWOOD loves Detroit, and anyplace else where cars are dreamed up. Why not? Car power is star power. Where would movies be without the automobile? Action pictures would be much shorter without car chases, for one. Teenagers would have to neck on park benches, and there wouldn't be road pictures, unless you count the ones with Conestoga wagons. Sometimes cars have the title roles; in other films they are scene-stealing supporting players, often as memorable as the actors. Remember the Mustang Fastback that Steve McQueen drove in ''Bullitt''? Here are 10 other movies in which the cars gave particularly moving performances. ANITA GATES

title: Dining Out? Let Your Friend Be Your Guide
description: To the Editor:

title: What Parents Can Do, Besides Fret, to Keep Children Safe
description: BAD things can happen when cars and children come together.

title: Pollution Fight Turns From Smog to Global Warming
description: THE next big regulatory battle between California and the auto industry will be over global warming.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bush Nominates Naval Chief To Serve Again
description: President Bush has nominated Adm. Vern Clark, the chief of naval operations, to serve two more years as the Navy's senior officer, the Pentagon announced. The armed service chiefs traditionally serve only one four-year tour, but the law allows them to be reappointed in times of national emergency. If confirmed by the Senate, Admiral Clark would be the first to have a chance to hold the position for six years since Adm. Arleigh A. Burke, who served from 1955 to 1961. Thom Shanker (NYT)

title: IRAN WILL ALLOW U.N. INSPECTIONS OF NUCLEAR SITES
description: Iran agreed Tuesday, after months of resistance, to accept stricter international inspections of its nuclear sites and to suspend production of enriched uranium, which can be used to develop nuclear weapons.

title: This Old Factory, Refurbished by Bob Vila and Others
description: Where pigeons once nested and squatters roamed free there are now designer furnishings and expensively buffed walls. Windows that once rested askew in a cracked brick faade now hang straight, while rotting floors once punctured by industrial chutes have been replaced by blond wood.

title: Nelson and Garcia Face Hearing
description: A hearing has been scheduled in Boston on Nov. 7 to decide whether the Yankees' Jeff Nelson and Karim Garcia should be charged with beating a Fenway Park employee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPRAGUE, GRETCHEN BURNHAM
description: SPRAGUE--Gretchen Burnham, 77, died on October 18, 2003. She was a graduate of the University of Nebraska Lincoln, 1947, and Columbia Law School, 1975. She was an attorney with the Brooklyn Legal Services Corp. B, from 1975-1986. She was also an author. Her young adult novel ''Signpost to Terror'' won an Edgar award in 1967. Recently, she wrote the three crime novels of the Martha Patterson series, published by St. Martins' press. She was active in the legal protection of the wetlands and watercourses of Philipstown, NY, where she lived for the last 16 years of her life. She is survived by her husband, Elmer and her children, Emily Leeds and Timothy. Memorial contributions may be made to The Constitution Marsh Sanctuary, Garrison, NY, 10524 or to The Desmond-Fish Library, Garrison, NY 10524.

title: U.S. Contends Qaeda Leader Executed Pearl
description: American officials said Tuesday that Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, once Al Qaeda's top operational commander, personally executed Daniel Pearl, a Wall Street Journal reporter who was abducted in Pakistan early last year. Mr. Mohammed had previously been linked to a militant group believed to have committed the murder.

title: Workers Feel Pinch of Rising Health Costs
description: As health care costs head into a fourth consecutive year of double-digit increases, employers are shifting a growing share of the burden onto people who make the heaviest use of medical services.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 3 about the writer's experiences as a student at the French Culinary Institute in New York misstated her tuition and fees. They were $25,750, not $28,000. The institute reported the error on Oct. 8; the writer was abroad, and this correction was delayed for research.

title: Nuclear Policy And North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article yesterday about President Bush's criticism of Mahathir Mohamad, the Malaysian prime minister, for his recent remarks attacking Jews misstated Mr. Mahathir's planned retirement date. It is Oct. 31, not a few months from now.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Budget Aided By Debt Refinancing
description: New York City will receive an additional $232 million through the refinancing of the Battery Park City Authority's $800 million debt obligation, aides to Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday. The money is a one-time source of revenue, and was agreed upon by the governor and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg this year as part of a plan to help the city close a multibillion-dollar budget gap. Under the Pataki administration, the authority's annual payments to the city from rents and leases has doubled to $60 million from $30 million. The authority raised more than $1 billion this month through a bond sale.

title: Hot-Dog Heaven: 4 Days, 40 Bikers And Buzz in Front
description: WHEN I step out of my shower unscathed on a warm August morning, I know it will be a safe day aboard my motorcycle heading toward Milwaukee. After all, haven't I read that many accidents occur in the bathroom? Still, I defy the heat, don a leather jacket, jeans, boots, gloves and a helmet, just in case. I also pack a new rain suit, as a talisman to ward off rain.

title: Roadside Giants: Icons That Are Large, Literal and Loved
description: ''PLEASE don't steal the teeth,'' read the sign at the Big Fish Supper Club in Bena, Minn., a 65-foot-long fish-shaped building modeled on a Minnesota muskellunge, a type of pike. But the souvenir hunters paid no heed.

title: The General Who Roared
description: Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld announced yesterday that the Pentagon was investigating speeches in churches by a high-ranking Defense Department official who called the war on terrorism a Christian battle against Satan and disparaged a Muslim adversary as an idol worshiper. The inquiry seems like a waste of time. Mr. Rumsfeld should remove the officer, Lt. Gen. William Boykin, as deputy under secretary of defense for intelligence, where he leads the effort to capture the people on a most-wanted list headed by Osama bin Laden and Saddam Hussein.

title: Wherever You Say, Yvonne, I Will Go
description: MY co-pilot's name, I like to think, is Yvonne. She is 25 or 35 and majored in math, geography and self-restraint. She is patient and forgiving, if anxious at times, comforting and unmistakably female in demeanor and pitch. I am sure of all this although she is a mere voice behind the furrow-free brow of a dashboard screen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENWALD, RAYMOND J.
description: GREENWALD--Raymond J. On October 18, 2003 at age 81. Ray left a beloved wife, Pearl, nephew James Kaye and his wife Meryl, his adored ''grandchildren'' Marissa, Mathew and Sarah Kaye, and loving cousins. Son of the late Samuel and Anne Greenwald, brother of the late Muriel Kaye. A life long resident of Manhattan and successful real estate entrepreneur whose fairness and humanity earned the respect and affection of colleagues, employees, tenants and everyone he met, and earned as well the devotion and friendship of his long-time assistant, Blanche Christian-Crawford. After WWII, when he served in the South Pacific as an Army Air Force Captain, he studied acting and directing before entering the real estate business, and becoming an owner of commercial real estate. He co-produced many Broadway and Off Broadway shows, most recently ''Enchanted April''. His intelligence, humor and generosity, even in illness will remain in the memory of all who knew him. Services were held. Shiva at his home, Wednesday 11AM to 9PM.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Orbitz Expects To Sell Shares At $22 Each
description: Orbitz Inc., an Internet travel company that has planned a public share sale for more than a year, said yesterday that it expected its initial public offering to be priced at $22 a share. Orbitz, which is based in Chicago, is owned by the nation's five biggest airlines. It did not indicate in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing when or how many shares it planned to sell. In July 2002, it filed to sell as much as $125 million of stock. Initial stock sales in the United States are picking up, encouraged by the 31 percent gain in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index since March 11. There have been 26 public offerings worth $3.97 billion in the second half of the year, compared with 12 worth $2.94 billion in the first half. Orbitz had a net loss of $5.3 million on revenue of $107.8 million in the six months to June 30, the filing said; in the period a year ago, it had a net loss of $16.5 million on revenue of $74.7 million. American Airlines owns 26 percent of Orbitz; Continental Airlines owns 14 percent; Delta Air Lines has 18 percent; Northwest Airlines owns 15 percent; and United Air Lines, a unit of UAL, has 26 percent.

title: Help Moves Out of the Dashboard and Into the Phone
description: IF you have an old cellphone and are lost, you might have a conversation that goes like this: ''Hi, can you hear me? I'm on Smith Street and I missed the turn for the highway. No, I don't see a Dunkin' Donuts. Can you hear me?''

title: Essence of Anchovy From the Amalfi Coast
description: IN June, July and August, Cetara, a village near Capri on the Amalfi coast of Italy, looks like any other postcard-pretty spot: the sea in impossible shades of blue, a backdrop of jagged mountains dotted with citrus trees and souvenir shops filled with the usual tourist bait.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOLBER, HELEN
description: KOLBER--Helen. On October 20, 2003, of East Brunswick, New Jersey, in her 97th year. Beloved wife of the late Aaron Kolber. Loving mother of Harriet & Gilbert Ehrenreich, Warren and Jane Kolber. Adored grandmother of Charlie, Elizabeth, Jennifer, Jill, Kenneth, Mark, Mindy and Sharon and special greatgrandmother of Adam, Allison, Amanda, Amy, Andrew, Emily, Matthew and Zachary. Graveside service October 22 at 1 P.M., at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Janice Rule, 72, Film Actress Who Became a Psychoanalyst
description: Janice Rule, an actress in film and onstage who became a psychoanalyst late in her career, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 72.

title: Time Warner Posts Strong Profit and Says AOL Is Recovering
description: Time Warner Inc., the giant media and entertainment company, reported a strong improvement in its third-quarter financial results today, telling investors that its slumping America Online Internet service had apparently hit bottom and begun to turn around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINKELSTEIN, SHIRLEY
description: FINKELSTEIN--Shirley. On October 21, 2003. Beloved wife of Jerry. Devoted and loving mother of Andrew Stein and James Finkelstein. Cherished grandmother of Paige, Eliza, Jennifer, Benjamin, Zachary, Jake, Gregory and Alexander, and great grandmother of Tia. Fond sister of Ruth Caine. Her kind, gentle, sweet and loving spirit will be missed forever. Funeral services today, 9:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St.

title: Ban on Videos for Oscar Voters May Be Lifted
description: Jack Valenti, the chief lobbyist for the movie industry, is expected this week to reverse an edict barring studios from sending videos of their films to Academy Award voters, two industry executives involved in the discussions said on Tuesday. The ban, instituted three weeks ago as an anti-piracy measure, touched off a revolt in Hollywood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POLSKY, HOWARD W.
description: POLSKY--Howard W. The Faculty, Advisory Council, alumni, staff and students of the Columbia University School of Social Work note with sorrow the untimely death of Professor Howard W. Polsky on October 20 at St. Luke's Hospital in NYC. A member of the School's faculty since 1961, he received his M.S.W. and Ph.D. from the University of Wisconsin. A distinguished educator, researcher and prolific author, his book ''Cottage Six, The Social System of Delinquent Boys in Residential Treatment'' is regarded as a social work classic. He made major contributions in the application of social theory to social work, organization development, effectiveness training and other fields of practice. He will be greatly missed by his professional colleagues, and his friends and students at the school. Deepest sympathies are extended to his wife, Dr. Ronnie Berger and the members of his family. Jeanette C. Takamura, Dean

title: Swift-Footed W.
description: On the eve of our invasion of Iraq, I went to ancient Troy in Turkey. It's a haunting spot, quiet and deserted, though if you scrunch up your eyes you may still catch a glimpse of Helen on the walls. Those walls include a gate that shows signs of having been widened -- or so my guide claimed, probably fancifully -- as if to accommodate a giant wooden horse.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Disputed Insurance Rule Upheld
description: The state's highest court yesterday let stand an administrative rule that the Pataki administration said helps reduce insurance fraud, but that some groups, including doctors, said makes it more difficult for auto-accident victims to get benefits. In 2001, the state superintendent of insurance, Gregory Serio, shortened deadlines for filing no-fault claims to 30 days from 90 days. A coalition of groups, led by the Medical Society of the State of New York, a doctor and patient advocacy group, sued to stop the change. In a 6-0 decision, the Court of Appeals affirmed two lower court decisions supporting the change. In the decision, Chief Judge Judith Kaye acknowledged that the new deadline might hurt some claimants, but concluded that the superintendent had the authority to make such a change. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: HCA SAYS LOWER MEDICARE PAYMENTS WILL HURT EARNINGS
description: HCA Inc., the hospital chain, said falling payments from Medicare and rising competition will hurt earnings in 2003 and in years to come. Full-year profit, excluding some costs and gains, may fall to about $2.56 to $2.60 a share from $2.68 last year, HCA said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call forecast a profit of $2.80 a share. HCA attributed the reduced forecast to lower Medicare payments for its most expensive patients, a change in its charity policy for uninsured people and an increase in unpaid bills. HCA, which is based in Nashville, also reported third-quarter results. HCA said it earned $306 million, or 61 cents a share, up from $200 million, or 38 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 11 percent to $5.47 billion.

title: STANDARD & POOR'S MAY CUT FORD'S DEBT RATINGS
description: The Ford Motor Company's debt ratings may be cut to the lowest investment grade by Standard & Poor's, which said yesterday that the company's automotive operations faced intensifying competition. Ford, based in Dearborn, Mich., reported a third-quarter net loss of $25 million last week, and most of the profit it has posted for the year has come from its consumer credit unit, Ford Motor Credit. The company was ''disappointed'' with S.& P.'s decision to put its ratings under review for a possible downgrading, the chief financial officer, Donat R. Leclair, said in a statement. Ford's long-term debt is currently rated BBB, two steps above noninvestment grade.

title: U.S. Erecting a Solid Prison At Guantnamo for Long Term
description: The detention facility here for prisoners captured mostly in the Afghanistan war is increasingly taking on a permanent air as the authorities are building a hard-walled traditional prison alongside the corrugated metal units that have housed detainees for nearly two years.

title: Composition in Service to a Poet's Words
description: The later poetry of Stanley Kunitz shuttles between an old man's autumnal weariness and a defiant love for a world he will not give up. He writes in plain-spoken confessional language that is rooted in daily life but that can coalesce at any moment to frame sudden glimpses of the infinite.

title: The Motor City And California: Is It Splitsville?
description: CALIFORNIA and the Motor City used to be the perfect couple.

title: Powell Says Sudan Is Committed to Ending Civil War
description: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt, Oct. 22  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell won a commitment from Sudanese negotiators today to reach an agreement to end the civil war in Sudan by the end of December. He then invited the parties in the talks to the White House to celebrate their settlement with President Bush.

title: Boo Heaven
description: Trick or treat...or tweed.

title: The London Shows
description: The London home and design shows last month revealed many eccentric but practical ideas.

title: And to Think I Saw It in a Show House
description: A worthy show house provides ideas that can be translated to any home.

title: Wireless Networking Products
Yankees Take Series Lead
description: Behind starting pitcher Mike Mussina, the Yankees cruised to a 6-1 win over the Florida Marlins, taking Game 3 and leading the series, 2-1.

title: A Showcase for Surgeries
description: Ten women proudly displayed their cosmetic surgery at a "coming-out" party in Long Island on Wednesday.

title: Global Faith
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Civilians Contradict Police in Shooting Case
description: Neighbors of Gidone Busch, who was killed in a police shooting in 1999, told a jury in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday that Mr. Busch was not lunging toward police officers with a hammer when he was shot, as officers have claimed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POLSKY, HOWARD W.
description: POLSKY--Howard W. All of Elem/Youth in Distress in Israel, staff, Board of Directors, professionals, colleagues, students, and friends in both Israel and America are deeply saddened by the sudden loss of Howard Polsky. Many of us have known and loved Howard since the beginning of Elem in 1982. Besides caring personally for him, and considering him our longtime friend, his professional interest and knowledge, his continuous involvement in all the important issues of Elem, and he and his wife, Ronni Berger's generous use of their professional expertise to positively expand the knowledge of so many Elem youth and Elem staff in Israel, all of this cannot be replaced. Howard was a distinguished educator, researcher, and author. We and the whole social work profession benefitted from his many books, such as the classic, ''Cottage Six, The Social System of Delinquent Boys in Residential Treatment.'' He made major contributions to the social work field and shared his immense knowledge regularly to better the lives of many Israeli troubled youths. He will be greatly missed, but often remembered by his lifetime of contributions to the field. Ann Bialkin, President

title: Bolivian Leader's Ouster Seen As Warning on U.S. Drug Policy
description: On a visit to the White House last year, President Gonzalo Snchez de Lozada told President Bush that he would push ahead with a plan to eradicate coca but that he needed more money to ease the impact on farmers.

title: Julie Connelly
description: The reporter answered questions about America's newest labor force as a companion to her article in the Working special section.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK SAYS NET INCOME TRIPLES
description: The Bank of New York Company said quarterly net income tripled as it set aside less money for bad loans. Net income in the third quarter rose to $260 million, or 34 cents a share, from $79 million, or 11 cents, a year earlier, the company said. The bank set aside $40 million for bad loans compared with $225 million a year earlier. Profit from continuing operations was 42 cents a share, matching the estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. The company reduced corporate loans on its balance sheet by 23 percent to $26.2 billion as of Sept. 30. Lending revenue before bad loan provisions fell to $284 million from $359 million.

title: With a Smile and a Joke, Rumsfeld Defends Iraq Memo
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  Pressed about the leak of a memo in which he questioned progress in the war on terrorism, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld brushed aside questions today with a wry smile, saying that defense secretaries were not instructed, upon taking office, to "cage your brain and stop thinking."

title: Slipping Into a New Shell
description: MIKE CHIN'S eureka moment came in an Ikea store, on a spring day in 2002.

title: Oregon Delays Bond Sale for Review
description: Oregon postponed a $2.09 billion taxable bond sale after a resident filed a complaint that challenged whether the state can legally sell debt to finance pension obligations.

title: Time Warner Reports Modest Gains for 3rd Quarter
description: Time Warner Inc., the largest media company in the world, reported a mixed bag of third-quarter financial results yesterday that modestly exceeded Wall Street's expectations.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Blog Bog

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZIRINSKY, NANCY S.
description: ZIRINSKY--Nancy S. We mourn the premature passing of our cherished sister and aunt. Nancy was a beautiful woman with a great spirit who always made a valiant effort to overcome more than her share of life's problems. In spite of everything she lived her life with great curiosity, enthusiasm and depth. She did many things, went many places and cared dearly about the people in her life, the welfare of others and the issues of the day. We love her and will miss her enormously. Olga, Hanna, Jacob, and John

title: Kenyas Judiciary Thrown Into Disarray by Inquiry
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 23  Kenya's judiciary has been thrown into disarray by a wide-ranging corruption inquiry that has many of the country's most brazen judges trembling under their robes.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: BellSouth Posts 46% Rise In Profit
description: Growth in its Latin America division and its long-distance and high-speed Internet services helped the BellSouth Corporation report a 46 percent jump in net income in the third quarter yesterday. That was welcome news for a company battling fierce competition in the telecom sector. As phone companies increasingly fight over customers looking for lower rates and more options, BellSouth has focused on its bundled packages of services that offer a one-stop communications shop. The strategy spurred the strong results. BellSouth, which is based in Atlanta, said it earned $936 million, or 51 cents a share, for the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with $640 million, or 34 cents a share, in the year-earlier period, which included hefty charges related to job and service cuts. Excluding one-time items -- charges related to asset impairment and foreign-currency transaction losses -- BellSouth said it earned $980 million, or 53 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call were expecting earnings of 50 cents a share excluding one-time items. Revenue rose 5.3 percent to $5.72 billion from $5.43 billion in the year-earlier period. Shares of BellSouth rose $1.22, or 5.1 percent, to $25.

title: Editorial Observer; What China's First Man in Space Should Learn From Cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin
description: I don't know how many of them remain, but when I was a correspondent in the Soviet Union in the 1980's, there wasn't a single city, town or even village across the entire 11 time zones that didn't have a Gagarin Street. Many also had Gagarin Squares, quite a few had Gagarin Institutes or Gagarin Schools, and many had Gagarin statues. Moscow's was a particular atrocity: a stainless steel Flash Gordon atop a soaring column in the center of a smoggy traffic circle.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Jury Deadlocked In Gravano Case
description: The jury considering allegations against a reputed Mafia soldier on charges of conspiring to kill Salvatore Gravano, the Mafia turncoat, sent a note to the trial judge late yesterday saying that it was deadlocked. But the judge, Allyne R. Ross, said she would instruct the jurors this morning to continue trying to reach a verdict. The note, sent on the second day of deliberations in the trial of Thomas Carbonaro, who prosecutors say is a soldier in the Gambino crime family, said that ''there will never be a unanimous vote'' and that the atmosphere in the jury room had become ''extremely hostile.''

title: Forget the Sequins; Give Me a Hammer
description: When these women dreamed of running away to join the circus, did they imagine they would be putting up the tent themselves?

title: LORAL GETS COURT APPROVAL FOR SATELLITES
description: Loral Space and Communications said it had won approval from a federal bankruptcy court in New York to provide three satellites for the Hughes Electronics Corporation's DirecTV and one satellite for the PanAmSat Corporation. One satellite will be delivered to DirecTV under an existing contract, Loral said. The other three satellites are new orders valued at more than $320 million, Loral said. EchoStar Communications, the nation's No.2 satellite-television service, had challenged Loral's request for court permission to build satellites for DirecTV, EchoStar's larger competitor. Loral filed for bankruptcy protection in July.

title: Science Panel Recommends Limits on Routine SARS Testing
description: An independent scientific advisory panel convened by the World Health Organization yesterday recommended against routine testing for the SARS virus unless a cluster of cases develops and all other infectious agents have been ruled out.

title: A Farmer Kills Another and Town Asks, How Did It Come to This?
description: On the cold evening that Tom Lyon's body was found dumped in an old well, hidden under two bales of hay, people here suspected an outsider had done it, maybe one of the drug dealers they had heard so much about lately, running methamphetamine around the rural Midwest.

title: Venture to Offer ID Card for Use at Security Checks
description: Americans hate to wait. But will they pay -- and submit to security screenings and even high-technology fingerprinting -- to avoid the long lines snaking behind checkpoints in airports, office buildings and sports arenas?

title: Elliott Smith, 34, Rock Songwriter and Singer
description: Elliott Smith, whose songs of despair and self-doubt made him a luminary of independent rock and earned him an Academy Award nomination, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 34.

title: Architects' Clashing Visions Threaten To Delay World Trade Center Tower
description: Only 10 months before groundbreaking is expected to take place for the Freedom Tower at the World Trade Center site, the master planner of the site and the architect for the tower's developer, who are supposed to be collaborating, have reached an impasse on how the skyscraper should look.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: G.O.P. In Disarray
description: Marty Ryall, chairman and chief executive officer of the Arkansas Republican Party, resigned amid growing uncertainty over the organization's financial health. The Federal Election Commission said last week that an Arkansas Republican fund-raising organization had exceeded by $330,000 the amount it could lawfully contribute to the unsuccessful 2000 re-election campaign of Representative Jay Dickey of Arkansas and said there were errors in other reports required of parties. Lawyers for the party are negotiating a fine with the commission. Several Republican legislators have called for an audit of party accounts. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday on the continuation of a front-page article about an order to restore the feeding tube of a Florida woman in a right-to-die case misstated her condition in some copies. She is brain-damaged, not comatose.

title: Columbia University at 250
description: On the campus of Columbia University, you feel both timelessness and breathlessness, a sense of traditions and accelerating change. The central task Columbia faces as it begins to celebrate its 250th anniversary is managing change.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: New Spy Gear Aims to Thwart Attacks in Iraq
description: The Air Force and the Army are working on a classified project to use new combinations of surveillance aircraft and other sensors, along with intelligence on the ground, to try to detect and counter the increasingly deadly ambushes against American forces in Iraq, senior Pentagon officials said on Wednesday.

title: Get(ting) a Job
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including advice on how to seek employment.

title: A Landmark Vote on Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Stiff Penalties Are Proposed To Rein In U.S. Drug Cheats
description: The governing body for track and field in the United States yesterday outlined a new anti-doping strategy that would penalize first-time steroid users with a lifetime ban and a fine of up to $100,000.

title: Civil Rights Leader Defends Role in Connecticut Pension Deal
description: On his first day on the stand in his own defense, a civil rights leader and former Republican candidate for secretary of the state said on Wednesday that he was hired as a legitimate consultant on a state investment deal and was unaware part of his fee would be funneled to Paul J. Silvester, then the state treasurer.

title: He Stores City's Past (Unless You'd Care to Buy It)
description: BRIAN G. ANDERSSON, the commissioner of the city's Department of Records, seems to be the personification of the stereotypical Irish pol: the bubbling bonhomie, the ''grip your elbow and tell a story'' instant familiarity, the bartender's round, merry and rosy face with a little mustache, and the office lined with pictures of himself with various famous people, even if he is kind of on the edge of some of the frames.

title: Guiyang Journal; A Match Made in Heaven, if You Have Enough Yuan
description: Zhang Jin's wedding this summer turned out to be even better than she could have hoped for. The S320 Mercedes-Benz escort. The banquet for 300 friends, relatives and business associates at the best seafood restaurant -- and, as an unexpected bonus, the splashy backdrop of a nearby skyscraper crowned by a miniature rooftop replica of the Eiffel Tower.

title: Enigmatic Fairy Tales With Uncertain Endings
description: As a choreographer, Susan Marshall delights in emotional situations but rarely tells straightforward tales. She was once again dramatically oblique in ''Sleeping Beauty'' and ''Other Stories,'' the New York premieres her troupe, Susan Marshall and Company, offered on Tuesday night in the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Satirist of Apartheid Finds New Target
description: In his earliest days as a satirist and showman, Pieter-Dirk Uys said, he was terrified that his lampooning of South Africa's apartheid government would land him in trouble, which it frequently did.

title: Jeter Tries to Keep His Predictions Quiet
description: Derek Jeter told Luis Sojo that he was ''going to get'' the Florida Marlins' Josh Beckett after Beckett struck him out in the first inning in Game 3 of the World Series. Sure enough, Jeter smacked three straight hits and started two rallies to help the Yankees stifle the Marlins, 6-1, at Pro Player Stadium on Tuesday night.

title: Greeted Coolly, Bush Urges Indonesia to Bolster Democracy
description: President Bush injected himself directly on Wednesday into Indonesia's struggle between democratization and Islamic fundamentalism, saying during a lightning visit that both peace and economic growth in Asia depend on Indonesia's success ''as a pluralistic and democratic state.'' Mr. Bush's three-hour stopover in the most populous Muslim nation was restricted for security reasons to Bali, the overwhelmingly Hindu resort island, and he traveled less than a mile from where Air Force One was parked on the tarmac.

title: Where the Great Outdoors Meets a Great Bathing Place
description: The Phytolab bathing space (above) by the French designer Matali Crasset at the Design Museum's exhibition ''Somewhere Totally Else: the European Design Show'' (through Jan. 4) is a stunner. Phytolab is made of interlocking Perspex squares, each holding a flowerpot with a growing plant that sits suspended half inside and half outside of the room; inside is a bathtub and a dressing table.

title: Bush Says He Disagrees With General's Remarks on Religion
description: President Bush said on Wednesday that he disagreed with comments by a top Pentagon general who had cast the war on terrorism in religious terms, but the Defense Department said the officer would not be reassigned.

title: Ex-Tyco Treasurer Testifies on Loans
description: A former Tyco International treasurer told a New York jury yesterday that she approved loans sought by the former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski, that did not conform with the rules of a company loan program he is accused of corrupting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, WILLIAM
description: GOLDBERG--William. Joyfully explaining the love for his trade, a righteous man said diamonds were smiles of G'd. Therefore with devotion he always made his diamonds the prettiest of all, extracting as much light and sparkle as they could possibly give. He was bringing them to life. He, himself was a diamond among men, his facets very defined, his cut was unique, constantly shining and ever sparkling with light and love. A light that came from within and brighter will shine forever. G'd must be very happy today, he got back one of his gems. To the Goldberg family, my sympathy and my love, Natan Volkmar

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Financial Community Supports Bush Re-election

title: Some Positive News Aside, Kodak's Quarterly Profit Falls 63%
description: Eastman Kodak, struggling to wring profits from digital products as film sales slide, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings plunged 63 percent from the quarter last year.

title: Authenticity, As Beethoven Whizzes By
description: The New York Philharmonic had hoped to be on tour now, but when the plans fell through, Lorin Maazel and the orchestra's management decided that the best way to fill these weeks was with a Beethoven festival: all nine symphonies and the five piano concertos, each with a different soloist. At a time when orchestras around the country are trying to push the boundaries of their programming, this seemed a supremely uncreative choice, a triumph of conductorial egotism and the desire for easy ticket sales over the prospect of renovation.

title: Rumsfeld Sees Need to Realign Military Fight Against Terror
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld has told military commanders that the Pentagon is ill suited to combat terrorism and suggested that a new, more agile security agency may be needed to overcome the global threat.

title: Clinton Announces Plan to Cut Cost of AIDS Drugs
description: Former President Bill Clinton announced today that his foundation has brokered an agreement with four generic drug companies to cut the cost of certain AIDS anti-retroviral drugs by about a third, and in one case, by half, for distribution in poor countries.

title: Sports of The Times; The End Comes With a Whimper
description: WHEN the end finally came it was neither ignominious nor classic. It was the bottom of the seventh inning at Pro Player Stadium. The Yankees were trailing the Marlins, 3-1. Roger Clemens threw a fastball on a 3-2 pitch to Luis Castillo, who took it for a called third strike. Clemens slapped his glove with his right hand as he walked from the mound toward the third-base dugout. The crowd of 65,000-plus fans cheered Clemens and summoned him from the dugout for a last curtain call.

title: Woody Allen's Memoir
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICE, REV. PATRICK J.
description: RICE--Rev. Patrick J., of the Order of Saint Augustine, age 84 died peacefully on Tuesday, October 21, 2003 at St. Joseph's Friary, Villanova, PA. Born in NYC, the son of Patrick Rice and Catherine Callan. He attended school in NYC and graduated from Manhattan College in 1941 with a degree in Business Administration. He entered the Augustinian Novitiate in 1943 and made first profession on September 10, 1944. He professed solemn vows in 1947 and was ordained to the priesthood in Washington, DC, on June 8, 1948. In 1949, he was assigned as an associate pastor at St. Nicholas of Tolentine Parish in Jamaica, NY and served there until 1955. He was assigned to Msgr. Bonner High School from 1955-1956. In 1956 he was appointed to Saint Mary's Hall, Villanova, as submaster and procurator. He was assistant director of the Augustinian Seminary Guild from 1958 to 1959. In 1959 he was assigned to Merrimack College, North Andover, MA, and he worked there as college procurator until 1965 and served on the Board of Trustees, from 1961 to 1966. In 1965, Fr. Rice came to Villanova University and he spent the next 34 years working at the university and living at the Villanova Monastery. Among the many offices and duties he had at the university was assistant procurator for the college, vice-president for student affairs, and executive vice president for administration. He retired from the university May 1, 1998. Fr. Rice was a quiet gentleman, a dedicated priest, a gracious brother, a keen administrator, and faithful confessor for the Villanova students. He assisted on weekends at various parishes in Pomona, NJ and later at St. Mary Magdalen in Rose Tree, PA. His love for the university and for the campus led him to oversee in detail the maintenance of the campus. He was well loved by the university's maintenance staff. Surviving is his sister, Theresa (nee Rice) Devine of Allendale. Visiting Friday, October 24, 2003 at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Ave, Wyckoff, NJ from 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:45AM at St. Elizabeth's RC Church, 700 Wyckoff Ave, Wyckoff, NJ. Interment Maryrest Cemetery, Mahwah, NJ.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: SafeNet To Buy Rainbow For $455 Million
description: SafeNet Inc., an Internet-security software company based in Baltimore, agreed yesterday to buy Rainbow Technologies Inc. for $455 million in stock, a move that triples SafeNet's revenue and expands its sales to government agencies. SafeNet will exchange 0.374 share of its stock for each share of Rainbow. That values Rainbow, which is based in Irvine, Calif., at $15.34 a share, or 36 percent above its closing price yesterday of $11.25. Shares of SafeNet fell $1.93, or 4.5 percent, to $41.02. It fell another $3.52, or 8.6 percent, to $37.50 in after-hours trading. SafeNet expects to issue 11.1 million shares. Rainbow's authentication technology will help SafeNet increase sales to existing customers, SafeNet said. Rainbow will also add about $70 million in government business and give SafeNet anti-piracy software applications for the consumer market, the company said.

title: INSURANCE COMPANIES GET VERDICT REDUCTION
description: MetLife and the UnumProvident Corporation won a $72 million reduction in an $85.7 million verdict awarded in April to an Arizona cardiologist who said the insurance companies unfairly denied her disability claims. The cardiologist, Joanne Ceimo, said a herniated disk in her neck prevented her from doing surgery and sued MetLife's General American Life Insurance and Unum's Paul Revere and Provident subsidiaries when her claim was denied. In April, a federal jury in Phoenix awarded Ms. Ceimo $85.7 million, including $79 million in punitive damages. MetLife and UnumProvident called the verdict excessive and sought to have it set aside. Judge Frederick J. Martone of United States District Court in Phoenix reduced the punitive damages to $7 million while denying the insurance companies motions to reverse the verdict. MetLife said it had appealed the decision, seeking dismissal of the entire award. UnumProvident said it intended to appeal.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Senate's approval of the first federal ban on a specific abortion procedure gave an outdated name for the advocacy group that is planning television advertisements criticizing the Bush administration for its support of the bill. It is Naral Pro-Choice America, formerly the National Abortion Rights Action League. (For a time the group was also called the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League.)

title: A Landmark Vote on Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: A Night Out in Moscow That Became a Nightmare
description: Most documentaries about terrorism subliminally warn that this could happen anywhere, anytime, to anyone, even you. ''Terror in Moscow,'' a documentary on HBO tonight about the siege of a Moscow theater by rebels from Chechnya, is chilling for another reason: its horrible, blundered denouement could have happened only in Russia.

title: J. P. Morgan Reports Gain In Net Income
description: J. P. Morgan Chase reported rising profits for the third consecutive quarter yesterday as the bank set aside less for potential loan losses.

title: Speaker Urges $12.9 Billion For School Building Projects
description: The City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, proposed yesterday that New York City spend $12.9 billion on school construction, renovation and repairs over the next five years, issuing a direct challenge to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who must propose his own education capital plan next month.

title: One Deadly Morning In Beirut
description: With the allied occupation of Iraq dominating the news, few Americans are likely to remember that 20 years ago today the United States suffered its most humiliating military defeat since Pearl Harbor. Early in the morning of Oct. 23, 1983, a truck loaded with six tons of explosives smashed into the Marine headquarters at Beirut International Airport. Two hundred and forty-one Americans were killed. I helped dig their bodies out of the rubble.

title: Apple's Latest 0.1 Adds a Lot
description: THE reputation of the personal computer has taken a horrible hit this year. Viruses have made headlines week after week. Spam now exceeds 50 percent of all e-mail. Hackers and academics have uncovered one Windows security hole after another, turning Microsoft into a frantic little Dutch boy at the dike without enough fingers. If the computer industry were a celebrity, it would hire an image consultant.

title: Senate Votes to Crack Down on Some Spam
description: The Senate on Wednesday agreed to crack down on the torrent of unsolicited messages clogging the nation's e-mail inboxes, voting unanimously to outlaw the methods used by most spammers and to allow the creation of a national do-not-e-mail registry.

title: Economic Boom in Albania Widens Gulf Between Rich and Poor
description: Once the exclusive domain of Communist apparatchiks who made this the most isolated country in Europe, Tirana's politburo quarter has undergone a radical transformation, becoming the hottest spot for night life.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the official closing of the United States air base in Saudi Arabia referred imprecisely to Security Council Resolution 688, which was part of the original basis for the Air Force's presence there to enforce a no-flight zone in Iraq. The resolution, passed in 1991, demanded that the government of Saddam Hussein stop attacks on Iraqi citizens and said the secretary general should use "all the resources at his disposal" to enforce that demand. The resolution did not specifically create the no-flight zone, although American officials regarded the resolution as the legal justification for it.

title: Gonzalez Homers and Marlins Walk Off
description: All season, Roger Clemens has been a man with a retirement plan, a pitcher on a recurring mission, a legend trying to leave the game he has dominated over the last two decades as a champion. Clemens has been pitching powerfully, trying to help the Yankees snatch one more World Series title, to allow himself to slip one more ring on his thick finger.

title: 2 Senior Executives Join New Agencies
description: Two senior executives are leaving for new posts. In the continuing reorganization of top management at Leo Burnett USA in Chicago, Ben Kline was named to fill the vacant post of chief marketing officer. Mr. Kline, 40, had been director for client services at Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., most recently supervising work on the accounts of Miller and Belvedere vodka. Mr. Kline's duties at Wieden & Kennedy will be assigned to other agency employees. Burnett is part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide division of the Publicis Groupe.

title: New Jersey Seeks to Stem Gang Violence
description: Denouncing the growth of violent street gangs in New Jersey, state legislators from Essex County on Wednesday proposed creation of both a task force to study why youths join them and a statewide office to repel the gangs.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: L-3 To Buy Vertex For $650 Million
description: Level 3 Communications Holdings Inc., a maker of military electronics, agreed yesterday to acquire Vertex Aerospace from Veritas Capital, a private New York equity firm, for $650 million in cash. Vertex provides aerospace and other technical services to federal government agencies including the Department of Defense, Air Force and NASA. The purchase is expected to close in December, L-3 said. The chief executive, Frank C. Lanza, is relying on acquisitions to meet a new goal of more than 22 percent annual sales growth this year, up from a previous goal of 20 percent. Vertex will be the company's second-largest acquisition, adding $800 million of sales and 12 cents a share to earnings. Its biggest purchase was the Raytheon Company's aircraft integration systems unit in March 2002 for $1.1 billion. Lehman Brothers Inc. was financial adviser to L-3, which is based in Broomfield, Colo., on the acquisition. Vertex was created after Veritas Capital bought a 70 percent stake in Raytheon Aerospace for $270 million in 2001. Veritas was started in 1992 by former Wasserstein Perella Group Inc. private equity chief Robert McKeon.

title: CONE MILLS ACCEPTS BUYOUT FROM W.L. ROSS
description: The Cone Mills Corporation, the denim maker, accepted a $46 million buyout bid from Wilbur Ross's W.L. Ross & Company under bankruptcy reorganization plans. The Ross company will also assume debts from Cone Mills, raising the offer's value to more than $90 million. The deal is scheduled to close by Dec. 31, Cone Mills said. W.L. Ross, based in New York, has said it plans to merge Cone Mills with the bankrupt Burlington Industries, another company that Ross is acquiring. Cone Mills sought bankruptcy protection last month.

description: To the Editor:

description: BASEBALL

title: Louise Day Hicks Dies at 87; Led Fight on Busing in Boston
description: Louise Day Hicks, the Boston public school official and City Council member whose opposition to busing to achieve school integration helped to polarize the city in the 1960's and made her a national symbol of racial division, died on Tuesday at her home in South Boston. She was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DULL, SUSAN
description: DULL--Susan on October 21, 2003 of Pt. Washington, NY. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Cousin of Gloria Ficalora, and aunt of Louis & Lena Giobbe. Sister-in-law of Homer Mensch. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Thursday 3-5 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass St. Peter of Alcantara RC Church, 9:30AM. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Donations in her memory may be made to the Port Washington Library Concert Series.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the opening of the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles mistakenly attributed a comment in some copies about the hall's symbolism. It was Supervisor Zev Yaroslavsky, not former Mayor Richard Riordan, who said, ''It's about possibility, it's about dynamism, it's about movement, it's about optimism, it's about upward mobility.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DURFEE, CARDER HAZARD
description: DURFEE -- Carder Hazard. The entire Treillage Ltd. family mourns the death of Hazard Durfee. An exceptional artist, a consummate gentleman, a great friend. John Rosselli Bunny Williams Howard Christian

title: PANEL FAULTS U.N. ON LAX SECURITY FOR IRAQ OFFICE
description: An independent panel appointed to investigate the bombing of the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad in August said on Wednesday in a scathing report that security breaches, inadequate security analysis and poor management left the organization vulnerable to attack.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: U.N. Curfew After Killings
description: The United Nations ordered its staff working in the breakaway Republic of Somaliland to remain in the capital city of Hargeisa and observe a 6 p.m. curfew in response to the recent murders of four international aid workers. On Monday night, gunmen killed two British teachers working for SOS Children's Villages, an Austrian charity. On Oct. 5, an Italian aid worker was killed in Borama, 80 miles northwest of Hargeisa. Owaw Abdiwahid Ukask, a Kenyan aid worker, was killed in the Gedo region last month. 'The deliberate targeting of aid workers threatens the lives not only of those who are trying help the Somali people, but the Somalis themselves, whose access to aid may be jeopardized if we can't do our work safely,'' said Maxwell Gaylard, the United Nations relief coordinator. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOALKIN, MURIEL
description: KOALKIN--Muriel. Age 79. Of California, formerly of New Jersey and New York, passed away October 19, 2003. Beloved mother of Barbara and Al, Sheila and Alan, and grandmother of Joshua, Eric and Justin. Devoted to her predeceased sister, Harriet. Dear aunt to Adrienne, Sharon and Andrew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERL, JOSEF
description: PERL--Josef. At the age of 90. Beloved husband of Sabina. Loving pappa of Mary and Ralph Gutt and Berndt and Gail Perl. Adoring opa to Michele, Jeffrey, Steven, Spencer, Sandra and Michael. Funeral Services in Israel.

description: ASIA

title: Indy League Driver Dies In a Crash
description: The Indy Racing League driver Tony Renna was killed yesterday morning after crashing during a tire test at Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

title: AT HOME WITH/Margo Howard; 'Dear Margo,' the Voice Still Says
description: ''THE phone,'' Margo Howard said, putting down her soupspoon and saying what she misses most since her mother's death last year. ''It's almost in your hand, and you say, 'No, she's not there.' I miss telling her what's going on.'' She smiled. ''But a girl's mother is always alive in her head.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LONGFORD, ELIZABETH
description: LONGFORD--Elizabeth. October 23, 2002. In memory of Elizabeth Longford, historian and beloved mother from her loving daughter, Judith Kazantzis

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Drug Maker's Profit Rises
description: GlaxoSmithKline said yesterday that pretax profit rose 50 percent in the third quarter from a year ago, to 1.66 billion ($2.81 billion), helped by sales of its asthma drug Advair. Overall sales rose 9 percent, to 5.5 billion ($9.27 billion). Generic competition for Paxil, Glaxo's antidepression drug, is expected to hurt sales in the fourth quarter, the company said. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Powell Says Sudanese Hope to Reach a Peace Accord This Year
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell won a commitment on Wednesday from Sudanese negotiators to reach agreement by the end of December to end the civil war in Sudan, and he invited the parties to the White House to celebrate a settlement with President Bush.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Assets Sold
description: The Elan Corporation, the drug maker, said it would sell four painkillers and related assets to AaiPharma Inc. for about $100 million. AaiPharma will also take over $51.4 million of product-related payments. Elan expects a pretax gain of about $30 million from the sale. Elan said it had now sold almost $1.9 billion of assets to pay down debt and focus on its new drugs

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOCHBERG, IRWIN
description: HOCHBERG--Irwin. On Tuesday, October 21, 2003 at the age of 73. Survived by his loving family, wife Ilene, children Carolyn, Steven and Gail, and Seth and Lindy, sister Sandra Lewen, grandchildren Hayleigh, Alex, Rachel and Daniel. Services Thursday, October 23 at 12:45PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St & Amsterdam Ave, NY, NY. Contributions in his memory to American Friends of Hebrew University, 11 East 69 St, Suite 400, NY, NY, 10021.

title: Pataki Seeks Two Inquiries In Canal Deal
description: Gov. George E. Pataki called Wednesday for investigations of a controversial deal that granted access to the Erie Canal, two days after the state comptroller accused state Canal Corporation officials of steering a contract to a favored developer and trying to cover it up.

title: SNIPER SUSPECT REGAINS LAWYERS
description: Two days after he fired his lawyers and took control of his own defense in the Washington-area sniper trial, John A. Muhammad reinstated them on Wednesday, telling the court that he thought it was in the best interest of his case.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Balanced Budget Postponed
description: The new financial secretary, Henry Tang, has postponed the government's self-imposed deadline for balancing the budget by two years, to the 2008-9 fiscal year. He cited economic harm from the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome last spring and a public desire for faster growth after six years of a mostly stagnant economy since Britain returned the territory to China in 1997. Mr. Tang hinted that low interest rates might tempt the government to issue bonds to pay some of its deficit, even though Hong Kong still had large reserves left from surpluses under British rule. The International Monetary Fund's deputy director for research, David Robinson, said the timing of a balanced budget was less important than a credible strategy for reducing deficits. Standard & Poor's, the rating agency, warned that the government had a narrow tax base that made it vulnerable to economic cycles, but said that it wanted to learn more about Mr. Tang's plans before commenting. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Cheap Drugs From Canada: Another Political Hot Potato
description: For years, just about the only Americans regularly buying drugs in Canada were thrifty gray-haired New Englanders. Now, with state budgets squeezed, it is the nation's governors who are demanding access to Canada's cheap drugs. Here in Kentucky, the issue has become central to a tight governor's race.

title: Amid Ruins of Iraqi Oil Wells, Investors See Field of Riches
description: After spending Monday listening to the captains of the Iraqi oil industry talk about the future, Alain Lechevalier was trying to cheer himself up with a sherry and memories of Iraq's past in the bar of the Hotel Intercontinental.

title: Politicians Scramble to Revive Peace Effort in Northern Ireland
description: Politicians struggled Wednesday to get the stalemated Northern Ireland peace effort back on track, a day after expectations of a breakthrough suffered a last-minute setback because of an arms dispute.

title: INVENSYS WILL SELL ITS METERING UNIT
description: Invensys, the British engineering company with debts of 1.6 billion ($2.7 billion), agreed to sell a United States metering business to a company backed by the Jordan Company, an investment firm, for $650 million, at the low end of its earlier expectations. Invensys is trying to raise 1.8 billion by selling half its businesses to cut debt and reduce a pension deficit. The company aims to focus on rail signals and factory controls like monitors used in the cement and oil industries.

title: Review by Federated Uncovers Questions
description: Federated Investors Inc. said yesterday that an internal investigation turned up possible improper mutual fund trading.

title: More Thoughts on Apples New Operating System
description: In todays "State of the Art" column, I reviewed the new version of Apples operating system, Mac OS X 10.3, code-named Panther. But there are 150 new features in Panther, and theres only so much you can say in 1300 words.
