The resolution, passed in 1991, demanded that the government of Saddam Hussein stop attacks on Iraqi citizens and said the secretary general should use ''all the resources at his disposal'' to enforce that demand. The resolution did not specifically create the no-flight zone, although American officials regarded the resolution as the legal justification for it.

title: Merry Pranksters From Tuscany
description: `Tuscan Dance in Movement,'' the festival of Italian modern dance at the John Jay Theater, concluded with boisterous clowning by the Sosta Palmizi Association of Cortona on Oct. 17 and dignified lyricism by the Florence Dance Company the night before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHUYLER, IRVING M.
description: SCHUYLER--Irving M. Age 94. On Tuesday, October 21, 2003. Devoted husband of 58 years of the late Pearl Bressler. Adoring father of Harvey Bressler Schuyler. Also surviving is a daughter Sandra Jaffee and a grandson Evan Jaffee.

title: Sheet Music to Set Tiny Hands a-Tinkling
description: LEGS dangling above the pedals, my 6-year-old had her first piano lesson the other day.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Head Named
description: The French government said yesterday that Christian Noyer, left, would lead the Bank of France, succeeding Jean-Claude Trichet who will become the head of the European Central Bank on Nov. 1. Mr. Noyer, a former vice president of the European Central Bank, has spent most of his career in the French treasury and has served as a ministerial adviser. Since the euro was introduced in 1999, the importance of central banks of member countries has decreased, because they no longer have responsibility for setting interest rates in their countries. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEON, MILDRED C.
description: LEON--Mildred C. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Nancy Gershon, Maryanne and Sander Lehrer, Dr. Robert and Nancy Leon. Loving grandmother and great grandmother of Russ and Alessandra, Andrew and Gail, Jill, Laurie, Jon, Rise, Marc, Michael, David, Luca, Sophie and Alex. Dear sister of Irene Zerchner and Edith Morrison. Funeral service Friday 10AM at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI. In lieu of flowers, kindly contribute to Tuberous Sclerosis Alliance, 801 Roeder Rd, Suite 750, Silver Springs, MD. 20910-4467.

title: Clark Outlines Plan for Taxes And New Jobs
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark on Wednesday outlined his plan for the economy, which he said would save more than $2.3 trillion over 10 years by repealing some of President Bush's tax cuts, eliminating government waste and managing the war in Iraq better.

title: Jury Ordered to Try Harder In Trial of Former Banker
description: The deadlocked jury in the trial of Frank P. Quattrone, the former star technology banker at Credit Suisse First Boston, resumed deliberations yesterday and asked for a copy of an e-mail message that the prosecution contends shows his role in allocating shares of initial stock offerings.

title: Marlins Rallying Cry: Remember the Cubs
description: MIAMI, Oct. 22  Josh Beckett remained defiant to the end, standing before his locker early Wednesday morning, taking questions on how the Florida Marlins could have lost behind him, their ace starting pitcher, when Beckett resorted to unusual logic. The Marlins had lost Game 3 to the Yankees, 6-1, falling behind in the World Series, two games to one, and Beckett said that the game had not been crucial to winning the Series.

title: The Devil's in the Details of a Hellish Account of War
description: FLYBOYS

title: Sports Briefing
description: PRO BASKETBALL

title: Harlem Looks Up, in Plans for 29-Story Hotel Tower
description: Harlem, which has everything from an Old Navy shop to a Disney store these days, has been without a major hotel since 1966, when the Hotel Theresa, where Fidel Castro once stayed while visiting the city, closed for good.

title: Bill Barring Abortion Procedure Drew on Backing From Many Friends of Roe v. Wade
description: Senator Blanche Lincoln, Democrat of Arkansas, considers herself decidedly in favor of a woman's right to abortion. ''I'm about 99 percent pro-choice,'' she says.

title: Merck, Its Income Shy of Estimates, Plans to Cut Jobs
description: Merck & Company, the nation's second-biggest drug maker, reported sluggish results for the third quarter yesterday and said it planned to cut as many as 4,400 jobs.

title: Scrutiny of Video Suggests Israelis Didn't See Gazans They Shot
description: An Israeli military official acknowledged Wednesday that an Air Force video appears to show Palestinians gathering in an alley near the site of a helicopter strike in the Gaza Strip, and that their presence could account for the high casualty toll in a missile attack on Monday.

title: Victim's Son Is Given Award for Forgiving Father's Murderer
description: A striking act of forgiveness for a gruesome murder earned Brandon Biggs a $10,000 college scholarship on Wednesday from an equally unlikely group of donors: prisoners on death row.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MELLO, JUDY HENDREN (SCHWAMM)
description: MELLO -- Judy Hendren (Schwamm). Judy: You have filled my life, and all the world, with love and happiness. You have fought the courageous battle. Undaunted, head upright, never without optimism and always with a joyful spirit. Wherever you have walked you have given forth love, caring and generosity and have been a source of comfort and inspiration to many. There has never been a mother who loved her children and grandchildren more or was more loved by children and grandchildren than you were. You helped them all grow and to become better and more caring people. You will be missed by all. A day shall never pass that your memory will not fill my heart with gladness for having had the joy and privilege of knowing and loving you. ''A woman of valour who can find? For her price is far above rubies. Strength and dignity are her clothing and she laugheth at the time to come. Many daughters have done valiantly but thou excellest them all.'' Everyone is searching the sky--looking for the newest and brightest star in the firmament. Jay.

title: Goodyear Tire Will Restate Earnings Dating Back to 1998
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said on Wednesday that it expected to restate as much as $100 million in earnings dating back to 1998 because of a series of accounting and billing errors.

title: Its Freedoms No Longer New, Russian Cinema Matures
description: At first glance the new Russian film ''Bimmer,'' about four car thieves who run afoul of gangsters in Moscow, is a routine exercise in mafia chic, post-Soviet style: leather jackets, flashy cars, copious blood.

title: Gadget Knows Grandma Inside Out
description: BEBE FARIDA RAOUF lives alone in Manhattan and, like many elderly people, fears a sudden injury or illness. When she recognized the symptoms of a heart attack four years ago, she called for help, lay down on pillows on her floor and left the front door ajar for paramedics.

title: Donors Meet to Help Iraq
description: Over the next two days in Madrid, the world's richer nations and financial institutions will announce contributions to the reconstruction of Iraq. They should be generous. Even those that opposed military action have a strong interest in making sure that the basic needs of the Iraqi people are met and that a secure and prosperous society emerges from the ruins of Saddam Hussein's tyranny.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Rich Color, Poor Flavor

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Push For I-95 Tolls
description: The State Department of Transportation will ask the Federal Highway Administration for permission to charge tolls on Interstate 95 to pay for improvements on the highway, the main north-south route on the East Coast. The department hopes to build six toll booths, charging $3 each, to recoup the $3 billion it spent for the upgrades in about 10 years, a department spokeswoman said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Metro Matters; Latecomer On Openness In Ferry Crash
description: IT took longer than New Yorkers would have liked, but at least the mayor and his appointees have recognized the public's need for information about last week's deadly crash of a Staten Island ferry and finally released the city's regulations for operating ferries.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about fuel sales in Iraq referred incorrectly at one point to subsidies for gasoline sales. They come from the United Nations oil-for-food program, not from United States taxpayers. In an appropriations bill, the Bush administration is proposing that American taxpayers subsidize them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIZER, LOUIS M.
description: PIZER--Louis M. on October 20, 2003 of Clinton, NJ. Retired Vice President of Sales for G.H.I. Health Insurance New York, NY. Beloved father of Mark, Gary, Glenn, Luanne & Patricia. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Jonathon, Vanessa, Michele, Billy & Christine. Friends may visit The Alexander-Tuthill Funeral Home, 6447 Rte. 25A, Wading River, Friday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral Private.

title: A Landmark Vote on Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Narrow Vote On Rates
description: The Bank of England came within a vote of raising interest rates this month, leading European markets to think that a rate increase is inevitable before the end of the year. The bank voted 5 to 4 to keep interest rates in Britain at 48-year lows of 3.5 percent. The minority voted to increase rates by a quarter of a point. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, SR. ELEANOR (AQUINAS)
description: BROWN--Sr. Eleanor (Aquinas), RSHM, 95, on October 22. Tarrytown, NY. Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary for 73 years. Educator in Los Angeles, Studio City, and Palos Verdes, CA; Tarrytown, NY; Boca Raton, FL; Kingston, England; Neuilly and Bougival, France. Pastoral minister in Richmond and Virginia Beach, VA. Survived by sister-in-law Jean Owens Brown of Sand Point, Idaho, and many nieces and nephews. Visiting Friday, 3-7PM; Mass Saturday, 10:30AM; both at Marymount Convent, Tarrytown, NY. For additional information, please contact me at 914-329-2277 (cell) or 914-631-8330 (office).

title: INSIDE
description: How Abortion Bill Passed

title: City Says Man Bilked Clients In Home Improvement Projects
description: For those unfamiliar with the classic home improvement horror story, here is a primer: Contractor gives reasonable estimate on renovation; contractor inevitably finds ''unexpected'' problems that double the time and money originally estimated; contractor does shoddy work, collects money and abandons the job, leaving the home looking like a wreck.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Policemen Resign Over Racism Film
description: Five police constables resigned after an undercover television documentary on racism showed one of them wearing a homemade hood similar to those used by the Ku Klux Klan and saying Hitler had the ''right idea.'' The constable was also filmed saying that he would kill an Asian if he could get away with burying the body under a train track. The documentary stunned senior officers, particularly those in North Wales and northwestern England where the documentary was made by a BBC reporter using hidden cameras. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Free Advice to G.O.P.
description: Republicans seem to think they don't have to think when it comes to Iraq. They only have to applaud the president and whack the press for not reporting more good news from Baghdad -- and everything will be fine. Well, think again.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: More Peacekeepers
description: Prime Minister Jos Mara Aznar announced a $54 million spending increase to add troops for the Civil Guard, a militarized police corps, and other law-enforcement bodies, noting the Guard's increased role in international peacekeeping missions. The proposal came just days after Mr. Aznar announced plans to increase military spending to modernize the Spanish armed forces. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: The Price of a Textbook, Here and There
description: To the Editor:

title: Class-Action Legislation Fails in Senate
description: Senate Democrats effectively killed a measure on Wednesday that would push certain class-action lawsuits out of state courts and into the federal judiciary, handing President Bush and the Republican leadership a significant defeat.

title: The Times's New Look
description: To the Editor:

title: A Landmark Vote on Abortion (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Groups Offer E-Mail Guidelines
description: In the latest effort to preserve e-mail messages as an advertising medium, three online organizations issued guidelines yesterday to discourage unsolicited commercial e-mail, often called spam.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Pornographer In Plea Deal
description: Al Goldstein, the outspoken pornographer, brought to a close yesterday his rancorous 20-month legal saga, in which he was accused of harassing a former employee over her decision to resign. Mr. Goldstein pleaded guilty to a minor offense below a misdemeanor for harassing his former assistant by, among other things, sending her unflattering depictions of her that had appeared in his sex magazine, Screw. Last year, Mr. Goldstein was convicted on five misdemeanor charges of aggravated harassment, but in July of this year, an appeals court panel unanimously reversed the verdict on the ground that Mr. Goldstein had been denied a fair trial. As part of a plea agreement, Mr. Goldstein apologized yesterday to his former assistant in court and was credited for the six days he spent in jail. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about third-quarter earnings for AT&T and SBC Communications misstated AT&T's operating profit for the period a year ago. It was $525 million, not $458 million.

title: 2 Goals in Final 5:23 Beat the Devils
description: Each shot that clanged off a post seemed to be a warning. A shot that slid wide was an ominous sign.

title: Survey Finds Even Split in Support for Teams Among Those Who Care
description: Regardless of how the World Series turns out, in the world of public opinion, the teams are dead even. Some fans are ''tired of seeing reruns'' while others consider the Yankees' success over the years as proof that ''they're the best.'' Then again, a lot of people would rather be watching football.

title: A Home for Family Photos With an Internet Address
description: Digital photographs are a great way to share your adventures with family and friends over the Internet, but not if your picture files are so enormous that they clog a dial-up connection, become scrambled in transit, or are translated into a format that your relatives cannot open.

title: For a Perfect Companion Just Flip the On Switch
description: There were many innovative lamps at the London design shows, but few had the charm of the Doglight (below). Its designers, the Back4 team, call it the ''ideal city companion.'' The Doglight can't fetch, but it can play dead. It won't cost you vet fees, either, just the occasional bulb. The 15 1/2-inch-high pooch (14 3/4 inches long) is made of translucent sheets of polycarbonate and uses one small, internal light bulb.

title: Redskins Slipping Away From Spurrier
description: In a week marked by futile play, criticism, doubt and confusion, the Washington Redskins added one more chapter on Tuesday morning.

title: City Tells Political Donors: Skip Those Who Starve Us
description: For years New York officials have complained that the state sends more money to Washington in taxes than it gets back in aid. And for years New York City has been an epicenter of fund-raising for politicians from across the nation, with New Yorkers donating some $153 million to federal candidates and national parties in 2000 and 2002.

title: CONGRESS STRIKES A TENTATIVE DEAL ON DRUG BENEFITS
description: House and Senate negotiators said on Wednesday that they had agreed on the structure of prescription drug benefits to be offered to 40 million elderly and disabled people in the biggest expansion of Medicare to date.

title: Ikea Index Indicates the Euro Is Not a Price Equalizer Yet
description: That a storage chest sold by the Swedish home furnishing giant Ikea costs 59 percent more in Austria than in the United States is perhaps not surprising, considering the countries are on different continents and have different currencies, taxes, inflation, labor laws and interest rates.

title: Tour de France Course Unveiled
description: As he watched on the big-screen television in Paris during the closed-circuit presentation yesterday of the route of the next Tour de France, Lance Armstrong's jaw seemed to drop a little when the 16th of 20 daily stages was unveiled. He later called it "probably a day that will decide the Tour."

title: National Briefing | Education: Big Man On Campuses: Bush
description: President Bush's approval rating among college students is as high now, 61 percent, as it was in April, according to a new survey released by the Harvard University Institute of Politics. The president's overall approval rating has declined by more than 20 percent percentage points during the same period. Still, more college students say they consider themselves Republican than Democrat, the study showed; students who classified themselves as independents outnumbered those in either party. The Harvard survey, a nationwide telephone poll of 1,202 students, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus two percentage points. Jonathan Marino (NYT)

title: Drawing PC, TV and Stereo Into an Entertainment Loop
description: WHEN it comes to storing digital photos, editing video and downloading music files, computers are useful tools. But compared with even a modest home entertainment system, a computer is terribly inadequate when you want to display photos, play a movie or listen to music.

title: In Uniform, Mocking Islam
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinian Gunmen Kill Suspected Informants for Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 23  Masked Palestinian gunmen carried out execution-style killings at dawn today of two fellow Palestinians suspected of being informants for Israel, then placed their bodies in the central square of the Tulkarm refugee camp in the West Bank.

title: Waste Management Pair to Pay $4 Million
description: Former Waste Management Inc. executives Rodney Proto and Earl DeFrates have agreed to pay a total of $4.2 million to settle insider-trading and other charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Expos Closer to Agreement
description: Major League Baseball and the Players Association are close to an agreement that would return the Montreal Expos to San Juan, P.R., for 22 games next season, a person close to the negotiations said Wednesday. An agreement could come within 10 days; that would fit in with the hope of the commissioner's office to resolve the issue shortly after the World Series.

title: For Woods, Nelsons Cuts MarkIs in Sight
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Oct. 22  While pursuing another victory this weekend, Tiger Woods is poised to set another record.

title: Scorning the Courts in Florida
description: Drawing the line between life and death is one of society's most challenging tasks. Florida's courts discharged that duty admirably when they ruled that Terri Schiavo, who has been in a vegetative state for 13 years, should be allowed to die. But the State Legislature and Gov. Jeb Bush have mocked the courts' careful deliberations and embarked on a ghoulish medical journey by directing that her feeding resume. The courts should reaffirm Ms. Schiavo's right to die in peace.

title: In a Sign of Stronger Finances, American Airlines Reports a Profit
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, reported a profit yesterday of $1 million in the third quarter, a sign of a weak recovery in the air travel industry. But company executives and analysts warned that a much slower business season is ahead.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Gruesome Columbine Rehearsal
description: A 15-minute videotape of the Columbine gunmen using trees and bowling pins for target practice weeks before their 1999 high school shooting rampage was made public by the Jefferson County Sheriff's Office. The video was made about one month before the school shootings and shows the gunmen, Eric Harris, above, and Dylan Klebold, with the weapons they used to kill 12 classmates, a teacher and themselves on April 20, 1999. ''Imagine that in someone's'' brain, Mr. Harris says as he fires a round. The gunmen are joined in the video by two other men who have since been convicted of supplying the guns. The tape was released as part of an effort to have more evidence from the case made public. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Rooms Dressed in Novelty and New Ideas
description: For most visitors, a decorator show house is a reverie, a chance to walk through the pages of a glossy design magazine. But a worthy show house provides ideas that can be translated to any home. Such is the case with the International Designer Show House, held in an 1876 row house (left) at 59 East 77th Street. The show house, a benefit for the American Hospital of Paris, is open through Nov. 16. Admission is $20; for information, (212) 838-0157.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHENCK, DORIS D.
description: SCHENCK--Doris D. Mrs. Doris D. Schenck, of Southbury, Connecticut, died in her home on Tuesday, October 21. She leaves two children, John C. Schenck of New York City and Anita Zednik of Santa Fe, NM; six grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Smith College Alumnae Fund.

title: Appeals System Is Urged for Regents Exams
description: A member of the State Board of Regents said at a legislative hearing Wednesday that an appeals system should be created to allow students who fail Regents exams to graduate from high school if they can show solid performance in their classes and meet other criteria.

title: Playing His Hand, Torre Wins Once But Loses Later
description: Three World Series games are being played under National League rules this week, and Yankees Manager Joe Torre, a onetime National League manager, seemed to look forward to the possibility of games' turning into cagey chess matches.

title: Jack Elam, Lazy-Eyed Movie Villain, Is Dead
description: Jack Elam, whose leer, bulging eye and precise acting skills transformed him from an accountant into one of the movies' most identifiable villains, died on Monday at his home in Ashland, Ore. Most published sources list him as 86.

title: Times Should Lose Pulitzer From 30's, Consultant Says
description: A Columbia University history professor hired by The New York Times to make an independent assessment of the coverage of one of its correspondents in the Soviet Union during the 1930's said yesterday that the Pulitzer Prize the reporter received should be rescinded because of his ''lack of balance'' in covering Stalin's government.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: And Won't Rush Be Pleased To Get a Card

title: In Florida Right-to-Die Case, Legislation That Puts the Constitution at Issue
description: In enacting a tightly focused, one-time-only law that effectively reversed a series of court decisions allowing a Florida man to withdraw life support from his brain-damaged wife, the Florida Legislature has created a constitutional crisis, legal scholars said yesterday.

title: They Got It in Surgery. Now They Flaunt It.; Nose Jobs and Implants on the Runway
description: With music throbbing and her proud family looking on, Amanda Draizin, 16, strutted down a runway, wearing a little black dress and her brand new nose. Corrine Hernandez showed off her breast implants. Roslyn Kaufman displayed her slimmed-down stomach and wrinkle-free eyelids.

title: Selig Advises Patience
description: With Barry Bonds of the Giants and Jason Giambi of the Yankees subpoenaed to appear before a federal grand jury investigating a drug company that may be the source of a new steroid, Commissioner Bud Selig advised patience on Wednesday.

title: Economic Scene; Rising productivity is a good thing, right? Tell that to the newly unemployed.
description: RECENTLY productivity has been growing at a rate of about 4 percent a year. For the country as a whole, this means that each year we can work as much as we did last year and consume 4 percent more; or we can consume as much as we did last year and work 4 percent less.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the custom-made ambulances purchased by the New York City Fire Department misidentified the union that has a hand in shaping the bid specifications. It is the one representing emergency medical technicians, not firefighters.

title: Design Eye for the Sales Guy
description: STANDING in the middle of a $10 million apartment at Time Warner Center, the not-quite-finished luxury condominium complex on Columbus Circle, Louise Sunshine surveyed the Central Park views, Chinese porcelain lamps, Empire chairs, mahogany doors and a table piled with expensive art books. ''We could easily increase the price to $20 million,'' she said of the apartment, which is on the market. ''You could easily be standing in John D. Rockefeller's apartment in 740 Park Avenue, which traded for $37 million.''

title: The Mullahs and the Bomb
description: With much fanfare, and the reluctant endorsement of the Bush administration, Iran has vowed to suspend its controversial effort to produce enriched uranium -- which can be used as fuel in nuclear weapons -- and to clear up a host of suspicions about its nuclear program. In exchange, the foreign ministers of Britain, France and Germany promised new ''cooperation'' -- meaning trade -- in high technology with Tehran. While perhaps getting any concessions out of the mullahs should be seen as a step forward, this particular deal won't prevent Iran from making the bomb. It also risks having the same outcome as the deal North Korea made in 1994 and later violated, and threatens to drive a wedge between the United States and its European allies on Iran policy.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: 10 DEAD, 23 HOSPITALIZED IN POISONING A mass poisoning at a lunch held after a farmer's funeral in Yuanbao, a town in central Hubei Province, killed 10 people and left 23, including the man above, hospitalized, state news media said. Investigators suspect the food was tainted with a powerful rat poison. Scores of people have been killed in China over the last two years in attacks linked to feuds or business disputes, all involving the same banned brand of rat poison.    (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLARD, CHARLES E.F.
description: MILLARD--Charles E.F. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Charles E.F. Millard, a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. John H. FitzSimons, Pres. Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: India Proposes Steps Aimed at Normalizing Ties With Pakistan
description: India's foreign minister announced a dozen proposals on Wednesday to revive stalled efforts to normalize relations with Pakistan.

title: Roy A. Anderson, 82, Chief Who Revived Lockheed Profit
description: Roy A. Anderson, who as chairman and chief executive of the Lockheed Corporation steadied and rebuilt the floundering company in the late 1970's and early 1980's, died on Saturday at his home in California. He was 82.

title: Two Unlikely Heroes Save the Marlins
description: Carl Pavano had been sent to the bench for the ninth inning, his masterwork seemingly complete. Ugueth Urbina, the Florida Marlins' closer, only needed to finish it off and Pavano would have a victory in Game 4 of the World Series. That never happened, however, and Pavano had to reserve his celebration on a night when he had outdueled Roger Clemens.

title: The 3-D Laptop's Secret? A Skewed Double Screen
description: First-person shooter games and other software that promise 3-D effects have never quite delivered on the sensation of depth, at least not without 3-D glasses, but such software was bound by the confines of a conventional 2-D screen.

title: Testaverde Prepares To Hand Over Controls
description: Hanging in Vinny Testaverde's locker is a very short list of the other players who were drafted in 1987 and remain in the league. There are just three on the list, and the quarterbacks on it, Steve Beuerlein and Rich Gannon, are injured.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Maneuvers By Suspended Chief Justice
description: The state's suspended chief justice, Roy Moore, has asked five of the nine members of the Court of the Judiciary to disqualify themselves from deciding whether he is to be permanently removed. He said some of them were biased, some of their terms had expired, and some had been discourteous. He said one lawyer on the panel, James North, was biased against one of Chief Justice Moore's lawyers from interaction with him in previous trials. The court denied Chief Justice Moore's request that the state attorney general, Bill Pryor, who will prosecute the case, recuse himself as well. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Ex-Member Of Council Goes on Trial In Fraud Case
description: As he ran for Queens borough president in the fall of 2001, Sheldon S. Leffler was ''obsessed with the fund-raising aspects of the campaign'' and turned to fraud to try to raise more money, a prosecutor said yesterday as Mr. Leffler's trial on conspiracy charges opened.

title: Picture This: From Absence Comes Light
description: Yosuke Watanabe designed the Silhouette floor lamp (left) while a student at Buckinghamshire Chilterns University College. Mr. Watanabe was among the design-school students who were handpicked for the first Undu Graduates show in London earlier this year. He also won a British Council award. Mr. Watanabe was one of seven Undu graduates exhibiting at 100 Percent Design. His Silhouette light, 43 inches high and 20 inches wide, is actually fiberboard with a lamp-shape cutout; the bulb is suspended behind and shines through canvas stretched over the cutout. There's also a wall model, a cutout of a chandelier. For information: www.undugraduates.co.uk.

title: U.S. Faces Skepticism at Conference on Funds for Iraq
description: MADRID, Oct. 23  Bush administration officials expressed growing confidence today that they would raise large sums of aid to reconstruct Iraq at a donors conference here, but they also faced intensive questions about whether Iraq's security troubles would prevent at least some of the money from being spent.

title: Council Threatening to Block Cathedral's Landmark Status
description: City Council officials say they are poised to reject the landmark status granted to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, hoping to prevent the construction of large new buildings on the grounds surrounding the church, a 111-year-old Gothic structure in Morningside Heights.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HOLNESS, ELSA
description: HOLNESS--Elsa. October 23, 1985. Always loving in God; forever loved in God. Nieces Shirley and Lorraine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAVES, JOHN C.
description: GRAVES--John C., 65, died of heart failure on October 13. Graduated from Buckley, Collegiate and Princeton University and received a Ph.D. in Philosophy from Princeton. Taught philosophy at M.I.T. Became a psychotherapist in Boston and Ft. Lauderdale. Survived by a sister, Emily Graves Jones and three nieces, Virginia, Catherine and Leila and his partner, Raymond Trevino. Donations may be sent to The Stonewall Library or The Sunshine Cathedral, both in Fort Lauderdale.

description: ELAHI--Cyrus One With Love In His Heart Never Dies

title: Illegal Immigrants Arrested at Wal-Mart Stores
description: Federal officials arrested more than 300 illegal workers at 61 Wal-Mart stores around the country today after an investigation that focused on janitorial crews employed by outside contractors.

title: People
description: * Robert Thompson was named to the new post of senior vice president for finance at the Interpublic Group of Companies, New York. He will report to Chris Coughlin, chief financial officer, and was brought on to help further improve the agency company's financial systems, Interpublic said. Mr. Thompson had been senior vice president at Pharmacia, which was acquired by Pfizer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HENDERSON, HARRY B., JR.
description: HENDERSON--Harry B., Jr. Saturday, October 25, 2003, at 2 PM, Croton Free Library, 171 Cleveland Drive, Crotonon-Hudson, New York.

title: Ex-Freddie Mac Chief to Cooperate With Inquiry
description: Federal regulators announced today that they had entered a consent decree with the former Freddie Mac executive David Glenn, under which he will pay a $125,000 fine and cooperate with an ongoing investigation of the company's accounting.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ELLENBOGEN, JOAN L.
description: ELLENBOGEN--Joan L. You are remembered. Marcia

title: Margaret Murie, 101; Helped Save Wilderness
description: Margaret E. Murie, a conservationist and an author who helped preserve millions of acres of unspoiled land in Alaska and across the United States by encouraging the creation of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and the passage of the Wilderness Act, died on Sunday at her ranch in Moose, Wyo. She was 101.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAILEY, LLOYD LEE
description: BAILEY--Lloyd Lee. Funeral services for the award-winning designer and author Lee Bailey, 76, of New York City, will be at 2 P.M. Saturday, October 25, in the chapel of Hixson-Ducote Funeral Home, 302 St. John Street, in his native Bunkie, LA. Visitation will begin at 1 P.M. and burial will follow in the family plot at Pythian Cemetery.

title: Police to Review Video That Appears to Show Officers Kicking Suspect
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that the department's Internal Affairs Bureau would review a videotape that seems to show officers kicking a suspect during an arrest. The tape was broadcast Tuesday night by Channel 2, the local CBS affiliate.

title: Start a Movie in Your Office, Finish Watching on the Road
description: Virgin, the British company, has announced a new line of personal entertainment products that includes an array of portable devices. At the high end of the line, called Virgin Pulse, is a portable hybrid TV-DVD player whose features make it a good fit for the kitchen or the automobile.

title: Shoring Up the Signal Of a Faltering Network
description: Q. My 802.11b wireless network cannot reach from one end of my apartment to the other. Is there a way to extend its range?

title: Rangers Don't Want Lindros to Ease Up
description: Given the choice of having Eric Lindros play his trademark wrecking-ball style with the risk of injury, or having him play an injury-free season on the perimeter, as he did last season, which was his most unproductive one, Rangers Coach Glen Sather did not vacillate.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ARKANSAS: G.O.P. IN DISARRAY Marty Ryall, chairman and chief executive officer of the Arkansas Republican Party, resigned amid growing uncertainty over the organization's financial health. The Federal Election Commission said last week that an Arkansas Republican fund-raising organization had exceeded by $330,000 the amount it could lawfully contribute to the unsuccessful 2000 re-election campaign of Representative Jay Dickey of Arkansas and said there were errors in other reports required of parties. Lawyers for the party are negotiating a fine with the commission. Several Republican legislators have called for an audit of party accounts.

title: WEBMD TO PAY $280 MILLION FOR MEDIFAX-EDI
description: The WebMD Corporation, which operates health information Web sites and manages transactions between doctors and insurers, has agreed to buy Medifax-EDI for $280 million to improve its data collection ability. The cash-and-debt deal is expected to close late next month, WebMD said. Medifax-EDI, which is closely held and based in Nashville, provides services that help verify insurance coverage for patients quickly and will be combined with WebMD's Envoy unit, it said. WebMD has spent $400 million in 12 months on acquisitions while shedding other assets to focus on its primary businesses.

title: A Moon Palace for the Hollywood Dream
description: Walt Disney Concert Hall, the new home of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, is a French curve in a city of T squares. The T squares are loving it madly. Why shouldn't they? Disney Hall was designed for them. It's a home for everyone who's ever felt like a French curve in a T square world.

title: Poison Found At Post Office; No Tie Is Seen To Terrorism
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating a letter containing a deadly poison, ricin, which was found late last week in an airport postal office in Greenville, S.C., administration officials said Wednesday.

title: Game 3 Rating Is Up From 2002
description: The rain-interrupted Game 3 of the World Series between the Yankees and Marlins on Tuesday night on Fox attracted an average of 18.9 million viewers, up 11 percent from the comparable Anaheim-San Francisco broadcast last year.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Taking a While to Heed Opportunity's Knock
description: Robert N. Serros was one of those entrepreneurs who see opportunity everywhere but take a long time to grasp it.

title: In New Ads, Dean Becomes First in Campaign to Attack Fellow Democrats
description: Howard Dean this week began running two new television advertisements that criticize his rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination as ''Washington politicians'' who have failed to deliver prescription drug benefits and were inconsistent on the Iraq war.

title: Durst Tells Murder Case Jury of His Life on the Run
description: Robert A. Durst, the New York real estate scion on trial for the shooting and beheading of a 71-year-old neighbor, told a rapt courtroom on Wednesday how he came to this faded island on the Gulf of Mexico and donned a woman's wig after learning that detectives had reopened the investigation into the disappearance of his first wife 21 years ago.

title: Texaco Goes on Trial in Ecuador Pollution Case
description: When Ren Arvalo draws water from his well, it is brown and gummy, requiring him to run it through a makeshift filtering system outside his wood-plank home in the jungle outside this town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FITZGERALD, LIBUSE O. (LIBY)
description: FITZGERALD--Libuse O. (Liby), 84, of Valhalla, formerly of Eastchester, NY, died on October 21, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Loving mother of Eileen (Paul Rosenblum) Fitzgerald and Kevin (Linda) Fitzgerald. Cherished grandmother of Leona Rosenblum. Liby was an accomplished ceramicist, Liby also gave generously of her time to community services and organizations. She will be greatly missed by her family and many friends. Service at Westchester Funeral Home in Eastchester on October 25th at 11 AM. Visitation Thursday 7-9 PM and Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Casting an Online Net For Priests and Nuns
description: JOHN KLEIN sold software for a living until one day in 1996 when he went online and suddenly found himself on the road to the seminary. One year later he had left his high-powered job, sold his townhouse in the Chicago suburbs and given away most of his possessions and was living in a dormitory room studying theology. Five years after that, he was ordained a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Keep Your Eye on the Ballerina in This Modern Dance
description: Daniel Catanach was appointed dance director last year at the Henry Street Settlement Abrons Art Center, following in the illustrious footsteps of Louis Johnson and Alwin Nikolais. Mr. Johnson came to the settlement as an established choreographer. But Nikolais, who died in 1993, used it as a laboratory to develop his pioneering modern-dance style. Judging from the program presented there by Mr. Catanach's Urban Ballet Theater on Oct. 17, the Settlement could profitably serve as a similar crucible for Mr. Catanach.

title: Blow It Up, Set It Down And Invite the In-Laws
description: The London home and design shows last month provided an instructional display of young (and some not-so-young) designers, many of whom exhibited a preference for eccentric but practical ideas. The shows, which were divided into two major parts -- Designers Block (more experimental) and 100 Percent Design (more commercial) -- proved that good design and whimsy need not live in separate worlds. An exhibition of recent European design at the Design Museum (which had a great view of David Blaine inside his cube) emphasized the combination, displaying jet engines next to paper dresses.

title: A Prosperous Russian City Is Also Fatal for Journalists
description: ''The City of Dead Journalists,'' a Moscow newspaper has called this automobile capital on the Volga. Freedom of speech, it seems, is under the gun.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Pulling Out Of Terrorism Database
description: Gov. Sonny Perdue pulled the state out of a multistate law enforcement database after the state attorney general said it would be illegal to transfer driver's license records to it. The database, known as Matrix, for Multistate Antiterrorism Information Exchange, is being developed and managed by Seisint Inc., of Florida, in partnership with the Florida Department of Law Enforcement, and contains records of criminals as well as ordinary citizens, including Social Security numbers, vehicle registration data and some credit information, officials said. Several other states have pulled out, citing cost and security concerns, including Kentucky, Oregon and South Carolina. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Poll Finds Smoking Ban Popular
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's smoking ban may have made him one of the most cursed men in city barrooms, but a poll released yesterday found that the ban was popular with most New Yorkers. The poll, by Quinnipiac University, of registered city voters found that 62 percent support the smoking ban, while 35 percent oppose it. The poll also reported that 42 percent of respondents said they approved of the job the mayor was doing, while 47 percent said they disapproved. It is the first time Mr. Bloomberg's approval rating has topped 40 percent in the poll since last winter. Voters praised the mayor for the smoking ban and for his handling of crime, but criticized his handling of the budget, taxes and the area he has staked his mayoralty on: the public schools. Maurice Carroll, the director of the Quinnipiac University Polling Institute, said that the poll showed that the smoking ban, which has often been described as a political liability for the mayor, is turning out to be a plus for him. The poll, conducted Oct. 16-20, surveyed 887 registered city voters. It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chip Maker's Profit Rises

Net income rose to a higher-than-expected 6.07 billion yen ($55 million) from 3.67 billion yen a year earlier. Sales in NEC's second quarter, which ended Sept. 30, fell 8 percent, in line with analysts' expectations.

Or that the audience liked them better when they were playing bebop. Or that their instincts don't excite other people as much as themselves.

title: Beyond Love, But Coming From the Heart
description: Sooner or later self-absorption has its limits. Most of the time Fran Healy, Travis's songwriter, sang about loneliness and the loves who got away. But on Travis's new album, ''12 Memories'' (Epic/Independiente), Mr. Healy has started to look beyond private troubles to public affairs, in one more unexpected pop repercussion of the campaign against terrorism and the invasion of Iraq.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Group Claims Police Harassment

In a complaint filed yesterday in federal court against the city and the police, the civil liberties union said the police were using an antiloitering statute to stop the group from leafleting near school grounds. The civil liberties union contends that the police have ''arrested and threatened to arrest young people who have engaged in protected activity.'' A spokeswoman for the city's corporation counsel said the office had not yet been served with a formal complaint and could not comment.

title: Horrors! Mysticism May Never Be The Same
description: Anyone who hasn't seen ''Signs,'' ''The Ring'' or the first two ''Matrix'' films may be baffled by much of ''Scary Movie 3,'' the third installment of the comedy franchise whose jokes derive largely from references to recent hit films. Where the first two episodes took aim at teen horror movies like ''I Know What You Did Last Summer'' and the ''Scream'' series, this time the main targets are an inch or two more elevated: the supernatural claptrap of blockbusters that take themselves far too seriously. The maniacal destruction wrought should satisfy moviegoers (like me) who found ''Signs'' a big nothing and ''The Matrix Reloaded'' an impenetrable mess.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BECKEY, SYLVIA LOUISE
description: BECKEY -- Sylvia Louise. Lawyer and international businesswoman, died October 20, 2003. Born February 8, 1946, in Lynwood, California, she graduated from New York University (LLM), Duke University (JD) and University of Texas at Austin (BA), and was Salutatorian and voted ''Most Likely to Succeed'' at high school graduation. After government service with the Library of Congress and as a law clerk for Judge Mary Johnson Lowe, an assistant Corporation Counsel for the City of New York and a staff member of the Securities & Exchange Commission, she handled international matters, bringing to China the Clio Awards Winners Reels in l999, and the Clio Awards Ad China Show & Exposition in 2000. A member of St. Bartholomew's Church in New York City and St. Vincent De Paul Catholic Church in Houston, Texas, she is survived by her mother Rita J. Beckey, her brothers Colonel Andrew D. Beckey and Arthur J. Beckey, her sister Rita D. Cinquemani, and numerous nieces and nephews. She will be deeply missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDENTHAL, MEYER ''MIKE''
description: FRIEDENTHAL -- Meyer ''Mike''. During a battle in France, American GI's lay wounded on a mine field. Dr. Meyer ''Mike'' Friedenthal, a young medical officer, volunteered to lead a rescue. One soldier in his squad lost a foot to a mine. But all returned alive, bringing home the wounded. Mike received the Silver Star for his valor. A gifted diagnostician, Mike was a hero to his patients too. Many of them, too poor to pay their bills, received loans instead. Mike never bragged. Even his movie star looks seemed unexceptional to him. At 90, having suffered a stroke, and confined to a wheel chair, Mike died of heart failure. Mike is survived by his two sons, step-daughter, step-son, three grandchildren and wife, who loved him and always will.

title: Knicks Face Roster Decisions

After scoring just 60 points against Utah on Thursday night in a loss to close out the exhibition schedule with a 2-6 record, the Knicks have just three practices left in which to heal, to sort out the roster and perhaps to add a shooter before their season opener Wednesday.

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: FORECASTERS EXPECT GEOMAGNETIC STORM A strong geomagnetic storm with the potential to affect electrical grids and satellite communications was expected to hit Earth today. One of the largest sunspot clusters in years developed over the past three days and early Wednesday produced a coronal mass ejection, similar to a solar flare, forecasters at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said. The disturbance was expected to result in a geomagnetic storm with an aurora visible as far south as Illinois and New York.    (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Deflation Slows
description: After nearly five years of falling prices that have hurt the property market and contributed to unemployment, there are signs that deflation is coming under control. The monthly average price drop was 0.3 percent for July through September, in contrast to 0.6 percent from June through August. Consumer prices were 3.2 percent lower last month in Hong Kong than a year earlier, less of a drop than in August, when prices were 3.8 percent below the level of August 2002. Rising prices for fresh vegetables and women's outerwear were the biggest contributors to the slowing of deflation. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

A successor from outside the company, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., has been chosen and will be announced in December, said Julia Bentley, a spokeswoman for the company. Steve Sadove, vice chairman of the company, will take over in the interim.

title: Decoding Rumsfeld's Memo
description: Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld is a master of relentlessly upbeat progress reports on the Pentagon's military gains against terrorism. So it was startling to see his real assessment in a memo circulated last week to top military officials, and then publicly released this week. Mr. Rumsfeld questioned whether America was ''winning or losing the global war on terror'' and asked whether an institution as big as the Pentagon was capable of changing itself fast enough to win. The results so far in shutting down Al Qaeda, he concluded, have only been ''mixed.'' Progress in hunting down top Taliban leaders, he noted, has also been relatively slow.

title: Modernist Prophets Of Disparate Arts
description: Before the advent of recordings, musical revolution was necessarily a local event, and on Jan. 2, 1911, the revolution went to Munich. It began about 15 minutes into a performance of Arnold Schoenberg's Second String Quartet, when the music floated shockingly free of tonality. Moments later a soprano sang an upward-soaring phrase, with the now-famous words from a Stefan George poem, ''I feel the air of another planet.'' People started fidgeting, and later laughed and hissed; others applauded vigorously. But most curiously of all, one man began to paint.

title: Problems on Space Station Stir Debate About Safety
description: NASA officials acknowledged yesterday that air, water and radiation monitors, medical devices and some other systems on the International Space Station were ailing or broken.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Associates Posts $9.9 Million Profit
description: Network Associates, the maker of McAfee computer-security software, yesterday reported third-quarter net income of $9.9 million, or 6 cents a share, on revenue of $226.9 million. Results in the same period a year earlier are not comparable because the company next week will complete a restatement of 2002 results to reflect a change in the way it books revenue, the company said in a conference call. Fourth-quarter profit will be 20 cents to 22 cents a share, on sales of $255 million to $260 million, the company said. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a profit of 21 cents a share and sales of $256.7 million. Shares of Network Associates fell $2.15, or 14 percent, to $13.18.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: New Zealand: Air Alliance Rejected
description: Regulators in New Zealand rejected a proposal for the Australian airline Qantas to acquire 22 percent of Air New Zealand for $300 million. The New Zealand Commerce Commission said the terms of the bid were anticompetitive, ''against public interest'' and likely to raise fares up to 20 percent as well as cut service between Australia and New Zealand. Australian regulators have also rejected the proposal. Qantas and Air New Zealand said they would consider an appeal. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway's 3rd-Quarter Loss Widens
description: Gateway, the money-losing personal-computer maker whose stock has dropped 93 percent since its peak, had a wider third-quarter loss as fewer consumers bought PC's and sales declined 21 percent. The net loss expanded to $136.1 million, or 43 cents a share, from $46.9 million, or 15 cents a share, a year earlier, Gateway said yesterday. Sales declined to $883.1 million from $1.12 billion. Shares of Gateway fell 35 cents, to $5.75, in extended trading after the announcement. They fell 5 cents, to $6.10, in regular trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENRY, JACK D.
description: HENRY--Jack D. Died suddenly at home on September 25. Mourned by his sister Patsy Sillyman, two nephews, three grand nieces, a grand nephew and many friends.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Captain Accused Of Impaired Driving
description: A police captain was arrested and suspended from duty yesterday after being charged with driving while intoxicated, the police said. The captain, Robert Iovino, a senior officer in a Manhattan detective bureau, was off duty and driving his own car on the Bronx River Parkway in Westchester County when he hit another car, the police said. There were no injuries, they said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: SPRINT REPORTS $498 MILLION LOSS The Sprint Corporation yesterday posted a third-quarter net loss of $498 million because of write-downs. Shares of the PCS wireless unit tumbled after customer additions missed goals. Sprint's loss compared with net income of $519 million a year earlier. The company, based in Overland Park, Kan., said its revenue fell 1.2 percent to $6.71 billion, as long-distance sales declined for an 11th consecutive quarter. Wireless subscriber additions were about half of what analysts forecast. Shares of Sprint PCS fell 91 cents, or 17 percent, to $4.41. The shares that track Sprint's long-distance and local division, known as FON Group, rose 16 cents, to $15.90.

title: Shell's Net For Quarter Falls Below Estimates
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group reported third-quarter earnings on Thursday that missed analysts' estimates in part because of one-time factors; the company said that it would not make its production targets this year.

title: European Court Tells Unilever It Can't Restrict Store Freezers
description: In a ruling that could have implications across the European Union, the European Court of First Instance said on Thursday that the British-Dutch food group Unilever was restricting competition in the fiercely contested market for ice cream bars in Ireland.

title: Iraqis on the Sidelines
description: In pressing their request for nearly $20 billion for reconstructing Iraq, Bush administration officials have been invoking the Marshall Plan, as President Bush himself did when he addressed the United Nations General Assembly last month. L. Paul Bremer III, who heads the Coalition Provisional Authority in Iraq, did the same when testifying before Congress. In fact, however, such invocations are highly misleading, and the Congressional conferees who are shaping the final version of the Iraq appropriation bill would do well to review what made the Marshall Plan a success -- and how the Bremer plan may be headed for failure.

title: Marlins Looper Shows Old Form at Right Time
description: MIAMI, Oct. 23  The turn of events was not lost on Braden Looper. Looper lost his job as the Florida Marlins' closer in the final week of the regular season as Florida played some of its best baseball, seemingly a misfit among all the feel-good stories. Yet early Thursday, there was Looper saving the Marlins from falling behind, three games to one, in the World Series.

title: More Than Rococo Pinups Among Boucher's Drawings
description: Rococo, the dominant artistic trend of 18th-century France, has its apologists, but for a modern audience it remains a puzzling and not easily acquired taste. Everybody loves Watteau, the first Rococo artist, whose moody, enigmatic romance still captivates. But who, other than scholarly specialists and professionally eccentric contemporary painters like John Currin and Lisa Yuskavage, really cares about the acres of decorative froth painted by Boucher, Fragonard and their ilk?

title: A Delightful Throwback to Concerts of an Earlier Era
description: The case of the pianist Menahem Pressler provides yet more evidence for the theory that chamber music can keep a person youthful and sharp. Mr. Pressler turns 80 in December, and is still a vivid and effervescent presence in the Beaux Arts Trio, which he co-founded in 1955. It may also help that Mr. Pressler has staffed the ensemble with younger players; one was barely born when the trio celebrated its 20th anniversary.

No amount of misguided effort is going to help.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Briton Guilty Of Running Prostitution Ring
description: Margaret MacDonald, a Briton, was found guilty of running an international prostitution ring and was sentenced to four years in prison. She was arrested last year in a Paris hotel room, where the police found computer records for 538 women and 36 men who are accused of working for her agency, European Escort Service. Ms. MacDonald, 44, reportedly holds several business degrees.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Airline Posts Profit
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said yesterday that it earned 90 million euros ($106 million) in its second quarter, helped by cost-cutting programs and staff reductions but continued to warn investors about several problems, including passenger anxiety about the SARS virus and potential terrorist attacks. KLM, which recently agreed to a merger with Air France, earned 86 million euros in the period a year earlier. Operating profit for the quarter, which ended Sept. 30, fell 7.1 percent, to 131 million euros. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: A.I.G. Says Net Rose 27% in Quarter
description: The American International Group, one of the world's biggest insurers, reported a nearly 27 percent increase in net income for the third quarter, as prices for its insurance have been rising and claims costs have been declining.

title: Family's Case Against Police Is Bolstered
description: When a city emergency medical technician pulled up in an ambulance on the Brooklyn street where Gidone Busch had just been shot by the police in 1999, he asked a group of officers if everyone was O.K., he testified yesterday. Yes, was the answer from a police sergeant, except for a small bruise on the sergeant's arm, he said. It was only then, the technician told the jury, that he noticed on his own that someone was bleeding to death on the sidewalk.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Cosmetics Merger
description: Two of Japan's largest cosmetics companies, the Kao Corporation and Kanebo Ltd., will merge their cosmetics divisions by March 2007. The new company will share production and sales. As a first step, Kanebo will spin off its cosmetics operations by next March. Kao will then take a 49 percent stake in the new company. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: EUROPEAN COURT REJECTS TRADEMARK ON DOUBLEMINT
description: The European Court of Justice rejected an attempt by the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company to register Doublemint as a trademark, overturning a previous ruling that favored the company. The court, the highest legal authority in the European Union, said Doublemint could not be registered because the term describes the product. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Senator Clinton Accuses Pataki of Stalling Antiterrorism Aid at the State Level
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton accused Gov. George E. Pataki on Thursday of failing to give local governments in New York State the money they need to defend themselves against terrorist attacks.

title: Clinton Group Gets Discount For AIDS Drugs
description: Former President Bill Clinton announced yesterday that his foundation had brokered an agreement with four generic drug companies to cut the cost of certain AIDS antiretroviral drugs by about a third, and in one case, by about half, for distribution in poor countries.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

description: Anyone who has spent time in Northern California knows that many people consider Oakland the region's ugly sister, spurned by suitors in favor of the more refined attractions of San Francisco.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Party Expels Lawmaker Over Iraq Remarks
description: George Galloway, a Labor member of Parliament who gave an interview to Abu Dhabi TV in which he said Prime Minister Tony Blair and President Bush attacked Iraq ''like wolves,'' complained that Arab armies were not putting up any resistance and urged British soldiers to disobey orders was expelled from the party. A member of Parliament since 1987, Mr. Galloway, 49, denounced his two-day hearing as a ''political show trial.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Briefing | United Nations: 5 Nations Win Security Council Seats
description: Algeria, Benin, Brazil, the Philippines and Romania were elected to fill the next set of vacancies among the 10 nonpermanent seats on the Security Council. They will begin their two-year terms on Jan. 1. Kirk Semple (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 22 about the official closing of the United States air base in Saudi Arabia referred imprecisely to Security Council Resolution 688, which was part of the original basis for the Air Force's presence there to enforce a no-flight zone in Iraq. The resolution, passed in 1991, demanded that the government of Saddam Hussein stop attacks on Iraqi citizens and said the secretary general should use ''all the resources at his disposal'' to enforce that demand. The resolution did not specifically create the no-flight zone, although American officials regarded the resolution as the legal justification for it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, BILL
description: GOLDBERG--Bill. The members of the Diamond Dealers Club mourn the passing of Bill Goldberg, one of our industry's giants. A DDC member for nearly half a century, Mr. Goldberg was a President and Honorary President of our Club. A trusted colleague, and successful businessman, Bill's commitment to the highest standards of integrity and leadership will be sorely missed by all who knew him. His dynamic guidance of our industry is irreplaceable. Our sincerest condolences to his wife Mrs. Lili Goldberg, and to the Goldberg family. Jacob Banda, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PURNELL, RICHARD
description: PURNELL -- Richard. We mourn the passing of Richard Purnell, husband of Marguerite Purnell, trustee of the Central Park Conservancy and co-founder of the Women's Committee. Mr. Purnell was a great friend of Central Park and a committed supporter of the Conservancy's work for over 20 years. He and Maggie were a driving force in the renaissance of the Central Park we know and love today. Mr. Purnell, a Princeton graduate and decorated officer in the Army Air Force, enjoyed a distinguished 35-year career at Johnson & Higgins that culminated in his retirement as Chairman in 1981. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Maggie and their family. The Board of Trustees Central Park Conservancy A.J.C. Smith, Chairman Regina S. Peruggi, President

Few artists have pursued self-portraiture with his intensity and gift for role-playing, and in three different mediums: painting, drawing and etching.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Meriden: Judge To Review Juror Remark In Scruggs Trial
description: A hearing will be held next week on whether one member of the jury that convicted a mother of creating a home environment so unhealthy that it helped lead to her son's suicide is himself guilty of misconduct. The mother's lawyer said the juror's comments were grounds for a mistrial. Evidence of juror misconduct could also result in overturning the conviction. Superior Court Judge Stephen F. Frazzini will hold a hearing on Oct. 31 on possible misconduct in the trial of Judith Scruggs, 52, above, who was convicted on Oct. 6. After the verdict, Vincent Giardina, a member of the six-person jury, told The New York Times that he supported a conviction in part because he did not want Ms. Scruggs to sue the city if she were acquitted. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: U.S. Is Confident Conference Will Produce Enough Donations to Rebuild Iraq
description: Bush administration officials expressed growing confidence Thursday that they would raise large sums to reconstruct Iraq at a donors conference here. But they faced persistent questions about security troubles in Iraq and accountability for spending decisions that could put a damper on contributions from some countries.

title: Kandinsky and Schoenberg, Seen and Heard on Canvas
description: When it comes to ''Schoenberg, Kandinsky and the Blue Rider'' at the Jewish Museum, we can be grateful on two counts. First, in a time when recorded music often wafts through museum exhibitions, the organizers of this show have refrained from making us listen while we look -- even though they might have claimed every right to do so. The show examines a historical intersection of art and music: the friendship between the Viennese Modernist composer Arnold Schoenberg and the Russian Modernist painter Wassily Kandinsky.

title: Party Speeds Across Atlantic to Say Cheerio to Concorde
description: ON BOARD THE CONCORDE, Above the Atlantic, Oct. 24 - Flight attendants waltzed down the aisle with glasses of champagne just as Concorde broke the sound barrier this morning.

title: Professors With No Flash and Shows With Too Much of It
description: For many years, as he was forging his reputation as a playwright, A. R. Gurney was also a college professor, and in recent plays like ''Human Events'' and ''The Fourth Wall'' he has portrayed campus denizens in not-so-flattering terms. The academic life he depicts is an insular one, the academics themselves self-absorbed and self-important. They behave almost as if they were performing for an audience.

description: Silver is gold for the guilty. Or so you might conclude from the introduction to ''Viennese Silver,'' the handsome new show at the Neue Galerie. title: 3 Israeli Soldiers Killed in Attack in Gaza Strip

title: In Refusing Case, State's High Court Ends Chance for Class-Size Referendum
description: A ballot measure that could have led to smaller classes in New York City public schools effectively died yesterday -- at least for this year -- when the state's highest court refused to review a lower court ruling.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Grows
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus grew a slower-than-expected 4.8 percent in September from the month a year ago. Exports increased for the third consecutive month, but imports grew even faster, partly because of the yen's continued rise against the dollar. The surge in imports suggests that net exports may contribute less than forecast to Japan's gross domestic product in the July-September quarter. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: New York's Top Dog? It Depends on the ZIP Code
description: Maybe you can't judge a book by its cover, but it sure looks as if you can judge New Yorkers by their dogs.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: The Blustery and Visceral Arise From a Brisk Approach
description: Zoltan Kocsis's Bartok recordings have established him as one of the best current interpreters of that composer, but they also may have unfairly eclipsed his other strengths. Earlier in his career, this 51-year old pianist's affinity for Bach and Liszt were more frequently noted, and a victory in a Beethoven competition in 1970 was his first professional milestone. For his recital on Oct. 16 at the 92nd Street Y, Mr. Kocsis set Bartok aside and offered sonatas by Beethoven and Schubert, and a set of character pieces by Liszt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPENCER, BRYAN
description: SPENCER--Bryan. Born Scituate, MA., 1949. Died New York City, October 19, 2003. A life-long artist and lover of art in all its forms. Graduated McGill University with a degree in Music Composition and held a Ph.D. in the school of courageous survival. Performer, poet, composer, lyricist, brother, uncle and friend. Bryan gave all he had to give, always. He is survived by brother Pete, sister-in-law Marilyn and nephews Scott and Shawn. We love you Bryan: Marilyn and Norm Bartner & family, Dale Soules, & Peter Randsman. Viewing Friday, October 24, 2-5 and 7-9PM, Buckley Funeral Home, 445 W. 43 St, N.Y.C.

title: Carrying a Brother's Torch, Shakily; Davis in Tough Race to Win Council Seat Vacated by Murder
description: In the days after James E. Davis was murdered in the City Council chambers of City Hall, there was an outpouring of shock, grief and a stream of tributes for Mr. Davis. Into this well of emotion and good will walked the slain councilman's brother, Geoffrey A. Davis, a political novice with a troubled past who was determined to win James's seat and carry on his legacy.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about the popularity of Nascar racing omitted the identity of one network that holds television rights for races. In addition to NBC and Fox, TNT has bought rights to some events.

title: A Happy 21-Year Marriage of 'Figaro' and Its Rotating Set
description: John Cox's turntable-mounted staging of Rossini's ''Barbiere di Siviglia'' has been a solid crowd-pleaser since the Metropolitan Opera unveiled it in 1982. And with 21 seasons behind it, it looked as fresh as ever when it returned to the repertory on Monday evening. As a piece of staging, it works with well-oiled efficiency, the set rotating to show a variety of interiors and exteriors of Dr. Bartolo's house, as well as a tavern and Figaro's shop. One almost expects to see an Alan Ayckbourn play as an interlude.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MISSOURI: 2 INMATES MISSING Two convicted murderers disappeared from a state prison in Jefferson City hours after an inmate who had killed his three siblings was found dead. The police set up roadblocks outside the prison, but it was not clear whether the two inmates had escaped. Officials were searching the penitentiary grounds, which cover 47 acres and include 25 buildings and numerous tunnels. The two inmates, Chris Sims, 27, and Shannon Phillips, 35, have been missing since Wednesday night when another inmate, Toby Viles, 28, was found dead in the ice-making plant with wounds to his neck and head. The three men worked in the plant alone with chisels and hammers.   (AP)

title: When the Summer Crowds Ebb
description: VISITING Fire Island in late fall might seem like roughing it. Stores closed. Restaurants boarded up. And as few as two ferries a day traveling between the island and the mainland.

title: Vibrant Simplicity With a Wink: A Design Revolt in Old Japan
description: A TSUNAMI in a tea bowl: that was Japan in the late 16th century, a time when people were thinking extra big and ultra small. The tempests of social and political change were very real. So were the tea bowls: funky, wild-style, fanatically valued little things in a world gone suddenly, thrillingly askew.

title: They Won't Miss Much
description: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, can fairly be accused of giving aid to the enemy by advising contenders for the Democratic presidential nomination to skip Iowa and focus on New Hampshire. Gen. Wesley Clark and Senator Joseph Lieberman embraced that sound advice this week and announced they would sit out the caucuses.

title: Margaret Murie's Vision
description: Over the centuries, the ink has gone to the discoverers, the men who found or claimed or opened new territories. But we've gotten to a place in history where the preservers are the ones who deserve the ink. One of those was Margaret Murie, better known as Mardy, who died on Sunday at her ranch near Moose, Wyo., at the age of 101.

title: Martin Sustains Ligament Damage to Right Thumb
description: Before last night's exhibition game against the 76ers, the Nets' Lucious Harris gave Kenyon Martin a hug and said, ''Be careful out there.''

title: Syria, Long Ruthlessly Secular, Sees Fervent Islamic Resurgence
description: Two decades after Syria ruthlessly uprooted militant Islam, killing an estimated 10,000 people, this most secular of Arab states is experiencing a dramatic religious resurgence.

title: Pitching Line for Wells: One Inning, One Injury
description: Mel Stottlemyre, the Yankees' pitching coach, returned to the dugout after David Wells had fitfully warmed up for tonight's game. Stottlemyre had a sobering suggestion for Manager Joe Torre: Start thinking about relief pitchers.

title: Turkey Begins To Think Twice About Sending Troops to Iraq
description: Caught between the Bush administration's entreaties to commit troops for peacekeeping duties and equally strong resistance from the Iraqis, Turkey has begun to back away from its initial readiness to deploy thousands of its soldiers to Iraq.

description: Starting sometime Friday night, if all goes as planned, the mail sorting plant here will become a 280,000-square-foot execution chamber for anthrax spores and for at least some of the bad memories lingering from the awful fall of 2001.

description: Facing regulatory pressure and citing negative news articles, AmeriDebt, a leading credit counseling service, said yesterday that it was sharply cutting its operations.
