description: LONDON, Oct. 24  Imagine a world where Porsche came out with its 911 series shortly after Henry Ford invented the Model T, only to take its sleek roadsters off the street because they became expensive to maintain and appealed to only the most elitist of drivers.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. New York City clubs are exceptionally busy with showcases for the annual CMJ Music Marathon, the music-business convention that continues through tomorrow. Most clubs have more bands than usual on each bill, playing shorter sets. Many clubs are also packed with conventiongoers who have paid up to $495 for CMJ registration, which provides admission to the dozens of participating clubs. But the events are also open to the public, and the clubs welcome paying customers. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: O'Leary Gets A Second Chance And Thrives
description: After his rsum became the most scrutinized document in South Bend, Ind., George O'Leary sequestered himself in his home on Lake Oconee, Ga., 75 miles east of Atlanta, chagrined and uncertain about his future. Unbeknown to O'Leary, hundreds of miles away, one of his former players was about to save his career.

title: What Teenagers Need
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pulp Novelist's Dreams Invade a Distressing Reality
description: ''The Singing Detective,'' Dennis Potter's 1986 mini-series, is the kind of television production that justifies the existence of the medium -- a gloomy, episodic swirl of old pop music, film noir and psychological subtext that rewards repeated viewing. In the mind of its creator, it also deserved to be made again, as a feature film.

title: Soriano and Giambi Don't Start but Crack the Lineup
description: Alfonso Soriano and Jason Giambi are two of the Yankees' biggest run producers, with a combined 79 home runs in the regular season. But they have hit poorly in the postseason, and neither was in the starting lineup against Florida for Game 5 of the World Series on Thursday night.

title: In New York, Even a Free Paper Has to Be Sold
description: THERE is no doubt that Russel Pergament, the publisher of amNew York, is a master of the sales pitch. He is bounding about the cramped temporary newsroom of his free weekday tabloid, explaining why morning commuters in their 20's and 30's will get hooked on it.

title: U.S. Islamic Leader Is Linked To Terror Groups in Indictment
description: One of the country's most prominent Islamic leaders was charged in an 18-count indictment on Thursday with laundering hundreds of thousands of dollars from Libya, and law enforcement officials said they suspected that he provided money to Al Qaeda, Hamas and other terrorist groups.

title: Iraqi AIDS Patients Faced Confinement as Well as Pain and Death
description: Muhanid Hassan, a hemophiliac who earns a small living driving a taxi here, has been infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, for 18 years. But it was not until the other day that he learned how AIDS patients have been treated in most places outside Iraq, and the news astonished him.

title: Jobless Claims at Lowest Level Since April
description: The number of Americans collecting unemployment benefits fell to the lowest level since April and initial jobless claims last week matched an eight-month low, the Labor Department said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLY, JAMES J.
description: KELLY--James J. Age 68, formerly of New York, N.Y. and Cincinnati, Ohio; on Saturday, October 18, 2003. Received his law degree at NYU in 1964, retired in 1992 from Kroger Company, Cincinnati, as Senior Attorney. Survived by his wife Brighid O'Donnell Kelly; children Jim and Mary, six grandchildren and two sisters Terri Conzowe and Anne Kelly. Relatives and friends are invited to attend visitation at Adams-Green Funeral Home, Herndon, VA. on Sunday October 26, 2003 from 68PM. Services will be held at St. John Neumann Catholic Church, Reston, VA. on Monday, October 27th at 11:30AM, followed by graveside services with military honors at Quantico National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to Catholic Relief Service, 209 W. Fayette St., Baltimore, MD 21201-3443.

title: 36 Hours | Omaha
description: AS the birthplace of both Warren Buffet and TV dinners, Omaha is a pragmatic, come-as-you-are sort of place. Although its metropolitan area has half a million people, it is still a Friday-and-Saturday-night town -- a holdover from when cowboys came in to carouse through the weekend. Now the spiritual cowboys are the men and women working in the city's primary industries of food-processing, construction and telecommunications. Or like Jack Nicholson's character in Alexander Payne's latest film set in Omaha, ''About Schmidt,'' at one of the 20 insurance companies based in town. Visitors can glimpse the Old World influences of immigrants who settled here. The restaurants, shops and galleries in the century-old warehouses of the Old Market, a progressive zoo and public spaces along the Missouri River offer visitors a place that is part hearty frontier town and part arty downtown. ANNA BAHNEY

title: Massive Strike Leads Italy Into Temporary Paralysis
description: ROME, Oct. 24  Planes idled on tarmacs, trains stopped running and much of Italy slipped into a state of temporary paralysis today as a result of a massive strike to protest a proposed increase in the retirement age.

description: SIMON -- Peter. Dedicated husband, father, grandfather and friend. Our thoughts and love are with Susan and your loved ones. The Fuchs Family

title: A Ring of Droll Spies, Slightly Fictionalized
description: ''Cambridge Spies,'' on BBC America tomorrow night, is, of all things, a gauzily romantic look at the 20th century's most famous ring of double agents. The five-part series is less a faithful telling of Britain's most shocking espionage scandal than an Evelyn Waugh-style homage to white flannel and male bonding -- ''Spieshead Revisited.''

title: Kerry Still Nagged by Questions On Vote to Authorize Iraq War
description: It dogs him at nearly every step on his presidential campaign: If Senator John Kerry is so critical of the Bush administration's handling of the war in Iraq and its aftermath, why did he vote to authorize the use of force in the first place?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABDALE, DARLENE V. LEISCHNER
description: ABDALE--Darlene V. Leischner. Educator, 57, died on Friday, October 17, 2003 after a courageous battle with cancer. Ms. Abdale was Emerita Chair of the Science Department at Collegiate School in Manhattan, where she taught for 25 years. She previously taught biology at Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn. She was loved and is survived by her partner Darcy Beadle, daughter Lindsey and brothers Robert and William Leischner. A memorial service will be held at 3:30PM, Sunday October 26, 2003 in the Collegiate School Chapel, 368 West 77th Street, New York, NY.

title: INVESTOR GROUP MAKES BID FOR BEIERSDORF
description: A German consumer products company, Beiersdorf, which makes Nivea skin cream, may remain in German hands after a German coffee retailer and a group of investors from Hamburg bid 4.4 billion euros ($5.2 billion) to acquire control of the company from its largest shareholder, Allianz. Since the coffee retailer, Tchibo Group, already owns 30 percent of Beiersdorf, which is based in Hamburg, it is not obliged to make the same offer to minority shareholders. That could thwart the Procter & Gamble Company, which is interested in Beiersdorf, but as an outsider would have to offer the same terms to all shareholders. Procter, based in Cincinnati, declined to comment on its plans. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Democrats Say G.O.P. Endangers Medicare Drug Accord
description: A day after Republican negotiators said they had reached a tentative agreement on a prescription drug benefit for the elderly, Senate Democrats said on Thursday that the benefit could be in jeopardy if House Republicans insisted on a plan forcing the traditional Medicare program to compete directly with private health plans.

title: Jailed Man Accused Of Plotting to Kill 5
description: A man who was jailed on robbery charges plotted from Rikers Island to kill five people who had been witnesses to the holdups, the authorities said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Flat Economic Outlook
description: The German government confirmed what most private-sector economists have been saying for months: the economy is not expected to grow this year. The economics and labor ministry cut its forecast for growth in 2003 to zero, from an earlier projection of 0.75 percent. It also trimmed its expectations of growth in 2004 to a range of 1.5 percent to 2 percent, down from 2 percent. While no growth would be Germany's weakest performance over a full year since 1993, the economics and labor minister, Wolfgang Clement, above, said it would be a ''black zero,'' meaning the economy was not in danger of finishing the year in the red. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Tour de France Course Unveiled
description: As he watched on the big-screen television in Paris during the closed-circuit presentation yesterday of the route of the next Tour de France, Lance Armstrong's jaw seemed to drop a little when the 16th of 20 daily stages was unveiled. He later called it ''probably a day that will decide the Tour.''

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: ARAISE FOR THE SENATE The Senate voted to accept an automatic raise of about $3,400, rejecting an effort to remove the increase from a spending measure. Lawmakers voted 60 to 34 to defeat an effort by Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, who regularly challenges the cost-of-living adjustment that was instituted to avoid politically difficult fights over pay increases. The raise of 2.2 percent will bring the pay of most lawmakers to about $158,000 annually. Defenders say the increase was similar to raises given to other federal employees.

title: PC Demand Helps Microsoft Beat Earnings Estimates
description: Lifted by strong demand in the consumer market for personal computers, Microsoft reported solid quarterly gains in sales and profits yesterday that slightly surpassed Wall Street's expectations.

title: Distributor and Opening Are Set For Mel Gibson's Film on Jesus
description: Mel Gibson's film ''The Passion of Christ'' has found a distributor and will open nationwide on Feb. 25, Ash Wednesday, Mr. Gibson's company and the distributor announced on Thursday.

title: HEALTH NET AGREES TO PAY $137 MILLION TO SETTLE SUIT
description: Health Net Inc., one of California's biggest health insurers, said it agreed to pay $137 million to settle a lawsuit over the 1998 sale of a workers compensation business that was later taken over by state regulators. The suit, brought by the Superior National Insurance Group three years ago, was scheduled for trial next month. The cost of the settlement reduced Health Net's third-quarter net income, the company said. The lawsuit sought $300 million in compensatory damages and unspecified punitive awards related to the sale of the Business Insurance Group, Health Net said in an Aug. 11 regulatory filing. Superior claimed that Health Net made misleading statements about Business Insurance's financial reserves.

description: There will be no red jersey tucked into the Jets' equipment bags on Sunday, so Chad Pennington may as well be wearing a bull's-eye.

description: GOLDSTEIN--Gerald, on October 22, 2003. Former controller and senior vice president of R.H. Macy's NY. Beloved husband of Pearl for 69 years. Loving father of Mary Goldstein, Ellen Miller, and father-in-law of Aaron Miller. Cherished grandfather of Alexandra and Caroline Miller. Services Friday, 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Madame Chiang, 105, Chinese Leader's Widow, Dies
description: Madame Chiang Kai-shek, a pivotal player in one of the 20th century's great epics -- the struggle for control of post-imperial China waged between the Nationalists and the Communists during the Japanese invasion and the violent aftermath of World War II -- died on Thursday in New York City, the Foreign Ministry of Taiwan reported early Friday. She was 105 years old.

description: Robert A. Durst, the New York real estate heir who is on trial for shooting and dismembering a neighbor, told a jury on Thursday that the victim was killed accidentally after the two struggled over a gun and it went off in the victim's face.

title: Living for the Moments: When Contemplation Turns to Ecstasy
description: Mesmerizing moments are what those of us addicted to performance live for. Suddenly and unexpectedly we are lifted from our normal detached contemplation into another place, where time stops and our breath catches and we can hardly believe that those responsible for this pleasure can sustain it another second.

description: Giants running back Dorsey Levens knows all too well how the Metrodome can mess with a quarterback. In his eight seasons with Green Bay, Levens played there eight times. The Packers lost six of those games, some that were among the worst games of Brett Favre's spectacular career.

title: Unsung Penny Lifts The Marlins
description: Enrique Wilson laid down a bunt, and the ball rolled off the glove of Marlins pitcher Brad Penny. First baseman Derrek Lee had charged the ball, and he tried flipping it to second baseman Luis Castillo covering first, but the ball appeared to deflect off Penny and past the bag, putting runners on first and third.

Charming, formidable, witty, up-to-date, with something to say to each generation. She will be sorely missed. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 11AM, Friday, October 24.

title: Co-op Seeks to Raise Money To Preserve Nearby Church
description: A co-op apartment building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan has voted to offer $1.5 million to a nonprofit group set up to prevent the church next door from being demolished for an apartment building.

title: Here Lies The Ruin Of a Love
description: BRRR. An early, unforgiving and highly symbolic winter has descended upon the stage of the Booth Theater, where a dreary domestic drama called ''The Retreat From Moscow'' opened last night.

title: Ranching 101: Hey, Dude, Where's My Herd?
description: ''A LOT of cowboys don't like dudes riding with their cattle,'' Bob Cochran, a cowboy who looks as if he just got off the set of a John Ford western, tells me somewhat delicately. We are moving a small herd up a mountainside, and my son and I have broken the first rule of cattle wrangling: don't ride too close to the cows.

title: Steroid Is Reportedly Found In Top Runner's Urine Test
description: Regina Jacobs, the country's top female middle-distance runner, who has sustained a remarkable track career past her 40th birthday, has tested positive for a steroid that drug-testing officials say is at the center of a widespread doping scandal, a person familiar with her test result said yesterday.

title: Victory in Florida Feeding Case Emboldens the Religious Right
description: Religious conservatives say that with an arsenal of prayer vigils, Christian radio broadcasts and thousands of e-mail messages to Florida lawmakers, they played a pivotal role in the legislative battle this week over whether to feed a brain-damaged woman who has been kept alive artificially for 13 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIENER, DR. HOWARD E.
description: WIENER--Dr. Howard E. Of Sarasota, FL. Born October 30, 1918, formerly of Hewlett Neck NY, died at home on October 23, 2003. Beloved husband of Marilyn, adored father of Leslie, Rick and Mary, John and Karen, Patty and Dave. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer, Sam, Liz, Michael, Audrey and Jake, brother of Arnold and the late Lester. Howard practiced ophthalmology for 45 years and served as Chief of Ophthalmology at St. John's Episcopal Hospital, Far Rockaway, NY. A memorial service will be held Sunday, October 26, 1 PM at Temple Sinai, 1802 Kenilworth, Sarasota, FL. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to Sarasota Memorial Hospital, or Hospice of Southwest Florida, 5955 Rand Blvd. Sarasota, FL 34238 or to a charity of your choice.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: NETWORK ASSOCIATES POSTS $9.9 MILLION PROFIT Net- work Associates, the maker of McAfee computer-security software, yesterday reported third-quarter net income of $9.9 million, or 6 cents a share, on revenue of $226.9 million. Results in the same period a year earlier are not comparable because the company next week will complete a restatement of 2002 results to reflect a change in the way it books revenue, the company said in a conference call. Fourth-quarter profit will be 20 cents to 22 cents a share, on sales of $255 million to $260 million, the company said. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a profit of 21 cents a share and sales of $256.7 million. Shares of Network Associates fell $2.15, or 14 percent, to $13.18.   (Bloomberg News)

title: A Town's Innocent Outcast, Facing Gentleness and Jeers
description: Since winning an Academy Award six years ago for ''Jerry Maguire,'' Cuba Gooding Jr. has spread himself dangerously thin in a succession of often junky movies. But the encouraging news about his role in the inspirational drama ''Radio'' is that he really gets to act, even though the film is a synthetic mush of molasses-soaked pablum.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Drug Convictions And Race
description: Nine of 10 inmates imprisoned for drug offenses in the state are African-American, though blacks represent less than 30 percent of the state's population, a study by the Justice Policy Institute of Washington has found. The study said that blacks make up 76 percent of all those imprisoned in the state and that more than 5 percent of Maryland's black men are incarcerated, compared with less than 1 percent of white men. Delegate Obie Patterson, a Democrat who is chairman of the General Assembly's black caucus, which commissioned the study, said more drug offenders should receive treatment instead of prison sentences.

title: Ratings Improve
description: Viewership on Wednesday for Florida's 4-3 victory over the Yankees in Game 4 of the World Series on Fox rose 15.5 percent, to 20.9 million from 18.1 million, for the comparable game last year.

title: A Songwriter Being Honest With Himself
description: The music of Phil Roy, a sadly under-recognized songwriter who toiled in Los Angeles for two decades before deciding to record and perform his own work, accomplishes a delicate emotional surgery that countless troubadours have tried but few have been able to carry off. In the most direct language and without irony, the frizzy-haired, bearded composer, who today lives outside of Philadelphia, describes personal experiences of love, loss and spiritual revelation with a naked honesty untainted by narcissism.

title: Ex-Brokers At Prudential Are Said to Be Part of Inquiry
description: The New York attorney general and the Securities and Exchange Commission are investigating former Prudential Securities brokers in Garden City, N.Y., who may have engaged in improper mutual fund trading, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: History on Every Mile, and Sometimes a Stone
description: A JOURNEY that begins among the Chinese storefronts and restaurant supply stores along the Bowery in New York City and that includes a pilgrimage to an Economy True Value Hardware store in suburban Boston more than 200 miles later may not sound like a road trip of much historical interest. (Or, to be frank, of any interest whatsoever.) But this road, which winds through the Bronx; Mamaroneck, N.Y.; and New Haven -- veering off to Springfield, Mass., and Providence, R.I., and changing names probably more than two dozen times along the way -- has an important pedigree.

title: To-Do Lists for the Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Low A Bar
description: John Snow, the Treasury secretary, told The Times of London on Monday that he expected the U.S. economy to add two million jobs before the next election -- that is, almost 200,000 per month. His forecast was higher than those of most independent analysts; nothing in the data suggests that jobs are being created at that rate. (New claims for unemployment insurance are running at slightly less than 400,000 a week, the number that corresponds to zero job growth. If jobs were being created as rapidly as Mr. Snow forecasts, the new claims number would be closer to 300,000.)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel To Restate Results
description: The Canadian communications equipment supplier Nortel Networks said yesterday that it would restate financial results for the last three and a half years after discovering mistakes in recording close to $1 billion of liabilities and revenues. Nortel, based in Brampton, Ontario, said a review of the earlier financial statements would probably result in reduced losses and higher shareholders equity and assets. The company reported preliminary net earnings of $179 million for the three months to Sept. 30 and revenues of $2.27 billion. For the same period last year, it reported a loss of $1.8 billion and revenue of $2.36 billion. Frank A. Dunn, Nortel's chief executive, said the accounting errors reflected the volatile environment in the telecommunications industry in the last three years. Nortel shares fell 22 cents in extended trading after the announcement. They closed at $4.44 in regular trading. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Nominee For Domestic Security Post
description: The White House announced that Adm. James M. Loy, head of the Transportation Security Administration, was being nominated to be deputy secretary of the Department of Homeland Security. The seven-month-old transportation security agency has been the object of intense criticism, including last week when the government ordered the inspection of all passenger planes in the country after the discovery of box cutters on two Southwest Airlines planes. But Admiral Loy, the 61-year-old former commandant of the Coast Guard, has retained the confidence of key members of Congress from both parties. They credit him with improving transportation security. Philip Shenon (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Faked Cancer Leads To Charges
description: A former student at Ball State University faked cancer for three years, bilking sympathetic students for cash, school officials and prosecutors say. The student, Brookelyn Walters, 24, of Culver, has been charged with forgery and theft. She shaved her head, faked deafness and created false medical documentation as part of her ruse, the authorities said. University officials, who became suspicious after noting inconsistencies in her story, said they realized in the spring that Ms. Walters was trying to deceive them. They say that she admitted fabricating her illness and that she left the university. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PUFFER, TED
description: PUFFER--Ted. The Manhattan School of Music deeply mourns the passing of Ted Puffer, a distinguished member of the voice faculty since 1994. His intellect, energy and compassion have had an enormous impact on generations of singers who have performed on opera stages worldwide. As a colleague and friend he will be sorely missed by all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. David A. Rahm, Chairman, Board of Trustees Marta Istomin, President

title: U.S. CHALLENGES FIRST DATA'S DEAL WITH CONCORD
description: The First Data Corporation's proposed $6.9 billion acquisition of Concord EFS Inc. was challenged by the Justice Department, which said the combination would hurt competition in debit card networks. The Justice Department and seven states filed a lawsuit in Washington seeking a permanent injunction from a federal judge to prevent First Data, the world's largest processor of credit card transactions, from acquiring Concord EFS, the owner of the nation's largest A.T.M.. network. The combination of the Star Network of Concord EFS and NYCE from First Data would lead to higher costs for merchants to process debit transactions, the Justice Department said. Concord, which is based in Memphis, and First Data, which is based in Greenwood Village, Colo., said they would comment on the case once they had received the government's complaint.

title: RUMSFELD DRAWS REPUBLICANS' IRE
description: Last Friday, the Republican chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee and his top Democratic colleague sent a private letter to Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld that questioned the propriety of comments made by a top Pentagon general, William G. Boykin.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Suit Over Health At Army Depot
description: Arguments began this week in a federal lawsuit in Portland about whether the Army was negligent in protecting the health of workers building an incinerator at a chemical weapons depot. The case involves a September 1999 incident in eastern Oregon in which dozens of workers fell ill at the construction site in the Umatilla Chemical Depot. The workers say a leaked nerve agent from a storage unit caused long-term health effects. The Army says its investigation found that regular construction materials caused the illnesses. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MELLO, JUDY HENDREN (SCHWAMM)
description: MELLO -- Judy Hendren (Schwamm). On October 21st, while sleeping peacefully and with great dignity at Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center, NYC, after a seventeen year courageous battle fought with strength and dignity. Born July 14, 1943 to the late Colonel Ed Hendren and Dorthy May Hendren in Chickasha, Oklahoma. She is survived by her husband, Jay Marc Schwamm of NYC; six step children and seven step grandchildren; her brother Ed Hendren, Esquire, of Chico, CA; 28 nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grand-nephews, and her stepmother Irene Hendren of Rome, GA. She is the sister of the late Jerry Hendren and Kathryn Hendren. There will be a Memorial Service at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Deep Hollow Road, Lithgow, Millbrook, NY on Saturday, November 29th at 2:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, those who wish may send contributions in her name to St. Peter's Episcopal Church, attention of the Reverend Ed Johnston.

title: Let the Public See the Plans
description: A new creative spat over the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan surfaced this week. As David Dunlap wrote in yesterday's New York Times, Daniel Libeskind, the master designer for the site, and David Childs, the architect for the developer, Larry Silverstein, appear to be at odds over the 1,776-foot tower that will be the focal point for the site's new skyline. Mr. Libeskind originally sketched a sleek, asymmetrical tower that seemed to echo the Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor. Mr. Childs's design is not available to the public, but descriptions of a monolith that twists as it tapers upward make it sound a lot different than the structure envisioned in the Libeskind plan.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Developer Set For Harlem Site
description: The city has selected a developer to modernize an East Harlem market established under Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia for pushcart vendors to sell their products. The city selected the developer, the East Harlem Business Capital Corporation, as part of a project to revitalize under-used properties. The market occupies two buildings and an outdoor plaza on city-owned property between East 111th and 116th streets. The developer has a one-year lease and plans to create a Latino-themed food market with glass facades. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 22 about the official closing of the United States air base in Saudi Arabia referred imprecisely to Security Council Resolution 688, which was part of the original basis for the Air Force's presence there to enforce a no-flight zone in Iraq. The resolution, passed in 1991, demanded that the government of Saddam Hussein stop attacks on Iraqi citizens and said the secretary general should use "all the resources at his disposal" to enforce that demand. The resolution did not specifically create the no-flight zone, although American officials regarded the resolution as the legal justification for it.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Two Producers In a Busy Swirl

title: Ex-Mentor At L.I. Church Is Charged With Sodomy
description: A former youth minister at a Long Island Roman Catholic parish was arraigned on Thursday on a felony charge that he sodomized a teenager he had met through the church, the police said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Poisonous Snakes In Apartment
description: An Inwood man was issued five summonses yesterday for having 12 snakes in containers in his bedroom, the police said. The man, Perisio Nunez, 35, of 195 Nagle Avenue, had the snakes in a terrarium and other containers in a locked bedroom, the police said. The snakes included two green tree pythons, two Gaboon vipers, four emerald tree boas, all of which were taken to the Bronx Zoo, and an Amazon tree boa, two common boas, and a yellow anaconda, which were taken to the Center for Animal Care and Control, said Detective Thomas Kuchma. The Gaboon vipers were poisonous, he said. Mr. Nunez's building is owned by the city Housing Authority and the police were called after the authority warned Mr. Nunez that he could keep the animals. The snakes did not pose a danger to anyone, said the police, who were called in to help the Center for Animal Care and Control remove the snakes. Mr. Nunez was cited for violating the health code and the Environmental Conservation Law. against owning wild animals. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Conviction In Plot To Kill Gravano
description: Thomas Carbonaro, a reputed Mafia soldier, was convicted yesterday of plotting to kill Salvatore Gravano, the Mafia turncoat known as Sammy the Bull. A federal jury found Mr. Carbonaro guilty of conspiring to murder in aid of racketeering. Mr. Carbonaro was acquitted on charges of conspiracy to possess a weapon and possession of a weapon. He faces up to 10 years in prison and is to be sentenced on Jan. 26. Colin Moynihan (NYT)

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Just One Of Those Days

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Investigator For Chicago Fire
description: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich appointed a former head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency to investigate a fire in a county building in Chicago that killed six people on Oct. 18. His announcement came just after John Stroger, the president of the Cook County Board of Commissioners, said he was assembling a committee to look into the fire. The governor said he ''was not satisfied that enough substantive expertise has been brought in to find out what went wrong,'' and he asked James L. Witt, who was the director of the federal agency when it handled the Oklahoma City bombing, to investigate. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Arctic Sea Ice At A Low
description: The amount of summer sea ice in the Arctic remained at a record low level in 2003 and the rate of Arctic warming during the past two decades is almost eight times that of the rate during the past century, a NASA has found. Most of the Arctic warmed significantly in the past decade, with the greatest temperature increases coming over the area nearest North America, said the study, written by Josefino Comiso, a senior research scientist at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md.

title: Bjorn Melhus
description: Satellite

title: Knicks Seek Character, Not Characters Anymore
description: The Knicks, who have the highest payroll in the N.B.A., are coming off two seasons without making the playoffs, empty seats at Madison Square Garden, a controversial summer trade of the team's most popular player and a preseason pockmarked by injuries.

title: Defendant In Bribe Case Is Called Liar
description: The prosecution in the corruption trial of a former Republican candidate for secretary of the state sought to convince jurors Thursday that the defendant had a habit of lying about facts ranging from his birth date to statements on his financial documents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KURTZ, DORA
description: KURTZ--Dora. Wife of Irving. Mother of Marcia and Judy. Grandmother of Aaron and Elena. Mother-in-law of Sidney. Aunt, sister and sister-inlaw of the Kurtz/Rosenstein clans. Her life revolved around her near and extended family. She had a great zest for life, a wonderful sense of humor and she loved to sing and dance. She was truly one of the sweet souls of the earth and taught everyone who came into contact with her that love was the most important thing in life.

title: Inheriting Much More Than a Car
description: AN automobile can be like any other heirloom, a Victorian brooch or the portrait of an obscure uncle, passed down through the generations as a symbol of clan continuity. In my case, the car is a 1965 Austin Healey 3000 Mark III convertible in British racing green. It sits in my sister's spotless garage in Los Angeles, rarely driven but highly prized, a six-cylinder reminder of all that survives in a family and all that doesn't.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STOLLERMAN, HANNAH
description: STOLLERMAN--Hannah. On October 22, 2003 in her 100th year at home. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Maurice Stollerman. Devoted mother of Jan Litwack, Judith Stollerman and Joan Sun. Cherished grandmother of Kim, Kathy, Lauri, Jody, Ari, Gia and nine great - grandchildren. Also survived by nieces, nephews and good friends. Graveside service on Sunday 11 AM at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Judy H. Mello Is Dead at 60; Executive of Women's Bank
description: Judy Hendren Mello, former president and chief executive of the First Women's Bank in Manhattan, died Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 60 and had homes in Manhattan; Millbrook, N.Y.; and Moose, Wyo.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   EDELSON, TOBY
description: EDELSON--Toby. Always Remembered With Love Shuli

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILBER, SYLVIA
description: SILBER--Sylvia, on October 22, 2003. Beloved mother of Josh, Fred and Nina. Cherished grandmother of Benjamin and Franny. Teacher, social activist and champion of peace.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bid For Retailer Raised
description: Baroness Retail, led by CVC Capital Partners of Britain and the Texas Pacific Group of the United States, raised its bid for Debenhams department store chain to about $2.9 billion. That forced the withdrawal of a rival bidder, Laragrove, a consortium led by Permira of Britain and the Blackstone Group of the United States. Investors have been drawn to retailers like Debenhams because of their strong cash flow and substantial real estate holdings. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Sony Says Profit Tumbled 25% From a Year Ago
description: The Sony Corporation's troubles continued last quarter, as its net profit fell 25 percent from the period a year earlier, the company said Thursday. Income from its games division plunged and its movie studio posted a loss.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint Reports $498 Million Loss
description: The Sprint Corporation yesterday posted a third-quarter net loss of $498 million because of write-downs. Shares of the PCS wireless unit tumbled after customer additions missed goals. Sprint's loss compared with net income of $519 million a year earlier. The company, based in Overland Park, Kan., said its revenue fell 1.2 percent to $6.71 billion, as long-distance sales declined for an 11th consecutive quarter. Wireless subscriber additions were about half of what analysts forecast. Shares of Sprint PCS fell 91 cents, or 17 percent, to $4.41. The shares that track Sprint's long-distance and local division, known as FON Group, rose 16 cents, to $15.90.

title: Rediscovering the Vineyard of Memory
description: I HAVEN'T seen Lambert's Cove this barren since 1986. A seaside slice of beach beside a neat expanse of water perfect for family swimming, Lambert's Cove, on the northwest side of Martha's Vineyard, is down a crooked woodsy path and open only to West Tisbury residents with special car stickers. Despite that, the beach has become strictly sardine can in July and August. But today, a brisk and glorious October afternoon, there are only a handful of sand dwellers and a few fistfuls of fishermen. One group, made up mostly of Vineyard summer residents, has come back for the 58th annual Martha's Vineyard Striped Bass and Bluefish Derby, a one-month anglers' extravaganza. ''We caught 33 stripers off the boat Machaka this morning,'' brags Rick Schrade, 44.

title: Likelihood Of Mistrial Grows in Case Of Ex-Banker
description: The jurors in the trial of Frank P. Quattrone, the former Credit Suisse First Boston investment banker, said they were still deadlocked yesterday, increasing the likelihood that a mistrial will be declared.

title: Three Israelis Killed in Attack on Settlement
description: Three Israelis were killed and two wounded early Friday morning when at least one Palestinian gunman entered a Jewish settlement in the Gaza Strip and opened fire, Israeli security officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LERNER, RABBI ISRAEL D
description: LERNER--Rabbi Israel D, survived by wife, Chaniett (Ethel), daughter Tova and Daniel Rhein, son Eli and Sharon Lerner and grandchildren. Shiva in Israel 011 972 2 563 9955 eslerner@bezeqint.net

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEMAN, M. JANET
description: FREEMAN--M. Janet. On October 10. Loving mother of April, Meg, Robert and Christopher. Memorial service Saturday, 11:30AM at The Chapel at 777 UN Plaza, 44th Street & 1st Avenue.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Interest Rate Cut
description: Brazil's central bank lowered its base lending rate to 19 percent from 20 percent, but analysts said that it would have to cut more to get Brazil's economy growing again. The cut, the fifth this year, was announced as markets closed Wednesday and was in line with expectations. Core inflation has ticked lower but is still a worry for the central bank. Even before the announcement, Brazil's vice president, Jos Alencar, said rates would have to come down sharply to help get the economy moving. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 16 about fund-raising by Democratic candidates for the presidential nomination carried incorrect figures in some copies for the amount raised by the Rev. Al Sharpton. His campaign reported raising more than $121,000 (not $259,000), in the quarter that ended on Sept. 30, bringing his total for the campaign to about $284,000 (not $443,000).

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: World War II Bomb At Train Station
description: A 550-pound American bomb from World War II was detonated at Friedrichstrasse rail station in Berlin after it was found during construction work. Nearly 1,000 people were evacuated from the station while the bomb was defused.

title: Seeking Funny Cide's Hollywood Ending
description: It's a screenwriter's ending: the girl rider makes history in America's richest race aboard the beloved gelding who was the hero of the spring, an enigma in the summer and now the mystery of the fall. It could happen Saturday when Julie Krone takes the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner, Funny Cide, for a mile and a quarter spin, aiming to beat the best horses in the world here in the $4 million Breeders' Cup Classic.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CIRKER, MINNETTE
description: CIRKER--Minnette. 10/24/86. In loving memory of my dear Minnette. ''Rest my sweet darling.'' Stanley

title: No Ligament Damage for Nets Martin
description: The Nets received good news yesterday when they learned that although Kenyon Martin sustained a sprained right thumb on Thursday night, he did not tear a ligament, as was feared. Martin was injured in the fourth quarter of a preseason game in Philadelphia. He is listed as day to day. The Nets, who were in Boston last night for their final preseason game, will open the regular season in Toronto on Wednesday.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: PeopleSoft Earnings Beat Forecasts
description: PeopleSoft said yesterday that it beat earnings forecasts and its own guidance for the third quarter, posting revenue of $624 million, as company executives described its strong showing as proof that Oracle's hostile takeover bid was having no ill effects on sales. Despite the better-than-expected revenues, PeopleSoft lost $7.3 million, or 2 cents a share, in the three months that ended Sept. 30, in contrast to a profit of $44.6 million, or 14 cents a share, last year. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Parents Perplexed by High School Admissions Rule
description: At East Side Middle School in Manhattan, an information session this month devolved into what one parent called ''a free-for-all,'' with frustrated parents bombarding officials with questions about the city's new high school admissions policy.

title: Cablevision Says It Will Spin Off Satellite Unit And 3 Channels
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation said late yesterday that it planned to spin off into a separate company a collection of assets including its fledgling satellite TV service and three cable channels.

title: House Leaders Are Pushing to Cut Corporate Taxes
description: House Republican leaders are nearing agreement on a bill to give nearly $60 billion in additional tax breaks to corporations, brushing aside Democratic complaints that the measure would deepen the federal budget deficit.

title: Study Finds Few Latinos in Financial Services
description: Latinos in the United States remain underrepresented in management and ownership positions in the financial services industry despite the rapid expansion of the Latino population in recent years, according to a study expected to be released today in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHUYLER, IRVING M.
description: SCHUYLER--Irving M. Age 94. On Tuesday, October 21, 2003. Devoted husband of 58 years of the late Pearl Bressler. Adoring father of Harvey Bressler Schuyler. Also surviving is a daughter Sandra Jaffee and a grandson Evan Jaffee.

title: Don Evans, 65, a Playwright Who Focused on Black Lives
description: Don Evans, a playwright of the African-American experience, about which he also taught at the College of New Jersey for 30 years, died on Oct. 16 at his home in Merchantville, N.J. He was 65.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Asylum Law
description: Parliament passed a new asylum law described as one of the most restrictive in Europe. Under the law, officials will decide within just 72 hours whether asylum seekers will be granted permission to stay or be returned to their home countries. The law also allows refugees to be expelled while a rejection is appealed. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: U.S. in Consent Decree With Ex-Freddie Mac President
description: Federal regulators announced yesterday that they had entered a consent decree with David W. Glenn, the former Freddie Mac president, who agreed to pay a $125,000 fine and cooperate with an investigation of the company's accounting.

title: Britain Reverses Part of Rail Privatization
description: LONDON, Oct. 24  Spurred by growing safety concerns, Britain's railway authorities reversed a crucial element of the nation's rail privatization today, announcing that maintenance contracts awarded to seven private companies and worth $2 billion a year would be taken over by the government-backed Network Rail.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARBERRY, JAMES R.
description: CARBERRY--James R., 73, writer and newspaperman, died October 21 at home in Staatsburgh, NY. Beloved husband of Ava Miller Carberry. Graveside service will be held October 26, 1 PM, at Pleasant Plains Cemetery. For information, call DapsonChestney Funeral Home, Rhinebeck, NY (845-876-6000).

title: Where Poetry, Rhythm and Harmony Meet
description: The trumpeter Dave Douglas has a new band, and this is not the first time I've written that sentence. At the moment he has four working groups and eight other back-burner projects involving groups that were working not too long ago. The new group is called Word. Its project is to set other people's poems to music as songs, as opposed to the old reciting-poetry-with-jazz idea. It's not the first time I've written that sentence, either. Steve Lacy, as the prime example, has been doing this for more than 30 years.

That was the case on Oct. 18 when the company, directed by Ella Thompson Moore, performed at Symphony Space.

description: In a firm rebuke to President Bush over Cuba policy, the Senate on Thursday overwhelmingly voted to ease travel restrictions on Americans seeking to visit the island.

title: National Briefing | Washington: A Raise For The Senate
description: The Senate voted to accept an automatic raise of about $3,400, rejecting an effort to remove the increase from a spending measure. Lawmakers voted 60 to 34 to defeat an effort by Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, who regularly challenges the cost-of-living adjustment that was instituted to avoid politically difficult fights over pay increases. The raise of 2.2 percent will bring the pay of most lawmakers to about $158,000 annually. Defenders say the increase was similar to raises given to other federal employees.

description: THERE have been better nights to be the pitching coach of the Yankees than last night, when in the second inning of the biggest game of the season, Mel Stottlemyre looked out to his bullpen and had only choices ranging from bad to very bad.

title: Women With Genetic Mutation at High Risk for Breast Cancer, Study Confirms
description: For women who carry genetic mutations linked to breast cancer, a new study provides grim confirmation that their risk is high and that younger women with the genes are more likely to develop the disease at an early age than were previous generations of carriers.

description: After a year's delay, the Senate Armed Services Committee on Thursday approved the promotion of a general who commanded a base where a gay soldier was beaten to death in 1999.

description: The first two batters in the thinner Yankees' starting lineup produced hits in Game 5 of the World Series when Derek Jeter singled and Enrique Wilson reached on a bunt that traveled about 50 feet. The Yankees exhaled a little. This blip of an offensive display was a relief to a team whose season is evaporating because it cannot hit, cannot score.

title: Wildfire in Southern California Forces Thousands to Evacuate
description: Driven by powerful desert winds, a wildfire that tore through the southern foothills of the San Bernardino National Forest early Friday forced the evacuation of several thousand people and spread dense smoke all the way to Los Angeles, 50 miles to the west.

title: Crash of Ferry Leaves Questions On Enforcement of Safety Rules
description: Since at least the 1950's, the Staten Island ferry has been governed by a detailed set of rules written to ensure the safety of one of the nation's busiest waterborne commuter routes.

title: His Hunches Having Paid Off So Far, McKeon Plays One More
description: Florida Marlins Manager Jack McKeon went against convention yesterday in deciding to use his two best pitchers, Josh Beckett and Carl Pavano, on short rest in Game 6 and, if necessary, Game 7 of the World Series. But it should not have been a surprise. For it conformed with McKeon's managing style throughout the postseason, in which he has made unpredictable decisions to win on a daily basis while ignoring the inevitable questions.

title: The Russians Are Coming To Take Over Rouge Steel
description: Rouge Steel, whose sprawling works became a symbol of raw 20th-century capitalism, may soon rest in the hands of even rawer owners: Russian investors.

title: McCain for Defense? Lieberman Likes Idea
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman said on Friday that if elected president he would offer the job of secretary of defense to Senator John McCain, a Republican from Arizona.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg disclosed yesterday that he has provided $2 million of his own money to finance a campaign urging people to vote to ban party primaries in citywide elections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, DENNIS
description: STEIN--Dennis, (70), July 3, 1933 to October 23, 2003. Beloved father of Pamela (Earl) Kluft & grandfather of Michelle, Julianne, & Alexander Kluft. Sister of Eleanor (Joel) Hinderstein. Uncle of David (Leslie) & Glenn Hinderstein. Inside this frequently prickly man was a golden heart and a generous nature. A fixture on the sidewalks of Manhattan and at the NY Friars Club. Always impeccably dressed, well-groomed and crowned with his trademark silver hair, it was impossible not to notice him. Anyone who knew him would tell you ''To know him was to love him''. New York will never be the same. Services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91st on Sunday, October 26 at 11:00 AM. Donations may be made to City of Hope, 800544-3541.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: Ghana: Bid For Mining Company Raised
description: The British-based mining company Randgold Resources raised its bid for Ashanti, the Ghanaian gold mining company, to $1.7 billion in stock, topping a rival bid from AngloGold. Randgold's stock bid values Ashanti at $1.7 billion, 12.3 percent higher than the bid made on Oct. 14 by AngloGold. AngloGold, which is based in South Africa, said then that its offer, which is in cash, was final. A winning bidder needs approval from the Ghanaian government, which owns 17 percent of Ashanti, and controls its mining rights. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Beliefs; Some modest proposals of alternatives in the weighty debate over 'one nation under God.'
description: Does exposing public school students to the phrase ''under God'' in the Pledge of Allegiance violate the First Amendment? Earlier this month, the Supreme Court agreed that it would seek to answer that question. This column, by contrast, will not.

She is Susan MacManus, not McManus.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about the Staten Island ferry crash that killed 10 people misstated the time of the most recent mass transit accident in New York City that had a higher toll. It was about 53 years ago, not more than 70. (In November 1950, 79 people died in a Long Island Rail Road accident in the Richmond Hill section of Queens.)

title: Giants and a Giant Killer at the Breeders' Cup
description: He is known as The Chief or the Giant Killer and is one of the most eccentric and successful trainers to saddle a horse. Allen Jerkens is never far from the rail to watch one of his horses race, and to watch him watch them captures both the lunacy and majesty of an old sport. He stomps, hollers and waves his Panama hat, often before bounding to the winner's circle. Once there, tears zigzag down a lined face that maps more than 60 years spent at racetracks.

title: Custom Ambulances
description: To the Editor:

title: Justifying 'Ecospeak'
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: No Landmark Status for St. John the Divine
description: The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine has punctuated the New York skyline for more than a century, but its designation as an official city landmark was rejected yesterday by the City Council.

title: At New Disney Hall, The Time to Listen Has Finally Arrived
description: Will Walt Disney Concert Hall, the new home of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, bring urban vitality to the city's uninviting downtown area? Will it become the mission control center for high culture in Southern California, solidify the reputation of Frank Gehry as the visionary architect of our time and make Angelenos better people? All this and more have been hoped for in the rush of press coverage in recent months.

title: S.E.C. Finding Fund Abuses, Official Says
description: An investigation by securities regulators has uncovered widespread improper trading of mutual fund shares at the nation's largest fund companies and brokerage firms, an official at the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.

title: N.F.L. Has Started Testing for the Steroid THG
description: The National Football League has started testing its players for a previously unidentified and undetectable steroid.

title: AT HOME ABROAD: It's often harder away from home
description: PARIS  Standing tall behind a large plastic drawer, a woman picks a pebble from one of the open drawers. The small pebble is known as a sobriety stone. Each stone stands for the number of years a person has not touched alcohol or become high on drugs.

title: Bucs Have Endured a Bumpy Ride
description: The defending Super Bowl champion Tampa Bay Buccaneers have stumbled to a 3-3 start. They are playing with an injury-depleted secondary and on Sunday will face one of the N.F.L.'s surprise teams, the Dallas Cowboys. Yet defensive tackle Warren Sapp advises people to save their sympathy for others.

title: A SPECIAL REPORT: ARTS & ANTIQUES: Dismantling of work by Noguchi sets off protests
description: The recent dismantling in Tokyo of an important site-specific work of art and architecture has rekindled the debate over whether urban development ever justifies the destruction of a historically significant work of art.

title: Washington Talk; This Memo Must Not Be Leaked: Wink, Wink
description: Technically, they are called confidential memorandums. But in the capital, as it became vividly clear again this week, there is really no such thing.

title: Political Memo; Debates Lose Allure for Some in Democratic Field
description: Their nearly weekly debates have been the biggest events of the season for the Democratic presidential candidates. They build their travel schedules around the televised encounters. Their aides devote hours to coming up with catchy retorts. And the forums draw more press coverage than anything else the candidates do.

title: The Death of a Top Australian Recalls a Paradoxical Twist
description: Success in world championships has belonged almost exclusively to teams from North America and Europe. The obvious exception is Brazil, whose players have three major world titles.

title: Tudor's Emotional Portrait Retains Its Impact
description: It is hard to believe that American Ballet Theater audiences were shocked, shocked by the fabled 1942 premiere of Antony Tudor's ''Pillar of Fire,'' which the company revived with sensational dancing on Thursday night in a redesigned new production. But there is no question of the ballet's original impact and its place in dance history.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Telecommunications Acquisition
description: The Mexican phone company Telmex said it won an auction for the assets of the bankrupt AT&T Latin America as the billionaire Carlos Slim Hel, Telmex's controlling shareholder, continues his strategy of expanding into the region's telecommunications markets. Telmex, formally Telfonos de Mexico, beat Telefnica of Spain and Embratel of Brazil in the auction, which was held in United States Bankruptcy Court in Miami. The transaction is subject to the court's approval. AT&T Latin America has fixed-line phone operations in Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Chile and Peru but could not make them profitable enough to keep up with payments on the money it borrowed to buy them. Telmex did not say how much it bid. However, under the auction rules the price was at least $117 million. Mr. Slim's mobile phone company, America Mvil, is also increasing its regional presence. John Moody (NYT)

title: High-Tech Voting, or More Rube Goldberg?
description: To the Editor:

title: Houston Sidelined by Sore Knee
description: As the Knicks near their season opener Wednesday against Orlando, their injury concerns mount. Guard Allan Houston sat out the latter part of practice because of discomfort in his surgically repaired right knee.

title: Strong Debut for Stock of Carter's, Children's Apparel Maker
description: For most companies that aspire to go public, the initial offering market is still a very inhospitable place. But businesses that have an established presence and a recognizable brand and that operate in an enormous, expanding market can attract any number of investors.

title: When Students Run the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: PRIMEDIA AGREES TO SELL ONLINE AD UNIT TO GOOGLE
description: Primedia, the publisher of magazines like New York and the owner of the Internet directory About.com, said yesterday that it would sell its Sprinks online advertising division to the Web search company Google. Terms were not disclosed. Sprinks, with 10,000 advertising clients, tries to attract consumers by placing an ad for baking pans, for example, next to an article about cooking. Google, which is closely held, has 150,000 advertising clients, Primedia said. Google will provide advertising for Primedia's Web sites as part of a four-year revenue-sharing agreement, Primedia said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas last Saturday about scientists who present their ideas in novels omitted the name of the co-author of a work in progress with Christos H. Papadimitriou, a professor of computer science at the University of California at Berkeley. He is Apostolos Doxiades. The article also omitted the co-publisher of Great Discoveries, a new series of nonfiction books about scientific breakthroughs. It is Atlas Books (along with W. W. Norton).

title: Caviar, Pfft. Now When You Cross the Atlantic, You'd Better Have Cucumber Slices.
description: Flight attendants waltzed down the aisle with glasses of Champagne just as the Concorde broke the sound barrier on Friday morning.

title: Op-Art; The Year The Pumpkin Crop Failed
Ali's Camp and Frazier's Bag Are Up for Auction
description: It is not a commonplace sports auction item. It is not a signed ball, a game-used uniform, a 500th home run bat or a rare tobacco trading card.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Arrest Over Bomblike Device
description: A man was arrested at Logan Airport in Boston after screeners found a bomblike device in his luggage, officials said. The man, Jacques Jean, 43, of Malden, was scheduled to fly to Miami on an American Airlines flight, en route to Haiti. When security employees searched his oversized bag, they found an alarm clock attached to three red tubes with protruding wires, an official at the Transportation Security Administration said. Mr. Jean, who was charged with transporting a hoax device, faces up to five years in prison and a $5,000 fine. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Woods Ties Record, But Singh Has Lead
description: Tiger Woods reached a milestone with ease on Friday, but Vijay Singh and Davis Love III continued to challenge him for the PGA Tour money title.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Pipeline Explodes During Welding
description: A gas pipeline in the Gulf of Mexico exploded during welding. Two people suffered severe burns and flew on a Coast Guard helicopter to a hospital in New Orleans, 75 miles northwest of the work site, while crews searched for a diver who was reported missing. Officials said they had not determined whether the explosion resulted from the welding. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toshiba's Loss Grows
description: The electronics maker Toshiba said its losses widened in the April-September period because of falling demand for its computers and other digital products. Toshiba lost 32.2 billion yen ($293 million) in the first half of its fiscal year, 22 percent more than it lost in the period a year earlier. The company, which is based in Tokyo, lowered its profit forecast for the full year by 29 percent because of the rising cost of components used in the computers it builds. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Rev. V. Gene Robinson, a gay man whose election as bishop has caused a rift in the Anglican Communion, misstated the given name of the former presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church who is expected to help consecrate him. He is Edmond L. Browning, not Frank.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: I.R.A. Apologizes For Killings
description: The Irish Republican Army apologized to relatives of about a dozen people whom it murdered and buried in hidden graves over the 30 years of Northern Ireland's sectarian conflict. The bodies of four victims have been exhumed recently after years of searching. Jean McConville, a Belfast mother of 10, was executed by the I.R.A. in 1972 because she was believed to be aiding British Army soldiers; her remains were identified this week after DNA testing. Her children rejected the apology as meaningless. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Teenager Slain At Playground He Called Too Dangerous
description: Last year, Kamal Singh, a Bronx teenager and a leader of his Norwood neighborhood's youth group, stood before a board of community advocates and said his playground was too dangerous. Yesterday, he was shot and killed there.

title: WorldCom Investor Case Cleared to Proceed as Class Action
description: Citigroup Inc. and its former telecommunications stock analyst, Jack Grubman, must defend class- action claims that they helped defraud WorldCom Inc. investors of $11 billion, a federal judge in New York ruled yesterday.

title: Memorial for Varnedoe
description: A memorial service for Kirk Varnedoe, the former chief curator of painting and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art, will be held on Monday at 5 p.m. at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mr. Varnedoe died on Aug. 14 at 57. Speakers are to include the artist Chuck Close and Philippe de Montebello, the director of the Metropolitan Museum.

title: ABC Replaces Kimmel Producer
description: Looking to expand the audience for the late-night comedy show ''Jimmy Kimmel Live'' beyond its young male base, ABC said this week that it was replacing one of the show's creators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEGLITZ, ANDREW C.
description: STEGLITZ--Andrew C. Age 51. Of Stratford, CT. Died October 22, 2003. Born in Newark, N.J., he was the son of the late Jerome and Charlotte Sobo Steglitz. Survivors include his wife Kathy Schiller Steglitz, a daughter Samanatha, brothers Marc Steglitz and his wife Ilene, Stephen and his wife Laurence, sisters Gail Sager and her husband Ron, Suzy Keegan and her husband Joe, all of New Jersey, and father-inlaw and mother - in - law, George and Lucine Schiller of Niantic, CT. Funeral services Sunday, October 26th, 9:30AM in the Abriola Parkview Funeral Home, 419 White Plains Road, Trumbull, CT.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Peace Corps Head Is Resigning
description: Director Gaddi H. Vasquez of the Peace Corps has resigned effective Nov. 14, saying he wants to help care for his parents in California. Mr. Vasquez, 48, a former Orange County, Calif., supervisor who became director in February 2002, faced opposition to his nomination because he lacked experience with foreign policy and the Peace Corps. He said President Bush gave him steadfast support. John Files (NYT)

title: Fund Manager To Face Charges
description: Burton G. Friedlander, a former hedge fund manager, was indicted yesterday on charges of cheating investors by inflating and misrepresenting the value of his funds.

title: Remembering When Maoists Met the Klan
description: THE Bermanzohns are in their 50's now, and the old chants and slogans do not come so readily to mind. The couple blended years ago into the middle-class anonymity of Park Slope, where they raised two daughters and joined the local food co-op. On weekends their thoughts turn to that modest upstate getaway.

title: Concerns on Safety Push Britain to Reassume Control of Rail Maintenance
description: Spurred by growing safety concerns, Britain's railway authorities reversed a crucial element of the nation's rail privatization on Friday, announcing that maintenance contracts awarded to seven private companies -- worth $2 billion a year -- would be taken over by the government-backed Network Rail.

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: PENNSYLVANIA: REPORT ON MAYOR'S BUG An F.B.I. bug found more than two weeks ago in the office of Mayor John F. Street of Philadelphia did not record incriminating words from him, a federal official said. The official cautioned, however, that investigators could have other evidence that involved Mr. Street that was not from the listening device. The bug was in place for two weeks before a police sweep found it. Mr. Street repeated that the bug would find "no corruption, no sex, no profanity." (AP)

title: Marlins Put Best Pitcher Forward Against Yanks
description: The Florida Marlins want to finish off the Yankees and win the World Series tonight. They have the advantage in games, three to two, but they will not concede a game to bring back their best starter, Josh Beckett, on his normal four days' rest for a possible Game 7 tomorrow. Marlins Manager Jack McKeon is going for it now.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 345 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: When Students Run the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Bank Acquisition Set
description: Australia's fourth-largest bank, the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, said that it would buy the National Bank of New Zealand from Lloyds TSB Group of Britain for 4.9 billion Australian dollars ($3.4 billion) as it seeks to expand beyond its home market. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ASH, GERALDINE (''GERRY'')
description: ASH--Geraldine (''Gerry''), of New York, NY. Formerly of Pound Ridge, NY. Died October 22, 2003. Born to Leo and Gertrude Gage in Providence Rhode Island. She was the owner operator of Gerry Ash. Real Estate Broker in Pound Ridge, NY. Retiring in 1997. Beloved wife to the late Ingram Ash. Loving mother to Steve Ash and Jeff Ash. Grandmother to four. Graveside service Monday, October 27, 2003, 11AM at Pound Ridge Cemetery, Pound Ridge, NY. For information Oelker & Cox Funeral Home, 914 - 666 - 5891. Contributions may be made to Mysitis Association of America.

title: MAXIM INTEGRATED BUYS PHILIPS PLANT IN SAN ANTONIO
description: Maxim Integrated Products, which makes microchips for mobile phones and industrial testing equipment, said yesterday that it had bought a plant that manufactures semiconductor wafers from Royal Philips Electronics for $40 million. The plant, in San Antonio, has as much as $500 million in revenue annually, Maxim said. Maxim plans to add equipment to the plant to produce as much as $1 billion in annual revenue. Maxim, which had no debt at the end of the third quarter, has increased sales and profit for seven straight quarters. The company is based in Sunnyvale, Calif.

title: Covering Their Ears One Last Time for Concorde
description: The Champagne was fake, but the relief for long-suffering residents of Queens was very real at a gathering yesterday at a waterfront park in Howard Beach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZBERG, NEIL
description: SCHWARTZBERG--Neil. On October 21, 2003 at the age of 61 our much loved Neil lost his heroic battle to overcome a prolonged illness. Beloved brother of Paul J. Sutton and Nancy Miller. Cherished uncle of Daniel and Lily Sutton. A gentle soul who had a great capacity to accept whatever life and nature dealt him, Neil devoted most of his professional life in the service of children and young adults with special needs. The family requests that contributions in Neil's memory be made to The Jewish Board of Family and Children Services, 120 West 57th St, NY NY 10019, Attn: Jane Berenbeim, whose work he admired and supported. A memorial service will take place at Noon, Sunday October 26, at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Dissecting the Slugger's Slumps
description: Jason Giambi and Alfonso Soriano combined for 79 home runs for the Yankees during the regular season. But in Game 5 of the World Series neither was in the starting lineup. Giambi, whose batting average was well below his career norm this season, has battled a sore left knee. Soriano has succumbed to a steady diet of sliders, stymying his production and making him look overmatched at the plate.

title: C.I.A. Disputes Accusations That Its Prewar Conclusions On Iraq Arms Were Flawed
description: The Central Intelligence Agency responded angrily on Friday to new Congressional criticism of its handling of prewar intelligence about Iraq's suspected illicit weapons program. At a briefing at C.I.A. headquarters, four senior intelligence officials said that a top-secret internal review now underway had found no evidence of faulty work.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Senator Whom Colleagues Are Hesitant to Cross
description: Senator Ted Stevens has a short fuse and a long memory.
