description: New Plans for Israeli Barrier

title: Bowling Green Anticipating First-of-Its-Kind Showdown
description: West Wooster Street is clogged with cars on a Friday afternoon. The bottleneck has nothing to do with people leaving town for the weekend.

title: Discovering Magdalene the Apostle, Not the Fallen Woman
description: THE GOSPEL OF MARY OF MAGDALA

title: Judge Approves Plan to Settle Doctors' Dispute With Aetna
description: A federal judge in Miami gave final approval yesterday to an agreement between Aetna, the big health insurer, and nearly one million doctors to end a longrunning dispute dispute over patient care and billing practices.

title: Mistrial Shows Risks in Choosing A Path for Prosecution
description: Corporate executives battling criminal charges arising from recent scandals may take some solace in the jury's failure to reach a verdict in the case against Frank P. Quattrone, the former investment banker.

title: World Business Briefing: Africa
description: GHANA: BID FOR MINING COMPANY RAISED The British-based mining company Randgold Resources raised its bid for Ashanti, the Ghanaian gold mining company, to $1.7 billion in stock, topping a rival bid from AngloGold . Randgold's stock bid values Ashanti at $1.7 billion, 12.3 percent higher than the bid made on Oct. 14 by AngloGold. AngloGold, which is based in South Africa, said then that its offer, which is in cash, was final. A winning bidder needs approval from the Ghanaian government, which owns 17 percent of Ashanti, and controls its mining rights. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Bracing for Big Windup As Marlins Go for Knockout
description: PANIC and desperation have gripped Yankeeville. Baseball's most decorated franchise and fattest payroll have come face to face with mortality. The Yankees face elimination from the World Series tonight at the hands of the Florida Marlins. I suspect those fans who felt that nothing could have been worse than losing at home to the hated Red Sox are rethinking their positions: this is worse.

title: Tackling Culpepper Is No Easy Task
description: Giants defensive end Michael Strahan will spend Sunday's game against the Minnesota Vikings chasing a very large target. Normally, Strahan's main worry is getting to the opposing quarterback. With Vikings quarterback Daunte Culpepper, Strahan and the Giants' pass rushers will still have work to do once they reach him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHAZEN, FRANK
description: CHAZEN--Frank. Everyone at Day & Meyer Murray & Young Corp is deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Frank Chazen. An invaluable employee for more than 15 years, Frank was a tireless worker who was both loyal to the Company and fair to everyone. Frank loved the moving and storage industry, and the industry loved him in return. With his rare combination of compassion and a wicked sense of humor, he had more friends than he could count. He was also a proud father, devoted to his daughter Rebecca and his wife Maria. To them, and to the rest of his family, we extend our deepest sympathies.

title: In Bind, Torre Is Expected To Meet Lofty Goals Again
description: Joe Torre has one or two more games to manage with the Yankees in this endless baseball season, to restore order to an unraveling team. The always complex chore of shepherding the Yankees to a World Series title that their principal owner believes they should win in their sleep continues tonight.

title: Man Faces Charges in His Wife's Suicide
description: A Norwalk man whose wife killed herself two years ago was arraigned on Friday in Norwalk Superior Court on charges of second-degree manslaughter.

title: High-Tech Voting, or More Rube Goldberg?
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of the Mainstream, Again
description: Of the many unworthy judicial nominees President Bush has put forward, Janice Rogers Brown is among the very worst. As an archconservative justice on the California Supreme Court, she has declared war on the mainstream legal values that most Americans hold dear. And she has let ideology be her guide in deciding cases. At her confirmation hearing this week, Justice Brown only ratified her critics' worst fears. Both Republican and Democratic senators should oppose her confirmation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, RUTH E. (NEE EMDEN)
description: SIEGEL--Ruth E. (nee Emden). Age 84, of Eastchester, died on October 23. Beloved wife of Frank C. Siegel. Devoted mother of Barbara, Jill and Monica. Cherished grandmother of Lisa, Jay, Jordan, Matthew, Jesse, Leigh, Josh and Allison. She was active in the community. Friends may gather at Westchester Funeral Home Inc., Eastchester on Sunday, October 26, starting at 12 Noon. Service at the funeral home at 1PM followed by interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla. Contributions may be made to the Eastchester Beautification Foundation or to The Association for Macular Diseases.

title: Democrats on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay At Birth?
description: Some people say we should settle gay rights disputes on the basis of the Old Testament. I say we should rely on blinking patterns.

title: Brooklyn Historical Society to Mark New Era
description: For years it has been shrouded, a prized jewel lost behind scaffolding and a century of filth at the corner of Clinton and Pierrepont Streets in Brooklyn Heights. But tomorrow, the now fiery red terra-cotta and brick home of the Brooklyn Historical Society will celebrate its reopening, inviting the public to peruse its exhibits and roam its grand halls and library, whose collection is still cloistered in storage upstate and reopens in June.

title: Monk's Spirit Hovers Over a French Evening
description: France has a number of pianists who are Thelonious Monk-friendly, if not Monk-obsessed. The best of them is Martial Solal, who headlined a concert of French jazz at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night and will appear again this evening.

title: Living In the Age Of Edge
description: If you type the word ''edgy'' into Google, you get half a million hits. You find fashion designers bragging that their new fall line is edgy, magazine editors vowing to be edgy. HBO and Comedy Central claim to be edgy. You find edgy rap and edgy chamber music. But what exactly are these people talking about?

title: When Students Run the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: Straight From the Heart Of a Long-Distance Lover
description: These days, lots of bands are overachieving in the studio. Recording technology is getting cheaper, which means that even indie-rock bands can spend months fiddling with microphones, getting everything just right. Then the CD comes out, and the musicians have to figure out a way to recreate the music onstage.

title: AT HOME ABROAD: Stresses of a move can expose wide cracks in a marriage
description: VIENNA  This isn't the way it was supposed to be, thought Sylvia, as she knelt down to change the baby on the bare hardwood floor. She had agreed to move overseas thinking it would be a good thing for the family, but one month later, with her furniture still in transit, her children unsettled and upset, her husband mostly absent with a new job, Sylvia had bruised knees and sore feelings.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: TOSHIBA' S LOSS GROWS The electronics maker Toshiba said its losses widened in the April-September period because of falling demand for its computers and other digital products. Toshiba lost 32.2 billion yen ($293 million) in the first half of its fiscal year, 22 percent more than it lost in the period a year earlier. The company, which is based in Tokyo, lowered its profit forecast for the full year by 29 percent because of the rising cost of components used in the computers it builds. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: College Football |Kickoff
description: TODAY'S TOP MATCHES

title: The Germans Came; Now They Are Us; An Ethnic Queens Neighborhood Is Melting Away Into America
description: Not long ago, Ridgewood, Queens, was the city's quintessential German neighborhood, where residents would flock on weekends to the nearby Metropolitan Oval for soccer matches between teams with German names, follow up the game with sauerbraten, dumplings and beer, and end the day with polkas at a German social club.

title: Graphic Evidence Offered In Sniper Suspect's Trial
description: The prosecution in the Washington-area sniper case was preparing to show a photograph to the courtroom on Friday when a lawyer for John A. Muhammad leaped to his feet.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR DROPS. The dollar fell as a decline in stocks heightened concern the United States will not attract enough investment to cover its trade deficit. In New York, the dollar settled at 109.25 yen, down from 109.61 on Thursday.

title: Architects Agree to Meet To Work Out Tower Design
description: Trying to resolve their differences over the Freedom Tower at the World Trade Center site, the tower's architect and Daniel Libeskind, the site's master planner, agreed yesterday to work together on a design that would more closely follow the Libeskind plan.

title: U.S. Forces to Lift Night Curfew for Muslim Holy Month
description: Iraq's American overseers said Friday that they would lift the nighttime curfew on Baghdad's five million residents beginning Sunday, to accommodate the country's Muslims during Ramadan and demonstrate that the country is returning to normal despite the persistent armed resistance to the occupation.

title: JUDGE APPROVES PURCHASE OF 6 LORAL SATELLITES
description: Loral Space and Communications, the satellite maker, won bankruptcy court approval yesterday to sell six North American telecommunications satellites for $1.1 billion to Intelsat. Judge Robert Drain of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan approved Intelsat's winning bid, which beat a $1.03 billion offer by EchoStar Communications earlier this week. Loral filed for bankruptcy protection in July, with more than $3 billion in debt. Loral, based in New York, wants to keep five satellites and its manufacturing businesses and sell only its North American satellites as part of the Chapter 11 reorganization. Intelsat, based in Bermuda, said the purchase included four satellites in orbit and two scheduled for launching next year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit For Computer Maker
description: The French computer group Bull said it earned 1.3 million euros ($1.5 million) in the first half, its first profit since 1988, and said it expected to report a profit for the full year as well. The earnings contrasted to a loss of 524.2 million euros ($617 million) for the period a year earlier. Sales, however, fell 18 percent, to 642 million euros ($756 million). The chief executive, Pierre Bonelli, said the return to profit might help the company obtain the financing it needed to repay an overdue 450 million euro government loan ($530 million) and stay afloat. ''We have found lots of investors who are interested,'' Mr. Bonelli said. He added that he expected the company to be able to repay the loan, which was due on June 17, by the end of the year. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Les Misrables
description: The nearest freestanding pay toilet, or sanisette, to my house is in the Place Monge, cunningly disguised as a kiosk covered with film posters. Having never ventured into a sanisette, much preferring to use the pay toilets that abound in cafes and department stores, I approached it reluctantly. I had the required coins (two 20-cent pieces) ready to put into the slot when I saw that the red occupied sign was showing, so I waited. Finally, the door opened and a homeless man, a clochard, stumbled out, fell to his knees and passed out. This was not at all encouraging.

title: A Cultural Scorecard Says West Is Ahead
description: ''I do not set out to write controversial books,'' Charles Murray says with an easy laugh. ''I don't know whether part of the attraction might be the forbidden,'' he adds earnestly. ''If it is, it's not very much.''

title: Madame Chiang Kai-shek, a Power in Husband's China and Abroad, Dies at 105
description: Madame Chiang Kai-shek, a pivotal figure in one of the 20th century's great epics -- the struggle for control of post-imperial China waged between the Nationalists and the Communists during the Japanese invasion and the violent aftermath of World War II -- died on Thursday in Manhattan, the Foreign Ministry of Taiwan reported yesterday. She was 105.

title: Nuclear Plant's Courtship of Its Neighbors Pays Off
description: Given the eventful history of the Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station, people who live near the plant might be excused for the occasional case of the jitters.

title: FORD AND FIRESTONE SETTLE 90 SUITS IN ROLLOVER CASES
description: Ford Motor and Bridgestone's Firestone unit said yesterday that they had settled 90 lawsuits over rollovers of Ford Explorers in Venezuela, Mexico and Colombia. Terms were not disclosed. The agreements lift the threat of large verdicts in the cases, filed in United States courts after the recall in 2000 and 2001 of 10 million Firestone tires made for the Explorer. The cases were consolidated in United States District Court in Indianapolis to streamline proceedings. Bridgestone/Firestone North American Tire said it had resolved 1,300 cases since the tire recall; Ford has settled hundreds of rollover suits.

title: Rights Group Says Zimbabwe Starves Dissidents
description: On the heels of new reports of growing desperation in Zimbabwe, Human Rights Watch charged Friday that the nation's rulers were using its limited food supplies as a weapon of political control.

title: Strike Against Proposal to Raise Retirement Age Paralyzes Italy
description: Planes idled on runways, trains stopped moving and much of Italy slipped into a state of temporary paralysis on Friday, the result of a nationwide strike to protest a proposed increase in the retirement age.

title: Air France Pilot Said to Remark That Jet at J.F.K. Would Explode
description: The police escorted a pilot off an Air France plane that was scheduled to fly to Paris yesterday, after he had made comments to baggage screeners that the plane was going to blow up, he was going to blow up, and the story would end up on the front page of The New York Times, the authorities said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL ELECTRIC, Fairfield, Conn., said it would sell about 5 percent of its reinsurance unit's life policies to Scottish Re Group, Hamilton, Bermuda, a global life reinsurance specialist, for $151 million.

title: New Luxury-Car Specifications: Styling. Performance. Aroma.
description: For Cadillac, the new-car smell, that ethereal scent of factory freshness, is no longer just a product of chance.

title: Lottery Numbers
Germany's Toll-Collection Plan Stalls
description: Few countries take more pride in their highways than does Germany. And few countries get more credit for their engineering talent, especially when it comes to automotive matters.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 16 about two men who were asked by the pastor of St. Benedict's Church in the Bronx to leave the choir after they were married in Canada misspelled the pastor's surname in some references. He is Msgr. Edmund G. Whalen, not Whalan. The article also misattributed a comment. It was Monsignor Whalen -- not Joseph Zwilling, spokesman for the Archdiocese of New York -- who said: ''This is a parish matter. This is not something for the press.''

title: Hevesi Says LIPA Paid Far Too Much To a Top Aide
description: The Long Island Power Authority illegally paid its chief financial officer an exorbitant sum of nearly $600,000 for 14 months of work and should now try to recoup most of the money, the state comptroller said yesterday.

title: No Ligament Damage for Nets' Martin
description: The Nets received good news yesterday when they learned that although Kenyon Martin sprained his right thumb on Thursday night, he did not tear a ligament, as was feared. Martin was injured in the fourth quarter of a preseason game in Philadelphia. He is listed as day to day. The Nets, who lost to the Celtics, 86-82, last night in Boston in their final preseason game, will open the regular season in Toronto on Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Pop and Jazz Guide in Weekend yesterday for a concert by the Japanese band Shonen Knife at Southpaw, 125 Fifth Avenue, in Park Slope, Brooklyn, misstated the day. It is tonight at 8; it was not last night.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a television review in Weekend on Sept. 26 about the PBS series ''The Blues'' misstated the number of blues artists represented by Wixen Music Publishing, whose president accused the show of underpaying for the musical works it used. It is one artist; 500 was the number of songs included in the series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAMPF, ETTA
description: KRAMPF--Etta. October 24, 2003 in her 90th year. Adored and devoted wife of the late Charles. Loving mother of Ira and mother-in-law of Karen (deceased). Devoted grandmother of Brian and Wendy. Dear sister of Ann, Iris, and Sam (deceased). Graveside service October 26, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ 1PM. We will miss you.

title: Zimbabwe's Woes Are Bringing Grief To Its Wildlife, Too
description: Once this 5,700-square-mile expanse of wilderness, Zimbabwe's largest, was one of Africa's grandest showcases of wild animals. These days, it is exhibit A in the unfolding story of their destruction.

title: Beirut and Baghdad: Americans Beware
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Accord To Clean Up Nuclear Complex
description: The state and federal Energy Departments said they had ended a dispute over cleaning up the Hanford nuclear complex, the most contaminated nuclear site in the country. The accord sets goals for the federal government to remove and treat radioactive waste from the reservation in eastern Washington. The federal government stored the equivalent of 78,000 55-gallon drums of waste at Hanford from 1970 to 1985. In World War II and the cold war, Hanford made plutonium for nuclear weapons, including the one dropped on Nagasaki in 1945. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: After Shaky Start, Cohen Takes the Lead
description: Sasha Cohen made her first appearance Friday night in the Skate America competition. Despite a shaky start, she quickly outdistanced the field.

title: Lawyer Upset By Treatment Of Ex-Chaplain For Detainees
description: Capt. James Yee, the former Muslim chaplain at the detention facility at the naval base in Guantnamo, Cuba, who has been charged with mishandling classified information, is being held in maximum security, kept in leg irons and prohibited from reading anything but the Koran, his new defense lawyer said on Thursday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Japan Succumbs to Its Own Pork
description: America's agricultural policies may be outrageous, but when it comes to coddling powerful farming interests, Japan leads the way. That's important to the rest of the world because Japan's determination to protect its farmers at all costs helps reinforce the international status quo, in which rich countries demand that poor countries open markets to manufactured goods even as the rich nations throw up barriers to imported farm products. It's also a stunning example of how agricultural protectionism can hurt a nation's general welfare.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Protest Against Nuclear Controls
description: More than a thousand people who came for Friday Prayers in Tehran demonstrated against a decision to allow more intense inspections of Iran's nuclear sites and to suspend uranium-enrichment programs. After a meeting with the French, British and German foreign ministers in Tehran on Tuesday, Iran announced that it would sign a protocol on inspections and enrichment. Despite the protest, the leader of the Friday Prayers, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, avoided the subject in his sermon, suggesting a consensus on the matter among Iran's decision makers. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Decline on Wariness About Rally So Far This Year

title: A Journey Back to Egypt for a Mummy Thought to Be a Pharaoh
description: Wrapped in clear nylon, a mummy that museum curators here believe to be Rameses I, pharaoh of Egypt from 1293 B.C. to 1291 B.C., is returning to Egypt after more than a century in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BERNSTEIN, SOL
description: BERNSTEIN--Sol. 10/25/99. In 4 long years the memories do recede, but never my loveand guilt. My father, tho the earth covers you, my heart will always see you. Barbar

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS. Natural gas fell as some underground storage tanks approached full capacity. In New York, natural gas for November delivery fell 12.7 cents, or 2.6 percent, to $4.786 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: AK STEEL REPORTS LOSS AND SAYS IT WILL CUT 475 JOBS
description: AK Steel Holding, a maker of automotive steel, said yesterday that it had a third-quarter net loss because of write-downs and said it would lay off 475 salaried workers amid increases in production costs. The net loss widened to $277.5 million, or $2.56 a share, from $3.3 million, or 3 cents, a year earlier, AK Steel said. Sales fell 4.8 percent, to $1.06 billion from $1.12 billion. Most of the third-quarter loss came from writing off the value of assets and deferred tax benefits and from higher prices for energy and raw materials. The job cuts, about 20 percent of AK Steel's salaried work force, will create $35 million in annual savings, the company said.

title: Government Report Links Sports to Rising Cable Fees
description: The soaring cost of sports programming has pushed up cable rates, according to a study released yesterday by the General Accounting Office. The study showed that sports costs had soared 59 percent, while overall costs of cable programming had jumped 34 percent.

title: Companies Everywhere Seek Role in Iraq
description: A DaimlerChrysler vice president described himself as ''eager'' to do business there. And the leader of a Spanish construction consortium dismissed concerns for safety with a shrug.

title: Inside the Workings of a Money Machine
description: The trial of Frank P. Quattrone did not produce a verdict. But it did shed light on the flexible ethical world of initial public offerings in the late 1990's when huge profits were available to anyone able to get in on hot deals.

title: HUNG JURY ENDS TRIAL OF BANKER
description: A federal judge declared a mistrial yesterday in the obstruction of justice trial of Frank P. Quattrone, the Wall Street banker whose pay and deals made him a vivid symbol of the 1990's technology boom.

title: Jets Are Expecting Eagles To Play a Physical Game
description: Jets Coach Herman Edwards will not talk about it publicly, but he has been doing his best in meetings this week to emphasize how physical and tough Sunday's game against the Eagles in Philadelphia will be.

title: Chicago Fire Inquiry Leaves Crucial Question Unanswered
description: Calling for sweeping changes after a fire last Friday killed six people, city officials were unable to say why firefighters could not locate six people who died when they were trapped in a smoke-filled stairway.

title: World Business Briefing: Australia/New Zealand
description: BANK ACQUISITION SET Australia's fourth-largest bank, the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group , said that it would buy the National Bank of New Zealand from Lloyds TSB Group of Britain for 4.9 billion Australian dollars ($3.4 billion) as it seeks to expand beyond its home market.

title: ALLETE, A UTILITY OWNER, TO SPIN OFF CAR AUCTION UNIT
description: Allete, a Minnesota-based utility owner, said yesterday that it would spin off a used-car auction business that is its biggest and most profitable unit. Shares of the business, Adesa, will be distributed to Allete shareholders as a tax-free dividend, the company said. The spinoff is expected to occur in mid-2004 and is subject to approval by securities regulators. Investors had pushed the chief executive, David G. Gartzke, to separate the auto unit from Allete's utilities, which deliver electricity and natural gas in Minnesota and Wisconsin. The auto unit by itself would be more attractive to shareholders willing to accept higher risk for faster growth, investors said.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Weekend yesterday on a review of a Metropolitan Opera production misstated the name of the work. It is ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia.'' (The protagonist, Figaro, fulfills the same function in ''The Marriage of Figaro,'' and the two operas are based on related plays by Beaumarchais.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURTHA, TIMOTHY M.
description: MURTHA--Timothy M. Of Orlando, Fla. Formerly of Crestwood. On October 24, 2003. Devoted husband of Florence Jackman Murtha. Loving father of James and Timothy. Dearest son of the late Thomas and Anne Murtha. Dear brother of the late James, Thomas and John Murtha. Born in Harlem, raised in the Bronx, Tim spent most of his life in New York until he took on the good life in Orlando, Fla. He was a Captain in the U.S. Army, Xerox Account Manager and a golfer. Most importantly, he was a loving husband, caring father and devoted friend. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM Sunday and Monday. Mass of Christian Burial Annunciation Church, Crestwood on Tuesday, October 28 at 10AM.

description: Standard time resumes at 2 a.m. tomorrow. Clocks are set back one hour.

title: Needing a Break, Riley Resigns as Miami's Coach
description: Pat Riley was excited. He had a 6-foot-10 playmaker with similarities to Magic Johnson, three athletic swingmen who were eager to run the floor and a hardy rebounder. They were not his old Los Angeles Lakers, but after missing the playoffs the past two seasons, Riley was optimistic about the potential of his new Miami Heat.

title: ChevronTexaco Signs China Gas Pact
description: The ChevronTexaco Corporation has agreed to supply about $21 billion of liquefied natural gas to China from its Gorgon project in Western Australia.

title: In the Democracy Of Design, Even Bad Taste Is O.K.
description: It is tempting to mock the makeover efforts of the Fab Five, but they've already taken care of that job themselves. As chronicled on Bravo's hit television series, these five gay fashionistas begin their adventures in superhero fashion, responding to bat-signals beamed to their cellphones. They leap into their pumped-up S.U.V. and race to the scene of a crime against taste, teaching hapless heteros about the evils of matted back hair, two-button sport jackets and dirty bath tubs.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Nicaragua: Pesticide Claims Dismissed
description: Dole Food, Dow Chemical and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group won the dismissal of a complaint brought by Nicaraguans seeking to enforce $489 million in judgments obtained in their country for injuries caused by pesticides. Judge Nora Manella of United States District Court in Los Angeles ruled that the judgment could not be enforced against the companies because they were not properly named or legally notified in the Nicaraguan court action. The pesticide, dibromochloropropane, has been linked to cancer and sterility and has been pulled from the market in the United States.

title: High-Tech Voting, or More Rube Goldberg? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: 9 on Council Endorse Brother of Slain Colleague
description: Nine New York City Council members gathered on the steps of City Hall yesterday to honor the memory of the slain Councilman James E. Davis and to endorse his brother, Geoffrey A. Davis, who is running for his Council seat in Brooklyn.

title: High-Priced College Textbooks
description: Many outstanding students do not even apply to college because their families cannot afford the soaring cost of tuition. The most determined students make the leap by borrowing steeply and working long hours. Still, they struggle to pay for textbooks, which can cost nearly $1,000 per year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CULLEN, JOHN B.
description: CULLEN--John B. CEO of King Kullen Supermarkets son of the late Michael J. Cullen founder of America's first supermarket King Kullen on October 23, 2003 of Point Lookout and Montauk, Long Island. Beloved and devoted husband to Doris (nee Hudson) of 58 years. Loving father of Dana Conklin and her husband Ronald, Gail Cullen and her fiance Charles Rencountre, and the late John M. Cullen. Proud and loving grandfather of Paige Bertuglia and her husband Robert, Chad Conklin and his wife Cindy Ann. Cherished great grandfather of Tyler Conklin, Halle Conklin, Skylar Bertuglia and Christopher Bertuglia. John Cullen was a modest, courteous man who will be remembered for his kindness, and his gentle sense of humor. John's three great loves were his family, fishing, and his job. He will be missed by all. Reposing after 2PM Sunday at Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Avenue (Exit 28 N SSPKWY), Wantagh. The rosary will be led by Father Willie Gomes, Sunday 1:00 PM at the funeral home for anyone who would like to attend. A memorial mass will be held Thursday 11 AM At Our Lady Of Miraculous Medal RC Church, Point Lookout, Long Island. Cremation private. In lieu of flowers donations can be sent to: Long Beach Medical Center, 445 East Bay Dr, Long Beach, NY 11561, or St. Mary's Foundation for children, 2901 216th Street, Bayside, N.Y. 11360. Family will receive friends Sunday and Monday 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: Rockers Fast-Forward To Yesteryear's Rebels
description: My life has been flashing before my eyes during the CMJ Music Marathon, which winds up tonight. Not my whole life, just the considerable part that I've spent standing in clubs listening to noisy new bands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOVICK, LOUIS K.
description: NOVICK--Louis K., 84, WW II veteran. Endearing father, CEO, unsurpassed Joie De Vivre. Survived by sons Stephen and Kenny: Maitte; grandchildren Jared, Kerry; step-children Wendy and Rabbi Steven Burton, dearest nephew Joel, nieces Isabel, Jackie among others. Riverside Memorial Chapel, October 26th at 2:15PM.

title: Sharon Says Israel May Extend Barrier Deeper in West Bank
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said Friday that Israel's military was working on a proposal to extend a contentious West Bank barrier with a section that could go into the Jordan Valley near the border with Jordan.

description: The judge overseeing Microsoft's settlement of the government's antitrust case asked yesterday for an explanation of why only nine companies have licensed software to help their programs communicate with Windows.

title: Talking Like a Firebrand, Dean Walks a Fine Line
description: As Howard Dean walked over to pet the 600-pound hogs on a visit to a family farm here on Wednesday morning, he blurted out his imaginary headline, ''Governor speaks with Washington lobbyists.''

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actor Lyle Bettger on Oct. 9 misstated the name used by his father as a third baseman for the St. Louis Cardinals. It was Frank Betcher, not Franklin Bettger; the family later changed the name to Bettger.

title: Safety Note
description: Fire prevention authorities recommend that smoke alarm batteries be changed twice yearly, at the start and the end of daylight time. The change occurs tomorrow morning.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA JAPAN: TOSHIBA' S LOSS GROWS The electronics maker Toshiba said its losses widened in the April-September period because of falling demand for its computers and other digital products. Toshiba lost 32.2 billion yen ($293 million) in the first half of its fiscal year, 22 percent more than it lost in the period a year earlier. The company, which is based in Tokyo, lowered its profit forecast for the full year by 29 percent because of the rising cost of components used in the computers it builds. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Cleaner at Wal-Mart Tells of Few Breaks and Low Pay
description: Every night for months, Victor Zavala Jr., who was arrested on Thursday in a 21-state immigration raid, said he showed up at the Wal-Mart store in New Jersey to clean floors.

title: 'Taboo' Delays Previews 4 Days
description: ''Taboo,'' the new $10 million musical produced by Rosie O'Donnell with music by Boy George, has delayed its first preview, scheduled for last night, for four days. Opening night is still scheduled for Nov. 13 at the Plymouth Theater. The first performance is to be on Tuesday.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: PROFIT FOR COMPUTER MAKER The French computer group Bull said it earned 1.3 million euros ($1.5 million) in the first half, its first profit since 1988, and said it expected to report a profit for the full year as well. The earnings contrasted to a loss of 524.2 million euros ($617 million) for the period a year earlier. Sales, however, fell 18 percent, to 642 million euros ($756 million). The chief executive, Pierre Bonelli, said the return to profit might help the company obtain the financing it needed to repay an overdue 450 million euro government loan ($530 million) and stay afloat. "We have found lots of investors who are interested," Mr. Bonelli said. He added that he expected the company to be able to repay the loan, which was due on June 17, by the end of the year. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: A Visitor From China Eclipses Bush's Stop in Australia
description: The Chinese president, Hu Jintao, addressed Australia's Parliament on Friday, a privilege accorded to him just one day after President Bush, and a juxtaposition almost inconceivable even a year ago in a nation long fearful of China.

title: When Students Run the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: A SPECIAL REPORT: ARTS & ANTIQUES: Sheen of history makes English pieces irresistible
description: LONDON  The irresistible rise of English furniture over the last decade goes beyond the confines of the art market. Rarely discussed in these terms, it is a cultural phenomenon that has more to do with the deeper aspirations of Western society and its yearning for the lifestyle of a bygone age.

title: In Heisman Competition, Fitting Into the Formula Helps
description: Bruce Madej chuckles at the suggestion that his ''publicity machine'' at the University of Michigan won the Heisman Trophy for Charles Woodson in 1997.

title: Westchester Officials Lash Out at Indian Point Owners for Circulating Petition
description: Elected officials in Westchester County lashed out at the owners of the Indian Point nuclear power plant yesterday after learning that people working on behalf of the plant had been circulating a petition in predominantly black and Latino neighborhoods warning of dire environmental consequences to their communities if the plant were to shut down.

title: OVER $13 BILLION IN AID IS PLEDGED TO REBUILD IRAQ
description: The United States, completing an extraordinary campaign for economic aid to Iraq, won commitments on Friday of at least $13 billion over five years for reconstruction of water, power, health care and other systems devastated by the American invasion six months ago.

title: COURT APPROVES SALE OF UAL'S STAKE IN HOTWIRE.COM
description: The UAL Corporation won approval in bankruptcy court yesterday to sell its stake in the Internet travel site Hotwire.com to InterActiveCorp and Hydrogen Properties Inc. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, has said that it expects to earn about $85 million from the sale. It bought its stake in the Internet company for $3.8 million, a UAL spokesman said. UAL and five other airlines own slightly more than 50 percent of Hotwire, but they have not disclosed their individual holdings. Judge Eugene R. Wedoff declined to act on UAL's request to sell part of its 26 percent ownership of the Internet travel agency Orbitz, and scheduled a hearing for next Thursday to consider objections.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: MEXICO: TELECOMMUNICATIONS ACQUISITION The Mexican phone company Telmex said it won an auction for the assets of the bankrupt AT&T Latin America as the billionaire Carlos Slim Helu, Telmex's controlling shareholder, continues his strategy of expanding into the region's telecommunications markets. Telmex, formally Telefonos de Mexico, beat Telefonica of Spain and Embratel of Brazil in the auction, which was held in United States Bankruptcy Court in Miami. The transaction is subject to the court's approval. AT&T Latin America has fixed-line phone operations in Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Chile and Peru but could not make them profitable enough to keep up with payments on the money it borrowed to buy them. Telmex did not say how much it bid. However, under the auction rules the price was at least $117 million. Mr. Slim's mobile phone company, America Movil, is also increasing its regional presence. John Moody (NYT)

title: Report Says E.P.A. Aide Knew Rule Change Could Hurt Lawsuits
description: Congressional investigators have determined that a top Bush administration air-quality regulator was warned that administration proposals to revise federal clean-air regulations could harm government lawsuits to force power plants and refineries to make upgrades that would sharply reduce the pollution they produce.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: A 'Gorby' By Any Other Name Won't Sell
description: He does not like people calling their products ''Gorby'' -- or ''Gorbachev,'' for that matter -- so the former Soviet president, Mikhail Gorbachev, is trademarking his name, his nickname and his distinctive forehead, with its ornate birthmark. He has lent his image to Pizza Hut and Apple computers, but he was paid well for that. When he recently came across his face on a brand of Russian vodka, he decided to take control and allow himself to be associated only with what a spokesman called ''respectable products.'' Mr. Gorbachev has no plans to put out his own brand of vodka, the spokesman said. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Congressional Resolve on Cuba
description: Though normally inclined to follow their president's lead on foreign policy, many Congressional Republicans have now broken ranks on Cuba. By a wide margin, the Senate joined the House on Thursday in voting to ease travel restrictions to Cuba, just two weeks after President Bush vowed to toughen sanctions on the government of Fidel Castro and enforce them more energetically. The renegade Republicans apparently think that Mr. Bush's approach is dictated less by a coherent vision than by electoral concerns involving anti-Castro Republican voters in Florida.

title: Giambi to Have Surgery On Knee After the Season
description: The Yankees learned yesterday the extent of the knee injury that forced Jason Giambi to take himself out of the lineup for Game 5 of the World Series on Thursday. The Yankees announced that Giambi would have surgery after the World Series, something Giambi has expected for months.

title: AT HOME ABROAD: Number of Japanese expats rises
description: TOKYO  While Japan grapples with the demographic challenges of aging and declining birth rates, its citizens living abroad are on a steady rise.

title: Congress Planning to Curb Growth of Medicare Budget
description: Congress will create a mechanism to slow the growth of Medicare spending when it adds drug benefits to the health insurance program for the elderly, the chairman of a panel writing the law said on Friday.

title: Leaping Forward Online, With Amazon as Her Guide
description: PEGGY YU requires all employees at her online book business here to read ''E-Commerce Empire: The Legend of Amazon.'' She sifts for fresh ideas by analyzing Amazon's latest database and customer-service innovations. She still recalls her husband's reaction when she first showed him the Amazon Web site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PURNELL, RICHARD I.
description: PURNELL--Richard I. Of Locust Valley and Fishers Island, N.Y. On October 21, 2003, age 85. Beloved husband of Marguerite H., cherished father of Marguerite W. and Peter F. (Suzanne) and proud grandfather of Jimmy, Teddy, Bobby and Henry. Survived by many nieces, nephews and cousins. Visitation will be at Dodge-Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, N.Y. on Monday, October 27th from 4-7PM and Tuesday, October 28th from 9AM10AM. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, October 28th at 11AM at St. Johns of Lattingtown. Private burial to be held at Fishers Island. In lieu of flowers donations in Richard I. Purnell's name may be made to Princeton University Class of 1940. Memorial Scholarship Fund, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center or The Kent School.

title: Viewership Up in Game 5
description: Florida's 6-4 victory over the Yankees in Game 5 on Thursday night attracted an average of 19.9 million viewers, a 26 percent increase from the comparable game last year in the Anaheim-San Francisco series. There has been a 14 percent increase in viewership in the five games of the Series over last year. Richard Sandomir

description: BASEBALL

title: Knicks Face Roster Decisions
description: The Knicks' starters did not play one game as a unit during the preseason. After scoring just 60 points against Utah on Thursday night in a loss to close out the exhibition schedule with a 2-6 record, the Knicks have just three practices left in which to heal, to sort out the roster and perhaps to add a shooter before their season opener Wednesday.

title: Congress Is Close To Eliminating A Privacy Law
description: Congress is poised to pass a law that would strike down groundbreaking rules in California intended to give people the power to stop banks, insurers and brokerage firms owned by the same company from swapping their financial secrets.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: 6 Red Brigades Suspects Arrested
description: The police arrested six suspected members of the Red Brigades terrorist group on Thursday night in connection with the murder of a government adviser in 1999. The arrests were the fruits of a fresh investigation after a fatal shootout in March between Brigades members and police officers on a train in central Italy. The leftist group, which terrorized Italy in the 1970's, claimed responsibility for the shooting of the adviser, Massimo d'Antona. Last year, a bullet from the same gun killed another government adviser. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

Boston for Beans

description: TICHNER--Alan. Uncle Alan, my mentor and my friend. I will miss you. Your loving nephew, Jay

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 28 with a diagram of the Queen Mary 2, which is scheduled to be berthed in New York at the same time as the Queen Elizabeth 2 in April 2004, misstated the date the original Queen Mary and Queen Elizabeth were last docked together in the city. It was December 1948, not March 1940.

title: The River: An Object of Beauty, and a Mode of Transport
description: FROM George Bingham's paintings of pioneer life on the Missouri to the adventures of Huckleberry Finn, rivers have long been a source of inspiration for American artists and writers. Partly this is because of their natural beauty, and partly because, until the 1870's, rivers were the byways of America. As a means of trade and communication, they were superseded only by the railroad and the telegraph.

title: Peter Oehrlein, Mark Rinis
description: Peter Herbert Oehrlein and Mark David Rinis are to affirm their partnership today in a civil union ceremony at the gazebo in Faulkner Park in Woodstock, Vt. Paul H. Wildasin, a Vermont justice of the peace, will officiate.

title: My Father's House
description: Unlike other 20th-century architects, Louis Kahn designed modern buildings that captured, with ordinary brick and concrete, the grandeur of ancient structures. His forms -- like the shallow, light-washed arches of the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, or the fortresslike turrets of the capital buildings in Dhaka, Bangladesh -- are both starkly abstract and richly evocative.

title: Colleen Meade, Thomas Claps
description: Colleen E. Meade, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Meade of Oakland, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas E. Claps, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Claps of Glen Ridge, N.J. The Rev. George W. Rutler, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCDONALD, MICHAEL F.
description: McDONALD--Michael F. Age 52. On September 26, 2003 in Manhattan, of complications from AIDS. Volunteer at Gay Men's Health Crisis from beginning of epidemic, later a staff member for several years. Long-time member of NYC Gay Men's Chorus. Survived by many friends and family including brothers Tom and John and sister Patrice. Donations: NYC Gay Men's Chorus, 1133 Broadway, Suite 1001, NY, NY 10010

title: Habitats/East Fifth Street; For an Old Music Hall, Urban Alchemy
description: RECYCLING is both a modern buzzword and an urban necessity. Architecturally, of course, it is what makes cities so visually rich, and so efficient. Consider the nine lives of the broad gray building on East Fifth Street just off the Bowery.

title: A Sunday at the Pool in Kigali
description: In the middle of Kigali there is a swimming pool surrounded by deckchairs and a score of tables all made of white plastic. And forming a huge L overhanging this patch of blue stands the Hotel des Mille-Collines, with its habitual clientele of international experts and aid workers, middle-class Rwandans, screwed-up or melancholy expatriates of various origins, and prostitutes. All around the pool and hotel in lascivious disorder lies the part of the city that matters, that makes the decisions, that steals, kills, and lives very nicely, thank you. The French Cultural Centre, the UNICEF offices, the Ministry of Information, the embassies, the president's palace (recognizable by the tanks on guard), the crafts shops popular with departing visitors where one can unload surplus black market currency, the radio station, the World Bank offices, the archbishop's palace. Encircling this artificial paradise are the obligatory symbols of decolonization: Constitution Square, Development Avenue, Boulevard of the Republic, Justice Avenue, and an ugly, modern cathedral. Farther down, almost in the underbelly of the city, stands the red brick mass of the Church of the Holy Family, disgorging the poor in their Sunday best into crooked mud lanes bordered by houses made of the same clay. Small red houses - just far enough away from the swimming pool not to offend the nostrils of the important - filled with shouting, happy children, with men and women dying of AIDS and malaria, thousands of small households that know nothing of the pool around which others plan their lives and, more importantly, their predictable deaths.

Our managing agent suggested putting the vents on a timer that would turn them off for specific periods, when we could use our fireplaces. Should I be circling daffodil sites with stakes and yellow ribbons?

title: 'My Father Wasn't There'
description: TERRI SCHIAVO'S eyes are often open, and, in photographs, seem clear. She smiles. When her parents, Bob and Mary Schindler, look at her face, they think she is still there. That is how we try to measure people. The stranger we encounter. The salesman. The actor on the movie screen. The boyfriend. The wife or husband. The child -- especially if it is our child. Especially if the child is hurt, and we think we can help.

People said he'd been in a terrible car accident, which was the reason for his surly temperament and the scar that curled between his bushy eyebrows. There were the rumors that Mr. Wells drank too much, that he once sang opera and that he liked young women, as young as we were then. What I could see was that one of his eyes was larger than the other. His look was belligerent and quizzical, the wider eye sizing everyone up and being, as usual, summarily disappointed.

title: Franju's Extremely Haunting Makeover
description: HORROR movies have traditionally received little to no respect from educated, art-house-type audiences, so it's hardly surprising that Georges Franju's haunting ''Eyes Without a Face'' (''Les Yeux sans Visage,'' 1960) was totally ignored by the foreign-film crowd when it opened in the United States in 1962. At the time, of course, viewers wouldn't have easily recognized it as an ''art film,'' since it was released dubbed, on a double-bill with some long-forgotten shocker, and retitled ''The Horror Chamber of Dr. Faustus.'' (Was ''Eyes Without a Face'' somehow not a scary enough concept? Or was the wily distributor hoping to rope in unsuspecting fans of Christopher Marlowe?) But ''Eyes Without a Face'' will rise from the grave of B-movie oblivion this Halloween, when it begins a two-week run on Friday at Film Forum in Manhattan in a new, freshly subtitled print. ''Dr. Faustus'' will not be present.

The International Teleworkers Association estimates that there are 28 million workers who fit that description and predicts that this will increase by 6 million over the next three years.

But he is also from North Carolina, loves his mama (with whom he has collaborated on three cookbooks) and knows the value of a good casserole. In fact, he has written a new book about them, ''Crazy for Casseroles'' (Harvard Common Press), in which he asserts that they ''remain one of America's greatest contributions to world gastronomy'' and that they ''will undoubtedly still be around long after much of today's phony novelty has been burned to a crisp.''

title: The Perils of Living Too Long

Others (Billie Holiday, Chet Baker, Bill Evans) lead lives that are like slow-motion deaths, lives that give their music a sweet, decadent perfume and make the flaws in their art seem like so many needle tracks, scattered traces of disintegration. But there is another way of exiting the scene: living too long, passing the years unproductively, falling silent. Less noticed and far more common, it's the surest route to obscurity that the music offers.

title: The (Agri)Cultural Contradictions of Obesity
description: Pollan's thesis that government subsidies in the early 1970's helped to produce ''cheap'' food, enabling fast food institutions to force ever larger burgers down our throats, ignores more significant historical and technological developments. It was exactly at this time that women of child-rearing age greatly expanded their roles in the labor force. This reduced the likelihood that children would be coming home to healthy, home-cooked meals as time became an increasingly scarce commodity. This radical change in family structure, more so than the declining price of corn feed, prompted the extraordinary growth of the McDonald's and Burger Kings. Furthermore, by 1975, sales of microwave ovens exceeded those of gas ovens for the first time. And of course, let's not forget the explosion of cheap electronic games that produced more sedentary children than ever before!

description: The Habitats column last Sunday, about an executive who recently moved from the Upper East Side to the West Side, described her building's lobby incorrectly and misstated the location of a store. The lobby has no fireplace, and the Victoria's Secret store is part of the building, not next to it. A picture caption misstated the street; it is 85th, not 86th.

title: Corrections
description: A footnote with the mutual fund performance tables provided by Morningstar Inc. on Oct. 5 in the Mutual Funds Report, Part 2 of this section, defined ''manager years'' incorrectly. It is the average tenure of all past and current managers of a fund, not the tenure of the current manager.

title: Corrections
description: A review of ''Hawthorne: A Life,'' by Brenda Wineapple, on Oct. 5 included a name incorrectly among those of Nathaniel Hawthorne's fellow members of the Bowdoin College class of 1825. Henry Wadsworth Longfellow was a member, but Franklin Pierce (later the 14th president of the United States) was in the class of 1824.

title: Page Two: Oct. 19-25; THE READING FILE
description: Bleak Reading, From Arabs, About the Arab World

title: End of the Big Map Is No Big Deal? Really?
description: The demise of a state plan to contain sprawl -- called the Big Map, in Trenton's shorthand -- has surprised more than a few, including environmentalists, who sense a wobbling in the McGreevey administration.

title: Riley Taught Hard Lesson, Fashionably
description: About five years ago, Pat Riley heard that Todd Day was upset with his methods. A marginal N.B.A. player had been talking smack behind his back.

title: BENEFITS
description: Athletes Help Fight A.L.S.

title: Redrawn by Rembrandt
description: ''REMBRANDT'S JOURNEY,'' a subtle exhibition examining the artist as storyteller at the Museum of Fine Arts here through Jan. 18, includes only one image not by Rembrandt. It is an etching by Hercules Segers, a Dutch painter and printmaker who died around 1638, when Rembrandt was 32. Segers made this print, ''Tobias and the Angel,'' sometime in the 1620's. About 30 years later, Rembrandt altered the copper plate to tell a different story, ''The Flight Into Egypt.''

title: Singing Off-Key for Hollywood
description: IF it seems like a shockingly bad idea to turn the brilliant, meandering mini-series ''The Singing Detective'' into a less-than-two-hour film -- a concept as silly as reducing Proust to a paragraph -- consider this: Dennis Potter did the damage to himself. Potter was among the greatest television writers who ever lived, but he was eager to sell out to Hollywood.

title: Cheese, Salami and Curry For a Star of 'The Cooler'
description: FOOD was certainly the No. 1 topic of conversation for the actress Maria Bello and her family last week. Ms. Bello lives in Los Angeles but was in New York for filming on ''Secret Windows, Secret Garden,'' a movie starring Johnny Depp based on a Stephen King novella. She used a day off to have dinner with her parents and grandmother, who live near Philadelphia. Ms. Bello, also in ''The Cooler,'' which opened the Hamptons International Film Festival on Wednesday, went to Balducci's on West 66th Street with her mother to stalk cheese and salami.

title: Young Ace Has Winning Hand, And Yankees Are Sent Reeling
description: They had seemed so close to overcoming everything, to stamping a most uncomfortable season with a happy ending. When the Yankees beat the Florida Marlins' Josh Beckett last Tuesday in Miami, they were two victories from the championship demanded by their principal owner, George Steinbrenner. They were that close to a winter of relief.

title: Streetscapes/Broadway Between 122nd and 135th Streets; 125th St. Viaduct: Architecture, Engineering or Both?
description: IS it purely engineering -- or is it significant architecture? Either way, the 125th Street viaduct of the Nos. 1 and 9 Broadway subway line was designated a landmark in 1981 -- although the City Planning Commission later objected that preserving the viaduct would depress the area. Now New York City Transit is halfway through a two-year rehabilitation of the striking structure, a renovation that can help an architectural pilgrim judge whether it is blight or beauty.

title: BooHeaven
description: Trick or treat . . . or tweed.

title: Enough to Make You Sick?
description: Twenty-five years ago, I had a good friend (he later died from AIDS) who grew up near the ''Fort Apache'' precinct of the South Bronx. Coming from an upper-middle-class background, I could never understand the extent to which his and his extended family's lives were riddled with illness, bad fortune and seemingly random tragedy. Your article makes it clear that it is not a matter of bad fortune but a quagmire of impossible obstacles to overcome each day.

title: Lauren Effron, Mark Posin
description: Lauren Rae Effron and Mark Abraham Posin were married last evening by Rabbi Stephen J. Einstein at Congregation B'nai Tzedek in Fountain Valley, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNURR, WILLIAM B.
description: SCHNURR--William B. and Constance T. of Cinnaminson, NJ. William B., 76, author and writer, on March 27, 2003. Constance T. Burke, 70, author and illustrator, on December 21, 2002. Survived by sister Eileen, brother Herman, nieces and nephews Lisa and Maura Schnurr, Lee, Linda, Maryann, Tim, Terry, and John Wilkinson. Loved and mourned forever.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THERE'S perky Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis, barely 20), walking to school at the beginning of the original HALLOWEEN (1978), John Carpenter's truly scary movie. She's going to wish she'd never agreed to baby-sit that night. For those who have never seen this or any of the seven ''Halloween'' sequels (so far), the problem in Laurie's town is little Michael Myers (Will Sandin), who stabbed his big sister to death 15 years ago. He's all grown up and out of the mental institution, and his psychiatrist (Donald Pleasence) is worried that big Michael (Tony Moran) may do something really evil. The psychiatrist is right -- Sunday at 4 p.m., Thursday at 8 and 11:30 p.m. and Friday at 6 p.m. on FX.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Jazzy B; Riffs From the Punjab
description: ''JAZZY!'' yelled a turbaned cab driver on West 34th Street. ''Hey, Jazzy B.'' The driver had stopped his cab -- and traffic -- and was waving at a slight young man on the sidewalk wearing tight velour pants, lots of jewelry and spiked hair. It was the bhangra singer known as Jazzy B, who until then had been walking in Midtown Manhattan unrecognized.

title: Locker Room Luxury
description: Even in a market that is oversaturated with high-end leisure wear, shoppers are flocking to soak up one more drop in the form of a fur-lined hooded sweatshirt jacket from Juicy Couture.

title: As Yankees Face Change, Torre Will Be a Constant
description: Joe Torre was vacationing in San Francisco last October with his wife, Ali. The Yankees had been eliminated in the first round of the playoffs, and the World Series, by coincidence, was taking place a few blocks from Torre's hotel.

title: Enough to Make You Sick?
description: As an Episcopal priest serving in an inner-city neighborhood in North Philadelphia, I have personally witnessed the miseries that are so well described in Epstein's article. For people living in such destructive circumstances, the only sane response is deep depression. It has been frustrating to see the billions of dollars going first to conquer and now rebuild Iraq while our own cities and people suffer so much from lack of concern on the part of our government. One wonders about our priorities.

title: No More Plath, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Jo Laird, Michael Danoff
description: Jo Backer Laird, the general counsel of Christie's auction house in New York, was married last evening to I. Michael Danoff, an art historian and a curator. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: His Job Is in New York City, But His Heart Is at the Shore
description: JACK FORD was home in Spring Lake that day, two years ago, waiting for his wife and son to drive home from his daughter's lacrosse game at Yale. On the way, though, there was a car accident; his wife, Dorothy, broke her back, and their son, Colin, then 15, suffered internal injuries and was in critical condition for a time.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on Oct. 12, about Chicago, misstated a word in a quotation attributed to the architect Daniel Burnham, for whom a local hotel is named. Willis Polk, a friend, wrote to Burnham's friends and colleagues after his death that the architect had said, ''Make no little plans,'' not ''small.''

title: A Gymnast's (Bigger) Room of Her Own
description: Tasha Schwikert, a Las Vegas native, won the world's attention at the 2000 Olympics after she took the place of an injured athlete. Now 18, she just moved into a bedroom with its own bath and more privacy from her sister, Jordan, and her parents.

title: The 'Kill Bill' Soundtrack: D.J. Quentin's Recycled Mix
description: MUCH has been made of the kung-fu grip of Quentin Tarantino's constantly morphing ''Kill Bill Vol. 1.'' But the commentary has missed one essential fact about Mr. Tarantino: he is the movie world's D.J., and ''Kill Bill'' is another one of his mix tapes. He nestles his flamboyantly shallow film in a comforting bed of recycled music.

title: Been Down So Long It Looks Like Up to Them
description: Declaring a new low is always dangerous in New Jersey politics. Just when you think you have hit rock bottom, someone is busy tunneling under your feet.

title: Brooklyn Man Held In Shooting of Officer
description: A man wanted in the Oct. 19 shooting of an off-duty police officer in Brownsville, Brooklyn, was arrested early yesterday in Norwich, Conn., the police said.

title: Tending to an Estate, but It's Not Your Own
description: FOR 23 years, sailboats bobbing in Manhasset Bay and the sweeping lawns of Sands Point beyond were the views Victor Marchese enjoyed from his hilltop cottage near the tip of the Great Neck peninsula. His gardens were extensive: more than seven acres of towering copper beeches and weeping willows, fragrant lilac bushes and nearly half an acre of tomatoes, Swiss chard and lettuces encircled by hydrangeas, snapdragons and dahlias. Bright yellow chrysanthemums blossomed in his greenhouse, along with an assortment of orchids.

title: Page Two: Oct. 19-25; MEANWHILE, IN ASIA
description: The most interesting moments in the president's six-nation tour of Asia and Australia came when his hosts told him what they thought of American foreign policy. Sometimes, it was a rude surprise for the president, as when when Indonesian religious leaders said that they thought Americans regarded all Muslims as terrorists.

title: Center for Disabled Faces Fiscal Hard Times
description: Financial problems at the Westchester Institute for Human Development in Valhalla are threatening to bring some layoffs or service changes next year, officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MATTERN, THEODORE
description: MATTERN -- Theodore. On October 20, 2003. He leaves two children, Marc Fisher of New York City and Lynne Karen of Waccabuc, NY; seven grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Services were private.

title: Lost in Column A and B For Authenticity, and Adventure,
description: IN the lobby of Hunan Cottage is a blackboard, and on the blackboard are columns of Chinese characters. Presumably they are today's specials, but all I can read are the numbers at the foot of each column: $16.95, $22.95, $32.95. I ask a waiter to translate. His responses are cryptic: ''Lobster. Crab. Soup.'' He smiles, shrugs, walks away.

title: Business; Turning to Tutors, Instead of Schools
description: PARENTS who want to educate their children at home, but lack the time, skill or inclination to do it themselves, are increasingly replacing school with tutors. While most tutors work on their own, a few small companies are getting into the act as middlemen or to provide tutors directly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DANIEL, BEVERLY L.
description: DANIEL--Beverly L. On September 19th, 2003. A remarkable woman who we will truly miss. We were blessed to have her in our lives. She loved us and taught us great values. She lived her life for peace on earth and justice for all. Service will be held 11 AM, Sunday, November 23rd, at Temple Ansche Chesed, 251 West 100th Street, NYC. Shalom and love, Josh, Sean, Emily, Ruthie, Lily, Ruby, Quincy and Jo

title: Notion Building
description: While I applaud the development of a ''think tank on steroids'' for Democrats, I was surprised to see no mention of the environment or alternative energy sources as potential big ideas. A rational and forward-looking policy effort here could pay great dividends. Jobs and the economy? If we don't develop the green technologies of the future, Europe, Japan and China will.

title: Glamorous Generic, As a Shield From the Glare
description: SOME hold that you can't be too thin. But come on -- that's thinking small. The truth is, you can't be too flat. At least, that's what one imagines upon slipping into the spectacularly two-dimensional world of Alex Katz.

title: The Storytellers Daughter
description: Iam three years old. I am sitting on my father's knee. He is telling me of a magical place: the fairytale landscape you enter in dreams. Fountains fling diamond droplets into mosaic pools. Coloured birds sing in the fruit-laden orchards. The pomegranates burst and their insides are rubies. Fruit is so abundant that even the goats are fed on melons. The water has magical properties: you can fill to bursting with fragrant pilau, then step to the brook and drink-and you will be ready to eat another meal.

description: To the Editor:

title: Kasparov Plays the Wily Spider To His Opponent's Hapless Fly
description: One of the most intricate subterfuges in chess strategy is to feign a weakness to beckon hapless opponents into a trap. It's risky, because if you have not judged all the complications, you might turn out to be the one caught in a trap. On the one hand, you must instill in your adversaries the belief that they are facing an attractive opportunity to win, while, on the other, concealing the resources to set them back.

title: Italian Racer Ends a Long, Tough Climb
description: CANTU, Italy  He has had a tough time lately, but the Cricket is still chirping.

description: ROSNER--Anne. On October 25. Beloved wife of Harold for 54 years. Loving mother to Jeffrey, Susan and Phil Ragusa. Devoted grandmother to Michelle, Vanessa, Jessica and Zachary. Devoted sister and sister-in-law to Shirley and Charlie Simon, Rita Abelson and Shirley Dubin, and ''mother'' to her many nieces and nephews.

title: While Fans Headed Out, Steinbrenner Lingered
description: Frank Sinatra sang ''New York, New York'' solo last night. Yankees fans were in no mood to sing along, and they could not get to the exits quickly enough. They grumbled when they found barricades blocking the gate behind home plate, making their stay longer than it had to be.

title: Editors' Note; Safety Note
description: Fire prevention authorities recommend that smoke alarm batteries be changed twice yearly, at the start and the end of daylight time. The time change occurred this morning.

title: Eileen Atkins, Performing As Herself
description: ''THE RETREAT FROM MOSCOW'' at the Booth Theater opens with Eileen Atkins in the shadows. The men (John Lithgow as the departing husband, Ben Chaplin as the concerned son) chat uneasily and the lights go up on Alice, a woman of a certain age in an Eileen Fisher outfit, revealing only a fraction of the splendid Atkins legs, the kind of woman who lives for her family, with just a little left over for her poetry anthology and the church, a woman who knows all about becoming ''invisible,'' possibly the one thing Dame Eileen cannot quite manage.

title: Point and Click, Or Call Agent?
description: BOBBY TUCKER, an executive at a brokerage in Little Rock, Ark., was looking forward to a vacation most travelers only dream about: a quick stop in London, a safari in Tanzania with a week to unwind afterward in the Seychelles and possibly a few days in Paris and Burgundy on the way home.

title: Page Two: Oct. 19-25; Videotapes, Unbound
description: THERE was a sigh of relief in Hollywood after it was announced last week that, yes, movie studios could send videotapes of films to Academy voters for Oscar consideration.

title: For Many College Students, A Job (or Two) to Pay Tuition
description: BRANDON COX, a senior at the University of Kansas, has struggled to make ends meet throughout his college years. In particularly hard times, he has considered selling his blood to earn extra cash.

title: Corrections
description: An automobile review of two Toyota Scion models last Sunday misidentified the version that is available with side air bags. The xA hatchback, not the boxy xB wagon, offers side air bags for the front seats, along with curtain bags that cover the side windows, as an option.

title: How Fourth and Eighth Graders Fared on the New York State Math Test
description: Math scores for fourth graders soared so high around the state this year that some experts wondered whether the tests, which were given in the spring, were simply too easy. In the city, the gains were even greater.

title: The Jersey Genre: It Works for Him
description: MYRON BOLTAR lives a rather lumpen life. A sports agent based in New Jersey, he always seems to be struggling with his business -- clients die on him with regularity and he often appears to be distracted in resolving one or another major crisis laid on him by friends, former lovers and other dastardly types.

title: The Sinister Beauty of Global Conspiracies
description: CONSPIRACY theories are a grand old American tradition -- the mother of them all being the speculation surrounding President John F. Kennedy's assassination. In the entertainment field, paranoia sells -- from the novels of Tom Clancy to the ''X-Files'' to an endless series of Hollywood blockbusters. After pornography, among the most visited sites on the Internet are those devoted to conspiracies.

title: RANDY MOSS VS. WILL ALLEN
description: MOSS -- The Vikings receiver has impressed teammates with improved discipline and work ethic. He has dazzled opponents with his 39 catches for a league-leading 666 receiving yards. His six touchdown catches tie him with the Colts' Marvin Harrison for the league lead.

title: Chinatown Journal; Store Founded in 1891 Succumbs to Effects of 9/11
description: Next to a kitschy gift shop that sells ninja action figures and wax paper umbrellas, a metal security gate shrouds a storefront. Standing on the sidewalk, Paul J. Q. Lee, the stocky 53-year-old proprietor of the shuttered business, peers inside through a tiny slit and shakes his head.

title: Preparing for SARS
description: Health authorities are preparing for the possible return of the SARS virus this fall, but with any luck they should be able to prevent a global epidemic. The virus is a nasty germ that can inflict terrible harm on anyone who contracts SARS. But the virus is relatively hard to spread and the conditions that allowed the disease to race from nation to nation last season seem unlikely to repeat themselves.

Feury and Theodore P. Feury Jr. of Manlius, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Gregg performed the ceremony at the West Charlton United Presbyterian Church.

description: INSURANCE companies have long covered towns and cities against losses from liability lawsuits, but since the Sept. 11 attacks the premiums for the insurance have risen so dramatically that many municipalities have decided to take on the risk themselves.

description: LADEN--Donald. On October 24, 2003. Beloved companion of Donna Carter and husband of the late Rose. Loving father of Wendy and Glenn, and father-in-law of Seth. Dear brother of Bob. Adoring grandfather of Samantha and Jared. We will miss you and we love you very much. Service Sunday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: The (Agri)Cultural Contradictions of Obesity
description: Regarding Pollan's explanation of increasing obesity in Americans, are we absolutely certain that the drugs and hormones administered to livestock aren't having an effect? Their purpose, obviously, is to make the animal gain weight.

description: More than half a century since Paul Robeson was brought before the House Un-American Activities Committee, he will be honored with a quintessential American tribute: a commemorative postage stamp.

description: IN looking to buy a house in Nassau County that would be convenient to their jobs, Danny and Gina O'Connor found that new or renovated homes averaged around $400,000, which was more than they could afford.

Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CULLEN, JOHN B.
description: CULLEN--John B. CEO of King Kullen Supermarkets son of the late Michael J. Cullen founder of America's first supermarket King Kullen on October 23, 2003 of Point Lookout and Montauk, Long Island. Beloved and devoted husband to Doris (nee Hudson) of 58 years. Loving father of Dana Conklin and her husband Ronald, Gail Cullen and her fiance Charles Rencountre, and the late John M. Cullen. Proud and loving grandfather of Paige Bertuglia and her husband Robert, Chad Conklin and his wife Cindy Ann. In lieu of flowers donations can be sent to: Long Beach Medical Center, 445 East Bay Dr, Long Beach, NY 11561, or St. Mary's Foundation for children, 2901 216th Street, Bayside, N.Y. 11360. Family will receive friends Sunday and Monday 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: Corrections

The play has performances on Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m. and Sundays at 2. It does not have performances on Fridays and Saturdays at 2 p.m.

title: In a Battered City, Hope
description: ON the weekend that ground was broken for the much talked about Mount Vernon Hip-Hop Culture Gallery, four young people were shot on the city's rough south side.

title: The Fortress of Monoglot Nation
description: ''There is no Frigate like a book / To take us Lands away,'' wrote Emily Dickinson. But the ship most American readers sail remains strictly within national borders. According to a recent Publishers Weekly article, of all the books translated worldwide, only 6 percent (maybe less) are translated from other languages into English. By contrast, almost 50 percent are translated from English into those other languages. We all know that events of global importance take place outside our linguistic borders every day. And since our educational system is famous for how poorly it teaches foreign languages, it might try to compensate by offering students a lot more books in translation.

description: THIS is the history of science as if told by J.R.R. Tolkien or George Lucas.

title: Transfer Taxes at Work: Big Bucks for Outbuildings

But it would not stop an 18th-century farmhouse -- the most important historical feature -- from being turned into a modern-day office building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENWALD, RAYMOND J.
description: GREENWALD--Raymond J. Our gratitude for his gracious and long time support of the two Park Avenue beautification programs. Ronald D. Spencer, Chairman Margaret Ternes, Executive Director The Fund for Park Avenue

title: Expanding Club NATO
description: I've been a long and cranky opponent of NATO expansion, out of fear that it was going to dilute the organization. But now that NATO is expanding to 26 countries, I say: why stop there? Virtually all of NATO's future threats are going to come not from the east and Russia, but from the south -- the Middle East and Afghanistan. So if NATO really wants to secure Europe, it can no longer just be in Europe. It needs to help stabilize these other regions. To do that, NATO needs to add three more members: Iraq, Egypt and Israel. Yes, you read that right.

title: An Old Coach Feels Well Enough to Watch His Son
description: Tom Pettitte does not avoid the games anymore. There used to be a time when he could not watch his son, Andy, pitch for the Yankees. Tom often grew too anxious when he saw Andy in person, and he routinely grew too ornery when he watched the games on television and heard even the most benign criticism of the left-hander who happened to be his gentle, Bible-reading son.

title: City to Hold Memorial Service To Honor Ferry Crash Victims
description: New York City will hold an outdoor memorial service on Wednesday evening to honor the victims of the Staten Island ferry crash that killed 10 people and injured scores of others on Oct. 15.

title: The Philippines Struggles to Cope With Deficits and Insurgents
description: In the last few months, Armando Rosimo had become a symbol of hope in the Philippines, a fearless government investigator leading a series of inquiries into the pervasive tax evasion, corruption and fraud by wealthy families and big businesses that have crippled this nation's finances for decades.

title: Investing; Gingerly, Companies Offer 401(k) Advice
description: MORE 401(k) plans are offering menus so elaborate that employees have trouble making any investment choices. Some employers are reluctant to provide guidance, fearing that they will be held liable if their suggestions turn out to be unpalatable.

description: ALL those Yankee Stadium ghosts could not get the Yankees off the brink of a World Series loss in the House that Ruth Built and that Josh Beckett leveled.

title: Notion Building
description: Who better than John Podesta to lead a new liberal think tank? In the Oxford English Dictionary, ''podesta'' is defined as ''a chief magistrate elected annually in medieval Italian towns and republics with judicial functions and almost unlimited powers.'' I have long thought it a good job description for the man who bears that name.

title: After Girl Is Found Hanged, Father Is Accused of Rape
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 22  On the morning of Sept. 30, a Tuesday, 11-year-old Valerie Charlene Lucie washed dishes and went upstairs to study in her room. By lunchtime, her 7-year-old brother had found her dead, hanging from a dog collar fastened to a tow chain, hooked to the top of her twin-sized canopy bed.

title: Corrections

description: As the Knicks near their season opener Wednesday against Orlando, their injury concerns mount. Guard Allan Houston sat out the latter part of practice yesterday because of discomfort in his surgically repaired right knee.

title: A Quiet Island in Montclair, Mon
description: FIVE years ago Ann-Marie Senior moved into her Montclair home and began creating a second home behind it. Transforming a cinder-block garage and a weed-choked back lot, she and her husband, Kenton, used paint, plants and an eclectic combination of indoor and outdoor furniture to create a garden retreat in the style of their native Jamaica. Now the smell of Blue Mountain coffee and the reggae sound of Bob Marley drift through the brightly colored building and out over a lush array of cannas, castor beans, caladium, passion flower vines and hibiscus.

description: REAL ESTATE transfer taxes have been on the books for four years now in the five East End towns, where they have raised $140 million for the preservation of the region's dwindling tracts of undeveloped land.
