description: Black and white, a favorite color combination of the international fashion world, turned up in Paris two weeks ago for the annual showings, where designers were meanwhile pitching a garden of flowing colors for next spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELIGMANN, LISE R.
description: SELIGMANN--Lise R. Wife of the late Herbert J. Seligmann. On October 19, 2003 in New York City. Born April 24, 1917 in Basel, Switzerland. An erudite woman who gave generously to her many organizations involved in the arts and medical research, especially the Harvard University Library Judaica Division and the Kathleen Ferrier Foundation of London. She is survived by her brother Jean-Marcel Rueff, her niece Lady Catherine Goode (Sir Roy), nephew Philip Rueff (Sandra), her great-niece Naomi Goode, all of England, her first cousin Madeleine Gekiere of New York City and numerous distant cousins and loving friends.

title: U.S. Military Officer Dies in Rocket Barrage at Baghdad Hotel
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 26  An American colonel was killed and at least 16 people were wounded early Sunday when a barrage of air-to-ground missiles from a homemade launchpad slammed into a highly protected hotel where Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz was staying.

title: Dolly Bross, Jack Geary
description: Medora de Marigny Smith Bross, a daughter of John A. Bross of Chicago and the late Louise Smith Bross, was married yesterday to John W. Geary III, a son of Hilary Geary of Southampton, N.Y., and the late Mr. Geary II. The Very Rev. Ralph T. Blackman, dean of St. James Episcopal Cathedral in Chicago, officiated there.

description: A WALKING GUIDE

title: The Night Country
description: COME, DO YOU HEAR IT? The wind-murmuring in the eaves, scouring the bare trees. How it howls, almost musical, a harmony of old moans. The house seems to breathe, an invalid. Leave your scary movie marathon; this is better than TV. Leave the lights out. The blue glow follows you down the hall. Go to the window in the unused room, the cold seeping through the glass. The moon is risen, caught in nodding branches. The image holds you, black trunks backlit, one silver ray fallen across the deck, beckoning. It's a romance, this invitation to lunacy (lycanthropy, a dance with the vampire), elemental yet forbidden, tempting, something remembered in the blood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHUYLER, IRVING M.
description: SCHUYLER--Irving M. Age 94. On Tuesday, October 21, 2003. Devoted husband of 58 years of the late Pearl Bressler. Adoring father of Harvey Bressler Schuyler. Also surviving is a daughter Sandra Jaffee and a grandson Evan Jaffee.

title: Children and Art
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Babes on Broadway'' (Oct. 12): How about making the theaters more child-friendly?

title: With 4 Winners, Trainer Seizes Day at Breeders' Cup
description: It had already been an extraordinary day of racing when a field of 10 horses, with the San Gabriel Mountains in the backdrop anointing them with a rouge halo, high-stepped along the track Saturday for the $4 million Breeders' Cup Classic.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Evangelicals have thought historically, 'Well, we'll do politics the way we do faith -- we'll just convert the opposition.' But you can't do politics the same way you do religion.''

title: Sticker Shock Hits When Student Loans Are Due
description: The image: rosy-faced college graduates bursting into the adult world, unencumbered. The reality: uh, not exactly. Aside from the little matter of finding a job, there are those pesky student loans. And rising tuition equals rising debt; more than half of graduates owe $10,001 to $40,000, according to a Harris Interactive study for Collegiate Funding Services.

title: The Week Ahead; CALLING ALL YOUNG MEN
description: Television's biggest mystery this fall is the case of the missing guys. The audience of 18-to-24-year-old men seems to have suddenly tuned out all of prime-time television, with ratings dropping up to 20 percent. Bewildered television executives may turn panicky if results remain poor this week for the premieres, on the male-friendly Fox network, of shows heavily promoted during the World Series, especially the drama ''24'' and a new comedy, ''Arrested Development.''

title: Don't Tread on Us; Radical Islam Gains a Seductive New Voice
description: AMERICAN officials scolded Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia last week for declaring to the world's largest Muslim organization that Jews control the world and that frustrated Muslims should try to learn from them. President Bush privately told the Malaysian leader that his comments were ''wrong and divisive,'' presidential aides said. The national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, said, ''I don't think they are emblematic of the Muslim world.''

title: Private Sector; Building a Dream on Aching Feet
description: TARYN ROSE loves stylish shoes -- so much so that when she was a resident in orthopedic surgery in the 1990's, she regularly walked the hard hospital floors in 2- and 3-inch heels. As she click-clacked down the halls on her rounds, she noticed that many of her patients were women ''in a lot of pain, and it often came from wearing fashionable shoes that didn't fit,'' she said.

title: Subversive Reading
description: I was thrilled to see the text to three of my ''Five 'Technically' Legal Signs for Your Library'' listed in a sidebar to Margaret Talbot's essay (The Way We Live Now, Sept. 28). The Patriot Act makes it difficult to legally protect patron confidentiality. The associated gag order also means that librarians cannot inform patrons if their personal information has been requested and provided. My signs are a way to end-run the gag order by allowing the library to provide the perfectly legal information that the F.B.I. has not been there . . . yet.

description: Opening This Week

title: Jeter Leaves With a Bad Taste
description: Derek Jeter finished the World Series with perhaps his worst game of the postseason. Jeter led off with a strikeout and went hitless in his last three at-bats, all with a runner on base. Jeter also made an error in the sixth inning on a grounder by Jeff Conine, who scored Florida's second and final run.

The hospital, which has been beset by financial problems and is expected to lose another $13 million this year, said it had already corrected the violations.

title: Bush Praises Aid Donors for Pledges to Help Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  President Bush said on Saturday that the money pledged this week by other countries and international financial institutions to rebuild Iraq would allow the United States "to build on the success" of the military operations there.

Donations may be made to CCNY City College Fund or Pembroke Hill School (Kansas City, MO).

description: IT'S taken us this long to speak openly about his death. The problem for more than half a century, you see, has been that the death of Donald Kinsey seemed so incongruous with everything else that we knew about him.

description: On Thursday, the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York will honor seven local women at its 11th annual Women of Distinction breakfast. One honoree is Joanna Barsh, a director of McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm. While Ms. Barsh was selected because of her efforts to mentor young businesswomen, she may also have the distinction of having the shortest Girl Scout career ever.

title: Learning to Love to Hate
description: Scrutiny of the New York Times best-seller list discloses a new and important trend: Bush-hating has eclipsed Clinton-, Democrat- and liberal-elite-hating. There's Bill O'Reilly, liberal-hater in chief at Fox News, at the No. 2 slot; but Michael Moore's ''Dude, Where's My Country?'' sits on top of the greasy pole, while Al Franken's ''Lies (and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them)'' occupies the No. 3 spot. Molly Ivins's ''Bushwhacked'' is farther down, as is David Corn's ''Lies of George W. Bush,'' a register of alleged mendacity so relentless that it puts one in mind of Mary McCarthy's famous gibe at Lillian Hellman: ''Every word she writes is a lie, including 'and' and 'the.' '' And Jonathan Chait, a centrist who backed the war in Iraq, has given new legitimacy to the genre with a recent Bush-hating confessional of his own in a cover article for The New Republic.

title: The (Agri)Cultural Contradictions of Obesity
description: After reading your article, I am unsure which hypocrisy is more disturbing: that of subsidizing agriculture while calling ourselves a free-market economy or shifting the blame for overeating from consumer to producer in a society that links personal freedom with personal responsibility.

title: Tenants' Group Sues Nassau Rent Board
description: IN a move to avert sharp rent increases for a slowly dwindling supply of affordable apartments, a tenants' group is charging that the Nassau County Rent Guidelines Board violated the state's open meeting law when it set the rent increases last June.

description: WHAT does an increase in jobs really mean?

title: It's a Bird. It's a Helmet. It's an Eyelid.
description: WALKING around Santiago Calatrava's Park Avenue town house is like helicoptering over some of the world's most striking buildings. On one pedestal is a bronze sculpture that resembles the architect's birdlike addition to the Milwaukee Art Museum. In another room, an assemblage of steel cables and ebony cubes echoes his twisting apartment tower in Malmo, Sweden. And upstairs is a bronze sculpture in the form of a long, curved wing. ''This one,'' he says, ''is Tenerife.''

title: She Plays, She Vocalizes, She Accompanies Herself
description: IN a basement control room at the Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens recently, the cellist Maya Beiser was sipping coffee and listening to a mix of David Lang's ''World to Come,'' the 23-minute centerpiece and title track of her latest CD. A computer monitor displayed a rainbow of wave forms representing the work's eight cello and two vocal lines, all performed by Ms. Beiser. And Susan DelGiorno, who produced the recording, soon to be released by Koch International Classics, was using a trackball mouse to play isolated tracks.

It is a place that time forgot, a jumble of auto repair stores and junkyards off I-95 in the northeastern Bronx. Tucked in the middle of the block is Dennis Barbaria's small machine shop, B&L Automotive, hardly bigger than a two-car garage.

description: ONE LAST LOOK

title: What Celebrity Looks Like: The Annie Leibovitz Aesthetic
description: IN August 1991, Demi Moore appeared on the cover of Vanity Fair. As creatures from here to Uranus may recall, she was eight months pregnant and wore nothing but a diamond ring. The picture was taken by Annie Leibovitz, who, a year later, in a commemoration of the controversy, photographed the actress for the cover of Vanity Fair again. Undecided on where to shoot, Ms. Leibovitz and her crew reserved two mobile homes, four hotel rooms and five houses. Like the subjects who surrendered themselves to interminable poses in the earliest days of the camera, Ms. Moore lay for more than 13 hours as make-up artists colored virtually every square millimeter of her skin.

description: William Goldberg, a leader of Manhattan's diamond district known both for dealing in some of the biggest diamonds sold in modern times and for trying to lift his industry's historic veil of secrecy, died Monday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 77.

description: ANTHONY L. T. CRAGG, manager of the $115 million Strong Asia Pacific fund, says that his mutual fund is dominated by value stocks, a lingering result of the Asian financial crisis that began in 1998, but that he is beginning to look for shares of faster-growing companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIFFORD, MARJORIE OTIS
description: GIFFORD -- Marjorie Otis, composer, choir master and music teacher, died at her home in Katonah, NY, on October 8 at the age of 94. Starting in 1930, she taught at various schools, notably Wykeham Rise in Washington, CT; Nightengale Bamford and Lenox in Manhattan; and the Bedford Rippowam School. She then served for 15 years as a volunteer in the Bedford Correctional System teaching both men and women. Mrs. Gifford was a powerful influence in the lives of her many pupils. A memorial service will be held on November 8 at 2 PM at Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Caramoor, 149 Girdle Ridge Rd, Katonah, NY 10536

title: Drawing Inspiration From Struggle
description: They met five years ago, Billy Mills, the Olympic distance-running champion, and Clint Wells, a discouraged University of Colorado graduate. They were both American Indians, one living in the afterglow of a startling accomplishment, the other having reached what he thought was the sunset of an unfulfilled career. Without that meeting, Wells would not be running the New York City Marathon on Nov. 2. He might be out of the sport entirely, teaching, selling cars, working in some other employ of consolation.

description: To the Editor:

description: A NEW adult store has opened in Elmsford with little warning, provoking surprise and dismay among local officials and residents, who have staged several protests against the business.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Sept. 14 about the marriage of Amy Alexandra Julia Dowden and Roger Ange Pena Muio misstated the bridegroom's surname in the headline. He is Roger Pena, not Muio. (The family alerted The Times to the error last week.)

title: Sandra Contreras, Lisi DeHaas
description: Sandra Contreras and Elizabeth Cullen DeHaas affirmed their partnership yesterday at the Ingleside Inn in Palm Springs, Calif. Deborah Hull and Thomas M. Hilbink, both friends of the couple, presided at the commitment ceremony.

title: The Eminent Photographer of Eminent Victorians
description: IN 1872, her reputation as a photographer established, Julia Margaret Cameron explained in a letter how she chose her subjects: ''great beauty -- great celebrity -- and great friendship so I have kept my Portfolio choice.'' Lucky for her she had a lot of famous friends. And if some were better looking than others -- no one ever called Charles Darwin a hunk -- the connection of fame and friendship did more than inspire her art. It made her one of the first celebrity photographers, an artist whose portraits of the famous helped fame bounce back to her.

title: Jenny Rigg, Barry Donohue
description: Jenny Catherine Emily Rigg, the daughter of Dr. Karen T. Rigg and Frank Rigg of Carlisle, Mass., was married yesterday to Barry Michael Donohue, a son of Virginia and Barry J. Donohue of Little Falls, N.J. The Rev. John Talbird, an Episcopal priest and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Redeemer in Lexington, Mass.

title: Whooping Cough Cases Spread
description: MOST of the people who contracted whooping cough during the current Westchester County outbreak of the disease had been immunized against it, according to the pediatrician who treated many of the cases, and the disease has continued to spread.

title: Cond Nast Redesigns Its Future
description: THE lights of Midtown Manhattan still twinkle in the early-morning darkness as a man walks toward 4 Times Square, a huge office tower. He is short and moves with a shuffle, a gait that suggests he may be a bit old for punching a clock at 5 a.m. With his khakis, loafers and a green sweatshirt that seems too big on him, he could be one of the kitchen staff showing up to prep food at the vaunted Cond Nast cafeteria, four floors up.

title: A Hearty Match For Meaty Fare
description: Wildbacher, a rare grape, is found mainly in Styria in Austria. Collalto's dark-ruby 2001 wildbacher, from Colli Trevigiani in Veneto, is likely to entice adventurous lovers of hearty Italian winter-weight reds with tannins that need taming by roast beef, game and stews. Expect a deep aroma and pleasingly bitter raspberryish flavor.

title: Sprawl. Taxes. It's Easier To Gripe Than to Change.
description: Governor McGreevey isn't dumb or unlucky or incompetent. He's just the governor of a state that doesn't want its politicians to mess with the status quo.

title: Children and Art
description: To the Editor: We lived in Germany for three years when our children were quite young -- they were 9, 8, and 6 when we returned to the United States. My husband and I planned trips that included all of us whenever we could. The kids were always eager to go along, sharing our excitement and enthusiasm by osmosis or contagion, I suppose, and they were excellent travelers (their teen years were a different story!).

title: Children and Art
description: To the Editor: I highly recommend that young theatergoers (or their parents) buy the cast albums of the musicals they will see before attending the performances. Young piano students who attend musicals may want to try playing the shows' musical numbers. Vocal and piano arrangements for songs from many current shows are available at music stores.

title: His Masterpiece May Be Himself, Remade as Fiction
description: EZRA POUND, Paul Bowles and Gerard Manley Hopkins are among the few writers who have also been known as composers. The composers Hector Berlioz and Robert Schumann were also fluent prose writers. But arguably no one has been as acclaimed in both endeavors as Ned Rorem, whose 80th birthday, last Thursday, is being celebrated in numerous concerts around New York and elsewhere. Mr. Rorem's 17 books include 6 tell-all diaries, a memoir and collections of essays. He has composed some 500 songs, 3 symphonies, concertos and chamber works.

title: European Fashion With a Touch of Bronx Attitude
description: Looking for the Bronx Shoes store? No problem. Just catch a cab to Kennedy Airport, grab a flight to Oslo, head to Lillegrensen Street and look for the sign that says ''BRONX'' in big yellow letters. That is the only retail location for Bronx Shoes, the principal brand name from a shoe designer in Waalwijk, the Netherlands.

title: Multimedia's Multitasking Pioneer
description: A rare retrospective of the work of the modern-dance pioneer Alwin Nikolais, including signature pieces from 1953 on, will be presented by the Ririe-Woodbury Dance Company of Utah at the Joyce Theater this week. The program was arranged by Murray Louis, Nikolais's longtime collaborator and companion. Here he recalls ''Nik,'' who died in 1993 at the age of 82.

title: Rewards Become Focus Of Scoring Experiment
description: To many critics, figure skating has gone from one excess (too many dull figures) to another (too many jumps). Now, with an experimental scoring system that was used at Skate America, those critics think charm and style can return to the sport.

title: Personal Business; A Tight Job Market Dampens Ivy League Hopes
description: LIKE many other Ivy League students, Rachael M. Roewe had lofty dreams when she entered the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania four years ago. She would study econom ics, then embark on a career analyzing emerging markets.

title: A Style Grows In Brooklyn
description: With bands like the Strokes on the national radar, the punk-rock thrift-shop Williamsburg look, inspired by the Brooklyn neighborhood, is entrenched in fashion's mainstream.

title: Corrections
description: A film listing last Sunday for the documentary ''Sister Helen'' misstated the causes of death of the husband and one son of Sister Helen Travis, the film's subject. Before she became a nun, her husband had a heart attack after years of alcoholism and her oldest son was stabbed; they did not die of overdoses. Her youngest son did die of a drug overdose.

title: Voices From the Wilderness Reunite
description: TO mark the 40th anniversary of the day the first wrecking ball struck Penn Station, the New York Preservation Archive Project, a nonprofit group, has been trying to contact everyone involved in efforts to save the station. The group has identified 300 people who marched, wrote letters, signed newspaper ads or spoke at hearings. Anthony C. Wood, the group's director, believes that at least 65 of them have died, but his group hopes to contact 100 others, and at least 20 will be honored Tuesday at an event at the Century Association. The group plans to take oral histories from them at that time. Here are recollections of three original protesters.

title: Celebrating Library And Series
description: ALONG with celebrating its 100th year, the Ossining Public Library is opening the silver anniversary season of its ''Great Music in a Great Place,'' a series of free Sunday afternoon concerts. Today at 3:30 p.m. the Transfiguration Ensemble will perform large-scale chamber works, made possible by the group's extended instrumentation -- string quartet, plus clarinet, bassoon and piano. No tickets are needed, but seating is limited.

title: Lives of the Circus Animals
description: ou want strangers to love you?"

title: In Search of French Soul: A School With La Diffrence
description: THE SCENE -- The Lyce Franais de New York, where a smattering of students, alumni, school officials and architects gathered Monday night for an open house to celebrate the school's new 158,000-square-foot, $95 million building. The structure rose between East 75th and East 76th Streets, just east of York Avenue, in a mere 18 months.

title: What's The Value Of a Fetus?
description: With the Senate's passage last week of the Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act of 2003, supporters of abortion rights face an increasingly conspicuous problem. It's not simply that it is set to be the first federal law to criminalize a specific abortion procedure. It's that they still don't know how to articulate the value of unborn human life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PURNELL, RICHARD I.
description: PURNELL--Richard I. Of Locust Valley and Fishers Island, N.Y. On October 21, 2003, age 85. Beloved husband of Marguerite H., cherished father of Marguerite W. and Peter F. (Suzanne) and proud grandfather of Jimmy, Teddy, Bobby and Henry. Survived by many nieces, nephews and cousins. Visitation will be at Dodge-Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, N.Y. on Monday, October 27th from 4-7PM and Tuesday, October 28th from 9AM10AM. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, October 28th at 11AM at St. Johns of Lattingtown. Private burial to be held at Fishers Island. In lieu of flowers donations in Richard I. Purnell's name may be made to Princeton University Class of 1940. Memorial Scholarship Fund, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center or The Kent School.

title: More Violent Than Chess
description: THE GIRL WHO PLAYED GO (Knopf, $22.95), Shan Sa's first novel to appear in English, is itself much like a game of go, in which two opponents place stones in turn on the grid of a stylized battlefield, each trying to surround the other. It is 1937 and the nameless players are a 16-year-old Manchurian girl and a 24-year-old Japanese officer garrisoned in her town. As they take turns in brief first-person chapters, their stories circle each other slowly, warily. And like the black and white stones on the board, life for each is starkly defined. He is devoted to the art of war, the honor and sublime hatred of battle. She has given herself to a student revolutionary whose betrayal hurls her into adolescent despair. When the officer, incognito, meets the girl across a go table in the town square, the strategies of the game reveal each to the other, a nearly wordless communion that mounts to an apocalyptic climax. Shan, who was born in Beijing in 1972 but now lives in France, writes spare prose adorned with images that linger in the mind -- the girl's loneliness is ''like a bolt of crimson silk stowed in the bottom of a wooden chest.'' But in this elegant translation from the French by Adriana Hunter, the dreamlike, mesmerizing alternation of voices stands in uneasy contrast to the operatic violence of the plot. Janice P. Nimura

title: Breeders Cup Victory Is Another Milestone for Krone

title: The World; Cheap and Lethal, It Fits in a Golf Bag
description: AT a series of training seminars held in Bangkok earlier this month, about 5,000 taxi motorcyclists were asked to take a good long look at a golf bag. Inside the bag was a plastic tube, and inside the tube was a shoulder-fired antiaircraft missile.

title: A Murder's Shadow Only Grows As the Years Pass

title: Handicapped Parking? How About Cellphones?
description: The use of citizen volunteers to assist in the enforcement of Nassau's handicapped parking regulations is commendable [''The Guardians of Handicapped Parking,'' Oct. 19]. I was surprised, however, to learn that the fine for illegal parking in a handicapped space exceeds the penalty for driving while talking on a cellphone. The law against using hand-held cellphones while driving, already compromised by permitting hands-free phones in vehicles, continues to be disregarded by an alarming number of drivers in all locations from parking lots to heavily trafficked highways. It is obvious that sufficient enforcement personnel are unavailable to deal with all of those who are willing to chance their safety and that of others. Unfortunately, the use of volunteers to identify these scofflaws is impractical. It would seem that the next logical step in gaining greater compliance with the cellphone use laws would be to increase fines to a realistic level commensurate with effecting deterrence. Surely, the penalty for flagrantly jeopardizing the lives and safety of others should be greater than that imposed on those who, in essence, cause inconvenience to a special, albeit limited segment of the population.

Naturally, what we'll notice most this evening -- this afternoon -- is the early onset of darkness, the certain herald of winter. If you can just stay focused on that extra morning light -- a bright sky by 6 -- it almost eases the trauma of sunset by 5.

title: MOSCOW: THE BALLERINA SUES
description: Anastasia Volochkova, the star ballerina, has carried out her threat to sue the Bolshoi Theater, which dismissed her in September amid accusations that she had grown too heavy to be lifted. Today a Moscow court is to hear her suit for restoration of her job and back pay. Ms. Volochkova, 27, who stands 5 feet 6 inches tall and says she weighs 109 pounds, told the Itar-Tass news agency, ''Unfortunately I was compelled to take this step, and I intend to restore my rights and those of other artists through the court.'' Russia's labor minister, Alexander Pochinok, has also said the dismissal violated labor laws and urged the Bolshoi to take Ms. Volochkova back. Although the Bolshoi initially refused, Anatoly Iksanov, its director, has now told Itar-Tass that it is ''highly likely'' that the theater will have to welcome the ballerina back after the court hearing. Meanwhile, she has thrown her support behind the parliamentary election campaign of Unity, the party that backs President Vladimir V. Putin. She has also been rehearsing for ''Stairway to Heaven,'' a series of solo performances at the Kremlin Palace concert hall that is being advertised on billboards and banners around Moscow. SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNURER, BERNICE LUNIN
description: SCHNURER--Bernice Lunin. 79, was born in New York City and lived there for the first half of her life. A child of immigrants who died when she was young, Bernice became, in spite of her humble financial circumstances, an ardent patron of the arts, and for the remainder of her life avidly followed the NYC art and performing arts scenes. In 1957, she married Harold Schnurer, a former New York businessman and state commerce director. They moved to Arizona in 1961, with their two children, where she helped build Phoenix into the community it is today, including service as president of both the Opera League and Symphony Guild. She and her husband were also early and active supporters of civil rights, each serving as president of the Phoenix Urban League. Bernice also served for many years on the Board of the American Jewish Committee, and was a co-founder of Temple Solel. She is survived by son Eric, daughter Danielle Gold, grandson Ryan Harold Gold, and stepson Anthony T. Schnurer. She will be laid to rest beside her husband, Tuesday, October 28, at Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

The bullet was fired in a third-floor apartment in a building at 1205 Rogers Avenue in East Flatbush, pierced the floor and entered a second-floor apartment, where it struck the man, the police said. title: Nepotism in Central Asia
description: On Oct. 15, Ilham Aliyev, businessman, playboy and novice politician, received a nice gift from his father -- the country of Azerbaijan. Heydar Aliyev had ruled Azerbaijan almost continuously for 34 years, first as an agent of the Soviet Politburo and then as an autocrat in his own right. When he became too ill to continue, he anointed his son to run for president in his place. Ilham Aliyev ran a rigged campaign, using all the powers of the state, and then celebrated his victory by arresting most of the opposition. To conclude this nasty exercise in dynasty building, Azerbaijan's new president accepted the fawning congratulations of the outside world -- including Washington.

title: Testing the Senate's Mettle

The bill is a long shot. But it will provide the first true test of the sincerity of senators who say they care about the problem and have faulted President Bush for not doing enough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICKERT, EDWIN WEIMER
description: RICKERT -- Edwin Weimer. Age 89. Beloved husband of Ruth Alma Fulcher. Cherished father of Jean Adelia, Wendy Grace, Allen Edwin and grandfather of Michael. Born in Connersville, IN, June 17, 1914, son of Edwin and Grace (Weimer) Rickert. Ed Rickert was a member of the Class of 1936 of Columbia University, where he received a BA. He served as a security analyst, economist, for Mackubin, Legg and Co, Baltimore, 1936-40; industrial analyst, Office of Production Management, Washington, 1940-41; supervisor commodity economic research, Standard Brands, Inc, NYC, 194653; investment counselor with Brundage, Story & Rose, NYC, 1953-2000, partner 196683, senior investment consultant 1984-2000, retired 2000; Trustee Columbia Univeristy Press, 1977-96, Trustee Emeritus 1996-2001; Columbia College Board of Visitors, 198692. Colubmia created a professorship of economics in his name. Ed served to Captain in the US Army, 194146, retired Lt Col, Army Reserves. He was a member of the New York Society Security Analysts, India House, Grachur Club, and Republican Party. He was active in the United Church of Rockville Centre, NY (Presbyterian and Congreational), and Boy Scout Master Troop 40, for many years. Died October 14, 2003. Ed had an enthusiam for living and traveled extensively, visiting eastern and western Europe, the Middle East, Far East, and Central America. He was a generous and loving man of high integrity. His warm smile and encouragement of the those around him will be deeply missed. Donations may be made in Ed's memory to the charity of your choice.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: JACKSON: TIGER PRESERVE MAY SOON CLOSE The nearly five-year-long legal saga of Joan Byron-Marasek, who has fought state efforts to close her private tiger compound, appears to be nearing an end. Two dozen tigers housed at Ms. Byron-Marasek's Ocean County animal preserve are headed to a Texas sanctuary next month. Representatives from the Wild Animal Orphanage in San Antonio plan to arrive in New Jersey in two weeks to meet with State Department of Environmental Protection officials. The tigers could be moved as early as Nov. 11, said Carol Asvestas, the sanctuary's executive director. Officials sought to close Ms. Byron-Marasek's preserve after a loose tiger that authorities said was hers was shot and killed by police in Jackson in January 1999. Ms. Byron-Marasek, known as the Tiger Lady, could not be reached for comment. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENDOZA, DR. BARBARA M.
description: MENDOZA--Dr. Barbara M., died at her home on October 26, 2003 of lung cancer. In 1940, Eleanor Roosevelt invited a few college students to tea at the White House. Dr. Mendoza was at that meeting, which set the course for her life. Mrs. Roosevelt was very enthusiastic about the role of women, whether they were homemakers or career women. In each case, she said there were three things women should always be interested in-politics, education and the arts. Dr. Mendoza followed this advice in her personal and professional career. She was awarded a B.A. from Brooklyn College, a M.A. from Columbia University, and a Ph.D from New York University. For 20 years, she headed the Drama Dept. at St. John's University, Staten Island. She was a member of Common Cause, Amnesty International, Planned Parenthood, the National Democratic Party, and the New York Speech Association. She was a member of The Cosmopolitan Club in New York City and served on the Board of Governors. She is survived by her husband, Wyn, who has proved to be trustworthy, beloved and amusing for over 60 years, by her daughters, Kathy, Susan, Liza and Julie, and by her grandson, Joseph.

title: Technology Briefs | Software: Symantec To Buy On Technology For $100 Million
description: The Symantec Corporation, which makes antivirus software, has agreed to buy ON Technology for $100 million to add programs that manage networks for companies including Home Depot Inc. ON Technology shareholders will get $4 a share, Symantec said. That is 16 percent more than ON Technology's closing price Friday. ON Technology's software helps clients, including Motorola and Bank of Montreal, manage computer networks remotely. The chief executive, Robert Doretti, has said ON Technology may lose money this year because sales are slowing. Shares of Symantec, based in Cupertino, Calif., fell 14 cents to $65.45. Shares of ON Technology, based in Waltham, Mass., rose 48 cents, to $3.93.

title: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Prosecutors Seek Delay In Murder Trial
description: Saying they need time to retest crime-scene evidence, federal prosecutors asked for a six-month delay in the capital murder trial of Darrell Rice, who is accused of killing two women who had been hiking in the Shenandoah National Park in 1996. Prosecutors said they needed more time to evaluate what they called a recent troubling conclusion by a government expert, who said that male DNA found on the cloth used to bind the victims could not have come from Mr. Rice. The trial had been scheduled to start next Monday. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERELMAN, MARK
description: PERELMAN--Mark. We celebrate the long, vigorous, loving life of Mark Perelman, who died October 24, 2003 in Palm Beach, FL. His family and friends are grateful that he had the good fortune to marry Marjorie Raskin Perelman, whom he loved and treasured. Born 1909 in New Castle, PA to Jacob and Sue Rizika Perelman, for 50 years he was the devoted husband of the late Evelyn Strassels Perelman. He was the loving father of their two children, Robert Perelman of Philadelphia and Nancy Sondow of New York City, and the doting grandfather of Max and Reuben Perelman and James and Joseph Sondow. Mark was president of a chain of stores in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, King's Jewelry, and founded and ran Appliance Wholesalers in Youngstown, OH, where he was voted Businessman of the Year. He was an accomplished pilot, having a commercial license and flying his own plane for more than 50 years. Taking great pleasure in flying, travel, golf and tennis, he lived life with gusto. Blessed with a never-failing abundance of kindness, humor, generosity, determination and love, he will be sorely missed. Calling hours were 1-2 PM on Monday, October 27, at the R. Cunningham Funeral Home, Inc., 2429 Wilmington Rd., New Castle, PA. Funeral services were at 2 PM Monday also at the funeral home and were conducted by Rabbi Sheldon Clark.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: ALLIGATOR BAGS WITH A DIFFERENCE Three alligators and two crocodiles were confiscated last night at the Marriott Marquis Hotel, where they were being kept before a scheduled appearance on a television show this morning, the police said. Someone aware of the reptiles' presence in the hotel, at 45th Street and Broadway, called the Department of Environmental Protection, a police spokesman said, and environmental officers found that the handlers did not have the proper permits. The handlers received summonses, and the animals were taken to the Center for Animal Care and Control, the police said. The reptiles included two that had been found yesterday in a plane at Newark Liberty International Airport. Two of the alligators, both more than four feet long, had been discovered in burlap bags in the cargo hold of an American Airlines flight from Miami. The Port Authority Police did not issue any summonses.   Tina Kelley

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: O.A.S. To Weigh Poverty As Security Threat

The Daily News, which has been battling a government decree strictly regulating the press, had been shut down for six weeks until an administrative court ordered the government of President Robert G. title: Victory in Iraq, One Tribe at a Time
description: While we do not yet know who was responsible for the latest series of attacks across Iraq, there is no question that some of the bombings -- including, American officials suspect, the missile attack on the hotel where Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz was staying -- were the work of forces loyal to Saddam Hussein. That these terrorists, mostly Sunni Muslims from the so-called Sunni Triangle northwest of Baghdad, retain a stubborn fealty to the former dictator seems to puzzle the coalition leadership. But it should not: their loyalty is rooted in part in centuries-old tribal kinship and religious identity. Only by understanding these ties and then using them to its advantage will the coalition authority reduce the resistance.

title: Technology Briefs | Internet: Financial Web Sites Studied
description: A majority of the nation's large banks, insurance companies and other financial institutions collect personal information on Web sites that are not properly protected from online identity thieves, according to a study released yesterday. The study, which was conducted by I.B.M. and Watchfire, found that 66 percent of the financial institutions examined had one or more Web forms that collect personal data, like credit card information, that is not encrypted before it is sent across the Internet. Most companies, the study found, use encryption that does not meet the government's security guidelines. The office of the comptroller of the currency states that when collecting consumer information, companies should use ''security technology that, at a minimum, is equivalent to 128-bit encryption.'' According to the study, 91 percent of the companies supported lower levels of encryption, or less than the 128-bit level. The study was released by I.B.M. and Watchfire, a software maker, as they introduced an online service that monitors and reports privacy shortcomings in corporate Web sites. Steve Lohr (NYT)

Someone aware of the reptiles' presence in the hotel, at 45th Street and Broadway, called the Department of Environmental Protection, a police spokesman said, and environmental officers found that the handlers did not have the proper permits. The handlers received summonses, and the animals were taken to the Center for Animal Care and Control, the police said. The reptiles included two that had been found yesterday in a plane at Newark Liberty International Airport. Two of the alligators, both more than four feet long, had been discovered in burlap bags in the cargo hold of an American Airlines flight from Miami. The Port Authority Police did not issue any summonses. Tina Kelley

title: How the Governor Pays Big Salaries
description: The bad news piles up steadily these days at Gov. George Pataki's office door. A few months ago, it was his friend, former Senator Alfonse D'Amato, earning $500,000 for one phone call to lobby the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Then it was the growing cloud over a $30,000 option on a stretch of the Erie Canal. And last week, Comptroller Alan Hevesi pointed out that a former Pataki colleague, Anastasia Song, had earned $582,000 in 14 months as acting financial officer for the Long Island Power Authority. Mr. Hevesi noted that she should have been paid about $150,000 for her work.

description: Young adults who are prone to impatience and hostility are more likely to develop high blood pressure, researchers have found.

title: Garrett Hardin, 88, Ecologist Who Warned About Excesses
description: Garrett Hardin, an ecologist and author who warned of the dangers of overpopulation and whose concept of the ''tragedy of the commons'' brought attention to the damage that innocent actions by individuals can inflict on the environment, died at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif., on Sept. 14. He was 88.

description: An article in Business Day yesterday about questions on the use of dietary supplements to lose weight carried a dual byline erroneously. It was by Marian Burros alone.

title: Hypnosis: A Hit in the Gut
description: Many patients suffering from irritable bowel syndrome, a painful disorder that does not generally respond well to conventional treatments, have found relief through hypnotherapy. Now British researchers say the benefits can last five years or longer.

title: Bush Says Bombings Will Not Deter Him
description: President Bush said Monday that the latest wave of violence in Baghdad was a response by increasingly desperate terrorists to the progress being made by the United States in stabilizing Iraq.

description: Bruce Jackson was found rooting through his neighbors' garbage, so weak from starvation that he could not open the Tastykake that the shocked couple had given him out of pity.

title: Pyongyang official dies of crash injuries
description: SEOUL:  North Korea's top official in charge of dealing with South Korea has died from injuries received in a car accident earlier this year, Pyongyang's official news agency said Monday.

title: Market Place; Here's a well-kept secret: America Online may be having a recovery and turn a profit early next year.
description: BACK during the Internet boom, there seemed to be no advertising deal or marketing partnership too trivial for America Online to trumpet with a glowing press release. But these days, America Online may be playing down a hidden recovery in its online advertising business that will help it pull off a promised turnaround right on schedule at the beginning of next year. Some investors are wondering whether AOL has in effect hidden an ace up its sleeve.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the security situation in Iraq and the possibility that Turkish troops might help stabilize the country misstated the duration of the Turkish occupation of Iraq during the Ottoman Empire. It was from 1533 until after World War I, not World War II.

title: HALLIBURTON ORDERED TO PAY $64 MILLION PENALTY
description: The Halliburton Company should pay Anglo Dutch Tenge $64 million for breaching a confidentiality agreement over plans to develop a Kazakhstan oil field, a Texas jury ruled. Halliburton, which is based in Houston, plans to ask the judge to reduce or eliminate the award, a spokeswoman, Wendy Hall, said. The jury also ruled against Halliburton's partner, Ramco Energy P.L.C., which was ordered to pay $6.4 million.

title: A Surge in Money Sent Home by Mexicans
description: Nearly one Mexican in five regularly gets money from relatives employed in the United States, making this country the largest repository of such remittances in the world, according to a poll sponsored by the Inter-American Development Bank.

title: A Fire Bill to Fight Fires
description: Californians are no strangers to the deadly confluence of heat, low humidity and high winds that have created an implacable crescent of fire in Southern California, destroying woodlands, brush, homes and lives. The worst damage is along the ridges and hills where suburbia meets the forests; the danger is sure to increase as runaway development turns the stretch between Los Angeles and San Diego into one giant suburb.

title: Class of 2003: What They Wanted, What They Got
description: Chanda J. Davis, 22, Cincinnati

title: Countering Terrorists, And a Dense Daughter
description: One of the best series on television is ''24,'' and it could be even better if there were less of it -- if, say, the world had adopted the time-keeping system of the ancient Sumerians. The show would then be called ''12'' and its hero, Jack Bauer (Kiefer Sutherland), could save the country from an apocalyptic terrorist attack in a 12-hour day -- eliminating the need for some of the sillier side plots delaying the denouement. (How many times can a daughter be kidnapped, found, then captured again?)

title: Researchers Build a Case for Earthworm's Slimy Reputation
description: No one would argue that earthworms are cute. But to most people, they are benign and helpful creatures -- fertilizers of the garden, aerators of the soil, indispensable fishing companions. ''Earthworms are truly nature's little farmers,'' goes one common view, this one on the Web site of Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada, ''plowing the soil and fertilizing at the same time!''

title: Health Service In Nassau Dismisses 35 Doctors
description: Nassau County's financially troubled public health agency is firing 35 to 40 doctors, including the staff of its seven community health centers and many of its pediatricians, to cut costs.

title: TENET'S BANKS AGREE TO AMEND COVENANT TERMS
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the large hospital chain, said its banks agreed to amend terms of a credit facility, allowing the company to avoid a possible default. The amendment resolves concerns, raised by its preliminary results for the third quarter, that Tenet might violate a covenant with its lenders. Nonpayment of bills by patients left third-quarter earnings for Tenet significantly below analysts' estimates of 20 cents a share and pushed up bad debt to $500 million to $550 million, about twice as much as expected, the company said last week. A spokesman for Tenet said the company spoke with its lenders after announcing the preliminary results and worked out an agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUER, W. RICHARD
description: DUER--W. Richard. October 26, 2003 in his 82nd year. Devoted husband for 32 years to Lucille St. Peters. Loving father to Celeste Malott of Los Angeles, CA; Camille Greenwald of St. Louis, MO; Jeffrey Duer of Cleveland, OH; and Monica Pennington of Beaufort, SC. Beloved grandfather of eight and great-grandfather of two. A Purple Heart decorated WWII Veteran, graduate of Carnegie Mellon School of Architecture, he was an avid bike rider, a champion for women's rights, he was forever young. His career with McGraw Hill Sweets Catalogue spanned over 30 years, he was an active member of St. Paul the Apostle's Church and established the Alter Service Program which included girls, a member of the Construction Specifications Institute and a volunteer at St. Paul's Homeless Shelter. Reposing at Barrett & Sons Funeral Home, 424 W. 51st St., NYC, 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM Wednesday, October 29. Funeral Mass 10 AM Thursday, October 30 at St. Paul the Apostle's Church, 405 W. 59th St., and refreshments will be served afterwards. Interment at St. Sylvester's Cemetery in East Bernsteadt, KY. In lieu of flowers please make a donation to St. Paul's Alter Service Program.

title: Doctors Tread a Thin Line on Marijuana Advice
description: For doctors who want to discuss using medical marijuana with their patients, the line between advice and advocacy remains almost as blurred as it was before a recent court decision guaranteed a physician's right to address the issue openly.

title: Shares Move Up Amid Acquisitions in Banking and Health
description: Stocks rose yesterday as companies announced $62.9 billion worth of takeovers, persuading investors that share prices are inexpensive even after a 29 percent surge in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index since mid-March.

title: Superfund Undermined
description: The industry-financed trust fund that helps underwrite one of the country's most valued environmental programs, the Superfund, will soon run out of money. It will be a milestone of sorts, and a sad one. Unless Congress renews the fund, which pays for cleaning up toxic waste dumps, taxpayers will have to foot the bill instead of the companies that caused the messes in the first place. An important principle will have gone down the drain, and public health may suffer as a result.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Fund Manager Bought
description: The British banking company Barclays has agreed to buy Gerrard Management Services from Old Mutual for 210 million ($356 million) to become Britain's largest adviser and money manager for clients with more than 70,000 to invest. Gerrard, which Old Mutual bought for 525 million in May 2000, oversees 12.5 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DALY, MARIE, PH.D.
description: DALY--Marie, Ph.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine notes with profound sorrow the passing of Dr. Marie Daly, a member of our department of biochemistry for more than 25 years. A distinguished scientist, and believed to be the first African-American woman to receive a Ph.D. in chemistry (Columbia University, 1948), her research on histones, with colleagues at the Rockefeller Institute, was seminal. She joined Einstein in 1960 where her research continued to flourish, focusing on cholesterol metabolism and creatine uptake by cells. In addition to her impressive scientific career, Dr. Daly was actively involved in the recruitment and training of minority students at Einstein and is warmly remembered as a creative and involved teacher. Our sincere condolences to her family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Sam Seifter, Ph.D. Distinguished University Professor Emeritus of Biochemistry Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEIBERG, KENNETH S.
description: HEIBERG--Kenneth S. On October 27, 2003. Beloved husband of Ragna and the late Edna. Loving father of Judith Fogarty (Joseph) and Susan Lambert (Benjamin). Dear brother of the late Ethel Eisinger, Carl and Milton. Proud grandfather of Eireann Fogarty, Joseph P. Fogarty, Karen Lambert-Wurts and Andrew Lambert. Adored great grandfather of Samantha Wurts. Also survived by many nieces, nephews and grand nieces and grand nephews. Long-time member of Trinity Lutheran Church, 46th St, Brooklyn. President of the Brooklyn Press, commercial printers, family owned for over 80 years. Former Trustee for Lutheran Medical Center, past President for the Municipal Club of Brooklyn, member of the Masonic Lodge, Kilwinning - Sunset Lodge 936, Montauk Club, and the Faith Home Foundation. Served in U.S. Air National Guard. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Bklyn. Service Wednesday, 8PM at the funeral home. Interment Greenwood Cemetery.

title: For Aging Runners, a Formula Makes Time Stand Still
description: For hundreds of runners, the New York Marathon on Sunday will bring the same dispiriting experience. Setting out to beat a personal best established when their legs were years younger, they will fall short and become convinced that they simply did not run a good enough race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNS, MARGARET
description: JOHNS -- Margaret. The Trustees and staff of the World Monuments Fund mark with great sadness the death of Margaret Johns. With her husband, Peter Stern, Vice Chairman and long-serving trustee of the World Monuments Fund, Margaret shared a passion for the work of the organization and participated with energy and intelligence in countless WMF events, trips, and gatherings. She brightened our lives with her informed and cheerful enthusiasm and greatly expanded our knowledge through her own many accomplishments, as a scientist, gardener, artist, music lover, reader, and passionate traveler. She will be missed by all. Our heartfelt condolences go to her beloved family including Peter Stern and daughters, Kate Johns and Sara Griffen.

title: Technology Briefs | Telecommunications: CommScope To Buy Avaya Unit For $263 Million
description: Avaya, the nation's largest maker of office telephone equipment, has agreed to sell its cabling unit to the cable maker CommScope for $263 million to focus on its phone gear and services businesses. The price includes $210 million cash, CommScope shares valued at $34.9 million and an $18 million note convertible into stock, the companies said in statements. The purchase will add to CommScope's earnings per share next year, according to CommScope, which is based in Hickory, N.C. The Avaya unit makes a wider range of cables to connect devices in corporate phone and computer networks than CommScope, which specializes in high-capacity cabling. Shares of CommScope, which had risen 63 percent this year, rose $1.70, or 13 percent, to $14.60. Avaya stock, which had quintupled this year, rose 17 cents, to $12.95. The operation being sold to CommScope, Avaya Connectivity Solutions, is based in Richardson, Tex.

description: Buying FleetBoston Financial might fill out Bank of America's national branch network, but it would not fulfill the acquirer's Wall Street dreams.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Drug-Offender Program To Expand
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, announced plans yesterday to expand a drug-treatment program for nonviolent drug offenders. The program is operating now in the five counties of New York City and five upstate counties. It will be expanded to 12 more counties statewide, said Lynn Rasic, a spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki. An additional $2.8 million, including $285,000 for New York City's special narcotics prosecutor, will be provided, Mr. Pataki and Mr. Bruno said. The governor said the initiative, available to district attorneys, was not a substitute for his efforts to revise the state's Rockefeller-era drug laws, which require strict sentences for minor drug offenses. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Despite Attacks, Bush Sees No Need for More Troops in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  President Bush indicated today that he saw no need for additional United States troops in Iraq, despite the escalating violence there. But he declined to say whether he thought there might be fewer American troops in Iraq a year from now.

title: Iraq Paradox: Cracking Down While Promoting Freedom
description: At one of the first meetings of the White House's new Iraq Stabilization Group, days before the series of attacks on Monday that left at least 34 dead, President Bush's aides debated the trade-off between locking down Baghdad and demonstrating to Iraqis that they now live in an open society, where they are free to shop, go to work or even protest the American-led occupation.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  The director of an American spy agency said today that he believed that material from Iraq's illicit weapons program had been transported into Syria and perhaps other countries as part of an effort by Iraqis to disperse and destroy evidence immediately before the war last spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRAMS, EMILY THORBURN
description: ABRAMS--Emily Thorburn, of Pittsburgh, PA, formerly of Brookside, NJ, passed away on Saturday, October 25th, 2003. Emily is the widow of Lawrence B. Abrams, Jr. She is survived by her brother, Grant Thorburn, of Florida, and her four children, Lawrence B. III of Camp Hill, PA, Martha Broderick, of Mt. Lebanon, PA, Priscilla Hays, of Boardman, OH and Grant, of New Paltz, NY, and eleven grandchildren. On Saturday, November 15, there will be a memorial service at 11:00 a.m. at Holy Cross Episcopal Church, in North Plainfield, NJ. Interment will follow at Rosedale Cemetery, West Orange, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAHN, JEROME S.
description: HAHN--Jerome S., age 73 on October 25, 2003, founder and President of Regent Sheffield Ltd, New York and Chairman of Richardson Sheffield, England and Taiwan, manufactured and distributed cutlery and flatware around the world. Jerry's vision and innovative approach transformed an archaic manufacturing process into a modern computer and robotic assisted industry. During a Royal visit to Richardson Sheffield, his development of the 'Laser' knife was recognized by the prestigious ''Queen's Award''. When Jerry and his wife Lynn moved to Boca Raton, Florida, he became committed to an observant life and Torah studies. As a Member of the Boca Raton Synagogue he was deeply involved in financial matters. His generosity enabled the Synagogue to establish the The Hahn Judaic Campus, now the site of the Boca Raton Synagogue, The Community Kollel, The Community Mikvah, The Weinbaum Yeshiva High School and The Senders Library. He was committed to Aish Hatorah Yeshiva in Israel, where the Hahns had a residence in the Old City of Jerusalem. Jerry created and edited ''BIBLE BASICS'', a user friendly guide to the Five Books of Moses. His other interests included archaeology, creative writing, and computer technology. He is survived by his devoted wife Lynn, sister June and family, 3 sons Jonathan (Rachayel) Ari (Esther) and Steven (Avital), 16 grandchildren and 12 great grandchildren. May the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem comfort the Hahn family.

title: Without Airs, Breezing Through a Night of Song
description: Adisclosure: I came with a certain bias to Matthew Polenzani's New York recital debut on Oct. 21. It was based not on personal acquaintance with this tenor but simply on the experience of having been delighted with his singing, even in normally overlooked smaller roles, on so many occasions. So you could dismiss my view that Mr. Polenzani's recital, at Weill Hall, was a tremendous pleasure. But blame Mr. Polenzani himself for my bias.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Britain: Governor's Stepson Arraigned
description: Gov. John G. Rowland's stepson, Ryan Largay, arrested earlier this month, was arraigned yesterday on a marijuana possession charge and applied to participate in a program for first-time offenders. If Mr. Largay, 18, completes the Community Service Labor Program successfully, the criminal charges will be dropped. He is free on $1,000 bond and must appear in court on Nov. 21. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: BERLIN: HELMUT NEWTON'S GALLERY
description: Helmut Newton, left, the photographer famed for his images of fashion and nudes, has donated more than 1,000 of his pictures to a German cultural foundation for a museum scheduled to open in June in Berlin and intended to become a national center for photography. Announcing his gift at a news conference in Berlin, Mr. Newton, 82, said that it did not include his negatives, as he still needed them for his work, but he added that eventually they, too, would go to the foundation, Stiftung Preussischer Kulturbesitz, in Charlottenburg, the neighborhood where he grew up in a prominent Jewish family and took his first photography lessons before leaving Nazi Germany for exile in Singapore in 1938. He and his wife, June, a photographer who works under the name Alice Springs, are paying for the establishment of the new gallery.

To get on a plane, you must pass yourself and your belongings through a security checkpoint run by federal screeners who use electronic devices to look for guns, knives and other potential weapons. Setting off the metal detector with as much as a forgotten quarter in a pocket automatically elicits an embarrassing public pat-down and electronic wanding.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Doctor Faces Child Pornography Charges
description: Federal prosecutors charged a Chicago doctor with possessing child pornography after law enforcement officials found more than 3,000 sexually explicit images of children in his home. The doctor, H. Marc Watzman, 37, who specializes in pediatric medicine and anesthesiology, had worked in pediatric hospitals in Illinois, Kansas and Pennsylvania over the years. Law enforcement officials said they also found morphine, Viagra and drugs that bring on temporary paralysis and unconsciousness hidden in Mr. Watzman's car. If convicted, Dr. Watzman could face five years in prison. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Lord of the Paycheck: Film Directors Move Up
description: When Universal Pictures ushered the ''Lord of the Rings'' auteur Peter Jackson and his team into Hollywood's elite 20/20 club -- $20 million in guaranteed up-front salary against 20 percent of the gross receipts -- the action underscored a major Hollywood shift: event-movie directors are becoming as valuable as stars like Tom Cruise and Mel Gibson.

title: National Briefing: Northwest
description: WASHINGTON: COURT UPHOLDS LIMITS ON POLITICAL PAMPHLETS A Seattle law that prohibits political candidates from discussing their opponents in the city's official voter-education pamphlet does not violate the First Amendment, the federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled. The law was challenged by Grant T. Cogswell, a City Council candidate in 2001, who had wanted to criticize his opponent's voting record. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that the law was constitutional because it did not discriminate based on the candidates' viewpoints and because the pamphlets were intended only to introduce candidates to the public. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Dark Tones And Light, For 2 Friends; Sendak and Kushner Let Humor Get Through
description: Maurice Sendak and Tony Kushner are friends and collaborators. Together they created ''Brundibar,'' a picture book based on the opera performed in the 1940's by children in the Theresienstadt concentration camp, and they have designed and translated a new version of the opera. And both have cameo roles in Mike Nichols's mini-series of Mr. Kushner's play ''Angels in America.''

description: The string theorists on ''The Elegant Universe'' talk like stoners, and their ruminations are precisely as soporific and as wondrous as someone else's hallucinations usually are.

description: Google.com has begun talks with book publishers to compile a searchable database of the contents of thousands of volumes, a publishing executive briefed on the project said yesterday.

title: VETERAN ABC CORRESPONDENT JOINS FOX NEWS
description: Chris Wallace, a longtime correspondent at ABC News, was named yesterday as the host of ''Fox News Sunday,'' Fox's Sunday morning public affairs program. Mr. Wallace, whose father is the CBS ''60 Minutes'' correspondent Mike Wallace, has been at ABC News since 1989 and had most recently served as a senior correspondent for ''Primetime Thursday'' and as a substitute anchor for ''Nightline.'' Mr. Wallace is succeeding the ''Fox News Sunday'' host Tony Snow, who is going to devote much of his time to a new syndicated radio talk show for Fox News. Jim Rutenberg (NYT)

title: Expectations For a Mentor And Yourself
description: DAVID A. THOMAS thinks the notion of the perfect mentor is a myth. Professor Thomas teaches leadership and career management at the Harvard Business School, is a co-author of ''Breaking Through: The Making of Minority Executives in Corporate America'' and a consultant to multinational corporations. He says that rather than seeking mentor relationships, ''mentees'' should create a network of workplace relationships.

title: MetroStars Stagger Into Playoffs
description: Defender Steve Jolley is sanguine about the playoffs, and he does not mind saying so. Still, he knows the MetroStars have a problem.

title: Fear of Losing Name With Roots in Colonial Boston
description: Through mergers and acquisitions over the years, FleetBoston Financial has become the foremost banking institution in New England. But with Bank of America's announcement on Monday that it will acquire Fleet in a $48 billion deal, the Fleet name may soon disappear from the cityscape it now dominates.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Court Upholds Limits On Political Pamphlets
description: A Seattle law that prohibits political candidates from discussing their opponents in the city's official voter-education pamphlet does not violate the First Amendment, the federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled. The law was challenged by Grant T. Cogswell, a City Council candidate in 2001, who had wanted to criticize his opponent's voting record. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that the law was constitutional because it did not discriminate based on the candidates' viewpoints and because the pamphlets were intended only to introduce candidates to the public. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Evolving Tokyo: A 'City' Within the City
description: Six months ago, Minoru Mori looked like a high-rolling gambler when he opened Roppongi Hills, his $2.2 billion ''city within a city'' in the capital of Japan, a nation that pundits thought rhymed with ''stagnation.''

title: Procter & Gamble Reports Earnings Gain of 20 Percent
description: Procter & Gamble said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 20 percent as beauty care acquisitions and a new Prilosec heartburn drug produced a significant sales increase.

title: A Hip-Hop Star's Fashion Line Is Tagged With a Sweatshop Label
description: A 19-year-old Honduran apparel worker and a leading workers' rights group said yesterday that the hip-hop artist Sean Combs was using a sweatshop in Honduras to produce tens of thousands of shirts for his Sean John fashion company.

title: Disappointed Jeter Sounds a Little Bit Like His Employer
description: Derek Jeter made up with George Steinbrenner two Visa commercials ago, so it seems like a long time since Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, criticized him for keeping late hours last winter. Now, after the Yankees' third season in a row without a World Series title, Jeter, the team captain, sounds as agitated as his boss. He finds no solace in falling two victories short of a championship.

title: LAW FIRM FIRES HEAD OF TAX SHELTER UNIT
description: The law firm of Sidley Austin Brown & Wood said yesterday that it had fired R.J. Ruble, the head of its tax shelter unit, for misconduct. The firm said it expelled Mr. Ruble from the partnership ''for breaches of fiduciary duty and violations of the partnership agreement.'' The firm said it ''learned of the activities'' on Thursday. Mr. Ruble, who worked in New York, has been named in court records as one of the principal designers of a tax shelter that let wealthy individuals avoid capital gains taxes by claiming losses from offshore currency transactions with companies that are not subject to tax and that took offsetting gains from the currency deals. David Cay Johnston (NYT)

description: I.R.S. Is Expected to Retain Credits for Fuel Producers

title: Families Grab an Asthma Lifeline That Keeps Children Well and Active
description: John Christian Hashagen, a third grader in Springfield, Mo., has asthma, bad asthma. Bad enough to result at age 6 in a respiratory arrest after soccer practice. Rescue efforts, potent steroids and four days in the hospital on a ventilator saved his life.

title: Child Agency Tries to Grasp How One Case Got Away
description: In the eight months before the police found Bruce Jackson looking for food in his neighbor's garbage, three different state workers had visited his adoptive parents' home a total of 10 times.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tories Force Leadership Vote
description: Restive members of the opposition Conservative Party succeeded in forcing a vote of confidence in their beleaguered leader, Iain Duncan Smith. Mr. Duncan Smith, the target of internal plotting and maneuvering during much of the two years he has held the post, announced that he would fight to keep his job. Outside Conservative headquarters with his wife, Betsy, by his side, Mr. Duncan Smith said he welcomed the chance to end ''this ludicrous leadership speculation'' and predicted he would prevail. He will address the Conservative membership of Parliament today, and a secret ballot will follow. To stay in office, he must win half the votes of the 166 Conservatives in the Commons. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROGOFF, PAUL
description: ROGOFF--Paul. The partners, principals and staff of Marks Paneth & Shron, LLP mourn the passing of our partner Paul Rogoff. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Ana Maria and his sister Lee and to his children and grandchildren.

title: Two C.I.A. Operatives Killed In an Ambush in Afghanistan
description: Two Central Intelligence Agency operatives were killed in an ambush in Afghanistan over the weekend, the agency said Tuesday, bringing to four the number of C.I.A. operatives acknowledged to have been killed in the line of duty since the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Upper Saddle River: Ex-Teacher Arrested
description: A former middle-school teacher was arraigned yesterday for what the authorities called bizarre behavior involving an ax and a mallet at a Halloween dance at his former school. He was also charged in what the police said was the attempted abduction of a child. Bail was set at $350,000. The man, Bruce Engelke, 60, of Congers, N.Y., was a music teacher at the Emil A. Cavallini Middle School in Saddle River from 1972 to 1984. Witnesses said that last Friday, Mr. Engelke walked uninvited into a student dance at the school. He was dressed, witnesses said, in a costume inspired by ''The Scream'' by Edvard Munch and popularized in a horror movie. He also held an ax and a mallet, which he used to tap several children on the head. Mr. Engelke was charged with two counts of weapons possession. It was unclear why he returned to the school after nearly 20 years. Earlier the same day, the police said, Mr. Engelke, wearing street clothes, asked a child to get into his car. Alicia Zubikowski (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNS, MARGARET
description: JOHNS -- Margaret. The Trustees and staff of the World Monuments Fund mark with great sadness the death of Margaret Johns. With her husband, Peter Stern, Vice Chairman and long-serving trustee of the World Monuments Fund, Margaret shared a passion for the work of the organization and participated with energy and intelligence in countless WMF events, trips, and gatherings. She brightened our lives with her informed and cheerful enthusiasm and greatly expanded our knowledge through her own many accomplishments, as a scientist, gardener, artist, music lover, reader, and passionate traveler. She will be missed by all. Our heartfelt condolences go to her beloved family including Peter Stern and daughters, Kate Johns and Sara Griffen.

title: Bush Prevails in Deal on $87 Billion for War Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  Senate and House negotiators reached general agreement on an $87 billion aid package for Iraq and Afghanistan today, and they specified that all the money would be in the form of grants, as President Bush had wanted.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: 2000 Festival's Crucifix Is Scrapped
description: Lawmakers demanded to know why a two-ton bronze crucifix used in a Mass for World Youth Day 2000 celebrated by John Paul II before two million people has ended up in a Rome garbage dump. Church officials said the cross was supposed to be installed in a new church. The discovery of the junked crucifix comes amid outrage from Vatican officials over a judge's order that crucifixes be removed from a public school. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Miracles of Small Class Size Unfold Daily in California
description: IT has been seven years since California's Republican governor, Pete Wilson, and Democratic Legislature passed a law limiting school class size, and to this day, teachers and parents here remember it as a remarkable moment.

description: Think of it as music to watch girls by. Or if you prefer, as women to hear music with. But if your priorities are visual or aural, you should still be able to have a perfectly good time at the newly recast Broadway revival of ''Nine'' at the Eugene O'Neill Theater, even now that Antonio Banderas, its original leading man and box-office magnet, has left.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Oxford Suspends Professor
description: An Oxford University professor who rejected a student for graduate work last summer because he was an Israeli has been suspended without pay for two months and ordered to attend anti-discrimination training. The professor, Andrew Wilkie, a geneticist, also resigned as a fellow of Pembroke College. Dr. Wilkie, citing his opposition to Israeli policies, had refused to accept Amit Duvshani, the student, for work in his laboratory. The student union called the punishment too mild. An Oxford spokesman said suspension was the most serious penalty the university could impose, short of dismissal. Diana Jean Schemo (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: After Long Delay, Senate Confirms Utah Governor as Head of E.P.A.
description: Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah was confirmed on Tuesday as head of the Environmental Protection Agency and will take over next week at the agency, which is the scene of major environmental battles.

title: Pasta That Adds Bite to Vodka
description: MUCH as I believe that the kitchen should not be a place you escape from, but a place you can escape to, I am also a realist. There are times when however much -- in theory -- you enjoy chatting with friends over a little chopping or stirring, it just isn't going to play.

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Bermuda: HSBC To Acquire Bank Of Bermuda
description: HSBC Holdings has agreed to buy Bank of Bermuda for $1.3 billion in cash in an effort to expand its international fund administration business. Bank of Bermuda shareholders will receive $45 a share in cash, 16 percent more than the average closing price for the last three months. Shareholders will receive $40 a share from HSBC and $5 a share from Bank of Bermuda as a special dividend, the statement said. The purchase comes a day after Barclays agreed to buy Gerrard Management Services to become the biggest adviser in Britain to clients with more than 70,000 ($118,000) to invest.

title: PROFIT AT SONIC AUTOMOTIVE DECREASES
description: Sonic Automotive, an automotive retailer, said yesterday that third-quarter profit slumped 44 percent on costs to retire high-interest debt and as sales of domestic brands dropped. Shares of Sonic fell as much as 24 percent. Net income fell to $17.5 million, or 41 cents a share, from $31.6 million, or 73 cents, a year earlier. Excluding costs to retire debt, the company would have earned 64 cents a share in the quarter, below the 81-cent average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Friday about political protests in Saudi Arabia misidentified the London-based Saudi dissident group that instigated them. It is the Movement for Islamic Reform in Arabia. (Saad al-Fagih is the name of the group's leader, a member of a prominent Saudi family.)

title: The Long Last Gasp of Tube-Based TV
description: America's love affair with all things big has moved from supersize French fries and sport utility vehicles to large flat-panel, wide-screen, HDTV-compatible televisions, the kind that can hang on a wall. While comparatively few are bought today -- because of their high cost -- sales are expected to explode this decade as prices plunge.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Progress In Rebuilding Dispute
description: The Silverstein Organization said yesterday that it was making progress in settling a dispute that had hobbled the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site. The developer, which controls the commercial lease at the site, told a state judge that it had reached a tentative agreement with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to buy out Silverstein's lender, the GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation. GMAC had sued Silverstein over its loan and the developer's handling of the insurance proceeds. To settle the suit, the developer, headed by Larry Silverstein, has sought approval from the Port Authority, which owns the site, for a GMAC buyout, for $570 million. The Port Authority is also buying out Westfield America, the mall operator that had the retail leases at the trade center, for $140 million. Justice Herman Cahn of State Supreme Court ordered Silverstein and GMAC to return to court tomorrow for a hearing. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Sauces That Provide a Helping Of the Rarest Ingredient: Time
description: Maya Kaimal, left, a cookbook author, has introduced three fresh, versatile Indian sauces called Simmer Sauces. Pour one of them in a pan, add an ingredient like raw shrimp and simmer until done for a quick main dish to serve four. Ms. Kaimal has done all the heavy lifting, so the cook doesn't have to toast, grind or blend the spices and other sauce ingredients.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Agere Posts First Profit
description: Agere Systems, a chip maker, reported its first quarterly profit yesterday since it was spun off from Lucent Technologies in 2001. Profit from continuing operations in the fourth quarter that ended on Sept. 30 was $22 million, or 1 cent a share, compared with a loss of $356 million, or 22 cents a share, a year earlier, Agere said. Cost cutting and sales of units helped Agere turn a profit. Sales were $504 million, up 2.6 percent from the fourth quarter of 2002.

title: Traders Wonder if U.S. Will Reverse Weak-Dollar Policy
description: The Bush administration's virtual weak-dollar policy has not done any damage so far to the American financial markets. There are some reasons for concern, however.

title: Bush Backs His Brother's Decision in Feeding Tube Case
description: President Bush waded into the right-to-die debate for the first time on Tuesday, declaring that his brother Jeb, the governor of Florida, acted correctly this month when he ordered that a brain-damaged woman be placed back on a feeding tube.

description: The statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday is nearly identical to its statements after monetary policy meetings in September and August. title: Letting John Cage Ring Out, Then Space Out
description: Anyone who passed the corner of 53rd Street and Fifth Avenue late Sunday afternoon might have wondered: what on earth is that sonic pandemonium raining down on Midtown? A simple answer: it was John Cage's strange and wonderful Music for Carillon, performed by George Steel and Nico Muhly from the top of St. Thomas Church. It must have been audible for dozens of blocks around, but most of the audience was gathered across the street from the church where the sound was clear and at times almost deafening.

description: A leading Internet standards-setting organization took the unusual step yesterday of urging the director of the United States Patent and Trademark Office to invalidate a software patent that the group says threatens the development of the World Wide Web.
