description: Investment bankers and other executives at the Goldman Sachs Group will stop serving as directors of other companies, a shift intended to head off any conflicts of interest.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: SYRACUSE: CARRIER REJECTS JOBS PLAN The Carrier Corporation yesterday rejected a $210 million package of state, federal and union assistance intended to keep Carrier from moving 1,200 manufacturing jobs out of the state and overseas. The package included wage cuts and other savings offered by one of its unions. Carrier officials said the aid package did not deal with the company's economic realities. On Oct. 6, Carrier said it would close the two manufacturing plants at its East Syracuse site and move them to Georgia, Singapore and China. Most of Carrier's customers for products built in Syracuse are now in the Far East. About 1,600 Carrier jobs remain in the area. State and federal officials, who made the offer despite Carrier's insistence that no amount of money could change its decision, expressed disappointment. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Pumpkin Vines, to Eat? Who Knew?
description: ''HOW do you cook them?'' a customer asked, looking at a tangle of greens with prickly ribbed stems, fuzzy jagged-edged leaves and spiraling antennae at Vang-Mee Lor Yang's stall at the Newton farmers' market. Most people at the market would have been able to identify the exotic-looking greens if they had seen them in the field, with pumpkins attached.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAHN, JERRY

May his wife Lynn, sister June, sons Jonathan, Ari, Steven and their families be comforted among the mourners of Zion & Jerusalem. Kenneth Brander, Rabbi Efrem Goldberg, Assistant Rabbi Hommy Tannenbaum, President

description: The Bloomberg administration released a report yesterday recommending an overhaul of the 911 emergency phone system to strengthen its technology and streamline the way calls are handled.

title: Bushs Urgent Task: To Calm Publics Growing Impatience
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  Early on Tuesday morning, as many Americans were scanning newspaper headlines about the latest wave of deadly bombings in Iraq, President Bush met with his press secretary and his communications director in the Oval Office. He told them, aides said, that he wanted to hold a full-scale news conference a few hours later.

title: A Rebel on the Governments Side
description: Juanes, the Colombian songwriter who dominated this year's Latin Grammy Awards, looked like a typical rocker during his sold-out show on Oct. 24 at the Theater at Madison Square Garden. Lean and boyish, with an amiable baritone voice, Juanes poured sincerity into love songs, held his guitar aloft for solos and promised, ``The party starts now!'' But his guitar was red, blue and yellow, the colors of the Colombian flag, and Colombia - its musical traditions and its long civil war - was never far from his songs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JONES, GERTRUDE L. (NEE LOWERRE)
description: JONES--Gertrude L. (nee Lowerre) formerly of Flushing. At the age of 100 passed away on October 26, 2003 in Lawrenceville, Georgia. Loving daughter of Thomas B. Lowerre IV, the former Postmaster of Flushing, and Administrator of Flushing Hospital; and Margaret Field. Preceded in death by husbands, John Morrison and William B. Jones, daughter, Margaret Smith and son, John D. Morrison. Mrs Jones lived most of her life in Flushing and Haines Falls. She worked many years for Flushing Obstetricians. She was a charter member and officer of the Matinecock Chapter of Daughters of the American Revolution; board member of the Bowne House, and member of the Church On The Hill. She is survived by her grandchildren, Nancy Smith, Wendy Barber, Douglas Morrison, Lynne McHenry, Scott Morrison, Amy Parker and Timothy Morrison; 15 great grandchildren, and niece and nephews. A graveside service will be held at Flushing Cemetery on Thursday, October 30th at 10AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Charity of your choice.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a debate in Detroit by Democratic presidential candidates referred incorrectly to a response from Gen. Wesley K. Clark: ''Right after 9/11, this administration determined to do bait-and-switch on the American public. President Bush said he was going to get Osama bin Laden, dead or alive. Instead, he went after Saddam Hussein. He doesn't have either one of them today.'' The comment responded to a question about where he stands on the war in Iraq, not to the question ''Are we to understand that what you're saying now is that those things you have said that were positive about the war was not what you meant?''

title: Warning of Budget Gap, M.T.A. May Pare MetroCard Discounts
description: Warning that it could face a budget gap of more than a billion dollars by 2006, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it would consider reducing MetroCard discounts as early as 2005 to help balance its books.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MINNESOTA: FUN CITY, U.S.A. Minneapolis has been designated the most fun city in the country by Cranium, a board game company in Seattle. Minneapolis, which beat out New York, 41st, and Las Vegas, 25th, was praised for shopping malls, sports teams, toy stores, restaurants, shopping areas and money spent on recreation, among other criteria. Orange County, Calif.; San Jose, Calif.; Atlanta; and Chicago completed the top five. New Orleans was 50th. The rankings were based on a survey that Cranium commissioned from Bert Sperling, who operates BestPlaces.net, a Web site that rates regions. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Clark Lays Responsibility For 9/11 at Bush's Feet
description: In a blistering review of President Bush's national security policy, Gen. Wesley K. Clark said on Tuesday that the administration could not ''walk away from its responsibilities for 9/11.''

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: TORIES FORCE LEADERSHIP VOTE Restive members of the opposition Conservative Party succeeded in forcing a vote of confidence in their beleaguered leader, Iain Duncan Smith. Mr. Duncan Smith, the target of internal plotting and maneuvering during much of the two years he has held the post, announced that he would fight to keep his job. Outside Conservative headquarters with his wife, Betsy, by his side, Mr. Duncan Smith said he welcomed the chance to end "this ludicrous leadership speculation" and predicted he would prevail. He will address the Conservative membership of Parliament today, and a secret ballot will follow. To stay in office, he must win half the votes of the 166 Conservatives in the Commons.    Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: About New York; A New Account of Sept. 11 Loss, With 40 Fewer Souls to Mourn
description: The sun inched across a cloudless sky yesterday, the breath of October rustled trees, and the number of people killed in the World Trade Center disaster dropped by 40. Just like that: 40 fewer souls to imagine rising from the dust; 40 fewer people to include in nightly prayers.

title: A News Conference or a Mayor's Daydream?
description: For months, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has publicly joked about his crush on Jennifer Lopez, even going as far as to suggest that his companion, Diana Taylor, might be jealous of his fixation.

title: Pairings: Standing Up to a Wine That's Not Always a Standout
description: WHILE the wine panel agreed that most super-Tuscans we tasted were less than super, these wines were at least respectable, and often make very good choices for a drink with dinner. A number were original blends, deep in fruit and not shy on tannins, all qualities that make for easy pairing.

title: Growth Spurt Accelerates In Wal-Mart's Backyard
description: Rising steps away from Wal-Mart's warehouse-style world headquarters is Bentonville Plaza, a nine-story brick-and-concrete building that will offer an amenity that has not been seen before in this mostly rural but fast-growing corner of northwest Arkansas: a concierge.

title: House G.O.P. Risks Battle With Senators on Tax Cuts
description: House Republicans pushed ahead on Tuesday with a bill that would give corporations $128 billion in new tax breaks over the next decade, setting themselves up for a fight with Senate leaders from both parties who want to rein in the federal deficit.

title: Punishing the Pell Grant Program
description: The maximum award of the federal Pell Grant program, created to encourage low- and middle-income students to attend college, covered more than 80 percent of public-college tuition a quarter-century ago but covers only about 40 percent today. Faced with high tuition, up to 25 percent of the low-income students with grades and scores that make them prime college material no longer even apply.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLEN, JOHN (JACK) J., SR.
description: ALLEN--John (Jack) J., Sr. On Sunday, October 26, 2003. Of Pottstown, PA. Husband of Ann Marie. Funeral Thursday, October 30, 10 AM St. Aloysius Church, Pottstown. Viewing Wednesday, 2-4, 7-9, Catagnus Funeral Home, Pottstown.

title: A British retailer calls its logo tongue in cheek. Critics call it inappropriate.
description: FASHION houses have a long tradition of branding merchandise with their initials, from Yves Saint Laurent sunglasses to Louis Vuitton luggage.

title: An Unlikely Leader Emerges As Europe's Economy Mends
description: Europe's bruised economies are more firmly on the mend, according to several new surveys, with the Continent's recovery now being led by perhaps its least likely candidate: Germany.

title: As Contract Witching Hour Nears, Restaurant Workers Talk Strike
description: ABOUT 250 waiters, cooks, busboys, bartenders and dishwashers marched across Midtown Manhattan yesterday afternoon, calling for contract settlements that would avoid strikes at some of New York's top restaurants.

title: Like the Cheese? You'll Love the Goats
description: Hundreds of artisanal goat-cheese makers are working in the United States now, but in the early 1980's Miles and Lillian Cahn were among the pioneers when they started Coach Farm in the Hudson Valley. ''The Perils and Pleasures of Domesticating Goat Cheese,'' by Mr. Cahn (Catskill Press, $19.95 in paperback), tells the story of their adventures and successes in a way that both children and adults can understand and enjoy. The first 22 pages explain the cheese-making process, but most of the book consists of charming color photographs of the goats that make it all possible, taken by the Cahns' daughter Julie.

title: $50 Million Gift Is Left to Notre Dame
description: Joan B. Kroc, whose husband, Ray, founded the McDonald's Corporation empire, has left $50 million to the University of Notre Dame, the largest single gift in the 160-year history of the university.

title: A Bright Addition to the Curry Hill Buffet
description: I HAVE never cared much for the custom in Indian restaurants of serving a buffet at lunch.

title: Oxford Health Income Up
description: Third-quarter net income at Oxford Health Plans surged more than 300 percent because premium rates for benefits outpaced rising medical costs. But Oxford warned that enrollment had slowed, and it forecast a drop in membership in 2004. Its shares closed at $41.63, down $4.36, or 9.5 percent.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: BP Posts Profit Increase
description: BP reported a 25 percent increase in third-quarter net profit to $2.87 billion, below analyst forecasts. The company's results reflected an increase in oil prices, but weakening margins in the chemical business. BP's chief executive, Lord Browne, said that world economic activity had strengthened in the third quarter, but that the company did not anticipate any share buybacks before the end of the year. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Birthday Party Video Takes Center Stage at Kozlowski Trial
description: For about 21 minutes yesterday, Courtroom No. 1324 at State Supreme Court in Manhattan was pin-drop quiet as prosecutors played a videotape of a $2 million weeklong birthday party on the island of Sardinia for L. Dennis Kozlowski's wife, Karen.

title: Facing the Truth of Sept. 11
description: The commission investigating the government's failures before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks is in danger of becoming a study in recalcitrance by the Bush administration. The independent commission's mandate is to supply a definitive account of the government's handling of the terrorist plot that killed almost 3,000 people. But the White House continues to fence with requests for classified documents crucial to the inquiry.

title: Justice Dept. Tightens Security in C.I.A. Leak Case
description: Justice Department and F.B.I. officials have imposed tighter secrecy restrictions over the inquiry into the leak of the identity of a C.I.A. operative, government officials said on Tuesday. In an unusual step, they have removed the director of the F.B.I's Washington office from the list of officials with access to the case.

title: Iraqis Removed Arms Material, U.S. Aide Says
description: The director of a top American spy agency said Tuesday that he believed that material from Iraq's illicit weapons program had been transported into Syria and perhaps other countries as part of an effort by the Iraqis to disperse and destroy evidence immediately before the recent war.

title: LOCKHEED'S PROFIT FALLS 28% ON PENSION COSTS
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, the military contractor, said yesterday that third-quarter profit declined 28 percent because of pension and debt-retirement expenses. Sales jumped to a record on demand for fighter jets. Net income was $217 million, or 48 cents a share, compared with profit from continuing operations of $300 million, or 66 cents, a year ago, the company said. Sales rose 23 percent, to $8.1 billion from $6.5 billion. Results included $163 million of costs for pension and debt. Profit this year will be $2.95 to $3.05 a share, excluding pension and debt costs, said James Ryan, Lockheed's vice president for investor relations.

title: A Documentary Illuminates Young Lives at the Crossroads of Redemption and Devastation
description: Liz Garbus's hard-headed documentary film ''Girlhood'' is prefaced with an unsettling statistic: in the last decade the number of violent assaults by under-age girls in this country has doubled. The film then narrows its focus to concentrate on the lives of two teenagers, Shanae Owens and Megan Jensen, both incarcerated for assault at the Waxter Juvenile Facility in Baltimore. With its drab green walls and sparse furnishings, Waxter is no country club. But its staff emerges as a caring if overstressed group of people who do what they can to steer the girls in their charge toward a productive life. Often it's not enough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POCHAPIN, KOHN, SANDRA
description: POCHAPIN - KOHN -- Sandra. Our hearts are saddened by the death of our beloved sister-in-law and aunt, Sandy. We share the loss with all her loved ones. She will be missed by us all and always remembered. Rita & Philip Rosen, Phyllis, Wendy, Robert, Michael,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALL, JOHN H.
description: BALL--John H. Died in his 83rd year. Son of the late Hattie and Nathan Ball. Cherished husband of the late Alice W. Ball. Adored father of Joan B. Joffe and Jean Ball Scheinert, father-in-law of Dean and loving grandfather of Andrew and Michael. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions to Central Synagogue where he was honored to serve as president for 6 years or the Hebrew Home for the Aged, Riverdale would be appreciated.

title: TV-Radio Contract Is Set
description: Performers in television and radio commercials agreed yesterday to a new three-year contract.

title: Jackson's Neutrality Hindering Sharpton Campaign
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson is again on the campaign trail. He was in California stumping against the recall of Gov. Gray Davis, a Democrat. He was in Connecticut marching with Yale employees working without a contract. He has been attacking a Texas plan to redraw Congressional election districts.

title: Ndereba Favored Among Elite 48
description: It was early February 1999 and Catherine Ndereba, a 26-year-old cross-country runner, was trying to make the Kenyan national team.

title: Accounts and People of Note
description: Performers in television and radio commercials agreed yesterday to a new three-year contract.

title: BUSH SAYS HE SEES NO NEED IN IRAQ FOR ADDING G.I.'S
description: President Bush said Tuesday that he saw no need for additional American troops in Iraq despite a lethal series of bomb and rocket attacks in Baghdad over the past three days, but he vowed that the United States ''will stay the course'' until stability is restored.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ALABAMA: BID FOR BOMB FILES Lawyers representing Eric Rudolph in the bombing of an abortion clinic have asked the government for information on Richard Jewell, the security guard who was investigated but not charged in the bombing at the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta. Mr. Rudolph is charged with the Olympics bombing, as well as the bombing that killed a police officer and critically injured a nurse at a clinic in Birmingham. Court documents made public on Monday indicate that Mr. Rudolph's lawyers seek government documents about Mr. Jewell as they try to show that someone other than Mr. Rudolph is culpable. (AP)

title: If It Walks Like, and Quacks Like, a Tornado
description: When a tornado strikes out West, the local news organizations seem to be able to find some folksy-sounding person to say that the storm sounded like a freight train a-coming.

title: The Devils Show How A Strategy Is Executed
description: Hockey's neutral-zone trap, in which defenders clog the middle of the ice, can numb spectators and frustrate imitators. Just ask the Islanders.

title: Trucker Sentenced to 20 Years in Plot Against Brooklyn Bridge
description: An Ohio truck driver who admitted six months ago that he plotted with senior operatives of Al Qaeda to destroy the Brooklyn Bridge was sentenced on Tuesday to 20 years in prison. Minutes before the sentencing, the driver, Iyman Faris, 34, tried to withdraw his earlier guilty plea, saying he had admitted a role in the plot only to fool the F.B.I. and secure a book deal for himself.

title: Young Victim of Sniper Recounts His Ordeal
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Oct. 29  He had been kicked off the school bus for eating candy, so his aunt drove him to school that fall morning. He got out of her car, set his backpack on a ledge and suddenly realized he had just been shot in the chest.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about an apartment fire in Manhattan that injured eight people gave a misspelled surname in various editions for a victim and for her father, who traveled from Philadelphia after hearing about the fire. They are Melissa and Dennis Bloch, not Blach or Block.

title: Council Proposes 2 Moves to Intensify City's War on Rats
description: The City Council moved yesterday to step up the city's war against rats, proposing legislation to establish a pest control board and to sharply increase fines for the improper disposal of trash.

title: Ailing Knicks Relying On Ex-Nets
description: Keith Van Horn and Dikembe Mutombo have passed each other on the turnpike and have traveled across the swamp and through the tunnel, emerging together at Madison Square Garden for tonight's Knicks season opener against Orlando.

title: N.Y.S.E. Chief Is Planning To Split Board
description: John S. Reed, the interim director of the New York Stock Exchange, has decided to split the board of the exchange, say exchange members who have been briefed on the proposal. The move is intended to create a board structure that is both independent and representative of its members' interests.

title: Fall's Cornucopia Isn't Empty Just Yet
description: As the weather turns cold and crops dwindle, some vegetables thrive -- notably celery and its cousins celery root and parsley root. Alex Paffenroth of Paffenroth Gardens in Warwick, N.Y., shown at right at the Union Square Greenmarket, grows them all.

title: For Lakers, It's Winning And Healing
description: Last season, Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant were at peace. As O'Neal put it, he was the ''big brother'' and Bryant was the ''little brother.'' The two Los Angeles Lakers All-Stars even united in criticizing their teammates when the team struggled early.

title: Olympic Bidders Land in Court
description: Twenty months after the flame was extinguished on Utah's triumphant 2002 Winter Olympics, a less uplifting Olympic event -- the messy retelling of how the state won the Games -- began here Tuesday in Federal District Court.

title: BAGHDAD OFFICIAL REPORTED KILLED
description: After a two-day delay, the American-led occupation authority disclosed Tuesday that a Baghdad deputy mayor was assassinated here at the start of the latest round of insurgent violence that has already killed and wounded more than 250 Iraqi civilians.

title: CALENDAR
description: A Primer on Oysters

title: Los Angeles Takes Offensive; San Diego Faces Flare-Up
description: Emergency helicopters loaded with water crisscrossed the skies above the city's northern suburbs on Tuesday as firefighters appeared confident that a barreling blaze in the Santa Monica Mountains could be stopped short of the city of Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, BERNICE
description: BERNSTEIN -- Bernice. Passed away October 28, 2003. Devoted wife of the late Bertram, beloved mother of Ilene Davis, Marlene Hess and JoAnn Leder. Cherished grandmother and greatgrandmother. Her love of life gave great joy to all who knew her. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services Thursday, October 30 at 12:45PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to Hospice Atlanta, 1244 Park Vista Drive, Atlanta, Ga. 30319.

title: Sony Plans To Eliminate 20,000 Jobs Over 3 Years
description: In an attempt to achieve a turnaround, the Sony Corporation announced on Tuesday a three-year plan that includes laying off 20,000 workers, ending production of older-model TV sets in Japan, sharply cutting the numbers of parts and suppliers, and starting a joint venture to make flat screens with its archrival, Samsung Electronics of South Korea.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Charged In Baby's Death
description: The police have charged a 34-year-old Rockaways man with manslaughter and endangering the welfare of a child in the death of his 3-month-old son. The man, Andre Cooper, of Beach 66th Street, was arrested on Monday, three days after the medical examiner's office classified the death of his son, Allah, as a homicide by suffocation. He was found unconscious at home on Sept. 8. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Recipe: Blond Mocha Sauce
description: Time: 15 minutes, plus chilling

title: The Warming Is Global but the Legislating, in the U.S., Is All Local
description: Motivated by environmental and economic concerns, states have become the driving force in efforts to combat global warming even as mandatory programs on the federal level have largely stalled.

title: Days of Growing Carnage in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Conviction of Ex-C.I.A. Operative Is Set Aside
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  A federal judge in Texas has thrown out the 1983 conviction there of Edwin P. Wilson, a former Central Intelligence Agency officer, for selling tons of explosives to Libya, ruling that prosecutors knowingly used false testimony to undermine his defense.

title: Refinement From Geneva
description: For record collectors of a certain age - or at least, for those who collect recordings of a certain age - the Orchestre de la Suisse Romande will always be associated with Ernest Ansermet, who founded it in 1918 and, toward the end of his 50-year tenure, led it in a series of magnificent, natural-sounding discs. As the resident orchestra of the Swiss Broadcasting Service, in Geneva, it is part of a tradition that continues to thrive in Europe, but died long ago in the United States, where even the biggest cities are lucky to have classical radio at all, let alone stations with their own ensembles.

title: Days of Growing Carnage in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tragedy of National Complacency
description: WHY AMERICA SLEPT

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Putnam Investments Accused of Fraud

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENDOZA, DR. BARBARA M.
description: MENDOZA--Dr. Barbara M., died at her home on October 26, 2003 of lung cancer. In 1940, Eleanor Roosevelt invited a few college students to tea at the White House. Dr. Mendoza was at that meeting, which set the course for her life. Mrs. Roosevelt was very enthusiastic about the role of women, whether they were homemakers or career women. In each case, she said there were three things women should always be interested in-politics, education and the arts. Dr. Mendoza followed this advice in her personal and professional career. She was awarded a B.A. from Brooklyn College, a M.A. from Columbia University, and a Ph.D from New York University. For 20 years, she headed the Drama Dept. at St. John's University, Staten Island. She was a member of Common Cause, Amnesty International, Planned Parenthood, the National Democratic Party, and the New York Speech Association. She was a member of The Cosmopolitan Club in New York City and served on the Board of Governors. She is survived by her husband, Wyn, who has proved to be trustworthy, beloved and amusing for over 60 years, by her daughters, Kathy, Susan, Liza and Julie, and by her grandson, Joseph.

title: Following the Pepper Grinder All the Way to Its Source
description: OF all the distinctively flavored seeds, barks, roots, fruits and leaves that we call spices, pepper is the most widely used, and for centuries it was the most valuable.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Lawyer Sentenced
description: A lawyer, Zheng Enchong, who helped expose a real estate scandal in Shanghai, has been sentenced to three years in prison on charges that he disclosed state secrets, his lawyer, Guo Guoting, said. Mr. Zheng was convicted of ''illegally providing state secrets to people abroad,'' Mr. Guo said. Mr. Zheng's five-hour trial last month was closed to the public, and officials have not said why he was accused of revealing state secrets. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: U.S. STEEL POSTS A NET LOSS OF $349 MILLION
description: The U.S. Steel Corporation had a third-quarter loss, its biggest in more than a decade, because of $432 million in expenses to pay retirees, fire workers and write down assets. The net loss was $349 million, or $3.42 a share, compared with net income of $106 million, or $1.04, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 32 percent, to $2.5 billion, from $1.9 billion. U.S. Steel had $402 million in expenses to start reducing its work force by 20 percent and to pay benefits to early retirees after acquiring the National Steel Corporation in May and its 8,200 employees.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cox Loss Widens
description: Cox Communications, the cable television company, said yesterday that its third-quarter loss widened after it wrote down the value of some debt securities. The net loss expanded to $215.1 million, or 35 cents a share, from $73.1 million, or 12 cents a share, a year earlier, said Cox, which is based in Atlanta. Revenue rose 15 percent, to $1.46 billion from $1.28 billion.

title: Please, Forget Some More
description: To the Editor:

title: Reports Detail a Hypothetical Shuttle Rescue
description: A pair of spacewalking astronauts could have climbed out of the Columbia's air hatch and inspected its damaged left wing if one of them had used the other as a ladder, according to documents released on Tuesday by the Columbia Accident Investigation Board.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: For Rangers, Good Morning, Bad Night
description: The best news the Rangers received yesterday came at their morning skate, which says plenty about how the Rangers fared against the Anaheim Mighty Ducks at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Walker, Giants' Rookie Cornerback, Keeps Them Smiling
description: Ask any of the Giants' defensive players about the rookie cornerback Frank Walker and their reaction starts with a smile. Or a snicker. Or a shake of the head.

title: ATLANTIC COAST AIRLINES SUES MESA OVER BID
description: Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings, which is trying to fend off an unsolicited takeover offer from the Mesa Air Group, sued in federal court yesterday to stop Mesa from taking the bid directly to shareholders. Atlantic Coast accused Mesa of misleading investors by failing to say in government filings that United Airlines, a unit of UAL, is a ''participant'' in the plan. Insider stock sales by Mesa executives before the offer are at odds with Mesa's ''ebullient'' view of its future, Atlantic Coast said. United reiterated that it was not involved in Mesa's offer and said that ''to suggest otherwise is baseless and irresponsible.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: WPP Reports 10.9% Earnings Rise
description: The WPP Group reported a 10.9 increase in third-quarter revenue, to 1.03 billion ($1.7 billion), helped by its acquisition of the Cordiant Communications Group this year and a soft dollar. Revenue would have climbed 2 percent without the deal and foreign exchange fluctuations. Sales rose most in Mexico and China in the quarter. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Durable Goods Orders Rose in September
description: Durable goods orders rose in September for a fourth month in five, the Commerce Department said yesterday. And the Conference Board, a private research group in New York, said consumers grew more confident in October as their job prospects improved.

title: American Soldiers Kill Six Iraqi Civilians After a Bomb Explosion Near a U.S. Convoy
description: American soldiers killed six civilians just west of this city on Monday after a roadside bomb exploded near their convoy, according to town officials and witnesses.

title: Artist's Journey From Billboards to Supersize Art
description: WE are looking at the big picture here.

title: Cash Incentives for Adoptions Seen as Risk to Some Children
description: In December 1995, Raymond and Vanessa Jackson, who had already adopted a young girl, formally adopted another child -- Bruce, a foster child then age 11. Over the next 12 months, the parents adopted two more boys from the state, and in 1997 they scooped up a fourth. Yet another girl was made legally theirs in 2000.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Vote To Go Ahead
description: The British and Irish governments acknowledged that they had been unable to resolve a pre-election dispute over the disarming of the Irish Republican Army but confirmed that the vote for the Northern Ireland Assembly would go ahead on Nov. 26. The Catholic-Protestant assembly has been suspended for a year, and intensive efforts have gone into reviving it before the election. Those efforts collapsed a week ago after David Trimble, the Protestant leader, said he found the details of a new I.R.A. act of disarmament to be inadequate. The British and Irish were unable to persuade the I.R.A. to lift its right of confidentiality. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: University President To Resign
description: The president of the State University at Albany, Karen R. Hitchcock, left, announced yesterday that she will step down at the end of the academic year. A university spokeswoman said Dr. Hitchcock, who has been president since 1996, was not available for an interview. But in her resignation speech to the faculty yesterday, Dr. Hitchcock said that her recent candidacy for the presidency of the University of Florida -- she was a finalist -- had led her to realize it was time for a change. Her timing was unusual in that she had announced a $500 million capital campaign in April, the largest in SUNY's history, and presidents rarely walk away from such campaigns. And New York State announced last year that it was working with a consortium of computer-chip companies to build a huge research center at the University at Albany. But SUNY recently moved control of that project to its headquarters, and there have been reports, in The Times Union in Albany, and elsewhere, of growing friction between Dr. Hitchcock and SUNY's chancellor, Robert L. King. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: New Jersey Democrats Campaign Without Mentioning McGreevey
description: Listening to many of the Democrats campaigning for New Jersey's Legislature this fall, it would be easy to get the impression that the state is now governed by a governor with no name.

title: Punk Rocker or Majorette?
description: The progressive hard-core band the Mars Volta took the Roseland Ballroom stage around 10 p.m. on Oct. 24, knowing that the concert had to be finished by 11. That left just enough time for a three-song set, which included an anti-slam-dancing lecture, some postpunk cheerleading (Cedric Bixler Zavala, the lead singer, loves to toss and twirl the microphone stand as if it were a majorette's baton) and lots of guitar solos.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: A Theater Closing, A Hit Show In the Cold
description: ''Urinetown,'' the unlikely musical hit that has been occupying Henry Miller's Theater on West 43rd Street for more than two years under the threat of eviction, has finally gotten the bad news. The producers were told on Monday that the show would have to leave the theater by Feb. 15 because a 57-story skyscraper was about to be built on the Avenue of the Americas between 42nd and 43rd Streets, a site that includes the theater.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FIRST DATA CORP., Greenwood Village, Colo., said its shareholders had voted to approve a nearly $7 billion acquisition of Concord EFS, Memphis, although regulators sued to block the deal.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Chip Giant Posts Big Profit
description: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the world's largest supplier of made-to-order chips, said third-quarter profit rose to its highest level in three years. Net income soared to 15.2 billion Taiwan dollars ($448 million), higher than analysts' forecasts, from 3.2 billion Taiwan dollars a year ago, the company said. Sales rose 38 percent. The earnings, along with reports this month from Intel and Samsung Electronics, underscore a recovery in semiconductor sales, which barely rose last year after falling by a third in 2001. Some of Taiwan Semiconductors' most-advanced factories are operating at capacity as demand rises for digital cameras and other gadgets. Net income was the highest since the fourth quarter of 2000, when the company made 21.5 billion Taiwan dollars.

title: U.S. Takes Softer Tone on Iran, Once in the 'Axis of Evil'
description: The Bush administration assured Iran on Tuesday that the United States did not favor ''regime change'' in Tehran and signaled a new willingness to engage in a dialogue with Iran over its nuclear program, its alleged support of terrorism and other issues.

title: Praying Amid the Ashes For Any Precious Artifact
description: To a passer-by, the smoking mound of debris at 10333 Avenida Magnifica looked just like the remains of scores of other houses destroyed in the inferno that roared through the Scripps Ranch neighborhood on Sunday morning, mere ashes and charred timbers and a sentinel chimney against a sepia sky.

title: Bush's Urgent Task: To Calm Public's Growing Impatience
description: Early on Tuesday morning, as many Americans were scanning newspaper headlines about the latest wave of deadly bombings in Iraq, President Bush met with his press secretary and his communications director in the Oval Office. He told them, aides said, that he wanted to hold a full-scale news conference a few hours later.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PINE, ARTHUR (ARTIE)
description: PINE--Arthur (Artie), October 26, 2000. Our friendship began in 1946. We loved him and miss him more and more. Leonard Wurzel

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Fun City, U.S.A.
description: Minneapolis has been designated the most fun city in the country by Cranium, a board game company in Seattle. Minneapolis, which beat out New York, 41st, and Las Vegas, 25th, was praised for shopping malls, sports teams, toy stores, restaurants, shopping areas and money spent on recreation, among other criteria. Orange County, Calif.; San Jose, Calif.; Atlanta; and Chicago completed the top five. New Orleans was 50th. The rankings were based on a survey that Cranium commissioned from Bert Sperling, who operates BestPlaces.net, a Web site that rates regions. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINTRAUB, MORRIS
description: WEINTRAUB -- Morris. The Solomon Schechter School of Westchester notes with deep sadness the death of our former trustee, Morris ''Tiny'' Weintraub, husband of our esteemed friend Selma, and grandfather of alumni Neil and Scott Kaufman, Heather Stein, Jennifer, Rebecca and Lexie Weintraub. Tiny was a vital force for many years in the development of this institution. His energy, wisdow and generosity were an example for our community in the formative years of this school. Tiny Weintraub's memory will be a blessing to the children of this school for generations to come. M. Mac Schwebel, Chairman, Board of Trustees James M. Dubin, Vice Chairman Dr. Elliot Spiegel, Headmaster

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GORMAN, ETHEL
description: GORMAN--Ethel. October 29, 1914. Lovingly remembered by her family each and every day. Linda, Doug, Abby and Richard

title: Margaret Johns, Pheromone Expert, Dies at 75
description: Dr. Margaret A. Johns, who showed that pheromones can set off hormonal changes in mammals when they activate receptors in a tiny nasal cavity, a process that can attract animals of the opposite sex, died Saturday at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital. She was 75.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about William Goldberg, a leader of New York's diamond district who dealt in large gems, omitted the name of his wife, who survives him. She is Lili Gordon Goldberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, LEO
description: SCHWARTZ--Leo. Of Pearl River. Died October 9. He was born in New York to the late Minnie and Henry Schwartz. He was a New York City Fireman for over 20 years, then went to work for The New York Times. He worked at The Times for over 20 years until his retirement. He is survived by his wife Elaine, his daughter Roberta and her husband Jeff Dunn, son Dr. Martin Schwartz and wife Sally, and grandchildren Alisa and Lonnie Shupak, Sheryl Dunn and Eric, Alison and Jaclyn Schwartz, and a sister, Florence Urband.

title: Some Succession Questions at BSkyB
description: James Murdoch, the youngest son of Rupert Murdoch, seemed for a while to be moving smoothly toward the top job at British Sky Broadcasting, one of Britain's largest public media companies, at least until now.

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: Law Firm In Conflict
description: The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled that a law firm that the Energy Department hired to prepare a license application apparently had a conflict of interest, because it was simultaneously lobbying Congress to approve Yucca Mountain, a proposed nuclear waste repository 90 miles north of Las Vegas. The ruling, by a three-judge panel, could delay plans for the site. The court ordered that a lower court determine whether the firm, Winston & Strawn, had been properly reviewed and suggested that a competing firm could be awarded the work. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: Optimistic on Jobs, Fed Keeps Interest Low
description: The Federal Reserve kept short-term interest rates at 1 percent on Tuesday, the lowest level in 45 years, and suggested that it would continue to do so until at least sometime next year.

title: The Pollyanna Conspiracy
description: A giggling gaggle of cockeyed economic optimists who operate under cover as ''the Pollyanna Conspiracy'' are threatening to seize control of American public opinion.

title: Reduced-Fat Choices That Pass the Taste Test
description: SEVERAL fast-food chains offer lower fat alternatives to burgers and fries. Here are some of the best tasting:

title: Heartburn in the Heartland: Cheese, Anyone?
description: In 1997 it was rumored that Norm Macdonald was removed as anchor of the fake-news segment on ''Saturday Night Live'' because he regularly satirized O. J. Simpson, a friend of one of the show's producers. Mr. Macdonald had some swagger then, jerky, my-way power, the kind that says to being sidelined, especially being sidelined for sending up O. J.: fine.

title: Nets Raise Bar, Hoping The Banner Will Follow
description: Alonzo Mourning was not around the last two seasons when the Nets walked off the court in the N.B.A. finals with heads down and the opposition celebrating. But he has endured enough heartbreak in his career to understand.

title: Music Retailers Slow to Adopt Plan to Lower Price of CD's
description: A month after Universal Music announced it was cutting CD prices by as much as 30 percent, shoppers looking for the results in the aisles of music stores may be coming away disappointed.

title: John J. Fay Jr., 76, Ombudsman For the Elderly of New Jersey
description: John J. Fay Jr., the New Jersey lawmaker who wrote legislation creating the post of ombudsman to monitor care of the elderly in institutions and then became the first to fill the job, died on Monday at his home in Metuchen, N.J. He was 76.

title: Palestinian Premier Seems Likely to Continue
description: The Palestinian prime minister, Ahmed Qurei, who threatened to quit this month just days after taking his job on an emergency basis, now appears likely to lead a permanent government, Palestinian officials said Tuesday.

title: Putin Aide Reported to Have Quit Over Oil Chiefs Arrest
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 29  President Vladimir V. Putin's powerful chief of staff was reported today to have resigned in protest over the arrest of the country's richest businessman, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, even as the investigation into his company widened on other fronts.

title: Days of Growing Carnage in Iraq (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Olympic Team Faces a Difficult Task to Qualify
description: When the United States Olympic baseball qualifying team gathered for the first time in early October, Manager Frank Robinson wondered how to set the tone. He did not need to worry. Ernie Young, a veteran of the 2000 squad that won in Sydney, Australia, brought his gold medal. As it was handed around, everyone became spellbound by it, even Robinson, a Hall of Famer with 21 years as a player in the big leagues.

title: Man Held in Attack on Cabdriver Is Accused of Plotting to Kill Her
description: A 20-year-old Long Island man jailed on charges of robbing and sexually assaulting a cabdriver at knife point faces additional charges that he and his girlfriend plotted to kill the driver to keep her from testifying, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Dear New Jersey: No More Excuses
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Commissioner's Support
description: Days after critics called for firing Fire Commissioner James T. Joyce of Chicago, Mayor Richard M. Daley said he was happy with Mr. Joyce's work and did not plan to oust him. Mr. Joyce said last week that he would not change how the Fire Department fought the office tower fire on Oct. 17 that killed six people. Critics say Mr. Joyce effectively faulted the six victims, who were trapped in a locked, smoke-filled staircase. Mr. Joyce apologized to victims' families on Monday and said he would continue to review the department's response to the fire. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Microsoft Settles 6 More Suits

title: Despite Last-Minute Appeal, Tories Force Leader to Quit
description: LONDON, Oct. 29  Despite a last-minute appeal for support, Iain Duncan Smith, the leader of Britain's parliamentary opposition, lost a confidence vote within his party and offered his resignation tonight, plunging the fractured Conservatives into maneuvering over their leadership.

title: A Piece Reveals Its Beauty Hour After Hour After . . .

The Flux Quartet, which had played Morton Feldman's String Quartet No. 2 in 1999 at 6 hours 15 minutes, hustled through it on Saturday in a mere 5 hours 54 minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CALABRESI, PAUL
description: CALABRESI--Paul, 73, of Barrington, RI, died peacefully on October 25, 2003 after a courageous battle with cancer, the disease of which he cured so many. He was Professor of Medicine and Chairman Emeritus of the Brown University Department of Medicine and the First Chairman of the National Cancer Advisory Board. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, Celia, three children, Steven, Janice and Peter, eight grandchildren and a brother, Guido. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, November 1 at 10:30am in the First Unitarian Church of Providence, 1 Benevolent St, Providence. Memorial contributions may be made to the Calabresi Professorship at Rhode Island Hospital Foundation to support an endowed chair at Brown University, c/o Lifespan Development Office, PO Box H, Providence, RI 02901 or to the Yale Cancer Center, Paul Calabresi Lectureship, Office of Medical Development, PO Box 7611, New Haven, CT 06519-1714.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Syracuse: Carrier Rejects Jobs Plan
description: The Carrier Corporation yesterday rejected a $210 million package of state, federal and union assistance intended to keep Carrier from moving 1,200 manufacturing jobs out of the state and overseas. The package included wage cuts and other savings offered by one of its unions. Carrier officials said the aid package did not deal with the company's economic realities. On Oct. 6, Carrier said it would close the two plants at its East Syracuse site and move them to Georgia, Singapore and China. About 1,600 Carrier jobs remain in the area. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCOTT, GEORGE C.
description: SCOTT--George C., former Vice Chairman of Citibank, N.A. and Chairman of the Credit Committee, passed away at his home in Locust, New Jersey at the age of 95. He had a full and varied life, which he shared with his beloved wife of 64 years, Jane Chadbourne Scott. He was born in Brooklyn, New York in 1908, the son of George C. Scott Sr., President of the U.S. Steel Corporation, and Ruth Spencer Scott whose father was Corwin Spencer, President of the Saint Louis World's Fair Committee. George Scott was one of three children. His two brothers, Corwin and David, predeceased him. He graduated from The Principia Upper School in Saint Louis in 1927 and attended Principia College. George Scott started work at Citibank (then The National City Bank of New York) in 1929 as a messenger in the Foreign Tellers Department. He ws promoted to the Correspondent Desk and then to the Comptroller's department where he worked as an auditor. He was assigned to the Foreign Inspection Staff where he audited the foreign branches of Citibank for five years. In 1935 he married Jane Chadbourne whom he had known since childhood. He was then assigned to a domestic district to develop business for the bank. The Domestic Loan Desk was his next assignment and then he moved to cover the Southwest. He was in Dallas when he heard the news of the bombing of Pearl Harbor and immediately returned to enlist. He was made an officer in the Navy and, having a private pilot's license, was assigned to Squadron 7, an OS2U Sea Plane Operation based in Pensacola. In 1944 he was transferred to Washington, D.C. to work in the Office of Procurement and Material making Victory and Termination loans to manufacturers enabling them to change over from the production of military goods to civilian goods. With the end of World War II, he returned to Citibank and was promoted to Assistant Vice President, then Vice President heading the Southwestern District. After a few years he took charge of all activities west of the Mississippi River. Later he transferred to the Overseas Division and handled all foreign credit activities. Under George Moore, Chairman of Citibank, he was asked to assume the responsibilities of Credit Policy Chairmanship. When asked why-George Moore replied that he did not want a ''yes'' man and that George Scott was the only person he knew who would tell him if he were wrong. When George Moore retired, Walter Wriston became Chief Executive Officer promoting George Scott to Vice Chairman and asking him to continue supervising all Citibank credit activity. During his years in Credit Policy, he and his wife visited most of the countries where the bank had activities. Some years after George Scott's retirement, Walter Wriston was questioned as to how Citibank had gotten into their current bad loan situation. His reply was that George Scott was no longer there. George Scott served on the Board of Directors of Citibank, N.A., Dresser Industries in Dallas, and an American subsidiary of Siemens in Munich, Germany. He was Chairman of the Consumer Credit Counseling Service founded to help people with financial difficulties. In addition to his business life, George Scott had numerous interests. He flew his own single engine plane holding both instrument and water ratings. He owned a variety of sailboats during his lifetime and greatly enjoyed sailing and cruising. He was a past president of the Seabright Lawn and Tennis Club, a current member of the Seabright Beach Club, and a past Director and current member of the Rumson Country Club where he recently won the Club Senior golf championship. He delighted in playing the piano and the concertina. He was a member of both the First Church of Christ Scientist in Boston, MA and its local branch in Keyport, NJ. Two nieces, Nancy Mills Crabbe and Nancy Scott Cameron, four grandnieces, two grandnephews, nine great grandnieces, and one great grandnephew survive him. He was a consummate gentleman, a role model for many, and will be deeply missed. Funeral services are private and at the convenience of the family. For information Posten's Funeral Home, Atlantic Highlands, NJ

description: When the Kmart Corporation, struggling to come out of bankruptcy protection, announced in early January that it was closing 316 stores nationwide, the move came less than a year after a decision to close 283 stores.

description: A subheading in Business Day yesterday with the Market Place column, about the performance of America Online, referred incorrectly to its profitability. While its revenue has dropped, it has consistently turned a profit; it is not losing money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFMAN, STEVEN
description: HOFFMAN--Steven. Beloved son of Linda and Bernie, dear brother of Robby. Personal manager in the music industry. Worked with such artists as Van Halen, Rush, Wilson Philips, the Tea Party and Extreme. You were an inspiration to us all and we will miss you.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: WOLFGANG PUCK, right, whose Los Angeles-area phenomena Spago and Chinois now have branches in places like Chicago and Las Vegas, has opened his first outpost in the Northeast: WOLFGANG PUCK EXPRESS, a bright, casual spot in Hoboken, N.J. Why Hoboken? The space, a block from Hoboken Terminal in the Waterfront Corporate Center, 100 Sinatra Drive (First Street), was immediately available and has a splendid view of Manhattan. The restaurant, one of a chain of 28, has a pizza bar as well as tables and booths. Prices range from $4.50 to $13.95 for dishes like squash soup, Chinois chicken salad and smoked salmon pizza.

title: To Perk Up Pasta, A Jolt of Espresso
description: FROM pasta puttanesca (a quick and spicy dish purportedly created by busy prostitutes in Naples) to gnocchi strozapreti (''priest stranglers,'' said to satisfy even the most voracious vicar), it seems that no Italian dish lacks a historical context.

title: Bookseller of Kabul v. Journalist of Oslo; A Host Is Surprised by His Guest's Account of the Condition of Afghan Women
description: For almost a year after Asne Seierstad, a Norwegian journalist, published ''The Bookseller of Kabul,'' her unblinking account of the inner workings of an Afghan family, she was the toast of the Scandinavian publishing world. With 220,000 copies sold to date in Norway alone, her book is the country's biggest nonfiction best seller ever. And it has done almost as well in Sweden and Denmark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ASH, HIRAM NEWTON
description: ASH--Hiram Newton. Died Monday, October 20, at home in Colebrook, CT, after a long battle with cancer. He was 68. A memorial service will be held at the Church of Christ Congregational in Norfolk, CT, on November 8, 2003 at 3:00 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TEMCHIN, JACK
description: TEMCHIN -- Jack. Beloved son of Mira Sommerstein Temchin and the late Michael Temchin, brother of Shelley Temchin, brother-inlaw of Tom Parker, uncle of Mark and Teddy Parker, cousin of Lea Kutchin Rabinowitz and Henry Temchin, died suddenly on Sunday October 26. Co-founder and producer of The Play Company, he was producer of the film ''Home Movies'' and actively involved in all aspects of theater as a writer, producer, dramaturg, director, literary consultant, and editor of collections of monologues and scenes. He worked, among others, with The American Jewish Theatre, the Manhattan Theater Club, and for several years produced the repertory season of the New School University's Actors Studio Drama School, and was the creator of many original productions. Services will be held Thursday, 11:30 AM at the ''Riverside'' 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: A New Globalism, Starting in Morocco
description: DJANGO got off to a bad start when it opened a year and a half ago. Its catchy name suggested no cuisine in particular, and the menu did not do much to clear things up. The restaurant served uninspired, overly polite global bistro cuisine in a blandly agreeable setting. There was not a lot to find fault with, and not a lot to love, either. This wasn't jazz, it was Muzak.

title: Winner of the Pick Six May Now Go to a Track
description: With three former Drexel University fraternity brothers in prison because of their involvement in last year's Breeders' Cup scandal, it can be said that crime doesn't pay when it comes to the pick six. But a nice run of luck, combined with ingenuity, intuition and savvy handicapping, can.

description: A black, burned patch of asphalt marks the spot where Ashleigh Roach died in her car in a whipping storm of fire, less than 200 feet from the front gate of her home.

title: Yanks Meet And Discuss Torre's Staff
description: George Steinbrenner met with General Manager Brian Cashman, Manager Joe Torre and other executives of the Yankees yesterday at Malio's, the restaurant near the team's training complex in Tampa, Fla.

title: As Trustees Waver, Choice to Lead University Vows a Fight
description: Daniel S. Goldin, a former NASA administrator, is determined to become the next president of Boston University. And if the trustees who voted unanimously to hire him have had a change of heart, he will not back down without a fight.

title: U.S. Naval Academy Demotes Professor Over Copied Work
description: The United States Naval Academy yesterday demoted a history professor whose book on the creation of the atomic bomb contained dozens of uncredited passages identical or nearly identical to those in the works of at least four other authors.

title: Under the Tuscan Sun, Changing the Rules
description: WINES can be divided into any number of categories -- that's part of the fun of tasting. Are they conceptual wines that appeal to the head, or soulful wines that go straight to the heart? Are they earthy wines that speak of their soil and region, or are they airy wines that can transport you anywhere? Are they, as the writer Jay McInerney once asked, Lennon wines or McCartney wines?

title: New Appointments for 2 Editors at Times
description: Glenn Kramon, who has been the business editor of The New York Times since 1997, has been appointed associate managing editor for career development, a newly created post. William E. Schmidt, associate managing editor for personnel and newsroom administration since 1997, has been named associate managing editor for resources and planning.

title: Holocaust Legacy: Germans and Jews Debate Redemption
description: It might seem obvious, at first glance anyway, that a German affiliate of a company that once supplied poison gas to the Nazis should not be a subcontractor for the very memorial now being constructed in Berlin to the Nazis' many millions of victims.

title: Mutual Fund Accused of Fraud In Rapid Trading by Managers
description: Federal and state securities regulators filed civil lawsuits yesterday against Putnam Investments and two of its former fund managers, accusing them of fraud. They are the first lawsuits against a mutual fund company and some of its executives produced by a widening investigation into the trading of fund shares.

title: Waiting for the Apocalypse
description: It is dark here today, the generous golden sun of the Golden State reduced to a pink gumball hanging powerlessly over the treetops. Indoors, the house is a wash of strange, muted colors, the floors glowing red, the kitchen countertops thinly painted in the hue of vin rouge. Outside, the birds are holding their breath as fine threads of white ash roll down out of the sky and the distant thunder of aircraft rumbles through the leaves.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: RealNetworks Music Subscribers Up 46%
description: Online subscription music services from RealNetworks have 250,000 paying subscribers, the company said yesterday. That number, announced as part of the company's earnings statement for the third quarter, is a 46 percent increase over membership in the previous quarter. The company's two on-demand music services, Rhapsody and RealOne RadioPass, differ from services like Apple Computer's iTunes, which sell music for downloading. Instead, customers can listen to an unlimited number of songs without recording them for a $10 monthly fee. Robert Glaser, the company's chief executive, said RealNetworks would also start an  la carte digital download store later this year. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Now, Standardized Achievement Tests in Head Start
description: The new federal emphasis on accountability in education reached Nate Kidder recently in the form of his first standardized achievement test. Nate is 4 years old.

title: Putin's Old-Style K.G.B. Tactics
description: After laboring to project the image of a rational, law-abiding statesman, President Vladimir Putin of Russia has reverted to the vengeful violence of his old employer, the K.G.B. No longer willing to pursue Russia's most prominent tycoon through the courts, Mr. Putin sent masked agents to seize the business magnate, Mikhail Khodorkovsky, aboard his airplane and threw him into the notorious Matrosskaya Tishina jail, where he will stay at least through the end of the year.

title: A 'Touchdown' Teaches a Lesson for Life
description: On a recent Saturday morning, on the home football field of the Somers Middle School here, in this quiet town about an hour's drive north of New York City, the coach of the Somers team of primarily seventh graders called a play to begin the second quarter. He had alerted the opponents, John Jay Middle School, as well.

title: Private Banking: Hot talent heads for hedge funds
description: PARIS  For investors disenchanted with the equities market, and for money managers with bold ambitions, hedge funds are the current fashion.

title: Ex-Officer Indicted in Fatal Toss of Radio
description: Just one day shy of the five-year statute of limitations, a federal grand jury filed a civil rights indictment yesterday against a former New York City police officer who threw his radio and hit a fleeing suspect in the head, leading to his death.

title: Game Played in Tempe; Thoughts Were Elsewhere
description: Players on the San Diego Chargers and the Miami Dolphins tried their best to overlook the extraordinary setting of their nationally televised N.F.L. game Monday night.

title: Officer Describes Order to Use Mace in Fatal Police Shooting
description: A police sergeant ordered an officer to spray Mace at Gidone Busch before he had hit any officers with his hammer, according to the officer's videotaped testimony. The tape was played for jurors yesterday at the civil trial focusing on the fatal police shooting of Mr. Busch in 1999.

title: Survivors of war camp lament Italy's amnesia
description: RAB, Croatia:  Metod Milac says he remembers October on this wind-swept island because the nights turned cold and disease spread more quickly.

title: The Big Bet: A Restaurant Unreels
description: THREE years ago, John McCormick and Billy Phelps set out to open a restaurant, a business with a painfully high failure rate. They had no cooking experience and no restaurant experience. They just barely had an idea. Mr. McCormick was riding his motorcycle through a seedy neighborhood in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, one day when he saw the spot: on a street corner under the elevated line was a worn-down, graffiti-ridden building in the shape of a slice of cake. Moto, named after the owners' passions for motorcycles, was conceived.

title: City to Use Private Funds In Creating Charter Schools
description: New York City education officials plan to turn the charter school concept on its head by becoming the first school district in the nation to use private donations to open as many as 50 of the schools.
