description: Time: 45 minutes

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Drug Company Profit Up 31%
description: Biogen, the biotechnology company that agreed to merge with the Idec Pharmaceuticals Corporation, reported yesterday that profit rose 31 percent in the third quarter as more doctors prescribed its Avonex medicine for multiple sclerosis. Net income climbed to $55.2 million, or 36 cents a share, from $42.2 million, or 28 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue increased 19 percent, to $341.8 million from $288.3 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected a profit of 43 cents a share, on average.

title: MONSTER POSTS A LOSS ON DECLINE IN SALES
description: Monster Worldwide, the employment-advertising company, said yesterday that third-quarter profit fell 13 percent as sales declined at its division that places recruitment ads in newspapers. The shares fell as much as 14 percent after the announcement. Net income dropped to $12.2 million, or 11 cents a share, from $14 million, or 12 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue fell 2.9 percent to $173.7 million.

title: Weapons Searchers May Switch to Security
description: The Bush administration is weighing whether to shift scarce intelligence resources in Iraq away from the search for unconventional weapons in order to bolster counterinsurgency efforts, American officials said on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINKOWSKY, RAYMOND
description: MINKOWSKY -- Raymond, M.D. Of White Plains, NY. Loving husband of Estelle and devoted brother of Alex and Bill. A compassionate physician who trained at the Sorbonne in Paris then in his 40's. Survived by his stepsons, Ross and Henry Kazer. May he find peace.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia Color-Screen Phones
description: Nokia, the world's largest maker of cellphones, said yesterday that it planned to ship 100 million phones with color screens next year after introducing 35 new models this year. The phones will also be able to send and receive picture messages, Nokia executives said at a news conference in Nice, France. Nokia also unveiled five new phones at the event. Nokia, which is based in Espoo, Finland, also said it planned to start selling its first folding phone next year.

title: Car Sticker Prices Mask Some Big Bargains
description: There is an adage in the auto industry that says if you want the best deal on a car, you wait until the last month of the model year. But last month, the end of the 2003 model year, there were bargains beyond belief.

title: BellSouth Said to Halt Talks With AT&T
description: BellSouth called off preliminary merger talks with the AT&T Corporation late yesterday, executives close to the talks said.

title: Halloween Treats For Little Souls
description: Perhaps because Halloween is on Friday, ushering in a weekend and making partying a little easier, restaurants all over New York City are celebrating the occasion with special menus, costume contests and the like. Most of the festivities are for adult trick-or-treaters, but on Friday, Michael Sullivan, the chef at Le Zinc, 139 Duane Street (West Broadway), will provide cupcakes and caramel apples for little ghosts and witches to decorate, free of charge, starting at 3 p.m. (His children, Lucy and Owen, practice above.)

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 353 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: A Growing Number Of Video Viewers Watch From Crib
description: Half an hour before bedtime, John Hill-Edgar is in his blue bouncy chair, watching the ''Baby Bach'' DVD, riveted by the sound of ''Jesu, Joy of Man's Desiring'' and the pictures of a toy train, a baby, a bubble-blowing toy bear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AXELROD, PETER GILMAN
description: AXELROD -- Peter Gilman. On October 26. Beloved husband of Sari Scheer, loving father to Eric and William, cherished son to Edith Axelrod and brother to Laurie Lowenberger. He passed away at the family home in East Hampton at the age of 57. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. He was a special soul. Funeral service Wednesday, October 29, 11:45 AM at The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Foreigners' Jobs In Peril
description: Kenya's labor minister said the government would not renew the work permits for about 16,000 foreigners, mostly Europeans, in an attempt to provide positions for the more than 2 million jobless Kenyans. ''I believe that there are enough qualified Kenyans, who are currently languishing in poverty yet they can earn a living by taking up those jobs,'' the minister, Ali Mwakwere, told Agence France-Presse. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Friday about political protests in Saudi Arabia misidentified the London-based Saudi dissident group that instigated them. It is the Movement for Islamic Reform in Arabia. (Saad al-Fagih is the name of the group's leader, a member of a prominent Saudi family.)

title: Most Smiles? Dachshunds, Paws Down!
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about partisan rancor on the Senate Judiciary Committee referred incorrectly to the status of President Bush's nomination of Janice Rogers Brown to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The committee is expected to vote on the nomination next week; it has not already voted.

title: Corrections
description: The Wine Talk column last Wednesday referred incorrectly to several California wines blended from the grape varieties used in Bordeaux. Insignia, Rubicon and Dominus are made according to the rules of the Meritage Association, whose members create high-quality blends using those grapes. But their makers are not members of the association.

title: Fried Rice Skips To the Dinner Table
description: TO the list of dishes better prepared at home than elsewhere, please add fried rice. This afterthought of Chinese restaurants is almost as easily varied as pasta, and has one distinct advantage: It can be made with leftover rice.

title: Sightings of Car Emerge as Central Evidence in Sniper Case
description: Karl Largie was standing in the parking lot of a Washington restaurant one evening last fall when he heard a loud bang. A minute or two later, he testified on Tuesday, he noticed a Chevrolet Caprice pull away from a nearby curb and slip into the night with its lights off.

title: Iowans' Savvy Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WASHINGTON, WALTER E.
description: WASHINGTON -- Walter E. The NYC Housing Authority mourns the passing of Walter E. Washington. He was the tenth Chairman of NYCHA, the nation's largest public housing authority, from 1966-1967 and the first African-American to serve in that capacity. He was a great pioneer in urban social progress who understood the complex problems of our cities. He will be deeply missed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a dispute over the liquor license for Schiller's Liquor Bar, a new bistro on the Lower East Side owned by Keith McNally, misstated his relationship to the restaurant Odeon. He is a former owner, not a current one.

title: A Right to Health Care?
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Jazz Into Strange (90 Minute) Territory
description: Like many other young lions of New Orleans jazz, the trumpeter Irvin Mayfield began playing in public before he was even in his teens. As he matured, he developed both a polished trumpet style and a wide-ranging musical imagination. In recent years he has caught the attention of the wider world with tours and recordings, some with his modern-jazz sextet and others with his acclaimed Latin-based band, Los Hombres Calientes.

title: Russian Stock Markets Regain Some Losses
description: The Russian stock markets recovered somewhat on Tuesday from a plummet that followed the arrest of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the head of the oil giant Yukos and the country's wealthiest citizen, on charges of tax evasion, fraud and forgery.

title: Bush on Right to Die
description: President Bush said he thought his brother Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida had acted correctly in ordering that a brain-damaged woman be put back on a feeding tube. Page A23.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Briton Dies In Train Station Accident
description: An escalator at the Tiburtina train station collapsed, killing a British woman and injuring three other people. Witnesses said that a portion of the escalator gave way under the 63-year-old woman and that she fell onto the moving gears and was crushed. A man who tried to rescue her became caught in the machinery and suffered serious leg injuries. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Ernie Calverley, 79, College Basketball Player
description: Ernie Calverley, a basketball star at Rhode Island State who was remembered for a 62-foot game-tying shot in the 1946 National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden, died Oct. 20 at a hospital in Providence, R.I. Calverley, who lived in Wakefield, R.I., was 79.

title: A Gathering of Stars From Many Firmaments Glitter for One Night
description: Dancing stars from the realms of film, theater and ballet filled the City Center stage on Monday night when Career Transition for Dancers presented ''Gotta Dance! A Dance Tribute to Hollywood,'' its ninth annual gala.

title: No on the Mayor's Election Plan
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg says there's a lot wrong with New York City politics. The system of choosing judges is corrupt. Party bosses hold too much sway. Getting a place on a ballot is tough, and staying on even tougher if a party organization wants a candidate off. Voter turnout is pathetically low. Mr. Bloomberg is right that there is a problem. Unfortunately, his solution is off the mark.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Years From Now, Scholars Will Peruse Us

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEMEO, JAMES J.
description: DeMEO--James J. on October 25, 2003, of Maplewood, NJ. Beloved husband of Carol Zipse. Also survived by three children & three grandchildren. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Sorrows Church, S. Orange, NJ., on Saturday, November 1st at 10:30am. Interment St. Stephen's Cemetery, Millburn, NJ. Visitation will be held at the Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, Maplewood, NJ on Friday, 2-4 and 7-9pm.

title: Arab World Is of Two Minds About U.S. Involvement in Iraq
description: The bright red headline across four columns in an Egyptian government-owned newspaper, Al Gumhuria, on Tuesday trumpeted the latest bombings in Iraq as somehow religiously sanctioned: ''Five Consecutive Martyrdom Operations Rock Baghdad.''

title: Duquette Has Job; Now Comes the Hard Part
description: Jim Duquette smiled. He joked. He told stories, including one about his mother. When Fred Wilpon, the Mets' principal owner, called to tell her he was removing the interim tag from Duquette's role as general manager, she thought it was a prank.

title: MGM POSTS A $32.6 MILLION LOSS IN QUARTER
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer yesterday posted a $32.6 million loss in the third quarter, in contrast to a profit a year earlier, because of higher marketing costs at its film business. The net loss of 13 cents a share was in contrast to net income of $11.7 million, or 5 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 20 percent, to $457.1 million, MGM said. The film business was less profitable because the company recorded marketing expenses for two films, ''Out of Time'' and ''Good Boy,'' that did not generate ticket sales until after the quarter ended.

title: Online Music Business, Neither Quick Nor Sure
description: In the last decade a new record business has been forming online. It has been coalescing by trial and error, largely error. And its evolution is in no way complete as it moves toward a finish line at the rate of one step forward for every nine-tenths of a step back.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day last Wednesday about the development of commercial property for biotechnology companies in Berkeley, Calif., misspelled the surname of a spokeswoman for Bayer HealthCare, which moved a unit into a building in the city. She is Clelia Baur, not Bauer.

title: Dear New Jersey: No More Excuses (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Friday about Chris Daly, a San Francisco supervisor who acted as mayor for a day, misstated his age. He is 31, not 28.

title: Doubt Is Cast On Accounts Of Ferry Crash
description: Two witnesses to the Staten Island ferry crash this month said they saw the ferry's assistant captain erect and alone at the controls about a minute before the vessel slammed into a pier, killing 10 people, an official briefed on the investigation said yesterday.

title: Make Way for Buffalo
description: This forlorn farm town Rawson, population 6 -- is a fine place to contemplate the boldest idea in America today: rescuing the rural Great Plains by returning much of it to a vast ''Buffalo Commons.''

title: Days of Growing Carnage in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Men and Fire
description: ''But how did someone set the fire?'' my daughters asked, horror quivering in their voices, as we watched the flames trembling inside our TV like a parody of a cozy fireplace.

title: Blast From Sun Disrupts Earths Magnetic Field
description: An exceptionally powerful blast of gas from the Sun disrupted the Earth's magnetic field today, affecting power grids and airplane radio communications but posing no danger to air travel, experts said.

title: The Aftermath of War
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Show House in a Tower
description: "Rooms With a View," a  design exhibition, is in two apartments at the Time Warner Center, high above Columbus Circle.

title: A Loft of One's Own
description: In the South Bronx, finding peace and quiet.

title: A Tailor to Two Empires
description: A selection of costumes by the designer Ngila Dickson for "The Last Samurai" and "The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King."

title: Paying the Piper, Round 2: The Repertory Grows
description: IT'S the wacky parlor game that's sweeping the country: Design That Business Model!

title: A Huge Solar Storm, but Little Impact Is Seen
description: One of the largest solar upheavals ever recorded bombarded Earth yesterday with a speeding cloud of charged particles, prompting officials in the United States and Canada to warn airline passengers and crew members that they could be exposed to abnormally high levels of radiation.

title: Ceiling's Cleaning Grows Into a Tale of Re-Creation
description: It's not quite the Sistine Chapel, but New York now has its own newly restored ceiling murals, in the lobby of the Verizon Building.

title: Nominee to Justice Department Post Vows Fair Inquiry on Leak
description: James B. Comey, the Manhattan prosecutor nominated by President Bush for the No. 2 post at the Justice Department, told lawmakers on Wednesday that he would work to ensure that the department conducted a ''fair and aggressive'' inquiry into the disclosure of a C.I.A. officer's identity.

title: Democrats Prevail in Blocking Senate Vote on Bush Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 — Senate Democrats succeeded again today in blocking the elevation of Judge Charles W. Pickering Sr. to a federal appeals court, thus prolonging a two-year drama with elements of history, race relations and bare-knuckle politics.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 15 about the debate over removing the feeding tube of a brain-damaged Florida woman, Terri Schiavo, misattributed a statement from a protester at a vigil opposing the state's right-to-die law. It was Nancy Kramer, not Carrie Kirkland, another protester, who said: "We don't even divine hanging chads in this state and yet we're divining that Terri wants to die. Floridians will take a stand so that these laws can be revisited."

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Support For Indian Peace Moves
description: Pakistani officials responded positively to a 12-point Indian proposal last week to re-establish air, rail and other links between the countries. Pakistan agreed to resume sports matches and to hold negotiations on air links. It also proposed the immediate restoration of rail links and of full staffs in each other's respective embassies. Pakistani officials said they would discuss other proposals in future talks, and called for an immediate dialogue with India over Kashmir, which the countries have fought two wars over. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Citing Economic Figures, Bush Says Tax Cuts Are Working
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 30  The White House claimed credit today for the surge in economic growth, saying the $1.7 trillion in tax cuts championed by President Bush had helped the nation overcome recession and the economic effects of the terrorist attacks, two wars and corporate scandals.

title: Sports of The Times; LeBron Carnival Makes Its Debut
description: THE executive caregivers of the National Basketball Association fret over the immaturity of teenagers who arrive swathed in blue blankets on their doorstep without so much as a college kegger for a life experience, yet they have become playground pushers of LeBron James.

title: Still Lovely Aalto Table Is Delightful to Know
description: Artek, the Finnish manufacturer of furniture by Alvar Aalto, has reintroduced a rare Aalto coffee table from 1933. Herman Miller is importing the tables, which Artek has not produced since the 1940's. The legs are bent with the same technique used in making Aalto stools. A thin magazine shelf is suspended from the legs, but appears to float. Model 907B, above, is 29 1/2 inches wide and about 22 inches high. In a honey finish birch, which mimics the patina of vintage Aalto pieces, it is $1,095 and is scheduled to arrive in December at FinnStyle in Minneapolis; (866) 346-6474 or www.finnstyle

title: Steve Levy for Suffolk County Executive
description: Perhaps the most important office at stake in Tuesday's elections is that of Suffolk County executive. Steve Levy, a Democratic state assemblyman, and Edward Romaine, a Republican who is the county clerk, are battling to succeed Robert Gaffney, a Republican. For the winner, there will be no shortage of urgent issues to attend to, including land preservation and budget problems. There is also the matter of electorate ennui from a string of public scandals and investigations.

title: Hints in Russia of Crisis Over Tycoon Case
description: Reports that President Vladimir V. Putin's powerful chief of staff resigned in protest over the arrest of the country's richest businessman heightened concern on Wednesday that the Kremlin had gone a step too far in cracking down on him and his oil company, risking capital flight and political instability.

title: Ex-Executive With Lipper Is Indicted
description: Edward J. Strafaci, a former executive of Lipper Holdings, was indicted yesterday for overstating by millions of dollars the values of two hedge funds he ran. At the same time, the Securities and Exchange Commission brought civil fraud charges against Mr. Strafaci for the same reason.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: Ghana: Bid For Miner Endorsed
description: The Ghanaian government said Tuesday that it would back AngloGold's $1.48 billion bid for the Ghanian gold mining company Ashanti. The decision ends a heated battle for Ashanti between AngloGold and Randgold Resources, a smaller company that offered a higher bid. The Ghanaian government said it backed AngloGold because of the company's greater experience and history of paying high dividends.

title: Fighting Fire With Steel, Pools And Plaster
description: The forecourt of Madeline and Edward A. Landry's new house -- on 134 acres with a 180-degree view of Rocky Peak State Park -- became a command post last weekend for firefighters combatting the Simi Valley inferno raging just north of the Los Angeles County line. With his binoculars, a fire captain was picking out fires on the hills, and planes were bombing them with water. ''Most of the time the pilots were hitting their mark,'' Ms. Landry said on Tuesday, recalling the scene. ''There were so many planes in the air, it was like a battle.''

title: She Hears From Murder Victims And Goes Back in Time to Help
description: Having stretched the limits of science, police dramas this season are exploring forensic mysticism. The heroine of ''Joan of Arcadia'' on CBS gets clues from God. Fox's new series ''Tru Calling,'' which begins tonight, introduces yet another twist on crime-solving: murdered souls ask Tru Davies (Eliza Dushku) for help, and she redresses the wrongs against them by reliving the 24 hours leading up to their deaths.

title: Postwar G.I. Death Toll Exceeds Wartime Total
description: American military casualties spiked Tuesday night into Wednesday with a new round of mortar attacks, roadside bombs and shootings that left four soldiers dead and more wounded.

title: Specs: Vintages, Room by Room
description: FOR the home of Tom Viertel and Pat Daily, Patrick Gallagher created a period beach-house ambience, the period being the 1950's and 60's. The sofa in the study is upholstered with a cuddly yellow Yorke Chenille; to the trade, $73 a yard from Brunschwig & Fils, (212) 838-7878. The 1940's yellow kitchen dinette set was $395 at Carousel Antique Center, Hudson, N.Y., (518) 828-9127. Mark King, an artist in Stonington, Conn., hand stenciled the wood floor in blocks of blue-violet and cream for $2,500; he charges $20 to $100 a square foot; (860) 535-3857. The Northstar 1950 Retro refrigerator is new; $2,795 at Preston Trading Post, Preston, Conn., (860) 886-1484. The 1940's stove is $6,900 at Antique Stove Heaven, Los Angeles, (323) 298-5581.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: UNITED AIRLINES PARENT ASKS TO PAY IN TAX AMNESTY
description: The parent of United Airlines, the UAL Corporation, has asked a bankruptcy judge to permit the payment of overdue income taxes to Illinois under an amnesty program that may save the company $1 million in interest. UAL filed an emergency motion on Tuesday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Chicago seeking permission to pay taxes that were due as long ago as 1986. The amnesty program lets taxpayers who pay before Nov. 17 avoid interest and penalties, which double after the deadline. Judge Eugene R. Wedoff will consider the motion at a hearing tomorrow. UAL is trying to complete its bankruptcy reorganization by the middle of next year.

title: Squinting at the Fine Print? A Lens to Ease Your Eyestrain
description: Add a few accessories like a modem, a keyboard and a word-processing program to a personal organizer, and it can do nearly everything a laptop can, while being much lighter to haul. Most organizers' screens are too tiny to be read comfortably for long periods, but the Magnifico Portable PDA Screen Magnifier from Officeonthegogo helps take eyestrain out of the equation.

title: Corrections
description: The Critic's Choice column on Monday, about new CD's, misstated the issue year of ''Mono'' by Paul Westerberg, who has two new releases. It was 2002, not 2001. The column also referred incorrectly to the song ''Take Out Some Insurance.'' It is by Charles Singleton and Waldenese Hall; it is not an example of Mr. Westerberg's verbal flair.

title: Economic Scene; Europe is shooting itself in the foot, but not for the officially accepted reasons.
description: WHAT is causing the slow economic growth and high unemployment in Europe?

title: This Time, Actually Helping Voters; Remedial Class Tries to Improve Poll Workers' Performance
description: ''Ben lives at 340 Ocean Parkway. Where does Ben vote?''

title: Europe Proposes Overhaul of Chemical Industry
description: The European Commission on Wednesday announced plans for a sweeping overhaul of Europe's chemical industry that it said would weed out health risks in everything from carpets to laundry detergents.

title: Glendale, Phoenix Suburb, Is Awarded Super Bowl for 2008
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 30  The National Football League today awarded the 2008 Super Bowl to Glendale, Ariz., after a vote by league owners at their meetings here.

title: Jack and Jane Meador, Figures in Stolen Wartime Art Case
description: Jack Meador, a Texas hardware salesman who became a central figure in a scheme to sell medieval art treasures stolen from a German cathedral in World War II, died on May 25 in Sherman, Tex., unnoticed by the art world he had tried to deceive. He was 83.

title: An Epitaph for Madame Chiang Kai-shek: 'Mama'
description: For half a century, she was a flinty symbol of a political dream, the reunification of Taiwan and China under a non-Communist government.

title: What's Right With This Picture?
description: THE best payment I ever got for writing a magazine article was a photograph.

title: Latin America Needs Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Cars section on Oct. 22 about Saturn's efforts to tap into the market for customized cars misstated the name of a trade association of companies that sell parts used for them. It is the Specialty Equipment Market Association, not Manufacturers Association.

title: A Shutterbug's Guide to Meting Out the Megapixels
description: THE more megapixels the merrier -- or so you'd gather from digital camera prices. The higher the number of megapixels, the more expensive the camera will be in comparison with others with similar features. But what are megapixels? How many do you need? Is more always better?

title: McGrady Saved Best For Last
description: Before last night's game against the Knicks, Magic guard Tracy McGrady said that with Latrell Sprewell gone, there was no player on the Knicks who could match up with him. For 47 minutes, Knicks Coach Don Chaney's defensive scheme made it look as if McGrady might have to eat his words.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, BERNICE
description: BERNSTEIN -- Bernice. We mourn the loss of the mother of Ilene, Marlene and Jo Ann. A dedicated woman whose home was open to all. We will miss you. Malcolm, George and Ted Davis

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Judy Hendren Mello, former president and chief executive of the First Women's Bank in Manhattan, misstated the day of her death. It was last Tuesday, not Oct. 20.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: A Dogwood Look-Alike

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Backs Drug Petition
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a petition yesterday circulated by Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois calling on the federal government to allow cities and states to import less expensive prescription drugs from Canada. At a news conference in City Hall with Governor Blagojevich, Mr. Bloomberg said that importing the drugs could save the city $108 million a year on Medicaid costs alone. The drug maker Pfizer said it was disappointed by the mayor's action.

title: The N.B.A. Expands Its Game And Makes a House Call to Japan
description: There is something about Allen Iverson, the Philadelphia 76ers guard, that gets Tadashi Togashi and his friends going. They like Iverson's up-tempo style, and how he finds a way to score even though he is often the shortest man on the court. It does not hurt that his team is a perennial playoff contender in the National Basketball Association.

title: Cart 54, Where Are You? The Tracking System Knows
description: ''LOCATION, location, location'' is no longer a truism limited to real estate agents: it has become the mantra of a growing number of wireless companies as they seek new ways to track people and things.

title: After Sticker Shock, Just Scrape It Off
description: The teapot you bought is lovely -- if you could only scratch off the price sticker. Now a solvent called Goo Gone comes with a plastic implement that easily lifts stickers off. It costs $5.49 at Gracious Home, 1220 Third Avenue (70th Street) and 1992 Broadway (68th Street), or online at www.magicamerican.com for stores all over the country. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Finding Elegance and Power In a Dozen Years of Romance
description: The Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes, now 33, has become one of the more eloquent interpreters of the younger generation of pianists. One might wish he spent more time looking beyond the 19th century -- as he did in his early years -- yet there is something seductive in the balance of elegance and power that he brings to the Romantic repertory.

title: The Way to Answer Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Selection for Salt Lake Trial Continues
description: The jury selection process in the federal trial of Tom Welch and Dave Johnson, bidders for the 2002 Salt Lake Olympics, continued with interviews in closed chambers yesterday. It will conclude today, when a jury of 14 Utah residents will be seated in United States District Court in Salt Lake City. Opening statements in the trial are scheduled for tomorrow morning. Lex Hemphill

title: N.F.L. to Impose Old Penalties For New Steroid
description: The National Football League management council said Wednesday that players who test positive for tetrahydrogestrinone, a newly detected steroid known as THG, will face the same penalty as those who use other anabolic steroids, even if the players claim they used it mistakenly.

title: CORINTHIAN FORECASTS 52% REVENUE INCREASE
description: Corinthian Colleges, which operates 79 colleges in the United States, estimated yesterday that fiscal 2004 revenue would increase 52 percent after first-quarter profit reached a record $19.4 million. Corinthian Colleges had revenue of $517.3 million in the year ended June 30. In the first quarter, which ended Sept. 30, net income rose 41 percent to $19.4 million, or 41 cents a share, from $13.7 million, or 30 cents a share, a year earlier, Corinthian said. Corinthian had 57,580 students at the end of the first quarter. Corinthian said first-quarter revenue increased 26 percent at schools it has owned and operated at least a year.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Report On Capital Cases
description: Despite a state law guaranteeing adequate legal representation, indigent defendants in capital cases are not likely to receive it, a study by two nonprofit groups has found. The Equal Justice Center and the Texas Defender Service said a study of murder trials in 33 counties that produce almost 90 percent of death sentences in Texas revealed that only two counties had complied with a 2001 law requiring experienced lawyers and adequate trial resources. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Miner's Profit Falls
description: The world's biggest mining company, BHP Billiton, said first-quarter profit fell 6.3 percent as gains by Australian and South African currencies increased costs and erased gains from rising demand for metals like aluminum. Net income fell to $518 million, or 8 cents a share, in the three months ended Sept. 30, from $553 million, or 9 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 23 percent to $4.83 billion, BHP said.

title: Pension Funds Weighing Putnam's Role
description: The Massachusetts state treasurer, Timothy Cahill, will recommend today that the state pension board fire Putnam Investments as manager of $1.7 billion of $29 billion the state has set aside for its public employees' retirement benefits, a spokeswoman for the treasurer's office said.

title: CORPORATE PLEA FOR TAX BREAKS: OURS COME FIRST
description: It has been promoted as a bill to create jobs, to enhance American competitiveness and to level the playing field for companies overseas.

title: A Musical, A Lawsuit And a Lot Of Pressure
description: It has been nearly 18 months since Rosie O'Donnell left television, shutting down her popular talk show and retreating to her Nyack, N.Y., home to ''retire'' and recapture her personal life, at the ripe old age of 41.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 2 Convicted In Parliament Attack Freed
description: Citing insufficient evidence, the New Delhi High Court overturned the convictions and death sentences of a Delhi University lecturer, S. A. R. Geelani, and a woman, Afsan Guru, for their roles in an attack on Parliament two years ago that killed nine people. The court upheld the death sentences for two other Kashmiri Muslims, Muhammad Afzal and Shaukat Hussain Guru. Rights groups had said the case against the professor and woman was an example of anti-Muslim treatment in Hindu-dominated India. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CORELLI, FRANCO
description: CORELLI--Franco. The Metropolitan Opera deeply mourns the passing of one of the twentieth century's greatest tenors, Franco Corelli. From the time of his Met debut in 1961, he became a favorite of New York audiences. Although he began his career in Italy, the Met became his home theater, and we were privileged to have him perform 368 times over 24 years with our company. His large, vibrant voice and his tall, strikingly handsome stage presence perfectly fit the great romantic tenor roles of Verdi and Puccini. The thrill of hearing his fullthroated tones flooding the theater became operatic legend, and rightfully so. Few singers of any era have had so loyal and devoted a following. We join in the bereavement of his admirers everywhere and extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, Loretta. Joseph Volpe General Manager James Levine Artistic Director

title: National Briefing | Washington: House Doubles Benefits
description: The House voted unanimously to double the benefit for family members of military personnel killed on duty to $12,000 and make the entire sum tax-free. The measure also made the benefit retroactive to Sept. 11, 2001, to include the spouses and children of those killed that day at the Pentagon and later in Iraq and Afghanistan. Previously, $3,000 of the $6,000 payment was subject to taxes. Carl Hulse (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Crime Figure Is Sentenced
description: Ronald Trucchio, whom prosecutors have called a captain in the Gambino crime family, was sentenced to prison yesterday for running a gambling enterprise worth $30 million a year. Justice Richard L. Buchter of State Supreme Court sentenced Mr. Trucchio, 51, to one to three years in prison. Mr. Trucchio, above, pleaded guilty in April to charges related to his role in the gambling ring. His son, Alphonse Trucchio, 25, pleaded guilty to enterprise corruption and was sentenced to one and one-half years to four and one-half years in prison. An associate, Anthony Moscatiello, was sentenced to one to three years in prison. Prosecutors said the operation was based in two apartments in Ozone Park. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Wyoming: Council Votes To Move Ten Commandments From Park
description: The Casper City Council has voted 5 to 4 to move a Ten Commandments monument from the city park after being threatened with a lawsuit by the Wisconsin-based Freedom From Religion Foundation. The council voted unanimously to reject the proposal of the Rev. Fred Phelps of Kansas for a monument stating that Matthew Shepard, a native of Casper, is in hell. Mr. Shepard, a gay college student, was beaten to death in Laramie in 1998. Mr. Phelps said a court ruling allowed monuments of all religious convictions to be displayed on city property if the Ten Commandments monument was allowed. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Economy Grew at 7.2% Rate in 3rd Quarter, Fastest Since 1984
description: The American economy expanded during the third quarter at the fastest rate since 1984, the government reported today, offering hope that the long economic malaise has finally ended.

title: CENDANT TO PAY MILLIONS TO SETTLE SALES DISPUTE
description: The Cendant Corporation's Trendwest Resorts, which operates time-share resorts in California, Asia and the Pacific Rim, will pay as much as $4.3 million to settle complaints that it misled consumers with deceptive sales practices. The attorney general of California, Bill Lockyer, said in a statement that Trendwest would pay restitution to consumers who bought time-share contracts and were illegally denied the right to cancel them. The company will also pay $795,000 in civil penalties, Mr. Lockyer said. Trendwest said it had ''reviewed, and where necessary revised, its internal policies and procedures to ensure that they meet the highest standards for our industry.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It brought me closer to God.''

title: J.C. PENNEY IS SELLING ITS STORES IN MEXICO
description: The J.C. Penney Corporation has agreed to sell its stores in Mexico to the billionaire Carlos Slim. Grupo Sanborns, a retailer controlled by Mr. Slim, will buy the six Penney stores in Mexico. Financial terms were not disclosed. But Penney said it would take a charge of $40 million while its cash flow would increase $25 million, including tax benefits. Penney, based in Plano, Tex., opened its first store in Mexico in 1995. John Moody (NYT)

title: For Sale in Oakland: 1 Room, Great View, Quiet Neighborhood, $250,000
description: It is the choice neighborhood of the dead. When Frederick Law Olmsted laid out the tree-lined boulevards of Mountain View Cemetery in 1863, he envisioned a sylvan spot in which to contemplate eternity, ''a sheltering cove extended over the place of the dead.''

title: From Dream Cars to Big Trucks, Auto Show has It All
description: I'd tell you to show up and kick some tires, but in this day of low-profile rubber that could be a hazardous endeavor resulting in broken toes. Instead, I'll advise the other option: Show up, open and shut doors, and feel-listen for solidity; sit in the cars and luxuriate in that new-car smell; and fantasize beyond your wildest dreams or depth of your checking account.

title: 250 Officers Being Rehired In Department Of Correction
description: The city's Department of Correction plans to rehire 250 of the 315 officers it laid off as part of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's $2.1 billion in budget cuts earlier this year, city officials said yesterday.

title: Met's Concerns Threaten A Lincoln Center Plan
description: The redevelopment of 65th Street was supposed to be the easy part.

title: Franco Corelli, Italian Tenor of Power and Charisma, and Pillar of the Met, Dies at 82
description: Franco Corelli, the Italian tenor whose powerhouse voice, charismatic presence and movie-star good looks earned him the adoration of opera fans from the 1950's until his retirement in 1976, died yesterday in Milan. He was 82 and lived in Milan.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Hundreds Of Migrants Land
description: Dilapidated boats carrying hundreds of illegal immigrants landed on Italy's southern coast. Coast guard officials said up to 450 immigrants started arriving on small boats to the tiny island of Lampedusa on Tuesday afternoon, and that more vessels had been sighted off shore. This latest wave of immigrants comes just more than a week after the bodies of 13 African immigrants were discovered in a rickety boat adrift at sea. Survivors on the boat said that at least 50 more bodies had been thrown overboard before their rescue. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: COUNCIL CONTESTS: 49th District, Staten Island's north shore; Staten Island Democrat Defends Tax Vote
description: Among the City Council members who came to office after the 2001 election, Michael E. McMahon has established his reputation as an expert on the city's sanitation issues and as an intensely media-friendly politician. His readiness to answer reporters' questions stands out, even by the standards of City Council members.

title: For Two Veterans, Old Wars Resonate (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: On Harlem River, Hope Floats
description: THE Peter Jay Sharp Boathouse, soon to set sail from a marina in Norwalk, Conn., is not the type of vessel normally seen in those waters. Neither is Bette Midler the usual sort of captain. But when the green and yellow boathouse, flying three colorful pennants from its hipped roof and looking like a modest but proud Victorian train station, is ceremonially towed around the Battery late next month en route to its Harlem River home at Dyckman Street, Ms. Midler will be very much in command, if only symbolically.

title: Honda Says Its Cars Will Be Among Safest
description: Honda announced on Wednesday an ambitious plan to make its vehicles among the safest on the road.

title: With Due Respect, Ms. Knoll, It Seems Kilroy Was Here
description: Eight pieces of Knoll furniture with graffiti by the fashion designer Stephen Sprouse, above, are being auctioned on eBay through Sunday. Proceeds will benefit the Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS. Mr. Sprouse and Suzanne Tick, the creative director of Knoll Textiles, are also introducing a fabric collection. Techno Tweed updates the classic Cato, designed by Florence Knoll 40 years ago, with neon tones and plastic tape ($34 a yard). Graffiti Camo is camouflage-patterned velvet with words from the Declaration of Independence ($45 a yard); (800) 343-5665 for store locations or www.knoll.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: 2 Big Fires Break Out In the Denver Region
description: Two fires broke out along the Front Range on Wednesday, forcing thousands of people to leave. The dry and windy conditions that fanned fires in California contributed to the fires here.

title: A Set-Top Box With 100 Rentable Films
description: Could renting a movie be much simpler than it already is? The Walt Disney Company is betting it could be with a new service called MovieBeam that includes a no-fuss set-top box that arrives in your home loaded with 100 DVD-quality feature films that can be rented with a press of a remote control.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER CO., Columbus, Ohio, a large utility, said it had extended a bidding deadline for 10 electricity plants in Texas.

title: The Bad News Is Good News For Democrats
description: Iraq is a mess, the world resents America and its debt-burdened economy is an international embarrassment. That was the Democratic perspective voiced at a conference that ended here on Wednesday, that things could hardly be more grim.

title: DeGregorio Awarded a Diamond Campaign
description: DeGregorio Awarded a Diamond Campaign

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRUFETA, RAYMOND A.
description: PRUFETA--Raymond A. Of East Northport, LI on October 28, 2003. Beloved husband of Maureen and loving father of John Prufeta and his wife, Patricia, Robert Prufeta and his wife, Christine, cherished grandfather of Anthony, John, Tara and Michael, dear brother of Jennie Prufeta, Vera Hayden and Rosemary Prufeta. Visiting Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Brueggemann Funeral Home, 522 Larkfield Road, East Northport. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:15 AM, at St. Anthony of Padua RC Church, East Northport. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery, Kew Gardens.

title: Senate Panel Demands C.I.A. Data Leading Up to Iraq War by Friday Noon
description: In a new clash between Congress and the Central Intelligence Agency, the Senate Intelligence Committee has demanded that the C.I.A. turn over by noon on Friday all of the documents and interviews still being sought by the panel for its inquiry into prewar intelligence on Iraq.

title: Money Pours In to Races for Seats in Trenton
description: In the final stage of the campaign, New Jersey's legislative races are drawing contributions at a record pace -- millions of dollars a week -- most of them aimed at giving Democrats control of the evenly divided State Senate.

title: Countries Rated by Cost Of Doing Business
description: Stretched by the rising cost of fighting terrorism and its large budget deficit, the United States dropped to second from first in the annual ranking of global economic competitiveness.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Flying Corpse Ties Up Traffic
description: A hearse overturned on the autobahn near Duisburg, smashing a coffin and ejecting a corpse onto the roadway, along with a bag of coffin nails, the authorities said. The undertaker, who had fallen asleep, was slightly hurt, and traffic was brought to a standstill for an hour. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: In the South Bronx, Peace and Quiet in a Loft of One's Own
description: ''I don't like to be in the center of everything,'' said Patrick Eck, 42, a cabinetmaker. ''And I need a lot of space.'' He has found both solitude and space in the South Bronx. Last month, Mr. Eck and his companion, Marketa Psenickova, left, finished renovating their 3,000-square-foot loft in a former vinegar distillery (the white building, right), a block west of the Bruckner Expressway. The rent is $1,000 a month. Next door, he and Emad Ebrahim, his partner at Inform Studio, a cabinetmaking company, share a 9,000-square-foot woodworking shop, with a monthly rent of $3,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RADER, GILBERT
description: RADER--Gilbert. The Board of Directors of Associated Health Foundation mourn the loss of our esteemed Corporate Secretary. He was a past Grand Chancellor of the Knights of Pythias and current Supreme Representative, also serving as Secretary of The Pythian Camp. His energy and wisdom will be missed. Our sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. Edward Birnbaum, President Assoc. Health Foundation

title: ANTITRUST TRIAL SET FOR FIRST DATA-CONCORD DEAL
description: The government's bid to block the First Data Corporation from acquiring Concord EFS will go to trial on Dec. 15. Judge Rosemary M.Collyer of Federal District Court in Washington set the trial date after a closed hearing on Tuesday. Judge Collyer rejected the government's proposal to start the trial on Jan. 5, granting the companies' request for a speedier timetable, according to court records. The companies said earlier that they wanted Judge Collyer to issue a final ruling in the government's antitrust case before Jan. 31, when their merger agreement expires. The Justice Department and seven states asserted that the proposed acquisition would hurt competition for debit-card services. Pennsylvania asked Judge Collyer yesterday for permission to join the case to block the deal. Concord owns the STAR network. First Data owns 64 percent of the NYCE network.

title: Little Rest for Weary Crews As Duty Calls Relentlessly
description: The toll of the fires in the mountains east of San Diego was beginning to tell on Wednesday and could be seen in the blank, weary faces of countless firefighters, some of whom have been battling the raging flames for five days or more.

title: It May Only Be October, but Its Still Devils-Flyers
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 29 — If Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur had his way, the Devils would play the Philadelphia Flyers and the other teams in the Eastern Conference 12 times each a season. Scratch games against Western Conference teams, he said.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column on Tuesday about a new museum dedicated to Picasso in Mlaga, Spain, misspelled its name. In Spanish, it is the Museo Picasso. (The Picasso museum in Barcelona, capital of the Catalonia region, bears the Catalan name Museu Picasso.)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Poor Outlook At Volkswagen
description: Profit will fall by more than half this year, Volkswagen said, as weak demand for its cars, a strong euro and the cost of eliminating jobs in Brazil cut into its third-quarter earnings. Volkswagen earned more in the three-month period from its financial services arm than it did from selling cars. Although it expects demand to pick up next year, it said business would not recover before 2005. In the third quarter, its profit fell 57 percent, to 510 million euros ($595 million).

title: Lack of Rape Charges Clarified
description: Court documents released this week show that the district attorney in Boulder decided not to file rape charges against football players involved in a sexual incident at an off-campus party at the University of Colorado two years ago because the players believed the women at the party had consented to sex.

title: Schwarzenegger Visits Washington, as Much an Idol as Governor
description: Star-struck lawmakers cozied up to him, angling for a picture. Senate pages stood in line, pens and notecards in hand, hoping for an autograph. Plainclothes police officers kept gawkers at bay.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Apple Loyalty Unrewarded?

title: Let Us Run Charter School, Teachers' Union Head Says
description: If Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein hopes to turn the concept of charter schools upside down by having the city create as many as 50 of them, the head of the teacher's union, Randi Weingarten, wants to turn Mr. Klein's plan inside out -- by having her union run one of the new charter schools.

title: Metalworkers Stage Strike At Carmakers In Brazil
description: Although their industry is facing its worst crisis in years, thousands of metalworkers in Brazil's industrial heartland downed tools on Wednesday, halting about one-third of the country's auto and truck production at plants belonging to Ford Motor, Volkswagen, DaimlerChrysler and Scania.

title: Plan for Iraq to Repay U.S. Aid Is Rejected
description: Congressional negotiators on Wednesday rejected a Senate proposal that would have required Iraq to repay billions in reconstruction aid, ending a brief rebellion against President Bush's $87 billion plan for the occupation and rebuilding of Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHENKER, PAUL
description: SCHENKER--Paul. Died October 28 in Delray Beach, FL at age 71. Beloved husband, father, brother and grandfather of nine. Attended Trinity College and Brooklyn Law School. Served as an officer in the U.S. Air Force. His memory will live on in our hearts. Memorial service Sunday, November 2nd, 11:30AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St, N.Y.C.

title: Iran Demands Concessions From U.S. in Return for Cooperation
description: Iran said Wednesday that it would not share intelligence with the United States on operatives of Al Qaeda or hand over Qaeda suspects in Iranian detention and would resume dialogue only after the United States undertakes what it termed measures to build confidence.

title: Ramirez Is Put On Waivers In Bid to Shed Big Contract
description: The Boston Red Sox placed outfielder Manny Ramirez on irrevocable waivers yesterday, and they are hoping that another team will claim him and enable them to shed the five years and $104 million remaining on his eight-year, $160 million contract, two major league executives said.

title: Fall Art Auctions Offer A Wealth of Big Names
description: For the first time in about four years, ''well timed'' deaths, in auction world parlance, have brought sought-after works to the fall market. These estate sales have in turn encouraged other sellers to ride what they perceive will be a tailwind of excitement. The result is two weeks of back-to-back auctions, starting Tuesday, featuring prime examples of works by masters like van Gogh, Lger, Klimt and Jasper Johns.

title: Insider Trading at Mutual Funds
description: Mutual funds are supposed to be the small investors' sanctuary on Wall Street, a way for them to get in on the action without fear of being taken. Nearly 100 million Americans have entrusted $7 trillion to mutual funds. But an ever-widening series of inquiries suggests that many of these consumer-friendly investment vehicles have been improperly manipulated by Wall Street insiders.

title: Drug Makers' New Intensity In Defense of U.S. Borders
description: On Capitol Hill, pharmaceutical executives say that legalizing drug imports would endanger American patients and sap profits that pay for research. But their message to Wall Street has been more reassuring -- that the problem of drug imports, at least for now, is well in hand.

title: Big East Basketball Goes Forward
description: Big East Commissioner Mike Tranghese, speaking yesterday at the Big East men's basketball media day, offered no specific details about the future of the league.

title: Medicare Bill Won't Include A Co-Payment for Home Care
description: After intense lobbying by Medicare beneficiaries and by former Senator Bob Dole, Congress has discarded the idea of imposing a co-payment on home health care services provided to the elderly and the disabled, lawmakers said on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REZNICK, IDA
description: REZNICK--Ida. On October 28, 2003. Cherished wife of Avram. Adored aunt of Arthur and Joel Leeds. She will always be remembered.

title: Guilty Verdict in Connecticut Treasury Scandal
description: Ben F. Andrews, an N.A.A.C.P. board member and a former Republican candidate for secretary of the state, was convicted on federal bribery and money-laundering charges on Wednesday after a two-week trial in connection with a state treasury scandal.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Walter Washington, the first mayor of Washington in modern times, misidentified President Lyndon B. Johnson's initial choice for an appointee before the job became an elective office. It was the historian and journalist Roger Wilkins, not his uncle Roy Wilkins, longtime head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: 2 Officers Shot in Brooklyn; Police Kill Robbery Suspect
description: Two police officers chasing robbery suspects were shot and wounded in Brooklyn last night -- one of them a sergeant whose bullet-resistant vest deflected a shot to the chest, the police said.

title: Artistic Director Of Playwrights Conference Resigns Post
description: James Houghton has resigned in a pique as the artistic director of the O'Neill Playwrights Conference, the country's leading workshop for new plays, saying he was excluded from the board's reorganization plans.

title: Play Tunes on the Treadmill Without Getting Tangled
description: Attempts to integrate radios and other devices into headphones have often been less than successful, resulting in products that are bulky and difficult to use. So Erik Vlugt, a product marketing manager at TDK Electronics, had doubts when he learned that his company was making a combined headphone and MP3 music player.

title: Giuliani Joins Effort to Alter City Primaries
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani is lending his clout to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's campaign to ban party primaries, appearing in a mailing that the mayor is sending out urging voters to support the ballot measure.

title: Milestones . . . and Things Still to Do . . . at Tower Site
description: A WEEK ago, it looked as if Gov. George E. Pataki would have some explaining to do in the speech he is to deliver this morning about Lower Manhattan.

title: Virtual Haunts for Your Inner Goblin
description: ALTHOUGH research shows that Halloween is the second most commercial holiday (after you-know-what), you may be disinclined to outfit yourself as, say, Sponge Bob or Pocahontas and trek door to door. In the age of the Internet, there is no need to have anything but a virtual costume -- indeed, you can experience the entire holiday without leaving the computer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRISBURG, AMY
description: KRISBURG--Amy. Of NYC, on October 29th, 2003 of a brain tumor. She was 34. Services Friday, 11:45 AM at The Riverside, 180 West 76th Street. Donations may be made to the American Brain Tumor Association at 800886-2282.

description: In the thick of the war with Iraq, President Bush used to pop out of meetings to catch the Iraqi information minister slipcovering grim reality with willful, idiotic optimism.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: China: Trade Delegation
description: China will send a business delegation to the United States to order goods in a bid to defuse American complaints about the ballooning trade imbalance between the countries, a senior Chinese trade official said. The president of the China Chamber for International Commerce, Wan Jifei, said the delegation would leave soon, but he did not provide any details about how much it would spend. Mr. Jifei said the shopping list would include high-technology products and urged the United States to ease restrictions on the export of such products. Chris Buckley (NYT)

title: RIVAL'S LAWSUIT AGAINST NIKE IS DISMISSED
description: Nike has won the dismissal of a lawsuit by DaDa Footwear that claimed that the heel of Nike's Air Jordan XVII shoe had copied the look of DaDa's products. Judge Lourdes G. Baird of Federal District Court in Los Angeles granted Nike's motion to dismiss the suit ahead of trial, ruling that an ordinary observer could tell the difference between Nike's shoe and DaDa's patented design. Lavetta Williams, the chief executive of the LL International Shoe Company, which owns DaDa, did not return a call seeking comment. LL International is based in Los Angeles. Nike is based in Beaverton, Ore.

description: WHATEVER YOU SAY I AM

title: Roses in Harbor, a Farewell to Ferry Victims
description: The police sergeant lifted the broad wreath of yellow roses, and the Rev. Calvin Rice bade him to ''cast it into the sea with all the mysteries it may hold.''

title: Israel's Chief of Staff Denounces Policies Against Palestinians
description: Israel's top-ranking soldier said that current hard-line policies against the Palestinians were working against Israel's ''strategic interest'' and had contributed to the downfall of the previous Palestinian prime minister, Israeli news organizations reported on Wednesday.

title: It's No Vietnam
description: Since 9/11, we've seen so much depraved violence we don't notice anymore when we hit a new low. Monday's attacks in Baghdad were a new low. Just stop for one second and contemplate what happened: A suicide bomber, driving an ambulance loaded with explosives, crashed into the Red Cross office and blew himself up on the first day of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan. This suicide bomber was not restrained by either the sanctity of the Muslim holy day or the sanctity of the Red Cross. All civilizational norms were tossed aside. This is very unnerving. Because the message from these terrorists is: ''There are no limits. We have created our own moral universe, where anything we do against Americans or Iraqis who cooperate with them is O.K.''

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Appeals Court Upholds Rule On TV Tuners
description: A federal appeals court has upheld a government rule that requires most new television sets to include special tuners that receive digital signals by July 2007. The Consumer Electronics Association, a trade group for manufacturers of television sets, VCR's and DVD players, sought to block the Federal Communications Commission rule, contending that the tuners were not necessary and that they would make television sets more expensive. But the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit deferred to the F.C.C., saying ''we will not here second-guess the commission's weighing of costs and benefits.'' The first phase of the F.C.C.'s plan requires, beginning next year, that half of all large television sets -- those with screens of at least 36 inches -- have the tuners. By July 1, 2007, according to the rule, all sets with screens of at least 13 inches and all VCR's and DVD players must meet the tuner standard. ''The commission is not crying wolf,'' the court said.

title: North Korea Ready to Resume Nuclear Talks
description: BEIJING, Oct. 30  North Korea said today that it was ready to enter a new round of negotiations on its nuclear program with the United States, China and other countries in the region, suggesting that President Bush's offer last week to discuss a security guarantee might have been enough to revive the on-again, off-again dialogue with the reclusive Communist state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODMAN, ARTHUR
description: GOODMAN -- Arthur. Suc cumbed to lymphoma on Monday, October 27, 2003. His loss is sustained by his second wife Patricia Clancy, his children Judith Finn, Howard Goodman and Sally Goodman-Schwartz; grandchildren Zachary, Katie, Aaron, Michael, Rebecca, Rachel and Lucy. Born on February 14, 1924, Arthur's first marriage to Beatrice Belford ended in divorce. In addition to building a highly successful answering service business, Arthur was also an avid small plane pilot, photographer and naturalist. His burial service will be held at 11:30am on Friday, October 31, 2003 at the Sharon Gardens-Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, N.Y.

title: When Good Photo-Ops Go Bad
description: Democrats gnashed their teeth last spring when President Bush pulled off what looked like the ultimate photo-op: his jet-pilot landing on an aircraft carrier to announce the end of major hostilities in Iraq. As much as they complained of showboating, the Democrats had nightmares about the campaign commercials that would be made from the pictures of Mr. Bush striding past the cheering sailors in his flight suit.

description: Yes, there are witches among us, or so they say. Not ''pointy black hat, pointy green nose'' witches, but the modern kind, the urban sophisticated witches, and this is their time of year. They seem to enjoy their moment in the sun, or the darkness, as the case may be.

title: Youngest Victim of Sniper Tells of Bullet in Chest
description: Iran Brown had been kicked off the school bus for eating candy, so his aunt drove him to Benjamin Tasker Middle School in Bowie, Md., that Monday morning last fall. Moments after he got out of her car, he fell to the ground, a gunshot wound in his chest.

description: How fast is fast? For a runner as gifted as Marla Runyan, one of the women's favorites in the New York City Marathon on Sunday, the answer is almost cruel.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arbitration For Trade Center Dispute
description: A federal judge yesterday ordered the developer Larry A. Silverstein and his insurers to arbitration on Nov. 6 to try to settle their battle over billions of dollars in insurance proceeds for rebuilding at the World Trade Center site. If the process fails, Judge Michael B. Mukasey said, the first of what could be three successive trials will begin in February. Mr. Silverstein's lawyer, Herbert M. Wachtell, expressed reservations about the proposed arbitrator, John S. Martin, a retired federal judge. He said Mr. Martin was a friend of his but had ruled against Mr. Silverstein in earlier stages of the case. But Mr. Wachtell agreed to the choice when Judge Mukasey said that ''you couldn't conceivably have anyone better to mediate this case.'' Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: British Conservative Leader Is Rejected in Party Vote
description: Iain Duncan Smith, the opposition leader in Britain's Parliament, said Wednesday that he would resign after his fellow Conservative lawmakers rejected him in a confidence vote.

title: Wendy Marx, Liver Patient, 36; Inspired Organ Donation Group
description: Wendy Marx, who became the spokeswoman of a foundation named for her after being saved by a liver transplant, died on Tuesday in Palo Alto, Calif. She was 36 and lived in San Francisco.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Electronic Data To Cut 2,500 More Jobs
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the world's second-largest seller of computer services, said yesterday that it would eliminate an additional 2,500 jobs after the company had a third-quarter loss as sales declined 1.8 percent. The net loss was $600,000, or break-even on a per-share basis, compared with net income of $86 million, or 18 cents, a year earlier, the company said in a statement. Sales fell to $5.24 billion from $5.33 billion. The job cuts are in addition to 2,700 firings announced in June by the chief executive, Michael Jordan. Shares of Electronic Data rose 8 cents, to $21.85. They rose another 15 cents in extended trading after the announcement.

title: The October Fires in California
description: The classic brief account of the conditions that have set Southern California on fire comes from Joan Didion. In 1966 she described a region ''devastated by the hot dry Santa Ana wind that comes down through the passes at 100 miles an hour and whines through the eucalyptus windbreaks and works on the nerves. October is the bad month for the wind, the month when breathing is difficult and the hills blaze up spontaneously.'' The winds have not been that high this October, but the temperatures have, and the hills have blazed up, spontaneously and, in the case of at least three fires where arson is suspected, not so spontaneously. It's easy to forget what wild edges the cities and subdivisions of Southern California have -- until they start to burn.

The countries have been locked in a dispute over a number of areas on their border, including territory rich in oil and fish. (Reuters)

description: Despite sentiment for a shortened preseason from players and fans after quarterbacks Michael Vick and Chad Pennington sustained devastating injuries within days of each other during August preseason games, the N.F.L. will maintain its format of 4 preseason games and 16 regular-season games for the foreseeable future.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Posts Profit
description: Germany's second-largest bank, HypoVereinsbank, said it returned to profit for the first time in five quarters and beat analysts' expectations. The HVB group, which is based in Munich, said it posted a net profit of 294 million euros ($343 million) in the period from July to September, in contrast to a net loss of 166 million euros a year earlier. The bank said its results were helped by a one-time gain of 279 million euros ($326 million) from the sale of its Norisbank subsidiary. Victor Homola (NYT)

description: In the predawn Siberian darkness five days ago, agents of the Russian security agency stormed the private jet of Russia's richest man. Mikhail Khodorkovsky, the chief executive and principal owner of Russia's largest oil company, Yukos, was arrested and charged with tax evasion, fraud, forgery and embezzlement.

description: The New York attorney general said yesterday that he planned to take action against Richard S. Strong, the chairman and founder of the Strong mutual funds, contending that Mr. Strong improperly traded in and out of the shares of his company's funds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARMINGTON, NICHOLAS MEISTER
description: ARMINGTON -- Nicholas Meister. Nicholas Meister Armington, a maker of documentary films, died October 18, 2003 while scuba diving in the waters off Anacapa Island, California. His death was an accident. He had turned 41 on October 15th, the previous Wednesday. Born in New York City, Mr. Armington and his wife Sari were currently living in San Rafael, California. Prior to moving to California, he lived and worked in New York City, spending his summers at the family home in Siasconset, Nantucket Island. Mr. Armington was an accomplished filmmaker who, with his wife, Sari, formed a film production company, Alchemedia, Ltd. He also had numerous corporate clients. At the time of his death, they had been in production on the public television documentary, ''The Funnies: Life in the Comics'' with KQED TV in San Francisco. The film is a celebration of the role that newspaper comics have played in American society. He also was an accomplished music composer and played the keyboards. Mr. Armington followed his late father, Hervey Foster Armington, into filmmaking. He attended Dartmouth College, where he earned a bachelor's degree in computer sciences in 1984. After summer positions with McKinsey & Company and American Express Company, he worked for many years for MeadWestvaco Corporation in New York producing numerous coporate films and videos. He left in 1996 to start Alchemedia, which is based in San Rafael, California. Mr. Armington is survived by his wife, Sari Armington of San Rafael, and by his mother, Dr. Irene Meister-Armington, of New York and Nantucket. A memorial service will take place on November 4, 2003 at 10 A.M. at the Church of Saint Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street, New York, NY 10128.

title: Powell and Ashcroft Warn of Fallout From Senate Spending Proposal
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Attorney General John Ashcroft have raised serious objections to the Senate spending plan for their departments, saying the measure could undermine American counterterrorism efforts and diplomacy.

title: Effects of Wildfire Smoke Vary, Experts Say
description: The inhalation of tiny smoke particles from wildfires, while unpleasant, is unlikely to cause long-term damage to healthy people unless it occurs over a prolonged period, doctors and environmental health specialists said.

title: Accounts
description: The Alzheimer's Association, Chicago, named three agencies of the Omnicom Group, New York, to handle parts of its account, with billings estimated at $20 million. Rapp Collins Worldwide will handle advertising; Porter Novelli International will handle public relations; and Changing Our World will handle philanthropic services and fund-raising support. The association had not previously advertised.

description: Can a middle-aged gay former Broadway chorus boy whose acerbic demeanor hides a deep loneliness and the elderly widow of a Baptist minister who submerges her liberal, fun-loving nature beneath a prim formality find happiness together in a Florida condominium?

title: Is There an Echo in Here? Software Lets Architects Predict
description: ARCHITECTS use computer software to construct three-dimensional models so their clients can see how a finished building will look. Now some of them are also creating computer models that simulate the acoustics of the building so that clients can find out how it is likely to sound, too.

description: COLE--Charles J. We can't believe it's been eleven years. Still loving and missing you every day. Abbie and Bra

title: Tailored Rooms for a Tower Home
description: IT is unusual for a show house to be in a high-rise apartment building. But ''Rooms With a View,'' a design exhibition, is in two apartments at the Time Warner Center, high above Columbus Circle. Twenty-one decorators dressed the rooms, offering visitors many variations on luxury apartment living, in 7,000 square feet. There are ideas for every home, from bath to kitchen. The show runs Monday through Saturday at 25 Columbus Circle (58th Street near Eighth Avenue), through Nov. 15. Tickets, available only from Telecharge, (973) 239-6200 are $50. Proceeds will go to the Central Park Conservancy, Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS and the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Judge Removes Himself From Case
description: A judge who completed an alcohol rehabilitation program this summer has reluctantly removed himself from a death penalty case after defense lawyers said he was too impaired to preside. Judge Kenneth Scheibenberger of Superior Court, was slated to preside over the February penalty hearing for Zolo Azania, who has twice been convicted and sentenced to death for the 1981 killing of a Gary police officer. The sentence was overturned each time. On Monday, the judge said that while the defense contentions were unfounded he was removing himself from the case ''in the best interest of justice.'' Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: ARBITRATION FOR TRADE CENTER DISPUTE A federal judge yesterday ordered the developer Larry A. Silverstein and his insurers to arbitration on Nov. 6 to try to settle their battle over billions of dollars in insurance proceeds for rebuilding at the World Trade Center site. If the process fails, Judge Michael B. Mukasey said, the first of what could be three successive trials will begin in February. Mr. Silverstein's lawyer, Herbert M. Wachtell, expressed reservations about the proposed arbitrator, John S. Martin, a retired federal judge. He said Mr. Martin was a friend of his but had ruled against Mr. Silverstein in earlier stages of the case. But Mr. Wachtell agreed to the choice when Judge Mukasey said that "you couldn't conceivably have anyone better to mediate this case."   Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Fussy About the Small Things, and Back on Top
description: AS lunch hour at Union Square Cafe crests and the kitchen fervor rises exponentially, Chef Michael Romano's hands are everywhere. He dips a testing, tasting forefinger into a lamb stew, then rescues a wounded fettuccine from a flustered young assistant.

title: BROOKFIELD BUYS BUILDING IN WASHINGTON
description: The Brookfield Properties Corporation, one of Lower Manhattan's largest office landlords, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $157.5 million for a 12-story office building two blocks away from the White House to enter the Washington market. Brookfield is buying the 383,000-square-foot building from the Union Labor Life Insurance Company, a unit of Ullico, Brookfield's chief executive, Richard B. Clark, said in a conference call with investors and analysts. The building is at 1625 Eye Street.

title: Michael Leavitt's First Task
description: Michael Leavitt, the Utah governor chosen by President Bush to run the Environmental Protection Agency, has finally won Senate confirmation after 56 days. The embarrassing delay was less a reflection of senatorial dismay with Mr. Bush's choice than a means of showing displeasure with his regressive environmental policies.

title: At Walt Disney Concert Hall, Good Design Is the Spice of Life
description: Hagy Belzberg, inset, 39, an architect based in Santa Monica, was selected last year by the Music Center of Los Angeles County to design a restaurant, a cafe and a shop for Frank Gehry's Walt Disney Concert Hall, which opened last week. The restaurant, Patina, is California-French and was transplanted by the chef Joachim Splichal from Melrose Avenue. It has a private room, above right, with a trompe l'oeil curtain of carved walnut and an undulating ceiling. The upholstered chairs are by Christian Liaigre, the lamps by Holly Hunt, and the artwork is on loan from the nearby Museum of Contemporary Art. In the hall lobby, above left, Mr. Belzberg tucked the Concert Hall Cafe behind a luminous scrim of frosted glass. The bent plywood Taino chairs are by Vitra and are available for $475 from Vitra stores; (888) 298-2855 for locations. The restaurant, (213) 972-3331, and cafe, (213) 972-3550 are open daily; 141 South Grand Avenue. Mr. Belzberg can be reached at (310) 453-9611. EMILY YOUNG

title: Sex Criminals From Abroad Are Arrested In Crackdown
description: Federal agents yesterday arrested more than 50 foreign citizens from 25 countries who were living in New York and New Jersey despite the federal government's desire to deport them after they were convicted of sex crimes, mostly against children.

title: As Breakable as Big Kids' Stuff
description: Alfredo Hberli, a designer in Zurich, has created a sleek 10-piece tableware set, above, for diners 3 and up. The bowl and plate are porcelain, and the tumbler is made of glass. ''Three-year-olds are not babies anymore,'' Mr. Hberli said. ''It's important to teach them to use real glass and porcelain.'' Made by iittala of Finland, the set includes a plastic tray, a chopping board and a butter knife ($140). A three-piece set (bowl, plate and glass) is $70. From mid-November at Moss, 146 Greene Street (Houston Street); (212) 204-7100. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Googles Popular Toolbar
description: THE Google toolbar, a thin row of buttons and a query window that sits within the Internet Explorer browser, has become a big hit, with millions of people using it each day. Last summer it attracted even more users when Google added a pop-up blocker to the toolbar's features, effectively filtering the unsolicited advertisements that appear along with many Web pages.

title: For Hair-Trigger Fingers, A New Way With Buttons
description: A fraction of a second can be the difference between life and death in a video game, but gamers often lose time when moving their thumbs off the thumb stick to press the Crouch or Jump button. Now Gamester's FPS Master Xbox controller saves those important milliseconds with a design that lets you push the buttons without ever moving your thumbs.

title: Spouse Fights New Law Over Feeding Tube
description: Lawyers for the husband of Terri Schiavo argued in court papers filed Wednesday that the law granting Gov. Jeb Bush the power to reinstate her feeding tube was unconstitutional because it violated the separation of the judicial and executive branches of state government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FARNAN, DOROTHY J.
description: FARNAN--Dorothy J., Educator, writer, painter died peacefully at home on October 23, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Edward Kallman, cherished godmother of Rev. Carla Valentine Pryne of Seattle, WA. Loving stepmother of Bill Kallman of Greenfield, Indiana, and the late Chester and Malcolm Kallman. Dear friend of Lisa Lesavoy. Friends may call at The Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, NYC on Friday, October 31, 2-5 and 7-9pm. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Guilty Verdict In Triple Homicide
description: A man was found guilty yesterday in a notorious triple murder on the Lower East Side in June 2002 and could face three life sentences, officials said. At trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, prosecutors said the man, Steven Santos, 21, had climbed through the bathroom windows of his victims, Larry Sprung, 86, his wife, Sara Sprung, 88, and their neighbor, Raymond Damelio, 49. After shooting them in the head, he stole from them, drank their liquor and watched pornographic videos, officials said. Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, said he would seek three consecutive life sentences without parole for Mr. Santos when he is sentenced on Nov. 19.
