description: COMNINEL--Ann. Died October 25, 2003. Born August 9, 1918 in New York City where she lived for 74 years. Beloved sister, adored aunt and loyal friend; she was a lady of fine character and great integrity who brought love and kindness to all who knew her. Retired international real estate broker for Midocean Brokers Inc., in Manhattan, where she worked for many years. She was a resident of Parkway Place, Houston, TX for the last four years. Services will be held at Memorial Oaks, 13001 Katy Freeway, Houston, TX at 2 PM, Friday, October 31.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: $30,000 Reward In Killing Of Student
description: With the investigation into the slaying of a Connecticut college student stalled, the police and the student's family have offered a $30,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the killer. The student, Mark S. Fisher, 19, was found shot to death on a street in Prospect Park South after a night out with friends. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that knowledgeable people ''have not been fully forthcoming'' about the case. The city is contributing $10,000 to the reward, and Mr. Fisher's family is adding $20,000. Anyone with information on the case should call 1-800-577-TIPS (1-800-577-8477). Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Islamic Leader Tied to Libya Is Denied Bail
description: A federal judge on Wednesday denied bail to a prominent Islamic leader accused of illegally funneling money from Libya, saying the man posed too great a risk of fleeing the country if freed from custody.

title: DRUG WHOLESALER TO BUY PACKAGING COMPANY
description: Cardinal Health, a drug wholesaler, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the InterCare Group of Britain for $530 million to gain its sterile-packaging business and expand abroad. The company will pay 280 pence ($4.75) for each share of InterCare and take on about $130 million in debt, it said. The boards of the companies have approved the transaction, which Cardinal expects to complete by the end of the year. InterCare makes and distributes products like prefilled syringes for use by patients. The acquisition will allow Cardinal, which is based in Dublin, Ohio, to serve more international customers, a spokesman, Jim Mazzola, said. Less than 10 percent of the company business is outside the United States, he said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 15 about the debate over removing the feeding tube of a brain-damaged Florida woman, Terri Schiavo, misattributed a statement from a protester at a vigil opposing the state's right-to-die law. It was Nancy Kramer, not Carrie Kirkland, another protester, who said: ''We don't even divine hanging chads in this state and yet we're divining that Terri wants to die. Floridians will take a stand so that these laws can be revisited.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELMS, MARGARET (NEE MACCREADY)
description: ELMS--Margaret (nee MacCready). Longtime resident of Manhattan, Fair Harbor Fire Island and Waretown, NJ. For information call John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 914-834-0144.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Singapore: Airline's Profit Rises
description: Singapore Airlines posted an unexpected increase in its second-quarter profit, helped by wage cuts and a recovery in business travel. It forecast an improvement in passenger traffic. Earnings for the three months ended Sept. 30 rose 3.6 percent, to 305.8 million Singapore dollars ($175.2 million), or 25 cents a share, from 295.1 million Singapore dollars, or 24 cents a share, a year earlier. Second-quarter sales fell to 2.5 billion Singapore dollars from 2.7 billion.

title: Metro Matters; A Mayor Basking In J.Glow
description: WAITING for the show to begin -- the J.Lo-and-Mike show -- the entertainment reporter turned to the political writer and said: ''A smart move. They could use a little positive press.'' The political reporter agreed: ''Absolutely. The mayor's polls are still not great, and he's on this toot about nonpartisan elections, the ferry disaster depressed the city, and we still don't know what happened, and ----''

title: South African Court Told of Plot for Coup and Ouster of Blacks
description: A white extremist sect plotted in 2001 to overthrow South Africa's government, assassinate its former president, Nelson Mandela, and march more than 35 million blacks and other nonwhites into exile along two superhighways, prosecutors said in a Pretoria court on Wednesday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mount Kisco: Judge Suspended For Pirro Remarks
description: A Westchester village justice who is accused of saying that Jeanine F. Pirro, the district attorney, was tapping his telephone has been suspended with pay by the State Court of Appeals. On Tuesday, the court ordered the suspension of the justice, Joseph J. Cerbone, for his remarks. Earlier this month, the State Commission on Judicial Conduct said Justice Cerbone was unwilling to adhere to what it called ''high ethical standards.'' Mrs. Pirro has accused Justice Cerbone of failing to disclose his personal connection to an accused attacker appearing in his courtroom. Later, from the bench, the judge said Mrs. Pirro had tapped his phones and kept a dossier on him. Mr. Cerbone has 30 days to seek review of the appeals court's decision. Justice Cerbone's lawyer, Richard Grayson, said he had not yet decided whether he would seek action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHANOWITZ, KAREN OLSHAN
description: CHANOWITZ--Karen Olshan. No one knows better than I, the daily contributions Karen made to the company where we worked together for many years. She had an extraordinary intellect and a devotion to integrity that made her stand out in every respect. Karen spent no time dwelling on the challenges she faced; all of her time spent doing what she did best. We call that grace. I shall dearly miss my colleague and my friend. Bruce Meyers

title: Suit Accuses Police in Brooklyn Of Strip-Searches in Minor Cases
description: Near the warren of cells that smelled of feces and vomit, the woman did not quite believe what was happening. She had been arrested in 2001 in Brooklyn on a minor charge and now, in a room with an open door, a police officer had asked her to strip naked and squat. ''She used her finger to examine me internally,'' the woman testified at a deposition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YUSKA, HENRY
description: YUSKA--Henry. November 7, 1914 to October 25, 2003. Professor Henry B. Yuska died October 25, 2003 after a prolonged illness. For the past two years he has resided at Attic Angel Place. In his 89 years Henry lived a full and happy life. He began his career as an organic polymer chemist and was responsible for seven patents. He rose in the industry to Research Manager of Interchemical Corporation and later as Technical Manager of Sun Chemical Corporation manufacturing paints, coatings and varnishes. In mid-career he switched to academia as Professor and deputy chairman of chemistry at Brooklyn College of the City University of NY. Many of his students have gone on to become medical doctors and scientists. He is preceded in death by his wife Lillian and survived by his son Dr. Kenneth H. Yuska and daughterin-law Ginny Yuska of Madison WI and son Reynold Yuska of Queens, NY, two grandsons and one great-granddaughter. Henry loved his family, friends, colleagues, students, and his work. At his retirement as Professor Emeritus in 1985 his students established the Henry Yuska Organic Chemistry Award Fund for Outstanding Students. Contributions in Henry's memory may be made to Henry Yuska Organic Chemistry Award Fund for Outstanding Students at: Chair Department of Chemistry, Room 359NE, Brooklyn College, 2900 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11210-2889. Graveside service will be held 11:30 AM, Saturday, November 1, 2003 at Cypress Hills Cemetery in Brooklyn. Visitation will be held from 9:00 AM until 10:45 AM at Simonson Funeral Home, 119 - 04 Hillside Avenue, Queens, NY; Phone 718-847-0300.

title: World Business Briefings
description: EUROPE

title: Free to Be?
description: Lisa Belkin's cover story in The Times Magazine, "The Opt-Out Revolution," proved to be one of those articles everyone has an opinion about . The thesis that highly educated women will largely "opt-out" of the jobs they are trained for in favor of motherhood unleashed an outpouring of reader commentary. Some posters wrote about how much they identified with the women quoted in the article and how surprised they were to find that staying home with their children was more fulfilling than the high-powered careers they began before becoming a parent. Others offered the assertion that office culture has become so stultifying and exploitative that most people who can choose a different life, would.

title: Shuttle Accident Investigator Cites Gains in NASA Protocol
description: The head of the panel that investigated the Columbia space shuttle accident said Wednesday that NASA had done many things right in deciding to send astronauts to the International Space Station this month despite some concerns about the safety of the station.

title: Town Asks Itself How 4 of Its Children Could Be Starved
description: Shocked residents packed into a community center Wednesday night to discuss the case of four starved, adopted boys, who had lived for years on a quiet block on the edge of town without their condition's ever being noticed. What could they have done, people asked, to prevent the abuse? What institution should have noticed their suffering? What changes needed to be made?

title: I.R.S. Clears Way for Fuel Tax Credits, Amid Doubts
description: The Internal Revenue Service announced yesterday that it was resuming issuing special rulings that help manufacturers of coal-based synthetic fuel qualify for rich tax credits.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Pataki Endorses Mayoral Candidate
description: In front of cheering supporters, Gov. George E. Pataki endorsed the Yonkers deputy mayor, Phil Amicone, yesterday in his bid to win the city's top job. Mr. Amicone, a Republican, seeks to replace his political mentor, Mayor John Spencer, who is barred by term limits from running for re-election. Mr. Amicone faces Joe L. Farmer, the former Yonkers school superintendent and a Democrat. Mr. Amicone won a bitterly fought primary battle against State Assemblyman Michael J. Spano, who had vowed to stay on the ballot on two minor-party lines, which could have split the Republican vote. Mr. Spano dropped out this month and threw his support to Mr. Amicone. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: In the Candidacies of Clark and Dean, Democrats Confront the Issue of Electability
description: Wesley K. Clark has a history of dalliances with the Republican Party. Caught up in conflicting statements on issues, he has endured what even his supporters describe as a rough first few weeks as a Democratic presidential candidate. Indeed, his stands on many issues are mysteries even to the Democrats who rushed to Little Rock, Ark., his hometown, to sign on with his campaign.

title: Actors Rally To Protest Non-Equity Road Shows
description: Seven months after the Broadway musicians' strike, another battle is brewing between organized labor and theatrical producers.

title: In a Greek Revival, Wit and Stagecraft
description: HERE is one difference between drama and architecture: a play sells its fictions to the audience, while a house sells its fictions to the actors inside. On a recent afternoon in this New England coastal village, Tom Viertel talked about the stories he wanted his weekend house to tell. Mr. Viertel, 61, belongs to the Broadway team that produced ''Hairspray,'' ''The Producers'' and, most recently, ''Little Shop of Horrors.'' The house is an 1844 Greek Revival number in the final stages of renovation.

title: Campaign for Medical Device Bypasses Doctors
description: Taking a page from the drug industry, two medical device makers are going head to head with national campaigns that advertise hip-replacement implants to consumers.

title: Nets Stumble in Opener As Carter Leads a Rally
description: The Nets opened their season Wednesday night with their eyes set on the questions they had to answer. How would Byron Scott fare without the help of the assistants who stood beside him in recent seasons? How would Alonzo Mourning contribute after an absence from the game that spanned 18 months?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CALABRESI, PAUL
description: CALABRESI--Paul, 73, of Barrington, RI, died peacefully on October 25, 2003 after a courageous battle with cancer, the disease of which he cured so many. He was Professor of Medicine and Chairman Emeritus of the Brown University Department of Medicine and the First Chairman of the National Cancer Advisory Board. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, Celia, three children, Steven, Janice and Peter, eight grandchildren and a brother, Guido. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, November 1 at 10:30am in the First Unitarian Church of Providence, 1 Benevolent St, Providence. Memorial contributions may be made to the Calabresi Professorship at Rhode Island Hospital Foundation to support an endowed chair at Brown University, c/o Lifespan Development Office, PO Box H, Providence, RI 02901 or to the Yale Cancer Center, Paul Calabresi Lectureship, Office of Medical Development, PO Box 7611, New Haven, CT 06519-1714.

title: The Vatican's Modernist Moment; A Church Designed by Richard Meier Is Consecrated in Rome
description: If any city is well supplied with churches, it is surely Rome. Yet 10 years ago, after concluding that 600,000 people here had no convenient place to worship, the archdiocese began an ambitious building program. On Sunday it consecrated the 50th new church, and the most spectacular: a striking Modernist structure designed by Richard Meier around three soaring ''sails'' of white concrete.

title: Senate Rejects a Measure on Curbing Global Warming
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  The Senate rejected a plan today that its supporters said would help curb global warming. But the 55-to-43 tally showed how remarkably the political landscape has changed in six years.

title: Ancient Maya Altar Retaken From Looters in Guatemala
description: The latest story coming out of the jungle of Guatemala, of plunder and violence in the illicit traffic of Maya antiquities, has an all too familiar plot line, except for the ending.

title: Jets Plan To Place A Rookie On Shockey

As soon as he could, he would hit the receiver in the face with a forearm. Edwards would draw a flag and his coach, Dick Vermeil, would get mad, but the message had been delivered.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Climate Exchange Postpones Trading Date

Sandor, its chairman and chief executive. title: Treasury Chief Says China Isnt Manipulating Its Currency
description: Seeking to avoid the onset of what could turn into a trade war with China, Treasury Secretary John W. Snow told senators today that Beijing was not manipulating its currency exchange rate to gain an unfair advantage over American manufacturers.

title: Russian Prosecutors Freeze Billions in Oil Company Stock
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30 — Prosecutors froze today billions worth of stocks in Russia's richest company, Yukos Oil, starkly raising the stakes of their investigation of its chief executive, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky.

title: Corrections
description: The front-page About New York column yesterday, about a reduction of the World Trade Center death toll, to 2,752, referred imprecisely to the comparison between the terrorist attack there and the Civil War battle of Antietam. That was the worst day of intentional bloodshed in United States history (with at least 3,650 dead). But the deadliest day over all was Sept. 8, 1900, when a hurricane struck Galveston, Tex. Estimates have varied, but The Galveston Daily News eventually identified 4,263 dead by name and estimated that 1,500 more bodies had been buried without identification.

title: Lakers Win Easily, and Bryant and ONeal Ease Tensions

He walked slowly toward the Lakers' bench while the crowd of 18,997 at Staples Center cheered him rabidly.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Galloway Township: Body Washes Ashore
description: The body of a New York City man missing for 16 months after a storm capsized his sailboat has been discovered, the New Jersey State Police said yesterday. Around 2 p.m. Monday, fishermen discovered the body of Werner D. Tissys, 63, of Flushing, Queens, after it washed ashore near Brigantine, N.J. Physicians conducting an autopsy at Shore Memorial Hospital determined that the death was accidental, said Stephen Jones, a state police spokesman. On June 7, 2002, Mr. Tissys' boat was found overturned on a sandbar in Long Beach Township. Jane Allande-Hession (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNS, MARGARET
description: JOHNS -- Margaret. The Trustees and staff of the World Monuments Fund mark with great sadness the death of Margaret Johns. With her husband, Peter Stern, Vice Chairman and long-serving trustee of the World Monuments Fund, Margaret shared a passion for the work of the organization and participated with energy and intelligence in countless WMF events, trips, and gatherings. She brightened our lives with her informed and cheerful enthusiasm and greatly expanded our knowledge through her own many accomplishments, as a scientist, gardener, artist, music lover, reader, and passionate traveler. She will be missed by all. Our heartfelt condolences go to her beloved family including Peter Stern and daughters, Kate Johns and Sara Griffen.

It served as a reminder of the United States' subsequent mediocrity in the 26.2-mile race. No American man has won the marathon since Salazar. The women's drought is longer, dating from 1977, when Miki Gorman won.

title: Welcome to Napa Nation
description: LAST Sunday afternoon, Monalee and Kent Smith and 26 of their friends were out in wine country, exploring the vineyards and stopping for tastings at various wineries. Off in the distance, rolling hills arched above a winding river, their colors an early fall combination of amber, rust and gold. Church steeples peeked out through a canopy of trees. Along a winding two-lane highway and its tributaries were almost 50 bed-and-breakfasts, many filled for the weekend, and the antiques stores and restaurants in the quaint nearby village were doing a brisk business.

title: Starving Children in Plain Sight
description: The frightening discovery in New Jersey of innocent youngsters systematically starved by their adoptive parents is doubly gruesome against the state's slipshod history of protecting children. First came the image of a 19-year-old weighing less than 50 pounds managing a midnight escape to rummage like a famine wraith in a neighbor's garbage can. The police discovered three more similarly abused and stunted boys in the South Jersey home, along with a padlocked refrigerator. Investigators found that the parents, while netting more than $30,000 a year in subsidies, had ladled out uncooked pancake batter to their charges, who gnawed on the walls and woodwork for extra sustenance.

title: Firefighters Growing Hopeful Worst Is Over in California
description: Fire officials monitoring conditions in the San Bernardino Mountains east of Los Angeles, one of the most intense battlegrounds in the relentless Southern California fires, said today that no homes had been destroyed on Thursday, the first time that they could report no new losses since the fires began on Oct. 21.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Port Authority To Fight Teterboro Plan
description: Anthony R. Coscia, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, has declared that the bistate agency will aggressively fight any effort by the Federal Aviation Administration to allow Boeing 737 jets to land at Teterboro Airport. Mr. Coscia made the promise in a meeting with top F.A.A. officials on Wednesday. The officials have pressed the authority to allow planes weighing more than 100,000 pounds to land at Teterboro, used now by small aircraft. The Port Authority chairman's stance reiterated the position of the agency and most local officials that big jets would damage the airport. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

Mr. Echols, who was 18 when found guilty, contended that the television program, broadcast on HBO, posed a conflict of interest for his lawyer. The court earlier rejected a similar appeal by Mr. Echols, whose two co-defendants received life prison sentences. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: $500,000 Phone Call Under Scrutiny
description: The office of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's inspector general, at the request of Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Democrat from Westchester County, has begun an inquiry into a telephone call made by Alfonse M. D'Amato for which he was paid $500,000. Some Democrats have questioned the independence of officially quasi-independent public authorities under Gov. George E. Pataki. In 1999, Mr. D'Amato, the former United States senator and mentor of Mr. Pataki, working as a corporate consultant, telephoned the chairman of the M.T.A. on behalf of a client. Mr. D'Amato was paid $100,000 for the call and a later ''success fee'' of $400,000, Mr. Brodsky said. The phone call was disclosed in hearings conducted in May by Mr. Brodsky, who requested the investigation. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Judicial Nomination Advances
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted yesterday in favor of a controversial nominee whom Gov. George E. Pataki has been backing for a federal judgeship in Brooklyn. By voice vote, the panel agreed to send the nomination of Dora Irizarry, who ran unsuccessfully against Eliot Spitzer for state attorney general, to the full Senate. The panel approved Judge Irizarry's nomination to a judgeship in the Eastern District of New York despite allegations that she screamed at lawyers during her years as a trial judge. Administration officials said that of the 200 people President Bush has nominated to become federal judges, the American Bar Association rated only three as unqualified, and that Judge Irizarry was one of them. President Bush nominated her at Mr. Pataki's urging, which was widely viewed as a reward for running on the Republican ticket when the governor was courting Hispanic voters. Raymond Hernandez (NYT)

title: The Hot Seat (Or the Cool)
description: The days are gone when leather car seats automatically chilled you to the tailbone on winter mornings and burned your shorts-clad legs in summer. Car seats with heating elements have been around for years. Many seats now also have fans that push room-temperature air through their perforated leather covers. But in front seats offered with some Ford, Mercury and Lincoln models, the air blown through the seat covering is cooled on hot days by the same device that heats that air on cold days. Novel, yes, but based on a discovery made more than a century and a half ago.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City May Release 9/11 Documents
description: New York City is expected to announce as early as today that it has agreed to let the federal government review key city documents long sought for a federal inquiry into the city's emergency response to the terror attack on Sept. 11, 2001. The city has argued that the material is confidential, although it never formally rejected the federal request, saying only that it needed more time. The documents are Fire and Police Department records that federal investigators requested a year ago as part of an inquiry by the National Institute of Standards and Technology, which wants to review police 911 tapes as well as transcripts of interviews with hundreds of surviving firefighters so that it can understand how the city handled the trade center evacuation. The institute has said that its goal is to save lives in any future building catastrophes. Eric Lipton (NYT)

title: Sneak Attack by Bloomberg
description: One source of Mayor Michael Bloomberg's problems with New York City voters is that he's not straight with them. One day he's a Democrat, the next day he's a Republican. He presents himself as a man who favors policies that will help the city's many struggling families. But he uses his influence and his personal wealth to advance the interests of a national party that is indifferent, at best, to the concerns of poor and working families, and unabashedly hostile to programs designed to help blacks and other ethnic minorities.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: BMC Posts Loss, But Revenue Gains
description: BMC Software reported a loss for its latest quarter yesterday because of charges for layoffs, but revenue rose 15 percent, buoyed by an acquisition. The Houston-based company's results exceeded Wall Street's diminished expectations. Shares of BMC rose $1.46, or 9.3 percent, to $17.12. BMC reported a net loss of $13.2 million, or 6 cents a share, in the period that ended on Sept. 30, including $34.4 million in restructuring charges. A year ago, it made a profit of $10.1 million, or 4 cents a share. Excluding restructuring charges and other charges, the company said it had a profit of 10 cents a share, double what analysts had expected. BMC reported a shortfall in the quarter that ended in June and said it would cut 13 percent of its 6,800 jobs.

title: Shootouts, Shopping, Sunshine
description: THE Old West, complete with tourist-friendly bank robberies and shootouts, lives on in Tucson. Visitors will also find living reminders of Arizona's Spanish colonial past, the flora and fauna of the Sonora Desert, mountain trails, inventive restaurants and a great place to buy heirloom seeds. Not to mention the low humidity. Page 4.

title: A Place of Beauty, and Then the Fires Came
description: To the Editor:

title: As He Visits New PATH Terminal, Governor Praises the Pace of the Rebuilding Effort
description: Gov. George E. Pataki told downtown business leaders yesterday that there is steady and certain progress in the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site, with the PATH station reopening next month, the exhibition of proposals for a memorial and, in December, the unveiling of a new design for the first skyscraper on the 16-acre parcel.

title: New Tries for Mideast Peace
description: Ami Ayalon took over as chief of the Shin Bet security service in Israel in 1996, as a string of Palestinian suicide bombings massacred scores of Israelis. In the first nine months of 2000, the year he left office, there was one Israeli death from Palestinian terror. Much as he would like to take credit for the shift, Mr. Ayalon says, it had little to do with Israeli security techniques and a great deal to do with Palestinians' hopes for a state. When there was optimism about their political future, he said, support for violence plummeted, and Palestinian security services fought radicals. When hope declined, terror rose and no one lifted a finger to stop it. The most urgent task for Israel today, he says rightly, is to find a way to renew that hope.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Threat, Blasts And Pullouts Raise Anxiety In Baghdad
description: This jittery city was unnerved further on Thursday by more explosions, a new terrorist threat against schoolchildren and a decision by the United Nations and international aid groups to evacuate their foreign staff from Baghdad.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page picture in this section last Friday, with a story about the off-season restfulness of Fire Island, in New York, gave an incomplete view of a ferry ride on a Saturday morning. Although the boat carried only about a quarter of its summertime passenger load, the riders numbered 70, most below deck and thus not visible.

title: Rare Sightings: Carter And Ranger Power Play
description: Through the Rangers' first seven games, it would have been difficult to say which had been more invisible this season: their woefully inept power play or right wing Anson Carter, who had not scored since March 19.

title: Treasury Loosens Pressure on China Over Exchange Rate
description: Treasury Secretary John W. Snow, who has been pressuring China for two months to permit its currency to float more freely against the dollar, adopted a conciliatory tone on Thursday, saying neither China nor any other country was manipulating its exchange rate.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: REFCO GROUP, New York, a diversified financial services firm, said that its futures subsidiary had acquired the customer assets of RB&H Financial Services, one of the oldest clearing member firms of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Terms were not disclosed.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Group Takes Blame For Vandalism
description: The Earth Liberation Front, a radical group, has claimed responsibility for about $25,000 in damages to equipment at a Wal-Mart Supercenter construction site in Martinsville, the F.B.I. said. The group has claimed responsibility for similar incidents throughout the country for more than 10 years. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: A Big Quarter
description: The Commerce Department announces very good growth during the previous quarter. Many observers declare the economy's troubles over. And the administration's supporters claim that the economy's turnaround validates its policies.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Drugs Tied To Fraud Case
description: Five people were indicted here yesterday in a $2 million scheme that investigators said used profits from the sale of crack cocaine to buy dilapidated houses at bargain prices and sell them to unqualified buyers at exorbitant prices. In the process, members of the ring -- which included real estate agents -- falsified financial, employment and tax records so the buyers could obtain federally guaranteed mortgages, investigators said. A majority of the buyers of the 25 houses the ring bought and resold defaulted on their federally insured loans within a few weeks, investigators said, costing the government and private lenders hundreds of thousands of dollars. Charged in the 37-count indictment were Kenneth D. Jenkins, 34, of Mount Laurel; his girlfriend, Sabena L. Ingalls, 32, a licensed real estate agent; Mr. Jenkins's father, Walter U. Jenkins, 63; Ms. Ingalls's mother, Rita L. Jackson-Paulk, 49, of Camden; and Ronald Rogers, 43, owner of Newmark Construction. Alicia Zubikowski (NYT)

title: A Crucial Case for the Supreme Court
description: In an alarming ruling earlier this year, a closely divided Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals refused to dismiss a patently unmeritorious libel action against Consumer Reports for a 1988 review that rated the Suzuki Samurai sports utility vehicle ''not acceptable.'' It said the car, since discontinued, had a life-endangering tendency to tip and roll over. The court's refusal to reject this flimsy libel case and avoid an expensive jury trial has set an awful First Amendment precedent that threatens to chill reporting about important public issues, especially health and safety. Dozens of media organizations, including The Times, are calling upon the Supreme Court to add the case to this term's docket and undo the damage.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Recall
description: The Nissan Motor Company will recall nearly 2.6 million cars because of defective sensors in the engine. About one million of the affected cars are in Japan. No injuries have been reported because of the defect, but the recall will cost Nissan about 15 billion yen ($140 million), according to a Nissan spokeswoman quoted by Kyodo News. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: A Metaphysician for Whom Baseball Is Life and Vice Versa
description: Yankee fans recuperating from the World Series calamity might be in need of comfort food. That would be the main reason to recommend ''Nobody Don't Like Yogi,'' a warm porridge of a one-man show, written by Tom Lysaght and starring Ben Gazzara, at the Lamb's Theater.

title: Vivendi Said To Be Buying Record Unit
description: Vivendi's Universal Music Group is expected to buy DreamWorks Records for about $100 million, people close to the company said yesterday.

description: WHO -- Celah Weaver, 31, a student

title: Court Clears Andreotti of Murder Charge
description: Italy's highest court cleared Giulio Andreotti, the former prime minister, of a murder charge on Thursday, overturning a previous conviction.

title: A Catastrophe in a Project Meant to Reach Lavish Levels of Pleasure
description: It was a symbol of a resurgent Atlantic City, a dazzling, luxurious, bigger-than-life amusement park cum casino that was supposed to bring a bit of Las Vegas to the Jersey Shore.

title: 36 Hours | Tucson
description: ALTHOUGH Tucson is a sprawling and fast-growing city (226 square miles in the city limits and 515,400 people at last count, a 25 percent increase since the 1990 census), you don't have to travel far to be in desert or mountains. Tucson bumps up against Saguaro National Park in the Tucson Mountains to the west and in the foothills of the Rincon Mountains to the east. North of the city are the Santa Catalina Mountains. The silhouettes of saguaro cactus (which, if you don't want to sound like a city slicker, you'll pronounce sa-WA-ro) at sunset and the ochre light on the faces of the mountains remind visitors that Tucson is an urban oasis in a vast desert basin. BRUCE STUTZ

title: Getting Ready for an Argentine Turnaround
description: The ravaged corporate landscape of postcrisis Argentina is strewn with the remains of the Exxel Group, once Latin America's mightiest private equity fund. Yet Juan Navarro, the man who built the Exxel empire over the last decade, seems sanguine.

title: Ambition, Loyalty and Betrayal
description: Hayden Christensen, below, with Chlo Sevigny, plays Stephen Glass, the young writer who fabricated articles and deceived his editors at The New Republic, in ''Shattered Glass.'' Billy Ray's drama deals with magazine ethics as well as the dynamics of office culture.

title: All in the (Rich, Dysfunctional) Family
description: ''Arrested Development,'' a sharply satirical comedy on Fox, is most easily likened to the 2001 film ''The Royal Tenenbaums,'' and that is unfair to Fox. This sitcom does borrow some of Wes Anderson's touches from the film -- absurdist biographical portraits and whimsical non sequiturs -- but it discards the highbrow preciousness.

title: O'Donnell and Publisher Spar Over Magazine's End
description: Rosie O'Donnell's latest show, the one that sets her against the publisher of her ill-fated magazine, began in a Manhattan courtroom yesterday. It was far less exciting, though, than the news and speculation surrounding ''Taboo,'' a splashy musical ode to the 1980's that she is producing on Broadway.

title: Senate Adds $289 Million to Fight AIDS
description: After several days of wrangling among Republicans, the Senate on Thursday night voted 89-1 in favor of adding $289 million to President Bush's global AIDS initiative -- over the objections of the White House, which did not ask for the money.

title: Residential Real Estate; Chelsea Rental Tower Set by Year-End
description: The newest rental building on the Avenue of the Americas in Chelsea is scheduled for completion by the end of the year, a 38-floor tower that will be the fifth built since the corridor from 24th to 31st Streets was rezoned to residential use from industrial in 1995.

title: Traffic Alert

title: Facing Vote to Alter Primaries, Many New Yorkers Just Yawn
description: On the steps of City Hall, on public affairs television programs and in the offices of civic organizations and political parties, the chatter these days dwells on a single topic: nonpartisan elections. The referendum to end party primaries and make party affiliation an afterthought in local races has so dominated conversations that it is referred to simply as Question No. 3, reflecting its order on this Tuesday's ballot.

title: KORN/FERRY UNIT TO HELP S.E.C. HIRE ACCOUNTANTS
description: A unit of Korn/Ferry, the Los Angeles-based recruitment firm, has been hired by the Securities and Exchange Commission to help hire about 110 accountants, Daniel Margolis, a company spokesman, said yesterday. The initial recruitment contract will focus on midlevel accountants in the division of corporation finance, whose staff members work in the S.E.C. headquarters in Washington, reviewing corporate filings and ensuring that companies comply with regulations. The commission has been hiring lawyers and accountants for several months, but, Mr. Margolis said, only in recent weeks has the agency turned to outside recruiters. Jonathan Glater (NYT)

description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: UAL SAYS LOWER LABOR COSTS HELPED REDUCE LOSSES
description: UAL, the parent of United Airlines, said yesterday that its third-quarter loss narrowed to $367 million as it reduced labor costs by about a third. The loss, equal to $3.47 a share, narrowed from $889 million, or $15.57, in the period last year, UAL said. Sales rose 2 percent, to $3.82 billion from $3.74 billion. UAL, which plans to exit bankruptcy by the middle of next year, cut costs 13 percent, to $3.8 billion, including a 34 percent drop, to $1.2 billion, for labor after negotiating worker concessions earlier this year.

title: That Prickly Princess Returns, Her Riddles as Risky as Ever
description: If you think the dating scene in New York is tough, just take a trip over to the New York State Theater, where heads have been rolling for a night out with Puccini's ultimate ice queen.

description: A selective listing by Times critics of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Teachers Threaten To Strike
description: After nearly six months of unsuccessful contract negotiations, the Chicago Teachers Union is threatening to strike for the first time in 16 years. The union's 33,300 members will vote on the strike on Nov. 18. Union members have rejected a five-year contract that included a 4 percent raise every year, saying it would not be enough to keep up with increased health care costs, including higher premiums and prescription drug co-payments. The Chicago public school system is the nation's third largest, serving nearly a half a million students. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Contradicted In Hasid's Shooting
description: A medical expert hired by the family of Gidone Busch testified yesterday that evidence suggested he was not lunging toward police officers when they shot him. On an August night in 1999, neighbors in Borough Park called the police to report that a disturbed man was wandering the streets nearly naked and wielding a hammer. Yesterday, the expert, Lone Tahanning, the Rockland County medical examiner, testified in federal court in Brooklyn at the family's civil suit against the city. She said that the matching patterns of bullet holes in Mr. Busch's body and on his clothing made it appear that he was standing in a ''normal resting'' position and probably did not have his arms raised in a confrontational manner when he was shot. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Why I Don't Believe in Ghosts
description: Tonight is Halloween, All Hallows' Eve, a time of ghosts and spirits walking by night . . . which leads me naturally to think about literary realism, and about politics. How can you write in a truthful and realistic way about something that doesn't exist?

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Consumer Company Posts Profit
description: The consumer products company Hindustan Lever Ltd. said its quarterly income rose 7.3 percent but fell short of expectations. Net profit rose to 4.4 billion rupees ($97 million) in the quarter, up from 4.13 billion rupees ($91 million) a year earlier. Hindustan Lever, the Indian unit of Unilever, the British-Dutch company, has faced slow growth the last few years because of poor rainfall in India, where two-thirds of the population relies on farm income. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: First U.S. Warship in 30 Years to Visit Vietnam
description: An American warship plans a port call at Vietnam next month, the first such visit since the Vietnam War ended 30 years ago, a United States diplomat said Wednesday during a briefing for journalists.

title: Rupp Ends Scoring Drought and Leads Devils to a Comeback Victory
description: The score was tied, but Philadelphia goaltender Jeff Hackett looked a little vulnerable to Devils center Michael Rupp. So Rupp swept over the Flyers' blue line, wound up and let a big slap shot fly.

title: Pete Carroll Finally Finds A Perfect Fit at U.S.C.
description: For Pete Carroll, in his third go-around as the man in charge, freedom is beautiful.

title: Dean Walks a Tightrope Over Positions on Gun Control
description: Back when Howard Dean was running for governor of Vermont in 1992, he told the National Rifle Association in a signed questionnaire that he opposed any restrictions on private ownership of assault weapons.

title: Abortion Rights Groups Sue to Block Restrictions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  With President Bush soon expected to sign the first federal law prohibiting a specific abortion procedure, opponents of the measure filed suit in three federal courts today seeking to overturn the ban on the grounds that it is overly broad and unconstitutional.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RYAN, MARY L.
description: RYAN--Mary L. Of NYC died Monday October 27th, 2003. Ms. Ryan also known as Didi, has been a resident of Manhattan for the past 23 years. She graduated in 1980 from St. Francis College of Loretto, PA, with a Bachelor of Arts in American History. Ms. Ryan also graduated from the Oldfields school in Glenco, MD in 1975. She is survived by her brother Thomas T. Ryan and her niece Meghan C. Ryan of Great Falls, VA. Visiting hours are Sunday, 5-7 P.M. and Monday 11 A.M. to 12:30 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC. Services will be held at St. Thomas More Church on East 89th Street, Monday at 2 P.M.

description: Theater

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Debt Plan Stumbles
description: The Asia Pulp and Paper Company failed to win the support of a majority of its creditors for plans to reorganize almost half its $14 billion of debt and one of them, the Export-Import Bank of the United States, sued the company to recover $104 million. The Export-Import bank sued Asia Pulp on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Asia Pulp has the support of creditors holding 35 to 40 percent of its debt, short of the 90 percent needed for approval. The company, which is controlled by the Widjaja family of Indonesia, defaulted on its debt in March 2001.

title: A Prostitute Downstairs, A Rich Fantasy Life Upstairs
description: Experiments are to be encouraged in the theater, and ''Wilder,'' a new chamber musical by the playwright Erin Cressida Wilson and the musicians Jack Herrick and Mike Craver, is one.

title: Tentative Houston Playing Way Back
description: Before each cut, each fake, each jump shot in the Knicks' season-opening debacle on Wednesday night, Allan Houston found himself hesitating and wondering if his surgically repaired right knee could handle it.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Building Owner Fined In Porch Collapse
description: The owner of a building in the Lincoln Park neighborhood of Chicago where 13 people died when a porch collapsed last summer has agreed to pay the city $112,700 in fines. The owner, Philip Pappas, and two of his businesses, L. G. Properties and Restoration Specialists, will pay $108,500 for violations at the Lincoln Park building as well as $4,200 in fines for illegally constructed porches in 21 other buildings. George Koutroumbis, who built the Lincoln Park building's porch, was fined $25,000 and has been barred from construction work in the city. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: With Critics at the Door, Funds Propose Cleaning Own House
description: Eliot Spitzer, the attorney general of New York, is calling for heads to roll at the Securities and Exchange Commission over the mutual fund trading abuses uncovered by his latest investigation of Wall Street. The fund industry, under pressure to react to the growing scandal, proposed rule changes yesterday intended to prevent future abuses.

title: Bill Sargent, 76, a Pioneer In Closed-Circuit and Pay TV
description: Bill Sargent, a Hollywood showman whose highly promoted videotaped events were among the first closed-circuit theatrical specials and pay-per-view television showings, died on Oct. 19 in Caddo, Okla., where he was born and later lived in retirement. He was 76.

title: Ex-Home Secretary Seeks to Lead Britain's Conservatives
description: Michael Howard, a lawyer and former home secretary, formally began his campaign on Thursday to take over the leadership of Britain's Conservative Party and challenge Prime Minister Tony Blair in elections that are likely to be held in 2005.

title: CNBC Gives Dennis Miller A Daily Show
description: CNBC said last night that it had hired the comedian Dennis Miller to be the host of a new prime-time program that will begin early next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAUBARD, SEYMOUR
description: GRAUBARD--Seymour. The Anti - Defamation League mourns the passing of Seymour Graubard, ADL Honorary National Chairman. Seymour, who became involved with the League in 1936, served as ADL National Chairman from 1970 through 1976. He dedicated his life to the welfare of the Jewish people and the State of Israel. Sy worked tirelessly as an advocate for Soviet Jewry and travelled to Russia with then NYC Mayor John Lindsay, to provide support for Jewish refuseniks. He lead the fight against Arab propaganda and the Arab boycott against Israel. He was a mentor to ADL's National Directors. For more than 65 years he provided ADL with his wise counsel. He will be sorely missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his daughter Katherine and the entire family. Glen A. Tobias National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: Mexico Awards Contract To Seek Gas
description: Petrleos Mexicanos, Mexico's state-owned oil monopoly, awarded a $1 billion contract on Thursday to drill for natural gas in northern Mexico to a joint venture of Techint of Argentina and a domestic group, Industrial Perforadora de Campeche, the only bidders in the process.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 357 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Global Research Chief at Goldman to Retire
description: Andrew J. Melnick, who supervised the former Internet analyst Henry S. Blodget at Merrill Lynch, is retiring from the Goldman Sachs Group 18 months after becoming Goldman's co-head of global investment research.

title: The Doping Scandal in Sports
description: The investigation into whether prominent athletes are using a new steroid that was designed to escape detection shows how difficult it will be to root out such cheating. The Food and Drug Administration wisely banned the substance as unsafe this week. Now it will be critically important to discipline any athletes who have used it.

title: A Choreographic Wizard's Book of Spells
description: Alwin Nikolais did just about everything. He choreographed dances. He composed electronic scores for them. He designed dazzling scenic effects and flooded bodies with ever-changing patterns of light, making it hard to tell dancers from objects and objects from dancers. Everything in his productions was apt to be in a state of perpetual metamorphosis.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Telecom Stake Sale Rejected
description: The Australian Senate has rejected a proposal to sell a controlling 50.01 percent share in Telstra, the national phone company. The rest of Telstra is listed on the Australian stock exchange with a market value of 30 billion Australian dollars. Earlier the House of Representatives approved the plan by the government of Prime Minister John Howard, but in the Senate, Labor Party members joined with independents to defeat the legislation. They said privatization would not protect consumer rights, particularly in rural and regional areas. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Corning Unit Subpoenaed By Grand Jury
description: Corning said yesterday that its defunct television-tube unit was subpoenaed by a federal grand jury as part of an investigation into pricing and bidding practices in the TV-parts industry. The Justice Department subpoenaed two employees in August and is seeking documents from the Corning Asahi Video Products Company, a venture of Corning and Asahi Glass, Corning said in a regulatory filing. ''We don't believe we violated any laws,'' a Corning spokeswoman, Monica L. Ott, said. She said the company was providing documents to the Justice Department. Corning, the Corning, N.Y.-based maker of fiber optic cable for telecommunications networks, and Tokyo-based Asahi closed the venture earlier this year amid slumping sales.

title: Too Fast. Too Furious. Too Old?
description: LES WONG'S car looks like something straight out of the ''Fast and Furious'' movies. The bright red 1993 Mazda RX-7 has a giant blue panther leaping along the passenger side, a tweaked 348-horsepower engine under the hood and an elegant winglike spoiler off the back. In fact, Dr. Wong, who has spent close to $60,000 customizing his car, could be a classic ''import tuner'' -- a young, car-obsessed street racer with a souped-up compact. Except for one thing: He's a 35-year-old dentist with a wife, two children and a house in Sacramento.

title: A CRITICAL STUDY, MINUS CRITICISM
description: An internal report that harshly criticized the Justice Department's diversity efforts was edited so heavily when it was posted on the department's Web site two weeks ago that half of its 186 pages, including the summary, were blacked out.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Praise And Criticism In European Report
description: In its annual report on Turkey's progress in making reforms ahead of a decision on whether the country will be admitted to the European Union, the European Commission praises the government's success in passing reforms but faults its failure to carry them out, according to Turkish press reports. The report, to be made public next week, is said to raise concerns about the military's continued influence in politics and broadcasting, continued use of torture, a lack of respect for free speech and association, and the failure to promote Kurdish education and broadcasting rights. The report also reiterates the European desire for a Cyprus settlement. Sebnem Arsu (NYT)

title: Harry Clement Stubbs, 81; Wrote Classic Science Fiction
description: Harry Clement Stubbs, whose rigorously worked out stories, published under the name Hal Clement, accentuated the science in science fiction, died on Wednesday in Milton, Mass. He was 81.

title: Lottery Numbers
Break in the Weather Aids in Fire Fight
description: Residents of Southern California looked skyward on Thursday with relief rather than dread for the first time in a week, as moisture-laden clouds replaced the sickening yellowish haze of wildfire smoke.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: One door closes, another opens. When a fire on the block temporarily closed the Chipper, my fish and chips standby in Sunnyside, Queens, I had to come up with a substitute. It didn't have to be fish and chips, but it had to be quick, easy and cheap. I found the solution to my problem just a couple of blocks away, at Hemsin, a Turkish restaurant.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about New York City residents who buy produce directly from local farmers referred incorrectly to the Rogowski Farm in Warwick, N.Y. While it uses mostly organic practices, it is not certified organic by the United States Department of Agriculture.

title: Pushing Limits Of Both Voice And Category
description: Betty Buckley's high-tension singing is so innately dramatic that everything she performs is infused with an urgency bordering on impatience. Add to that a fierce interpretive intelligence and an instinct for scooping out the essence of a song, and what you get is a performer who brooks no obstacles in her determination to get to the heart of the matter.

title: Serial Sex Offender Is Sought In Killing of Homeless Woman
description: When Anthony Jones, a serial sex offender, was sentenced to just two to four years for attempted assault instead of 25 to life for rape in 2000, Howard Safir, then the police commissioner, predicted, ''We'll see him again,'' adding, ''Unfortunately, there will be another victim.''

title: Sports of The Times; Fans Should Take Van Horn for What He Is
description: AS Tracy McGrady was powering up his Orlando Magic for a late-game run to ruin the Knicks at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, a couple of us at courtside were half-watching Vince Carter on a small television monitor as he finished off a 39-point night and the Nets in Toronto. Concurrent happy endings for the distant cousins and onetime colleagues did not obscure the pedestrian teams they are tethered to, however. They only made me wonder where these exceptional solo artists would now be had they recognized the fleeting promise of a two-man band.

title: As Solar Flares Reach Earth, House Reviews Forecasting Agency
description: As a solar storm continued to bathe Earth in an unusually dense flow of subatomic particles, affecting electric companies, airlines and space satellites, a House subcommittee held a hearing on Thursday on a plan to cut back or eliminate the office that forecasts such events.

title: Comcast Falls Short of Estimates
description: The Comcast Corporation reported financial results yesterday that fell slightly short of Wall Street's expectations, but the company also said that it had added 473,000 high-speed Internet subscribers, which is a record for a quarter.

title: Composing Indian History, One Carefully Framed View at a Time
description: Life happens, but history is made, as in invented, cooked up. You blend together events, people and places, stir in ideology, and presto, you have a docudrama version of reality. The truth is in the mix somewhere.

title: Thaksin, Thai tycoon turned prime minister, shows interest in buying British soccer team : Foot in another camp?
description: Turning his nose up at standard souvenirs, Thailand's prime minister on Wednesday almost came home from London with a soccer team.

title: 3 Dead and 20 Hurt in Collapse At Atlantic City Construction Site
description: Five levels of a 10-story casino parking garage under construction a block off the Boardwalk in Atlantic City collapsed in a thunderous roar of concrete slabs and twisted steel yesterday. Three people were killed, more than 20 were injured and one person was missing, the authorities said.

title: A Young Writer's Ambition, With Loyalty and Betrayal
description: I have to admit that of all the worthy and interesting movies opening this fall, ''Shattered Glass'' was the one I was most looking forward to. I also have to admit that the keenness of my anticipation made me a little suspicious -- of myself and of the movie, which opens today in New York and Los Angeles.

title: Columbia Women Run to the Front
description: On a recent afternoon at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, as the Columbia University women's cross-country team set out across the running trails bordering Broadway for a practice run, the coach, Craig Ann Lake, called out last-minute motivation: ''Work together. Expect success. Run with pride. You are part of one of the best distance programs in the nation.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Businessman, A Hero To Many, Freed
description: A court in northeastern Hebei Province convicted and then freed a rural businessman who has gained a national reputation as a modern Robin Hood. Under a law that many considered to be vague, the businessman, Sun Dawu, 50, was accused of running an illegal bank. To raise money for his agriculture business, Mr. Sun had accepted money from his employees, paying them interest rates above those of state banks. Soon even nonemployees were making deposits. The court found him guilty but ordered his immediate release, a decision hailed by advocates of precise definitions for Chinese laws. ''The criminal code still needs clearer explanation,'' one of his lawyers said, ''but this is one step forward.'' Chris Buckley (NYT)

title: Russias Prime Minister Says Tycoon Inquiry Hurts Economy
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 31 — Russia's prime minister today expressed concern over the freezing of shares of Yukos, the country's largest oil producer, a statement widely interpreted as being in defiance of Russia's President, Vladimir V. Putin, who warned cabinet ministers earlier this week not to meddle in prosecutors' case against the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WERWAISS, JULIA KITCHENKA
description: WERWAISS--Julia Kitchenka, died peacefully at age 93 on October 29 in Southbury, CT. Mother of William of Ivoryton, CT and John and Julanne, both of NYC, six grandchildren, four great-grandchildren. Calling hours Friday 4-7pm in the daily chapel of Sacred Heart Church, Main St. So., Southbury. Funeral Mass celebrating her life will be held Saturday, November 1st, 10am, Sacred Heart Church. Burial Evergreen Cemetery, New Haven.

description: People in New York will soon be able to see the Concorde doing what it was never built to do: sitting still.

title: Secrets of the Skin, And of the Heart
description: ''The Human Stain,'' directed by Robert Benton from a screenplay by Nicholas Meyer, is an honorable B+ term paper of a movie: sober, scrupulous and earnestly respectful of its literary source. This is precisely the problem: that source, Philip Roth's 2000 novel, is not especially sober, scrupulous or respectful. It is an angry, ungainly squall of a book, a clamorous defense of sexual vitality in an age of Puritan censoriousness and a lyrical inquiry into the mysteries of race, old age and recent American history. Like much of Mr. Roth's recent work, ''The Human Stain'' bursts with characters and ideas, and its apparently haphazard organization disguises an elegant and cunning narrative strategy.

title: Young Suspect in Sniper Case Becomes Central Figure in a Trial That Is Not His
description: He is not on trial, yet. But he has become such a familiar presence in the Washington-area sniper trial here that when a defense lawyer recently referred to him twice as ''the defendant,'' everyone in the courtroom seemed to know whom the lawyer was talking about.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Oct. 23 about celebrities who have written children's books, including Lynne Cheney, referred incorrectly to an article by Carol Iannone, whom Ms. Cheney nominated in 1991 to an advisory council of the National Endowment for the Humanities. Ms. Iannone criticized the use of race and gender as factors in the awarding of literary prizes; she did not write that awarding prestigious prizes to black writers like Toni Morrison and Alice Walker sacrificed ''the demands of excellence to the democratic dictatorship of mediocrity.'' And the phrase ''democratic dictatorship of mediocrity'' should have carried single quotation marks; it was a quotation from a character in a novel by Chinua Achebe.

title: Asias Longest Serving Ruler Steps Down
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Oct. 31  Asia's longest-serving ruler, Mahathir Mohamed, stepped down today, leaving a legacy of a modern Muslim nation that he molded on the back of often autocratic rule and the use of tirades  often anti-Western and anti-Semitic  designed to create national cohesiveness.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Utility Stake Sold
description: The Italian government sold about 2 billion euros ($2.3 billion) of shares in the utility Enel as it seeks to lower its debt. Italy sold 400 million shares, or 6.6 percent, to Morgan Stanley. The government has promised to reduce its stake in Enel as part of a plan to raise 20 billion euros; the money will be used to lower debt.

title: Managing Editor For Herald Tribune
description: Alison Smale, the deputy foreign editor of The New York Times, has been appointed managing editor of The International Herald Tribune.

title: Endorsements for the City Council
description: There are 51 seats in the City Council, and all are up for grabs next Tuesday. Among the few truly competitive races, here are our choices in Brooklyn and Staten Island.

title: Gonna Fly Now: When Triumph in Rock Films Rings True, It Soars
description: What does it mean that the heroes of two of the best rock 'n' roll movies of the last 12 years were named Jimmy Rabbit? Actually, Jimmy Rabbitte was the hero of ''The Commitments'' (1991), that loving tale of one man's determination to put together a Dublin soul band. And Eminem played Jimmy (B-Rabbit) Smith Jr., the star of his quasi-autobiographical film ''8 Mile'' (2002).

title: Agency Bolsters Supervision Of Foster Care
description: In response to the case of four boys believed to have been starved by adoptive parents, New Jersey's child welfare agency announced a series of emergency measures yesterday to increase the training of its workers and computerize the tracking of foster care cases around the state.

title: Comptroller Seeks to End Snapple Deal
description: The New York City comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., urged the Bloomberg administration yesterday to cancel a deal giving Snapple exclusive rights to sell drinks and snacks on city property, saying the bidding process was flawed and tainted by ethical conflicts.

description: Abingdon Theater Company

title: Finishing Touch Eludes Giants in the Red Zone
description: When quarterback Kerry Collins studies film of the Giants' adventures in the red zone, he picks out the mistakes. Most he chalks up to unremarkable errors: a missed read, a faulty route by a receiver, his tendency to try to stuff the ball into a tight spot. Only a few fall outside that category, including one in last Sunday's victory over Minnesota.

title: George Scott Jr., 95, Citibank Loan Official
description: George C. Scott Jr., a former vice chairman of Citibank who served as its top credit policy executive in the late 1960's and early 1970's, died Monday at his home in Locust, N.J., according to Nancy Crabbe, his niece. He was 95.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Sept. 8 about the performance of AOL Europe included an erroneous report from the company about the increase in the number of subscribers. The company acknowledged this week that the number doubled over the previous three years, not two and a half years.

title: Sacks, Tubes and Transsexuals
description: Striking visual images helped make Harry Mavromichalis's ''In the Borders of Ignorance'' theatrically impressive. There were elaborate costumes by Yiorgos Bellapaisiotis and imposing scenic devices by Panikos Michael and Panikos Tembriotis. Yet the two-part production, performed by Dance Anonymous on Wednesday night at the Duke on 42nd Street, was not always choreographically expressive.

title: Big East Coaches Vote UConn No. 1
description: The numbers are almost frightening. Since its breakthrough season of 1993-94, the Connecticut women's basketball team has won 339 games and lost only 21. That means that for the past 10 years it has had an average record of 34-2.

title: Get 'Em While They're Cool: Footwear for the Few
description: Just after midnight yesterday, almost 100 young men were lined up in stocking caps and heavy coats, lying on sleeping bags and reclining in camp chairs on a SoHo sidewalk. As passers-by asked what the line was for, the men gave flip answers like ''coke'' and ''Justin Timberlake tickets.'' The real object was at once more benign and nearly as addictive: sneakers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CORELLI, FRANCO
description: CORELLI -- Franco. The Board of the Richard Tucker Music Foundation and the Tucker family deeply mourn the passing of the great Franco Corelli, a member of the Foundation's Board of Artists. He was a magnificent singer and beloved colleague and friend of Richard Tucker's and his legacy will live on in the hearts of all who love great singing. We extend our sincerest sympathies to his wife, Loretta and the Corelli family. Jeffrey S. Tabak, Chairman Barry Tucker, President

title: F.D.A. Finds Cloned Animals Safe for Food
description: Milk and meat from cloned animals are safe to consume, the Food and Drug Administration has tentatively concluded, a finding that could eventually clear the way for such products to reach supermarket shelves and for cloning to be widely used to breed livestock.

title: Connecticut Has but Begun Its Cleanup Of Corruption
description: For the past four years, as budget battles have been fought, political campaigns waged and laws enacted, there has been a steady background noise in Connecticut state politics: the drip, drip, drip of an ever-widening public corruption scandal.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about objections from Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Attorney General John Ashcroft to the Senate spending plan for their departments misstated the sum Mr. Powell said would be cut from international peacekeeping. It was almost $67 million, not billion.

title: House Approves $87 Billion in Aid for Iraq and Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  The House of Representatives overwhelmingly passed an $87.5 billion aid package for Iraq and Afghanistan early today, giving President Bush a victory to savor as he relaxes at his Texas ranch over the weekend.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ARKANSAS: COURT REJECTS APPEAL IN MURDER CASE The production of a documentary during the trial of Damien Echols in the 1993 murder of three West Memphis boys did not impair his defense, the State Supreme Court ruled, refusing to overturn his conviction and death sentence. Mr. Echols, who was 18 when found guilty, contended that the television program, broadcast on HBO, posed a conflict of interest for his lawyer. The court earlier rejected a similar appeal by Mr. Echols, whose two co-defendants received life prison sentences. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Release 9/11 Documents
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopping List | The Country Hearth
description: IT'S fireplace season, the time to hunker down, cozy up and do some weekend woolgathering. And the colder it gets, the more comforting a crackling fire becomes -- assuming, of course, that you're prepared. Keeping the home fires burning is a lot easier if you've stocked up on wood and some serious fireplace equipment. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: Stefan Krtin -- 'Something to Believe In'
description: Alexander and Bonin

title: Police Pursue Drug Link In Shooting Of Officers
description: Investigators were trying to determine yesterday if a sergeant wounded in a shootout in Brooklyn on Wednesday night had unknowingly stepped into the middle of a drug deal gone bad, the police said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Postal Disruption
description: Wildcat postal strikes spread across England and Scotland with a huge backlog accumulating in London, where an estimated 16 million items a day are being held up. The Royal Mail advised customers not to post letters in central London, and mailboxes there were being sealed to stop people from trying. Talks between the Royal Mail and its unions disagreed on what the actions were about. Labor leaders said workers were angry at forced changes in working conditions while postal service heads said London workers were agitating to get pay increases to reflect higher costs of living in the capital. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Senate Panel Sends New Letter to Rice Demanding Papers on Iraq Arms Today
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee, in a letter to Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, demanded Thursday that the White House ''must lift'' its objections and hand over to the panel documents related to intelligence about Iraq and its illicit weapons before the war.

title: City Misses State's Deadline For Replacing School Boards
description: The New York City Department of Education has failed to meet a state deadline for holding elections by today to replace the city's 32 community school boards with new parent councils, the chairman of the State Assembly Education Committee said yesterday.

title: North Korea Agrees to Nuclear Talks, China Says
description: North Korea said Thursday that it was ready to enter a new round of negotiations about its nuclear weapons program with the United States, China and other countries in the region. The announcement suggests that President Bush's offer last week to discuss a security guarantee may have been enough to revive the on-again, off-again dialogue with North Korea.

title: A Wine Country, in All Its Varietals
description: OUTSIDE of California and Long Island lies a land of enthusiastic American winemakers. They are a daring bunch, willing to make wine out of everything from elderberries to honey to a strange grape called Norton. In a taste test, I found a couple of elegant wines, some grapes that should perhaps stay on the vine, and a few oddballs that could use a focus group before they hit the shelves. AMANDA HESSER

title: European poll calls Israel a big threat to world peace
description: PARIS:  Almost 60 percent of Europeans say that Israel is a larger threat to world peace than North Korea, Iran or Afghanistan, according to a poll scheduled to be made public Monday by the European Commission.

title: Penn Station Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: Mom's in Drag, the Maid's a Zealot and the Kids Could Kill
description: The candy-hued camp comedy ''Die Mommie Die!'' presents the latest variation of the playwright and drag performer Charles Busch's long-running and very funny alter ego, a swiveling red-haired diva whose exaggerated graciousness and noblesse oblige embody the ne plus ultra of Great Hollywood Ladies.

title: A Place of Beauty, and Then the Fires Came (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRONTE, DR. D. LYDIA
description: BRONTE--Dr. D. Lydia, died October 29, 2003 of breast cancer. Beloved daughter of the late Paul and Dorothy Bronte of McCrory, Arkansas. Devoted sister of Gloria Bronte Lane. Survived by many wonderful friends and cousins who made her life brighter in her illness. A brilliant scholar and researcher who worked in the field of aging and chronic illness related to mercury dental fillings. She devoted her life to making mankind healthier. She collaborated with Dr. Jonas Salk and Dr. Linus Pauling. She worked at Hunter College Brookdale Center on Aging, The Rockefeller Foundation and Carnegie Foundation. Previously faculty at George Washington University. Author of The Longevity Factor, The Aging Society and The Mercury In Your Mouth. Services Saturday, 1:30pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. Contributions may be made to Cancer Care Coalition, 24 Lawrence Rd, Scarsdale, NY 10583; Consumers For Dental Choice, 1725 K Street, NW, suite 511, Washington, DC 20006 or DAMS Inc (Dental Amalgam Mercury Syndrome) Box 7249 Minneapolis, MN 55407.

title: Scientists Find Lemmings Die As Dinners, Not Suicides
description: For centuries, people have puzzled over lemmings, the northern rodents whose populations surge and crash so quickly and so regularly that they inspired an enduring myth: that lemmings commit mass suicide when their numbers grow too large, eagerly pitching themselves off cliffs to their death in a foamy sea.

title: MOSCOW FREEZES BILLIONS IN STOCK OF OIL PRODUCER
description: Prosecutors on Thursday froze stock worth billions of dollars in Russia's richest company, Yukos Oil, raising the stakes in their investigation of its imprisoned chief executive, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky.

title: Jets Eager for Pennington to Start, Rust and All
description: Chad Pennington is still fuming over that interception. The fumble by Santana Moss that short-circuited Pennington's first drive, a drive so crisp that it surprised even Coach Herman Edwards, has been forgotten. The failure by LaMont Jordan to get a yard on fourth down, which would have allowed everyone to see if Pennington was ready to lead a fourth-quarter comeback drive, has receded.

title: Human Fate: Part Beast, Part Angel
description: Humans sometimes say, ''We're just animals.'' But we never think what that means. The ancient Greeks did, creating a whole pantheon of composite creatures that were part human and part beast. These included the centaur (half man, half horse), satyr (man with equine ears and tail and the legs of a goat), a siren (bird with a human head) and sphinx (a winged lion with a human head).

title: Mayor Turns U.S. Inquiry To Campaign Advantage
description: Mayor John F. Street regularly begins speeches by announcing, ''I'm having a great day!''

title: Putnam Gets Subpoena in Trading Inquiry
description: Putnam Investments, the mutual fund firm facing civil fraud accusations of improper trading, said yesterday that it had received a subpoena from the United States attorney's office in New York, indicating that the company could face criminal liability.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the federal civil rights indictment of a former New York City police officer who threw a radio at a fleeing man, causing his death, misidentified the jury that awarded the man's family $600,000. It was a federal jury in a civil case, not a federal grand jury.

title: 2 Acquitted Of Murder Of an Officer In Jersey City
description: Two brothers were acquitted of murder yesterday in the 2001 bludgeoning death of an off-duty Jersey City police officer, but one of them was found guilty of a less-serious charge, reckless manslaughter.

title: Captain Silent on Ferry Crash Has Stress Disorder, Filing Says
description: A lawyer for the Staten Island ferry captain who has refused to be interviewed about the crash on Oct. 15 said her client had a stress disorder and should not be required to meet with investigators now, claiming that he might provide incorrect information because of his ailment.

title: Martha Stewart Reports Loss in Quarter but Tops Forecast
description: Martha Stewart's legal troubles continue to haunt her company, which reported a loss of 8 cents a share yesterday for the third quarter.

title: AETNA LOWERS ITS PROFIT OUTLOOK FOR 2004
description: Aetna, the health insurer, said yesterday that profit would rise 15 percent next year, less than expected, after net income more than doubled in the third quarter and the company added customers for the first time in three years. Aetna said it expected to earn $5 to $5.05 a share this year, excluding gains from unused reserves it had set aside for medical claims, and $5.75 to $5.80 in 2004. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had expected $5.09 a share this year and $6 in 2004. Aetna's shares fell $2.49, or 4 percent, to $56.30. The chief executive, John W. Rowe, said that Aetna would add 650,000 customers in 2004 after pruning more than six million unprofitable members in three years.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Kohl To Appeal Lifting Of Secret Files
description: Former Chancellor Helmut Kohl will appeal a court ruling that permitted East German secret police files on him to be made public. The files will stay sealed until a new ruling. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RADER, GILBERT
description: RADER--Gilbert. The Grand Lodge Knights of Pythias of NY, notes with great sorrow the passing of Supreme Representative Sir Gilbert Rader. Gilbert served with distinction as a Grand Chancellor and Supreme Representative. He held various offices in Pythian Camp and was Chairman of countless committees. Brother Rader exemplified the Pythian values of friendship, charity and benevolence. He will be greatly missed by all and leaves a void that can never be filled.

title: Powerful Twists on Classical Dance, From Balanchine and More
description: The big news at American Ballet Theater is the return of the Cuban star Carlos Acosta for the current City Center season. His first performances on Sunday were on two programs that featured other major debuts, in ''Pillar of Fire'' and ''Le Grand Pas de Deux.''

title: Some Call Fund Chief a Contradictory Man
description: Richard S. Strong helped fuel the investing boom of the 1980's and 1990's, drawing individual investors into the stock market through mutual funds, and turning the firm he controls, the Strong Financial Corporation, into one of the nation's biggest mutual fund companies.

description: If anyone was going to bring millions in the basketball world back to reality, back from premature visions of an 18-year-old playing like an N.B.A. superstar, it would be Larry Bird.

title: Mohawk Tribe Is Rethinking Land Accord With Albany
description: Five months after Gov. George E. Pataki announced an agreement with the St. Regis Mohawk tribe to settle land claims, the deal has become bogged down in tribal politics and a newly elected Indian government has said it wants to rewrite the accord.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: U.N. Mission
description: The Security Council will begin a weeklong fact-finding and diplomatic mission in Afghanistan today to review progress toward national elections next year and to demonstrate support for the government, said Gunter Pleuger, Germany's ambassador to the United Nations and the leader of the delegation. The group will also press the government on gender issues, including the education of women and their integration into all parts of society, he said. Kirk Semple (NYT)
