title: Homemade Costumes Become as Rare as Goblins
description: Catherine A. Borgia, a mother of two and a legislative aide for a state assemblywoman, remembers Halloweens from her childhood, when her mother helped her make all sorts of quirky costumes by hand.

title: Privacy Was His Obsession, Beauty His Fount of Energy
description: To be a major collector of both paintings and drawings is almost to have a double identity. Paintings look at the collector and say: ''Admire me. Aren't I great?'' Drawings keep close to the wall, as if to say, ''Look if you must, but I, too, have my life to lead.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Puma Profit Rises
description: The sportswear and athletic equipment manufacturer Puma said that its third-quarter pretax profit more than doubled from the quarter a year earlier. The company, based in Herzogenaurach, had pretax earnings of 103.8 million euros ($121 million) on sales of 402.3 million euros ($469 million), up 37.8 percent. For 2003, Puma expects profit of at least 245 million euros, nearly triple its income last year. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: A Lady Who Lunches, With Child
description: ONE afternoon, my lunch companion and I held hands as we walked into Le Cirque 2000, a restaurant whose cheeky grandeur seemed perfect for the occasion. Led to a whispery enclave where big spenders were purring over loupe de mer, Katherine giggled happily and said, ''Walk knees!'' Before I could yank her up, my daughter (celebrating her second birthday that very day) sank down and swayed on her knees into the room -- a move that she, at least, thought was hilarious.

title: Several Lives Ruined Forever By Genetic Evil and Duct Tape
description: A psychological horror film from the Midwest-based independent director John D. Hancock, ''Suspended Animation'' is a sturdy, well-made piece that never quite overcomes its structural flaws.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture in this section last Friday, with a story about the off-season restfulness of Fire Island, in New York, gave an incomplete view of a ferry ride on a Saturday morning. Although the boat carried only about a quarter of its summertime passenger load, the riders numbered 70, most below deck and thus not visible.

title: Court Overturns Law Restricting Russian Media
description: Russia's Constitutional Court on Thursday overturned a crucial section of a sweeping law that had severely restricted news coverage of election campaigns, and had even prompted some news organizations to avoid election coverage altogether for fear of being accused of bias and electioneering.

title: Adam Fuss
description: Cheim & Read

title: Selling Off Yesterday's Art to Make Way for Tomorrow's
description: In a cavernous building in Binghamton, N.Y., that once housed a giant supermarket, the walls are lined with works that run the gamut of 20th-century art. By Sunday, when the entire collection arrives, there will be hand-colored etchings by Salvador Dal, a 1908 sketch by Fernand Lger, a 1967 print by Roy Lichtenstein and a working 1985 Chrysler LeBaron that was called ''Endless Summer'' eight years ago when Joel Otterson turned it into art.

title: Rice Faults Past Administrations on Terror
description: President Bush's national security adviser said Thursday that the Clinton and other past administrations had ignored evidence of growing terrorist threats and that despite repeated attacks on American interests, ''until Sept. 11, the terrorists faced no sustained, systematic and global response'' from the United States.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: DoCoMo Net Profit Rises NTT
description: DoCoMo, Japan's largest wireless provider, earned a net profit of 356 billion yen ($3.3 billion) in the six months that ended on Sept. 30, up from 4.2 billion yen a year earlier, when it took heavy losses because of soured investments in overseas subsidiaries. DoCoMo said sales grew 6.4 percent, helped by demand for third-generation phones. Operating profit, which more accurately reflects the company's business, fell 7.8 percent because of higher marketing costs for handsets. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Set the Voters Free
description: Ten years ago, I was one of 24 candidates in the Los Angeles mayoral election. Only about eight of us, however, were perceived to have some chance of winning: seven Democrats and one Republican.

title: Weekender | Great Barrington, Mass.
description: COMPARED with the tiny hill towns surrounding it, Great Barrington is the southern Berkshires' big city: it has a downtown of brick-front shops, an industrial area remade as artists' studios, even a triplex movie theater. And then there are the traffic jams. But it is also one of the few places in the area where you can get good sushi or, at 3 a.m., run out for a cup of coffee. And weekenders have access to high-quality opera, dance and symphony performances nearby.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in World Business on Wednesday with an article about succession plans at British Sky Broadcasting misstated the title for which James Murdoch, the youngest son of Rupert Murdoch, may be in line. It is chief executive, not chairman.

title: The Worst Place to Drop a Cellphone? Try This
description: It was a natural reaction to a simple problem: a cellphone falls into a toilet, and the phone's owner seeks to retrieve it with some exploratory handiwork.

description: U.S. Economic Growth Is Fastest Since 1984

title: Theater in Review
description: Listen to My Heart'

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MINNESOTA: DEMOCRATS COURT F.B.I. WHISTLE-BLOWER State Democrats are pressing Coleen Rowley, the Minneapolis F.B.I. agent who exposed intelligence failures related to the Sept. 11 attacks, to run for Congress. The state's Democratic Party chairman, Mike Erlandson, said party leaders had spoken with Ms. Rowley in recent weeks about challenging Representative John Kline, a first-term Republican. "We're excited about the prospect of her taking a serious look at the race," Mr. Erlandson said. Ms. Rowley, who would have to quit her job about a year short of qualifying for early retirement, has not disclosed her political leanings and declined to comment. (AP)

title: Senate Votes For a Measure To Thin Trees
description: Prodded by the wildfires raging across California, the Senate voted overwhelmingly on Thursday in favor of President Bush's plan to allow the thinning of trees on as much as 20 million acres of federal land.

title: BIOPURE TO LAY OFF 30% OF ITS WORK FORCE
description: Biopure, which is developing a human blood substitute, said yesterday that it was laying off 72 workers, or 30 percent of its work force, and replacing a top executive after failing to get federal approval of the product. The company's shares fell $2.37, or 39 percent, to $3.68. The Food and Drug Administration wants Biopure to clarify data in its studies, delaying an approval the company had expected in August. Biopure said it would respond to the F.D.A. by June 30. The layoffs will help Biopure save money to finance operations through the end of next year. David Zuchero, president of the consulting firm Chesapeake Regulatory Group, is temporarily directing the company's response to the F.D.A. after Howard Richman, senior vice president for regulatory affairs, stepped down.

title: U.S. Forces Battle Iraqi Guerrillas in Intense Firefight
description: ABU GHRAIB, Iraq, Oct. 31  Guerrillas and American troops battled for hours here today in an intense firefight after a demonstration in support of Saddam Hussein turned violent. Meanwhile, rumors of terrorist attacks this weekend roiled Baghdad.

title: Filibuster On Nominee To Court Seat Survives Vote
description: Senate Republicans failed on Thursday to overcome a filibuster blocking the vote on Charles W. Pickering's nomination to a federal appeals court seat.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit At Bank
description: Germany's largest bank, Deutsche Bank, posted a net profit of 576 million euros ($676 million) for the third quarter, slightly exceeding analysts' forecasts. A year earlier, Deutsche Bank lost 299 million euros ($351 million). The bank said declining provisions for bad loans and cost reductions had helped results, even while revenue decreased, to 5.2 billion euros from 5.5 billion euros. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: 3 Dead in Casino Parking Garage Collapse in Atlantic City

title: Sharon Is Questioned by Israeli Police in Two Political Corruption Cases
description: The Israeli police questioned Prime Minister Ariel Sharon for seven hours on Thursday in connection with two investigations into possible cases of political corruption involving Mr. Sharon and his two sons.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GREECE: OUTBREAK AT SEA Hundreds of British tourists on the British cruise ship Aurora have been hit by a contagious gastrointestinal virus and will not be allowed off when the ship reaches the Greek port of Piraeus today, officials said. P&O Cruises, the ship's owner, said the illnesses were mild and caused by a germ known as a Norwalk-like virus. But a spokeswoman for the Greek Merchant Marine Ministry said 450 people onboard "are having severe stomach problems." Greek officials said the ship was carrying 1,900 British tourists and 837 crew members. (Reuters)

title: The Tempura Treatment
description: The photographer James Wojcik and the food stylist Brett Kurzweil are caught red-handed, peddling deep-fried fashion accessories.

description: Globetrotting with Benedict Allen, explorer. Photographs by Bruce Weber.

description: The designer Narciso Rodriguez entertains on his heavenly terrace.

description: At Los Angeles Fashion Week Spring 2004 there were signs that jeans, sweatsuits and T-shirts were giving way to femininity and tailoring.
